id="L16092">16092</span><span id="L16093">16093</span><span id="L16094">16094</span><span id="L16095">16095</span><span id="L16096">16096</span><span id="L16097">16097</span><span id="L16098">16098</span><span id="L16099">16099</span><span id="L16100">16100</span><span id="L16101">16101</span><span id="L16102">16102</span><span id="L16103">16103</span><span id="L16122">16122</span><span id="L16123">16123</span><span id="L16124">16124</span><span id="L16125">16125</span><span id="L16126">16126</span><span id="L16127">16127</span><span id="L16128">16128</span><span id="L16129">16129</span><span id="L16130">16130</span><span id="L16131">16131</span><span id="L16132">16132</span><span id="L16133">16133</span><span id="L16134">16134</span><span id="L16135">16135</span><span id="L16136">16136</span><span id="L16137">16137</span><span id="L16138">16138</span><span id="L16139">16139</span><span id="L16140">16140</span><span id="L16141">16141</span><span id="L16142">16142</span><span id="L16143">16143</span><span id="L16144">16144</span><span id="L16145">16145</span><span id="L16146">16146</span><span id="L16147">16147</span><span id="L16148">16148</span><span id="L16149">16149</span><span id="L16150">16150</span><span id="L16151">16151</span><span id="L16152">16152</span><span id="L16153">16153</span><span id="L16154">16154</span><span id="L16155">16155</span><span id="L16156">16156</span><span id="L16157">16157</span><span id="L16158">16158</span><span id="L16159">16159</span><span id="L16160">16160</span><span id="L16161">16161</span><span id="L16162">16162</span><span id="L16163">16163</span><span id="L16164">16164</span><span id="L16165">16165</span><span id="L16166">16166</span><span id="L16167">16167</span><span id="L16168">16168</span><span id="L16169">16169</span><span id="L16170">16170</span><span id="L16171">16171</span><span id="L16172">16172</span><span id="L16173">16173</span><span id="L16174">16174</span><span id="L16175">16175</span><span id="L16176">16176</span><span id="L16177">16177</span><span id="L16178">16178</span><span id="L16179">16179</span><span id="L16180">16180</span><span id="L16181">16181</span><span id="L16182">16182</span><span id="L16183">16183</span><span id="L16184">16184</span><span id="L16185">16185</span><span id="L16186">16186</span><span id="L16187">16187</span><span id="L16188">16188</span><span id="L16189">16189</span><span id="L16190">16190</span><span id="L16191">16191</span><span id="L16192">16192</span><span id="L16193">16193</span><span id="L16194">16194</span><span id="L16195">16195</span><span id="L16196">16196</span><span id="L16197">16197</span><span id="L16198">16198</span><span id="L16199">16199</span><span id="L16200">16200</span><span id="L16201">16201</span><span id="L16202">16202</span><span id="L16203">16203</span><span id="L16204">16204</span><span id="L16205">16205</span><span id="L16206">16206</span><span id="L16207">16207</span><span id="L16208">16208</span><span id="L16209">16209</span><span id="L16210">16210</span><span id="L16211">16211</span><span id="L16212">16212</span><span id="L16213">16213</span><span id="L16214">16214</span><span id="L16215">16215</span><span id="L16216">16216</span><span id="L16217">16217</span><span id="L16218">16218</span><span id="L16219">16219</span><span id="L16220">16220</span><span id="L16221">16221</span><span id="L16222">16222</span><span id="L16223">16223</span><span id="L16224">16224</span><span id="L16225">16225</span><span id="L16226">16226</span><span id="L16227">16227</span><span id="L16228">16228</span><span id="L16229">16229</span><span id="L16230">16230</span><span id="L16231">16231</span><span id="L16232">16232</span><span id="L16233">16233</span><span id="L16234">16234</span><span id="L16235">16235</span><span id="L16236">16236</span><span id="L16237">16237</span><span id="L16238">16238</span><span id="L16239">16239</span><span id="L16240">16240</span><span id="L16241">16241</span><span id="L16242">16242</span><span id="L16243">16243</span><span id="L16244">16244</span><span id="L16245">16245</span><span id="L16246">16246</span><span id="L16247">16247</span><span id="L16248">16248</span><span id="L16249">16249</span><span id="L16250">16250</span><span id="L16251">16251</span><span id="L16252">16252</span><span id="L16253">16253</span><span id="L16254">16254</span><span id="L16255">16255</span><span id="L16256">16256</span><span id="L16257">16257</span><span id="L16258">16258</span><span id="L16259">16259</span><span id="L16260">16260</span><span id="L16261">16261</span><span id="L16262">16262</span><span id="L16263">16263</span><span id="L16264">16264</span><span id="L16265">16265</span><span id="L16266">16266</span><span id="L16267">16267</span><span id="L16268">16268</span><span id="L16269">16269</span><span id="L16270">16270</span><span id="L16271">16271</span><span id="L16272">16272</span><span id="L16273">16273</span></td>

<li class="L4" rel="L4">almost no restrictions whatsoever.  You may copy it, give it away or</li>
<li class="L5" rel="L5">re-use it under the terms of the Project Gutenberg License included</li>
<li class="L6" rel="L6">with this eBook or online at www.gutenberg.org</li>

<li class="L100" rel="L100">     Chapter XV     The Footsteps Die Out For Ever</li>
<li class="L101" rel="L101"></li>
<li class="L102" rel="L102"></li>
<li class="L103" rel="L103"></li>
<li class="L104" rel="L104"></li>
<li class="L105" rel="L105"></li>
<li class="L106" rel="L106">Book the First--Recalled to Life</li>
<li class="L107" rel="L107"></li>
<li class="L108" rel="L108"></li>
<li class="L109" rel="L109"></li>
<li class="L110" rel="L110"></li>
<li class="L111" rel="L111">I. The Period</li>
<li class="L112" rel="L112"></li>
<li class="L113" rel="L113"></li>
<li class="L114" rel="L114">It was the best of times,</li>
<li class="L115" rel="L115">it was the worst of times,</li>
<li class="L116" rel="L116">it was the age of wisdom,</li>
<li class="L117" rel="L117">it was the age of foolishness,</li>
<li class="L118" rel="L118">it was the epoch of belief,</li>
<li class="L119" rel="L119">it was the epoch of incredulity,</li>
<li class="L120" rel="L120">it was the season of Light,</li>
<li class="L121" rel="L121">it was the season of Darkness,</li>
<li class="L122" rel="L122">it was the spring of hope,</li>
<li class="L123" rel="L123">it was the winter of despair,</li>
<li class="L124" rel="L124">we had everything before us,</li>
<li class="L125" rel="L125">we had nothing before us,</li>
<li class="L126" rel="L126">we were all going direct to Heaven,</li>
<li class="L127" rel="L127">we were all going direct the other way--</li>
<li class="L128" rel="L128">in short, the period was so far like the present period, that some of</li>
<li class="L129" rel="L129">its noisiest authorities insisted on its being received, for good or for</li>
<li class="L130" rel="L130">evil, in the superlative degree of comparison only.</li>
<li class="L131" rel="L131"></li>
<li class="L132" rel="L132">There were a king with a large jaw and a queen with a plain face, on the</li>
<li class="L133" rel="L133">throne of England; there were a king with a large jaw and a queen with</li>
<li class="L134" rel="L134">a fair face, on the throne of France. In both countries it was clearer</li>
<li class="L135" rel="L135">than crystal to the lords of the State preserves of loaves and fishes,</li>
<li class="L136" rel="L136">that things in general were settled for ever.</li>
<li class="L137" rel="L137"></li>
<li class="L138" rel="L138">It was the year of Our Lord one thousand seven hundred and seventy-five.</li>
<li class="L139" rel="L139">Spiritual revelations were conceded to England at that favoured period,</li>
<li class="L140" rel="L140">as at this. Mrs. Southcott had recently attained her five-and-twentieth</li>
<li class="L141" rel="L141">blessed birthday, of whom a prophetic private in the Life Guards had</li>
<li class="L142" rel="L142">heralded the sublime appearance by announcing that arrangements were</li>
<li class="L143" rel="L143">made for the swallowing up of London and Westminster. Even the Cock-lane</li>
<li class="L144" rel="L144">ghost had been laid only a round dozen of years, after rapping out its</li>
<li class="L145" rel="L145">messages, as the spirits of this very year last past (supernaturally</li>
<li class="L146" rel="L146">deficient in originality) rapped out theirs. Mere messages in the</li>
<li class="L147" rel="L147">earthly order of events had lately come to the English Crown and People,</li>
<li class="L148" rel="L148">from a congress of British subjects in America: which, strange</li>
<li class="L149" rel="L149">to relate, have proved more important to the human race than any</li>
<li class="L150" rel="L150">communications yet received through any of the chickens of the Cock-lane</li>
<li class="L151" rel="L151">brood.</li>
<li class="L152" rel="L152"></li>
<li class="L153" rel="L153">France, less favoured on the whole as to matters spiritual than her</li>
<li class="L154" rel="L154">sister of the shield and trident, rolled with exceeding smoothness down</li>
<li class="L155" rel="L155">hill, making paper money and spending it. Under the guidance of her</li>
<li class="L156" rel="L156">Christian pastors, she entertained herself, besides, with such humane</li>
<li class="L157" rel="L157">achievements as sentencing a youth to have his hands cut off, his tongue</li>
<li class="L158" rel="L158">torn out with pincers, and his body burned alive, because he had not</li>
<li class="L159" rel="L159">kneeled down in the rain to do honour to a dirty procession of monks</li>
<li class="L160" rel="L160">which passed within his view, at a distance of some fifty or sixty</li>
<li class="L161" rel="L161">yards. It is likely enough that, rooted in the woods of France and</li>
<li class="L162" rel="L162">Norway, there were growing trees, when that sufferer was put to death,</li>
<li class="L163" rel="L163">already marked by the Woodman, Fate, to come down and be sawn into</li>
<li class="L164" rel="L164">boards, to make a certain movable framework with a sack and a knife in</li>
<li class="L165" rel="L165">it, terrible in history. It is likely enough that in the rough outhouses</li>
<li class="L166" rel="L166">of some tillers of the heavy lands adjacent to Paris, there were</li>
<li class="L167" rel="L167">sheltered from the weather that very day, rude carts, bespattered with</li>
<li class="L168" rel="L168">rustic mire, snuffed about by pigs, and roosted in by poultry, which</li>
<li class="L169" rel="L169">the Farmer, Death, had already set apart to be his tumbrils of</li>
<li class="L170" rel="L170">the Revolution. But that Woodman and that Farmer, though they work</li>
<li class="L171" rel="L171">unceasingly, work silently, and no one heard them as they went about</li>
<li class="L172" rel="L172">with muffled tread: the rather, forasmuch as to entertain any suspicion</li>
<li class="L173" rel="L173">that they were awake, was to be atheistical and traitorous.</li>
<li class="L174" rel="L174"></li>
<li class="L175" rel="L175">In England, there was scarcely an amount of order and protection to</li>
<li class="L176" rel="L176">justify much national boasting. Daring burglaries by armed men, and</li>
<li class="L177" rel="L177">highway robberies, took place in the capital itself every night;</li>
<li class="L178" rel="L178">families were publicly cautioned not to go out of town without removing</li>
<li class="L179" rel="L179">their furniture to upholsterers&#39; warehouses for security; the highwayman</li>
<li class="L180" rel="L180">in the dark was a City tradesman in the light, and, being recognised and</li>
<li class="L181" rel="L181">challenged by his fellow-tradesman whom he stopped in his character of</li>
<li class="L182" rel="L182">“the Captain,” gallantly shot him through the head and rode away; the</li>
<li class="L183" rel="L183">mail was waylaid by seven robbers, and the guard shot three dead, and</li>
<li class="L184" rel="L184">then got shot dead himself by the other four, “in consequence of the</li>
<li class="L185" rel="L185">failure of his ammunition:” after which the mail was robbed in peace;</li>
<li class="L186" rel="L186">that magnificent potentate, the Lord Mayor of London, was made to stand</li>
<li class="L187" rel="L187">and deliver on Turnham Green, by one highwayman, who despoiled the</li>
<li class="L188" rel="L188">illustrious creature in sight of all his retinue; prisoners in London</li>
<li class="L189" rel="L189">gaols fought battles with their turnkeys, and the majesty of the law</li>
<li class="L190" rel="L190">fired blunderbusses in among them, loaded with rounds of shot and ball;</li>
<li class="L191" rel="L191">thieves snipped off diamond crosses from the necks of noble lords at</li>
<li class="L192" rel="L192">Court drawing-rooms; musketeers went into St. Giles&#39;s, to search</li>
<li class="L193" rel="L193">for contraband goods, and the mob fired on the musketeers, and the</li>
<li class="L194" rel="L194">musketeers fired on the mob, and nobody thought any of these occurrences</li>
<li class="L195" rel="L195">much out of the common way. In the midst of them, the hangman, ever busy</li>
<li class="L196" rel="L196">and ever worse than useless, was in constant requisition; now, stringing</li>
<li class="L197" rel="L197">up long rows of miscellaneous criminals; now, hanging a housebreaker on</li>
<li class="L198" rel="L198">Saturday who had been taken on Tuesday; now, burning people in the</li>
<li class="L199" rel="L199">hand at Newgate by the dozen, and now burning pamphlets at the door of</li>
<li class="L200" rel="L200">Westminster Hall; to-day, taking the life of an atrocious murderer,</li>
<li class="L201" rel="L201">and to-morrow of a wretched pilferer who had robbed a farmer&#39;s boy of</li>
<li class="L202" rel="L202">sixpence.</li>
<li class="L203" rel="L203"></li>
<li class="L204" rel="L204">All these things, and a thousand like them, came to pass in and close</li>
<li class="L205" rel="L205">upon the dear old year one thousand seven hundred and seventy-five.</li>
<li class="L206" rel="L206">Environed by them, while the Woodman and the Farmer worked unheeded,</li>
<li class="L207" rel="L207">those two of the large jaws, and those other two of the plain and the</li>
<li class="L208" rel="L208">fair faces, trod with stir enough, and carried their divine rights</li>
<li class="L209" rel="L209">with a high hand. Thus did the year one thousand seven hundred</li>
<li class="L210" rel="L210">and seventy-five conduct their Greatnesses, and myriads of small</li>
<li class="L211" rel="L211">creatures--the creatures of this chronicle among the rest--along the</li>
<li class="L212" rel="L212">roads that lay before them.</li>
<li class="L213" rel="L213"></li>
<li class="L214" rel="L214"></li>
<li class="L215" rel="L215"></li>
<li class="L216" rel="L216"></li>
<li class="L217" rel="L217">II. The Mail</li>
<li class="L218" rel="L218"></li>
<li class="L219" rel="L219"></li>
<li class="L220" rel="L220">It was the Dover road that lay, on a Friday night late in November,</li>
<li class="L221" rel="L221">before the first of the persons with whom this history has business.</li>
<li class="L222" rel="L222">The Dover road lay, as to him, beyond the Dover mail, as it lumbered up</li>
<li class="L223" rel="L223">Shooter&#39;s Hill. He walked up hill in the mire by the side of the mail,</li>
<li class="L224" rel="L224">as the rest of the passengers did; not because they had the least relish</li>
<li class="L225" rel="L225">for walking exercise, under the circumstances, but because the hill,</li>
<li class="L226" rel="L226">and the harness, and the mud, and the mail, were all so heavy, that the</li>
<li class="L227" rel="L227">horses had three times already come to a stop, besides once drawing the</li>
<li class="L228" rel="L228">coach across the road, with the mutinous intent of taking it back</li>
<li class="L229" rel="L229">to Blackheath. Reins and whip and coachman and guard, however, in</li>
<li class="L230" rel="L230">combination, had read that article of war which forbade a purpose</li>
<li class="L231" rel="L231">otherwise strongly in favour of the argument, that some brute animals</li>
<li class="L232" rel="L232">are endued with Reason; and the team had capitulated and returned to</li>
<li class="L233" rel="L233">their duty.</li>
<li class="L234" rel="L234"></li>
<li class="L235" rel="L235">With drooping heads and tremulous tails, they mashed their way through</li>
<li class="L236" rel="L236">the thick mud, floundering and stumbling between whiles, as if they were</li>
<li class="L237" rel="L237">falling to pieces at the larger joints. As often as the driver rested</li>
<li class="L238" rel="L238">them and brought them to a stand, with a wary “Wo-ho! so-ho-then!” the</li>
<li class="L239" rel="L239">near leader violently shook his head and everything upon it--like an</li>
<li class="L240" rel="L240">unusually emphatic horse, denying that the coach could be got up the</li>
<li class="L241" rel="L241">hill. Whenever the leader made this rattle, the passenger started, as a</li>
<li class="L242" rel="L242">nervous passenger might, and was disturbed in mind.</li>
<li class="L243" rel="L243"></li>
<li class="L244" rel="L244">There was a steaming mist in all the hollows, and it had roamed in its</li>
<li class="L245" rel="L245">forlornness up the hill, like an evil spirit, seeking rest and finding</li>
<li class="L246" rel="L246">none. A clammy and intensely cold mist, it made its slow way through the</li>
<li class="L247" rel="L247">air in ripples that visibly followed and overspread one another, as the</li>
<li class="L248" rel="L248">waves of an unwholesome sea might do. It was dense enough to shut out</li>
<li class="L249" rel="L249">everything from the light of the coach-lamps but these its own workings,</li>
<li class="L250" rel="L250">and a few yards of road; and the reek of the labouring horses steamed</li>
<li class="L251" rel="L251">into it, as if they had made it all.</li>
<li class="L252" rel="L252"></li>
<li class="L253" rel="L253">Two other passengers, besides the one, were plodding up the hill by the</li>
<li class="L254" rel="L254">side of the mail. All three were wrapped to the cheekbones and over the</li>
<li class="L255" rel="L255">ears, and wore jack-boots. Not one of the three could have said, from</li>
<li class="L256" rel="L256">anything he saw, what either of the other two was like; and each was</li>
<li class="L257" rel="L257">hidden under almost as many wrappers from the eyes of the mind, as from</li>
<li class="L258" rel="L258">the eyes of the body, of his two companions. In those days, travellers</li>
<li class="L259" rel="L259">were very shy of being confidential on a short notice, for anybody on</li>
<li class="L260" rel="L260">the road might be a robber or in league with robbers. As to the latter,</li>
<li class="L261" rel="L261">when every posting-house and ale-house could produce somebody in</li>
<li class="L262" rel="L262">“the Captain&#39;s” pay, ranging from the landlord to the lowest stable</li>
<li class="L263" rel="L263">non-descript, it was the likeliest thing upon the cards. So the guard</li>
<li class="L264" rel="L264">of the Dover mail thought to himself, that Friday night in November, one</li>
<li class="L265" rel="L265">thousand seven hundred and seventy-five, lumbering up Shooter&#39;s Hill, as</li>
<li class="L266" rel="L266">he stood on his own particular perch behind the mail, beating his feet,</li>
<li class="L267" rel="L267">and keeping an eye and a hand on the arm-chest before him, where a</li>
<li class="L268" rel="L268">loaded blunderbuss lay at the top of six or eight loaded horse-pistols,</li>
<li class="L269" rel="L269">deposited on a substratum of cutlass.</li>
<li class="L270" rel="L270"></li>
<li class="L271" rel="L271">The Dover mail was in its usual genial position that the guard suspected</li>
<li class="L272" rel="L272">the passengers, the passengers suspected one another and the guard, they</li>
<li class="L273" rel="L273">all suspected everybody else, and the coachman was sure of nothing but</li>
<li class="L274" rel="L274">the horses; as to which cattle he could with a clear conscience have</li>
<li class="L275" rel="L275">taken his oath on the two Testaments that they were not fit for the</li>
<li class="L276" rel="L276">journey.</li>
<li class="L277" rel="L277"></li>
<li class="L278" rel="L278">“Wo-ho!” said the coachman. “So, then! One more pull and you&#39;re at the</li>
<li class="L279" rel="L279">top and be damned to you, for I have had trouble enough to get you to</li>
<li class="L280" rel="L280">it!--Joe!”</li>
<li class="L281" rel="L281"></li>
<li class="L282" rel="L282">“Halloa!” the guard replied.</li>
<li class="L283" rel="L283"></li>
<li class="L284" rel="L284">“What o&#39;clock do you make it, Joe?”</li>
<li class="L285" rel="L285"></li>
<li class="L286" rel="L286">“Ten minutes, good, past eleven.”</li>
<li class="L287" rel="L287"></li>
<li class="L288" rel="L288">“My blood!” ejaculated the vexed coachman, “and not atop of Shooter&#39;s</li>
<li class="L289" rel="L289">yet! Tst! Yah! Get on with you!”</li>
<li class="L290" rel="L290"></li>
<li class="L291" rel="L291">The emphatic horse, cut short by the whip in a most decided negative,</li>
<li class="L292" rel="L292">made a decided scramble for it, and the three other horses followed</li>
<li class="L293" rel="L293">suit. Once more, the Dover mail struggled on, with the jack-boots of its</li>
<li class="L294" rel="L294">passengers squashing along by its side. They had stopped when the coach</li>
<li class="L295" rel="L295">stopped, and they kept close company with it. If any one of the three</li>
<li class="L296" rel="L296">had had the hardihood to propose to another to walk on a little ahead</li>
<li class="L297" rel="L297">into the mist and darkness, he would have put himself in a fair way of</li>
<li class="L298" rel="L298">getting shot instantly as a highwayman.</li>
<li class="L299" rel="L299"></li>
<li class="L300" rel="L300">The last burst carried the mail to the summit of the hill. The horses</li>
<li class="L301" rel="L301">stopped to breathe again, and the guard got down to skid the wheel for</li>
<li class="L302" rel="L302">the descent, and open the coach-door to let the passengers in.</li>
<li class="L303" rel="L303"></li>
<li class="L304" rel="L304">“Tst! Joe!” cried the coachman in a warning voice, looking down from his</li>
<li class="L305" rel="L305">box.</li>
<li class="L306" rel="L306"></li>
<li class="L307" rel="L307">“What do you say, Tom?”</li>
<li class="L308" rel="L308"></li>
<li class="L309" rel="L309">They both listened.</li>
<li class="L310" rel="L310"></li>
<li class="L311" rel="L311">“I say a horse at a canter coming up, Joe.”</li>
<li class="L312" rel="L312"></li>
<li class="L313" rel="L313">“_I_ say a horse at a gallop, Tom,” returned the guard, leaving his hold</li>
<li class="L314" rel="L314">of the door, and mounting nimbly to his place. “Gentlemen! In the king&#39;s</li>
<li class="L315" rel="L315">name, all of you!”</li>
<li class="L316" rel="L316"></li>
<li class="L317" rel="L317">With this hurried adjuration, he cocked his blunderbuss, and stood on</li>
<li class="L318" rel="L318">the offensive.</li>
<li class="L319" rel="L319"></li>
<li class="L320" rel="L320">The passenger booked by this history, was on the coach-step, getting in;</li>
<li class="L321" rel="L321">the two other passengers were close behind him, and about to follow. He</li>
<li class="L322" rel="L322">remained on the step, half in the coach and half out of; they remained</li>
<li class="L323" rel="L323">in the road below him. They all looked from the coachman to the guard,</li>
<li class="L324" rel="L324">and from the guard to the coachman, and listened. The coachman looked</li>
<li class="L325" rel="L325">back and the guard looked back, and even the emphatic leader pricked up</li>
<li class="L326" rel="L326">his ears and looked back, without contradicting.</li>
<li class="L327" rel="L327"></li>
<li class="L328" rel="L328">The stillness consequent on the cessation of the rumbling and labouring</li>
<li class="L329" rel="L329">of the coach, added to the stillness of the night, made it very quiet</li>
<li class="L330" rel="L330">indeed. The panting of the horses communicated a tremulous motion to</li>
<li class="L331" rel="L331">the coach, as if it were in a state of agitation. The hearts of the</li>
<li class="L332" rel="L332">passengers beat loud enough perhaps to be heard; but at any rate, the</li>
<li class="L333" rel="L333">quiet pause was audibly expressive of people out of breath, and holding</li>
<li class="L334" rel="L334">the breath, and having the pulses quickened by expectation.</li>
<li class="L335" rel="L335"></li>
<li class="L336" rel="L336">The sound of a horse at a gallop came fast and furiously up the hill.</li>
<li class="L337" rel="L337"></li>
<li class="L338" rel="L338">“So-ho!” the guard sang out, as loud as he could roar. “Yo there! Stand!</li>
<li class="L339" rel="L339">I shall fire!”</li>
<li class="L340" rel="L340"></li>
<li class="L341" rel="L341">The pace was suddenly checked, and, with much splashing and floundering,</li>
<li class="L342" rel="L342">a man&#39;s voice called from the mist, “Is that the Dover mail?”</li>
<li class="L343" rel="L343"></li>
<li class="L344" rel="L344">“Never you mind what it is!” the guard retorted. “What are you?”</li>
<li class="L345" rel="L345"></li>
<li class="L346" rel="L346">“_Is_ that the Dover mail?”</li>
<li class="L347" rel="L347"></li>
<li class="L348" rel="L348">“Why do you want to know?”</li>
<li class="L349" rel="L349"></li>
<li class="L350" rel="L350">“I want a passenger, if it is.”</li>
<li class="L351" rel="L351"></li>
<li class="L352" rel="L352">“What passenger?”</li>
<li class="L353" rel="L353"></li>
<li class="L354" rel="L354">“Mr. Jarvis Lorry.”</li>
<li class="L355" rel="L355"></li>
<li class="L356" rel="L356">Our booked passenger showed in a moment that it was his name. The guard,</li>
<li class="L357" rel="L357">the coachman, and the two other passengers eyed him distrustfully.</li>
<li class="L358" rel="L358"></li>
<li class="L359" rel="L359">“Keep where you are,” the guard called to the voice in the mist,</li>
<li class="L360" rel="L360">“because, if I should make a mistake, it could never be set right in</li>
<li class="L361" rel="L361">your lifetime. Gentleman of the name of Lorry answer straight.”</li>
<li class="L362" rel="L362"></li>
<li class="L363" rel="L363">“What is the matter?” asked the passenger, then, with mildly quavering</li>
<li class="L364" rel="L364">speech. “Who wants me? Is it Jerry?”</li>
<li class="L365" rel="L365"></li>
<li class="L366" rel="L366">(“I don&#39;t like Jerry&#39;s voice, if it is Jerry,” growled the guard to</li>
<li class="L367" rel="L367">himself. “He&#39;s hoarser than suits me, is Jerry.”)</li>
<li class="L368" rel="L368"></li>
<li class="L369" rel="L369">“Yes, Mr. Lorry.”</li>
<li class="L370" rel="L370"></li>
<li class="L371" rel="L371">“What is the matter?”</li>
<li class="L372" rel="L372"></li>
<li class="L373" rel="L373">“A despatch sent after you from over yonder. T. and Co.”</li>
<li class="L374" rel="L374"></li>
<li class="L375" rel="L375">“I know this messenger, guard,” said Mr. Lorry, getting down into the</li>
<li class="L376" rel="L376">road--assisted from behind more swiftly than politely by the other two</li>
<li class="L377" rel="L377">passengers, who immediately scrambled into the coach, shut the door, and</li>
<li class="L378" rel="L378">pulled up the window. “He may come close; there&#39;s nothing wrong.”</li>
<li class="L379" rel="L379"></li>
<li class="L380" rel="L380">“I hope there ain&#39;t, but I can&#39;t make so &#39;Nation sure of that,” said the</li>
<li class="L381" rel="L381">guard, in gruff soliloquy. “Hallo you!”</li>
<li class="L382" rel="L382"></li>
<li class="L383" rel="L383">“Well! And hallo you!” said Jerry, more hoarsely than before.</li>
<li class="L384" rel="L384"></li>
<li class="L385" rel="L385">“Come on at a footpace! d&#39;ye mind me? And if you&#39;ve got holsters to that</li>
<li class="L386" rel="L386">saddle o&#39; yourn, don&#39;t let me see your hand go nigh &#39;em. For I&#39;m a devil</li>
<li class="L387" rel="L387">at a quick mistake, and when I make one it takes the form of Lead. So</li>
<li class="L388" rel="L388">now let&#39;s look at you.”</li>
<li class="L389" rel="L389"></li>
<li class="L390" rel="L390">The figures of a horse and rider came slowly through the eddying mist,</li>
<li class="L391" rel="L391">and came to the side of the mail, where the passenger stood. The rider</li>
<li class="L392" rel="L392">stooped, and, casting up his eyes at the guard, handed the passenger</li>
<li class="L393" rel="L393">a small folded paper. The rider&#39;s horse was blown, and both horse and</li>
<li class="L394" rel="L394">rider were covered with mud, from the hoofs of the horse to the hat of</li>
<li class="L395" rel="L395">the man.</li>
<li class="L396" rel="L396"></li>
<li class="L397" rel="L397">“Guard!” said the passenger, in a tone of quiet business confidence.</li>
<li class="L398" rel="L398"></li>
<li class="L399" rel="L399">The watchful guard, with his right hand at the stock of his raised</li>
<li class="L400" rel="L400">blunderbuss, his left at the barrel, and his eye on the horseman,</li>
<li class="L401" rel="L401">answered curtly, “Sir.”</li>
<li class="L402" rel="L402"></li>
<li class="L403" rel="L403">“There is nothing to apprehend. I belong to Tellson&#39;s Bank. You must</li>
<li class="L404" rel="L404">know Tellson&#39;s Bank in London. I am going to Paris on business. A crown</li>
<li class="L405" rel="L405">to drink. I may read this?”</li>
<li class="L406" rel="L406"></li>
<li class="L407" rel="L407">“If so be as you&#39;re quick, sir.”</li>
<li class="L408" rel="L408"></li>
<li class="L409" rel="L409">He opened it in the light of the coach-lamp on that side, and</li>
<li class="L410" rel="L410">read--first to himself and then aloud: “&#39;Wait at Dover for Mam&#39;selle.&#39;</li>
<li class="L411" rel="L411">It&#39;s not long, you see, guard. Jerry, say that my answer was, RECALLED</li>
<li class="L412" rel="L412">TO LIFE.”</li>
<li class="L413" rel="L413"></li>
<li class="L414" rel="L414">Jerry started in his saddle. “That&#39;s a Blazing strange answer, too,”</li>
<li class="L415" rel="L415"> said he, at his hoarsest.</li>
<li class="L416" rel="L416"></li>
<li class="L417" rel="L417">“Take that message back, and they will know that I received this, as</li>
<li class="L418" rel="L418">well as if I wrote. Make the best of your way. Good night.”</li>
<li class="L419" rel="L419"></li>
<li class="L420" rel="L420">With those words the passenger opened the coach-door and got in; not at</li>
<li class="L421" rel="L421">all assisted by his fellow-passengers, who had expeditiously secreted</li>
<li class="L422" rel="L422">their watches and purses in their boots, and were now making a general</li>
<li class="L423" rel="L423">pretence of being asleep. With no more definite purpose than to escape</li>
<li class="L424" rel="L424">the hazard of originating any other kind of action.</li>
<li class="L425" rel="L425"></li>
<li class="L426" rel="L426">The coach lumbered on again, with heavier wreaths of mist closing round</li>
<li class="L427" rel="L427">it as it began the descent. The guard soon replaced his blunderbuss</li>
<li class="L428" rel="L428">in his arm-chest, and, having looked to the rest of its contents, and</li>
<li class="L429" rel="L429">having looked to the supplementary pistols that he wore in his belt,</li>
<li class="L430" rel="L430">looked to a smaller chest beneath his seat, in which there were a</li>
<li class="L431" rel="L431">few smith&#39;s tools, a couple of torches, and a tinder-box. For he was</li>
<li class="L432" rel="L432">furnished with that completeness that if the coach-lamps had been blown</li>
<li class="L433" rel="L433">and stormed out, which did occasionally happen, he had only to shut</li>
<li class="L434" rel="L434">himself up inside, keep the flint and steel sparks well off the straw,</li>
<li class="L435" rel="L435">and get a light with tolerable safety and ease (if he were lucky) in</li>
<li class="L436" rel="L436">five minutes.</li>
<li class="L437" rel="L437"></li>
<li class="L438" rel="L438">“Tom!” softly over the coach roof.</li>
<li class="L439" rel="L439"></li>
<li class="L440" rel="L440">“Hallo, Joe.”</li>
<li class="L441" rel="L441"></li>
<li class="L442" rel="L442">“Did you hear the message?”</li>
<li class="L443" rel="L443"></li>
<li class="L444" rel="L444">“I did, Joe.”</li>
<li class="L445" rel="L445"></li>
<li class="L446" rel="L446">“What did you make of it, Tom?”</li>
<li class="L447" rel="L447"></li>
<li class="L448" rel="L448">“Nothing at all, Joe.”</li>
<li class="L449" rel="L449"></li>
<li class="L450" rel="L450">“That&#39;s a coincidence, too,” the guard mused, “for I made the same of it</li>
<li class="L451" rel="L451">myself.”</li>
<li class="L452" rel="L452"></li>
<li class="L453" rel="L453">Jerry, left alone in the mist and darkness, dismounted meanwhile, not</li>
<li class="L454" rel="L454">only to ease his spent horse, but to wipe the mud from his face, and</li>
<li class="L455" rel="L455">shake the wet out of his hat-brim, which might be capable of</li>
<li class="L456" rel="L456">holding about half a gallon. After standing with the bridle over his</li>
<li class="L457" rel="L457">heavily-splashed arm, until the wheels of the mail were no longer within</li>
<li class="L458" rel="L458">hearing and the night was quite still again, he turned to walk down the</li>
<li class="L459" rel="L459">hill.</li>
<li class="L460" rel="L460"></li>
<li class="L461" rel="L461">“After that there gallop from Temple Bar, old lady, I won&#39;t trust your</li>
<li class="L462" rel="L462">fore-legs till I get you on the level,” said this hoarse messenger,</li>
<li class="L463" rel="L463">glancing at his mare. “&#39;Recalled to life.&#39; That&#39;s a Blazing strange</li>
<li class="L464" rel="L464">message. Much of that wouldn&#39;t do for you, Jerry! I say, Jerry! You&#39;d</li>
<li class="L465" rel="L465">be in a Blazing bad way, if recalling to life was to come into fashion,</li>
<li class="L466" rel="L466">Jerry!”</li>
<li class="L467" rel="L467"></li>
<li class="L468" rel="L468"></li>
<li class="L469" rel="L469"></li>
<li class="L470" rel="L470"></li>
<li class="L471" rel="L471">III. The Night Shadows</li>
<li class="L472" rel="L472"></li>
<li class="L473" rel="L473"></li>
<li class="L474" rel="L474">A wonderful fact to reflect upon, that every human creature is</li>
<li class="L475" rel="L475">constituted to be that profound secret and mystery to every other. A</li>
<li class="L476" rel="L476">solemn consideration, when I enter a great city by night, that every</li>
<li class="L477" rel="L477">one of those darkly clustered houses encloses its own secret; that every</li>
<li class="L478" rel="L478">room in every one of them encloses its own secret; that every beating</li>
<li class="L479" rel="L479">heart in the hundreds of thousands of breasts there, is, in some of</li>
<li class="L480" rel="L480">its imaginings, a secret to the heart nearest it! Something of the</li>
<li class="L481" rel="L481">awfulness, even of Death itself, is referable to this. No more can I</li>
<li class="L482" rel="L482">turn the leaves of this dear book that I loved, and vainly hope in time</li>
<li class="L483" rel="L483">to read it all. No more can I look into the depths of this unfathomable</li>
<li class="L484" rel="L484">water, wherein, as momentary lights glanced into it, I have had glimpses</li>
<li class="L485" rel="L485">of buried treasure and other things submerged. It was appointed that the</li>
<li class="L486" rel="L486">book should shut with a spring, for ever and for ever, when I had read</li>
<li class="L487" rel="L487">but a page. It was appointed that the water should be locked in an</li>
<li class="L488" rel="L488">eternal frost, when the light was playing on its surface, and I stood</li>
<li class="L489" rel="L489">in ignorance on the shore. My friend is dead, my neighbour is dead,</li>
<li class="L490" rel="L490">my love, the darling of my soul, is dead; it is the inexorable</li>
<li class="L491" rel="L491">consolidation and perpetuation of the secret that was always in that</li>
<li class="L492" rel="L492">individuality, and which I shall carry in mine to my life&#39;s end. In</li>
<li class="L493" rel="L493">any of the burial-places of this city through which I pass, is there</li>
<li class="L494" rel="L494">a sleeper more inscrutable than its busy inhabitants are, in their</li>
<li class="L495" rel="L495">innermost personality, to me, or than I am to them?</li>
<li class="L496" rel="L496"></li>
<li class="L497" rel="L497">As to this, his natural and not to be alienated inheritance, the</li>
<li class="L498" rel="L498">messenger on horseback had exactly the same possessions as the King, the</li>
<li class="L499" rel="L499">first Minister of State, or the richest merchant in London. So with the</li>
<li class="L500" rel="L500">three passengers shut up in the narrow compass of one lumbering old mail</li>
<li class="L501" rel="L501">coach; they were mysteries to one another, as complete as if each had</li>
<li class="L502" rel="L502">been in his own coach and six, or his own coach and sixty, with the</li>
<li class="L503" rel="L503">breadth of a county between him and the next.</li>
<li class="L504" rel="L504"></li>
<li class="L505" rel="L505">The messenger rode back at an easy trot, stopping pretty often at</li>
<li class="L506" rel="L506">ale-houses by the way to drink, but evincing a tendency to keep his</li>
<li class="L507" rel="L507">own counsel, and to keep his hat cocked over his eyes. He had eyes that</li>
<li class="L508" rel="L508">assorted very well with that decoration, being of a surface black, with</li>
<li class="L509" rel="L509">no depth in the colour or form, and much too near together--as if they</li>
<li class="L510" rel="L510">were afraid of being found out in something, singly, if they kept too</li>
<li class="L511" rel="L511">far apart. They had a sinister expression, under an old cocked-hat like</li>
<li class="L512" rel="L512">a three-cornered spittoon, and over a great muffler for the chin and</li>
<li class="L513" rel="L513">throat, which descended nearly to the wearer&#39;s knees. When he stopped</li>
<li class="L514" rel="L514">for drink, he moved this muffler with his left hand, only while he</li>
<li class="L515" rel="L515">poured his liquor in with his right; as soon as that was done, he</li>
<li class="L516" rel="L516">muffled again.</li>
<li class="L517" rel="L517"></li>
<li class="L518" rel="L518">“No, Jerry, no!” said the messenger, harping on one theme as he rode.</li>
<li class="L519" rel="L519">“It wouldn&#39;t do for you, Jerry. Jerry, you honest tradesman, it wouldn&#39;t</li>
<li class="L520" rel="L520">suit _your_ line of business! Recalled--! Bust me if I don&#39;t think he&#39;d</li>
<li class="L521" rel="L521">been a drinking!”</li>
<li class="L522" rel="L522"></li>
<li class="L523" rel="L523">His message perplexed his mind to that degree that he was fain, several</li>
<li class="L524" rel="L524">times, to take off his hat to scratch his head. Except on the crown,</li>
<li class="L525" rel="L525">which was raggedly bald, he had stiff, black hair, standing jaggedly all</li>
<li class="L526" rel="L526">over it, and growing down hill almost to his broad, blunt nose. It was</li>
<li class="L527" rel="L527">so like Smith&#39;s work, so much more like the top of a strongly spiked</li>
<li class="L528" rel="L528">wall than a head of hair, that the best of players at leap-frog might</li>
<li class="L529" rel="L529">have declined him, as the most dangerous man in the world to go over.</li>
<li class="L530" rel="L530"></li>
<li class="L531" rel="L531">While he trotted back with the message he was to deliver to the night</li>
<li class="L532" rel="L532">watchman in his box at the door of Tellson&#39;s Bank, by Temple Bar, who</li>
<li class="L533" rel="L533">was to deliver it to greater authorities within, the shadows of the</li>
<li class="L534" rel="L534">night took such shapes to him as arose out of the message, and took such</li>
<li class="L535" rel="L535">shapes to the mare as arose out of _her_ private topics of uneasiness.</li>
<li class="L536" rel="L536">They seemed to be numerous, for she shied at every shadow on the road.</li>
<li class="L537" rel="L537"></li>
<li class="L538" rel="L538">What time, the mail-coach lumbered, jolted, rattled, and bumped upon</li>
<li class="L539" rel="L539">its tedious way, with its three fellow-inscrutables inside. To whom,</li>
<li class="L540" rel="L540">likewise, the shadows of the night revealed themselves, in the forms</li>
<li class="L541" rel="L541">their dozing eyes and wandering thoughts suggested.</li>
<li class="L542" rel="L542"></li>
<li class="L543" rel="L543">Tellson&#39;s Bank had a run upon it in the mail. As the bank</li>
<li class="L544" rel="L544">passenger--with an arm drawn through the leathern strap, which did what</li>
<li class="L545" rel="L545">lay in it to keep him from pounding against the next passenger,</li>
<li class="L546" rel="L546">and driving him into his corner, whenever the coach got a special</li>
<li class="L547" rel="L547">jolt--nodded in his place, with half-shut eyes, the little</li>
<li class="L548" rel="L548">coach-windows, and the coach-lamp dimly gleaming through them, and the</li>
<li class="L549" rel="L549">bulky bundle of opposite passenger, became the bank, and did a great</li>
<li class="L550" rel="L550">stroke of business. The rattle of the harness was the chink of money,</li>
<li class="L551" rel="L551">and more drafts were honoured in five minutes than even Tellson&#39;s, with</li>
<li class="L552" rel="L552">all its foreign and home connection, ever paid in thrice the time. Then</li>
<li class="L553" rel="L553">the strong-rooms underground, at Tellson&#39;s, with such of their valuable</li>
<li class="L554" rel="L554">stores and secrets as were known to the passenger (and it was not a</li>
<li class="L555" rel="L555">little that he knew about them), opened before him, and he went in among</li>
<li class="L556" rel="L556">them with the great keys and the feebly-burning candle, and found them</li>
<li class="L557" rel="L557">safe, and strong, and sound, and still, just as he had last seen them.</li>
<li class="L558" rel="L558"></li>
<li class="L559" rel="L559">But, though the bank was almost always with him, and though the coach</li>
<li class="L560" rel="L560">(in a confused way, like the presence of pain under an opiate) was</li>
<li class="L561" rel="L561">always with him, there was another current of impression that never</li>
<li class="L562" rel="L562">ceased to run, all through the night. He was on his way to dig some one</li>
<li class="L563" rel="L563">out of a grave.</li>
<li class="L564" rel="L564"></li>
<li class="L565" rel="L565">Now, which of the multitude of faces that showed themselves before him</li>
<li class="L566" rel="L566">was the true face of the buried person, the shadows of the night did</li>
<li class="L567" rel="L567">not indicate; but they were all the faces of a man of five-and-forty by</li>
<li class="L568" rel="L568">years, and they differed principally in the passions they expressed,</li>
<li class="L569" rel="L569">and in the ghastliness of their worn and wasted state. Pride, contempt,</li>
<li class="L570" rel="L570">defiance, stubbornness, submission, lamentation, succeeded one another;</li>
<li class="L571" rel="L571">so did varieties of sunken cheek, cadaverous colour, emaciated hands</li>
<li class="L572" rel="L572">and figures. But the face was in the main one face, and every head was</li>
<li class="L573" rel="L573">prematurely white. A hundred times the dozing passenger inquired of this</li>
<li class="L574" rel="L574">spectre:</li>
<li class="L575" rel="L575"></li>
<li class="L576" rel="L576">“Buried how long?”</li>
<li class="L577" rel="L577"></li>
<li class="L578" rel="L578">The answer was always the same: “Almost eighteen years.”</li>
<li class="L579" rel="L579"></li>
<li class="L580" rel="L580">“You had abandoned all hope of being dug out?”</li>
<li class="L581" rel="L581"></li>
<li class="L582" rel="L582">“Long ago.”</li>
<li class="L583" rel="L583"></li>
<li class="L584" rel="L584">“You know that you are recalled to life?”</li>
<li class="L585" rel="L585"></li>
<li class="L586" rel="L586">“They tell me so.”</li>
<li class="L587" rel="L587"></li>
<li class="L588" rel="L588">“I hope you care to live?”</li>
<li class="L589" rel="L589"></li>
<li class="L590" rel="L590">“I can&#39;t say.”</li>
<li class="L591" rel="L591"></li>
<li class="L592" rel="L592">“Shall I show her to you? Will you come and see her?”</li>
<li class="L593" rel="L593"></li>
<li class="L594" rel="L594">The answers to this question were various and contradictory. Sometimes</li>
<li class="L595" rel="L595">the broken reply was, “Wait! It would kill me if I saw her too soon.”</li>
<li class="L596" rel="L596"> Sometimes, it was given in a tender rain of tears, and then it was,</li>
<li class="L597" rel="L597">“Take me to her.” Sometimes it was staring and bewildered, and then it</li>
<li class="L598" rel="L598">was, “I don&#39;t know her. I don&#39;t understand.”</li>
<li class="L599" rel="L599"></li>
<li class="L600" rel="L600">After such imaginary discourse, the passenger in his fancy would dig,</li>
<li class="L601" rel="L601">and dig, dig--now with a spade, now with a great key, now with his</li>
<li class="L602" rel="L602">hands--to dig this wretched creature out. Got out at last, with earth</li>
<li class="L603" rel="L603">hanging about his face and hair, he would suddenly fan away to dust. The</li>
<li class="L604" rel="L604">passenger would then start to himself, and lower the window, to get the</li>
<li class="L605" rel="L605">reality of mist and rain on his cheek.</li>
<li class="L606" rel="L606"></li>
<li class="L607" rel="L607">Yet even when his eyes were opened on the mist and rain, on the moving</li>
<li class="L608" rel="L608">patch of light from the lamps, and the hedge at the roadside retreating</li>
<li class="L609" rel="L609">by jerks, the night shadows outside the coach would fall into the train</li>
<li class="L610" rel="L610">of the night shadows within. The real Banking-house by Temple Bar, the</li>
<li class="L611" rel="L611">real business of the past day, the real strong rooms, the real express</li>
<li class="L612" rel="L612">sent after him, and the real message returned, would all be there. Out</li>
<li class="L613" rel="L613">of the midst of them, the ghostly face would rise, and he would accost</li>
<li class="L614" rel="L614">it again.</li>
<li class="L615" rel="L615"></li>
<li class="L616" rel="L616">“Buried how long?”</li>
<li class="L617" rel="L617"></li>
<li class="L618" rel="L618">“Almost eighteen years.”</li>
<li class="L619" rel="L619"></li>
<li class="L620" rel="L620">“I hope you care to live?”</li>
<li class="L621" rel="L621"></li>
<li class="L622" rel="L622">“I can&#39;t say.”</li>
<li class="L623" rel="L623"></li>
<li class="L624" rel="L624">Dig--dig--dig--until an impatient movement from one of the two</li>
<li class="L625" rel="L625">passengers would admonish him to pull up the window, draw his arm</li>
<li class="L626" rel="L626">securely through the leathern strap, and speculate upon the two</li>
<li class="L627" rel="L627">slumbering forms, until his mind lost its hold of them, and they again</li>
<li class="L628" rel="L628">slid away into the bank and the grave.</li>
<li class="L629" rel="L629"></li>
<li class="L630" rel="L630">“Buried how long?”</li>
<li class="L631" rel="L631"></li>
<li class="L632" rel="L632">“Almost eighteen years.”</li>
<li class="L633" rel="L633"></li>
<li class="L634" rel="L634">“You had abandoned all hope of being dug out?”</li>
<li class="L635" rel="L635"></li>
<li class="L636" rel="L636">“Long ago.”</li>
<li class="L637" rel="L637"></li>
<li class="L638" rel="L638">The words were still in his hearing as just spoken--distinctly in</li>
<li class="L639" rel="L639">his hearing as ever spoken words had been in his life--when the weary</li>
<li class="L640" rel="L640">passenger started to the consciousness of daylight, and found that the</li>
<li class="L641" rel="L641">shadows of the night were gone.</li>
<li class="L642" rel="L642"></li>
<li class="L643" rel="L643">He lowered the window, and looked out at the rising sun. There was a</li>
<li class="L644" rel="L644">ridge of ploughed land, with a plough upon it where it had been left</li>
<li class="L645" rel="L645">last night when the horses were unyoked; beyond, a quiet coppice-wood,</li>
<li class="L646" rel="L646">in which many leaves of burning red and golden yellow still remained</li>
<li class="L647" rel="L647">upon the trees. Though the earth was cold and wet, the sky was clear,</li>
<li class="L648" rel="L648">and the sun rose bright, placid, and beautiful.</li>
<li class="L649" rel="L649"></li>
<li class="L650" rel="L650">“Eighteen years!” said the passenger, looking at the sun. “Gracious</li>
<li class="L651" rel="L651">Creator of day! To be buried alive for eighteen years!”</li>
<li class="L652" rel="L652"></li>
<li class="L653" rel="L653"></li>
<li class="L654" rel="L654"></li>
<li class="L655" rel="L655"></li>
<li class="L656" rel="L656">IV. The Preparation</li>
<li class="L657" rel="L657"></li>
<li class="L658" rel="L658"></li>
<li class="L659" rel="L659">When the mail got successfully to Dover, in the course of the forenoon,</li>
<li class="L660" rel="L660">the head drawer at the Royal George Hotel opened the coach-door as his</li>
<li class="L661" rel="L661">custom was. He did it with some flourish of ceremony, for a mail journey</li>
<li class="L662" rel="L662">from London in winter was an achievement to congratulate an adventurous</li>
<li class="L663" rel="L663">traveller upon.</li>
<li class="L664" rel="L664"></li>
<li class="L665" rel="L665">By that time, there was only one adventurous traveller left be</li>
<li class="L666" rel="L666">congratulated: for the two others had been set down at their respective</li>
<li class="L667" rel="L667">roadside destinations. The mildewy inside of the coach, with its damp</li>
<li class="L668" rel="L668">and dirty straw, its disagreeable smell, and its obscurity, was rather</li>
<li class="L669" rel="L669">like a larger dog-kennel. Mr. Lorry, the passenger, shaking himself out</li>
<li class="L670" rel="L670">of it in chains of straw, a tangle of shaggy wrapper, flapping hat, and</li>
<li class="L671" rel="L671">muddy legs, was rather like a larger sort of dog.</li>
<li class="L672" rel="L672"></li>
<li class="L673" rel="L673">“There will be a packet to Calais, tomorrow, drawer?”</li>
<li class="L674" rel="L674"></li>
<li class="L675" rel="L675">“Yes, sir, if the weather holds and the wind sets tolerable fair. The</li>
<li class="L676" rel="L676">tide will serve pretty nicely at about two in the afternoon, sir. Bed,</li>
<li class="L677" rel="L677">sir?”</li>
<li class="L678" rel="L678"></li>
<li class="L679" rel="L679">“I shall not go to bed till night; but I want a bedroom, and a barber.”</li>
<li class="L680" rel="L680"></li>
<li class="L681" rel="L681">“And then breakfast, sir? Yes, sir. That way, sir, if you please.</li>
<li class="L682" rel="L682">Show Concord! Gentleman&#39;s valise and hot water to Concord. Pull off</li>
<li class="L683" rel="L683">gentleman&#39;s boots in Concord. (You will find a fine sea-coal fire, sir.)</li>
<li class="L684" rel="L684">Fetch barber to Concord. Stir about there, now, for Concord!”</li>
<li class="L685" rel="L685"></li>
<li class="L686" rel="L686">The Concord bed-chamber being always assigned to a passenger by the</li>
<li class="L687" rel="L687">mail, and passengers by the mail being always heavily wrapped up from</li>
<li class="L688" rel="L688">head to foot, the room had the odd interest for the establishment of the</li>
<li class="L689" rel="L689">Royal George, that although but one kind of man was seen to go into it,</li>
<li class="L690" rel="L690">all kinds and varieties of men came out of it. Consequently, another</li>
<li class="L691" rel="L691">drawer, and two porters, and several maids and the landlady, were all</li>
<li class="L692" rel="L692">loitering by accident at various points of the road between the Concord</li>
<li class="L693" rel="L693">and the coffee-room, when a gentleman of sixty, formally dressed in a</li>
<li class="L694" rel="L694">brown suit of clothes, pretty well worn, but very well kept, with large</li>
<li class="L695" rel="L695">square cuffs and large flaps to the pockets, passed along on his way to</li>
<li class="L696" rel="L696">his breakfast.</li>
<li class="L697" rel="L697"></li>
<li class="L698" rel="L698">The coffee-room had no other occupant, that forenoon, than the gentleman</li>
<li class="L699" rel="L699">in brown. His breakfast-table was drawn before the fire, and as he sat,</li>
<li class="L700" rel="L700">with its light shining on him, waiting for the meal, he sat so still,</li>
<li class="L701" rel="L701">that he might have been sitting for his portrait.</li>
<li class="L702" rel="L702"></li>
<li class="L703" rel="L703">Very orderly and methodical he looked, with a hand on each knee, and a</li>
<li class="L704" rel="L704">loud watch ticking a sonorous sermon under his flapped waist-coat,</li>
<li class="L705" rel="L705">as though it pitted its gravity and longevity against the levity and</li>
<li class="L706" rel="L706">evanescence of the brisk fire. He had a good leg, and was a little vain</li>
<li class="L707" rel="L707">of it, for his brown stockings fitted sleek and close, and were of a</li>
<li class="L708" rel="L708">fine texture; his shoes and buckles, too, though plain, were trim. He</li>
<li class="L709" rel="L709">wore an odd little sleek crisp flaxen wig, setting very close to his</li>
<li class="L710" rel="L710">head: which wig, it is to be presumed, was made of hair, but which</li>
<li class="L711" rel="L711">looked far more as though it were spun from filaments of silk or glass.</li>
<li class="L712" rel="L712">His linen, though not of a fineness in accordance with his stockings,</li>
<li class="L713" rel="L713">was as white as the tops of the waves that broke upon the neighbouring</li>
<li class="L714" rel="L714">beach, or the specks of sail that glinted in the sunlight far at sea. A</li>
<li class="L715" rel="L715">face habitually suppressed and quieted, was still lighted up under the</li>
<li class="L716" rel="L716">quaint wig by a pair of moist bright eyes that it must have cost</li>
<li class="L717" rel="L717">their owner, in years gone by, some pains to drill to the composed and</li>
<li class="L718" rel="L718">reserved expression of Tellson&#39;s Bank. He had a healthy colour in his</li>
<li class="L719" rel="L719">cheeks, and his face, though lined, bore few traces of anxiety.</li>
<li class="L720" rel="L720">But, perhaps the confidential bachelor clerks in Tellson&#39;s Bank were</li>
<li class="L721" rel="L721">principally occupied with the cares of other people; and perhaps</li>
<li class="L722" rel="L722">second-hand cares, like second-hand clothes, come easily off and on.</li>
<li class="L723" rel="L723"></li>
<li class="L724" rel="L724">Completing his resemblance to a man who was sitting for his portrait,</li>
<li class="L725" rel="L725">Mr. Lorry dropped off to sleep. The arrival of his breakfast roused him,</li>
<li class="L726" rel="L726">and he said to the drawer, as he moved his chair to it:</li>
<li class="L727" rel="L727"></li>
<li class="L728" rel="L728">“I wish accommodation prepared for a young lady who may come here at any</li>
<li class="L729" rel="L729">time to-day. She may ask for Mr. Jarvis Lorry, or she may only ask for a</li>
<li class="L730" rel="L730">gentleman from Tellson&#39;s Bank. Please to let me know.”</li>
<li class="L731" rel="L731"></li>
<li class="L732" rel="L732">“Yes, sir. Tellson&#39;s Bank in London, sir?”</li>
<li class="L733" rel="L733"></li>
<li class="L734" rel="L734">“Yes.”</li>
<li class="L735" rel="L735"></li>
<li class="L736" rel="L736">“Yes, sir. We have oftentimes the honour to entertain your gentlemen in</li>
<li class="L737" rel="L737">their travelling backwards and forwards betwixt London and Paris, sir. A</li>
<li class="L738" rel="L738">vast deal of travelling, sir, in Tellson and Company&#39;s House.”</li>
<li class="L739" rel="L739"></li>
<li class="L740" rel="L740">“Yes. We are quite a French House, as well as an English one.”</li>
<li class="L741" rel="L741"></li>
<li class="L742" rel="L742">“Yes, sir. Not much in the habit of such travelling yourself, I think,</li>
<li class="L743" rel="L743">sir?”</li>
<li class="L744" rel="L744"></li>
<li class="L745" rel="L745">“Not of late years. It is fifteen years since we--since I--came last</li>
<li class="L746" rel="L746">from France.”</li>
<li class="L747" rel="L747"></li>
<li class="L748" rel="L748">“Indeed, sir? That was before my time here, sir. Before our people&#39;s</li>
<li class="L749" rel="L749">time here, sir. The George was in other hands at that time, sir.”</li>
<li class="L750" rel="L750"></li>
<li class="L751" rel="L751">“I believe so.”</li>
<li class="L752" rel="L752"></li>
<li class="L753" rel="L753">“But I would hold a pretty wager, sir, that a House like Tellson and</li>
<li class="L754" rel="L754">Company was flourishing, a matter of fifty, not to speak of fifteen</li>
<li class="L755" rel="L755">years ago?”</li>
<li class="L756" rel="L756"></li>
<li class="L757" rel="L757">“You might treble that, and say a hundred and fifty, yet not be far from</li>
<li class="L758" rel="L758">the truth.”</li>
<li class="L759" rel="L759"></li>
<li class="L760" rel="L760">“Indeed, sir!”</li>
<li class="L761" rel="L761"></li>
<li class="L762" rel="L762">Rounding his mouth and both his eyes, as he stepped backward from the</li>
<li class="L763" rel="L763">table, the waiter shifted his napkin from his right arm to his left,</li>
<li class="L764" rel="L764">dropped into a comfortable attitude, and stood surveying the guest while</li>
<li class="L765" rel="L765">he ate and drank, as from an observatory or watchtower. According to the</li>
<li class="L766" rel="L766">immemorial usage of waiters in all ages.</li>
<li class="L767" rel="L767"></li>
<li class="L768" rel="L768">When Mr. Lorry had finished his breakfast, he went out for a stroll on</li>
<li class="L769" rel="L769">the beach. The little narrow, crooked town of Dover hid itself away</li>
<li class="L770" rel="L770">from the beach, and ran its head into the chalk cliffs, like a marine</li>
<li class="L771" rel="L771">ostrich. The beach was a desert of heaps of sea and stones tumbling</li>
<li class="L772" rel="L772">wildly about, and the sea did what it liked, and what it liked was</li>
<li class="L773" rel="L773">destruction. It thundered at the town, and thundered at the cliffs, and</li>
<li class="L774" rel="L774">brought the coast down, madly. The air among the houses was of so strong</li>
<li class="L775" rel="L775">a piscatory flavour that one might have supposed sick fish went up to be</li>
<li class="L776" rel="L776">dipped in it, as sick people went down to be dipped in the sea. A little</li>
<li class="L777" rel="L777">fishing was done in the port, and a quantity of strolling about by</li>
<li class="L778" rel="L778">night, and looking seaward: particularly at those times when the tide</li>
<li class="L779" rel="L779">made, and was near flood. Small tradesmen, who did no business whatever,</li>
<li class="L780" rel="L780">sometimes unaccountably realised large fortunes, and it was remarkable</li>
<li class="L781" rel="L781">that nobody in the neighbourhood could endure a lamplighter.</li>
<li class="L782" rel="L782"></li>
<li class="L783" rel="L783">As the day declined into the afternoon, and the air, which had been</li>
<li class="L784" rel="L784">at intervals clear enough to allow the French coast to be seen, became</li>
<li class="L785" rel="L785">again charged with mist and vapour, Mr. Lorry&#39;s thoughts seemed to cloud</li>
<li class="L786" rel="L786">too. When it was dark, and he sat before the coffee-room fire, awaiting</li>
<li class="L787" rel="L787">his dinner as he had awaited his breakfast, his mind was busily digging,</li>
<li class="L788" rel="L788">digging, digging, in the live red coals.</li>
<li class="L789" rel="L789"></li>
<li class="L790" rel="L790">A bottle of good claret after dinner does a digger in the red coals no</li>
<li class="L791" rel="L791">harm, otherwise than as it has a tendency to throw him out of work.</li>
<li class="L792" rel="L792">Mr. Lorry had been idle a long time, and had just poured out his last</li>
<li class="L793" rel="L793">glassful of wine with as complete an appearance of satisfaction as is</li>
<li class="L794" rel="L794">ever to be found in an elderly gentleman of a fresh complexion who has</li>
<li class="L795" rel="L795">got to the end of a bottle, when a rattling of wheels came up the narrow</li>
<li class="L796" rel="L796">street, and rumbled into the inn-yard.</li>
<li class="L797" rel="L797"></li>
<li class="L798" rel="L798">He set down his glass untouched. “This is Mam&#39;selle!” said he.</li>
<li class="L799" rel="L799"></li>
<li class="L800" rel="L800">In a very few minutes the waiter came in to announce that Miss Manette</li>
<li class="L801" rel="L801">had arrived from London, and would be happy to see the gentleman from</li>
<li class="L802" rel="L802">Tellson&#39;s.</li>
<li class="L803" rel="L803"></li>
<li class="L804" rel="L804">“So soon?”</li>
<li class="L805" rel="L805"></li>
<li class="L806" rel="L806">Miss Manette had taken some refreshment on the road, and required none</li>
<li class="L807" rel="L807">then, and was extremely anxious to see the gentleman from Tellson&#39;s</li>
<li class="L808" rel="L808">immediately, if it suited his pleasure and convenience.</li>
<li class="L809" rel="L809"></li>
<li class="L810" rel="L810">The gentleman from Tellson&#39;s had nothing left for it but to empty his</li>
<li class="L811" rel="L811">glass with an air of stolid desperation, settle his odd little flaxen</li>
<li class="L812" rel="L812">wig at the ears, and follow the waiter to Miss Manette&#39;s apartment.</li>
<li class="L813" rel="L813">It was a large, dark room, furnished in a funereal manner with black</li>
<li class="L814" rel="L814">horsehair, and loaded with heavy dark tables. These had been oiled and</li>
<li class="L815" rel="L815">oiled, until the two tall candles on the table in the middle of the room</li>
<li class="L816" rel="L816">were gloomily reflected on every leaf; as if _they_ were buried, in deep</li>
<li class="L817" rel="L817">graves of black mahogany, and no light to speak of could be expected</li>
<li class="L818" rel="L818">from them until they were dug out.</li>
<li class="L819" rel="L819"></li>
<li class="L820" rel="L820">The obscurity was so difficult to penetrate that Mr. Lorry, picking his</li>
<li class="L821" rel="L821">way over the well-worn Turkey carpet, supposed Miss Manette to be, for</li>
<li class="L822" rel="L822">the moment, in some adjacent room, until, having got past the two tall</li>
<li class="L823" rel="L823">candles, he saw standing to receive him by the table between them and</li>
<li class="L824" rel="L824">the fire, a young lady of not more than seventeen, in a riding-cloak,</li>
<li class="L825" rel="L825">and still holding her straw travelling-hat by its ribbon in her hand. As</li>
<li class="L826" rel="L826">his eyes rested on a short, slight, pretty figure, a quantity of golden</li>
<li class="L827" rel="L827">hair, a pair of blue eyes that met his own with an inquiring look, and</li>
<li class="L828" rel="L828">a forehead with a singular capacity (remembering how young and smooth</li>
<li class="L829" rel="L829">it was), of rifting and knitting itself into an expression that was</li>
<li class="L830" rel="L830">not quite one of perplexity, or wonder, or alarm, or merely of a bright</li>
<li class="L831" rel="L831">fixed attention, though it included all the four expressions--as his</li>
<li class="L832" rel="L832">eyes rested on these things, a sudden vivid likeness passed before him,</li>
<li class="L833" rel="L833">of a child whom he had held in his arms on the passage across that very</li>
<li class="L834" rel="L834">Channel, one cold time, when the hail drifted heavily and the sea ran</li>
<li class="L835" rel="L835">high. The likeness passed away, like a breath along the surface of</li>
<li class="L836" rel="L836">the gaunt pier-glass behind her, on the frame of which, a hospital</li>
<li class="L837" rel="L837">procession of negro cupids, several headless and all cripples, were</li>
<li class="L838" rel="L838">offering black baskets of Dead Sea fruit to black divinities of the</li>
<li class="L839" rel="L839">feminine gender--and he made his formal bow to Miss Manette.</li>
<li class="L840" rel="L840"></li>
<li class="L841" rel="L841">“Pray take a seat, sir.” In a very clear and pleasant young voice; a</li>
<li class="L842" rel="L842">little foreign in its accent, but a very little indeed.</li>
<li class="L843" rel="L843"></li>
<li class="L844" rel="L844">“I kiss your hand, miss,” said Mr. Lorry, with the manners of an earlier</li>
<li class="L845" rel="L845">date, as he made his formal bow again, and took his seat.</li>
<li class="L846" rel="L846"></li>
<li class="L847" rel="L847">“I received a letter from the Bank, sir, yesterday, informing me that</li>
<li class="L848" rel="L848">some intelligence--or discovery--”</li>
<li class="L849" rel="L849"></li>
<li class="L850" rel="L850">“The word is not material, miss; either word will do.”</li>
<li class="L851" rel="L851"></li>
<li class="L852" rel="L852">“--respecting the small property of my poor father, whom I never saw--so</li>
<li class="L853" rel="L853">long dead--”</li>
<li class="L854" rel="L854"></li>
<li class="L855" rel="L855">Mr. Lorry moved in his chair, and cast a troubled look towards the</li>
<li class="L856" rel="L856">hospital procession of negro cupids. As if _they_ had any help for</li>
<li class="L857" rel="L857">anybody in their absurd baskets!</li>
<li class="L858" rel="L858"></li>
<li class="L859" rel="L859">“--rendered it necessary that I should go to Paris, there to communicate</li>
<li class="L860" rel="L860">with a gentleman of the Bank, so good as to be despatched to Paris for</li>
<li class="L861" rel="L861">the purpose.”</li>
<li class="L862" rel="L862"></li>
<li class="L863" rel="L863">“Myself.”</li>
<li class="L864" rel="L864"></li>
<li class="L865" rel="L865">“As I was prepared to hear, sir.”</li>
<li class="L866" rel="L866"></li>
<li class="L867" rel="L867">She curtseyed to him (young ladies made curtseys in those days), with a</li>
<li class="L868" rel="L868">pretty desire to convey to him that she felt how much older and wiser he</li>
<li class="L869" rel="L869">was than she. He made her another bow.</li>
<li class="L870" rel="L870"></li>
<li class="L871" rel="L871">“I replied to the Bank, sir, that as it was considered necessary, by</li>
<li class="L872" rel="L872">those who know, and who are so kind as to advise me, that I should go to</li>
<li class="L873" rel="L873">France, and that as I am an orphan and have no friend who could go with</li>
<li class="L874" rel="L874">me, I should esteem it highly if I might be permitted to place myself,</li>
<li class="L875" rel="L875">during the journey, under that worthy gentleman&#39;s protection. The</li>
<li class="L876" rel="L876">gentleman had left London, but I think a messenger was sent after him to</li>
<li class="L877" rel="L877">beg the favour of his waiting for me here.”</li>
<li class="L878" rel="L878"></li>
<li class="L879" rel="L879">“I was happy,” said Mr. Lorry, “to be entrusted with the charge. I shall</li>
<li class="L880" rel="L880">be more happy to execute it.”</li>
<li class="L881" rel="L881"></li>
<li class="L882" rel="L882">“Sir, I thank you indeed. I thank you very gratefully. It was told me</li>
<li class="L883" rel="L883">by the Bank that the gentleman would explain to me the details of the</li>
<li class="L884" rel="L884">business, and that I must prepare myself to find them of a surprising</li>
<li class="L885" rel="L885">nature. I have done my best to prepare myself, and I naturally have a</li>
<li class="L886" rel="L886">strong and eager interest to know what they are.”</li>
<li class="L887" rel="L887"></li>
<li class="L888" rel="L888">“Naturally,” said Mr. Lorry. “Yes--I--”</li>
<li class="L889" rel="L889"></li>
<li class="L890" rel="L890">After a pause, he added, again settling the crisp flaxen wig at the</li>
<li class="L891" rel="L891">ears, “It is very difficult to begin.”</li>
<li class="L892" rel="L892"></li>
<li class="L893" rel="L893">He did not begin, but, in his indecision, met her glance. The young</li>
<li class="L894" rel="L894">forehead lifted itself into that singular expression--but it was pretty</li>
<li class="L895" rel="L895">and characteristic, besides being singular--and she raised her hand,</li>
<li class="L896" rel="L896">as if with an involuntary action she caught at, or stayed some passing</li>
<li class="L897" rel="L897">shadow.</li>
<li class="L898" rel="L898"></li>
<li class="L899" rel="L899">“Are you quite a stranger to me, sir?”</li>
<li class="L900" rel="L900"></li>
<li class="L901" rel="L901">“Am I not?” Mr. Lorry opened his hands, and extended them outwards with</li>
<li class="L902" rel="L902">an argumentative smile.</li>
<li class="L903" rel="L903"></li>
<li class="L904" rel="L904">Between the eyebrows and just over the little feminine nose, the line of</li>
<li class="L905" rel="L905">which was as delicate and fine as it was possible to be, the expression</li>
<li class="L906" rel="L906">deepened itself as she took her seat thoughtfully in the chair by which</li>
<li class="L907" rel="L907">she had hitherto remained standing. He watched her as she mused, and the</li>
<li class="L908" rel="L908">moment she raised her eyes again, went on:</li>
<li class="L909" rel="L909"></li>
<li class="L910" rel="L910">“In your adopted country, I presume, I cannot do better than address you</li>
<li class="L911" rel="L911">as a young English lady, Miss Manette?”</li>
<li class="L912" rel="L912"></li>
<li class="L913" rel="L913">“If you please, sir.”</li>
<li class="L914" rel="L914"></li>
<li class="L915" rel="L915">“Miss Manette, I am a man of business. I have a business charge to</li>
<li class="L916" rel="L916">acquit myself of. In your reception of it, don&#39;t heed me any more than</li>
<li class="L917" rel="L917">if I was a speaking machine--truly, I am not much else. I will, with</li>
<li class="L918" rel="L918">your leave, relate to you, miss, the story of one of our customers.”</li>
<li class="L919" rel="L919"></li>
<li class="L920" rel="L920">“Story!”</li>
<li class="L921" rel="L921"></li>
<li class="L922" rel="L922">He seemed wilfully to mistake the word she had repeated, when he added,</li>
<li class="L923" rel="L923">in a hurry, “Yes, customers; in the banking business we usually call</li>
<li class="L924" rel="L924">our connection our customers. He was a French gentleman; a scientific</li>
<li class="L925" rel="L925">gentleman; a man of great acquirements--a Doctor.”</li>
<li class="L926" rel="L926"></li>
<li class="L927" rel="L927">“Not of Beauvais?”</li>
<li class="L928" rel="L928"></li>
<li class="L929" rel="L929">“Why, yes, of Beauvais. Like Monsieur Manette, your father, the</li>
<li class="L930" rel="L930">gentleman was of Beauvais. Like Monsieur Manette, your father, the</li>
<li class="L931" rel="L931">gentleman was of repute in Paris. I had the honour of knowing him there.</li>
<li class="L932" rel="L932">Our relations were business relations, but confidential. I was at that</li>
<li class="L933" rel="L933">time in our French House, and had been--oh! twenty years.”</li>
<li class="L934" rel="L934"></li>
<li class="L935" rel="L935">“At that time--I may ask, at what time, sir?”</li>
<li class="L936" rel="L936"></li>
<li class="L937" rel="L937">“I speak, miss, of twenty years ago. He married--an English lady--and</li>
<li class="L938" rel="L938">I was one of the trustees. His affairs, like the affairs of many other</li>
<li class="L939" rel="L939">French gentlemen and French families, were entirely in Tellson&#39;s hands.</li>
<li class="L940" rel="L940">In a similar way I am, or I have been, trustee of one kind or other for</li>
<li class="L941" rel="L941">scores of our customers. These are mere business relations, miss;</li>
<li class="L942" rel="L942">there is no friendship in them, no particular interest, nothing like</li>
<li class="L943" rel="L943">sentiment. I have passed from one to another, in the course of my</li>
<li class="L944" rel="L944">business life, just as I pass from one of our customers to another in</li>
<li class="L945" rel="L945">the course of my business day; in short, I have no feelings; I am a mere</li>
<li class="L946" rel="L946">machine. To go on--”</li>
<li class="L947" rel="L947"></li>
<li class="L948" rel="L948">“But this is my father&#39;s story, sir; and I begin to think”--the</li>
<li class="L949" rel="L949">curiously roughened forehead was very intent upon him--“that when I was</li>
<li class="L950" rel="L950">left an orphan through my mother&#39;s surviving my father only two years,</li>
<li class="L951" rel="L951">it was you who brought me to England. I am almost sure it was you.”</li>
<li class="L952" rel="L952"></li>
<li class="L953" rel="L953">Mr. Lorry took the hesitating little hand that confidingly advanced</li>
<li class="L954" rel="L954">to take his, and he put it with some ceremony to his lips. He then</li>
<li class="L955" rel="L955">conducted the young lady straightway to her chair again, and, holding</li>
<li class="L956" rel="L956">the chair-back with his left hand, and using his right by turns to rub</li>
<li class="L957" rel="L957">his chin, pull his wig at the ears, or point what he said, stood looking</li>
<li class="L958" rel="L958">down into her face while she sat looking up into his.</li>
<li class="L959" rel="L959"></li>
<li class="L960" rel="L960">“Miss Manette, it _was_ I. And you will see how truly I spoke of myself</li>
<li class="L961" rel="L961">just now, in saying I had no feelings, and that all the relations I hold</li>
<li class="L962" rel="L962">with my fellow-creatures are mere business relations, when you reflect</li>
<li class="L963" rel="L963">that I have never seen you since. No; you have been the ward of</li>
<li class="L964" rel="L964">Tellson&#39;s House since, and I have been busy with the other business of</li>
<li class="L965" rel="L965">Tellson&#39;s House since. Feelings! I have no time for them, no chance</li>
<li class="L966" rel="L966">of them. I pass my whole life, miss, in turning an immense pecuniary</li>
<li class="L967" rel="L967">Mangle.”</li>
<li class="L968" rel="L968"></li>
<li class="L969" rel="L969">After this odd description of his daily routine of employment, Mr. Lorry</li>
<li class="L970" rel="L970">flattened his flaxen wig upon his head with both hands (which was most</li>
<li class="L971" rel="L971">unnecessary, for nothing could be flatter than its shining surface was</li>
<li class="L972" rel="L972">before), and resumed his former attitude.</li>
<li class="L973" rel="L973"></li>
<li class="L974" rel="L974">“So far, miss (as you have remarked), this is the story of your</li>
<li class="L975" rel="L975">regretted father. Now comes the difference. If your father had not died</li>
<li class="L976" rel="L976">when he did--Don&#39;t be frightened! How you start!”</li>
<li class="L977" rel="L977"></li>
<li class="L978" rel="L978">She did, indeed, start. And she caught his wrist with both her hands.</li>
<li class="L979" rel="L979"></li>
<li class="L980" rel="L980">“Pray,” said Mr. Lorry, in a soothing tone, bringing his left hand from</li>
<li class="L981" rel="L981">the back of the chair to lay it on the supplicatory fingers that clasped</li>
<li class="L982" rel="L982">him in so violent a tremble: “pray control your agitation--a matter of</li>
<li class="L983" rel="L983">business. As I was saying--”</li>
<li class="L984" rel="L984"></li>
<li class="L985" rel="L985">Her look so discomposed him that he stopped, wandered, and began anew:</li>
<li class="L986" rel="L986"></li>
<li class="L987" rel="L987">“As I was saying; if Monsieur Manette had not died; if he had suddenly</li>
<li class="L988" rel="L988">and silently disappeared; if he had been spirited away; if it had not</li>
<li class="L989" rel="L989">been difficult to guess to what dreadful place, though no art could</li>
<li class="L990" rel="L990">trace him; if he had an enemy in some compatriot who could exercise a</li>
<li class="L991" rel="L991">privilege that I in my own time have known the boldest people afraid</li>
<li class="L992" rel="L992">to speak of in a whisper, across the water there; for instance, the</li>
<li class="L993" rel="L993">privilege of filling up blank forms for the consignment of any one</li>
<li class="L994" rel="L994">to the oblivion of a prison for any length of time; if his wife had</li>
<li class="L995" rel="L995">implored the king, the queen, the court, the clergy, for any tidings of</li>
<li class="L996" rel="L996">him, and all quite in vain;--then the history of your father would have</li>
<li class="L997" rel="L997">been the history of this unfortunate gentleman, the Doctor of Beauvais.”</li>
<li class="L998" rel="L998"></li>
<li class="L999" rel="L999">“I entreat you to tell me more, sir.”</li>
<li class="L1000" rel="L1000"></li>
<li class="L1001" rel="L1001">“I will. I am going to. You can bear it?”</li>
<li class="L1002" rel="L1002"></li>
<li class="L1003" rel="L1003">“I can bear anything but the uncertainty you leave me in at this</li>
<li class="L1004" rel="L1004">moment.”</li>
<li class="L1005" rel="L1005"></li>
<li class="L1006" rel="L1006">“You speak collectedly, and you--_are_ collected. That&#39;s good!” (Though</li>
<li class="L1007" rel="L1007">his manner was less satisfied than his words.) “A matter of business.</li>
<li class="L1008" rel="L1008">Regard it as a matter of business--business that must be done. Now</li>
<li class="L1009" rel="L1009">if this doctor&#39;s wife, though a lady of great courage and spirit,</li>
<li class="L1010" rel="L1010">had suffered so intensely from this cause before her little child was</li>
<li class="L1011" rel="L1011">born--”</li>
<li class="L1012" rel="L1012"></li>
<li class="L1013" rel="L1013">“The little child was a daughter, sir.”</li>
<li class="L1014" rel="L1014"></li>
<li class="L1015" rel="L1015">“A daughter. A-a-matter of business--don&#39;t be distressed. Miss, if the</li>
<li class="L1016" rel="L1016">poor lady had suffered so intensely before her little child was born,</li>
<li class="L1017" rel="L1017">that she came to the determination of sparing the poor child the</li>
<li class="L1018" rel="L1018">inheritance of any part of the agony she had known the pains of, by</li>
<li class="L1019" rel="L1019">rearing her in the belief that her father was dead--No, don&#39;t kneel! In</li>
<li class="L1020" rel="L1020">Heaven&#39;s name why should you kneel to me!”</li>
<li class="L1021" rel="L1021"></li>
