<li class="L1022" rel="L1022">“For the truth. O dear, good, compassionate sir, for the truth!”</li>
<li class="L1023" rel="L1023"></li>
<li class="L1024" rel="L1024">“A--a matter of business. You confuse me, and how can I transact</li>
<li class="L1025" rel="L1025">business if I am confused? Let us be clear-headed. If you could kindly</li>
<li class="L1026" rel="L1026">mention now, for instance, what nine times ninepence are, or how many</li>
<li class="L1027" rel="L1027">shillings in twenty guineas, it would be so encouraging. I should be so</li>
<li class="L1028" rel="L1028">much more at my ease about your state of mind.”</li>
<li class="L1029" rel="L1029"></li>
<li class="L1030" rel="L1030">Without directly answering to this appeal, she sat so still when he had</li>
<li class="L1031" rel="L1031">very gently raised her, and the hands that had not ceased to clasp</li>
<li class="L1032" rel="L1032">his wrists were so much more steady than they had been, that she</li>
<li class="L1033" rel="L1033">communicated some reassurance to Mr. Jarvis Lorry.</li>
<li class="L1034" rel="L1034"></li>
<li class="L1035" rel="L1035">“That&#39;s right, that&#39;s right. Courage! Business! You have business before</li>
<li class="L1036" rel="L1036">you; useful business. Miss Manette, your mother took this course with</li>
<li class="L1037" rel="L1037">you. And when she died--I believe broken-hearted--having never slackened</li>
<li class="L1038" rel="L1038">her unavailing search for your father, she left you, at two years old,</li>
<li class="L1039" rel="L1039">to grow to be blooming, beautiful, and happy, without the dark cloud</li>
<li class="L1040" rel="L1040">upon you of living in uncertainty whether your father soon wore his</li>
<li class="L1041" rel="L1041">heart out in prison, or wasted there through many lingering years.”</li>
<li class="L1042" rel="L1042"></li>
<li class="L1043" rel="L1043">As he said the words he looked down, with an admiring pity, on the</li>
<li class="L1044" rel="L1044">flowing golden hair; as if he pictured to himself that it might have</li>
<li class="L1045" rel="L1045">been already tinged with grey.</li>
<li class="L1046" rel="L1046"></li>
<li class="L1047" rel="L1047">“You know that your parents had no great possession, and that what</li>
<li class="L1048" rel="L1048">they had was secured to your mother and to you. There has been no new</li>
<li class="L1049" rel="L1049">discovery, of money, or of any other property; but--”</li>
<li class="L1050" rel="L1050"></li>
<li class="L1051" rel="L1051">He felt his wrist held closer, and he stopped. The expression in the</li>
<li class="L1052" rel="L1052">forehead, which had so particularly attracted his notice, and which was</li>
<li class="L1053" rel="L1053">now immovable, had deepened into one of pain and horror.</li>
<li class="L1054" rel="L1054"></li>
<li class="L1055" rel="L1055">“But he has been--been found. He is alive. Greatly changed, it is too</li>
<li class="L1056" rel="L1056">probable; almost a wreck, it is possible; though we will hope the best.</li>
<li class="L1057" rel="L1057">Still, alive. Your father has been taken to the house of an old servant</li>
<li class="L1058" rel="L1058">in Paris, and we are going there: I, to identify him if I can: you, to</li>
<li class="L1059" rel="L1059">restore him to life, love, duty, rest, comfort.”</li>
<li class="L1060" rel="L1060"></li>
<li class="L1061" rel="L1061">A shiver ran through her frame, and from it through his. She said, in a</li>
<li class="L1062" rel="L1062">low, distinct, awe-stricken voice, as if she were saying it in a dream,</li>
<li class="L1063" rel="L1063"></li>
<li class="L1064" rel="L1064">“I am going to see his Ghost! It will be his Ghost--not him!”</li>
<li class="L1065" rel="L1065"></li>
<li class="L1066" rel="L1066">Mr. Lorry quietly chafed the hands that held his arm. “There, there,</li>
<li class="L1067" rel="L1067">there! See now, see now! The best and the worst are known to you, now.</li>
<li class="L1068" rel="L1068">You are well on your way to the poor wronged gentleman, and, with a fair</li>
<li class="L1069" rel="L1069">sea voyage, and a fair land journey, you will be soon at his dear side.”</li>
<li class="L1070" rel="L1070"></li>
<li class="L1071" rel="L1071">She repeated in the same tone, sunk to a whisper, “I have been free, I</li>
<li class="L1072" rel="L1072">have been happy, yet his Ghost has never haunted me!”</li>
<li class="L1073" rel="L1073"></li>
<li class="L1074" rel="L1074">“Only one thing more,” said Mr. Lorry, laying stress upon it as a</li>
<li class="L1075" rel="L1075">wholesome means of enforcing her attention: “he has been found under</li>
<li class="L1076" rel="L1076">another name; his own, long forgotten or long concealed. It would be</li>
<li class="L1077" rel="L1077">worse than useless now to inquire which; worse than useless to seek to</li>
<li class="L1078" rel="L1078">know whether he has been for years overlooked, or always designedly</li>
<li class="L1079" rel="L1079">held prisoner. It would be worse than useless now to make any inquiries,</li>
<li class="L1080" rel="L1080">because it would be dangerous. Better not to mention the subject,</li>
<li class="L1081" rel="L1081">anywhere or in any way, and to remove him--for a while at all</li>
<li class="L1082" rel="L1082">events--out of France. Even I, safe as an Englishman, and even</li>
<li class="L1083" rel="L1083">Tellson&#39;s, important as they are to French credit, avoid all naming of</li>
<li class="L1084" rel="L1084">the matter. I carry about me, not a scrap of writing openly referring</li>
<li class="L1085" rel="L1085">to it. This is a secret service altogether. My credentials, entries,</li>
<li class="L1086" rel="L1086">and memoranda, are all comprehended in the one line, &#39;Recalled to Life;&#39;</li>
<li class="L1087" rel="L1087">which may mean anything. But what is the matter! She doesn&#39;t notice a</li>
<li class="L1088" rel="L1088">word! Miss Manette!”</li>
<li class="L1089" rel="L1089"></li>
<li class="L1090" rel="L1090">Perfectly still and silent, and not even fallen back in her chair, she</li>
<li class="L1091" rel="L1091">sat under his hand, utterly insensible; with her eyes open and fixed</li>
<li class="L1092" rel="L1092">upon him, and with that last expression looking as if it were carved or</li>
<li class="L1093" rel="L1093">branded into her forehead. So close was her hold upon his arm, that he</li>
<li class="L1094" rel="L1094">feared to detach himself lest he should hurt her; therefore he called</li>
<li class="L1095" rel="L1095">out loudly for assistance without moving.</li>
<li class="L1096" rel="L1096"></li>
<li class="L1097" rel="L1097">A wild-looking woman, whom even in his agitation, Mr. Lorry observed to</li>
<li class="L1098" rel="L1098">be all of a red colour, and to have red hair, and to be dressed in some</li>
<li class="L1099" rel="L1099">extraordinary tight-fitting fashion, and to have on her head a most</li>
<li class="L1100" rel="L1100">wonderful bonnet like a Grenadier wooden measure, and good measure too,</li>
<li class="L1101" rel="L1101">or a great Stilton cheese, came running into the room in advance of the</li>
<li class="L1102" rel="L1102">inn servants, and soon settled the question of his detachment from the</li>
<li class="L1103" rel="L1103">poor young lady, by laying a brawny hand upon his chest, and sending him</li>
<li class="L1104" rel="L1104">flying back against the nearest wall.</li>
<li class="L1105" rel="L1105"></li>
<li class="L1106" rel="L1106">(“I really think this must be a man!” was Mr. Lorry&#39;s breathless</li>
<li class="L1107" rel="L1107">reflection, simultaneously with his coming against the wall.)</li>
<li class="L1108" rel="L1108"></li>
<li class="L1109" rel="L1109">“Why, look at you all!” bawled this figure, addressing the inn servants.</li>
<li class="L1110" rel="L1110">“Why don&#39;t you go and fetch things, instead of standing there staring</li>
<li class="L1111" rel="L1111">at me? I am not so much to look at, am I? Why don&#39;t you go and fetch</li>
<li class="L1112" rel="L1112">things? I&#39;ll let you know, if you don&#39;t bring smelling-salts, cold</li>
<li class="L1113" rel="L1113">water, and vinegar, quick, I will.”</li>
<li class="L1114" rel="L1114"></li>
<li class="L1115" rel="L1115">There was an immediate dispersal for these restoratives, and she</li>
<li class="L1116" rel="L1116">softly laid the patient on a sofa, and tended her with great skill and</li>
<li class="L1117" rel="L1117">gentleness: calling her “my precious!” and “my bird!” and spreading her</li>
<li class="L1118" rel="L1118">golden hair aside over her shoulders with great pride and care.</li>
<li class="L1119" rel="L1119"></li>
<li class="L1120" rel="L1120">“And you in brown!” she said, indignantly turning to Mr. Lorry;</li>
<li class="L1121" rel="L1121">“couldn&#39;t you tell her what you had to tell her, without frightening her</li>
<li class="L1122" rel="L1122">to death? Look at her, with her pretty pale face and her cold hands. Do</li>
<li class="L1123" rel="L1123">you call _that_ being a Banker?”</li>
<li class="L1124" rel="L1124"></li>
<li class="L1125" rel="L1125">Mr. Lorry was so exceedingly disconcerted by a question so hard to</li>
<li class="L1126" rel="L1126">answer, that he could only look on, at a distance, with much feebler</li>
<li class="L1127" rel="L1127">sympathy and humility, while the strong woman, having banished the inn</li>
<li class="L1128" rel="L1128">servants under the mysterious penalty of “letting them know” something</li>
<li class="L1129" rel="L1129">not mentioned if they stayed there, staring, recovered her charge by a</li>
<li class="L1130" rel="L1130">regular series of gradations, and coaxed her to lay her drooping head</li>
<li class="L1131" rel="L1131">upon her shoulder.</li>
<li class="L1132" rel="L1132"></li>
<li class="L1133" rel="L1133">“I hope she will do well now,” said Mr. Lorry.</li>
<li class="L1134" rel="L1134"></li>
<li class="L1135" rel="L1135">“No thanks to you in brown, if she does. My darling pretty!”</li>
<li class="L1136" rel="L1136"></li>
<li class="L1137" rel="L1137">“I hope,” said Mr. Lorry, after another pause of feeble sympathy and</li>
<li class="L1138" rel="L1138">humility, “that you accompany Miss Manette to France?”</li>
<li class="L1139" rel="L1139"></li>
<li class="L1140" rel="L1140">“A likely thing, too!” replied the strong woman. “If it was ever</li>
<li class="L1141" rel="L1141">intended that I should go across salt water, do you suppose Providence</li>
<li class="L1142" rel="L1142">would have cast my lot in an island?”</li>
<li class="L1143" rel="L1143"></li>
<li class="L1144" rel="L1144">This being another question hard to answer, Mr. Jarvis Lorry withdrew to</li>
<li class="L1145" rel="L1145">consider it.</li>
<li class="L1146" rel="L1146"></li>
<li class="L1147" rel="L1147"></li>
<li class="L1148" rel="L1148"></li>
<li class="L1149" rel="L1149"></li>
<li class="L1150" rel="L1150">V. The Wine-shop</li>
<li class="L1151" rel="L1151"></li>
<li class="L1152" rel="L1152"></li>
<li class="L1153" rel="L1153">A large cask of wine had been dropped and broken, in the street. The</li>
<li class="L1154" rel="L1154">accident had happened in getting it out of a cart; the cask had tumbled</li>
<li class="L1155" rel="L1155">out with a run, the hoops had burst, and it lay on the stones just</li>
<li class="L1156" rel="L1156">outside the door of the wine-shop, shattered like a walnut-shell.</li>
<li class="L1157" rel="L1157"></li>
<li class="L1158" rel="L1158">All the people within reach had suspended their business, or their</li>
<li class="L1159" rel="L1159">idleness, to run to the spot and drink the wine. The rough, irregular</li>
<li class="L1160" rel="L1160">stones of the street, pointing every way, and designed, one might have</li>
<li class="L1161" rel="L1161">thought, expressly to lame all living creatures that approached them,</li>
<li class="L1162" rel="L1162">had dammed it into little pools; these were surrounded, each by its own</li>
<li class="L1163" rel="L1163">jostling group or crowd, according to its size. Some men kneeled down,</li>
<li class="L1164" rel="L1164">made scoops of their two hands joined, and sipped, or tried to help</li>
<li class="L1165" rel="L1165">women, who bent over their shoulders, to sip, before the wine had all</li>
<li class="L1166" rel="L1166">run out between their fingers. Others, men and women, dipped in</li>
<li class="L1167" rel="L1167">the puddles with little mugs of mutilated earthenware, or even with</li>
<li class="L1168" rel="L1168">handkerchiefs from women&#39;s heads, which were squeezed dry into infants&#39;</li>
<li class="L1169" rel="L1169">mouths; others made small mud-embankments, to stem the wine as it ran;</li>
<li class="L1170" rel="L1170">others, directed by lookers-on up at high windows, darted here and</li>
<li class="L1171" rel="L1171">there, to cut off little streams of wine that started away in new</li>
<li class="L1172" rel="L1172">directions; others devoted themselves to the sodden and lee-dyed</li>
<li class="L1173" rel="L1173">pieces of the cask, licking, and even champing the moister wine-rotted</li>
<li class="L1174" rel="L1174">fragments with eager relish. There was no drainage to carry off the</li>
<li class="L1175" rel="L1175">wine, and not only did it all get taken up, but so much mud got taken up</li>
<li class="L1176" rel="L1176">along with it, that there might have been a scavenger in the street,</li>
<li class="L1177" rel="L1177">if anybody acquainted with it could have believed in such a miraculous</li>
<li class="L1178" rel="L1178">presence.</li>
<li class="L1179" rel="L1179"></li>
<li class="L1180" rel="L1180">A shrill sound of laughter and of amused voices--voices of men, women,</li>
<li class="L1181" rel="L1181">and children--resounded in the street while this wine game lasted. There</li>
<li class="L1182" rel="L1182">was little roughness in the sport, and much playfulness. There was a</li>
<li class="L1183" rel="L1183">special companionship in it, an observable inclination on the part</li>
<li class="L1184" rel="L1184">of every one to join some other one, which led, especially among the</li>
<li class="L1185" rel="L1185">luckier or lighter-hearted, to frolicsome embraces, drinking of healths,</li>
<li class="L1186" rel="L1186">shaking of hands, and even joining of hands and dancing, a dozen</li>
<li class="L1187" rel="L1187">together. When the wine was gone, and the places where it had been</li>
<li class="L1188" rel="L1188">most abundant were raked into a gridiron-pattern by fingers, these</li>
<li class="L1189" rel="L1189">demonstrations ceased, as suddenly as they had broken out. The man who</li>
<li class="L1190" rel="L1190">had left his saw sticking in the firewood he was cutting, set it in</li>
<li class="L1191" rel="L1191">motion again; the women who had left on a door-step the little pot of</li>
<li class="L1192" rel="L1192">hot ashes, at which she had been trying to soften the pain in her own</li>
<li class="L1193" rel="L1193">starved fingers and toes, or in those of her child, returned to it; men</li>
<li class="L1194" rel="L1194">with bare arms, matted locks, and cadaverous faces, who had emerged into</li>
<li class="L1195" rel="L1195">the winter light from cellars, moved away, to descend again; and a gloom</li>
<li class="L1196" rel="L1196">gathered on the scene that appeared more natural to it than sunshine.</li>
<li class="L1197" rel="L1197"></li>
<li class="L1198" rel="L1198">The wine was red wine, and had stained the ground of the narrow street</li>
<li class="L1199" rel="L1199">in the suburb of Saint Antoine, in Paris, where it was spilled. It had</li>
<li class="L1200" rel="L1200">stained many hands, too, and many faces, and many naked feet, and many</li>
<li class="L1201" rel="L1201">wooden shoes. The hands of the man who sawed the wood, left red marks</li>
<li class="L1202" rel="L1202">on the billets; and the forehead of the woman who nursed her baby, was</li>
<li class="L1203" rel="L1203">stained with the stain of the old rag she wound about her head again.</li>
<li class="L1204" rel="L1204">Those who had been greedy with the staves of the cask, had acquired a</li>
<li class="L1205" rel="L1205">tigerish smear about the mouth; and one tall joker so besmirched, his</li>
<li class="L1206" rel="L1206">head more out of a long squalid bag of a nightcap than in it, scrawled</li>
<li class="L1207" rel="L1207">upon a wall with his finger dipped in muddy wine-lees--BLOOD.</li>
<li class="L1208" rel="L1208"></li>
<li class="L1209" rel="L1209">The time was to come, when that wine too would be spilled on the</li>
<li class="L1210" rel="L1210">street-stones, and when the stain of it would be red upon many there.</li>
<li class="L1211" rel="L1211"></li>
<li class="L1212" rel="L1212">And now that the cloud settled on Saint Antoine, which a momentary</li>
<li class="L1213" rel="L1213">gleam had driven from his sacred countenance, the darkness of it was</li>
<li class="L1214" rel="L1214">heavy--cold, dirt, sickness, ignorance, and want, were the lords in</li>
<li class="L1215" rel="L1215">waiting on the saintly presence--nobles of great power all of them;</li>
<li class="L1216" rel="L1216">but, most especially the last. Samples of a people that had undergone a</li>
<li class="L1217" rel="L1217">terrible grinding and regrinding in the mill, and certainly not in the</li>
<li class="L1218" rel="L1218">fabulous mill which ground old people young, shivered at every corner,</li>
<li class="L1219" rel="L1219">passed in and out at every doorway, looked from every window, fluttered</li>
<li class="L1220" rel="L1220">in every vestige of a garment that the wind shook. The mill which</li>
<li class="L1221" rel="L1221">had worked them down, was the mill that grinds young people old; the</li>
<li class="L1222" rel="L1222">children had ancient faces and grave voices; and upon them, and upon the</li>
<li class="L1223" rel="L1223">grown faces, and ploughed into every furrow of age and coming up afresh,</li>
<li class="L1224" rel="L1224">was the sigh, Hunger. It was prevalent everywhere. Hunger was pushed out</li>
<li class="L1225" rel="L1225">of the tall houses, in the wretched clothing that hung upon poles and</li>
<li class="L1226" rel="L1226">lines; Hunger was patched into them with straw and rag and wood and</li>
<li class="L1227" rel="L1227">paper; Hunger was repeated in every fragment of the small modicum of</li>
<li class="L1228" rel="L1228">firewood that the man sawed off; Hunger stared down from the smokeless</li>
<li class="L1229" rel="L1229">chimneys, and started up from the filthy street that had no offal,</li>
<li class="L1230" rel="L1230">among its refuse, of anything to eat. Hunger was the inscription on the</li>
<li class="L1231" rel="L1231">baker&#39;s shelves, written in every small loaf of his scanty stock of</li>
<li class="L1232" rel="L1232">bad bread; at the sausage-shop, in every dead-dog preparation that</li>
<li class="L1233" rel="L1233">was offered for sale. Hunger rattled its dry bones among the roasting</li>
<li class="L1234" rel="L1234">chestnuts in the turned cylinder; Hunger was shred into atomics in every</li>
<li class="L1235" rel="L1235">farthing porringer of husky chips of potato, fried with some reluctant</li>
<li class="L1236" rel="L1236">drops of oil.</li>
<li class="L1237" rel="L1237"></li>
<li class="L1238" rel="L1238">Its abiding place was in all things fitted to it. A narrow winding</li>
<li class="L1239" rel="L1239">street, full of offence and stench, with other narrow winding streets</li>
<li class="L1240" rel="L1240">diverging, all peopled by rags and nightcaps, and all smelling of rags</li>
<li class="L1241" rel="L1241">and nightcaps, and all visible things with a brooding look upon them</li>
<li class="L1242" rel="L1242">that looked ill. In the hunted air of the people there was yet some</li>
<li class="L1243" rel="L1243">wild-beast thought of the possibility of turning at bay. Depressed and</li>
<li class="L1244" rel="L1244">slinking though they were, eyes of fire were not wanting among them; nor</li>
<li class="L1245" rel="L1245">compressed lips, white with what they suppressed; nor foreheads knitted</li>
<li class="L1246" rel="L1246">into the likeness of the gallows-rope they mused about enduring, or</li>
<li class="L1247" rel="L1247">inflicting. The trade signs (and they were almost as many as the shops)</li>
<li class="L1248" rel="L1248">were, all, grim illustrations of Want. The butcher and the porkman</li>
<li class="L1249" rel="L1249">painted up, only the leanest scrags of meat; the baker, the coarsest of</li>
<li class="L1250" rel="L1250">meagre loaves. The people rudely pictured as drinking in the wine-shops,</li>
<li class="L1251" rel="L1251">croaked over their scanty measures of thin wine and beer, and were</li>
<li class="L1252" rel="L1252">gloweringly confidential together. Nothing was represented in a</li>
<li class="L1253" rel="L1253">flourishing condition, save tools and weapons; but, the cutler&#39;s knives</li>
<li class="L1254" rel="L1254">and axes were sharp and bright, the smith&#39;s hammers were heavy, and the</li>
<li class="L1255" rel="L1255">gunmaker&#39;s stock was murderous. The crippling stones of the pavement,</li>
<li class="L1256" rel="L1256">with their many little reservoirs of mud and water, had no footways, but</li>
<li class="L1257" rel="L1257">broke off abruptly at the doors. The kennel, to make amends, ran down</li>
<li class="L1258" rel="L1258">the middle of the street--when it ran at all: which was only after heavy</li>
<li class="L1259" rel="L1259">rains, and then it ran, by many eccentric fits, into the houses. Across</li>
<li class="L1260" rel="L1260">the streets, at wide intervals, one clumsy lamp was slung by a rope and</li>
<li class="L1261" rel="L1261">pulley; at night, when the lamplighter had let these down, and lighted,</li>
<li class="L1262" rel="L1262">and hoisted them again, a feeble grove of dim wicks swung in a sickly</li>
<li class="L1263" rel="L1263">manner overhead, as if they were at sea. Indeed they were at sea, and</li>
<li class="L1264" rel="L1264">the ship and crew were in peril of tempest.</li>
<li class="L1265" rel="L1265"></li>
<li class="L1266" rel="L1266">For, the time was to come, when the gaunt scarecrows of that region</li>
<li class="L1267" rel="L1267">should have watched the lamplighter, in their idleness and hunger, so</li>
<li class="L1268" rel="L1268">long, as to conceive the idea of improving on his method, and hauling</li>
<li class="L1269" rel="L1269">up men by those ropes and pulleys, to flare upon the darkness of their</li>
<li class="L1270" rel="L1270">condition. But, the time was not come yet; and every wind that blew over</li>
<li class="L1271" rel="L1271">France shook the rags of the scarecrows in vain, for the birds, fine of</li>
<li class="L1272" rel="L1272">song and feather, took no warning.</li>
<li class="L1273" rel="L1273"></li>
<li class="L1274" rel="L1274">The wine-shop was a corner shop, better than most others in its</li>
<li class="L1275" rel="L1275">appearance and degree, and the master of the wine-shop had stood outside</li>
<li class="L1276" rel="L1276">it, in a yellow waistcoat and green breeches, looking on at the struggle</li>
<li class="L1277" rel="L1277">for the lost wine. “It&#39;s not my affair,” said he, with a final shrug</li>
<li class="L1278" rel="L1278">of the shoulders. “The people from the market did it. Let them bring</li>
<li class="L1279" rel="L1279">another.”</li>
<li class="L1280" rel="L1280"></li>
<li class="L1281" rel="L1281">There, his eyes happening to catch the tall joker writing up his joke,</li>
<li class="L1282" rel="L1282">he called to him across the way:</li>
<li class="L1283" rel="L1283"></li>
<li class="L1284" rel="L1284">“Say, then, my Gaspard, what do you do there?”</li>
<li class="L1285" rel="L1285"></li>
<li class="L1286" rel="L1286">The fellow pointed to his joke with immense significance, as is often</li>
<li class="L1287" rel="L1287">the way with his tribe. It missed its mark, and completely failed, as is</li>
<li class="L1288" rel="L1288">often the way with his tribe too.</li>
<li class="L1289" rel="L1289"></li>
<li class="L1290" rel="L1290">“What now? Are you a subject for the mad hospital?” said the wine-shop</li>
<li class="L1291" rel="L1291">keeper, crossing the road, and obliterating the jest with a handful of</li>
<li class="L1292" rel="L1292">mud, picked up for the purpose, and smeared over it. “Why do you write</li>
<li class="L1293" rel="L1293">in the public streets? Is there--tell me thou--is there no other place</li>
<li class="L1294" rel="L1294">to write such words in?”</li>
<li class="L1295" rel="L1295"></li>
<li class="L1296" rel="L1296">In his expostulation he dropped his cleaner hand (perhaps accidentally,</li>
<li class="L1297" rel="L1297">perhaps not) upon the joker&#39;s heart. The joker rapped it with his</li>
<li class="L1298" rel="L1298">own, took a nimble spring upward, and came down in a fantastic dancing</li>
<li class="L1299" rel="L1299">attitude, with one of his stained shoes jerked off his foot into his</li>
<li class="L1300" rel="L1300">hand, and held out. A joker of an extremely, not to say wolfishly</li>
<li class="L1301" rel="L1301">practical character, he looked, under those circumstances.</li>
<li class="L1302" rel="L1302"></li>
<li class="L1303" rel="L1303">“Put it on, put it on,” said the other. “Call wine, wine; and finish</li>
<li class="L1304" rel="L1304">there.” With that advice, he wiped his soiled hand upon the joker&#39;s</li>
<li class="L1305" rel="L1305">dress, such as it was--quite deliberately, as having dirtied the hand on</li>
<li class="L1306" rel="L1306">his account; and then recrossed the road and entered the wine-shop.</li>
<li class="L1307" rel="L1307"></li>
<li class="L1308" rel="L1308">This wine-shop keeper was a bull-necked, martial-looking man of thirty,</li>
<li class="L1309" rel="L1309">and he should have been of a hot temperament, for, although it was a</li>
<li class="L1310" rel="L1310">bitter day, he wore no coat, but carried one slung over his shoulder.</li>
<li class="L1311" rel="L1311">His shirt-sleeves were rolled up, too, and his brown arms were bare to</li>
<li class="L1312" rel="L1312">the elbows. Neither did he wear anything more on his head than his own</li>
<li class="L1313" rel="L1313">crisply-curling short dark hair. He was a dark man altogether, with good</li>
<li class="L1314" rel="L1314">eyes and a good bold breadth between them. Good-humoured looking on</li>
<li class="L1315" rel="L1315">the whole, but implacable-looking, too; evidently a man of a strong</li>
<li class="L1316" rel="L1316">resolution and a set purpose; a man not desirable to be met, rushing</li>
<li class="L1317" rel="L1317">down a narrow pass with a gulf on either side, for nothing would turn</li>
<li class="L1318" rel="L1318">the man.</li>
<li class="L1319" rel="L1319"></li>
<li class="L1320" rel="L1320">Madame Defarge, his wife, sat in the shop behind the counter as he</li>
<li class="L1321" rel="L1321">came in. Madame Defarge was a stout woman of about his own age, with</li>
<li class="L1322" rel="L1322">a watchful eye that seldom seemed to look at anything, a large hand</li>
<li class="L1323" rel="L1323">heavily ringed, a steady face, strong features, and great composure of</li>
<li class="L1324" rel="L1324">manner. There was a character about Madame Defarge, from which one might</li>
<li class="L1325" rel="L1325">have predicated that she did not often make mistakes against herself</li>
<li class="L1326" rel="L1326">in any of the reckonings over which she presided. Madame Defarge being</li>
<li class="L1327" rel="L1327">sensitive to cold, was wrapped in fur, and had a quantity of bright</li>
<li class="L1328" rel="L1328">shawl twined about her head, though not to the concealment of her large</li>
<li class="L1329" rel="L1329">earrings. Her knitting was before her, but she had laid it down to pick</li>
<li class="L1330" rel="L1330">her teeth with a toothpick. Thus engaged, with her right elbow supported</li>
<li class="L1331" rel="L1331">by her left hand, Madame Defarge said nothing when her lord came in, but</li>
<li class="L1332" rel="L1332">coughed just one grain of cough. This, in combination with the lifting</li>
<li class="L1333" rel="L1333">of her darkly defined eyebrows over her toothpick by the breadth of a</li>
<li class="L1334" rel="L1334">line, suggested to her husband that he would do well to look round the</li>
<li class="L1335" rel="L1335">shop among the customers, for any new customer who had dropped in while</li>
<li class="L1336" rel="L1336">he stepped over the way.</li>
<li class="L1337" rel="L1337"></li>
<li class="L1338" rel="L1338">The wine-shop keeper accordingly rolled his eyes about, until they</li>
<li class="L1339" rel="L1339">rested upon an elderly gentleman and a young lady, who were seated in</li>
<li class="L1340" rel="L1340">a corner. Other company were there: two playing cards, two playing</li>
<li class="L1341" rel="L1341">dominoes, three standing by the counter lengthening out a short supply</li>
<li class="L1342" rel="L1342">of wine. As he passed behind the counter, he took notice that the</li>
<li class="L1343" rel="L1343">elderly gentleman said in a look to the young lady, “This is our man.”</li>
<li class="L1344" rel="L1344"></li>
<li class="L1345" rel="L1345">“What the devil do _you_ do in that galley there?” said Monsieur Defarge</li>
<li class="L1346" rel="L1346">to himself; “I don&#39;t know you.”</li>
<li class="L1347" rel="L1347"></li>
<li class="L1348" rel="L1348">But, he feigned not to notice the two strangers, and fell into discourse</li>
<li class="L1349" rel="L1349">with the triumvirate of customers who were drinking at the counter.</li>
<li class="L1350" rel="L1350"></li>
<li class="L1351" rel="L1351">“How goes it, Jacques?” said one of these three to Monsieur Defarge. “Is</li>
<li class="L1352" rel="L1352">all the spilt wine swallowed?”</li>
<li class="L1353" rel="L1353"></li>
<li class="L1354" rel="L1354">“Every drop, Jacques,” answered Monsieur Defarge.</li>
<li class="L1355" rel="L1355"></li>
<li class="L1356" rel="L1356">When this interchange of Christian name was effected, Madame Defarge,</li>
<li class="L1357" rel="L1357">picking her teeth with her toothpick, coughed another grain of cough,</li>
<li class="L1358" rel="L1358">and raised her eyebrows by the breadth of another line.</li>
<li class="L1359" rel="L1359"></li>
<li class="L1360" rel="L1360">“It is not often,” said the second of the three, addressing Monsieur</li>
<li class="L1361" rel="L1361">Defarge, “that many of these miserable beasts know the taste of wine, or</li>
<li class="L1362" rel="L1362">of anything but black bread and death. Is it not so, Jacques?”</li>
<li class="L1363" rel="L1363"></li>
<li class="L1364" rel="L1364">“It is so, Jacques,” Monsieur Defarge returned.</li>
<li class="L1365" rel="L1365"></li>
<li class="L1366" rel="L1366">At this second interchange of the Christian name, Madame Defarge, still</li>
<li class="L1367" rel="L1367">using her toothpick with profound composure, coughed another grain of</li>
<li class="L1368" rel="L1368">cough, and raised her eyebrows by the breadth of another line.</li>
<li class="L1369" rel="L1369"></li>
<li class="L1370" rel="L1370">The last of the three now said his say, as he put down his empty</li>
<li class="L1371" rel="L1371">drinking vessel and smacked his lips.</li>
<li class="L1372" rel="L1372"></li>
<li class="L1373" rel="L1373">“Ah! So much the worse! A bitter taste it is that such poor cattle</li>
<li class="L1374" rel="L1374">always have in their mouths, and hard lives they live, Jacques. Am I</li>
<li class="L1375" rel="L1375">right, Jacques?”</li>
<li class="L1376" rel="L1376"></li>
<li class="L1377" rel="L1377">“You are right, Jacques,” was the response of Monsieur Defarge.</li>
<li class="L1378" rel="L1378"></li>
<li class="L1379" rel="L1379">This third interchange of the Christian name was completed at the moment</li>
<li class="L1380" rel="L1380">when Madame Defarge put her toothpick by, kept her eyebrows up, and</li>
<li class="L1381" rel="L1381">slightly rustled in her seat.</li>
<li class="L1382" rel="L1382"></li>
<li class="L1383" rel="L1383">“Hold then! True!” muttered her husband. “Gentlemen--my wife!”</li>
<li class="L1384" rel="L1384"></li>
<li class="L1385" rel="L1385">The three customers pulled off their hats to Madame Defarge, with three</li>
<li class="L1386" rel="L1386">flourishes. She acknowledged their homage by bending her head, and</li>
<li class="L1387" rel="L1387">giving them a quick look. Then she glanced in a casual manner round the</li>
<li class="L1388" rel="L1388">wine-shop, took up her knitting with great apparent calmness and repose</li>
<li class="L1389" rel="L1389">of spirit, and became absorbed in it.</li>
<li class="L1390" rel="L1390"></li>
<li class="L1391" rel="L1391">“Gentlemen,” said her husband, who had kept his bright eye observantly</li>
<li class="L1392" rel="L1392">upon her, “good day. The chamber, furnished bachelor-fashion, that you</li>
<li class="L1393" rel="L1393">wished to see, and were inquiring for when I stepped out, is on the</li>
<li class="L1394" rel="L1394">fifth floor. The doorway of the staircase gives on the little courtyard</li>
<li class="L1395" rel="L1395">close to the left here,” pointing with his hand, “near to the window of</li>
<li class="L1396" rel="L1396">my establishment. But, now that I remember, one of you has already been</li>
<li class="L1397" rel="L1397">there, and can show the way. Gentlemen, adieu!”</li>
<li class="L1398" rel="L1398"></li>
<li class="L1399" rel="L1399">They paid for their wine, and left the place. The eyes of Monsieur</li>
<li class="L1400" rel="L1400">Defarge were studying his wife at her knitting when the elderly</li>
<li class="L1401" rel="L1401">gentleman advanced from his corner, and begged the favour of a word.</li>
<li class="L1402" rel="L1402"></li>
<li class="L1403" rel="L1403">“Willingly, sir,” said Monsieur Defarge, and quietly stepped with him to</li>
<li class="L1404" rel="L1404">the door.</li>
<li class="L1405" rel="L1405"></li>
<li class="L1406" rel="L1406">Their conference was very short, but very decided. Almost at the first</li>
<li class="L1407" rel="L1407">word, Monsieur Defarge started and became deeply attentive. It had</li>
<li class="L1408" rel="L1408">not lasted a minute, when he nodded and went out. The gentleman then</li>
<li class="L1409" rel="L1409">beckoned to the young lady, and they, too, went out. Madame Defarge</li>
<li class="L1410" rel="L1410">knitted with nimble fingers and steady eyebrows, and saw nothing.</li>
<li class="L1411" rel="L1411"></li>
<li class="L1412" rel="L1412">Mr. Jarvis Lorry and Miss Manette, emerging from the wine-shop thus,</li>
<li class="L1413" rel="L1413">joined Monsieur Defarge in the doorway to which he had directed his own</li>
<li class="L1414" rel="L1414">company just before. It opened from a stinking little black courtyard,</li>
<li class="L1415" rel="L1415">and was the general public entrance to a great pile of houses, inhabited</li>
<li class="L1416" rel="L1416">by a great number of people. In the gloomy tile-paved entry to the</li>
<li class="L1417" rel="L1417">gloomy tile-paved staircase, Monsieur Defarge bent down on one knee</li>
<li class="L1418" rel="L1418">to the child of his old master, and put her hand to his lips. It was</li>
<li class="L1419" rel="L1419">a gentle action, but not at all gently done; a very remarkable</li>
<li class="L1420" rel="L1420">transformation had come over him in a few seconds. He had no good-humour</li>
<li class="L1421" rel="L1421">in his face, nor any openness of aspect left, but had become a secret,</li>
<li class="L1422" rel="L1422">angry, dangerous man.</li>
<li class="L1423" rel="L1423"></li>
<li class="L1424" rel="L1424">“It is very high; it is a little difficult. Better to begin slowly.”</li>
<li class="L1425" rel="L1425"> Thus, Monsieur Defarge, in a stern voice, to Mr. Lorry, as they began</li>
<li class="L1426" rel="L1426">ascending the stairs.</li>
<li class="L1427" rel="L1427"></li>
<li class="L1428" rel="L1428">“Is he alone?” the latter whispered.</li>
<li class="L1429" rel="L1429"></li>
<li class="L1430" rel="L1430">“Alone! God help him, who should be with him!” said the other, in the</li>
<li class="L1431" rel="L1431">same low voice.</li>
<li class="L1432" rel="L1432"></li>
<li class="L1433" rel="L1433">“Is he always alone, then?”</li>
<li class="L1434" rel="L1434"></li>
<li class="L1435" rel="L1435">“Yes.”</li>
<li class="L1436" rel="L1436"></li>
<li class="L1437" rel="L1437">“Of his own desire?”</li>
<li class="L1438" rel="L1438"></li>
<li class="L1439" rel="L1439">“Of his own necessity. As he was, when I first saw him after they</li>
<li class="L1440" rel="L1440">found me and demanded to know if I would take him, and, at my peril be</li>
<li class="L1441" rel="L1441">discreet--as he was then, so he is now.”</li>
<li class="L1442" rel="L1442"></li>
<li class="L1443" rel="L1443">“He is greatly changed?”</li>
<li class="L1444" rel="L1444"></li>
<li class="L1445" rel="L1445">“Changed!”</li>
<li class="L1446" rel="L1446"></li>
<li class="L1447" rel="L1447">The keeper of the wine-shop stopped to strike the wall with his hand,</li>
<li class="L1448" rel="L1448">and mutter a tremendous curse. No direct answer could have been half so</li>
<li class="L1449" rel="L1449">forcible. Mr. Lorry&#39;s spirits grew heavier and heavier, as he and his</li>
<li class="L1450" rel="L1450">two companions ascended higher and higher.</li>
<li class="L1451" rel="L1451"></li>
<li class="L1452" rel="L1452">Such a staircase, with its accessories, in the older and more crowded</li>
<li class="L1453" rel="L1453">parts of Paris, would be bad enough now; but, at that time, it was vile</li>
<li class="L1454" rel="L1454">indeed to unaccustomed and unhardened senses. Every little habitation</li>
<li class="L1455" rel="L1455">within the great foul nest of one high building--that is to say,</li>
<li class="L1456" rel="L1456">the room or rooms within every door that opened on the general</li>
<li class="L1457" rel="L1457">staircase--left its own heap of refuse on its own landing, besides</li>
<li class="L1458" rel="L1458">flinging other refuse from its own windows. The uncontrollable and</li>
<li class="L1459" rel="L1459">hopeless mass of decomposition so engendered, would have polluted</li>
<li class="L1460" rel="L1460">the air, even if poverty and deprivation had not loaded it with their</li>
<li class="L1461" rel="L1461">intangible impurities; the two bad sources combined made it almost</li>
<li class="L1462" rel="L1462">insupportable. Through such an atmosphere, by a steep dark shaft of dirt</li>
<li class="L1463" rel="L1463">and poison, the way lay. Yielding to his own disturbance of mind, and to</li>
<li class="L1464" rel="L1464">his young companion&#39;s agitation, which became greater every instant, Mr.</li>
<li class="L1465" rel="L1465">Jarvis Lorry twice stopped to rest. Each of these stoppages was made</li>
<li class="L1466" rel="L1466">at a doleful grating, by which any languishing good airs that were left</li>
<li class="L1467" rel="L1467">uncorrupted, seemed to escape, and all spoilt and sickly vapours seemed</li>
<li class="L1468" rel="L1468">to crawl in. Through the rusted bars, tastes, rather than glimpses, were</li>
<li class="L1469" rel="L1469">caught of the jumbled neighbourhood; and nothing within range, nearer</li>
<li class="L1470" rel="L1470">or lower than the summits of the two great towers of Notre-Dame, had any</li>
<li class="L1471" rel="L1471">promise on it of healthy life or wholesome aspirations.</li>
<li class="L1472" rel="L1472"></li>
<li class="L1473" rel="L1473">At last, the top of the staircase was gained, and they stopped for the</li>
<li class="L1474" rel="L1474">third time. There was yet an upper staircase, of a steeper inclination</li>
<li class="L1475" rel="L1475">and of contracted dimensions, to be ascended, before the garret story</li>
<li class="L1476" rel="L1476">was reached. The keeper of the wine-shop, always going a little in</li>
<li class="L1477" rel="L1477">advance, and always going on the side which Mr. Lorry took, as though he</li>
<li class="L1478" rel="L1478">dreaded to be asked any question by the young lady, turned himself about</li>
<li class="L1479" rel="L1479">here, and, carefully feeling in the pockets of the coat he carried over</li>
<li class="L1480" rel="L1480">his shoulder, took out a key.</li>
<li class="L1481" rel="L1481"></li>
<li class="L1482" rel="L1482">“The door is locked then, my friend?” said Mr. Lorry, surprised.</li>
<li class="L1483" rel="L1483"></li>
<li class="L1484" rel="L1484">“Ay. Yes,” was the grim reply of Monsieur Defarge.</li>
<li class="L1485" rel="L1485"></li>
<li class="L1486" rel="L1486">“You think it necessary to keep the unfortunate gentleman so retired?”</li>
<li class="L1487" rel="L1487"></li>
<li class="L1488" rel="L1488">“I think it necessary to turn the key.” Monsieur Defarge whispered it</li>
<li class="L1489" rel="L1489">closer in his ear, and frowned heavily.</li>
<li class="L1490" rel="L1490"></li>
<li class="L1491" rel="L1491">“Why?”</li>
<li class="L1492" rel="L1492"></li>
<li class="L1493" rel="L1493">“Why! Because he has lived so long, locked up, that he would be</li>
<li class="L1494" rel="L1494">frightened--rave--tear himself to pieces--die--come to I know not what</li>
<li class="L1495" rel="L1495">harm--if his door was left open.”</li>
<li class="L1496" rel="L1496"></li>
<li class="L1497" rel="L1497">“Is it possible!” exclaimed Mr. Lorry.</li>
<li class="L1498" rel="L1498"></li>
<li class="L1499" rel="L1499">“Is it possible!” repeated Defarge, bitterly. “Yes. And a beautiful</li>
<li class="L1500" rel="L1500">world we live in, when it _is_ possible, and when many other such things</li>
<li class="L1501" rel="L1501">are possible, and not only possible, but done--done, see you!--under</li>
<li class="L1502" rel="L1502">that sky there, every day. Long live the Devil. Let us go on.”</li>
<li class="L1503" rel="L1503"></li>
<li class="L1504" rel="L1504">This dialogue had been held in so very low a whisper, that not a word</li>
<li class="L1505" rel="L1505">of it had reached the young lady&#39;s ears. But, by this time she trembled</li>
<li class="L1506" rel="L1506">under such strong emotion, and her face expressed such deep anxiety,</li>
<li class="L1507" rel="L1507">and, above all, such dread and terror, that Mr. Lorry felt it incumbent</li>
<li class="L1508" rel="L1508">on him to speak a word or two of reassurance.</li>
<li class="L1509" rel="L1509"></li>
<li class="L1510" rel="L1510">“Courage, dear miss! Courage! Business! The worst will be over in a</li>
<li class="L1511" rel="L1511">moment; it is but passing the room-door, and the worst is over. Then,</li>
<li class="L1512" rel="L1512">all the good you bring to him, all the relief, all the happiness you</li>
<li class="L1513" rel="L1513">bring to him, begin. Let our good friend here, assist you on that side.</li>
<li class="L1514" rel="L1514">That&#39;s well, friend Defarge. Come, now. Business, business!”</li>
<li class="L1515" rel="L1515"></li>
<li class="L1516" rel="L1516">They went up slowly and softly. The staircase was short, and they were</li>
<li class="L1517" rel="L1517">soon at the top. There, as it had an abrupt turn in it, they came all at</li>
<li class="L1518" rel="L1518">once in sight of three men, whose heads were bent down close together at</li>
<li class="L1519" rel="L1519">the side of a door, and who were intently looking into the room to which</li>
<li class="L1520" rel="L1520">the door belonged, through some chinks or holes in the wall. On hearing</li>
<li class="L1521" rel="L1521">footsteps close at hand, these three turned, and rose, and showed</li>
<li class="L1522" rel="L1522">themselves to be the three of one name who had been drinking in the</li>
<li class="L1523" rel="L1523">wine-shop.</li>
<li class="L1524" rel="L1524"></li>
<li class="L1525" rel="L1525">“I forgot them in the surprise of your visit,” explained Monsieur</li>
<li class="L1526" rel="L1526">Defarge. “Leave us, good boys; we have business here.”</li>
<li class="L1527" rel="L1527"></li>
<li class="L1528" rel="L1528">The three glided by, and went silently down.</li>
<li class="L1529" rel="L1529"></li>
<li class="L1530" rel="L1530">There appearing to be no other door on that floor, and the keeper of</li>
<li class="L1531" rel="L1531">the wine-shop going straight to this one when they were left alone, Mr.</li>
<li class="L1532" rel="L1532">Lorry asked him in a whisper, with a little anger:</li>
<li class="L1533" rel="L1533"></li>
<li class="L1534" rel="L1534">“Do you make a show of Monsieur Manette?”</li>
<li class="L1535" rel="L1535"></li>
<li class="L1536" rel="L1536">“I show him, in the way you have seen, to a chosen few.”</li>
<li class="L1537" rel="L1537"></li>
<li class="L1538" rel="L1538">“Is that well?”</li>
<li class="L1539" rel="L1539"></li>
<li class="L1540" rel="L1540">“_I_ think it is well.”</li>
<li class="L1541" rel="L1541"></li>
<li class="L1542" rel="L1542">“Who are the few? How do you choose them?”</li>
<li class="L1543" rel="L1543"></li>
<li class="L1544" rel="L1544">“I choose them as real men, of my name--Jacques is my name--to whom the</li>
<li class="L1545" rel="L1545">sight is likely to do good. Enough; you are English; that is another</li>
<li class="L1546" rel="L1546">thing. Stay there, if you please, a little moment.”</li>
<li class="L1547" rel="L1547"></li>
<li class="L1548" rel="L1548">With an admonitory gesture to keep them back, he stooped, and looked in</li>
<li class="L1549" rel="L1549">through the crevice in the wall. Soon raising his head again, he struck</li>
<li class="L1550" rel="L1550">twice or thrice upon the door--evidently with no other object than to</li>
<li class="L1551" rel="L1551">make a noise there. With the same intention, he drew the key across it,</li>
<li class="L1552" rel="L1552">three or four times, before he put it clumsily into the lock, and turned</li>
<li class="L1553" rel="L1553">it as heavily as he could.</li>
<li class="L1554" rel="L1554"></li>
<li class="L1555" rel="L1555">The door slowly opened inward under his hand, and he looked into the</li>
<li class="L1556" rel="L1556">room and said something. A faint voice answered something. Little more</li>
<li class="L1557" rel="L1557">than a single syllable could have been spoken on either side.</li>
<li class="L1558" rel="L1558"></li>
<li class="L1559" rel="L1559">He looked back over his shoulder, and beckoned them to enter. Mr. Lorry</li>
<li class="L1560" rel="L1560">got his arm securely round the daughter&#39;s waist, and held her; for he</li>
<li class="L1561" rel="L1561">felt that she was sinking.</li>
<li class="L1562" rel="L1562"></li>
<li class="L1563" rel="L1563">“A-a-a-business, business!” he urged, with a moisture that was not of</li>
<li class="L1564" rel="L1564">business shining on his cheek. “Come in, come in!”</li>
<li class="L1565" rel="L1565"></li>
<li class="L1566" rel="L1566">“I am afraid of it,” she answered, shuddering.</li>
<li class="L1567" rel="L1567"></li>
<li class="L1568" rel="L1568">“Of it? What?”</li>
<li class="L1569" rel="L1569"></li>
<li class="L1570" rel="L1570">“I mean of him. Of my father.”</li>
<li class="L1571" rel="L1571"></li>
<li class="L1572" rel="L1572">Rendered in a manner desperate, by her state and by the beckoning of</li>
<li class="L1573" rel="L1573">their conductor, he drew over his neck the arm that shook upon his</li>
<li class="L1574" rel="L1574">shoulder, lifted her a little, and hurried her into the room. He sat her</li>
<li class="L1575" rel="L1575">down just within the door, and held her, clinging to him.</li>
<li class="L1576" rel="L1576"></li>
<li class="L1577" rel="L1577">Defarge drew out the key, closed the door, locked it on the inside,</li>
<li class="L1578" rel="L1578">took out the key again, and held it in his hand. All this he did,</li>
<li class="L1579" rel="L1579">methodically, and with as loud and harsh an accompaniment of noise as he</li>
<li class="L1580" rel="L1580">could make. Finally, he walked across the room with a measured tread to</li>
<li class="L1581" rel="L1581">where the window was. He stopped there, and faced round.</li>
<li class="L1582" rel="L1582"></li>
<li class="L1583" rel="L1583">The garret, built to be a depository for firewood and the like, was dim</li>
<li class="L1584" rel="L1584">and dark: for, the window of dormer shape, was in truth a door in the</li>
<li class="L1585" rel="L1585">roof, with a little crane over it for the hoisting up of stores from</li>
<li class="L1586" rel="L1586">the street: unglazed, and closing up the middle in two pieces, like any</li>
<li class="L1587" rel="L1587">other door of French construction. To exclude the cold, one half of this</li>
<li class="L1588" rel="L1588">door was fast closed, and the other was opened but a very little way.</li>
<li class="L1589" rel="L1589">Such a scanty portion of light was admitted through these means, that it</li>
<li class="L1590" rel="L1590">was difficult, on first coming in, to see anything; and long habit</li>
<li class="L1591" rel="L1591">alone could have slowly formed in any one, the ability to do any work</li>
<li class="L1592" rel="L1592">requiring nicety in such obscurity. Yet, work of that kind was being</li>
<li class="L1593" rel="L1593">done in the garret; for, with his back towards the door, and his face</li>
<li class="L1594" rel="L1594">towards the window where the keeper of the wine-shop stood looking at</li>
<li class="L1595" rel="L1595">him, a white-haired man sat on a low bench, stooping forward and very</li>
<li class="L1596" rel="L1596">busy, making shoes.</li>
<li class="L1597" rel="L1597"></li>
<li class="L1598" rel="L1598"></li>
<li class="L1599" rel="L1599"></li>
<li class="L1600" rel="L1600"></li>
<li class="L1601" rel="L1601">VI. The Shoemaker</li>
<li class="L1602" rel="L1602"></li>
<li class="L1603" rel="L1603"></li>
<li class="L1604" rel="L1604">“Good day!” said Monsieur Defarge, looking down at the white head that</li>
<li class="L1605" rel="L1605">bent low over the shoemaking.</li>
<li class="L1606" rel="L1606"></li>
<li class="L1607" rel="L1607">It was raised for a moment, and a very faint voice responded to the</li>
<li class="L1608" rel="L1608">salutation, as if it were at a distance:</li>
<li class="L1609" rel="L1609"></li>
<li class="L1610" rel="L1610">“Good day!”</li>
<li class="L1611" rel="L1611"></li>
<li class="L1612" rel="L1612">“You are still hard at work, I see?”</li>
<li class="L1613" rel="L1613"></li>
<li class="L1614" rel="L1614">After a long silence, the head was lifted for another moment, and the</li>
<li class="L1615" rel="L1615">voice replied, “Yes--I am working.” This time, a pair of haggard eyes</li>
<li class="L1616" rel="L1616">had looked at the questioner, before the face had dropped again.</li>
<li class="L1617" rel="L1617"></li>
<li class="L1618" rel="L1618">The faintness of the voice was pitiable and dreadful. It was not the</li>
<li class="L1619" rel="L1619">faintness of physical weakness, though confinement and hard fare no</li>
<li class="L1620" rel="L1620">doubt had their part in it. Its deplorable peculiarity was, that it was</li>
<li class="L1621" rel="L1621">the faintness of solitude and disuse. It was like the last feeble echo</li>
<li class="L1622" rel="L1622">of a sound made long and long ago. So entirely had it lost the life and</li>
<li class="L1623" rel="L1623">resonance of the human voice, that it affected the senses like a once</li>
<li class="L1624" rel="L1624">beautiful colour faded away into a poor weak stain. So sunken and</li>
<li class="L1625" rel="L1625">suppressed it was, that it was like a voice underground. So expressive</li>
<li class="L1626" rel="L1626">it was, of a hopeless and lost creature, that a famished traveller,</li>
<li class="L1627" rel="L1627">wearied out by lonely wandering in a wilderness, would have remembered</li>
<li class="L1628" rel="L1628">home and friends in such a tone before lying down to die.</li>
<li class="L1629" rel="L1629"></li>
<li class="L1630" rel="L1630">Some minutes of silent work had passed: and the haggard eyes had looked</li>
<li class="L1631" rel="L1631">up again: not with any interest or curiosity, but with a dull mechanical</li>
<li class="L1632" rel="L1632">perception, beforehand, that the spot where the only visitor they were</li>
<li class="L1633" rel="L1633">aware of had stood, was not yet empty.</li>
<li class="L1634" rel="L1634"></li>
<li class="L1635" rel="L1635">“I want,” said Defarge, who had not removed his gaze from the shoemaker,</li>
<li class="L1636" rel="L1636">“to let in a little more light here. You can bear a little more?”</li>
<li class="L1637" rel="L1637"></li>
<li class="L1638" rel="L1638">The shoemaker stopped his work; looked with a vacant air of listening,</li>
<li class="L1639" rel="L1639">at the floor on one side of him; then similarly, at the floor on the</li>
<li class="L1640" rel="L1640">other side of him; then, upward at the speaker.</li>
<li class="L1641" rel="L1641"></li>
<li class="L1642" rel="L1642">“What did you say?”</li>
<li class="L1643" rel="L1643"></li>
<li class="L1644" rel="L1644">“You can bear a little more light?”</li>
<li class="L1645" rel="L1645"></li>
<li class="L1646" rel="L1646">“I must bear it, if you let it in.” (Laying the palest shadow of a</li>
<li class="L1647" rel="L1647">stress upon the second word.)</li>
<li class="L1648" rel="L1648"></li>
<li class="L1649" rel="L1649">The opened half-door was opened a little further, and secured at that</li>
<li class="L1650" rel="L1650">angle for the time. A broad ray of light fell into the garret, and</li>
<li class="L1651" rel="L1651">showed the workman with an unfinished shoe upon his lap, pausing in his</li>
<li class="L1652" rel="L1652">labour. His few common tools and various scraps of leather were at his</li>
<li class="L1653" rel="L1653">feet and on his bench. He had a white beard, raggedly cut, but not very</li>
<li class="L1654" rel="L1654">long, a hollow face, and exceedingly bright eyes. The hollowness and</li>
<li class="L1655" rel="L1655">thinness of his face would have caused them to look large, under his yet</li>
<li class="L1656" rel="L1656">dark eyebrows and his confused white hair, though they had been really</li>
<li class="L1657" rel="L1657">otherwise; but, they were naturally large, and looked unnaturally so.</li>
<li class="L1658" rel="L1658">His yellow rags of shirt lay open at the throat, and showed his body</li>
<li class="L1659" rel="L1659">to be withered and worn. He, and his old canvas frock, and his loose</li>
<li class="L1660" rel="L1660">stockings, and all his poor tatters of clothes, had, in a long seclusion</li>
<li class="L1661" rel="L1661">from direct light and air, faded down to such a dull uniformity of</li>
<li class="L1662" rel="L1662">parchment-yellow, that it would have been hard to say which was which.</li>
<li class="L1663" rel="L1663"></li>
<li class="L1664" rel="L1664">He had put up a hand between his eyes and the light, and the very bones</li>
<li class="L1665" rel="L1665">of it seemed transparent. So he sat, with a steadfastly vacant gaze,</li>
<li class="L1666" rel="L1666">pausing in his work. He never looked at the figure before him, without</li>
<li class="L1667" rel="L1667">first looking down on this side of himself, then on that, as if he had</li>
<li class="L1668" rel="L1668">lost the habit of associating place with sound; he never spoke, without</li>
<li class="L1669" rel="L1669">first wandering in this manner, and forgetting to speak.</li>
<li class="L1670" rel="L1670"></li>
<li class="L1671" rel="L1671">“Are you going to finish that pair of shoes to-day?” asked Defarge,</li>
<li class="L1672" rel="L1672">motioning to Mr. Lorry to come forward.</li>
<li class="L1673" rel="L1673"></li>
<li class="L1674" rel="L1674">“What did you say?”</li>
<li class="L1675" rel="L1675"></li>
<li class="L1676" rel="L1676">“Do you mean to finish that pair of shoes to-day?”</li>
<li class="L1677" rel="L1677"></li>
<li class="L1678" rel="L1678">“I can&#39;t say that I mean to. I suppose so. I don&#39;t know.”</li>
<li class="L1679" rel="L1679"></li>
<li class="L1680" rel="L1680">But, the question reminded him of his work, and he bent over it again.</li>
<li class="L1681" rel="L1681"></li>
<li class="L1682" rel="L1682">Mr. Lorry came silently forward, leaving the daughter by the door. When</li>
<li class="L1683" rel="L1683">he had stood, for a minute or two, by the side of Defarge, the shoemaker</li>
<li class="L1684" rel="L1684">looked up. He showed no surprise at seeing another figure, but the</li>
<li class="L1685" rel="L1685">unsteady fingers of one of his hands strayed to his lips as he looked at</li>
<li class="L1686" rel="L1686">it (his lips and his nails were of the same pale lead-colour), and then</li>
<li class="L1687" rel="L1687">the hand dropped to his work, and he once more bent over the shoe. The</li>
<li class="L1688" rel="L1688">look and the action had occupied but an instant.</li>
<li class="L1689" rel="L1689"></li>
<li class="L1690" rel="L1690">“You have a visitor, you see,” said Monsieur Defarge.</li>
<li class="L1691" rel="L1691"></li>
<li class="L1692" rel="L1692">“What did you say?”</li>
<li class="L1693" rel="L1693"></li>
<li class="L1694" rel="L1694">“Here is a visitor.”</li>
<li class="L1695" rel="L1695"></li>
<li class="L1696" rel="L1696">The shoemaker looked up as before, but without removing a hand from his</li>
<li class="L1697" rel="L1697">work.</li>
<li class="L1698" rel="L1698"></li>
<li class="L1699" rel="L1699">“Come!” said Defarge. “Here is monsieur, who knows a well-made shoe when</li>
<li class="L1700" rel="L1700">he sees one. Show him that shoe you are working at. Take it, monsieur.”</li>
<li class="L1701" rel="L1701"></li>
<li class="L1702" rel="L1702">Mr. Lorry took it in his hand.</li>
<li class="L1703" rel="L1703"></li>
<li class="L1704" rel="L1704">“Tell monsieur what kind of shoe it is, and the maker&#39;s name.”</li>
<li class="L1705" rel="L1705"></li>
<li class="L1706" rel="L1706">There was a longer pause than usual, before the shoemaker replied:</li>
<li class="L1707" rel="L1707"></li>
<li class="L1708" rel="L1708">“I forget what it was you asked me. What did you say?”</li>
<li class="L1709" rel="L1709"></li>
<li class="L1710" rel="L1710">“I said, couldn&#39;t you describe the kind of shoe, for monsieur&#39;s</li>
<li class="L1711" rel="L1711">information?”</li>
<li class="L1712" rel="L1712"></li>
<li class="L1713" rel="L1713">“It is a lady&#39;s shoe. It is a young lady&#39;s walking-shoe. It is in the</li>
<li class="L1714" rel="L1714">present mode. I never saw the mode. I have had a pattern in my hand.” He</li>
<li class="L1715" rel="L1715">glanced at the shoe with some little passing touch of pride.</li>
<li class="L1716" rel="L1716"></li>
<li class="L1717" rel="L1717">“And the maker&#39;s name?” said Defarge.</li>
<li class="L1718" rel="L1718"></li>
<li class="L1719" rel="L1719">Now that he had no work to hold, he laid the knuckles of the right hand</li>
<li class="L1720" rel="L1720">in the hollow of the left, and then the knuckles of the left hand in the</li>
<li class="L1721" rel="L1721">hollow of the right, and then passed a hand across his bearded chin, and</li>
<li class="L1722" rel="L1722">so on in regular changes, without a moment&#39;s intermission. The task of</li>
<li class="L1723" rel="L1723">recalling him from the vagrancy into which he always sank when he</li>
<li class="L1724" rel="L1724">had spoken, was like recalling some very weak person from a swoon, or</li>
<li class="L1725" rel="L1725">endeavouring, in the hope of some disclosure, to stay the spirit of a</li>
<li class="L1726" rel="L1726">fast-dying man.</li>
<li class="L1727" rel="L1727"></li>
<li class="L1728" rel="L1728">“Did you ask me for my name?”</li>
<li class="L1729" rel="L1729"></li>
<li class="L1730" rel="L1730">“Assuredly I did.”</li>
<li class="L1731" rel="L1731"></li>
<li class="L1732" rel="L1732">“One Hundred and Five, North Tower.”</li>
<li class="L1733" rel="L1733"></li>
<li class="L1734" rel="L1734">“Is that all?”</li>
<li class="L1735" rel="L1735"></li>
<li class="L1736" rel="L1736">“One Hundred and Five, North Tower.”</li>
<li class="L1737" rel="L1737"></li>
<li class="L1738" rel="L1738">With a weary sound that was not a sigh, nor a groan, he bent to work</li>
<li class="L1739" rel="L1739">again, until the silence was again broken.</li>
<li class="L1740" rel="L1740"></li>
<li class="L1741" rel="L1741">“You are not a shoemaker by trade?” said Mr. Lorry, looking steadfastly</li>
<li class="L1742" rel="L1742">at him.</li>
<li class="L1743" rel="L1743"></li>
<li class="L1744" rel="L1744">His haggard eyes turned to Defarge as if he would have transferred the</li>
<li class="L1745" rel="L1745">question to him: but as no help came from that quarter, they turned back</li>
<li class="L1746" rel="L1746">on the questioner when they had sought the ground.</li>
<li class="L1747" rel="L1747"></li>
<li class="L1748" rel="L1748">“I am not a shoemaker by trade? No, I was not a shoemaker by trade. I-I</li>
<li class="L1749" rel="L1749">learnt it here. I taught myself. I asked leave to--”</li>
<li class="L1750" rel="L1750"></li>
<li class="L1751" rel="L1751">He lapsed away, even for minutes, ringing those measured changes on his</li>
<li class="L1752" rel="L1752">hands the whole time. His eyes came slowly back, at last, to the face</li>
<li class="L1753" rel="L1753">from which they had wandered; when they rested on it, he started, and</li>
<li class="L1754" rel="L1754">resumed, in the manner of a sleeper that moment awake, reverting to a</li>
<li class="L1755" rel="L1755">subject of last night.</li>
<li class="L1756" rel="L1756"></li>
<li class="L1757" rel="L1757">“I asked leave to teach myself, and I got it with much difficulty after</li>
<li class="L1758" rel="L1758">a long while, and I have made shoes ever since.”</li>
<li class="L1759" rel="L1759"></li>
<li class="L1760" rel="L1760">As he held out his hand for the shoe that had been taken from him, Mr.</li>
<li class="L1761" rel="L1761">Lorry said, still looking steadfastly in his face:</li>
<li class="L1762" rel="L1762"></li>
<li class="L1763" rel="L1763">“Monsieur Manette, do you remember nothing of me?”</li>
<li class="L1764" rel="L1764"></li>
<li class="L1765" rel="L1765">The shoe dropped to the ground, and he sat looking fixedly at the</li>
<li class="L1766" rel="L1766">questioner.</li>
<li class="L1767" rel="L1767"></li>
<li class="L1768" rel="L1768">“Monsieur Manette”; Mr. Lorry laid his hand upon Defarge&#39;s arm; “do you</li>
<li class="L1769" rel="L1769">remember nothing of this man? Look at him. Look at me. Is there no old</li>
<li class="L1770" rel="L1770">banker, no old business, no old servant, no old time, rising in your</li>
<li class="L1771" rel="L1771">mind, Monsieur Manette?”</li>
<li class="L1772" rel="L1772"></li>
<li class="L1773" rel="L1773">As the captive of many years sat looking fixedly, by turns, at Mr.</li>
<li class="L1774" rel="L1774">Lorry and at Defarge, some long obliterated marks of an actively intent</li>
<li class="L1775" rel="L1775">intelligence in the middle of the forehead, gradually forced themselves</li>
<li class="L1776" rel="L1776">through the black mist that had fallen on him. They were overclouded</li>
<li class="L1777" rel="L1777">again, they were fainter, they were gone; but they had been there. And</li>
<li class="L1778" rel="L1778">so exactly was the expression repeated on the fair young face of her who</li>
<li class="L1779" rel="L1779">had crept along the wall to a point where she could see him, and where</li>
<li class="L1780" rel="L1780">she now stood looking at him, with hands which at first had been only</li>
<li class="L1781" rel="L1781">raised in frightened compassion, if not even to keep him off and</li>
<li class="L1782" rel="L1782">shut out the sight of him, but which were now extending towards him,</li>
<li class="L1783" rel="L1783">trembling with eagerness to lay the spectral face upon her warm young</li>
<li class="L1784" rel="L1784">breast, and love it back to life and hope--so exactly was the expression</li>
<li class="L1785" rel="L1785">repeated (though in stronger characters) on her fair young face, that it</li>
<li class="L1786" rel="L1786">looked as though it had passed like a moving light, from him to her.</li>
<li class="L1787" rel="L1787"></li>
<li class="L1788" rel="L1788">Darkness had fallen on him in its place. He looked at the two, less and</li>
<li class="L1789" rel="L1789">less attentively, and his eyes in gloomy abstraction sought the ground</li>
<li class="L1790" rel="L1790">and looked about him in the old way. Finally, with a deep long sigh, he</li>
<li class="L1791" rel="L1791">took the shoe up, and resumed his work.</li>
<li class="L1792" rel="L1792"></li>
<li class="L1793" rel="L1793">“Have you recognised him, monsieur?” asked Defarge in a whisper.</li>
<li class="L1794" rel="L1794"></li>
<li class="L1795" rel="L1795">“Yes; for a moment. At first I thought it quite hopeless, but I have</li>
<li class="L1796" rel="L1796">unquestionably seen, for a single moment, the face that I once knew so</li>
<li class="L1797" rel="L1797">well. Hush! Let us draw further back. Hush!”</li>
<li class="L1798" rel="L1798"></li>
<li class="L1799" rel="L1799">She had moved from the wall of the garret, very near to the bench on</li>
<li class="L1800" rel="L1800">which he sat. There was something awful in his unconsciousness of the</li>
<li class="L1801" rel="L1801">figure that could have put out its hand and touched him as he stooped</li>
<li class="L1802" rel="L1802">over his labour.</li>
<li class="L1803" rel="L1803"></li>
<li class="L1804" rel="L1804">Not a word was spoken, not a sound was made. She stood, like a spirit,</li>
<li class="L1805" rel="L1805">beside him, and he bent over his work.</li>
<li class="L1806" rel="L1806"></li>
<li class="L1807" rel="L1807">It happened, at length, that he had occasion to change the instrument</li>
<li class="L1808" rel="L1808">in his hand, for his shoemaker&#39;s knife. It lay on that side of him</li>
<li class="L1809" rel="L1809">which was not the side on which she stood. He had taken it up, and was</li>
<li class="L1810" rel="L1810">stooping to work again, when his eyes caught the skirt of her dress. He</li>
<li class="L1811" rel="L1811">raised them, and saw her face. The two spectators started forward,</li>
<li class="L1812" rel="L1812">but she stayed them with a motion of her hand. She had no fear of his</li>
<li class="L1813" rel="L1813">striking at her with the knife, though they had.</li>
<li class="L1814" rel="L1814"></li>
<li class="L1815" rel="L1815">He stared at her with a fearful look, and after a while his lips began</li>
<li class="L1816" rel="L1816">to form some words, though no sound proceeded from them. By degrees, in</li>
<li class="L1817" rel="L1817">the pauses of his quick and laboured breathing, he was heard to say:</li>
<li class="L1818" rel="L1818"></li>
<li class="L1819" rel="L1819">“What is this?”</li>
<li class="L1820" rel="L1820"></li>
<li class="L1821" rel="L1821">With the tears streaming down her face, she put her two hands to her</li>
<li class="L1822" rel="L1822">lips, and kissed them to him; then clasped them on her breast, as if she</li>
<li class="L1823" rel="L1823">laid his ruined head there.</li>
<li class="L1824" rel="L1824"></li>
<li class="L1825" rel="L1825">“You are not the gaoler&#39;s daughter?”</li>
<li class="L1826" rel="L1826"></li>
<li class="L1827" rel="L1827">She sighed “No.”</li>
<li class="L1828" rel="L1828"></li>
<li class="L1829" rel="L1829">“Who are you?”</li>
<li class="L1830" rel="L1830"></li>
<li class="L1831" rel="L1831">Not yet trusting the tones of her voice, she sat down on the bench</li>
<li class="L1832" rel="L1832">beside him. He recoiled, but she laid her hand upon his arm. A strange</li>
<li class="L1833" rel="L1833">thrill struck him when she did so, and visibly passed over his frame; he</li>
<li class="L1834" rel="L1834">laid the knife down softly, as he sat staring at her.</li>
<li class="L1835" rel="L1835"></li>
<li class="L1836" rel="L1836">Her golden hair, which she wore in long curls, had been hurriedly pushed</li>
<li class="L1837" rel="L1837">aside, and fell down over her neck. Advancing his hand by little and</li>
<li class="L1838" rel="L1838">little, he took it up and looked at it. In the midst of the action</li>
<li class="L1839" rel="L1839">he went astray, and, with another deep sigh, fell to work at his</li>
<li class="L1840" rel="L1840">shoemaking.</li>
<li class="L1841" rel="L1841"></li>
<li class="L1842" rel="L1842">But not for long. Releasing his arm, she laid her hand upon his</li>
<li class="L1843" rel="L1843">shoulder. After looking doubtfully at it, two or three times, as if to</li>
<li class="L1844" rel="L1844">be sure that it was really there, he laid down his work, put his hand</li>
<li class="L1845" rel="L1845">to his neck, and took off a blackened string with a scrap of folded rag</li>
<li class="L1846" rel="L1846">attached to it. He opened this, carefully, on his knee, and it contained</li>
<li class="L1847" rel="L1847">a very little quantity of hair: not more than one or two long golden</li>
<li class="L1848" rel="L1848">hairs, which he had, in some old day, wound off upon his finger.</li>
<li class="L1849" rel="L1849"></li>
<li class="L1850" rel="L1850">He took her hair into his hand again, and looked closely at it. “It is</li>
<li class="L1851" rel="L1851">the same. How can it be! When was it! How was it!”</li>
<li class="L1852" rel="L1852"></li>
<li class="L1853" rel="L1853">As the concentrated expression returned to his forehead, he seemed to</li>
<li class="L1854" rel="L1854">become conscious that it was in hers too. He turned her full to the</li>
<li class="L1855" rel="L1855">light, and looked at her.</li>
<li class="L1856" rel="L1856"></li>
<li class="L1857" rel="L1857">“She had laid her head upon my shoulder, that night when I was summoned</li>
<li class="L1858" rel="L1858">out--she had a fear of my going, though I had none--and when I was</li>
<li class="L1859" rel="L1859">brought to the North Tower they found these upon my sleeve. &#39;You will</li>
<li class="L1860" rel="L1860">leave me them? They can never help me to escape in the body, though they</li>
<li class="L1861" rel="L1861">may in the spirit.&#39; Those were the words I said. I remember them very</li>
<li class="L1862" rel="L1862">well.”</li>
<li class="L1863" rel="L1863"></li>
<li class="L1864" rel="L1864">He formed this speech with his lips many times before he could utter it.</li>
<li class="L1865" rel="L1865">But when he did find spoken words for it, they came to him coherently,</li>
<li class="L1866" rel="L1866">though slowly.</li>
<li class="L1867" rel="L1867"></li>
<li class="L1868" rel="L1868">“How was this?--_Was it you_?”</li>
<li class="L1869" rel="L1869"></li>
<li class="L1870" rel="L1870">Once more, the two spectators started, as he turned upon her with a</li>
<li class="L1871" rel="L1871">frightful suddenness. But she sat perfectly still in his grasp, and only</li>
<li class="L1872" rel="L1872">said, in a low voice, “I entreat you, good gentlemen, do not come near</li>
<li class="L1873" rel="L1873">us, do not speak, do not move!”</li>
<li class="L1874" rel="L1874"></li>
<li class="L1875" rel="L1875">“Hark!” he exclaimed. “Whose voice was that?”</li>
<li class="L1876" rel="L1876"></li>
<li class="L1877" rel="L1877">His hands released her as he uttered this cry, and went up to his white</li>
<li class="L1878" rel="L1878">hair, which they tore in a frenzy. It died out, as everything but his</li>
<li class="L1879" rel="L1879">shoemaking did die out of him, and he refolded his little packet and</li>
<li class="L1880" rel="L1880">tried to secure it in his breast; but he still looked at her, and</li>
<li class="L1881" rel="L1881">gloomily shook his head.</li>
<li class="L1882" rel="L1882"></li>
<li class="L1883" rel="L1883">“No, no, no; you are too young, too blooming. It can&#39;t be. See what the</li>
<li class="L1884" rel="L1884">prisoner is. These are not the hands she knew, this is not the face</li>
<li class="L1885" rel="L1885">she knew, this is not a voice she ever heard. No, no. She was--and He</li>
<li class="L1886" rel="L1886">was--before the slow years of the North Tower--ages ago. What is your</li>
<li class="L1887" rel="L1887">name, my gentle angel?”</li>
<li class="L1888" rel="L1888"></li>
<li class="L1889" rel="L1889">Hailing his softened tone and manner, his daughter fell upon her knees</li>
<li class="L1890" rel="L1890">before him, with her appealing hands upon his breast.</li>
<li class="L1891" rel="L1891"></li>
<li class="L1892" rel="L1892">“O, sir, at another time you shall know my name, and who my mother was,</li>
<li class="L1893" rel="L1893">and who my father, and how I never knew their hard, hard history. But I</li>
<li class="L1894" rel="L1894">cannot tell you at this time, and I cannot tell you here. All that I may</li>
<li class="L1895" rel="L1895">tell you, here and now, is, that I pray to you to touch me and to bless</li>
<li class="L1896" rel="L1896">me. Kiss me, kiss me! O my dear, my dear!”</li>
<li class="L1897" rel="L1897"></li>
<li class="L1898" rel="L1898">His cold white head mingled with her radiant hair, which warmed and</li>
<li class="L1899" rel="L1899">lighted it as though it were the light of Freedom shining on him.</li>
<li class="L1900" rel="L1900"></li>
<li class="L1901" rel="L1901">“If you hear in my voice--I don&#39;t know that it is so, but I hope it</li>
<li class="L1902" rel="L1902">is--if you hear in my voice any resemblance to a voice that once was</li>
<li class="L1903" rel="L1903">sweet music in your ears, weep for it, weep for it! If you touch, in</li>
<li class="L1904" rel="L1904">touching my hair, anything that recalls a beloved head that lay on your</li>
<li class="L1905" rel="L1905">breast when you were young and free, weep for it, weep for it! If, when</li>
<li class="L1906" rel="L1906">I hint to you of a Home that is before us, where I will be true to you</li>
<li class="L1907" rel="L1907">with all my duty and with all my faithful service, I bring back the</li>
<li class="L1908" rel="L1908">remembrance of a Home long desolate, while your poor heart pined away,</li>
<li class="L1909" rel="L1909">weep for it, weep for it!”</li>
<li class="L1910" rel="L1910"></li>
<li class="L1911" rel="L1911">She held him closer round the neck, and rocked him on her breast like a</li>
<li class="L1912" rel="L1912">child.</li>
<li class="L1913" rel="L1913"></li>
<li class="L1914" rel="L1914">“If, when I tell you, dearest dear, that your agony is over, and that I</li>
<li class="L1915" rel="L1915">have come here to take you from it, and that we go to England to be at</li>
<li class="L1916" rel="L1916">peace and at rest, I cause you to think of your useful life laid waste,</li>
<li class="L1917" rel="L1917">and of our native France so wicked to you, weep for it, weep for it! And</li>
<li class="L1918" rel="L1918">if, when I shall tell you of my name, and of my father who is living,</li>
<li class="L1919" rel="L1919">and of my mother who is dead, you learn that I have to kneel to my</li>
<li class="L1920" rel="L1920">honoured father, and implore his pardon for having never for his sake</li>
<li class="L1921" rel="L1921">striven all day and lain awake and wept all night, because the love of</li>
<li class="L1922" rel="L1922">my poor mother hid his torture from me, weep for it, weep for it! Weep</li>
<li class="L1923" rel="L1923">for her, then, and for me! Good gentlemen, thank God! I feel his sacred</li>
<li class="L1924" rel="L1924">tears upon my face, and his sobs strike against my heart. O, see! Thank</li>
<li class="L1925" rel="L1925">God for us, thank God!”</li>
<li class="L1926" rel="L1926"></li>
<li class="L1927" rel="L1927">He had sunk in her arms, and his face dropped on her breast: a sight so</li>
<li class="L1928" rel="L1928">touching, yet so terrible in the tremendous wrong and suffering which</li>
<li class="L1929" rel="L1929">had gone before it, that the two beholders covered their faces.</li>
<li class="L1930" rel="L1930"></li>
<li class="L1931" rel="L1931">When the quiet of the garret had been long undisturbed, and his heaving</li>
<li class="L1932" rel="L1932">breast and shaken form had long yielded to the calm that must follow all</li>
<li class="L1933" rel="L1933">storms--emblem to humanity, of the rest and silence into which the storm</li>
<li class="L1934" rel="L1934">called Life must hush at last--they came forward to raise the father and</li>
<li class="L1935" rel="L1935">daughter from the ground. He had gradually dropped to the floor, and lay</li>
<li class="L1936" rel="L1936">there in a lethargy, worn out. She had nestled down with him, that his</li>
<li class="L1937" rel="L1937">head might lie upon her arm; and her hair drooping over him curtained</li>
<li class="L1938" rel="L1938">him from the light.</li>
<li class="L1939" rel="L1939"></li>
<li class="L1940" rel="L1940">“If, without disturbing him,” she said, raising her hand to Mr. Lorry as</li>
<li class="L1941" rel="L1941">he stooped over them, after repeated blowings of his nose, “all could be</li>
<li class="L1942" rel="L1942">arranged for our leaving Paris at once, so that, from the very door, he</li>
<li class="L1943" rel="L1943">could be taken away--”</li>
<li class="L1944" rel="L1944"></li>
<li class="L1945" rel="L1945">“But, consider. Is he fit for the journey?” asked Mr. Lorry.</li>
<li class="L1946" rel="L1946"></li>
<li class="L1947" rel="L1947">“More fit for that, I think, than to remain in this city, so dreadful to</li>
<li class="L1948" rel="L1948">him.”</li>
<li class="L1949" rel="L1949"></li>
<li class="L1950" rel="L1950">“It is true,” said Defarge, who was kneeling to look on and hear. “More</li>
<li class="L1951" rel="L1951">than that; Monsieur Manette is, for all reasons, best out of France.</li>
<li class="L1952" rel="L1952">Say, shall I hire a carriage and post-horses?”</li>
<li class="L1953" rel="L1953"></li>
<li class="L1954" rel="L1954">“That&#39;s business,” said Mr. Lorry, resuming on the shortest notice his</li>
<li class="L1955" rel="L1955">methodical manners; “and if business is to be done, I had better do it.”</li>
<li class="L1956" rel="L1956"></li>
<li class="L1957" rel="L1957">“Then be so kind,” urged Miss Manette, “as to leave us here. You see how</li>
<li class="L1958" rel="L1958">composed he has become, and you cannot be afraid to leave him with me</li>
<li class="L1959" rel="L1959">now. Why should you be? If you will lock the door to secure us from</li>
<li class="L1960" rel="L1960">interruption, I do not doubt that you will find him, when you come back,</li>
<li class="L1961" rel="L1961">as quiet as you leave him. In any case, I will take care of him until</li>
<li class="L1962" rel="L1962">you return, and then we will remove him straight.”</li>
<li class="L1963" rel="L1963"></li>
<li class="L1964" rel="L1964">Both Mr. Lorry and Defarge were rather disinclined to this course, and</li>
<li class="L1965" rel="L1965">in favour of one of them remaining. But, as there were not only carriage</li>
<li class="L1966" rel="L1966">and horses to be seen to, but travelling papers; and as time pressed,</li>
