<li class="L1967" rel="L1967">for the day was drawing to an end, it came at last to their hastily</li>
<li class="L1968" rel="L1968">dividing the business that was necessary to be done, and hurrying away</li>
<li class="L1969" rel="L1969">to do it.</li>
<li class="L1970" rel="L1970"></li>
<li class="L1971" rel="L1971">Then, as the darkness closed in, the daughter laid her head down on the</li>
<li class="L1972" rel="L1972">hard ground close at the father&#39;s side, and watched him. The darkness</li>
<li class="L1973" rel="L1973">deepened and deepened, and they both lay quiet, until a light gleamed</li>
<li class="L1974" rel="L1974">through the chinks in the wall.</li>
<li class="L1975" rel="L1975"></li>
<li class="L1976" rel="L1976">Mr. Lorry and Monsieur Defarge had made all ready for the journey, and</li>
<li class="L1977" rel="L1977">had brought with them, besides travelling cloaks and wrappers, bread and</li>
<li class="L1978" rel="L1978">meat, wine, and hot coffee. Monsieur Defarge put this provender, and the</li>
<li class="L1979" rel="L1979">lamp he carried, on the shoemaker&#39;s bench (there was nothing else in the</li>
<li class="L1980" rel="L1980">garret but a pallet bed), and he and Mr. Lorry roused the captive, and</li>
<li class="L1981" rel="L1981">assisted him to his feet.</li>
<li class="L1982" rel="L1982"></li>
<li class="L1983" rel="L1983">No human intelligence could have read the mysteries of his mind, in</li>
<li class="L1984" rel="L1984">the scared blank wonder of his face. Whether he knew what had happened,</li>
<li class="L1985" rel="L1985">whether he recollected what they had said to him, whether he knew that</li>
<li class="L1986" rel="L1986">he was free, were questions which no sagacity could have solved. They</li>
<li class="L1987" rel="L1987">tried speaking to him; but, he was so confused, and so very slow to</li>
<li class="L1988" rel="L1988">answer, that they took fright at his bewilderment, and agreed for</li>
<li class="L1989" rel="L1989">the time to tamper with him no more. He had a wild, lost manner of</li>
<li class="L1990" rel="L1990">occasionally clasping his head in his hands, that had not been seen</li>
<li class="L1991" rel="L1991">in him before; yet, he had some pleasure in the mere sound of his</li>
<li class="L1992" rel="L1992">daughter&#39;s voice, and invariably turned to it when she spoke.</li>
<li class="L1993" rel="L1993"></li>
<li class="L1994" rel="L1994">In the submissive way of one long accustomed to obey under coercion, he</li>
<li class="L1995" rel="L1995">ate and drank what they gave him to eat and drink, and put on the cloak</li>
<li class="L1996" rel="L1996">and other wrappings, that they gave him to wear. He readily responded to</li>
<li class="L1997" rel="L1997">his daughter&#39;s drawing her arm through his, and took--and kept--her hand</li>
<li class="L1998" rel="L1998">in both his own.</li>
<li class="L1999" rel="L1999"></li>
<li class="L2000" rel="L2000">They began to descend; Monsieur Defarge going first with the lamp, Mr.</li>
<li class="L2001" rel="L2001">Lorry closing the little procession. They had not traversed many steps</li>
<li class="L2002" rel="L2002">of the long main staircase when he stopped, and stared at the roof and</li>
<li class="L2003" rel="L2003">round at the walls.</li>
<li class="L2004" rel="L2004"></li>
<li class="L2005" rel="L2005">“You remember the place, my father? You remember coming up here?”</li>
<li class="L2006" rel="L2006"></li>
<li class="L2007" rel="L2007">“What did you say?”</li>
<li class="L2008" rel="L2008"></li>
<li class="L2009" rel="L2009">But, before she could repeat the question, he murmured an answer as if</li>
<li class="L2010" rel="L2010">she had repeated it.</li>
<li class="L2011" rel="L2011"></li>
<li class="L2012" rel="L2012">“Remember? No, I don&#39;t remember. It was so very long ago.”</li>
<li class="L2013" rel="L2013"></li>
<li class="L2014" rel="L2014">That he had no recollection whatever of his having been brought from his</li>
<li class="L2015" rel="L2015">prison to that house, was apparent to them. They heard him mutter,</li>
<li class="L2016" rel="L2016">“One Hundred and Five, North Tower;” and when he looked about him, it</li>
<li class="L2017" rel="L2017">evidently was for the strong fortress-walls which had long encompassed</li>
<li class="L2018" rel="L2018">him. On their reaching the courtyard he instinctively altered his</li>
<li class="L2019" rel="L2019">tread, as being in expectation of a drawbridge; and when there was</li>
<li class="L2020" rel="L2020">no drawbridge, and he saw the carriage waiting in the open street, he</li>
<li class="L2021" rel="L2021">dropped his daughter&#39;s hand and clasped his head again.</li>
<li class="L2022" rel="L2022"></li>
<li class="L2023" rel="L2023">No crowd was about the door; no people were discernible at any of the</li>
<li class="L2024" rel="L2024">many windows; not even a chance passerby was in the street. An unnatural</li>
<li class="L2025" rel="L2025">silence and desertion reigned there. Only one soul was to be seen, and</li>
<li class="L2026" rel="L2026">that was Madame Defarge--who leaned against the door-post, knitting, and</li>
<li class="L2027" rel="L2027">saw nothing.</li>
<li class="L2028" rel="L2028"></li>
<li class="L2029" rel="L2029">The prisoner had got into a coach, and his daughter had followed</li>
<li class="L2030" rel="L2030">him, when Mr. Lorry&#39;s feet were arrested on the step by his asking,</li>
<li class="L2031" rel="L2031">miserably, for his shoemaking tools and the unfinished shoes. Madame</li>
<li class="L2032" rel="L2032">Defarge immediately called to her husband that she would get them, and</li>
<li class="L2033" rel="L2033">went, knitting, out of the lamplight, through the courtyard. She quickly</li>
<li class="L2034" rel="L2034">brought them down and handed them in;--and immediately afterwards leaned</li>
<li class="L2035" rel="L2035">against the door-post, knitting, and saw nothing.</li>
<li class="L2036" rel="L2036"></li>
<li class="L2037" rel="L2037">Defarge got upon the box, and gave the word “To the Barrier!” The</li>
<li class="L2038" rel="L2038">postilion cracked his whip, and they clattered away under the feeble</li>
<li class="L2039" rel="L2039">over-swinging lamps.</li>
<li class="L2040" rel="L2040"></li>
<li class="L2041" rel="L2041">Under the over-swinging lamps--swinging ever brighter in the better</li>
<li class="L2042" rel="L2042">streets, and ever dimmer in the worse--and by lighted shops, gay crowds,</li>
<li class="L2043" rel="L2043">illuminated coffee-houses, and theatre-doors, to one of the city</li>
<li class="L2044" rel="L2044">gates. Soldiers with lanterns, at the guard-house there. “Your papers,</li>
<li class="L2045" rel="L2045">travellers!” “See here then, Monsieur the Officer,” said Defarge,</li>
<li class="L2046" rel="L2046">getting down, and taking him gravely apart, “these are the papers of</li>
<li class="L2047" rel="L2047">monsieur inside, with the white head. They were consigned to me, with</li>
<li class="L2048" rel="L2048">him, at the--” He dropped his voice, there was a flutter among the</li>
<li class="L2049" rel="L2049">military lanterns, and one of them being handed into the coach by an arm</li>
<li class="L2050" rel="L2050">in uniform, the eyes connected with the arm looked, not an every day</li>
<li class="L2051" rel="L2051">or an every night look, at monsieur with the white head. “It is well.</li>
<li class="L2052" rel="L2052">Forward!” from the uniform. “Adieu!” from Defarge. And so, under a short</li>
<li class="L2053" rel="L2053">grove of feebler and feebler over-swinging lamps, out under the great</li>
<li class="L2054" rel="L2054">grove of stars.</li>
<li class="L2055" rel="L2055"></li>
<li class="L2056" rel="L2056">Beneath that arch of unmoved and eternal lights; some, so remote from</li>
<li class="L2057" rel="L2057">this little earth that the learned tell us it is doubtful whether their</li>
<li class="L2058" rel="L2058">rays have even yet discovered it, as a point in space where anything</li>
<li class="L2059" rel="L2059">is suffered or done: the shadows of the night were broad and black.</li>
<li class="L2060" rel="L2060">All through the cold and restless interval, until dawn, they once more</li>
<li class="L2061" rel="L2061">whispered in the ears of Mr. Jarvis Lorry--sitting opposite the buried</li>
<li class="L2062" rel="L2062">man who had been dug out, and wondering what subtle powers were for ever</li>
<li class="L2063" rel="L2063">lost to him, and what were capable of restoration--the old inquiry:</li>
<li class="L2064" rel="L2064"></li>
<li class="L2065" rel="L2065">“I hope you care to be recalled to life?”</li>
<li class="L2066" rel="L2066"></li>
<li class="L2067" rel="L2067">And the old answer:</li>
<li class="L2068" rel="L2068"></li>
<li class="L2069" rel="L2069">“I can&#39;t say.”</li>
<li class="L2070" rel="L2070"></li>
<li class="L2071" rel="L2071"></li>
<li class="L2072" rel="L2072">The end of the first book.</li>
<li class="L2073" rel="L2073"></li>
<li class="L2074" rel="L2074"></li>
<li class="L2075" rel="L2075"></li>
<li class="L2076" rel="L2076"></li>
<li class="L2077" rel="L2077"></li>
<li class="L2078" rel="L2078">Book the Second--the Golden Thread</li>
<li class="L2079" rel="L2079"></li>
<li class="L2080" rel="L2080"></li>
<li class="L2081" rel="L2081"></li>
<li class="L2082" rel="L2082"></li>
<li class="L2083" rel="L2083">I. Five Years Later</li>
<li class="L2084" rel="L2084"></li>
<li class="L2085" rel="L2085"></li>
<li class="L2086" rel="L2086">Tellson&#39;s Bank by Temple Bar was an old-fashioned place, even in the</li>
<li class="L2087" rel="L2087">year one thousand seven hundred and eighty. It was very small, very</li>
<li class="L2088" rel="L2088">dark, very ugly, very incommodious. It was an old-fashioned place,</li>
<li class="L2089" rel="L2089">moreover, in the moral attribute that the partners in the House were</li>
<li class="L2090" rel="L2090">proud of its smallness, proud of its darkness, proud of its ugliness,</li>
<li class="L2091" rel="L2091">proud of its incommodiousness. They were even boastful of its eminence</li>
<li class="L2092" rel="L2092">in those particulars, and were fired by an express conviction that, if</li>
<li class="L2093" rel="L2093">it were less objectionable, it would be less respectable. This was</li>
<li class="L2094" rel="L2094">no passive belief, but an active weapon which they flashed at more</li>
<li class="L2095" rel="L2095">convenient places of business. Tellson&#39;s (they said) wanted</li>
<li class="L2096" rel="L2096">no elbow-room, Tellson&#39;s wanted no light, Tellson&#39;s wanted no</li>
<li class="L2097" rel="L2097">embellishment. Noakes and Co.&#39;s might, or Snooks Brothers&#39; might; but</li>
<li class="L2098" rel="L2098">Tellson&#39;s, thank Heaven--!</li>
<li class="L2099" rel="L2099"></li>
<li class="L2100" rel="L2100">Any one of these partners would have disinherited his son on the</li>
<li class="L2101" rel="L2101">question of rebuilding Tellson&#39;s. In this respect the House was much</li>
<li class="L2102" rel="L2102">on a par with the Country; which did very often disinherit its sons for</li>
<li class="L2103" rel="L2103">suggesting improvements in laws and customs that had long been highly</li>
<li class="L2104" rel="L2104">objectionable, but were only the more respectable.</li>
<li class="L2105" rel="L2105"></li>
<li class="L2106" rel="L2106">Thus it had come to pass, that Tellson&#39;s was the triumphant perfection</li>
<li class="L2107" rel="L2107">of inconvenience. After bursting open a door of idiotic obstinacy with</li>
<li class="L2108" rel="L2108">a weak rattle in its throat, you fell into Tellson&#39;s down two steps,</li>
<li class="L2109" rel="L2109">and came to your senses in a miserable little shop, with two little</li>
<li class="L2110" rel="L2110">counters, where the oldest of men made your cheque shake as if the</li>
<li class="L2111" rel="L2111">wind rustled it, while they examined the signature by the dingiest of</li>
<li class="L2112" rel="L2112">windows, which were always under a shower-bath of mud from Fleet-street,</li>
<li class="L2113" rel="L2113">and which were made the dingier by their own iron bars proper, and the</li>
<li class="L2114" rel="L2114">heavy shadow of Temple Bar. If your business necessitated your seeing</li>
<li class="L2115" rel="L2115">“the House,” you were put into a species of Condemned Hold at the back,</li>
<li class="L2116" rel="L2116">where you meditated on a misspent life, until the House came with its</li>
<li class="L2117" rel="L2117">hands in its pockets, and you could hardly blink at it in the dismal</li>
<li class="L2118" rel="L2118">twilight. Your money came out of, or went into, wormy old wooden</li>
<li class="L2119" rel="L2119">drawers, particles of which flew up your nose and down your throat when</li>
<li class="L2120" rel="L2120">they were opened and shut. Your bank-notes had a musty odour, as if they</li>
<li class="L2121" rel="L2121">were fast decomposing into rags again. Your plate was stowed away among</li>
<li class="L2122" rel="L2122">the neighbouring cesspools, and evil communications corrupted its good</li>
<li class="L2123" rel="L2123">polish in a day or two. Your deeds got into extemporised strong-rooms</li>
<li class="L2124" rel="L2124">made of kitchens and sculleries, and fretted all the fat out of their</li>
<li class="L2125" rel="L2125">parchments into the banking-house air. Your lighter boxes of family</li>
<li class="L2126" rel="L2126">papers went up-stairs into a Barmecide room, that always had a great</li>
<li class="L2127" rel="L2127">dining-table in it and never had a dinner, and where, even in the year</li>
<li class="L2128" rel="L2128">one thousand seven hundred and eighty, the first letters written to you</li>
<li class="L2129" rel="L2129">by your old love, or by your little children, were but newly released</li>
<li class="L2130" rel="L2130">from the horror of being ogled through the windows, by the heads</li>
<li class="L2131" rel="L2131">exposed on Temple Bar with an insensate brutality and ferocity worthy of</li>
<li class="L2132" rel="L2132">Abyssinia or Ashantee.</li>
<li class="L2133" rel="L2133"></li>
<li class="L2134" rel="L2134">But indeed, at that time, putting to death was a recipe much in vogue</li>
<li class="L2135" rel="L2135">with all trades and professions, and not least of all with Tellson&#39;s.</li>
<li class="L2136" rel="L2136">Death is Nature&#39;s remedy for all things, and why not Legislation&#39;s?</li>
<li class="L2137" rel="L2137">Accordingly, the forger was put to Death; the utterer of a bad note</li>
<li class="L2138" rel="L2138">was put to Death; the unlawful opener of a letter was put to Death; the</li>
<li class="L2139" rel="L2139">purloiner of forty shillings and sixpence was put to Death; the holder</li>
<li class="L2140" rel="L2140">of a horse at Tellson&#39;s door, who made off with it, was put to</li>
<li class="L2141" rel="L2141">Death; the coiner of a bad shilling was put to Death; the sounders of</li>
<li class="L2142" rel="L2142">three-fourths of the notes in the whole gamut of Crime, were put to</li>
<li class="L2143" rel="L2143">Death. Not that it did the least good in the way of prevention--it</li>
<li class="L2144" rel="L2144">might almost have been worth remarking that the fact was exactly the</li>
<li class="L2145" rel="L2145">reverse--but, it cleared off (as to this world) the trouble of each</li>
<li class="L2146" rel="L2146">particular case, and left nothing else connected with it to be looked</li>
<li class="L2147" rel="L2147">after. Thus, Tellson&#39;s, in its day, like greater places of business,</li>
<li class="L2148" rel="L2148">its contemporaries, had taken so many lives, that, if the heads laid</li>
<li class="L2149" rel="L2149">low before it had been ranged on Temple Bar instead of being privately</li>
<li class="L2150" rel="L2150">disposed of, they would probably have excluded what little light the</li>
<li class="L2151" rel="L2151">ground floor had, in a rather significant manner.</li>
<li class="L2152" rel="L2152"></li>
<li class="L2153" rel="L2153">Cramped in all kinds of dim cupboards and hutches at Tellson&#39;s, the</li>
<li class="L2154" rel="L2154">oldest of men carried on the business gravely. When they took a young</li>
<li class="L2155" rel="L2155">man into Tellson&#39;s London house, they hid him somewhere till he was</li>
<li class="L2156" rel="L2156">old. They kept him in a dark place, like a cheese, until he had the full</li>
<li class="L2157" rel="L2157">Tellson flavour and blue-mould upon him. Then only was he permitted to</li>
<li class="L2158" rel="L2158">be seen, spectacularly poring over large books, and casting his breeches</li>
<li class="L2159" rel="L2159">and gaiters into the general weight of the establishment.</li>
<li class="L2160" rel="L2160"></li>
<li class="L2161" rel="L2161">Outside Tellson&#39;s--never by any means in it, unless called in--was an</li>
<li class="L2162" rel="L2162">odd-job-man, an occasional porter and messenger, who served as the live</li>
<li class="L2163" rel="L2163">sign of the house. He was never absent during business hours, unless</li>
<li class="L2164" rel="L2164">upon an errand, and then he was represented by his son: a grisly urchin</li>
<li class="L2165" rel="L2165">of twelve, who was his express image. People understood that Tellson&#39;s,</li>
<li class="L2166" rel="L2166">in a stately way, tolerated the odd-job-man. The house had always</li>
<li class="L2167" rel="L2167">tolerated some person in that capacity, and time and tide had drifted</li>
<li class="L2168" rel="L2168">this person to the post. His surname was Cruncher, and on the youthful</li>
<li class="L2169" rel="L2169">occasion of his renouncing by proxy the works of darkness, in the</li>
<li class="L2170" rel="L2170">easterly parish church of Hounsditch, he had received the added</li>
<li class="L2171" rel="L2171">appellation of Jerry.</li>
<li class="L2172" rel="L2172"></li>
<li class="L2173" rel="L2173">The scene was Mr. Cruncher&#39;s private lodging in Hanging-sword-alley,</li>
<li class="L2174" rel="L2174">Whitefriars: the time, half-past seven of the clock on a windy March</li>
<li class="L2175" rel="L2175">morning, Anno Domini seventeen hundred and eighty. (Mr. Cruncher himself</li>
<li class="L2176" rel="L2176">always spoke of the year of our Lord as Anna Dominoes: apparently under</li>
<li class="L2177" rel="L2177">the impression that the Christian era dated from the invention of a</li>
<li class="L2178" rel="L2178">popular game, by a lady who had bestowed her name upon it.)</li>
<li class="L2179" rel="L2179"></li>
<li class="L2180" rel="L2180">Mr. Cruncher&#39;s apartments were not in a savoury neighbourhood, and were</li>
<li class="L2181" rel="L2181">but two in number, even if a closet with a single pane of glass in it</li>
<li class="L2182" rel="L2182">might be counted as one. But they were very decently kept. Early as</li>
<li class="L2183" rel="L2183">it was, on the windy March morning, the room in which he lay abed was</li>
<li class="L2184" rel="L2184">already scrubbed throughout; and between the cups and saucers arranged</li>
<li class="L2185" rel="L2185">for breakfast, and the lumbering deal table, a very clean white cloth</li>
<li class="L2186" rel="L2186">was spread.</li>
<li class="L2187" rel="L2187"></li>
<li class="L2188" rel="L2188">Mr. Cruncher reposed under a patchwork counterpane, like a Harlequin</li>
<li class="L2189" rel="L2189">at home. At first, he slept heavily, but, by degrees, began to roll</li>
<li class="L2190" rel="L2190">and surge in bed, until he rose above the surface, with his spiky hair</li>
<li class="L2191" rel="L2191">looking as if it must tear the sheets to ribbons. At which juncture, he</li>
<li class="L2192" rel="L2192">exclaimed, in a voice of dire exasperation:</li>
<li class="L2193" rel="L2193"></li>
<li class="L2194" rel="L2194">“Bust me, if she ain&#39;t at it agin!”</li>
<li class="L2195" rel="L2195"></li>
<li class="L2196" rel="L2196">A woman of orderly and industrious appearance rose from her knees in a</li>
<li class="L2197" rel="L2197">corner, with sufficient haste and trepidation to show that she was the</li>
<li class="L2198" rel="L2198">person referred to.</li>
<li class="L2199" rel="L2199"></li>
<li class="L2200" rel="L2200">“What!” said Mr. Cruncher, looking out of bed for a boot. “You&#39;re at it</li>
<li class="L2201" rel="L2201">agin, are you?”</li>
<li class="L2202" rel="L2202"></li>
<li class="L2203" rel="L2203">After hailing the morn with this second salutation, he threw a boot at</li>
<li class="L2204" rel="L2204">the woman as a third. It was a very muddy boot, and may introduce the</li>
<li class="L2205" rel="L2205">odd circumstance connected with Mr. Cruncher&#39;s domestic economy, that,</li>
<li class="L2206" rel="L2206">whereas he often came home after banking hours with clean boots, he</li>
<li class="L2207" rel="L2207">often got up next morning to find the same boots covered with clay.</li>
<li class="L2208" rel="L2208"></li>
<li class="L2209" rel="L2209">“What,” said Mr. Cruncher, varying his apostrophe after missing his</li>
<li class="L2210" rel="L2210">mark--“what are you up to, Aggerawayter?”</li>
<li class="L2211" rel="L2211"></li>
<li class="L2212" rel="L2212">“I was only saying my prayers.”</li>
<li class="L2213" rel="L2213"></li>
<li class="L2214" rel="L2214">“Saying your prayers! You&#39;re a nice woman! What do you mean by flopping</li>
<li class="L2215" rel="L2215">yourself down and praying agin me?”</li>
<li class="L2216" rel="L2216"></li>
<li class="L2217" rel="L2217">“I was not praying against you; I was praying for you.”</li>
<li class="L2218" rel="L2218"></li>
<li class="L2219" rel="L2219">“You weren&#39;t. And if you were, I won&#39;t be took the liberty with. Here!</li>
<li class="L2220" rel="L2220">your mother&#39;s a nice woman, young Jerry, going a praying agin your</li>
<li class="L2221" rel="L2221">father&#39;s prosperity. You&#39;ve got a dutiful mother, you have, my son.</li>
<li class="L2222" rel="L2222">You&#39;ve got a religious mother, you have, my boy: going and flopping</li>
<li class="L2223" rel="L2223">herself down, and praying that the bread-and-butter may be snatched out</li>
<li class="L2224" rel="L2224">of the mouth of her only child.”</li>
<li class="L2225" rel="L2225"></li>
<li class="L2226" rel="L2226">Master Cruncher (who was in his shirt) took this very ill, and, turning</li>
<li class="L2227" rel="L2227">to his mother, strongly deprecated any praying away of his personal</li>
<li class="L2228" rel="L2228">board.</li>
<li class="L2229" rel="L2229"></li>
<li class="L2230" rel="L2230">“And what do you suppose, you conceited female,” said Mr. Cruncher, with</li>
<li class="L2231" rel="L2231">unconscious inconsistency, “that the worth of _your_ prayers may be?</li>
<li class="L2232" rel="L2232">Name the price that you put _your_ prayers at!”</li>
<li class="L2233" rel="L2233"></li>
<li class="L2234" rel="L2234">“They only come from the heart, Jerry. They are worth no more than</li>
<li class="L2235" rel="L2235">that.”</li>
<li class="L2236" rel="L2236"></li>
<li class="L2237" rel="L2237">“Worth no more than that,” repeated Mr. Cruncher. “They ain&#39;t worth</li>
<li class="L2238" rel="L2238">much, then. Whether or no, I won&#39;t be prayed agin, I tell you. I can&#39;t</li>
<li class="L2239" rel="L2239">afford it. I&#39;m not a going to be made unlucky by _your_ sneaking. If</li>
<li class="L2240" rel="L2240">you must go flopping yourself down, flop in favour of your husband and</li>
<li class="L2241" rel="L2241">child, and not in opposition to &#39;em. If I had had any but a unnat&#39;ral</li>
<li class="L2242" rel="L2242">wife, and this poor boy had had any but a unnat&#39;ral mother, I might</li>
<li class="L2243" rel="L2243">have made some money last week instead of being counter-prayed and</li>
<li class="L2244" rel="L2244">countermined and religiously circumwented into the worst of luck.</li>
<li class="L2245" rel="L2245">B-u-u-ust me!” said Mr. Cruncher, who all this time had been putting</li>
<li class="L2246" rel="L2246">on his clothes, “if I ain&#39;t, what with piety and one blowed thing and</li>
<li class="L2247" rel="L2247">another, been choused this last week into as bad luck as ever a poor</li>
<li class="L2248" rel="L2248">devil of a honest tradesman met with! Young Jerry, dress yourself, my</li>
<li class="L2249" rel="L2249">boy, and while I clean my boots keep a eye upon your mother now and</li>
<li class="L2250" rel="L2250">then, and if you see any signs of more flopping, give me a call. For, I</li>
<li class="L2251" rel="L2251">tell you,” here he addressed his wife once more, “I won&#39;t be gone agin,</li>
<li class="L2252" rel="L2252">in this manner. I am as rickety as a hackney-coach, I&#39;m as sleepy as</li>
<li class="L2253" rel="L2253">laudanum, my lines is strained to that degree that I shouldn&#39;t know, if</li>
<li class="L2254" rel="L2254">it wasn&#39;t for the pain in &#39;em, which was me and which somebody else, yet</li>
<li class="L2255" rel="L2255">I&#39;m none the better for it in pocket; and it&#39;s my suspicion that you&#39;ve</li>
<li class="L2256" rel="L2256">been at it from morning to night to prevent me from being the better for</li>
<li class="L2257" rel="L2257">it in pocket, and I won&#39;t put up with it, Aggerawayter, and what do you</li>
<li class="L2258" rel="L2258">say now!”</li>
<li class="L2259" rel="L2259"></li>
<li class="L2260" rel="L2260">Growling, in addition, such phrases as “Ah! yes! You&#39;re religious, too.</li>
<li class="L2261" rel="L2261">You wouldn&#39;t put yourself in opposition to the interests of your husband</li>
<li class="L2262" rel="L2262">and child, would you? Not you!” and throwing off other sarcastic sparks</li>
<li class="L2263" rel="L2263">from the whirling grindstone of his indignation, Mr. Cruncher betook</li>
<li class="L2264" rel="L2264">himself to his boot-cleaning and his general preparation for business.</li>
<li class="L2265" rel="L2265">In the meantime, his son, whose head was garnished with tenderer spikes,</li>
<li class="L2266" rel="L2266">and whose young eyes stood close by one another, as his father&#39;s did,</li>
<li class="L2267" rel="L2267">kept the required watch upon his mother. He greatly disturbed that poor</li>
<li class="L2268" rel="L2268">woman at intervals, by darting out of his sleeping closet, where he made</li>
<li class="L2269" rel="L2269">his toilet, with a suppressed cry of “You are going to flop, mother.</li>
<li class="L2270" rel="L2270">--Halloa, father!” and, after raising this fictitious alarm, darting in</li>
<li class="L2271" rel="L2271">again with an undutiful grin.</li>
<li class="L2272" rel="L2272"></li>
<li class="L2273" rel="L2273">Mr. Cruncher&#39;s temper was not at all improved when he came to his</li>
<li class="L2274" rel="L2274">breakfast. He resented Mrs. Cruncher&#39;s saying grace with particular</li>
<li class="L2275" rel="L2275">animosity.</li>
<li class="L2276" rel="L2276"></li>
<li class="L2277" rel="L2277">“Now, Aggerawayter! What are you up to? At it again?”</li>
<li class="L2278" rel="L2278"></li>
<li class="L2279" rel="L2279">His wife explained that she had merely “asked a blessing.”</li>
<li class="L2280" rel="L2280"></li>
<li class="L2281" rel="L2281">“Don&#39;t do it!” said Mr. Crunches looking about, as if he rather expected</li>
<li class="L2282" rel="L2282">to see the loaf disappear under the efficacy of his wife&#39;s petitions. “I</li>
<li class="L2283" rel="L2283">ain&#39;t a going to be blest out of house and home. I won&#39;t have my wittles</li>
<li class="L2284" rel="L2284">blest off my table. Keep still!”</li>
<li class="L2285" rel="L2285"></li>
<li class="L2286" rel="L2286">Exceedingly red-eyed and grim, as if he had been up all night at a party</li>
<li class="L2287" rel="L2287">which had taken anything but a convivial turn, Jerry Cruncher worried</li>
<li class="L2288" rel="L2288">his breakfast rather than ate it, growling over it like any four-footed</li>
<li class="L2289" rel="L2289">inmate of a menagerie. Towards nine o&#39;clock he smoothed his ruffled</li>
<li class="L2290" rel="L2290">aspect, and, presenting as respectable and business-like an exterior as</li>
<li class="L2291" rel="L2291">he could overlay his natural self with, issued forth to the occupation</li>
<li class="L2292" rel="L2292">of the day.</li>
<li class="L2293" rel="L2293"></li>
<li class="L2294" rel="L2294">It could scarcely be called a trade, in spite of his favourite</li>
<li class="L2295" rel="L2295">description of himself as “a honest tradesman.” His stock consisted of</li>
<li class="L2296" rel="L2296">a wooden stool, made out of a broken-backed chair cut down, which stool,</li>
<li class="L2297" rel="L2297">young Jerry, walking at his father&#39;s side, carried every morning to</li>
<li class="L2298" rel="L2298">beneath the banking-house window that was nearest Temple Bar: where,</li>
<li class="L2299" rel="L2299">with the addition of the first handful of straw that could be gleaned</li>
<li class="L2300" rel="L2300">from any passing vehicle to keep the cold and wet from the odd-job-man&#39;s</li>
<li class="L2301" rel="L2301">feet, it formed the encampment for the day. On this post of his, Mr.</li>
<li class="L2302" rel="L2302">Cruncher was as well known to Fleet-street and the Temple, as the Bar</li>
<li class="L2303" rel="L2303">itself,--and was almost as in-looking.</li>
<li class="L2304" rel="L2304"></li>
<li class="L2305" rel="L2305">Encamped at a quarter before nine, in good time to touch his</li>
<li class="L2306" rel="L2306">three-cornered hat to the oldest of men as they passed in to Tellson&#39;s,</li>
<li class="L2307" rel="L2307">Jerry took up his station on this windy March morning, with young Jerry</li>
<li class="L2308" rel="L2308">standing by him, when not engaged in making forays through the Bar, to</li>
<li class="L2309" rel="L2309">inflict bodily and mental injuries of an acute description on passing</li>
<li class="L2310" rel="L2310">boys who were small enough for his amiable purpose. Father and son,</li>
<li class="L2311" rel="L2311">extremely like each other, looking silently on at the morning traffic</li>
<li class="L2312" rel="L2312">in Fleet-street, with their two heads as near to one another as the two</li>
<li class="L2313" rel="L2313">eyes of each were, bore a considerable resemblance to a pair of monkeys.</li>
<li class="L2314" rel="L2314">The resemblance was not lessened by the accidental circumstance, that</li>
<li class="L2315" rel="L2315">the mature Jerry bit and spat out straw, while the twinkling eyes of the</li>
<li class="L2316" rel="L2316">youthful Jerry were as restlessly watchful of him as of everything else</li>
<li class="L2317" rel="L2317">in Fleet-street.</li>
<li class="L2318" rel="L2318"></li>
<li class="L2319" rel="L2319">The head of one of the regular indoor messengers attached to Tellson&#39;s</li>
<li class="L2320" rel="L2320">establishment was put through the door, and the word was given:</li>
<li class="L2321" rel="L2321"></li>
<li class="L2322" rel="L2322">“Porter wanted!”</li>
<li class="L2323" rel="L2323"></li>
<li class="L2324" rel="L2324">“Hooray, father! Here&#39;s an early job to begin with!”</li>
<li class="L2325" rel="L2325"></li>
<li class="L2326" rel="L2326">Having thus given his parent God speed, young Jerry seated himself on</li>
<li class="L2327" rel="L2327">the stool, entered on his reversionary interest in the straw his father</li>
<li class="L2328" rel="L2328">had been chewing, and cogitated.</li>
<li class="L2329" rel="L2329"></li>
<li class="L2330" rel="L2330">“Al-ways rusty! His fingers is al-ways rusty!” muttered young Jerry.</li>
<li class="L2331" rel="L2331">“Where does my father get all that iron rust from? He don&#39;t get no iron</li>
<li class="L2332" rel="L2332">rust here!”</li>
<li class="L2333" rel="L2333"></li>
<li class="L2334" rel="L2334"></li>
<li class="L2335" rel="L2335"></li>
<li class="L2336" rel="L2336"></li>
<li class="L2337" rel="L2337">II. A Sight</li>
<li class="L2338" rel="L2338"></li>
<li class="L2339" rel="L2339"></li>
<li class="L2340" rel="L2340">“You know the Old Bailey well, no doubt?” said one of the oldest of</li>
<li class="L2341" rel="L2341">clerks to Jerry the messenger.</li>
<li class="L2342" rel="L2342"></li>
<li class="L2343" rel="L2343">“Ye-es, sir,” returned Jerry, in something of a dogged manner. “I _do_</li>
<li class="L2344" rel="L2344">know the Bailey.”</li>
<li class="L2345" rel="L2345"></li>
<li class="L2346" rel="L2346">“Just so. And you know Mr. Lorry.”</li>
<li class="L2347" rel="L2347"></li>
<li class="L2348" rel="L2348">“I know Mr. Lorry, sir, much better than I know the Bailey. Much</li>
<li class="L2349" rel="L2349">better,” said Jerry, not unlike a reluctant witness at the establishment</li>
<li class="L2350" rel="L2350">in question, “than I, as a honest tradesman, wish to know the Bailey.”</li>
<li class="L2351" rel="L2351"></li>
<li class="L2352" rel="L2352">“Very well. Find the door where the witnesses go in, and show the</li>
<li class="L2353" rel="L2353">door-keeper this note for Mr. Lorry. He will then let you in.”</li>
<li class="L2354" rel="L2354"></li>
<li class="L2355" rel="L2355">“Into the court, sir?”</li>
<li class="L2356" rel="L2356"></li>
<li class="L2357" rel="L2357">“Into the court.”</li>
<li class="L2358" rel="L2358"></li>
<li class="L2359" rel="L2359">Mr. Cruncher&#39;s eyes seemed to get a little closer to one another, and to</li>
<li class="L2360" rel="L2360">interchange the inquiry, “What do you think of this?”</li>
<li class="L2361" rel="L2361"></li>
<li class="L2362" rel="L2362">“Am I to wait in the court, sir?” he asked, as the result of that</li>
<li class="L2363" rel="L2363">conference.</li>
<li class="L2364" rel="L2364"></li>
<li class="L2365" rel="L2365">“I am going to tell you. The door-keeper will pass the note to Mr.</li>
<li class="L2366" rel="L2366">Lorry, and do you make any gesture that will attract Mr. Lorry&#39;s</li>
<li class="L2367" rel="L2367">attention, and show him where you stand. Then what you have to do, is,</li>
<li class="L2368" rel="L2368">to remain there until he wants you.”</li>
<li class="L2369" rel="L2369"></li>
<li class="L2370" rel="L2370">“Is that all, sir?”</li>
<li class="L2371" rel="L2371"></li>
<li class="L2372" rel="L2372">“That&#39;s all. He wishes to have a messenger at hand. This is to tell him</li>
<li class="L2373" rel="L2373">you are there.”</li>
<li class="L2374" rel="L2374"></li>
<li class="L2375" rel="L2375">As the ancient clerk deliberately folded and superscribed the note,</li>
<li class="L2376" rel="L2376">Mr. Cruncher, after surveying him in silence until he came to the</li>
<li class="L2377" rel="L2377">blotting-paper stage, remarked:</li>
<li class="L2378" rel="L2378"></li>
<li class="L2379" rel="L2379">“I suppose they&#39;ll be trying Forgeries this morning?”</li>
<li class="L2380" rel="L2380"></li>
<li class="L2381" rel="L2381">“Treason!”</li>
<li class="L2382" rel="L2382"></li>
<li class="L2383" rel="L2383">“That&#39;s quartering,” said Jerry. “Barbarous!”</li>
<li class="L2384" rel="L2384"></li>
<li class="L2385" rel="L2385">“It is the law,” remarked the ancient clerk, turning his surprised</li>
<li class="L2386" rel="L2386">spectacles upon him. “It is the law.”</li>
<li class="L2387" rel="L2387"></li>
<li class="L2388" rel="L2388">“It&#39;s hard in the law to spile a man, I think. It&#39;s hard enough to kill</li>
<li class="L2389" rel="L2389">him, but it&#39;s wery hard to spile him, sir.”</li>
<li class="L2390" rel="L2390"></li>
<li class="L2391" rel="L2391">“Not at all,” retained the ancient clerk. “Speak well of the law. Take</li>
<li class="L2392" rel="L2392">care of your chest and voice, my good friend, and leave the law to take</li>
<li class="L2393" rel="L2393">care of itself. I give you that advice.”</li>
<li class="L2394" rel="L2394"></li>
<li class="L2395" rel="L2395">“It&#39;s the damp, sir, what settles on my chest and voice,” said Jerry. “I</li>
<li class="L2396" rel="L2396">leave you to judge what a damp way of earning a living mine is.”</li>
<li class="L2397" rel="L2397"></li>
<li class="L2398" rel="L2398">“Well, well,” said the old clerk; “we all have our various ways of</li>
<li class="L2399" rel="L2399">gaining a livelihood. Some of us have damp ways, and some of us have dry</li>
<li class="L2400" rel="L2400">ways. Here is the letter. Go along.”</li>
<li class="L2401" rel="L2401"></li>
<li class="L2402" rel="L2402">Jerry took the letter, and, remarking to himself with less internal</li>
<li class="L2403" rel="L2403">deference than he made an outward show of, “You are a lean old one,</li>
<li class="L2404" rel="L2404">too,” made his bow, informed his son, in passing, of his destination,</li>
<li class="L2405" rel="L2405">and went his way.</li>
<li class="L2406" rel="L2406"></li>
<li class="L2407" rel="L2407">They hanged at Tyburn, in those days, so the street outside Newgate had</li>
<li class="L2408" rel="L2408">not obtained one infamous notoriety that has since attached to it.</li>
<li class="L2409" rel="L2409">But, the gaol was a vile place, in which most kinds of debauchery and</li>
<li class="L2410" rel="L2410">villainy were practised, and where dire diseases were bred, that came</li>
<li class="L2411" rel="L2411">into court with the prisoners, and sometimes rushed straight from the</li>
<li class="L2412" rel="L2412">dock at my Lord Chief Justice himself, and pulled him off the bench. It</li>
<li class="L2413" rel="L2413">had more than once happened, that the Judge in the black cap pronounced</li>
<li class="L2414" rel="L2414">his own doom as certainly as the prisoner&#39;s, and even died before him.</li>
<li class="L2415" rel="L2415">For the rest, the Old Bailey was famous as a kind of deadly inn-yard,</li>
<li class="L2416" rel="L2416">from which pale travellers set out continually, in carts and coaches, on</li>
<li class="L2417" rel="L2417">a violent passage into the other world: traversing some two miles and a</li>
<li class="L2418" rel="L2418">half of public street and road, and shaming few good citizens, if any.</li>
<li class="L2419" rel="L2419">So powerful is use, and so desirable to be good use in the beginning. It</li>
<li class="L2420" rel="L2420">was famous, too, for the pillory, a wise old institution, that inflicted</li>
<li class="L2421" rel="L2421">a punishment of which no one could foresee the extent; also, for</li>
<li class="L2422" rel="L2422">the whipping-post, another dear old institution, very humanising and</li>
<li class="L2423" rel="L2423">softening to behold in action; also, for extensive transactions in</li>
<li class="L2424" rel="L2424">blood-money, another fragment of ancestral wisdom, systematically</li>
<li class="L2425" rel="L2425">leading to the most frightful mercenary crimes that could be committed</li>
<li class="L2426" rel="L2426">under Heaven. Altogether, the Old Bailey, at that date, was a choice</li>
<li class="L2427" rel="L2427">illustration of the precept, that “Whatever is is right;” an aphorism</li>
<li class="L2428" rel="L2428">that would be as final as it is lazy, did it not include the troublesome</li>
<li class="L2429" rel="L2429">consequence, that nothing that ever was, was wrong.</li>
<li class="L2430" rel="L2430"></li>
<li class="L2431" rel="L2431">Making his way through the tainted crowd, dispersed up and down this</li>
<li class="L2432" rel="L2432">hideous scene of action, with the skill of a man accustomed to make his</li>
<li class="L2433" rel="L2433">way quietly, the messenger found out the door he sought, and handed in</li>
<li class="L2434" rel="L2434">his letter through a trap in it. For, people then paid to see the play</li>
<li class="L2435" rel="L2435">at the Old Bailey, just as they paid to see the play in Bedlam--only the</li>
<li class="L2436" rel="L2436">former entertainment was much the dearer. Therefore, all the Old Bailey</li>
<li class="L2437" rel="L2437">doors were well guarded--except, indeed, the social doors by which the</li>
<li class="L2438" rel="L2438">criminals got there, and those were always left wide open.</li>
<li class="L2439" rel="L2439"></li>
<li class="L2440" rel="L2440">After some delay and demur, the door grudgingly turned on its hinges a</li>
<li class="L2441" rel="L2441">very little way, and allowed Mr. Jerry Cruncher to squeeze himself into</li>
<li class="L2442" rel="L2442">court.</li>
<li class="L2443" rel="L2443"></li>
<li class="L2444" rel="L2444">“What&#39;s on?” he asked, in a whisper, of the man he found himself next</li>
<li class="L2445" rel="L2445">to.</li>
<li class="L2446" rel="L2446"></li>
<li class="L2447" rel="L2447">“Nothing yet.”</li>
<li class="L2448" rel="L2448"></li>
<li class="L2449" rel="L2449">“What&#39;s coming on?”</li>
<li class="L2450" rel="L2450"></li>
<li class="L2451" rel="L2451">“The Treason case.”</li>
<li class="L2452" rel="L2452"></li>
<li class="L2453" rel="L2453">“The quartering one, eh?”</li>
<li class="L2454" rel="L2454"></li>
<li class="L2455" rel="L2455">“Ah!” returned the man, with a relish; “he&#39;ll be drawn on a hurdle to</li>
<li class="L2456" rel="L2456">be half hanged, and then he&#39;ll be taken down and sliced before his own</li>
<li class="L2457" rel="L2457">face, and then his inside will be taken out and burnt while he looks on,</li>
<li class="L2458" rel="L2458">and then his head will be chopped off, and he&#39;ll be cut into quarters.</li>
<li class="L2459" rel="L2459">That&#39;s the sentence.”</li>
<li class="L2460" rel="L2460"></li>
<li class="L2461" rel="L2461">“If he&#39;s found Guilty, you mean to say?” Jerry added, by way of proviso.</li>
<li class="L2462" rel="L2462"></li>
<li class="L2463" rel="L2463">“Oh! they&#39;ll find him guilty,” said the other. “Don&#39;t you be afraid of</li>
<li class="L2464" rel="L2464">that.”</li>
<li class="L2465" rel="L2465"></li>
<li class="L2466" rel="L2466">Mr. Cruncher&#39;s attention was here diverted to the door-keeper, whom he</li>
<li class="L2467" rel="L2467">saw making his way to Mr. Lorry, with the note in his hand. Mr. Lorry</li>
<li class="L2468" rel="L2468">sat at a table, among the gentlemen in wigs: not far from a wigged</li>
<li class="L2469" rel="L2469">gentleman, the prisoner&#39;s counsel, who had a great bundle of papers</li>
<li class="L2470" rel="L2470">before him: and nearly opposite another wigged gentleman with his hands</li>
<li class="L2471" rel="L2471">in his pockets, whose whole attention, when Mr. Cruncher looked at him</li>
<li class="L2472" rel="L2472">then or afterwards, seemed to be concentrated on the ceiling of the</li>
<li class="L2473" rel="L2473">court. After some gruff coughing and rubbing of his chin and signing</li>
<li class="L2474" rel="L2474">with his hand, Jerry attracted the notice of Mr. Lorry, who had stood up</li>
<li class="L2475" rel="L2475">to look for him, and who quietly nodded and sat down again.</li>
<li class="L2476" rel="L2476"></li>
<li class="L2477" rel="L2477">“What&#39;s _he_ got to do with the case?” asked the man he had spoken with.</li>
<li class="L2478" rel="L2478"></li>
<li class="L2479" rel="L2479">“Blest if I know,” said Jerry.</li>
<li class="L2480" rel="L2480"></li>
<li class="L2481" rel="L2481">“What have _you_ got to do with it, then, if a person may inquire?”</li>
<li class="L2482" rel="L2482"></li>
<li class="L2483" rel="L2483">“Blest if I know that either,” said Jerry.</li>
<li class="L2484" rel="L2484"></li>
<li class="L2485" rel="L2485">The entrance of the Judge, and a consequent great stir and settling</li>
<li class="L2486" rel="L2486">down in the court, stopped the dialogue. Presently, the dock became the</li>
<li class="L2487" rel="L2487">central point of interest. Two gaolers, who had been standing there,</li>
<li class="L2488" rel="L2488">went out, and the prisoner was brought in, and put to the bar.</li>
<li class="L2489" rel="L2489"></li>
<li class="L2490" rel="L2490">Everybody present, except the one wigged gentleman who looked at the</li>
<li class="L2491" rel="L2491">ceiling, stared at him. All the human breath in the place, rolled</li>
<li class="L2492" rel="L2492">at him, like a sea, or a wind, or a fire. Eager faces strained round</li>
<li class="L2493" rel="L2493">pillars and corners, to get a sight of him; spectators in back rows</li>
<li class="L2494" rel="L2494">stood up, not to miss a hair of him; people on the floor of the court,</li>
<li class="L2495" rel="L2495">laid their hands on the shoulders of the people before them, to help</li>
<li class="L2496" rel="L2496">themselves, at anybody&#39;s cost, to a view of him--stood a-tiptoe, got</li>
<li class="L2497" rel="L2497">upon ledges, stood upon next to nothing, to see every inch of him.</li>
<li class="L2498" rel="L2498">Conspicuous among these latter, like an animated bit of the spiked wall</li>
<li class="L2499" rel="L2499">of Newgate, Jerry stood: aiming at the prisoner the beery breath of a</li>
<li class="L2500" rel="L2500">whet he had taken as he came along, and discharging it to mingle with</li>
<li class="L2501" rel="L2501">the waves of other beer, and gin, and tea, and coffee, and what not,</li>
<li class="L2502" rel="L2502">that flowed at him, and already broke upon the great windows behind him</li>
<li class="L2503" rel="L2503">in an impure mist and rain.</li>
<li class="L2504" rel="L2504"></li>
<li class="L2505" rel="L2505">The object of all this staring and blaring, was a young man of about</li>
<li class="L2506" rel="L2506">five-and-twenty, well-grown and well-looking, with a sunburnt cheek and</li>
<li class="L2507" rel="L2507">a dark eye. His condition was that of a young gentleman. He was plainly</li>
<li class="L2508" rel="L2508">dressed in black, or very dark grey, and his hair, which was long and</li>
<li class="L2509" rel="L2509">dark, was gathered in a ribbon at the back of his neck; more to be out</li>
<li class="L2510" rel="L2510">of his way than for ornament. As an emotion of the mind will express</li>
<li class="L2511" rel="L2511">itself through any covering of the body, so the paleness which his</li>
<li class="L2512" rel="L2512">situation engendered came through the brown upon his cheek, showing the</li>
<li class="L2513" rel="L2513">soul to be stronger than the sun. He was otherwise quite self-possessed,</li>
<li class="L2514" rel="L2514">bowed to the Judge, and stood quiet.</li>
<li class="L2515" rel="L2515"></li>
<li class="L2516" rel="L2516">The sort of interest with which this man was stared and breathed at,</li>
<li class="L2517" rel="L2517">was not a sort that elevated humanity. Had he stood in peril of a less</li>
<li class="L2518" rel="L2518">horrible sentence--had there been a chance of any one of its savage</li>
<li class="L2519" rel="L2519">details being spared--by just so much would he have lost in his</li>
<li class="L2520" rel="L2520">fascination. The form that was to be doomed to be so shamefully mangled,</li>
<li class="L2521" rel="L2521">was the sight; the immortal creature that was to be so butchered</li>
<li class="L2522" rel="L2522">and torn asunder, yielded the sensation. Whatever gloss the various</li>
<li class="L2523" rel="L2523">spectators put upon the interest, according to their several arts and</li>
<li class="L2524" rel="L2524">powers of self-deceit, the interest was, at the root of it, Ogreish.</li>
<li class="L2525" rel="L2525"></li>
<li class="L2526" rel="L2526">Silence in the court! Charles Darnay had yesterday pleaded Not Guilty to</li>
<li class="L2527" rel="L2527">an indictment denouncing him (with infinite jingle and jangle) for that</li>
<li class="L2528" rel="L2528">he was a false traitor to our serene, illustrious, excellent, and so</li>
<li class="L2529" rel="L2529">forth, prince, our Lord the King, by reason of his having, on divers</li>
<li class="L2530" rel="L2530">occasions, and by divers means and ways, assisted Lewis, the French</li>
<li class="L2531" rel="L2531">King, in his wars against our said serene, illustrious, excellent, and</li>
<li class="L2532" rel="L2532">so forth; that was to say, by coming and going, between the dominions of</li>
<li class="L2533" rel="L2533">our said serene, illustrious, excellent, and so forth, and those of the</li>
<li class="L2534" rel="L2534">said French Lewis, and wickedly, falsely, traitorously, and otherwise</li>
<li class="L2535" rel="L2535">evil-adverbiously, revealing to the said French Lewis what forces our</li>
<li class="L2536" rel="L2536">said serene, illustrious, excellent, and so forth, had in preparation</li>
<li class="L2537" rel="L2537">to send to Canada and North America. This much, Jerry, with his head</li>
<li class="L2538" rel="L2538">becoming more and more spiky as the law terms bristled it, made out with</li>
<li class="L2539" rel="L2539">huge satisfaction, and so arrived circuitously at the understanding that</li>
<li class="L2540" rel="L2540">the aforesaid, and over and over again aforesaid, Charles Darnay, stood</li>
<li class="L2541" rel="L2541">there before him upon his trial; that the jury were swearing in; and</li>
<li class="L2542" rel="L2542">that Mr. Attorney-General was making ready to speak.</li>
<li class="L2543" rel="L2543"></li>
<li class="L2544" rel="L2544">The accused, who was (and who knew he was) being mentally hanged,</li>
<li class="L2545" rel="L2545">beheaded, and quartered, by everybody there, neither flinched from</li>
<li class="L2546" rel="L2546">the situation, nor assumed any theatrical air in it. He was quiet and</li>
<li class="L2547" rel="L2547">attentive; watched the opening proceedings with a grave interest;</li>
<li class="L2548" rel="L2548">and stood with his hands resting on the slab of wood before him, so</li>
<li class="L2549" rel="L2549">composedly, that they had not displaced a leaf of the herbs with which</li>
<li class="L2550" rel="L2550">it was strewn. The court was all bestrewn with herbs and sprinkled with</li>
<li class="L2551" rel="L2551">vinegar, as a precaution against gaol air and gaol fever.</li>
<li class="L2552" rel="L2552"></li>
<li class="L2553" rel="L2553">Over the prisoner&#39;s head there was a mirror, to throw the light down</li>
<li class="L2554" rel="L2554">upon him. Crowds of the wicked and the wretched had been reflected in</li>
<li class="L2555" rel="L2555">it, and had passed from its surface and this earth&#39;s together. Haunted</li>
<li class="L2556" rel="L2556">in a most ghastly manner that abominable place would have been, if the</li>
<li class="L2557" rel="L2557">glass could ever have rendered back its reflections, as the ocean is one</li>
<li class="L2558" rel="L2558">day to give up its dead. Some passing thought of the infamy and disgrace</li>
<li class="L2559" rel="L2559">for which it had been reserved, may have struck the prisoner&#39;s mind. Be</li>
<li class="L2560" rel="L2560">that as it may, a change in his position making him conscious of a bar</li>
<li class="L2561" rel="L2561">of light across his face, he looked up; and when he saw the glass his</li>
<li class="L2562" rel="L2562">face flushed, and his right hand pushed the herbs away.</li>
<li class="L2563" rel="L2563"></li>
<li class="L2564" rel="L2564">It happened, that the action turned his face to that side of the court</li>
<li class="L2565" rel="L2565">which was on his left. About on a level with his eyes, there sat,</li>
<li class="L2566" rel="L2566">in that corner of the Judge&#39;s bench, two persons upon whom his look</li>
<li class="L2567" rel="L2567">immediately rested; so immediately, and so much to the changing of his</li>
<li class="L2568" rel="L2568">aspect, that all the eyes that were turned upon him, turned to them.</li>
<li class="L2569" rel="L2569"></li>
<li class="L2570" rel="L2570">The spectators saw in the two figures, a young lady of little more than</li>
<li class="L2571" rel="L2571">twenty, and a gentleman who was evidently her father; a man of a very</li>
<li class="L2572" rel="L2572">remarkable appearance in respect of the absolute whiteness of his hair,</li>
<li class="L2573" rel="L2573">and a certain indescribable intensity of face: not of an active kind,</li>
<li class="L2574" rel="L2574">but pondering and self-communing. When this expression was upon him, he</li>
<li class="L2575" rel="L2575">looked as if he were old; but when it was stirred and broken up--as</li>
<li class="L2576" rel="L2576">it was now, in a moment, on his speaking to his daughter--he became a</li>
<li class="L2577" rel="L2577">handsome man, not past the prime of life.</li>
<li class="L2578" rel="L2578"></li>
<li class="L2579" rel="L2579">His daughter had one of her hands drawn through his arm, as she sat by</li>
<li class="L2580" rel="L2580">him, and the other pressed upon it. She had drawn close to him, in her</li>
<li class="L2581" rel="L2581">dread of the scene, and in her pity for the prisoner. Her forehead had</li>
<li class="L2582" rel="L2582">been strikingly expressive of an engrossing terror and compassion</li>
<li class="L2583" rel="L2583">that saw nothing but the peril of the accused. This had been so very</li>
<li class="L2584" rel="L2584">noticeable, so very powerfully and naturally shown, that starers who</li>
<li class="L2585" rel="L2585">had had no pity for him were touched by her; and the whisper went about,</li>
<li class="L2586" rel="L2586">“Who are they?”</li>
<li class="L2587" rel="L2587"></li>
<li class="L2588" rel="L2588">Jerry, the messenger, who had made his own observations, in his own</li>
<li class="L2589" rel="L2589">manner, and who had been sucking the rust off his fingers in his</li>
<li class="L2590" rel="L2590">absorption, stretched his neck to hear who they were. The crowd about</li>
<li class="L2591" rel="L2591">him had pressed and passed the inquiry on to the nearest attendant, and</li>
<li class="L2592" rel="L2592">from him it had been more slowly pressed and passed back; at last it got</li>
<li class="L2593" rel="L2593">to Jerry:</li>
<li class="L2594" rel="L2594"></li>
<li class="L2595" rel="L2595">“Witnesses.”</li>
<li class="L2596" rel="L2596"></li>
<li class="L2597" rel="L2597">“For which side?”</li>
<li class="L2598" rel="L2598"></li>
<li class="L2599" rel="L2599">“Against.”</li>
<li class="L2600" rel="L2600"></li>
<li class="L2601" rel="L2601">“Against what side?”</li>
<li class="L2602" rel="L2602"></li>
<li class="L2603" rel="L2603">“The prisoner&#39;s.”</li>
<li class="L2604" rel="L2604"></li>
<li class="L2605" rel="L2605">The Judge, whose eyes had gone in the general direction, recalled them,</li>
<li class="L2606" rel="L2606">leaned back in his seat, and looked steadily at the man whose life was</li>
<li class="L2607" rel="L2607">in his hand, as Mr. Attorney-General rose to spin the rope, grind the</li>
<li class="L2608" rel="L2608">axe, and hammer the nails into the scaffold.</li>
<li class="L2609" rel="L2609"></li>
<li class="L2610" rel="L2610"></li>
<li class="L2611" rel="L2611"></li>
<li class="L2612" rel="L2612"></li>
<li class="L2613" rel="L2613">III. A Disappointment</li>
<li class="L2614" rel="L2614"></li>
<li class="L2615" rel="L2615"></li>
<li class="L2616" rel="L2616">Mr. Attorney-General had to inform the jury, that the prisoner before</li>
<li class="L2617" rel="L2617">them, though young in years, was old in the treasonable practices which</li>
<li class="L2618" rel="L2618">claimed the forfeit of his life. That this correspondence with the</li>
<li class="L2619" rel="L2619">public enemy was not a correspondence of to-day, or of yesterday, or</li>
<li class="L2620" rel="L2620">even of last year, or of the year before. That, it was certain the</li>
<li class="L2621" rel="L2621">prisoner had, for longer than that, been in the habit of passing and</li>
<li class="L2622" rel="L2622">repassing between France and England, on secret business of which</li>
<li class="L2623" rel="L2623">he could give no honest account. That, if it were in the nature of</li>
<li class="L2624" rel="L2624">traitorous ways to thrive (which happily it never was), the real</li>
<li class="L2625" rel="L2625">wickedness and guilt of his business might have remained undiscovered.</li>
<li class="L2626" rel="L2626">That Providence, however, had put it into the heart of a person who</li>
<li class="L2627" rel="L2627">was beyond fear and beyond reproach, to ferret out the nature of the</li>
<li class="L2628" rel="L2628">prisoner&#39;s schemes, and, struck with horror, to disclose them to his</li>
<li class="L2629" rel="L2629">Majesty&#39;s Chief Secretary of State and most honourable Privy Council.</li>
<li class="L2630" rel="L2630">That, this patriot would be produced before them. That, his position and</li>
<li class="L2631" rel="L2631">attitude were, on the whole, sublime. That, he had been the prisoner&#39;s</li>
<li class="L2632" rel="L2632">friend, but, at once in an auspicious and an evil hour detecting his</li>
<li class="L2633" rel="L2633">infamy, had resolved to immolate the traitor he could no longer cherish</li>
<li class="L2634" rel="L2634">in his bosom, on the sacred altar of his country. That, if statues</li>
<li class="L2635" rel="L2635">were decreed in Britain, as in ancient Greece and Rome, to public</li>
<li class="L2636" rel="L2636">benefactors, this shining citizen would assuredly have had one. That, as</li>
<li class="L2637" rel="L2637">they were not so decreed, he probably would not have one. That, Virtue,</li>
<li class="L2638" rel="L2638">as had been observed by the poets (in many passages which he well</li>
<li class="L2639" rel="L2639">knew the jury would have, word for word, at the tips of their tongues;</li>
<li class="L2640" rel="L2640">whereat the jury&#39;s countenances displayed a guilty consciousness that</li>
<li class="L2641" rel="L2641">they knew nothing about the passages), was in a manner contagious; more</li>
<li class="L2642" rel="L2642">especially the bright virtue known as patriotism, or love of country.</li>
<li class="L2643" rel="L2643">That, the lofty example of this immaculate and unimpeachable witness</li>
<li class="L2644" rel="L2644">for the Crown, to refer to whom however unworthily was an honour, had</li>
<li class="L2645" rel="L2645">communicated itself to the prisoner&#39;s servant, and had engendered in him</li>
<li class="L2646" rel="L2646">a holy determination to examine his master&#39;s table-drawers and pockets,</li>
<li class="L2647" rel="L2647">and secrete his papers. That, he (Mr. Attorney-General) was prepared to</li>
<li class="L2648" rel="L2648">hear some disparagement attempted of this admirable servant; but that,</li>
<li class="L2649" rel="L2649">in a general way, he preferred him to his (Mr. Attorney-General&#39;s)</li>
<li class="L2650" rel="L2650">brothers and sisters, and honoured him more than his (Mr.</li>
<li class="L2651" rel="L2651">Attorney-General&#39;s) father and mother. That, he called with confidence</li>
<li class="L2652" rel="L2652">on the jury to come and do likewise. That, the evidence of these two</li>
<li class="L2653" rel="L2653">witnesses, coupled with the documents of their discovering that would be</li>
<li class="L2654" rel="L2654">produced, would show the prisoner to have been furnished with lists of</li>
<li class="L2655" rel="L2655">his Majesty&#39;s forces, and of their disposition and preparation, both by</li>
<li class="L2656" rel="L2656">sea and land, and would leave no doubt that he had habitually conveyed</li>
<li class="L2657" rel="L2657">such information to a hostile power. That, these lists could not be</li>
<li class="L2658" rel="L2658">proved to be in the prisoner&#39;s handwriting; but that it was all the</li>
<li class="L2659" rel="L2659">same; that, indeed, it was rather the better for the prosecution, as</li>
<li class="L2660" rel="L2660">showing the prisoner to be artful in his precautions. That, the proof</li>
<li class="L2661" rel="L2661">would go back five years, and would show the prisoner already engaged</li>
<li class="L2662" rel="L2662">in these pernicious missions, within a few weeks before the date of the</li>
<li class="L2663" rel="L2663">very first action fought between the British troops and the Americans.</li>
<li class="L2664" rel="L2664">That, for these reasons, the jury, being a loyal jury (as he knew they</li>
<li class="L2665" rel="L2665">were), and being a responsible jury (as _they_ knew they were), must</li>
<li class="L2666" rel="L2666">positively find the prisoner Guilty, and make an end of him, whether</li>
<li class="L2667" rel="L2667">they liked it or not. That, they never could lay their heads upon their</li>
<li class="L2668" rel="L2668">pillows; that, they never could tolerate the idea of their wives laying</li>
<li class="L2669" rel="L2669">their heads upon their pillows; that, they never could endure the notion</li>
<li class="L2670" rel="L2670">of their children laying their heads upon their pillows; in short, that</li>
<li class="L2671" rel="L2671">there never more could be, for them or theirs, any laying of heads upon</li>
<li class="L2672" rel="L2672">pillows at all, unless the prisoner&#39;s head was taken off. That head</li>
<li class="L2673" rel="L2673">Mr. Attorney-General concluded by demanding of them, in the name of</li>
<li class="L2674" rel="L2674">everything he could think of with a round turn in it, and on the faith</li>
<li class="L2675" rel="L2675">of his solemn asseveration that he already considered the prisoner as</li>
<li class="L2676" rel="L2676">good as dead and gone.</li>
<li class="L2677" rel="L2677"></li>
<li class="L2678" rel="L2678">When the Attorney-General ceased, a buzz arose in the court as if</li>
<li class="L2679" rel="L2679">a cloud of great blue-flies were swarming about the prisoner, in</li>
<li class="L2680" rel="L2680">anticipation of what he was soon to become. When toned down again, the</li>
<li class="L2681" rel="L2681">unimpeachable patriot appeared in the witness-box.</li>
<li class="L2682" rel="L2682"></li>
<li class="L2683" rel="L2683">Mr. Solicitor-General then, following his leader&#39;s lead, examined the</li>
<li class="L2684" rel="L2684">patriot: John Barsad, gentleman, by name. The story of his pure soul was</li>
<li class="L2685" rel="L2685">exactly what Mr. Attorney-General had described it to be--perhaps, if</li>
<li class="L2686" rel="L2686">it had a fault, a little too exactly. Having released his noble bosom</li>
<li class="L2687" rel="L2687">of its burden, he would have modestly withdrawn himself, but that the</li>
<li class="L2688" rel="L2688">wigged gentleman with the papers before him, sitting not far from Mr.</li>
<li class="L2689" rel="L2689">Lorry, begged to ask him a few questions. The wigged gentleman sitting</li>
<li class="L2690" rel="L2690">opposite, still looking at the ceiling of the court.</li>
<li class="L2691" rel="L2691"></li>
<li class="L2692" rel="L2692">Had he ever been a spy himself? No, he scorned the base insinuation.</li>
<li class="L2693" rel="L2693">What did he live upon? His property. Where was his property? He didn&#39;t</li>
<li class="L2694" rel="L2694">precisely remember where it was. What was it? No business of anybody&#39;s.</li>
<li class="L2695" rel="L2695">Had he inherited it? Yes, he had. From whom? Distant relation. Very</li>
<li class="L2696" rel="L2696">distant? Rather. Ever been in prison? Certainly not. Never in a debtors&#39;</li>
<li class="L2697" rel="L2697">prison? Didn&#39;t see what that had to do with it. Never in a debtors&#39;</li>
<li class="L2698" rel="L2698">prison?--Come, once again. Never? Yes. How many times? Two or three</li>
<li class="L2699" rel="L2699">times. Not five or six? Perhaps. Of what profession? Gentleman. Ever</li>
<li class="L2700" rel="L2700">been kicked? Might have been. Frequently? No. Ever kicked downstairs?</li>
<li class="L2701" rel="L2701">Decidedly not; once received a kick on the top of a staircase, and fell</li>
<li class="L2702" rel="L2702">downstairs of his own accord. Kicked on that occasion for cheating at</li>
<li class="L2703" rel="L2703">dice? Something to that effect was said by the intoxicated liar who</li>
<li class="L2704" rel="L2704">committed the assault, but it was not true. Swear it was not true?</li>
<li class="L2705" rel="L2705">Positively. Ever live by cheating at play? Never. Ever live by play? Not</li>
<li class="L2706" rel="L2706">more than other gentlemen do. Ever borrow money of the prisoner? Yes.</li>
<li class="L2707" rel="L2707">Ever pay him? No. Was not this intimacy with the prisoner, in reality a</li>
<li class="L2708" rel="L2708">very slight one, forced upon the prisoner in coaches, inns, and packets?</li>
<li class="L2709" rel="L2709">No. Sure he saw the prisoner with these lists? Certain. Knew no more</li>
<li class="L2710" rel="L2710">about the lists? No. Had not procured them himself, for instance? No.</li>
<li class="L2711" rel="L2711">Expect to get anything by this evidence? No. Not in regular government</li>
<li class="L2712" rel="L2712">pay and employment, to lay traps? Oh dear no. Or to do anything? Oh dear</li>
<li class="L2713" rel="L2713">no. Swear that? Over and over again. No motives but motives of sheer</li>
<li class="L2714" rel="L2714">patriotism? None whatever.</li>
<li class="L2715" rel="L2715"></li>
<li class="L2716" rel="L2716">The virtuous servant, Roger Cly, swore his way through the case at a</li>
<li class="L2717" rel="L2717">great rate. He had taken service with the prisoner, in good faith and</li>
<li class="L2718" rel="L2718">simplicity, four years ago. He had asked the prisoner, aboard the Calais</li>
<li class="L2719" rel="L2719">packet, if he wanted a handy fellow, and the prisoner had engaged him.</li>
<li class="L2720" rel="L2720">He had not asked the prisoner to take the handy fellow as an act of</li>
<li class="L2721" rel="L2721">charity--never thought of such a thing. He began to have suspicions of</li>
<li class="L2722" rel="L2722">the prisoner, and to keep an eye upon him, soon afterwards. In arranging</li>
<li class="L2723" rel="L2723">his clothes, while travelling, he had seen similar lists to these in the</li>
<li class="L2724" rel="L2724">prisoner&#39;s pockets, over and over again. He had taken these lists from</li>
<li class="L2725" rel="L2725">the drawer of the prisoner&#39;s desk. He had not put them there first. He</li>
<li class="L2726" rel="L2726">had seen the prisoner show these identical lists to French gentlemen</li>
<li class="L2727" rel="L2727">at Calais, and similar lists to French gentlemen, both at Calais and</li>
<li class="L2728" rel="L2728">Boulogne. He loved his country, and couldn&#39;t bear it, and had given</li>
<li class="L2729" rel="L2729">information. He had never been suspected of stealing a silver tea-pot;</li>
<li class="L2730" rel="L2730">he had been maligned respecting a mustard-pot, but it turned out to be</li>
<li class="L2731" rel="L2731">only a plated one. He had known the last witness seven or eight years;</li>
<li class="L2732" rel="L2732">that was merely a coincidence. He didn&#39;t call it a particularly curious</li>
<li class="L2733" rel="L2733">coincidence; most coincidences were curious. Neither did he call it a</li>
<li class="L2734" rel="L2734">curious coincidence that true patriotism was _his_ only motive too. He</li>
<li class="L2735" rel="L2735">was a true Briton, and hoped there were many like him.</li>
<li class="L2736" rel="L2736"></li>
<li class="L2737" rel="L2737">The blue-flies buzzed again, and Mr. Attorney-General called Mr. Jarvis</li>
<li class="L2738" rel="L2738">Lorry.</li>
<li class="L2739" rel="L2739"></li>
<li class="L2740" rel="L2740">“Mr. Jarvis Lorry, are you a clerk in Tellson&#39;s bank?”</li>
<li class="L2741" rel="L2741"></li>
<li class="L2742" rel="L2742">“I am.”</li>
<li class="L2743" rel="L2743"></li>
<li class="L2744" rel="L2744">“On a certain Friday night in November one thousand seven hundred and</li>
<li class="L2745" rel="L2745">seventy-five, did business occasion you to travel between London and</li>
<li class="L2746" rel="L2746">Dover by the mail?”</li>
<li class="L2747" rel="L2747"></li>
<li class="L2748" rel="L2748">“It did.”</li>
<li class="L2749" rel="L2749"></li>
<li class="L2750" rel="L2750">“Were there any other passengers in the mail?”</li>
<li class="L2751" rel="L2751"></li>
<li class="L2752" rel="L2752">“Two.”</li>
<li class="L2753" rel="L2753"></li>
<li class="L2754" rel="L2754">“Did they alight on the road in the course of the night?”</li>
<li class="L2755" rel="L2755"></li>
<li class="L2756" rel="L2756">“They did.”</li>
<li class="L2757" rel="L2757"></li>
<li class="L2758" rel="L2758">“Mr. Lorry, look upon the prisoner. Was he one of those two passengers?”</li>
<li class="L2759" rel="L2759"></li>
<li class="L2760" rel="L2760">“I cannot undertake to say that he was.”</li>
<li class="L2761" rel="L2761"></li>
<li class="L2762" rel="L2762">“Does he resemble either of these two passengers?”</li>
<li class="L2763" rel="L2763"></li>
<li class="L2764" rel="L2764">“Both were so wrapped up, and the night was so dark, and we were all so</li>
<li class="L2765" rel="L2765">reserved, that I cannot undertake to say even that.”</li>
<li class="L2766" rel="L2766"></li>
<li class="L2767" rel="L2767">“Mr. Lorry, look again upon the prisoner. Supposing him wrapped up as</li>
<li class="L2768" rel="L2768">those two passengers were, is there anything in his bulk and stature to</li>
<li class="L2769" rel="L2769">render it unlikely that he was one of them?”</li>
<li class="L2770" rel="L2770"></li>
<li class="L2771" rel="L2771">“No.”</li>
<li class="L2772" rel="L2772"></li>
<li class="L2773" rel="L2773">“You will not swear, Mr. Lorry, that he was not one of them?”</li>
<li class="L2774" rel="L2774"></li>
<li class="L2775" rel="L2775">“No.”</li>
<li class="L2776" rel="L2776"></li>
<li class="L2777" rel="L2777">“So at least you say he may have been one of them?”</li>
<li class="L2778" rel="L2778"></li>
<li class="L2779" rel="L2779">“Yes. Except that I remember them both to have been--like</li>
<li class="L2780" rel="L2780">myself--timorous of highwaymen, and the prisoner has not a timorous</li>
<li class="L2781" rel="L2781">air.”</li>
<li class="L2782" rel="L2782"></li>
<li class="L2783" rel="L2783">“Did you ever see a counterfeit of timidity, Mr. Lorry?”</li>
<li class="L2784" rel="L2784"></li>
<li class="L2785" rel="L2785">“I certainly have seen that.”</li>
<li class="L2786" rel="L2786"></li>
<li class="L2787" rel="L2787">“Mr. Lorry, look once more upon the prisoner. Have you seen him, to your</li>
<li class="L2788" rel="L2788">certain knowledge, before?”</li>
<li class="L2789" rel="L2789"></li>
<li class="L2790" rel="L2790">“I have.”</li>
<li class="L2791" rel="L2791"></li>
<li class="L2792" rel="L2792">“When?”</li>
<li class="L2793" rel="L2793"></li>
<li class="L2794" rel="L2794">“I was returning from France a few days afterwards, and, at Calais, the</li>
<li class="L2795" rel="L2795">prisoner came on board the packet-ship in which I returned, and made the</li>
<li class="L2796" rel="L2796">voyage with me.”</li>
<li class="L2797" rel="L2797"></li>
<li class="L2798" rel="L2798">“At what hour did he come on board?”</li>
<li class="L2799" rel="L2799"></li>
<li class="L2800" rel="L2800">“At a little after midnight.”</li>
<li class="L2801" rel="L2801"></li>
<li class="L2802" rel="L2802">“In the dead of the night. Was he the only passenger who came on board</li>
<li class="L2803" rel="L2803">at that untimely hour?”</li>
<li class="L2804" rel="L2804"></li>
<li class="L2805" rel="L2805">“He happened to be the only one.”</li>
<li class="L2806" rel="L2806"></li>
<li class="L2807" rel="L2807">“Never mind about &#39;happening,&#39; Mr. Lorry. He was the only passenger who</li>
<li class="L2808" rel="L2808">came on board in the dead of the night?”</li>
<li class="L2809" rel="L2809"></li>
<li class="L2810" rel="L2810">“He was.”</li>
<li class="L2811" rel="L2811"></li>
<li class="L2812" rel="L2812">“Were you travelling alone, Mr. Lorry, or with any companion?”</li>
<li class="L2813" rel="L2813"></li>
<li class="L2814" rel="L2814">“With two companions. A gentleman and lady. They are here.”</li>
<li class="L2815" rel="L2815"></li>
<li class="L2816" rel="L2816">“They are here. Had you any conversation with the prisoner?”</li>
<li class="L2817" rel="L2817"></li>
<li class="L2818" rel="L2818">“Hardly any. The weather was stormy, and the passage long and rough, and</li>
<li class="L2819" rel="L2819">I lay on a sofa, almost from shore to shore.”</li>
<li class="L2820" rel="L2820"></li>
<li class="L2821" rel="L2821">“Miss Manette!”</li>
<li class="L2822" rel="L2822"></li>
<li class="L2823" rel="L2823">The young lady, to whom all eyes had been turned before, and were now</li>
<li class="L2824" rel="L2824">turned again, stood up where she had sat. Her father rose with her, and</li>
<li class="L2825" rel="L2825">kept her hand drawn through his arm.</li>
<li class="L2826" rel="L2826"></li>
<li class="L2827" rel="L2827">“Miss Manette, look upon the prisoner.”</li>
<li class="L2828" rel="L2828"></li>
<li class="L2829" rel="L2829">To be confronted with such pity, and such earnest youth and beauty, was</li>
<li class="L2830" rel="L2830">far more trying to the accused than to be confronted with all the crowd.</li>
<li class="L2831" rel="L2831">Standing, as it were, apart with her on the edge of his grave, not all</li>
<li class="L2832" rel="L2832">the staring curiosity that looked on, could, for the moment, nerve him</li>
<li class="L2833" rel="L2833">to remain quite still. His hurried right hand parcelled out the herbs</li>
<li class="L2834" rel="L2834">before him into imaginary beds of flowers in a garden; and his efforts</li>
<li class="L2835" rel="L2835">to control and steady his breathing shook the lips from which the colour</li>
<li class="L2836" rel="L2836">rushed to his heart. The buzz of the great flies was loud again.</li>
<li class="L2837" rel="L2837"></li>
<li class="L2838" rel="L2838">“Miss Manette, have you seen the prisoner before?”</li>
<li class="L2839" rel="L2839"></li>
<li class="L2840" rel="L2840">“Yes, sir.”</li>
<li class="L2841" rel="L2841"></li>
<li class="L2842" rel="L2842">“Where?”</li>
<li class="L2843" rel="L2843"></li>
<li class="L2844" rel="L2844">“On board of the packet-ship just now referred to, sir, and on the same</li>
<li class="L2845" rel="L2845">occasion.”</li>
<li class="L2846" rel="L2846"></li>
<li class="L2847" rel="L2847">“You are the young lady just now referred to?”</li>
<li class="L2848" rel="L2848"></li>
<li class="L2849" rel="L2849">“O! most unhappily, I am!”</li>
<li class="L2850" rel="L2850"></li>
<li class="L2851" rel="L2851">The plaintive tone of her compassion merged into the less musical voice</li>
<li class="L2852" rel="L2852">of the Judge, as he said something fiercely: “Answer the questions put</li>
<li class="L2853" rel="L2853">to you, and make no remark upon them.”</li>
<li class="L2854" rel="L2854"></li>
<li class="L2855" rel="L2855">“Miss Manette, had you any conversation with the prisoner on that</li>
<li class="L2856" rel="L2856">passage across the Channel?”</li>
<li class="L2857" rel="L2857"></li>
<li class="L2858" rel="L2858">“Yes, sir.”</li>
<li class="L2859" rel="L2859"></li>
<li class="L2860" rel="L2860">“Recall it.”</li>
<li class="L2861" rel="L2861"></li>
<li class="L2862" rel="L2862">In the midst of a profound stillness, she faintly began: “When the</li>
<li class="L2863" rel="L2863">gentleman came on board--”</li>
<li class="L2864" rel="L2864"></li>
<li class="L2865" rel="L2865">“Do you mean the prisoner?” inquired the Judge, knitting his brows.</li>
<li class="L2866" rel="L2866"></li>
<li class="L2867" rel="L2867">“Yes, my Lord.”</li>
<li class="L2868" rel="L2868"></li>
<li class="L2869" rel="L2869">“Then say the prisoner.”</li>
<li class="L2870" rel="L2870"></li>
<li class="L2871" rel="L2871">“When the prisoner came on board, he noticed that my father,” turning</li>
<li class="L2872" rel="L2872">her eyes lovingly to him as he stood beside her, “was much fatigued</li>
<li class="L2873" rel="L2873">and in a very weak state of health. My father was so reduced that I was</li>
<li class="L2874" rel="L2874">afraid to take him out of the air, and I had made a bed for him on the</li>
<li class="L2875" rel="L2875">deck near the cabin steps, and I sat on the deck at his side to take</li>
<li class="L2876" rel="L2876">care of him. There were no other passengers that night, but we four.</li>
<li class="L2877" rel="L2877">The prisoner was so good as to beg permission to advise me how I could</li>
<li class="L2878" rel="L2878">shelter my father from the wind and weather, better than I had done. I</li>
<li class="L2879" rel="L2879">had not known how to do it well, not understanding how the wind would</li>
<li class="L2880" rel="L2880">set when we were out of the harbour. He did it for me. He expressed</li>
<li class="L2881" rel="L2881">great gentleness and kindness for my father&#39;s state, and I am sure he</li>
<li class="L2882" rel="L2882">felt it. That was the manner of our beginning to speak together.”</li>
<li class="L2883" rel="L2883"></li>
<li class="L2884" rel="L2884">“Let me interrupt you for a moment. Had he come on board alone?”</li>
<li class="L2885" rel="L2885"></li>
<li class="L2886" rel="L2886">“No.”</li>
<li class="L2887" rel="L2887"></li>
<li class="L2888" rel="L2888">“How many were with him?”</li>
<li class="L2889" rel="L2889"></li>
<li class="L2890" rel="L2890">“Two French gentlemen.”</li>
<li class="L2891" rel="L2891"></li>
<li class="L2892" rel="L2892">“Had they conferred together?”</li>
<li class="L2893" rel="L2893"></li>
<li class="L2894" rel="L2894">“They had conferred together until the last moment, when it was</li>
<li class="L2895" rel="L2895">necessary for the French gentlemen to be landed in their boat.”</li>
<li class="L2896" rel="L2896"></li>
<li class="L2897" rel="L2897">“Had any papers been handed about among them, similar to these lists?”</li>
<li class="L2898" rel="L2898"></li>
<li class="L2899" rel="L2899">“Some papers had been handed about among them, but I don&#39;t know what</li>
<li class="L2900" rel="L2900">papers.”</li>
<li class="L2901" rel="L2901"></li>
<li class="L2902" rel="L2902">“Like these in shape and size?”</li>
<li class="L2903" rel="L2903"></li>
<li class="L2904" rel="L2904">“Possibly, but indeed I don&#39;t know, although they stood whispering very</li>
<li class="L2905" rel="L2905">near to me: because they stood at the top of the cabin steps to have the</li>
<li class="L2906" rel="L2906">light of the lamp that was hanging there; it was a dull lamp, and they</li>
<li class="L2907" rel="L2907">spoke very low, and I did not hear what they said, and saw only that</li>
<li class="L2908" rel="L2908">they looked at papers.”</li>
<li class="L2909" rel="L2909"></li>
<li class="L2910" rel="L2910">“Now, to the prisoner&#39;s conversation, Miss Manette.”</li>
<li class="L2911" rel="L2911"></li>
<li class="L2912" rel="L2912">“The prisoner was as open in his confidence with me--which arose out</li>
<li class="L2913" rel="L2913">of my helpless situation--as he was kind, and good, and useful to my</li>
<li class="L2914" rel="L2914">father. I hope,” bursting into tears, “I may not repay him by doing him</li>
<li class="L2915" rel="L2915">harm to-day.”</li>
<li class="L2916" rel="L2916"></li>
<li class="L2917" rel="L2917">Buzzing from the blue-flies.</li>
<li class="L2918" rel="L2918"></li>
<li class="L2919" rel="L2919">“Miss Manette, if the prisoner does not perfectly understand that</li>
