<li class="L2920" rel="L2920">you give the evidence which it is your duty to give--which you must</li>
<li class="L2921" rel="L2921">give--and which you cannot escape from giving--with great unwillingness,</li>
<li class="L2922" rel="L2922">he is the only person present in that condition. Please to go on.”</li>
<li class="L2923" rel="L2923"></li>
<li class="L2924" rel="L2924">“He told me that he was travelling on business of a delicate and</li>
<li class="L2925" rel="L2925">difficult nature, which might get people into trouble, and that he was</li>
<li class="L2926" rel="L2926">therefore travelling under an assumed name. He said that this business</li>
<li class="L2927" rel="L2927">had, within a few days, taken him to France, and might, at intervals,</li>
<li class="L2928" rel="L2928">take him backwards and forwards between France and England for a long</li>
<li class="L2929" rel="L2929">time to come.”</li>
<li class="L2930" rel="L2930"></li>
<li class="L2931" rel="L2931">“Did he say anything about America, Miss Manette? Be particular.”</li>
<li class="L2932" rel="L2932"></li>
<li class="L2933" rel="L2933">“He tried to explain to me how that quarrel had arisen, and he said</li>
<li class="L2934" rel="L2934">that, so far as he could judge, it was a wrong and foolish one on</li>
<li class="L2935" rel="L2935">England&#39;s part. He added, in a jesting way, that perhaps George</li>
<li class="L2936" rel="L2936">Washington might gain almost as great a name in history as George the</li>
<li class="L2937" rel="L2937">Third. But there was no harm in his way of saying this: it was said</li>
<li class="L2938" rel="L2938">laughingly, and to beguile the time.”</li>
<li class="L2939" rel="L2939"></li>
<li class="L2940" rel="L2940">Any strongly marked expression of face on the part of a chief actor in</li>
<li class="L2941" rel="L2941">a scene of great interest to whom many eyes are directed, will be</li>
<li class="L2942" rel="L2942">unconsciously imitated by the spectators. Her forehead was painfully</li>
<li class="L2943" rel="L2943">anxious and intent as she gave this evidence, and, in the pauses when</li>
<li class="L2944" rel="L2944">she stopped for the Judge to write it down, watched its effect upon</li>
<li class="L2945" rel="L2945">the counsel for and against. Among the lookers-on there was the same</li>
<li class="L2946" rel="L2946">expression in all quarters of the court; insomuch, that a great majority</li>
<li class="L2947" rel="L2947">of the foreheads there, might have been mirrors reflecting the witness,</li>
<li class="L2948" rel="L2948">when the Judge looked up from his notes to glare at that tremendous</li>
<li class="L2949" rel="L2949">heresy about George Washington.</li>
<li class="L2950" rel="L2950"></li>
<li class="L2951" rel="L2951">Mr. Attorney-General now signified to my Lord, that he deemed it</li>
<li class="L2952" rel="L2952">necessary, as a matter of precaution and form, to call the young lady&#39;s</li>
<li class="L2953" rel="L2953">father, Doctor Manette. Who was called accordingly.</li>
<li class="L2954" rel="L2954"></li>
<li class="L2955" rel="L2955">“Doctor Manette, look upon the prisoner. Have you ever seen him before?”</li>
<li class="L2956" rel="L2956"></li>
<li class="L2957" rel="L2957">“Once. When he called at my lodgings in London. Some three years, or</li>
<li class="L2958" rel="L2958">three years and a half ago.”</li>
<li class="L2959" rel="L2959"></li>
<li class="L2960" rel="L2960">“Can you identify him as your fellow-passenger on board the packet, or</li>
<li class="L2961" rel="L2961">speak to his conversation with your daughter?”</li>
<li class="L2962" rel="L2962"></li>
<li class="L2963" rel="L2963">“Sir, I can do neither.”</li>
<li class="L2964" rel="L2964"></li>
<li class="L2965" rel="L2965">“Is there any particular and special reason for your being unable to do</li>
<li class="L2966" rel="L2966">either?”</li>
<li class="L2967" rel="L2967"></li>
<li class="L2968" rel="L2968">He answered, in a low voice, “There is.”</li>
<li class="L2969" rel="L2969"></li>
<li class="L2970" rel="L2970">“Has it been your misfortune to undergo a long imprisonment, without</li>
<li class="L2971" rel="L2971">trial, or even accusation, in your native country, Doctor Manette?”</li>
<li class="L2972" rel="L2972"></li>
<li class="L2973" rel="L2973">He answered, in a tone that went to every heart, “A long imprisonment.”</li>
<li class="L2974" rel="L2974"></li>
<li class="L2975" rel="L2975">“Were you newly released on the occasion in question?”</li>
<li class="L2976" rel="L2976"></li>
<li class="L2977" rel="L2977">“They tell me so.”</li>
<li class="L2978" rel="L2978"></li>
<li class="L2979" rel="L2979">“Have you no remembrance of the occasion?”</li>
<li class="L2980" rel="L2980"></li>
<li class="L2981" rel="L2981">“None. My mind is a blank, from some time--I cannot even say what</li>
<li class="L2982" rel="L2982">time--when I employed myself, in my captivity, in making shoes, to the</li>
<li class="L2983" rel="L2983">time when I found myself living in London with my dear daughter</li>
<li class="L2984" rel="L2984">here. She had become familiar to me, when a gracious God restored</li>
<li class="L2985" rel="L2985">my faculties; but, I am quite unable even to say how she had become</li>
<li class="L2986" rel="L2986">familiar. I have no remembrance of the process.”</li>
<li class="L2987" rel="L2987"></li>
<li class="L2988" rel="L2988">Mr. Attorney-General sat down, and the father and daughter sat down</li>
<li class="L2989" rel="L2989">together.</li>
<li class="L2990" rel="L2990"></li>
<li class="L2991" rel="L2991">A singular circumstance then arose in the case. The object in hand being</li>
<li class="L2992" rel="L2992">to show that the prisoner went down, with some fellow-plotter untracked,</li>
<li class="L2993" rel="L2993">in the Dover mail on that Friday night in November five years ago, and</li>
<li class="L2994" rel="L2994">got out of the mail in the night, as a blind, at a place where he did</li>
<li class="L2995" rel="L2995">not remain, but from which he travelled back some dozen miles or more,</li>
<li class="L2996" rel="L2996">to a garrison and dockyard, and there collected information; a witness</li>
<li class="L2997" rel="L2997">was called to identify him as having been at the precise time required,</li>
<li class="L2998" rel="L2998">in the coffee-room of an hotel in that garrison-and-dockyard town,</li>
<li class="L2999" rel="L2999">waiting for another person. The prisoner&#39;s counsel was cross-examining</li>
<li class="L3000" rel="L3000">this witness with no result, except that he had never seen the prisoner</li>
<li class="L3001" rel="L3001">on any other occasion, when the wigged gentleman who had all this time</li>
<li class="L3002" rel="L3002">been looking at the ceiling of the court, wrote a word or two on a</li>
<li class="L3003" rel="L3003">little piece of paper, screwed it up, and tossed it to him. Opening</li>
<li class="L3004" rel="L3004">this piece of paper in the next pause, the counsel looked with great</li>
<li class="L3005" rel="L3005">attention and curiosity at the prisoner.</li>
<li class="L3006" rel="L3006"></li>
<li class="L3007" rel="L3007">“You say again you are quite sure that it was the prisoner?”</li>
<li class="L3008" rel="L3008"></li>
<li class="L3009" rel="L3009">The witness was quite sure.</li>
<li class="L3010" rel="L3010"></li>
<li class="L3011" rel="L3011">“Did you ever see anybody very like the prisoner?”</li>
<li class="L3012" rel="L3012"></li>
<li class="L3013" rel="L3013">Not so like (the witness said) as that he could be mistaken.</li>
<li class="L3014" rel="L3014"></li>
<li class="L3015" rel="L3015">“Look well upon that gentleman, my learned friend there,” pointing</li>
<li class="L3016" rel="L3016">to him who had tossed the paper over, “and then look well upon the</li>
<li class="L3017" rel="L3017">prisoner. How say you? Are they very like each other?”</li>
<li class="L3018" rel="L3018"></li>
<li class="L3019" rel="L3019">Allowing for my learned friend&#39;s appearance being careless and slovenly</li>
<li class="L3020" rel="L3020">if not debauched, they were sufficiently like each other to surprise,</li>
<li class="L3021" rel="L3021">not only the witness, but everybody present, when they were thus brought</li>
<li class="L3022" rel="L3022">into comparison. My Lord being prayed to bid my learned friend lay aside</li>
<li class="L3023" rel="L3023">his wig, and giving no very gracious consent, the likeness became</li>
<li class="L3024" rel="L3024">much more remarkable. My Lord inquired of Mr. Stryver (the prisoner&#39;s</li>
<li class="L3025" rel="L3025">counsel), whether they were next to try Mr. Carton (name of my learned</li>
<li class="L3026" rel="L3026">friend) for treason? But, Mr. Stryver replied to my Lord, no; but he</li>
<li class="L3027" rel="L3027">would ask the witness to tell him whether what happened once, might</li>
<li class="L3028" rel="L3028">happen twice; whether he would have been so confident if he had seen</li>
<li class="L3029" rel="L3029">this illustration of his rashness sooner, whether he would be so</li>
<li class="L3030" rel="L3030">confident, having seen it; and more. The upshot of which, was, to smash</li>
<li class="L3031" rel="L3031">this witness like a crockery vessel, and shiver his part of the case to</li>
<li class="L3032" rel="L3032">useless lumber.</li>
<li class="L3033" rel="L3033"></li>
<li class="L3034" rel="L3034">Mr. Cruncher had by this time taken quite a lunch of rust off his</li>
<li class="L3035" rel="L3035">fingers in his following of the evidence. He had now to attend while Mr.</li>
<li class="L3036" rel="L3036">Stryver fitted the prisoner&#39;s case on the jury, like a compact suit</li>
<li class="L3037" rel="L3037">of clothes; showing them how the patriot, Barsad, was a hired spy and</li>
<li class="L3038" rel="L3038">traitor, an unblushing trafficker in blood, and one of the greatest</li>
<li class="L3039" rel="L3039">scoundrels upon earth since accursed Judas--which he certainly did look</li>
<li class="L3040" rel="L3040">rather like. How the virtuous servant, Cly, was his friend and partner,</li>
<li class="L3041" rel="L3041">and was worthy to be; how the watchful eyes of those forgers and false</li>
<li class="L3042" rel="L3042">swearers had rested on the prisoner as a victim, because some family</li>
<li class="L3043" rel="L3043">affairs in France, he being of French extraction, did require his making</li>
<li class="L3044" rel="L3044">those passages across the Channel--though what those affairs were, a</li>
<li class="L3045" rel="L3045">consideration for others who were near and dear to him, forbade him,</li>
<li class="L3046" rel="L3046">even for his life, to disclose. How the evidence that had been warped</li>
<li class="L3047" rel="L3047">and wrested from the young lady, whose anguish in giving it they</li>
<li class="L3048" rel="L3048">had witnessed, came to nothing, involving the mere little innocent</li>
<li class="L3049" rel="L3049">gallantries and politenesses likely to pass between any young gentleman</li>
<li class="L3050" rel="L3050">and young lady so thrown together;--with the exception of that</li>
<li class="L3051" rel="L3051">reference to George Washington, which was altogether too extravagant and</li>
<li class="L3052" rel="L3052">impossible to be regarded in any other light than as a monstrous joke.</li>
<li class="L3053" rel="L3053">How it would be a weakness in the government to break down in this</li>
<li class="L3054" rel="L3054">attempt to practise for popularity on the lowest national antipathies</li>
<li class="L3055" rel="L3055">and fears, and therefore Mr. Attorney-General had made the most of it;</li>
<li class="L3056" rel="L3056">how, nevertheless, it rested upon nothing, save that vile and infamous</li>
<li class="L3057" rel="L3057">character of evidence too often disfiguring such cases, and of which the</li>
<li class="L3058" rel="L3058">State Trials of this country were full. But, there my Lord interposed</li>
<li class="L3059" rel="L3059">(with as grave a face as if it had not been true), saying that he could</li>
<li class="L3060" rel="L3060">not sit upon that Bench and suffer those allusions.</li>
<li class="L3061" rel="L3061"></li>
<li class="L3062" rel="L3062">Mr. Stryver then called his few witnesses, and Mr. Cruncher had next to</li>
<li class="L3063" rel="L3063">attend while Mr. Attorney-General turned the whole suit of clothes Mr.</li>
<li class="L3064" rel="L3064">Stryver had fitted on the jury, inside out; showing how Barsad and</li>
<li class="L3065" rel="L3065">Cly were even a hundred times better than he had thought them, and the</li>
<li class="L3066" rel="L3066">prisoner a hundred times worse. Lastly, came my Lord himself, turning</li>
<li class="L3067" rel="L3067">the suit of clothes, now inside out, now outside in, but on the whole</li>
<li class="L3068" rel="L3068">decidedly trimming and shaping them into grave-clothes for the prisoner.</li>
<li class="L3069" rel="L3069"></li>
<li class="L3070" rel="L3070">And now, the jury turned to consider, and the great flies swarmed again.</li>
<li class="L3071" rel="L3071"></li>
<li class="L3072" rel="L3072">Mr. Carton, who had so long sat looking at the ceiling of the court,</li>
<li class="L3073" rel="L3073">changed neither his place nor his attitude, even in this excitement.</li>
<li class="L3074" rel="L3074">While his learned friend, Mr. Stryver, massing his papers before him,</li>
<li class="L3075" rel="L3075">whispered with those who sat near, and from time to time glanced</li>
<li class="L3076" rel="L3076">anxiously at the jury; while all the spectators moved more or less, and</li>
<li class="L3077" rel="L3077">grouped themselves anew; while even my Lord himself arose from his seat,</li>
<li class="L3078" rel="L3078">and slowly paced up and down his platform, not unattended by a suspicion</li>
<li class="L3079" rel="L3079">in the minds of the audience that his state was feverish; this one man</li>
<li class="L3080" rel="L3080">sat leaning back, with his torn gown half off him, his untidy wig put</li>
<li class="L3081" rel="L3081">on just as it had happened to light on his head after its removal, his</li>
<li class="L3082" rel="L3082">hands in his pockets, and his eyes on the ceiling as they had been all</li>
<li class="L3083" rel="L3083">day. Something especially reckless in his demeanour, not only gave him</li>
<li class="L3084" rel="L3084">a disreputable look, but so diminished the strong resemblance he</li>
<li class="L3085" rel="L3085">undoubtedly bore to the prisoner (which his momentary earnestness,</li>
<li class="L3086" rel="L3086">when they were compared together, had strengthened), that many of the</li>
<li class="L3087" rel="L3087">lookers-on, taking note of him now, said to one another they would</li>
<li class="L3088" rel="L3088">hardly have thought the two were so alike. Mr. Cruncher made the</li>
<li class="L3089" rel="L3089">observation to his next neighbour, and added, “I&#39;d hold half a guinea</li>
<li class="L3090" rel="L3090">that _he_ don&#39;t get no law-work to do. Don&#39;t look like the sort of one</li>
<li class="L3091" rel="L3091">to get any, do he?”</li>
<li class="L3092" rel="L3092"></li>
<li class="L3093" rel="L3093">Yet, this Mr. Carton took in more of the details of the scene than he</li>
<li class="L3094" rel="L3094">appeared to take in; for now, when Miss Manette&#39;s head dropped upon</li>
<li class="L3095" rel="L3095">her father&#39;s breast, he was the first to see it, and to say audibly:</li>
<li class="L3096" rel="L3096">“Officer! look to that young lady. Help the gentleman to take her out.</li>
<li class="L3097" rel="L3097">Don&#39;t you see she will fall!”</li>
<li class="L3098" rel="L3098"></li>
<li class="L3099" rel="L3099">There was much commiseration for her as she was removed, and much</li>
<li class="L3100" rel="L3100">sympathy with her father. It had evidently been a great distress to</li>
<li class="L3101" rel="L3101">him, to have the days of his imprisonment recalled. He had shown</li>
<li class="L3102" rel="L3102">strong internal agitation when he was questioned, and that pondering or</li>
<li class="L3103" rel="L3103">brooding look which made him old, had been upon him, like a heavy cloud,</li>
<li class="L3104" rel="L3104">ever since. As he passed out, the jury, who had turned back and paused a</li>
<li class="L3105" rel="L3105">moment, spoke, through their foreman.</li>
<li class="L3106" rel="L3106"></li>
<li class="L3107" rel="L3107">They were not agreed, and wished to retire. My Lord (perhaps with George</li>
<li class="L3108" rel="L3108">Washington on his mind) showed some surprise that they were not agreed,</li>
<li class="L3109" rel="L3109">but signified his pleasure that they should retire under watch and ward,</li>
<li class="L3110" rel="L3110">and retired himself. The trial had lasted all day, and the lamps in</li>
<li class="L3111" rel="L3111">the court were now being lighted. It began to be rumoured that the</li>
<li class="L3112" rel="L3112">jury would be out a long while. The spectators dropped off to get</li>
<li class="L3113" rel="L3113">refreshment, and the prisoner withdrew to the back of the dock, and sat</li>
<li class="L3114" rel="L3114">down.</li>
<li class="L3115" rel="L3115"></li>
<li class="L3116" rel="L3116">Mr. Lorry, who had gone out when the young lady and her father went out,</li>
<li class="L3117" rel="L3117">now reappeared, and beckoned to Jerry: who, in the slackened interest,</li>
<li class="L3118" rel="L3118">could easily get near him.</li>
<li class="L3119" rel="L3119"></li>
<li class="L3120" rel="L3120">“Jerry, if you wish to take something to eat, you can. But, keep in the</li>
<li class="L3121" rel="L3121">way. You will be sure to hear when the jury come in. Don&#39;t be a moment</li>
<li class="L3122" rel="L3122">behind them, for I want you to take the verdict back to the bank. You</li>
<li class="L3123" rel="L3123">are the quickest messenger I know, and will get to Temple Bar long</li>
<li class="L3124" rel="L3124">before I can.”</li>
<li class="L3125" rel="L3125"></li>
<li class="L3126" rel="L3126">Jerry had just enough forehead to knuckle, and he knuckled it in</li>
<li class="L3127" rel="L3127">acknowledgment of this communication and a shilling. Mr. Carton came up</li>
<li class="L3128" rel="L3128">at the moment, and touched Mr. Lorry on the arm.</li>
<li class="L3129" rel="L3129"></li>
<li class="L3130" rel="L3130">“How is the young lady?”</li>
<li class="L3131" rel="L3131"></li>
<li class="L3132" rel="L3132">“She is greatly distressed; but her father is comforting her, and she</li>
<li class="L3133" rel="L3133">feels the better for being out of court.”</li>
<li class="L3134" rel="L3134"></li>
<li class="L3135" rel="L3135">“I&#39;ll tell the prisoner so. It won&#39;t do for a respectable bank gentleman</li>
<li class="L3136" rel="L3136">like you, to be seen speaking to him publicly, you know.”</li>
<li class="L3137" rel="L3137"></li>
<li class="L3138" rel="L3138">Mr. Lorry reddened as if he were conscious of having debated the point</li>
<li class="L3139" rel="L3139">in his mind, and Mr. Carton made his way to the outside of the bar.</li>
<li class="L3140" rel="L3140">The way out of court lay in that direction, and Jerry followed him, all</li>
<li class="L3141" rel="L3141">eyes, ears, and spikes.</li>
<li class="L3142" rel="L3142"></li>
<li class="L3143" rel="L3143">“Mr. Darnay!”</li>
<li class="L3144" rel="L3144"></li>
<li class="L3145" rel="L3145">The prisoner came forward directly.</li>
<li class="L3146" rel="L3146"></li>
<li class="L3147" rel="L3147">“You will naturally be anxious to hear of the witness, Miss Manette. She</li>
<li class="L3148" rel="L3148">will do very well. You have seen the worst of her agitation.”</li>
<li class="L3149" rel="L3149"></li>
<li class="L3150" rel="L3150">“I am deeply sorry to have been the cause of it. Could you tell her so</li>
<li class="L3151" rel="L3151">for me, with my fervent acknowledgments?”</li>
<li class="L3152" rel="L3152"></li>
<li class="L3153" rel="L3153">“Yes, I could. I will, if you ask it.”</li>
<li class="L3154" rel="L3154"></li>
<li class="L3155" rel="L3155">Mr. Carton&#39;s manner was so careless as to be almost insolent. He stood,</li>
<li class="L3156" rel="L3156">half turned from the prisoner, lounging with his elbow against the bar.</li>
<li class="L3157" rel="L3157"></li>
<li class="L3158" rel="L3158">“I do ask it. Accept my cordial thanks.”</li>
<li class="L3159" rel="L3159"></li>
<li class="L3160" rel="L3160">“What,” said Carton, still only half turned towards him, “do you expect,</li>
<li class="L3161" rel="L3161">Mr. Darnay?”</li>
<li class="L3162" rel="L3162"></li>
<li class="L3163" rel="L3163">“The worst.”</li>
<li class="L3164" rel="L3164"></li>
<li class="L3165" rel="L3165">“It&#39;s the wisest thing to expect, and the likeliest. But I think their</li>
<li class="L3166" rel="L3166">withdrawing is in your favour.”</li>
<li class="L3167" rel="L3167"></li>
<li class="L3168" rel="L3168">Loitering on the way out of court not being allowed, Jerry heard no</li>
<li class="L3169" rel="L3169">more: but left them--so like each other in feature, so unlike each other</li>
<li class="L3170" rel="L3170">in manner--standing side by side, both reflected in the glass above</li>
<li class="L3171" rel="L3171">them.</li>
<li class="L3172" rel="L3172"></li>
<li class="L3173" rel="L3173">An hour and a half limped heavily away in the thief-and-rascal crowded</li>
<li class="L3174" rel="L3174">passages below, even though assisted off with mutton pies and ale.</li>
<li class="L3175" rel="L3175">The hoarse messenger, uncomfortably seated on a form after taking that</li>
<li class="L3176" rel="L3176">refection, had dropped into a doze, when a loud murmur and a rapid tide</li>
<li class="L3177" rel="L3177">of people setting up the stairs that led to the court, carried him along</li>
<li class="L3178" rel="L3178">with them.</li>
<li class="L3179" rel="L3179"></li>
<li class="L3180" rel="L3180">“Jerry! Jerry!” Mr. Lorry was already calling at the door when he got</li>
<li class="L3181" rel="L3181">there.</li>
<li class="L3182" rel="L3182"></li>
<li class="L3183" rel="L3183">“Here, sir! It&#39;s a fight to get back again. Here I am, sir!”</li>
<li class="L3184" rel="L3184"></li>
<li class="L3185" rel="L3185">Mr. Lorry handed him a paper through the throng. “Quick! Have you got</li>
<li class="L3186" rel="L3186">it?”</li>
<li class="L3187" rel="L3187"></li>
<li class="L3188" rel="L3188">“Yes, sir.”</li>
<li class="L3189" rel="L3189"></li>
<li class="L3190" rel="L3190">Hastily written on the paper was the word “ACQUITTED.”</li>
<li class="L3191" rel="L3191"></li>
<li class="L3192" rel="L3192">“If you had sent the message, &#39;Recalled to Life,&#39; again,” muttered</li>
<li class="L3193" rel="L3193">Jerry, as he turned, “I should have known what you meant, this time.”</li>
<li class="L3194" rel="L3194"></li>
<li class="L3195" rel="L3195">He had no opportunity of saying, or so much as thinking, anything else,</li>
<li class="L3196" rel="L3196">until he was clear of the Old Bailey; for, the crowd came pouring out</li>
<li class="L3197" rel="L3197">with a vehemence that nearly took him off his legs, and a loud buzz</li>
<li class="L3198" rel="L3198">swept into the street as if the baffled blue-flies were dispersing in</li>
<li class="L3199" rel="L3199">search of other carrion.</li>
<li class="L3200" rel="L3200"></li>
<li class="L3201" rel="L3201"></li>
<li class="L3202" rel="L3202"></li>
<li class="L3203" rel="L3203"></li>
<li class="L3204" rel="L3204">IV. Congratulatory</li>
<li class="L3205" rel="L3205"></li>
<li class="L3206" rel="L3206"></li>
<li class="L3207" rel="L3207">From the dimly-lighted passages of the court, the last sediment of the</li>
<li class="L3208" rel="L3208">human stew that had been boiling there all day, was straining off, when</li>
<li class="L3209" rel="L3209">Doctor Manette, Lucie Manette, his daughter, Mr. Lorry, the solicitor</li>
<li class="L3210" rel="L3210">for the defence, and its counsel, Mr. Stryver, stood gathered round Mr.</li>
<li class="L3211" rel="L3211">Charles Darnay--just released--congratulating him on his escape from</li>
<li class="L3212" rel="L3212">death.</li>
<li class="L3213" rel="L3213"></li>
<li class="L3214" rel="L3214">It would have been difficult by a far brighter light, to recognise</li>
<li class="L3215" rel="L3215">in Doctor Manette, intellectual of face and upright of bearing, the</li>
<li class="L3216" rel="L3216">shoemaker of the garret in Paris. Yet, no one could have looked at him</li>
<li class="L3217" rel="L3217">twice, without looking again: even though the opportunity of observation</li>
<li class="L3218" rel="L3218">had not extended to the mournful cadence of his low grave voice, and</li>
<li class="L3219" rel="L3219">to the abstraction that overclouded him fitfully, without any apparent</li>
<li class="L3220" rel="L3220">reason. While one external cause, and that a reference to his long</li>
<li class="L3221" rel="L3221">lingering agony, would always--as on the trial--evoke this condition</li>
<li class="L3222" rel="L3222">from the depths of his soul, it was also in its nature to arise of</li>
<li class="L3223" rel="L3223">itself, and to draw a gloom over him, as incomprehensible to those</li>
<li class="L3224" rel="L3224">unacquainted with his story as if they had seen the shadow of the actual</li>
<li class="L3225" rel="L3225">Bastille thrown upon him by a summer sun, when the substance was three</li>
<li class="L3226" rel="L3226">hundred miles away.</li>
<li class="L3227" rel="L3227"></li>
<li class="L3228" rel="L3228">Only his daughter had the power of charming this black brooding from</li>
<li class="L3229" rel="L3229">his mind. She was the golden thread that united him to a Past beyond his</li>
<li class="L3230" rel="L3230">misery, and to a Present beyond his misery: and the sound of her voice,</li>
<li class="L3231" rel="L3231">the light of her face, the touch of her hand, had a strong beneficial</li>
<li class="L3232" rel="L3232">influence with him almost always. Not absolutely always, for she could</li>
<li class="L3233" rel="L3233">recall some occasions on which her power had failed; but they were few</li>
<li class="L3234" rel="L3234">and slight, and she believed them over.</li>
<li class="L3235" rel="L3235"></li>
<li class="L3236" rel="L3236">Mr. Darnay had kissed her hand fervently and gratefully, and had turned</li>
<li class="L3237" rel="L3237">to Mr. Stryver, whom he warmly thanked. Mr. Stryver, a man of little</li>
<li class="L3238" rel="L3238">more than thirty, but looking twenty years older than he was, stout,</li>
<li class="L3239" rel="L3239">loud, red, bluff, and free from any drawback of delicacy, had a pushing</li>
<li class="L3240" rel="L3240">way of shouldering himself (morally and physically) into companies and</li>
<li class="L3241" rel="L3241">conversations, that argued well for his shouldering his way up in life.</li>
<li class="L3242" rel="L3242"></li>
<li class="L3243" rel="L3243">He still had his wig and gown on, and he said, squaring himself at his</li>
<li class="L3244" rel="L3244">late client to that degree that he squeezed the innocent Mr. Lorry clean</li>
<li class="L3245" rel="L3245">out of the group: “I am glad to have brought you off with honour, Mr.</li>
<li class="L3246" rel="L3246">Darnay. It was an infamous prosecution, grossly infamous; but not the</li>
<li class="L3247" rel="L3247">less likely to succeed on that account.”</li>
<li class="L3248" rel="L3248"></li>
<li class="L3249" rel="L3249">“You have laid me under an obligation to you for life--in two senses,”</li>
<li class="L3250" rel="L3250"> said his late client, taking his hand.</li>
<li class="L3251" rel="L3251"></li>
<li class="L3252" rel="L3252">“I have done my best for you, Mr. Darnay; and my best is as good as</li>
<li class="L3253" rel="L3253">another man&#39;s, I believe.”</li>
<li class="L3254" rel="L3254"></li>
<li class="L3255" rel="L3255">It clearly being incumbent on some one to say, “Much better,” Mr. Lorry</li>
<li class="L3256" rel="L3256">said it; perhaps not quite disinterestedly, but with the interested</li>
<li class="L3257" rel="L3257">object of squeezing himself back again.</li>
<li class="L3258" rel="L3258"></li>
<li class="L3259" rel="L3259">“You think so?” said Mr. Stryver. “Well! you have been present all day,</li>
<li class="L3260" rel="L3260">and you ought to know. You are a man of business, too.”</li>
<li class="L3261" rel="L3261"></li>
<li class="L3262" rel="L3262">“And as such,” quoth Mr. Lorry, whom the counsel learned in the law had</li>
<li class="L3263" rel="L3263">now shouldered back into the group, just as he had previously shouldered</li>
<li class="L3264" rel="L3264">him out of it--“as such I will appeal to Doctor Manette, to break up</li>
<li class="L3265" rel="L3265">this conference and order us all to our homes. Miss Lucie looks ill, Mr.</li>
<li class="L3266" rel="L3266">Darnay has had a terrible day, we are worn out.”</li>
<li class="L3267" rel="L3267"></li>
<li class="L3268" rel="L3268">“Speak for yourself, Mr. Lorry,” said Stryver; “I have a night&#39;s work to</li>
<li class="L3269" rel="L3269">do yet. Speak for yourself.”</li>
<li class="L3270" rel="L3270"></li>
<li class="L3271" rel="L3271">“I speak for myself,” answered Mr. Lorry, “and for Mr. Darnay, and for</li>
<li class="L3272" rel="L3272">Miss Lucie, and--Miss Lucie, do you not think I may speak for us all?”</li>
<li class="L3273" rel="L3273"> He asked her the question pointedly, and with a glance at her father.</li>
<li class="L3274" rel="L3274"></li>
<li class="L3275" rel="L3275">His face had become frozen, as it were, in a very curious look at</li>
<li class="L3276" rel="L3276">Darnay: an intent look, deepening into a frown of dislike and distrust,</li>
<li class="L3277" rel="L3277">not even unmixed with fear. With this strange expression on him his</li>
<li class="L3278" rel="L3278">thoughts had wandered away.</li>
<li class="L3279" rel="L3279"></li>
<li class="L3280" rel="L3280">“My father,” said Lucie, softly laying her hand on his.</li>
<li class="L3281" rel="L3281"></li>
<li class="L3282" rel="L3282">He slowly shook the shadow off, and turned to her.</li>
<li class="L3283" rel="L3283"></li>
<li class="L3284" rel="L3284">“Shall we go home, my father?”</li>
<li class="L3285" rel="L3285"></li>
<li class="L3286" rel="L3286">With a long breath, he answered “Yes.”</li>
<li class="L3287" rel="L3287"></li>
<li class="L3288" rel="L3288">The friends of the acquitted prisoner had dispersed, under the</li>
<li class="L3289" rel="L3289">impression--which he himself had originated--that he would not be</li>
<li class="L3290" rel="L3290">released that night. The lights were nearly all extinguished in the</li>
<li class="L3291" rel="L3291">passages, the iron gates were being closed with a jar and a rattle,</li>
<li class="L3292" rel="L3292">and the dismal place was deserted until to-morrow morning&#39;s interest of</li>
<li class="L3293" rel="L3293">gallows, pillory, whipping-post, and branding-iron, should repeople it.</li>
<li class="L3294" rel="L3294">Walking between her father and Mr. Darnay, Lucie Manette passed into</li>
<li class="L3295" rel="L3295">the open air. A hackney-coach was called, and the father and daughter</li>
<li class="L3296" rel="L3296">departed in it.</li>
<li class="L3297" rel="L3297"></li>
<li class="L3298" rel="L3298">Mr. Stryver had left them in the passages, to shoulder his way back</li>
<li class="L3299" rel="L3299">to the robing-room. Another person, who had not joined the group, or</li>
<li class="L3300" rel="L3300">interchanged a word with any one of them, but who had been leaning</li>
<li class="L3301" rel="L3301">against the wall where its shadow was darkest, had silently strolled</li>
<li class="L3302" rel="L3302">out after the rest, and had looked on until the coach drove away. He now</li>
<li class="L3303" rel="L3303">stepped up to where Mr. Lorry and Mr. Darnay stood upon the pavement.</li>
<li class="L3304" rel="L3304"></li>
<li class="L3305" rel="L3305">“So, Mr. Lorry! Men of business may speak to Mr. Darnay now?”</li>
<li class="L3306" rel="L3306"></li>
<li class="L3307" rel="L3307">Nobody had made any acknowledgment of Mr. Carton&#39;s part in the day&#39;s</li>
<li class="L3308" rel="L3308">proceedings; nobody had known of it. He was unrobed, and was none the</li>
<li class="L3309" rel="L3309">better for it in appearance.</li>
<li class="L3310" rel="L3310"></li>
<li class="L3311" rel="L3311">“If you knew what a conflict goes on in the business mind, when the</li>
<li class="L3312" rel="L3312">business mind is divided between good-natured impulse and business</li>
<li class="L3313" rel="L3313">appearances, you would be amused, Mr. Darnay.”</li>
<li class="L3314" rel="L3314"></li>
<li class="L3315" rel="L3315">Mr. Lorry reddened, and said, warmly, “You have mentioned that before,</li>
<li class="L3316" rel="L3316">sir. We men of business, who serve a House, are not our own masters. We</li>
<li class="L3317" rel="L3317">have to think of the House more than ourselves.”</li>
<li class="L3318" rel="L3318"></li>
<li class="L3319" rel="L3319">“_I_ know, _I_ know,” rejoined Mr. Carton, carelessly. “Don&#39;t be</li>
<li class="L3320" rel="L3320">nettled, Mr. Lorry. You are as good as another, I have no doubt: better,</li>
<li class="L3321" rel="L3321">I dare say.”</li>
<li class="L3322" rel="L3322"></li>
<li class="L3323" rel="L3323">“And indeed, sir,” pursued Mr. Lorry, not minding him, “I really don&#39;t</li>
<li class="L3324" rel="L3324">know what you have to do with the matter. If you&#39;ll excuse me, as very</li>
<li class="L3325" rel="L3325">much your elder, for saying so, I really don&#39;t know that it is your</li>
<li class="L3326" rel="L3326">business.”</li>
<li class="L3327" rel="L3327"></li>
<li class="L3328" rel="L3328">“Business! Bless you, _I_ have no business,” said Mr. Carton.</li>
<li class="L3329" rel="L3329"></li>
<li class="L3330" rel="L3330">“It is a pity you have not, sir.”</li>
<li class="L3331" rel="L3331"></li>
<li class="L3332" rel="L3332">“I think so, too.”</li>
<li class="L3333" rel="L3333"></li>
<li class="L3334" rel="L3334">“If you had,” pursued Mr. Lorry, “perhaps you would attend to it.”</li>
<li class="L3335" rel="L3335"></li>
<li class="L3336" rel="L3336">“Lord love you, no!--I shouldn&#39;t,” said Mr. Carton.</li>
<li class="L3337" rel="L3337"></li>
<li class="L3338" rel="L3338">“Well, sir!” cried Mr. Lorry, thoroughly heated by his indifference,</li>
<li class="L3339" rel="L3339">“business is a very good thing, and a very respectable thing. And, sir,</li>
<li class="L3340" rel="L3340">if business imposes its restraints and its silences and impediments, Mr.</li>
<li class="L3341" rel="L3341">Darnay as a young gentleman of generosity knows how to make allowance</li>
<li class="L3342" rel="L3342">for that circumstance. Mr. Darnay, good night, God bless you, sir!</li>
<li class="L3343" rel="L3343">I hope you have been this day preserved for a prosperous and happy</li>
<li class="L3344" rel="L3344">life.--Chair there!”</li>
<li class="L3345" rel="L3345"></li>
<li class="L3346" rel="L3346">Perhaps a little angry with himself, as well as with the barrister, Mr.</li>
<li class="L3347" rel="L3347">Lorry bustled into the chair, and was carried off to Tellson&#39;s. Carton,</li>
<li class="L3348" rel="L3348">who smelt of port wine, and did not appear to be quite sober, laughed</li>
<li class="L3349" rel="L3349">then, and turned to Darnay:</li>
<li class="L3350" rel="L3350"></li>
<li class="L3351" rel="L3351">“This is a strange chance that throws you and me together. This must</li>
<li class="L3352" rel="L3352">be a strange night to you, standing alone here with your counterpart on</li>
<li class="L3353" rel="L3353">these street stones?”</li>
<li class="L3354" rel="L3354"></li>
<li class="L3355" rel="L3355">“I hardly seem yet,” returned Charles Darnay, “to belong to this world</li>
<li class="L3356" rel="L3356">again.”</li>
<li class="L3357" rel="L3357"></li>
<li class="L3358" rel="L3358">“I don&#39;t wonder at it; it&#39;s not so long since you were pretty far</li>
<li class="L3359" rel="L3359">advanced on your way to another. You speak faintly.”</li>
<li class="L3360" rel="L3360"></li>
<li class="L3361" rel="L3361">“I begin to think I _am_ faint.”</li>
<li class="L3362" rel="L3362"></li>
<li class="L3363" rel="L3363">“Then why the devil don&#39;t you dine? I dined, myself, while those</li>
<li class="L3364" rel="L3364">numskulls were deliberating which world you should belong to--this, or</li>
<li class="L3365" rel="L3365">some other. Let me show you the nearest tavern to dine well at.”</li>
<li class="L3366" rel="L3366"></li>
<li class="L3367" rel="L3367">Drawing his arm through his own, he took him down Ludgate-hill to</li>
<li class="L3368" rel="L3368">Fleet-street, and so, up a covered way, into a tavern. Here, they were</li>
<li class="L3369" rel="L3369">shown into a little room, where Charles Darnay was soon recruiting</li>
<li class="L3370" rel="L3370">his strength with a good plain dinner and good wine: while Carton sat</li>
<li class="L3371" rel="L3371">opposite to him at the same table, with his separate bottle of port</li>
<li class="L3372" rel="L3372">before him, and his fully half-insolent manner upon him.</li>
<li class="L3373" rel="L3373"></li>
<li class="L3374" rel="L3374">“Do you feel, yet, that you belong to this terrestrial scheme again, Mr.</li>
<li class="L3375" rel="L3375">Darnay?”</li>
<li class="L3376" rel="L3376"></li>
<li class="L3377" rel="L3377">“I am frightfully confused regarding time and place; but I am so far</li>
<li class="L3378" rel="L3378">mended as to feel that.”</li>
<li class="L3379" rel="L3379"></li>
<li class="L3380" rel="L3380">“It must be an immense satisfaction!”</li>
<li class="L3381" rel="L3381"></li>
<li class="L3382" rel="L3382">He said it bitterly, and filled up his glass again: which was a large</li>
<li class="L3383" rel="L3383">one.</li>
<li class="L3384" rel="L3384"></li>
<li class="L3385" rel="L3385">“As to me, the greatest desire I have, is to forget that I belong to it.</li>
<li class="L3386" rel="L3386">It has no good in it for me--except wine like this--nor I for it. So we</li>
<li class="L3387" rel="L3387">are not much alike in that particular. Indeed, I begin to think we are</li>
<li class="L3388" rel="L3388">not much alike in any particular, you and I.”</li>
<li class="L3389" rel="L3389"></li>
<li class="L3390" rel="L3390">Confused by the emotion of the day, and feeling his being there with</li>
<li class="L3391" rel="L3391">this Double of coarse deportment, to be like a dream, Charles Darnay was</li>
<li class="L3392" rel="L3392">at a loss how to answer; finally, answered not at all.</li>
<li class="L3393" rel="L3393"></li>
<li class="L3394" rel="L3394">“Now your dinner is done,” Carton presently said, “why don&#39;t you call a</li>
<li class="L3395" rel="L3395">health, Mr. Darnay; why don&#39;t you give your toast?”</li>
<li class="L3396" rel="L3396"></li>
<li class="L3397" rel="L3397">“What health? What toast?”</li>
<li class="L3398" rel="L3398"></li>
<li class="L3399" rel="L3399">“Why, it&#39;s on the tip of your tongue. It ought to be, it must be, I&#39;ll</li>
<li class="L3400" rel="L3400">swear it&#39;s there.”</li>
<li class="L3401" rel="L3401"></li>
<li class="L3402" rel="L3402">“Miss Manette, then!”</li>
<li class="L3403" rel="L3403"></li>
<li class="L3404" rel="L3404">“Miss Manette, then!”</li>
<li class="L3405" rel="L3405"></li>
<li class="L3406" rel="L3406">Looking his companion full in the face while he drank the toast, Carton</li>
<li class="L3407" rel="L3407">flung his glass over his shoulder against the wall, where it shivered to</li>
<li class="L3408" rel="L3408">pieces; then, rang the bell, and ordered in another.</li>
<li class="L3409" rel="L3409"></li>
<li class="L3410" rel="L3410">“That&#39;s a fair young lady to hand to a coach in the dark, Mr. Darnay!”</li>
<li class="L3411" rel="L3411"> he said, filling his new goblet.</li>
<li class="L3412" rel="L3412"></li>
<li class="L3413" rel="L3413">A slight frown and a laconic “Yes,” were the answer.</li>
<li class="L3414" rel="L3414"></li>
<li class="L3415" rel="L3415">“That&#39;s a fair young lady to be pitied by and wept for by! How does it</li>
<li class="L3416" rel="L3416">feel? Is it worth being tried for one&#39;s life, to be the object of such</li>
<li class="L3417" rel="L3417">sympathy and compassion, Mr. Darnay?”</li>
<li class="L3418" rel="L3418"></li>
<li class="L3419" rel="L3419">Again Darnay answered not a word.</li>
<li class="L3420" rel="L3420"></li>
<li class="L3421" rel="L3421">“She was mightily pleased to have your message, when I gave it her. Not</li>
<li class="L3422" rel="L3422">that she showed she was pleased, but I suppose she was.”</li>
<li class="L3423" rel="L3423"></li>
<li class="L3424" rel="L3424">The allusion served as a timely reminder to Darnay that this</li>
<li class="L3425" rel="L3425">disagreeable companion had, of his own free will, assisted him in the</li>
<li class="L3426" rel="L3426">strait of the day. He turned the dialogue to that point, and thanked him</li>
<li class="L3427" rel="L3427">for it.</li>
<li class="L3428" rel="L3428"></li>
<li class="L3429" rel="L3429">“I neither want any thanks, nor merit any,” was the careless rejoinder.</li>
<li class="L3430" rel="L3430">“It was nothing to do, in the first place; and I don&#39;t know why I did</li>
<li class="L3431" rel="L3431">it, in the second. Mr. Darnay, let me ask you a question.”</li>
<li class="L3432" rel="L3432"></li>
<li class="L3433" rel="L3433">“Willingly, and a small return for your good offices.”</li>
<li class="L3434" rel="L3434"></li>
<li class="L3435" rel="L3435">“Do you think I particularly like you?”</li>
<li class="L3436" rel="L3436"></li>
<li class="L3437" rel="L3437">“Really, Mr. Carton,” returned the other, oddly disconcerted, “I have</li>
<li class="L3438" rel="L3438">not asked myself the question.”</li>
<li class="L3439" rel="L3439"></li>
<li class="L3440" rel="L3440">“But ask yourself the question now.”</li>
<li class="L3441" rel="L3441"></li>
<li class="L3442" rel="L3442">“You have acted as if you do; but I don&#39;t think you do.”</li>
<li class="L3443" rel="L3443"></li>
<li class="L3444" rel="L3444">“_I_ don&#39;t think I do,” said Carton. “I begin to have a very good</li>
<li class="L3445" rel="L3445">opinion of your understanding.”</li>
<li class="L3446" rel="L3446"></li>
<li class="L3447" rel="L3447">“Nevertheless,” pursued Darnay, rising to ring the bell, “there is</li>
<li class="L3448" rel="L3448">nothing in that, I hope, to prevent my calling the reckoning, and our</li>
<li class="L3449" rel="L3449">parting without ill-blood on either side.”</li>
<li class="L3450" rel="L3450"></li>
<li class="L3451" rel="L3451">Carton rejoining, “Nothing in life!” Darnay rang. “Do you call the whole</li>
<li class="L3452" rel="L3452">reckoning?” said Carton. On his answering in the affirmative, “Then</li>
<li class="L3453" rel="L3453">bring me another pint of this same wine, drawer, and come and wake me at</li>
<li class="L3454" rel="L3454">ten.”</li>
<li class="L3455" rel="L3455"></li>
<li class="L3456" rel="L3456">The bill being paid, Charles Darnay rose and wished him good night.</li>
<li class="L3457" rel="L3457">Without returning the wish, Carton rose too, with something of a threat</li>
<li class="L3458" rel="L3458">of defiance in his manner, and said, “A last word, Mr. Darnay: you think</li>
<li class="L3459" rel="L3459">I am drunk?”</li>
<li class="L3460" rel="L3460"></li>
<li class="L3461" rel="L3461">“I think you have been drinking, Mr. Carton.”</li>
<li class="L3462" rel="L3462"></li>
<li class="L3463" rel="L3463">“Think? You know I have been drinking.”</li>
<li class="L3464" rel="L3464"></li>
<li class="L3465" rel="L3465">“Since I must say so, I know it.”</li>
<li class="L3466" rel="L3466"></li>
<li class="L3467" rel="L3467">“Then you shall likewise know why. I am a disappointed drudge, sir. I</li>
<li class="L3468" rel="L3468">care for no man on earth, and no man on earth cares for me.”</li>
<li class="L3469" rel="L3469"></li>
<li class="L3470" rel="L3470">“Much to be regretted. You might have used your talents better.”</li>
<li class="L3471" rel="L3471"></li>
<li class="L3472" rel="L3472">“May be so, Mr. Darnay; may be not. Don&#39;t let your sober face elate you,</li>
<li class="L3473" rel="L3473">however; you don&#39;t know what it may come to. Good night!”</li>
<li class="L3474" rel="L3474"></li>
<li class="L3475" rel="L3475">When he was left alone, this strange being took up a candle, went to a</li>
<li class="L3476" rel="L3476">glass that hung against the wall, and surveyed himself minutely in it.</li>
<li class="L3477" rel="L3477"></li>
<li class="L3478" rel="L3478">“Do you particularly like the man?” he muttered, at his own image; “why</li>
<li class="L3479" rel="L3479">should you particularly like a man who resembles you? There is nothing</li>
<li class="L3480" rel="L3480">in you to like; you know that. Ah, confound you! What a change you have</li>
<li class="L3481" rel="L3481">made in yourself! A good reason for taking to a man, that he shows you</li>
<li class="L3482" rel="L3482">what you have fallen away from, and what you might have been! Change</li>
<li class="L3483" rel="L3483">places with him, and would you have been looked at by those blue eyes as</li>
<li class="L3484" rel="L3484">he was, and commiserated by that agitated face as he was? Come on, and</li>
<li class="L3485" rel="L3485">have it out in plain words! You hate the fellow.”</li>
<li class="L3486" rel="L3486"></li>
<li class="L3487" rel="L3487">He resorted to his pint of wine for consolation, drank it all in a few</li>
<li class="L3488" rel="L3488">minutes, and fell asleep on his arms, with his hair straggling over the</li>
<li class="L3489" rel="L3489">table, and a long winding-sheet in the candle dripping down upon him.</li>
<li class="L3490" rel="L3490"></li>
<li class="L3491" rel="L3491"></li>
<li class="L3492" rel="L3492"></li>
<li class="L3493" rel="L3493"></li>
<li class="L3494" rel="L3494">V. The Jackal</li>
<li class="L3495" rel="L3495"></li>
<li class="L3496" rel="L3496"></li>
<li class="L3497" rel="L3497">Those were drinking days, and most men drank hard. So very great is</li>
<li class="L3498" rel="L3498">the improvement Time has brought about in such habits, that a moderate</li>
<li class="L3499" rel="L3499">statement of the quantity of wine and punch which one man would swallow</li>
<li class="L3500" rel="L3500">in the course of a night, without any detriment to his reputation as a</li>
<li class="L3501" rel="L3501">perfect gentleman, would seem, in these days, a ridiculous exaggeration.</li>
<li class="L3502" rel="L3502">The learned profession of the law was certainly not behind any other</li>
<li class="L3503" rel="L3503">learned profession in its Bacchanalian propensities; neither was Mr.</li>
<li class="L3504" rel="L3504">Stryver, already fast shouldering his way to a large and lucrative</li>
<li class="L3505" rel="L3505">practice, behind his compeers in this particular, any more than in the</li>
<li class="L3506" rel="L3506">drier parts of the legal race.</li>
<li class="L3507" rel="L3507"></li>
<li class="L3508" rel="L3508">A favourite at the Old Bailey, and eke at the Sessions, Mr. Stryver had</li>
<li class="L3509" rel="L3509">begun cautiously to hew away the lower staves of the ladder on which</li>
<li class="L3510" rel="L3510">he mounted. Sessions and Old Bailey had now to summon their favourite,</li>
<li class="L3511" rel="L3511">specially, to their longing arms; and shouldering itself towards the</li>
<li class="L3512" rel="L3512">visage of the Lord Chief Justice in the Court of King&#39;s Bench, the</li>
<li class="L3513" rel="L3513">florid countenance of Mr. Stryver might be daily seen, bursting out of</li>
<li class="L3514" rel="L3514">the bed of wigs, like a great sunflower pushing its way at the sun from</li>
<li class="L3515" rel="L3515">among a rank garden-full of flaring companions.</li>
<li class="L3516" rel="L3516"></li>
<li class="L3517" rel="L3517">It had once been noted at the Bar, that while Mr. Stryver was a glib</li>
<li class="L3518" rel="L3518">man, and an unscrupulous, and a ready, and a bold, he had not that</li>
<li class="L3519" rel="L3519">faculty of extracting the essence from a heap of statements, which is</li>
<li class="L3520" rel="L3520">among the most striking and necessary of the advocate&#39;s accomplishments.</li>
<li class="L3521" rel="L3521">But, a remarkable improvement came upon him as to this. The more</li>
<li class="L3522" rel="L3522">business he got, the greater his power seemed to grow of getting at its</li>
<li class="L3523" rel="L3523">pith and marrow; and however late at night he sat carousing with Sydney</li>
<li class="L3524" rel="L3524">Carton, he always had his points at his fingers&#39; ends in the morning.</li>
<li class="L3525" rel="L3525"></li>
<li class="L3526" rel="L3526">Sydney Carton, idlest and most unpromising of men, was Stryver&#39;s great</li>
<li class="L3527" rel="L3527">ally. What the two drank together, between Hilary Term and Michaelmas,</li>
<li class="L3528" rel="L3528">might have floated a king&#39;s ship. Stryver never had a case in hand,</li>
<li class="L3529" rel="L3529">anywhere, but Carton was there, with his hands in his pockets, staring</li>
<li class="L3530" rel="L3530">at the ceiling of the court; they went the same Circuit, and even there</li>
<li class="L3531" rel="L3531">they prolonged their usual orgies late into the night, and Carton was</li>
<li class="L3532" rel="L3532">rumoured to be seen at broad day, going home stealthily and unsteadily</li>
<li class="L3533" rel="L3533">to his lodgings, like a dissipated cat. At last, it began to get about,</li>
<li class="L3534" rel="L3534">among such as were interested in the matter, that although Sydney Carton</li>
<li class="L3535" rel="L3535">would never be a lion, he was an amazingly good jackal, and that he</li>
<li class="L3536" rel="L3536">rendered suit and service to Stryver in that humble capacity.</li>
<li class="L3537" rel="L3537"></li>
<li class="L3538" rel="L3538">“Ten o&#39;clock, sir,” said the man at the tavern, whom he had charged to</li>
<li class="L3539" rel="L3539">wake him--“ten o&#39;clock, sir.”</li>
<li class="L3540" rel="L3540"></li>
<li class="L3541" rel="L3541">“_What&#39;s_ the matter?”</li>
<li class="L3542" rel="L3542"></li>
<li class="L3543" rel="L3543">“Ten o&#39;clock, sir.”</li>
<li class="L3544" rel="L3544"></li>
<li class="L3545" rel="L3545">“What do you mean? Ten o&#39;clock at night?”</li>
<li class="L3546" rel="L3546"></li>
<li class="L3547" rel="L3547">“Yes, sir. Your honour told me to call you.”</li>
<li class="L3548" rel="L3548"></li>
<li class="L3549" rel="L3549">“Oh! I remember. Very well, very well.”</li>
<li class="L3550" rel="L3550"></li>
<li class="L3551" rel="L3551">After a few dull efforts to get to sleep again, which the man</li>
<li class="L3552" rel="L3552">dexterously combated by stirring the fire continuously for five minutes,</li>
<li class="L3553" rel="L3553">he got up, tossed his hat on, and walked out. He turned into the Temple,</li>
<li class="L3554" rel="L3554">and, having revived himself by twice pacing the pavements of King&#39;s</li>
<li class="L3555" rel="L3555">Bench-walk and Paper-buildings, turned into the Stryver chambers.</li>
<li class="L3556" rel="L3556"></li>
<li class="L3557" rel="L3557">The Stryver clerk, who never assisted at these conferences, had gone</li>
<li class="L3558" rel="L3558">home, and the Stryver principal opened the door. He had his slippers on,</li>
<li class="L3559" rel="L3559">and a loose bed-gown, and his throat was bare for his greater ease. He</li>
<li class="L3560" rel="L3560">had that rather wild, strained, seared marking about the eyes, which</li>
<li class="L3561" rel="L3561">may be observed in all free livers of his class, from the portrait of</li>
<li class="L3562" rel="L3562">Jeffries downward, and which can be traced, under various disguises of</li>
<li class="L3563" rel="L3563">Art, through the portraits of every Drinking Age.</li>
<li class="L3564" rel="L3564"></li>
<li class="L3565" rel="L3565">“You are a little late, Memory,” said Stryver.</li>
<li class="L3566" rel="L3566"></li>
<li class="L3567" rel="L3567">“About the usual time; it may be a quarter of an hour later.”</li>
<li class="L3568" rel="L3568"></li>
<li class="L3569" rel="L3569">They went into a dingy room lined with books and littered with papers,</li>
<li class="L3570" rel="L3570">where there was a blazing fire. A kettle steamed upon the hob, and in</li>
<li class="L3571" rel="L3571">the midst of the wreck of papers a table shone, with plenty of wine upon</li>
<li class="L3572" rel="L3572">it, and brandy, and rum, and sugar, and lemons.</li>
<li class="L3573" rel="L3573"></li>
<li class="L3574" rel="L3574">“You have had your bottle, I perceive, Sydney.”</li>
<li class="L3575" rel="L3575"></li>
<li class="L3576" rel="L3576">“Two to-night, I think. I have been dining with the day&#39;s client; or</li>
<li class="L3577" rel="L3577">seeing him dine--it&#39;s all one!”</li>
<li class="L3578" rel="L3578"></li>
<li class="L3579" rel="L3579">“That was a rare point, Sydney, that you brought to bear upon the</li>
<li class="L3580" rel="L3580">identification. How did you come by it? When did it strike you?”</li>
<li class="L3581" rel="L3581"></li>
<li class="L3582" rel="L3582">“I thought he was rather a handsome fellow, and I thought I should have</li>
<li class="L3583" rel="L3583">been much the same sort of fellow, if I had had any luck.”</li>
<li class="L3584" rel="L3584"></li>
<li class="L3585" rel="L3585">Mr. Stryver laughed till he shook his precocious paunch.</li>
<li class="L3586" rel="L3586"></li>
<li class="L3587" rel="L3587">“You and your luck, Sydney! Get to work, get to work.”</li>
<li class="L3588" rel="L3588"></li>
<li class="L3589" rel="L3589">Sullenly enough, the jackal loosened his dress, went into an adjoining</li>
<li class="L3590" rel="L3590">room, and came back with a large jug of cold water, a basin, and a towel</li>
<li class="L3591" rel="L3591">or two. Steeping the towels in the water, and partially wringing them</li>
<li class="L3592" rel="L3592">out, he folded them on his head in a manner hideous to behold, sat down</li>
<li class="L3593" rel="L3593">at the table, and said, “Now I am ready!”</li>
<li class="L3594" rel="L3594"></li>
<li class="L3595" rel="L3595">“Not much boiling down to be done to-night, Memory,” said Mr. Stryver,</li>
<li class="L3596" rel="L3596">gaily, as he looked among his papers.</li>
<li class="L3597" rel="L3597"></li>
<li class="L3598" rel="L3598">“How much?”</li>
<li class="L3599" rel="L3599"></li>
<li class="L3600" rel="L3600">“Only two sets of them.”</li>
<li class="L3601" rel="L3601"></li>
<li class="L3602" rel="L3602">“Give me the worst first.”</li>
<li class="L3603" rel="L3603"></li>
<li class="L3604" rel="L3604">“There they are, Sydney. Fire away!”</li>
<li class="L3605" rel="L3605"></li>
<li class="L3606" rel="L3606">The lion then composed himself on his back on a sofa on one side of the</li>
<li class="L3607" rel="L3607">drinking-table, while the jackal sat at his own paper-bestrewn table</li>
<li class="L3608" rel="L3608">proper, on the other side of it, with the bottles and glasses ready to</li>
<li class="L3609" rel="L3609">his hand. Both resorted to the drinking-table without stint, but each in</li>
<li class="L3610" rel="L3610">a different way; the lion for the most part reclining with his hands in</li>
<li class="L3611" rel="L3611">his waistband, looking at the fire, or occasionally flirting with some</li>
<li class="L3612" rel="L3612">lighter document; the jackal, with knitted brows and intent face,</li>
<li class="L3613" rel="L3613">so deep in his task, that his eyes did not even follow the hand he</li>
<li class="L3614" rel="L3614">stretched out for his glass--which often groped about, for a minute or</li>
<li class="L3615" rel="L3615">more, before it found the glass for his lips. Two or three times, the</li>
<li class="L3616" rel="L3616">matter in hand became so knotty, that the jackal found it imperative on</li>
<li class="L3617" rel="L3617">him to get up, and steep his towels anew. From these pilgrimages to the</li>
<li class="L3618" rel="L3618">jug and basin, he returned with such eccentricities of damp headgear as</li>
<li class="L3619" rel="L3619">no words can describe; which were made the more ludicrous by his anxious</li>
<li class="L3620" rel="L3620">gravity.</li>
<li class="L3621" rel="L3621"></li>
<li class="L3622" rel="L3622">At length the jackal had got together a compact repast for the lion, and</li>
<li class="L3623" rel="L3623">proceeded to offer it to him. The lion took it with care and caution,</li>
<li class="L3624" rel="L3624">made his selections from it, and his remarks upon it, and the jackal</li>
<li class="L3625" rel="L3625">assisted both. When the repast was fully discussed, the lion put his</li>
<li class="L3626" rel="L3626">hands in his waistband again, and lay down to meditate. The jackal then</li>
<li class="L3627" rel="L3627">invigorated himself with a bumper for his throttle, and a fresh application</li>
<li class="L3628" rel="L3628">to his head, and applied himself to the collection of a second meal;</li>
<li class="L3629" rel="L3629">this was administered to the lion in the same manner, and was not</li>
<li class="L3630" rel="L3630">disposed of until the clocks struck three in the morning.</li>
<li class="L3631" rel="L3631"></li>
<li class="L3632" rel="L3632">“And now we have done, Sydney, fill a bumper of punch,” said Mr.</li>
<li class="L3633" rel="L3633">Stryver.</li>
<li class="L3634" rel="L3634"></li>
<li class="L3635" rel="L3635">The jackal removed the towels from his head, which had been steaming</li>
<li class="L3636" rel="L3636">again, shook himself, yawned, shivered, and complied.</li>
<li class="L3637" rel="L3637"></li>
<li class="L3638" rel="L3638">“You were very sound, Sydney, in the matter of those crown witnesses</li>
<li class="L3639" rel="L3639">to-day. Every question told.”</li>
<li class="L3640" rel="L3640"></li>
<li class="L3641" rel="L3641">“I always am sound; am I not?”</li>
<li class="L3642" rel="L3642"></li>
<li class="L3643" rel="L3643">“I don&#39;t gainsay it. What has roughened your temper? Put some punch to</li>
<li class="L3644" rel="L3644">it and smooth it again.”</li>
<li class="L3645" rel="L3645"></li>
<li class="L3646" rel="L3646">With a deprecatory grunt, the jackal again complied.</li>
<li class="L3647" rel="L3647"></li>
<li class="L3648" rel="L3648">“The old Sydney Carton of old Shrewsbury School,” said Stryver, nodding</li>
<li class="L3649" rel="L3649">his head over him as he reviewed him in the present and the past, “the</li>
<li class="L3650" rel="L3650">old seesaw Sydney. Up one minute and down the next; now in spirits and</li>
<li class="L3651" rel="L3651">now in despondency!”</li>
<li class="L3652" rel="L3652"></li>
<li class="L3653" rel="L3653">“Ah!” returned the other, sighing: “yes! The same Sydney, with the same</li>
<li class="L3654" rel="L3654">luck. Even then, I did exercises for other boys, and seldom did my own.”</li>
<li class="L3655" rel="L3655"></li>
<li class="L3656" rel="L3656">“And why not?”</li>
<li class="L3657" rel="L3657"></li>
<li class="L3658" rel="L3658">“God knows. It was my way, I suppose.”</li>
<li class="L3659" rel="L3659"></li>
<li class="L3660" rel="L3660">He sat, with his hands in his pockets and his legs stretched out before</li>
<li class="L3661" rel="L3661">him, looking at the fire.</li>
<li class="L3662" rel="L3662"></li>
<li class="L3663" rel="L3663">“Carton,” said his friend, squaring himself at him with a bullying air,</li>
<li class="L3664" rel="L3664">as if the fire-grate had been the furnace in which sustained endeavour</li>
<li class="L3665" rel="L3665">was forged, and the one delicate thing to be done for the old Sydney</li>
<li class="L3666" rel="L3666">Carton of old Shrewsbury School was to shoulder him into it, “your way</li>
<li class="L3667" rel="L3667">is, and always was, a lame way. You summon no energy and purpose. Look</li>
<li class="L3668" rel="L3668">at me.”</li>
<li class="L3669" rel="L3669"></li>
<li class="L3670" rel="L3670">“Oh, botheration!” returned Sydney, with a lighter and more</li>
<li class="L3671" rel="L3671">good-humoured laugh, “don&#39;t _you_ be moral!”</li>
<li class="L3672" rel="L3672"></li>
<li class="L3673" rel="L3673">“How have I done what I have done?” said Stryver; “how do I do what I</li>
<li class="L3674" rel="L3674">do?”</li>
<li class="L3675" rel="L3675"></li>
<li class="L3676" rel="L3676">“Partly through paying me to help you, I suppose. But it&#39;s not worth</li>
<li class="L3677" rel="L3677">your while to apostrophise me, or the air, about it; what you want to</li>
<li class="L3678" rel="L3678">do, you do. You were always in the front rank, and I was always behind.”</li>
<li class="L3679" rel="L3679"></li>
<li class="L3680" rel="L3680">“I had to get into the front rank; I was not born there, was I?”</li>
<li class="L3681" rel="L3681"></li>
<li class="L3682" rel="L3682">“I was not present at the ceremony; but my opinion is you were,” said</li>
<li class="L3683" rel="L3683">Carton. At this, he laughed again, and they both laughed.</li>
<li class="L3684" rel="L3684"></li>
<li class="L3685" rel="L3685">“Before Shrewsbury, and at Shrewsbury, and ever since Shrewsbury,”</li>
<li class="L3686" rel="L3686"> pursued Carton, “you have fallen into your rank, and I have fallen into</li>
<li class="L3687" rel="L3687">mine. Even when we were fellow-students in the Student-Quarter of Paris,</li>
<li class="L3688" rel="L3688">picking up French, and French law, and other French crumbs that we</li>
<li class="L3689" rel="L3689">didn&#39;t get much good of, you were always somewhere, and I was always</li>
<li class="L3690" rel="L3690">nowhere.”</li>
<li class="L3691" rel="L3691"></li>
<li class="L3692" rel="L3692">“And whose fault was that?”</li>
<li class="L3693" rel="L3693"></li>
<li class="L3694" rel="L3694">“Upon my soul, I am not sure that it was not yours. You were always</li>
<li class="L3695" rel="L3695">driving and riving and shouldering and passing, to that restless degree</li>
<li class="L3696" rel="L3696">that I had no chance for my life but in rust and repose. It&#39;s a gloomy</li>
<li class="L3697" rel="L3697">thing, however, to talk about one&#39;s own past, with the day breaking.</li>
<li class="L3698" rel="L3698">Turn me in some other direction before I go.”</li>
<li class="L3699" rel="L3699"></li>
<li class="L3700" rel="L3700">“Well then! Pledge me to the pretty witness,” said Stryver, holding up</li>
<li class="L3701" rel="L3701">his glass. “Are you turned in a pleasant direction?”</li>
<li class="L3702" rel="L3702"></li>
<li class="L3703" rel="L3703">Apparently not, for he became gloomy again.</li>
<li class="L3704" rel="L3704"></li>
<li class="L3705" rel="L3705">“Pretty witness,” he muttered, looking down into his glass. “I have had</li>
<li class="L3706" rel="L3706">enough of witnesses to-day and to-night; who&#39;s your pretty witness?”</li>
<li class="L3707" rel="L3707"></li>
<li class="L3708" rel="L3708">“The picturesque doctor&#39;s daughter, Miss Manette.”</li>
<li class="L3709" rel="L3709"></li>
<li class="L3710" rel="L3710">“_She_ pretty?”</li>
<li class="L3711" rel="L3711"></li>
<li class="L3712" rel="L3712">“Is she not?”</li>
<li class="L3713" rel="L3713"></li>
<li class="L3714" rel="L3714">“No.”</li>
<li class="L3715" rel="L3715"></li>
<li class="L3716" rel="L3716">“Why, man alive, she was the admiration of the whole Court!”</li>
<li class="L3717" rel="L3717"></li>
<li class="L3718" rel="L3718">“Rot the admiration of the whole Court! Who made the Old Bailey a judge</li>
<li class="L3719" rel="L3719">of beauty? She was a golden-haired doll!”</li>
<li class="L3720" rel="L3720"></li>
<li class="L3721" rel="L3721">“Do you know, Sydney,” said Mr. Stryver, looking at him with sharp eyes,</li>
<li class="L3722" rel="L3722">and slowly drawing a hand across his florid face: “do you know, I rather</li>
<li class="L3723" rel="L3723">thought, at the time, that you sympathised with the golden-haired doll,</li>
<li class="L3724" rel="L3724">and were quick to see what happened to the golden-haired doll?”</li>
<li class="L3725" rel="L3725"></li>
<li class="L3726" rel="L3726">“Quick to see what happened! If a girl, doll or no doll, swoons within a</li>
<li class="L3727" rel="L3727">yard or two of a man&#39;s nose, he can see it without a perspective-glass.</li>
<li class="L3728" rel="L3728">I pledge you, but I deny the beauty. And now I&#39;ll have no more drink;</li>
<li class="L3729" rel="L3729">I&#39;ll get to bed.”</li>
<li class="L3730" rel="L3730"></li>
<li class="L3731" rel="L3731">When his host followed him out on the staircase with a candle, to light</li>
<li class="L3732" rel="L3732">him down the stairs, the day was coldly looking in through its grimy</li>
<li class="L3733" rel="L3733">windows. When he got out of the house, the air was cold and sad, the</li>
<li class="L3734" rel="L3734">dull sky overcast, the river dark and dim, the whole scene like a</li>
<li class="L3735" rel="L3735">lifeless desert. And wreaths of dust were spinning round and round</li>
<li class="L3736" rel="L3736">before the morning blast, as if the desert-sand had risen far away, and</li>
<li class="L3737" rel="L3737">the first spray of it in its advance had begun to overwhelm the city.</li>
<li class="L3738" rel="L3738"></li>
<li class="L3739" rel="L3739">Waste forces within him, and a desert all around, this man stood still</li>
<li class="L3740" rel="L3740">on his way across a silent terrace, and saw for a moment, lying in the</li>
<li class="L3741" rel="L3741">wilderness before him, a mirage of honourable ambition, self-denial, and</li>
<li class="L3742" rel="L3742">perseverance. In the fair city of this vision, there were airy galleries</li>
<li class="L3743" rel="L3743">from which the loves and graces looked upon him, gardens in which the</li>
<li class="L3744" rel="L3744">fruits of life hung ripening, waters of Hope that sparkled in his sight.</li>
<li class="L3745" rel="L3745">A moment, and it was gone. Climbing to a high chamber in a well of</li>
<li class="L3746" rel="L3746">houses, he threw himself down in his clothes on a neglected bed, and its</li>
<li class="L3747" rel="L3747">pillow was wet with wasted tears.</li>
<li class="L3748" rel="L3748"></li>
<li class="L3749" rel="L3749">Sadly, sadly, the sun rose; it rose upon no sadder sight than the man of</li>
<li class="L3750" rel="L3750">good abilities and good emotions, incapable of their directed exercise,</li>
<li class="L3751" rel="L3751">incapable of his own help and his own happiness, sensible of the blight</li>
<li class="L3752" rel="L3752">on him, and resigning himself to let it eat him away.</li>
<li class="L3753" rel="L3753"></li>
<li class="L3754" rel="L3754"></li>
<li class="L3755" rel="L3755"></li>
<li class="L3756" rel="L3756"></li>
<li class="L3757" rel="L3757">VI. Hundreds of People</li>
<li class="L3758" rel="L3758"></li>
<li class="L3759" rel="L3759"></li>
<li class="L3760" rel="L3760">The quiet lodgings of Doctor Manette were in a quiet street-corner not</li>
<li class="L3761" rel="L3761">far from Soho-square. On the afternoon of a certain fine Sunday when the</li>
<li class="L3762" rel="L3762">waves of four months had rolled over the trial for treason, and carried</li>
<li class="L3763" rel="L3763">it, as to the public interest and memory, far out to sea, Mr. Jarvis</li>
<li class="L3764" rel="L3764">Lorry walked along the sunny streets from Clerkenwell where he lived,</li>
<li class="L3765" rel="L3765">on his way to dine with the Doctor. After several relapses into</li>
<li class="L3766" rel="L3766">business-absorption, Mr. Lorry had become the Doctor&#39;s friend, and the</li>
<li class="L3767" rel="L3767">quiet street-corner was the sunny part of his life.</li>
<li class="L3768" rel="L3768"></li>
<li class="L3769" rel="L3769">On this certain fine Sunday, Mr. Lorry walked towards Soho, early in</li>
<li class="L3770" rel="L3770">the afternoon, for three reasons of habit. Firstly, because, on fine</li>
<li class="L3771" rel="L3771">Sundays, he often walked out, before dinner, with the Doctor and Lucie;</li>
<li class="L3772" rel="L3772">secondly, because, on unfavourable Sundays, he was accustomed to be with</li>
<li class="L3773" rel="L3773">them as the family friend, talking, reading, looking out of window, and</li>
<li class="L3774" rel="L3774">generally getting through the day; thirdly, because he happened to have</li>
<li class="L3775" rel="L3775">his own little shrewd doubts to solve, and knew how the ways of the</li>
<li class="L3776" rel="L3776">Doctor&#39;s household pointed to that time as a likely time for solving</li>
<li class="L3777" rel="L3777">them.</li>
<li class="L3778" rel="L3778"></li>
<li class="L3779" rel="L3779">A quainter corner than the corner where the Doctor lived, was not to be</li>
<li class="L3780" rel="L3780">found in London. There was no way through it, and the front windows of</li>
<li class="L3781" rel="L3781">the Doctor&#39;s lodgings commanded a pleasant little vista of street that</li>
<li class="L3782" rel="L3782">had a congenial air of retirement on it. There were few buildings then,</li>
<li class="L3783" rel="L3783">north of the Oxford-road, and forest-trees flourished, and wild flowers</li>
<li class="L3784" rel="L3784">grew, and the hawthorn blossomed, in the now vanished fields. As a</li>
<li class="L3785" rel="L3785">consequence, country airs circulated in Soho with vigorous freedom,</li>
<li class="L3786" rel="L3786">instead of languishing into the parish like stray paupers without a</li>
<li class="L3787" rel="L3787">settlement; and there was many a good south wall, not far off, on which</li>
<li class="L3788" rel="L3788">the peaches ripened in their season.</li>
<li class="L3789" rel="L3789"></li>
<li class="L3790" rel="L3790">The summer light struck into the corner brilliantly in the earlier part</li>
<li class="L3791" rel="L3791">of the day; but, when the streets grew hot, the corner was in shadow,</li>
<li class="L3792" rel="L3792">though not in shadow so remote but that you could see beyond it into a</li>
<li class="L3793" rel="L3793">glare of brightness. It was a cool spot, staid but cheerful, a wonderful</li>
<li class="L3794" rel="L3794">place for echoes, and a very harbour from the raging streets.</li>
<li class="L3795" rel="L3795"></li>
<li class="L3796" rel="L3796">There ought to have been a tranquil bark in such an anchorage, and</li>
<li class="L3797" rel="L3797">there was. The Doctor occupied two floors of a large stiff house, where</li>
<li class="L3798" rel="L3798">several callings purported to be pursued by day, but whereof little was</li>
<li class="L3799" rel="L3799">audible any day, and which was shunned by all of them at night. In</li>
<li class="L3800" rel="L3800">a building at the back, attainable by a courtyard where a plane-tree</li>
<li class="L3801" rel="L3801">rustled its green leaves, church-organs claimed to be made, and silver</li>
<li class="L3802" rel="L3802">to be chased, and likewise gold to be beaten by some mysterious giant</li>
<li class="L3803" rel="L3803">who had a golden arm starting out of the wall of the front hall--as if</li>
<li class="L3804" rel="L3804">he had beaten himself precious, and menaced a similar conversion of all</li>
<li class="L3805" rel="L3805">visitors. Very little of these trades, or of a lonely lodger rumoured</li>
<li class="L3806" rel="L3806">to live up-stairs, or of a dim coach-trimming maker asserted to have</li>
<li class="L3807" rel="L3807">a counting-house below, was ever heard or seen. Occasionally, a stray</li>
<li class="L3808" rel="L3808">workman putting his coat on, traversed the hall, or a stranger peered</li>
<li class="L3809" rel="L3809">about there, or a distant clink was heard across the courtyard, or a</li>
<li class="L3810" rel="L3810">thump from the golden giant. These, however, were only the exceptions</li>
<li class="L3811" rel="L3811">required to prove the rule that the sparrows in the plane-tree behind</li>
<li class="L3812" rel="L3812">the house, and the echoes in the corner before it, had their own way</li>
<li class="L3813" rel="L3813">from Sunday morning unto Saturday night.</li>
<li class="L3814" rel="L3814"></li>
<li class="L3815" rel="L3815">Doctor Manette received such patients here as his old reputation, and</li>
<li class="L3816" rel="L3816">its revival in the floating whispers of his story, brought him.</li>
<li class="L3817" rel="L3817">His scientific knowledge, and his vigilance and skill in conducting</li>
<li class="L3818" rel="L3818">ingenious experiments, brought him otherwise into moderate request, and</li>
<li class="L3819" rel="L3819">he earned as much as he wanted.</li>
<li class="L3820" rel="L3820"></li>
<li class="L3821" rel="L3821">These things were within Mr. Jarvis Lorry&#39;s knowledge, thoughts, and</li>
<li class="L3822" rel="L3822">notice, when he rang the door-bell of the tranquil house in the corner,</li>
<li class="L3823" rel="L3823">on the fine Sunday afternoon.</li>
<li class="L3824" rel="L3824"></li>
<li class="L3825" rel="L3825">“Doctor Manette at home?”</li>
<li class="L3826" rel="L3826"></li>
<li class="L3827" rel="L3827">Expected home.</li>
<li class="L3828" rel="L3828"></li>
<li class="L3829" rel="L3829">“Miss Lucie at home?”</li>
<li class="L3830" rel="L3830"></li>
<li class="L3831" rel="L3831">Expected home.</li>
<li class="L3832" rel="L3832"></li>
<li class="L3833" rel="L3833">“Miss Pross at home?”</li>
<li class="L3834" rel="L3834"></li>
<li class="L3835" rel="L3835">Possibly at home, but of a certainty impossible for handmaid to</li>
<li class="L3836" rel="L3836">anticipate intentions of Miss Pross, as to admission or denial of the</li>
<li class="L3837" rel="L3837">fact.</li>
<li class="L3838" rel="L3838"></li>
<li class="L3839" rel="L3839">“As I am at home myself,” said Mr. Lorry, “I&#39;ll go upstairs.”</li>
<li class="L3840" rel="L3840"></li>
<li class="L3841" rel="L3841">Although the Doctor&#39;s daughter had known nothing of the country of her</li>
<li class="L3842" rel="L3842">birth, she appeared to have innately derived from it that ability to</li>
<li class="L3843" rel="L3843">make much of little means, which is one of its most useful and most</li>
<li class="L3844" rel="L3844">agreeable characteristics. Simple as the furniture was, it was set off</li>
<li class="L3845" rel="L3845">by so many little adornments, of no value but for their taste and fancy,</li>
<li class="L3846" rel="L3846">that its effect was delightful. The disposition of everything in the</li>
<li class="L3847" rel="L3847">rooms, from the largest object to the least; the arrangement of colours,</li>
<li class="L3848" rel="L3848">the elegant variety and contrast obtained by thrift in trifles, by</li>
<li class="L3849" rel="L3849">delicate hands, clear eyes, and good sense; were at once so pleasant in</li>
<li class="L3850" rel="L3850">themselves, and so expressive of their originator, that, as Mr. Lorry</li>
<li class="L3851" rel="L3851">stood looking about him, the very chairs and tables seemed to ask him,</li>
<li class="L3852" rel="L3852">with something of that peculiar expression which he knew so well by this</li>
<li class="L3853" rel="L3853">time, whether he approved?</li>
<li class="L3854" rel="L3854"></li>
<li class="L3855" rel="L3855">There were three rooms on a floor, and, the doors by which they</li>
<li class="L3856" rel="L3856">communicated being put open that the air might pass freely through them</li>
<li class="L3857" rel="L3857">all, Mr. Lorry, smilingly observant of that fanciful resemblance which</li>
<li class="L3858" rel="L3858">he detected all around him, walked from one to another. The first was</li>
<li class="L3859" rel="L3859">the best room, and in it were Lucie&#39;s birds, and flowers, and books,</li>
<li class="L3860" rel="L3860">and desk, and work-table, and box of water-colours; the second was</li>
<li class="L3861" rel="L3861">the Doctor&#39;s consulting-room, used also as the dining-room; the third,</li>
<li class="L3862" rel="L3862">changingly speckled by the rustle of the plane-tree in the yard, was the</li>
<li class="L3863" rel="L3863">Doctor&#39;s bedroom, and there, in a corner, stood the disused shoemaker&#39;s</li>
<li class="L3864" rel="L3864">bench and tray of tools, much as it had stood on the fifth floor of the</li>
<li class="L3865" rel="L3865">dismal house by the wine-shop, in the suburb of Saint Antoine in Paris.</li>
<li class="L3866" rel="L3866"></li>
<li class="L3867" rel="L3867">“I wonder,” said Mr. Lorry, pausing in his looking about, “that he keeps</li>
<li class="L3868" rel="L3868">that reminder of his sufferings about him!”</li>
<li class="L3869" rel="L3869"></li>
<li class="L3870" rel="L3870">“And why wonder at that?” was the abrupt inquiry that made him start.</li>
<li class="L3871" rel="L3871"></li>
<li class="L3872" rel="L3872">It proceeded from Miss Pross, the wild red woman, strong of hand, whose</li>
<li class="L3873" rel="L3873">acquaintance he had first made at the Royal George Hotel at Dover, and</li>
<li class="L3874" rel="L3874">had since improved.</li>
<li class="L3875" rel="L3875"></li>
<li class="L3876" rel="L3876">“I should have thought--” Mr. Lorry began.</li>
<li class="L3877" rel="L3877"></li>
<li class="L3878" rel="L3878">“Pooh! You&#39;d have thought!” said Miss Pross; and Mr. Lorry left off.</li>
<li class="L3879" rel="L3879"></li>
<li class="L3880" rel="L3880">“How do you do?” inquired that lady then--sharply, and yet as if to</li>
<li class="L3881" rel="L3881">express that she bore him no malice.</li>
<li class="L3882" rel="L3882"></li>
<li class="L3883" rel="L3883">“I am pretty well, I thank you,” answered Mr. Lorry, with meekness; “how</li>
<li class="L3884" rel="L3884">are you?”</li>
<li class="L3885" rel="L3885"></li>
<li class="L3886" rel="L3886">“Nothing to boast of,” said Miss Pross.</li>
<li class="L3887" rel="L3887"></li>
<li class="L3888" rel="L3888">“Indeed?”</li>
<li class="L3889" rel="L3889"></li>
<li class="L3890" rel="L3890">“Ah! indeed!” said Miss Pross. “I am very much put out about my</li>
<li class="L3891" rel="L3891">Ladybird.”</li>
<li class="L3892" rel="L3892"></li>
<li class="L3893" rel="L3893">“Indeed?”</li>
<li class="L3894" rel="L3894"></li>
<li class="L3895" rel="L3895">“For gracious sake say something else besides &#39;indeed,&#39; or you&#39;ll</li>
<li class="L3896" rel="L3896">fidget me to death,” said Miss Pross: whose character (dissociated from</li>
<li class="L3897" rel="L3897">stature) was shortness.</li>
<li class="L3898" rel="L3898"></li>
<li class="L3899" rel="L3899">“Really, then?” said Mr. Lorry, as an amendment.</li>
<li class="L3900" rel="L3900"></li>
<li class="L3901" rel="L3901">“Really, is bad enough,” returned Miss Pross, “but better. Yes, I am</li>
<li class="L3902" rel="L3902">very much put out.”</li>
<li class="L3903" rel="L3903"></li>
<li class="L3904" rel="L3904">“May I ask the cause?”</li>
<li class="L3905" rel="L3905"></li>
<li class="L3906" rel="L3906">“I don&#39;t want dozens of people who are not at all worthy of Ladybird, to</li>
