<li class="L3907" rel="L3907">come here looking after her,” said Miss Pross.</li>
<li class="L3908" rel="L3908"></li>
<li class="L3909" rel="L3909">“_Do_ dozens come for that purpose?”</li>
<li class="L3910" rel="L3910"></li>
<li class="L3911" rel="L3911">“Hundreds,” said Miss Pross.</li>
<li class="L3912" rel="L3912"></li>
<li class="L3913" rel="L3913">It was characteristic of this lady (as of some other people before her</li>
<li class="L3914" rel="L3914">time and since) that whenever her original proposition was questioned,</li>
<li class="L3915" rel="L3915">she exaggerated it.</li>
<li class="L3916" rel="L3916"></li>
<li class="L3917" rel="L3917">“Dear me!” said Mr. Lorry, as the safest remark he could think of.</li>
<li class="L3918" rel="L3918"></li>
<li class="L3919" rel="L3919">“I have lived with the darling--or the darling has lived with me, and</li>
<li class="L3920" rel="L3920">paid me for it; which she certainly should never have done, you may take</li>
<li class="L3921" rel="L3921">your affidavit, if I could have afforded to keep either myself or her</li>
<li class="L3922" rel="L3922">for nothing--since she was ten years old. And it&#39;s really very hard,”</li>
<li class="L3923" rel="L3923"> said Miss Pross.</li>
<li class="L3924" rel="L3924"></li>
<li class="L3925" rel="L3925">Not seeing with precision what was very hard, Mr. Lorry shook his head;</li>
<li class="L3926" rel="L3926">using that important part of himself as a sort of fairy cloak that would</li>
<li class="L3927" rel="L3927">fit anything.</li>
<li class="L3928" rel="L3928"></li>
<li class="L3929" rel="L3929">“All sorts of people who are not in the least degree worthy of the pet,</li>
<li class="L3930" rel="L3930">are always turning up,” said Miss Pross. “When you began it--”</li>
<li class="L3931" rel="L3931"></li>
<li class="L3932" rel="L3932">“_I_ began it, Miss Pross?”</li>
<li class="L3933" rel="L3933"></li>
<li class="L3934" rel="L3934">“Didn&#39;t you? Who brought her father to life?”</li>
<li class="L3935" rel="L3935"></li>
<li class="L3936" rel="L3936">“Oh! If _that_ was beginning it--” said Mr. Lorry.</li>
<li class="L3937" rel="L3937"></li>
<li class="L3938" rel="L3938">“It wasn&#39;t ending it, I suppose? I say, when you began it, it was hard</li>
<li class="L3939" rel="L3939">enough; not that I have any fault to find with Doctor Manette, except</li>
<li class="L3940" rel="L3940">that he is not worthy of such a daughter, which is no imputation on</li>
<li class="L3941" rel="L3941">him, for it was not to be expected that anybody should be, under any</li>
<li class="L3942" rel="L3942">circumstances. But it really is doubly and trebly hard to have crowds</li>
<li class="L3943" rel="L3943">and multitudes of people turning up after him (I could have forgiven</li>
<li class="L3944" rel="L3944">him), to take Ladybird&#39;s affections away from me.”</li>
<li class="L3945" rel="L3945"></li>
<li class="L3946" rel="L3946">Mr. Lorry knew Miss Pross to be very jealous, but he also knew her by</li>
<li class="L3947" rel="L3947">this time to be, beneath the service of her eccentricity, one of those</li>
<li class="L3948" rel="L3948">unselfish creatures--found only among women--who will, for pure love and</li>
<li class="L3949" rel="L3949">admiration, bind themselves willing slaves, to youth when they have lost</li>
<li class="L3950" rel="L3950">it, to beauty that they never had, to accomplishments that they were</li>
<li class="L3951" rel="L3951">never fortunate enough to gain, to bright hopes that never shone upon</li>
<li class="L3952" rel="L3952">their own sombre lives. He knew enough of the world to know that there</li>
<li class="L3953" rel="L3953">is nothing in it better than the faithful service of the heart; so</li>
<li class="L3954" rel="L3954">rendered and so free from any mercenary taint, he had such an exalted</li>
<li class="L3955" rel="L3955">respect for it, that in the retributive arrangements made by his own</li>
<li class="L3956" rel="L3956">mind--we all make such arrangements, more or less--he stationed Miss</li>
<li class="L3957" rel="L3957">Pross much nearer to the lower Angels than many ladies immeasurably</li>
<li class="L3958" rel="L3958">better got up both by Nature and Art, who had balances at Tellson&#39;s.</li>
<li class="L3959" rel="L3959"></li>
<li class="L3960" rel="L3960">“There never was, nor will be, but one man worthy of Ladybird,” said</li>
<li class="L3961" rel="L3961">Miss Pross; “and that was my brother Solomon, if he hadn&#39;t made a</li>
<li class="L3962" rel="L3962">mistake in life.”</li>
<li class="L3963" rel="L3963"></li>
<li class="L3964" rel="L3964">Here again: Mr. Lorry&#39;s inquiries into Miss Pross&#39;s personal history had</li>
<li class="L3965" rel="L3965">established the fact that her brother Solomon was a heartless scoundrel</li>
<li class="L3966" rel="L3966">who had stripped her of everything she possessed, as a stake to</li>
<li class="L3967" rel="L3967">speculate with, and had abandoned her in her poverty for evermore, with</li>
<li class="L3968" rel="L3968">no touch of compunction. Miss Pross&#39;s fidelity of belief in Solomon</li>
<li class="L3969" rel="L3969">(deducting a mere trifle for this slight mistake) was quite a serious</li>
<li class="L3970" rel="L3970">matter with Mr. Lorry, and had its weight in his good opinion of her.</li>
<li class="L3971" rel="L3971"></li>
<li class="L3972" rel="L3972">“As we happen to be alone for the moment, and are both people of</li>
<li class="L3973" rel="L3973">business,” he said, when they had got back to the drawing-room and had</li>
<li class="L3974" rel="L3974">sat down there in friendly relations, “let me ask you--does the Doctor,</li>
<li class="L3975" rel="L3975">in talking with Lucie, never refer to the shoemaking time, yet?”</li>
<li class="L3976" rel="L3976"></li>
<li class="L3977" rel="L3977">“Never.”</li>
<li class="L3978" rel="L3978"></li>
<li class="L3979" rel="L3979">“And yet keeps that bench and those tools beside him?”</li>
<li class="L3980" rel="L3980"></li>
<li class="L3981" rel="L3981">“Ah!” returned Miss Pross, shaking her head. “But I don&#39;t say he don&#39;t</li>
<li class="L3982" rel="L3982">refer to it within himself.”</li>
<li class="L3983" rel="L3983"></li>
<li class="L3984" rel="L3984">“Do you believe that he thinks of it much?”</li>
<li class="L3985" rel="L3985"></li>
<li class="L3986" rel="L3986">“I do,” said Miss Pross.</li>
<li class="L3987" rel="L3987"></li>
<li class="L3988" rel="L3988">“Do you imagine--” Mr. Lorry had begun, when Miss Pross took him up</li>
<li class="L3989" rel="L3989">short with:</li>
<li class="L3990" rel="L3990"></li>
<li class="L3991" rel="L3991">“Never imagine anything. Have no imagination at all.”</li>
<li class="L3992" rel="L3992"></li>
<li class="L3993" rel="L3993">“I stand corrected; do you suppose--you go so far as to suppose,</li>
<li class="L3994" rel="L3994">sometimes?”</li>
<li class="L3995" rel="L3995"></li>
<li class="L3996" rel="L3996">“Now and then,” said Miss Pross.</li>
<li class="L3997" rel="L3997"></li>
<li class="L3998" rel="L3998">“Do you suppose,” Mr. Lorry went on, with a laughing twinkle in his</li>
<li class="L3999" rel="L3999">bright eye, as it looked kindly at her, “that Doctor Manette has any</li>
<li class="L4000" rel="L4000">theory of his own, preserved through all those years, relative to</li>
<li class="L4001" rel="L4001">the cause of his being so oppressed; perhaps, even to the name of his</li>
<li class="L4002" rel="L4002">oppressor?”</li>
<li class="L4003" rel="L4003"></li>
<li class="L4004" rel="L4004">“I don&#39;t suppose anything about it but what Ladybird tells me.”</li>
<li class="L4005" rel="L4005"></li>
<li class="L4006" rel="L4006">“And that is--?”</li>
<li class="L4007" rel="L4007"></li>
<li class="L4008" rel="L4008">“That she thinks he has.”</li>
<li class="L4009" rel="L4009"></li>
<li class="L4010" rel="L4010">“Now don&#39;t be angry at my asking all these questions; because I am a</li>
<li class="L4011" rel="L4011">mere dull man of business, and you are a woman of business.”</li>
<li class="L4012" rel="L4012"></li>
<li class="L4013" rel="L4013">“Dull?” Miss Pross inquired, with placidity.</li>
<li class="L4014" rel="L4014"></li>
<li class="L4015" rel="L4015">Rather wishing his modest adjective away, Mr. Lorry replied, “No, no,</li>
<li class="L4016" rel="L4016">no. Surely not. To return to business:--Is it not remarkable that Doctor</li>
<li class="L4017" rel="L4017">Manette, unquestionably innocent of any crime as we are all well assured</li>
<li class="L4018" rel="L4018">he is, should never touch upon that question? I will not say with me,</li>
<li class="L4019" rel="L4019">though he had business relations with me many years ago, and we are now</li>
<li class="L4020" rel="L4020">intimate; I will say with the fair daughter to whom he is so devotedly</li>
<li class="L4021" rel="L4021">attached, and who is so devotedly attached to him? Believe me, Miss</li>
<li class="L4022" rel="L4022">Pross, I don&#39;t approach the topic with you, out of curiosity, but out of</li>
<li class="L4023" rel="L4023">zealous interest.”</li>
<li class="L4024" rel="L4024"></li>
<li class="L4025" rel="L4025">“Well! To the best of my understanding, and bad&#39;s the best, you&#39;ll tell</li>
<li class="L4026" rel="L4026">me,” said Miss Pross, softened by the tone of the apology, “he is afraid</li>
<li class="L4027" rel="L4027">of the whole subject.”</li>
<li class="L4028" rel="L4028"></li>
<li class="L4029" rel="L4029">“Afraid?”</li>
<li class="L4030" rel="L4030"></li>
<li class="L4031" rel="L4031">“It&#39;s plain enough, I should think, why he may be. It&#39;s a dreadful</li>
<li class="L4032" rel="L4032">remembrance. Besides that, his loss of himself grew out of it. Not</li>
<li class="L4033" rel="L4033">knowing how he lost himself, or how he recovered himself, he may never</li>
<li class="L4034" rel="L4034">feel certain of not losing himself again. That alone wouldn&#39;t make the</li>
<li class="L4035" rel="L4035">subject pleasant, I should think.”</li>
<li class="L4036" rel="L4036"></li>
<li class="L4037" rel="L4037">It was a profounder remark than Mr. Lorry had looked for. “True,” said</li>
<li class="L4038" rel="L4038">he, “and fearful to reflect upon. Yet, a doubt lurks in my mind, Miss</li>
<li class="L4039" rel="L4039">Pross, whether it is good for Doctor Manette to have that suppression</li>
<li class="L4040" rel="L4040">always shut up within him. Indeed, it is this doubt and the uneasiness</li>
<li class="L4041" rel="L4041">it sometimes causes me that has led me to our present confidence.”</li>
<li class="L4042" rel="L4042"></li>
<li class="L4043" rel="L4043">“Can&#39;t be helped,” said Miss Pross, shaking her head. “Touch that</li>
<li class="L4044" rel="L4044">string, and he instantly changes for the worse. Better leave it alone.</li>
<li class="L4045" rel="L4045">In short, must leave it alone, like or no like. Sometimes, he gets up in</li>
<li class="L4046" rel="L4046">the dead of the night, and will be heard, by us overhead there, walking</li>
<li class="L4047" rel="L4047">up and down, walking up and down, in his room. Ladybird has learnt to</li>
<li class="L4048" rel="L4048">know then that his mind is walking up and down, walking up and down, in</li>
<li class="L4049" rel="L4049">his old prison. She hurries to him, and they go on together, walking up</li>
<li class="L4050" rel="L4050">and down, walking up and down, until he is composed. But he never says</li>
<li class="L4051" rel="L4051">a word of the true reason of his restlessness, to her, and she finds it</li>
<li class="L4052" rel="L4052">best not to hint at it to him. In silence they go walking up and down</li>
<li class="L4053" rel="L4053">together, walking up and down together, till her love and company have</li>
<li class="L4054" rel="L4054">brought him to himself.”</li>
<li class="L4055" rel="L4055"></li>
<li class="L4056" rel="L4056">Notwithstanding Miss Pross&#39;s denial of her own imagination, there was a</li>
<li class="L4057" rel="L4057">perception of the pain of being monotonously haunted by one sad idea,</li>
<li class="L4058" rel="L4058">in her repetition of the phrase, walking up and down, which testified to</li>
<li class="L4059" rel="L4059">her possessing such a thing.</li>
<li class="L4060" rel="L4060"></li>
<li class="L4061" rel="L4061">The corner has been mentioned as a wonderful corner for echoes; it</li>
<li class="L4062" rel="L4062">had begun to echo so resoundingly to the tread of coming feet, that it</li>
<li class="L4063" rel="L4063">seemed as though the very mention of that weary pacing to and fro had</li>
<li class="L4064" rel="L4064">set it going.</li>
<li class="L4065" rel="L4065"></li>
<li class="L4066" rel="L4066">“Here they are!” said Miss Pross, rising to break up the conference;</li>
<li class="L4067" rel="L4067">“and now we shall have hundreds of people pretty soon!”</li>
<li class="L4068" rel="L4068"></li>
<li class="L4069" rel="L4069">It was such a curious corner in its acoustical properties, such a</li>
<li class="L4070" rel="L4070">peculiar Ear of a place, that as Mr. Lorry stood at the open window,</li>
<li class="L4071" rel="L4071">looking for the father and daughter whose steps he heard, he fancied</li>
<li class="L4072" rel="L4072">they would never approach. Not only would the echoes die away, as though</li>
<li class="L4073" rel="L4073">the steps had gone; but, echoes of other steps that never came would be</li>
<li class="L4074" rel="L4074">heard in their stead, and would die away for good when they seemed close</li>
<li class="L4075" rel="L4075">at hand. However, father and daughter did at last appear, and Miss Pross</li>
<li class="L4076" rel="L4076">was ready at the street door to receive them.</li>
<li class="L4077" rel="L4077"></li>
<li class="L4078" rel="L4078">Miss Pross was a pleasant sight, albeit wild, and red, and grim, taking</li>
<li class="L4079" rel="L4079">off her darling&#39;s bonnet when she came up-stairs, and touching it up</li>
<li class="L4080" rel="L4080">with the ends of her handkerchief, and blowing the dust off it, and</li>
<li class="L4081" rel="L4081">folding her mantle ready for laying by, and smoothing her rich hair with</li>
<li class="L4082" rel="L4082">as much pride as she could possibly have taken in her own hair if she</li>
<li class="L4083" rel="L4083">had been the vainest and handsomest of women. Her darling was a pleasant</li>
<li class="L4084" rel="L4084">sight too, embracing her and thanking her, and protesting against</li>
<li class="L4085" rel="L4085">her taking so much trouble for her--which last she only dared to do</li>
<li class="L4086" rel="L4086">playfully, or Miss Pross, sorely hurt, would have retired to her own</li>
<li class="L4087" rel="L4087">chamber and cried. The Doctor was a pleasant sight too, looking on at</li>
<li class="L4088" rel="L4088">them, and telling Miss Pross how she spoilt Lucie, in accents and with</li>
<li class="L4089" rel="L4089">eyes that had as much spoiling in them as Miss Pross had, and would</li>
<li class="L4090" rel="L4090">have had more if it were possible. Mr. Lorry was a pleasant sight too,</li>
<li class="L4091" rel="L4091">beaming at all this in his little wig, and thanking his bachelor</li>
<li class="L4092" rel="L4092">stars for having lighted him in his declining years to a Home. But, no</li>
<li class="L4093" rel="L4093">Hundreds of people came to see the sights, and Mr. Lorry looked in vain</li>
<li class="L4094" rel="L4094">for the fulfilment of Miss Pross&#39;s prediction.</li>
<li class="L4095" rel="L4095"></li>
<li class="L4096" rel="L4096">Dinner-time, and still no Hundreds of people. In the arrangements of</li>
<li class="L4097" rel="L4097">the little household, Miss Pross took charge of the lower regions, and</li>
<li class="L4098" rel="L4098">always acquitted herself marvellously. Her dinners, of a very modest</li>
<li class="L4099" rel="L4099">quality, were so well cooked and so well served, and so neat in their</li>
<li class="L4100" rel="L4100">contrivances, half English and half French, that nothing could be</li>
<li class="L4101" rel="L4101">better. Miss Pross&#39;s friendship being of the thoroughly practical</li>
<li class="L4102" rel="L4102">kind, she had ravaged Soho and the adjacent provinces, in search of</li>
<li class="L4103" rel="L4103">impoverished French, who, tempted by shillings and half-crowns, would</li>
<li class="L4104" rel="L4104">impart culinary mysteries to her. From these decayed sons and daughters</li>
<li class="L4105" rel="L4105">of Gaul, she had acquired such wonderful arts, that the woman and girl</li>
<li class="L4106" rel="L4106">who formed the staff of domestics regarded her as quite a Sorceress,</li>
<li class="L4107" rel="L4107">or Cinderella&#39;s Godmother: who would send out for a fowl, a rabbit,</li>
<li class="L4108" rel="L4108">a vegetable or two from the garden, and change them into anything she</li>
<li class="L4109" rel="L4109">pleased.</li>
<li class="L4110" rel="L4110"></li>
<li class="L4111" rel="L4111">On Sundays, Miss Pross dined at the Doctor&#39;s table, but on other days</li>
<li class="L4112" rel="L4112">persisted in taking her meals at unknown periods, either in the lower</li>
<li class="L4113" rel="L4113">regions, or in her own room on the second floor--a blue chamber, to</li>
<li class="L4114" rel="L4114">which no one but her Ladybird ever gained admittance. On this occasion,</li>
<li class="L4115" rel="L4115">Miss Pross, responding to Ladybird&#39;s pleasant face and pleasant efforts</li>
<li class="L4116" rel="L4116">to please her, unbent exceedingly; so the dinner was very pleasant, too.</li>
<li class="L4117" rel="L4117"></li>
<li class="L4118" rel="L4118">It was an oppressive day, and, after dinner, Lucie proposed that the</li>
<li class="L4119" rel="L4119">wine should be carried out under the plane-tree, and they should sit</li>
<li class="L4120" rel="L4120">there in the air. As everything turned upon her, and revolved about her,</li>
<li class="L4121" rel="L4121">they went out under the plane-tree, and she carried the wine down for</li>
<li class="L4122" rel="L4122">the special benefit of Mr. Lorry. She had installed herself, some</li>
<li class="L4123" rel="L4123">time before, as Mr. Lorry&#39;s cup-bearer; and while they sat under the</li>
<li class="L4124" rel="L4124">plane-tree, talking, she kept his glass replenished. Mysterious backs</li>
<li class="L4125" rel="L4125">and ends of houses peeped at them as they talked, and the plane-tree</li>
<li class="L4126" rel="L4126">whispered to them in its own way above their heads.</li>
<li class="L4127" rel="L4127"></li>
<li class="L4128" rel="L4128">Still, the Hundreds of people did not present themselves. Mr. Darnay</li>
<li class="L4129" rel="L4129">presented himself while they were sitting under the plane-tree, but he</li>
<li class="L4130" rel="L4130">was only One.</li>
<li class="L4131" rel="L4131"></li>
<li class="L4132" rel="L4132">Doctor Manette received him kindly, and so did Lucie. But, Miss Pross</li>
<li class="L4133" rel="L4133">suddenly became afflicted with a twitching in the head and body, and</li>
<li class="L4134" rel="L4134">retired into the house. She was not unfrequently the victim of this</li>
<li class="L4135" rel="L4135">disorder, and she called it, in familiar conversation, “a fit of the</li>
<li class="L4136" rel="L4136">jerks.”</li>
<li class="L4137" rel="L4137"></li>
<li class="L4138" rel="L4138">The Doctor was in his best condition, and looked specially young. The</li>
<li class="L4139" rel="L4139">resemblance between him and Lucie was very strong at such times, and as</li>
<li class="L4140" rel="L4140">they sat side by side, she leaning on his shoulder, and he resting</li>
<li class="L4141" rel="L4141">his arm on the back of her chair, it was very agreeable to trace the</li>
<li class="L4142" rel="L4142">likeness.</li>
<li class="L4143" rel="L4143"></li>
<li class="L4144" rel="L4144">He had been talking all day, on many subjects, and with unusual</li>
<li class="L4145" rel="L4145">vivacity. “Pray, Doctor Manette,” said Mr. Darnay, as they sat under the</li>
<li class="L4146" rel="L4146">plane-tree--and he said it in the natural pursuit of the topic in hand,</li>
<li class="L4147" rel="L4147">which happened to be the old buildings of London--“have you seen much of</li>
<li class="L4148" rel="L4148">the Tower?”</li>
<li class="L4149" rel="L4149"></li>
<li class="L4150" rel="L4150">“Lucie and I have been there; but only casually. We have seen enough of</li>
<li class="L4151" rel="L4151">it, to know that it teems with interest; little more.”</li>
<li class="L4152" rel="L4152"></li>
<li class="L4153" rel="L4153">“_I_ have been there, as you remember,” said Darnay, with a smile,</li>
<li class="L4154" rel="L4154">though reddening a little angrily, “in another character, and not in a</li>
<li class="L4155" rel="L4155">character that gives facilities for seeing much of it. They told me a</li>
<li class="L4156" rel="L4156">curious thing when I was there.”</li>
<li class="L4157" rel="L4157"></li>
<li class="L4158" rel="L4158">“What was that?” Lucie asked.</li>
<li class="L4159" rel="L4159"></li>
<li class="L4160" rel="L4160">“In making some alterations, the workmen came upon an old dungeon, which</li>
<li class="L4161" rel="L4161">had been, for many years, built up and forgotten. Every stone of</li>
<li class="L4162" rel="L4162">its inner wall was covered by inscriptions which had been carved by</li>
<li class="L4163" rel="L4163">prisoners--dates, names, complaints, and prayers. Upon a corner stone</li>
<li class="L4164" rel="L4164">in an angle of the wall, one prisoner, who seemed to have gone to</li>
<li class="L4165" rel="L4165">execution, had cut as his last work, three letters. They were done with</li>
<li class="L4166" rel="L4166">some very poor instrument, and hurriedly, with an unsteady hand.</li>
<li class="L4167" rel="L4167">At first, they were read as D. I. C.; but, on being more carefully</li>
<li class="L4168" rel="L4168">examined, the last letter was found to be G. There was no record or</li>
<li class="L4169" rel="L4169">legend of any prisoner with those initials, and many fruitless guesses</li>
<li class="L4170" rel="L4170">were made what the name could have been. At length, it was suggested</li>
<li class="L4171" rel="L4171">that the letters were not initials, but the complete word, DIG. The</li>
<li class="L4172" rel="L4172">floor was examined very carefully under the inscription, and, in the</li>
<li class="L4173" rel="L4173">earth beneath a stone, or tile, or some fragment of paving, were found</li>
<li class="L4174" rel="L4174">the ashes of a paper, mingled with the ashes of a small leathern case</li>
<li class="L4175" rel="L4175">or bag. What the unknown prisoner had written will never be read, but he</li>
<li class="L4176" rel="L4176">had written something, and hidden it away to keep it from the gaoler.”</li>
<li class="L4177" rel="L4177"></li>
<li class="L4178" rel="L4178">“My father,” exclaimed Lucie, “you are ill!”</li>
<li class="L4179" rel="L4179"></li>
<li class="L4180" rel="L4180">He had suddenly started up, with his hand to his head. His manner and</li>
<li class="L4181" rel="L4181">his look quite terrified them all.</li>
<li class="L4182" rel="L4182"></li>
<li class="L4183" rel="L4183">“No, my dear, not ill. There are large drops of rain falling, and they</li>
<li class="L4184" rel="L4184">made me start. We had better go in.”</li>
<li class="L4185" rel="L4185"></li>
<li class="L4186" rel="L4186">He recovered himself almost instantly. Rain was really falling in large</li>
<li class="L4187" rel="L4187">drops, and he showed the back of his hand with rain-drops on it. But, he</li>
<li class="L4188" rel="L4188">said not a single word in reference to the discovery that had been told</li>
<li class="L4189" rel="L4189">of, and, as they went into the house, the business eye of Mr. Lorry</li>
<li class="L4190" rel="L4190">either detected, or fancied it detected, on his face, as it turned</li>
<li class="L4191" rel="L4191">towards Charles Darnay, the same singular look that had been upon it</li>
<li class="L4192" rel="L4192">when it turned towards him in the passages of the Court House.</li>
<li class="L4193" rel="L4193"></li>
<li class="L4194" rel="L4194">He recovered himself so quickly, however, that Mr. Lorry had doubts of</li>
<li class="L4195" rel="L4195">his business eye. The arm of the golden giant in the hall was not more</li>
<li class="L4196" rel="L4196">steady than he was, when he stopped under it to remark to them that he</li>
<li class="L4197" rel="L4197">was not yet proof against slight surprises (if he ever would be), and</li>
<li class="L4198" rel="L4198">that the rain had startled him.</li>
<li class="L4199" rel="L4199"></li>
<li class="L4200" rel="L4200">Tea-time, and Miss Pross making tea, with another fit of the jerks upon</li>
<li class="L4201" rel="L4201">her, and yet no Hundreds of people. Mr. Carton had lounged in, but he</li>
<li class="L4202" rel="L4202">made only Two.</li>
<li class="L4203" rel="L4203"></li>
<li class="L4204" rel="L4204">The night was so very sultry, that although they sat with doors and</li>
<li class="L4205" rel="L4205">windows open, they were overpowered by heat. When the tea-table was</li>
<li class="L4206" rel="L4206">done with, they all moved to one of the windows, and looked out into the</li>
<li class="L4207" rel="L4207">heavy twilight. Lucie sat by her father; Darnay sat beside her; Carton</li>
<li class="L4208" rel="L4208">leaned against a window. The curtains were long and white, and some of</li>
<li class="L4209" rel="L4209">the thunder-gusts that whirled into the corner, caught them up to the</li>
<li class="L4210" rel="L4210">ceiling, and waved them like spectral wings.</li>
<li class="L4211" rel="L4211"></li>
<li class="L4212" rel="L4212">“The rain-drops are still falling, large, heavy, and few,” said Doctor</li>
<li class="L4213" rel="L4213">Manette. “It comes slowly.”</li>
<li class="L4214" rel="L4214"></li>
<li class="L4215" rel="L4215">“It comes surely,” said Carton.</li>
<li class="L4216" rel="L4216"></li>
<li class="L4217" rel="L4217">They spoke low, as people watching and waiting mostly do; as people in a</li>
<li class="L4218" rel="L4218">dark room, watching and waiting for Lightning, always do.</li>
<li class="L4219" rel="L4219"></li>
<li class="L4220" rel="L4220">There was a great hurry in the streets of people speeding away to</li>
<li class="L4221" rel="L4221">get shelter before the storm broke; the wonderful corner for echoes</li>
<li class="L4222" rel="L4222">resounded with the echoes of footsteps coming and going, yet not a</li>
<li class="L4223" rel="L4223">footstep was there.</li>
<li class="L4224" rel="L4224"></li>
<li class="L4225" rel="L4225">“A multitude of people, and yet a solitude!” said Darnay, when they had</li>
<li class="L4226" rel="L4226">listened for a while.</li>
<li class="L4227" rel="L4227"></li>
<li class="L4228" rel="L4228">“Is it not impressive, Mr. Darnay?” asked Lucie. “Sometimes, I have</li>
<li class="L4229" rel="L4229">sat here of an evening, until I have fancied--but even the shade of</li>
<li class="L4230" rel="L4230">a foolish fancy makes me shudder to-night, when all is so black and</li>
<li class="L4231" rel="L4231">solemn--”</li>
<li class="L4232" rel="L4232"></li>
<li class="L4233" rel="L4233">“Let us shudder too. We may know what it is.”</li>
<li class="L4234" rel="L4234"></li>
<li class="L4235" rel="L4235">“It will seem nothing to you. Such whims are only impressive as we</li>
<li class="L4236" rel="L4236">originate them, I think; they are not to be communicated. I have</li>
<li class="L4237" rel="L4237">sometimes sat alone here of an evening, listening, until I have made</li>
<li class="L4238" rel="L4238">the echoes out to be the echoes of all the footsteps that are coming</li>
<li class="L4239" rel="L4239">by-and-bye into our lives.”</li>
<li class="L4240" rel="L4240"></li>
<li class="L4241" rel="L4241">“There is a great crowd coming one day into our lives, if that be so,”</li>
<li class="L4242" rel="L4242"> Sydney Carton struck in, in his moody way.</li>
<li class="L4243" rel="L4243"></li>
<li class="L4244" rel="L4244">The footsteps were incessant, and the hurry of them became more and more</li>
<li class="L4245" rel="L4245">rapid. The corner echoed and re-echoed with the tread of feet; some,</li>
<li class="L4246" rel="L4246">as it seemed, under the windows; some, as it seemed, in the room; some</li>
<li class="L4247" rel="L4247">coming, some going, some breaking off, some stopping altogether; all in</li>
<li class="L4248" rel="L4248">the distant streets, and not one within sight.</li>
<li class="L4249" rel="L4249"></li>
<li class="L4250" rel="L4250">“Are all these footsteps destined to come to all of us, Miss Manette, or</li>
<li class="L4251" rel="L4251">are we to divide them among us?”</li>
<li class="L4252" rel="L4252"></li>
<li class="L4253" rel="L4253">“I don&#39;t know, Mr. Darnay; I told you it was a foolish fancy, but you</li>
<li class="L4254" rel="L4254">asked for it. When I have yielded myself to it, I have been alone, and</li>
<li class="L4255" rel="L4255">then I have imagined them the footsteps of the people who are to come</li>
<li class="L4256" rel="L4256">into my life, and my father&#39;s.”</li>
<li class="L4257" rel="L4257"></li>
<li class="L4258" rel="L4258">“I take them into mine!” said Carton. “_I_ ask no questions and make no</li>
<li class="L4259" rel="L4259">stipulations. There is a great crowd bearing down upon us, Miss Manette,</li>
<li class="L4260" rel="L4260">and I see them--by the Lightning.” He added the last words, after there</li>
<li class="L4261" rel="L4261">had been a vivid flash which had shown him lounging in the window.</li>
<li class="L4262" rel="L4262"></li>
<li class="L4263" rel="L4263">“And I hear them!” he added again, after a peal of thunder. “Here they</li>
<li class="L4264" rel="L4264">come, fast, fierce, and furious!”</li>
<li class="L4265" rel="L4265"></li>
<li class="L4266" rel="L4266">It was the rush and roar of rain that he typified, and it stopped him,</li>
<li class="L4267" rel="L4267">for no voice could be heard in it. A memorable storm of thunder and</li>
<li class="L4268" rel="L4268">lightning broke with that sweep of water, and there was not a moment&#39;s</li>
<li class="L4269" rel="L4269">interval in crash, and fire, and rain, until after the moon rose at</li>
<li class="L4270" rel="L4270">midnight.</li>
<li class="L4271" rel="L4271"></li>
<li class="L4272" rel="L4272">The great bell of Saint Paul&#39;s was striking one in the cleared air, when</li>
<li class="L4273" rel="L4273">Mr. Lorry, escorted by Jerry, high-booted and bearing a lantern, set</li>
<li class="L4274" rel="L4274">forth on his return-passage to Clerkenwell. There were solitary patches</li>
<li class="L4275" rel="L4275">of road on the way between Soho and Clerkenwell, and Mr. Lorry, mindful</li>
<li class="L4276" rel="L4276">of foot-pads, always retained Jerry for this service: though it was</li>
<li class="L4277" rel="L4277">usually performed a good two hours earlier.</li>
<li class="L4278" rel="L4278"></li>
<li class="L4279" rel="L4279">“What a night it has been! Almost a night, Jerry,” said Mr. Lorry, “to</li>
<li class="L4280" rel="L4280">bring the dead out of their graves.”</li>
<li class="L4281" rel="L4281"></li>
<li class="L4282" rel="L4282">“I never see the night myself, master--nor yet I don&#39;t expect to--what</li>
<li class="L4283" rel="L4283">would do that,” answered Jerry.</li>
<li class="L4284" rel="L4284"></li>
<li class="L4285" rel="L4285">“Good night, Mr. Carton,” said the man of business. “Good night, Mr.</li>
<li class="L4286" rel="L4286">Darnay. Shall we ever see such a night again, together!”</li>
<li class="L4287" rel="L4287"></li>
<li class="L4288" rel="L4288">Perhaps. Perhaps, see the great crowd of people with its rush and roar,</li>
<li class="L4289" rel="L4289">bearing down upon them, too.</li>
<li class="L4290" rel="L4290"></li>
<li class="L4291" rel="L4291"></li>
<li class="L4292" rel="L4292"></li>
<li class="L4293" rel="L4293"></li>
<li class="L4294" rel="L4294">VII. Monseigneur in Town</li>
<li class="L4295" rel="L4295"></li>
<li class="L4296" rel="L4296"></li>
<li class="L4297" rel="L4297">Monseigneur, one of the great lords in power at the Court, held his</li>
<li class="L4298" rel="L4298">fortnightly reception in his grand hotel in Paris. Monseigneur was in</li>
<li class="L4299" rel="L4299">his inner room, his sanctuary of sanctuaries, the Holiest of Holiests to</li>
<li class="L4300" rel="L4300">the crowd of worshippers in the suite of rooms without. Monseigneur</li>
<li class="L4301" rel="L4301">was about to take his chocolate. Monseigneur could swallow a great many</li>
<li class="L4302" rel="L4302">things with ease, and was by some few sullen minds supposed to be rather</li>
<li class="L4303" rel="L4303">rapidly swallowing France; but, his morning&#39;s chocolate could not so</li>
<li class="L4304" rel="L4304">much as get into the throat of Monseigneur, without the aid of four</li>
<li class="L4305" rel="L4305">strong men besides the Cook.</li>
<li class="L4306" rel="L4306"></li>
<li class="L4307" rel="L4307">Yes. It took four men, all four ablaze with gorgeous decoration, and the</li>
<li class="L4308" rel="L4308">Chief of them unable to exist with fewer than two gold watches in his</li>
<li class="L4309" rel="L4309">pocket, emulative of the noble and chaste fashion set by Monseigneur, to</li>
<li class="L4310" rel="L4310">conduct the happy chocolate to Monseigneur&#39;s lips. One lacquey carried</li>
<li class="L4311" rel="L4311">the chocolate-pot into the sacred presence; a second, milled and frothed</li>
<li class="L4312" rel="L4312">the chocolate with the little instrument he bore for that function;</li>
<li class="L4313" rel="L4313">a third, presented the favoured napkin; a fourth (he of the two gold</li>
<li class="L4314" rel="L4314">watches), poured the chocolate out. It was impossible for Monseigneur to</li>
<li class="L4315" rel="L4315">dispense with one of these attendants on the chocolate and hold his high</li>
<li class="L4316" rel="L4316">place under the admiring Heavens. Deep would have been the blot upon</li>
<li class="L4317" rel="L4317">his escutcheon if his chocolate had been ignobly waited on by only three</li>
<li class="L4318" rel="L4318">men; he must have died of two.</li>
<li class="L4319" rel="L4319"></li>
<li class="L4320" rel="L4320">Monseigneur had been out at a little supper last night, where the Comedy</li>
<li class="L4321" rel="L4321">and the Grand Opera were charmingly represented. Monseigneur was out at</li>
<li class="L4322" rel="L4322">a little supper most nights, with fascinating company. So polite and so</li>
<li class="L4323" rel="L4323">impressible was Monseigneur, that the Comedy and the Grand Opera had far</li>
<li class="L4324" rel="L4324">more influence with him in the tiresome articles of state affairs and</li>
<li class="L4325" rel="L4325">state secrets, than the needs of all France. A happy circumstance</li>
<li class="L4326" rel="L4326">for France, as the like always is for all countries similarly</li>
<li class="L4327" rel="L4327">favoured!--always was for England (by way of example), in the regretted</li>
<li class="L4328" rel="L4328">days of the merry Stuart who sold it.</li>
<li class="L4329" rel="L4329"></li>
<li class="L4330" rel="L4330">Monseigneur had one truly noble idea of general public business, which</li>
<li class="L4331" rel="L4331">was, to let everything go on in its own way; of particular public</li>
<li class="L4332" rel="L4332">business, Monseigneur had the other truly noble idea that it must all go</li>
<li class="L4333" rel="L4333">his way--tend to his own power and pocket. Of his pleasures, general and</li>
<li class="L4334" rel="L4334">particular, Monseigneur had the other truly noble idea, that the world</li>
<li class="L4335" rel="L4335">was made for them. The text of his order (altered from the original</li>
<li class="L4336" rel="L4336">by only a pronoun, which is not much) ran: “The earth and the fulness</li>
<li class="L4337" rel="L4337">thereof are mine, saith Monseigneur.”</li>
<li class="L4338" rel="L4338"></li>
<li class="L4339" rel="L4339">Yet, Monseigneur had slowly found that vulgar embarrassments crept into</li>
<li class="L4340" rel="L4340">his affairs, both private and public; and he had, as to both classes of</li>
<li class="L4341" rel="L4341">affairs, allied himself perforce with a Farmer-General. As to finances</li>
<li class="L4342" rel="L4342">public, because Monseigneur could not make anything at all of them, and</li>
<li class="L4343" rel="L4343">must consequently let them out to somebody who could; as to finances</li>
<li class="L4344" rel="L4344">private, because Farmer-Generals were rich, and Monseigneur, after</li>
<li class="L4345" rel="L4345">generations of great luxury and expense, was growing poor. Hence</li>
<li class="L4346" rel="L4346">Monseigneur had taken his sister from a convent, while there was yet</li>
<li class="L4347" rel="L4347">time to ward off the impending veil, the cheapest garment she could</li>
<li class="L4348" rel="L4348">wear, and had bestowed her as a prize upon a very rich Farmer-General,</li>
<li class="L4349" rel="L4349">poor in family. Which Farmer-General, carrying an appropriate cane with</li>
<li class="L4350" rel="L4350">a golden apple on the top of it, was now among the company in the outer</li>
<li class="L4351" rel="L4351">rooms, much prostrated before by mankind--always excepting superior</li>
<li class="L4352" rel="L4352">mankind of the blood of Monseigneur, who, his own wife included, looked</li>
<li class="L4353" rel="L4353">down upon him with the loftiest contempt.</li>
<li class="L4354" rel="L4354"></li>
<li class="L4355" rel="L4355">A sumptuous man was the Farmer-General. Thirty horses stood in his</li>
<li class="L4356" rel="L4356">stables, twenty-four male domestics sat in his halls, six body-women</li>
<li class="L4357" rel="L4357">waited on his wife. As one who pretended to do nothing but plunder and</li>
<li class="L4358" rel="L4358">forage where he could, the Farmer-General--howsoever his matrimonial</li>
<li class="L4359" rel="L4359">relations conduced to social morality--was at least the greatest reality</li>
<li class="L4360" rel="L4360">among the personages who attended at the hotel of Monseigneur that day.</li>
<li class="L4361" rel="L4361"></li>
<li class="L4362" rel="L4362">For, the rooms, though a beautiful scene to look at, and adorned with</li>
<li class="L4363" rel="L4363">every device of decoration that the taste and skill of the time could</li>
<li class="L4364" rel="L4364">achieve, were, in truth, not a sound business; considered with any</li>
<li class="L4365" rel="L4365">reference to the scarecrows in the rags and nightcaps elsewhere (and not</li>
<li class="L4366" rel="L4366">so far off, either, but that the watching towers of Notre Dame, almost</li>
<li class="L4367" rel="L4367">equidistant from the two extremes, could see them both), they would</li>
<li class="L4368" rel="L4368">have been an exceedingly uncomfortable business--if that could have</li>
<li class="L4369" rel="L4369">been anybody&#39;s business, at the house of Monseigneur. Military officers</li>
<li class="L4370" rel="L4370">destitute of military knowledge; naval officers with no idea of a ship;</li>
<li class="L4371" rel="L4371">civil officers without a notion of affairs; brazen ecclesiastics, of the</li>
<li class="L4372" rel="L4372">worst world worldly, with sensual eyes, loose tongues, and looser lives;</li>
<li class="L4373" rel="L4373">all totally unfit for their several callings, all lying horribly in</li>
<li class="L4374" rel="L4374">pretending to belong to them, but all nearly or remotely of the order of</li>
<li class="L4375" rel="L4375">Monseigneur, and therefore foisted on all public employments from which</li>
<li class="L4376" rel="L4376">anything was to be got; these were to be told off by the score and the</li>
<li class="L4377" rel="L4377">score. People not immediately connected with Monseigneur or the State,</li>
<li class="L4378" rel="L4378">yet equally unconnected with anything that was real, or with lives</li>
<li class="L4379" rel="L4379">passed in travelling by any straight road to any true earthly end, were</li>
<li class="L4380" rel="L4380">no less abundant. Doctors who made great fortunes out of dainty remedies</li>
<li class="L4381" rel="L4381">for imaginary disorders that never existed, smiled upon their courtly</li>
<li class="L4382" rel="L4382">patients in the ante-chambers of Monseigneur. Projectors who had</li>
<li class="L4383" rel="L4383">discovered every kind of remedy for the little evils with which the</li>
<li class="L4384" rel="L4384">State was touched, except the remedy of setting to work in earnest to</li>
<li class="L4385" rel="L4385">root out a single sin, poured their distracting babble into any ears</li>
<li class="L4386" rel="L4386">they could lay hold of, at the reception of Monseigneur. Unbelieving</li>
<li class="L4387" rel="L4387">Philosophers who were remodelling the world with words, and making</li>
<li class="L4388" rel="L4388">card-towers of Babel to scale the skies with, talked with Unbelieving</li>
<li class="L4389" rel="L4389">Chemists who had an eye on the transmutation of metals, at this</li>
<li class="L4390" rel="L4390">wonderful gathering accumulated by Monseigneur. Exquisite gentlemen of</li>
<li class="L4391" rel="L4391">the finest breeding, which was at that remarkable time--and has been</li>
<li class="L4392" rel="L4392">since--to be known by its fruits of indifference to every natural</li>
<li class="L4393" rel="L4393">subject of human interest, were in the most exemplary state of</li>
<li class="L4394" rel="L4394">exhaustion, at the hotel of Monseigneur. Such homes had these various</li>
<li class="L4395" rel="L4395">notabilities left behind them in the fine world of Paris, that the spies</li>
<li class="L4396" rel="L4396">among the assembled devotees of Monseigneur--forming a goodly half</li>
<li class="L4397" rel="L4397">of the polite company--would have found it hard to discover among</li>
<li class="L4398" rel="L4398">the angels of that sphere one solitary wife, who, in her manners and</li>
<li class="L4399" rel="L4399">appearance, owned to being a Mother. Indeed, except for the mere act of</li>
<li class="L4400" rel="L4400">bringing a troublesome creature into this world--which does not go far</li>
<li class="L4401" rel="L4401">towards the realisation of the name of mother--there was no such thing</li>
<li class="L4402" rel="L4402">known to the fashion. Peasant women kept the unfashionable babies close,</li>
<li class="L4403" rel="L4403">and brought them up, and charming grandmammas of sixty dressed and</li>
<li class="L4404" rel="L4404">supped as at twenty.</li>
<li class="L4405" rel="L4405"></li>
<li class="L4406" rel="L4406">The leprosy of unreality disfigured every human creature in attendance</li>
<li class="L4407" rel="L4407">upon Monseigneur. In the outermost room were half a dozen exceptional</li>
<li class="L4408" rel="L4408">people who had had, for a few years, some vague misgiving in them that</li>
<li class="L4409" rel="L4409">things in general were going rather wrong. As a promising way of setting</li>
<li class="L4410" rel="L4410">them right, half of the half-dozen had become members of a fantastic</li>
<li class="L4411" rel="L4411">sect of Convulsionists, and were even then considering within themselves</li>
<li class="L4412" rel="L4412">whether they should foam, rage, roar, and turn cataleptic on the</li>
<li class="L4413" rel="L4413">spot--thereby setting up a highly intelligible finger-post to the</li>
<li class="L4414" rel="L4414">Future, for Monseigneur&#39;s guidance. Besides these Dervishes, were other</li>
<li class="L4415" rel="L4415">three who had rushed into another sect, which mended matters with a</li>
<li class="L4416" rel="L4416">jargon about “the Centre of Truth:” holding that Man had got out of the</li>
<li class="L4417" rel="L4417">Centre of Truth--which did not need much demonstration--but had not got</li>
<li class="L4418" rel="L4418">out of the Circumference, and that he was to be kept from flying out of</li>
<li class="L4419" rel="L4419">the Circumference, and was even to be shoved back into the Centre,</li>
<li class="L4420" rel="L4420">by fasting and seeing of spirits. Among these, accordingly, much</li>
<li class="L4421" rel="L4421">discoursing with spirits went on--and it did a world of good which never</li>
<li class="L4422" rel="L4422">became manifest.</li>
<li class="L4423" rel="L4423"></li>
<li class="L4424" rel="L4424">But, the comfort was, that all the company at the grand hotel of</li>
<li class="L4425" rel="L4425">Monseigneur were perfectly dressed. If the Day of Judgment had only been</li>
<li class="L4426" rel="L4426">ascertained to be a dress day, everybody there would have been eternally</li>
<li class="L4427" rel="L4427">correct. Such frizzling and powdering and sticking up of hair, such</li>
<li class="L4428" rel="L4428">delicate complexions artificially preserved and mended, such gallant</li>
<li class="L4429" rel="L4429">swords to look at, and such delicate honour to the sense of smell, would</li>
<li class="L4430" rel="L4430">surely keep anything going, for ever and ever. The exquisite gentlemen</li>
<li class="L4431" rel="L4431">of the finest breeding wore little pendent trinkets that chinked as they</li>
<li class="L4432" rel="L4432">languidly moved; these golden fetters rang like precious little bells;</li>
<li class="L4433" rel="L4433">and what with that ringing, and with the rustle of silk and brocade and</li>
<li class="L4434" rel="L4434">fine linen, there was a flutter in the air that fanned Saint Antoine and</li>
<li class="L4435" rel="L4435">his devouring hunger far away.</li>
<li class="L4436" rel="L4436"></li>
<li class="L4437" rel="L4437">Dress was the one unfailing talisman and charm used for keeping all</li>
<li class="L4438" rel="L4438">things in their places. Everybody was dressed for a Fancy Ball that</li>
<li class="L4439" rel="L4439">was never to leave off. From the Palace of the Tuileries, through</li>
<li class="L4440" rel="L4440">Monseigneur and the whole Court, through the Chambers, the Tribunals</li>
<li class="L4441" rel="L4441">of Justice, and all society (except the scarecrows), the Fancy Ball</li>
<li class="L4442" rel="L4442">descended to the Common Executioner: who, in pursuance of the charm, was</li>
<li class="L4443" rel="L4443">required to officiate “frizzled, powdered, in a gold-laced coat, pumps,</li>
<li class="L4444" rel="L4444">and white silk stockings.” At the gallows and the wheel--the axe was a</li>
<li class="L4445" rel="L4445">rarity--Monsieur Paris, as it was the episcopal mode among his brother</li>
<li class="L4446" rel="L4446">Professors of the provinces, Monsieur Orleans, and the rest, to call</li>
<li class="L4447" rel="L4447">him, presided in this dainty dress. And who among the company at</li>
<li class="L4448" rel="L4448">Monseigneur&#39;s reception in that seventeen hundred and eightieth year</li>
<li class="L4449" rel="L4449">of our Lord, could possibly doubt, that a system rooted in a frizzled</li>
<li class="L4450" rel="L4450">hangman, powdered, gold-laced, pumped, and white-silk stockinged, would</li>
<li class="L4451" rel="L4451">see the very stars out!</li>
<li class="L4452" rel="L4452"></li>
<li class="L4453" rel="L4453">Monseigneur having eased his four men of their burdens and taken his</li>
<li class="L4454" rel="L4454">chocolate, caused the doors of the Holiest of Holiests to be thrown</li>
<li class="L4455" rel="L4455">open, and issued forth. Then, what submission, what cringing and</li>
<li class="L4456" rel="L4456">fawning, what servility, what abject humiliation! As to bowing down in</li>
<li class="L4457" rel="L4457">body and spirit, nothing in that way was left for Heaven--which may have</li>
<li class="L4458" rel="L4458">been one among other reasons why the worshippers of Monseigneur never</li>
<li class="L4459" rel="L4459">troubled it.</li>
<li class="L4460" rel="L4460"></li>
<li class="L4461" rel="L4461">Bestowing a word of promise here and a smile there, a whisper on one</li>
<li class="L4462" rel="L4462">happy slave and a wave of the hand on another, Monseigneur affably</li>
<li class="L4463" rel="L4463">passed through his rooms to the remote region of the Circumference of</li>
<li class="L4464" rel="L4464">Truth. There, Monseigneur turned, and came back again, and so in due</li>
<li class="L4465" rel="L4465">course of time got himself shut up in his sanctuary by the chocolate</li>
<li class="L4466" rel="L4466">sprites, and was seen no more.</li>
<li class="L4467" rel="L4467"></li>
<li class="L4468" rel="L4468">The show being over, the flutter in the air became quite a little storm,</li>
<li class="L4469" rel="L4469">and the precious little bells went ringing downstairs. There was soon</li>
<li class="L4470" rel="L4470">but one person left of all the crowd, and he, with his hat under his arm</li>
<li class="L4471" rel="L4471">and his snuff-box in his hand, slowly passed among the mirrors on his</li>
<li class="L4472" rel="L4472">way out.</li>
<li class="L4473" rel="L4473"></li>
<li class="L4474" rel="L4474">“I devote you,” said this person, stopping at the last door on his way,</li>
<li class="L4475" rel="L4475">and turning in the direction of the sanctuary, “to the Devil!”</li>
<li class="L4476" rel="L4476"></li>
<li class="L4477" rel="L4477">With that, he shook the snuff from his fingers as if he had shaken the</li>
<li class="L4478" rel="L4478">dust from his feet, and quietly walked downstairs.</li>
<li class="L4479" rel="L4479"></li>
<li class="L4480" rel="L4480">He was a man of about sixty, handsomely dressed, haughty in manner, and</li>
<li class="L4481" rel="L4481">with a face like a fine mask. A face of a transparent paleness; every</li>
<li class="L4482" rel="L4482">feature in it clearly defined; one set expression on it. The nose,</li>
<li class="L4483" rel="L4483">beautifully formed otherwise, was very slightly pinched at the top</li>
<li class="L4484" rel="L4484">of each nostril. In those two compressions, or dints, the only little</li>
<li class="L4485" rel="L4485">change that the face ever showed, resided. They persisted in changing</li>
<li class="L4486" rel="L4486">colour sometimes, and they would be occasionally dilated and contracted</li>
<li class="L4487" rel="L4487">by something like a faint pulsation; then, they gave a look of</li>
<li class="L4488" rel="L4488">treachery, and cruelty, to the whole countenance. Examined with</li>
<li class="L4489" rel="L4489">attention, its capacity of helping such a look was to be found in the</li>
<li class="L4490" rel="L4490">line of the mouth, and the lines of the orbits of the eyes, being much</li>
<li class="L4491" rel="L4491">too horizontal and thin; still, in the effect of the face made, it was a</li>
<li class="L4492" rel="L4492">handsome face, and a remarkable one.</li>
<li class="L4493" rel="L4493"></li>
<li class="L4494" rel="L4494">Its owner went downstairs into the courtyard, got into his carriage, and</li>
<li class="L4495" rel="L4495">drove away. Not many people had talked with him at the reception; he had</li>
<li class="L4496" rel="L4496">stood in a little space apart, and Monseigneur might have been warmer</li>
<li class="L4497" rel="L4497">in his manner. It appeared, under the circumstances, rather agreeable</li>
<li class="L4498" rel="L4498">to him to see the common people dispersed before his horses, and</li>
<li class="L4499" rel="L4499">often barely escaping from being run down. His man drove as if he were</li>
<li class="L4500" rel="L4500">charging an enemy, and the furious recklessness of the man brought no</li>
<li class="L4501" rel="L4501">check into the face, or to the lips, of the master. The complaint had</li>
<li class="L4502" rel="L4502">sometimes made itself audible, even in that deaf city and dumb age,</li>
<li class="L4503" rel="L4503">that, in the narrow streets without footways, the fierce patrician</li>
<li class="L4504" rel="L4504">custom of hard driving endangered and maimed the mere vulgar in a</li>
<li class="L4505" rel="L4505">barbarous manner. But, few cared enough for that to think of it a second</li>
<li class="L4506" rel="L4506">time, and, in this matter, as in all others, the common wretches were</li>
<li class="L4507" rel="L4507">left to get out of their difficulties as they could.</li>
<li class="L4508" rel="L4508"></li>
<li class="L4509" rel="L4509">With a wild rattle and clatter, and an inhuman abandonment of</li>
<li class="L4510" rel="L4510">consideration not easy to be understood in these days, the carriage</li>
<li class="L4511" rel="L4511">dashed through streets and swept round corners, with women screaming</li>
<li class="L4512" rel="L4512">before it, and men clutching each other and clutching children out of</li>
<li class="L4513" rel="L4513">its way. At last, swooping at a street corner by a fountain, one of its</li>
<li class="L4514" rel="L4514">wheels came to a sickening little jolt, and there was a loud cry from a</li>
<li class="L4515" rel="L4515">number of voices, and the horses reared and plunged.</li>
<li class="L4516" rel="L4516"></li>
<li class="L4517" rel="L4517">But for the latter inconvenience, the carriage probably would not have</li>
<li class="L4518" rel="L4518">stopped; carriages were often known to drive on, and leave their wounded</li>
<li class="L4519" rel="L4519">behind, and why not? But the frightened valet had got down in a hurry,</li>
<li class="L4520" rel="L4520">and there were twenty hands at the horses&#39; bridles.</li>
<li class="L4521" rel="L4521"></li>
<li class="L4522" rel="L4522">“What has gone wrong?” said Monsieur, calmly looking out.</li>
<li class="L4523" rel="L4523"></li>
<li class="L4524" rel="L4524">A tall man in a nightcap had caught up a bundle from among the feet of</li>
<li class="L4525" rel="L4525">the horses, and had laid it on the basement of the fountain, and was</li>
<li class="L4526" rel="L4526">down in the mud and wet, howling over it like a wild animal.</li>
<li class="L4527" rel="L4527"></li>
<li class="L4528" rel="L4528">“Pardon, Monsieur the Marquis!” said a ragged and submissive man, “it is</li>
<li class="L4529" rel="L4529">a child.”</li>
<li class="L4530" rel="L4530"></li>
<li class="L4531" rel="L4531">“Why does he make that abominable noise? Is it his child?”</li>
<li class="L4532" rel="L4532"></li>
<li class="L4533" rel="L4533">“Excuse me, Monsieur the Marquis--it is a pity--yes.”</li>
<li class="L4534" rel="L4534"></li>
<li class="L4535" rel="L4535">The fountain was a little removed; for the street opened, where it was,</li>
<li class="L4536" rel="L4536">into a space some ten or twelve yards square. As the tall man suddenly</li>
<li class="L4537" rel="L4537">got up from the ground, and came running at the carriage, Monsieur the</li>
<li class="L4538" rel="L4538">Marquis clapped his hand for an instant on his sword-hilt.</li>
<li class="L4539" rel="L4539"></li>
<li class="L4540" rel="L4540">“Killed!” shrieked the man, in wild desperation, extending both arms at</li>
<li class="L4541" rel="L4541">their length above his head, and staring at him. “Dead!”</li>
<li class="L4542" rel="L4542"></li>
<li class="L4543" rel="L4543">The people closed round, and looked at Monsieur the Marquis. There was</li>
<li class="L4544" rel="L4544">nothing revealed by the many eyes that looked at him but watchfulness</li>
<li class="L4545" rel="L4545">and eagerness; there was no visible menacing or anger. Neither did the</li>
<li class="L4546" rel="L4546">people say anything; after the first cry, they had been silent, and they</li>
<li class="L4547" rel="L4547">remained so. The voice of the submissive man who had spoken, was flat</li>
<li class="L4548" rel="L4548">and tame in its extreme submission. Monsieur the Marquis ran his eyes</li>
<li class="L4549" rel="L4549">over them all, as if they had been mere rats come out of their holes.</li>
<li class="L4550" rel="L4550"></li>
<li class="L4551" rel="L4551">He took out his purse.</li>
<li class="L4552" rel="L4552"></li>
<li class="L4553" rel="L4553">“It is extraordinary to me,” said he, “that you people cannot take care</li>
<li class="L4554" rel="L4554">of yourselves and your children. One or the other of you is for ever in</li>
<li class="L4555" rel="L4555">the way. How do I know what injury you have done my horses. See! Give</li>
<li class="L4556" rel="L4556">him that.”</li>
<li class="L4557" rel="L4557"></li>
<li class="L4558" rel="L4558">He threw out a gold coin for the valet to pick up, and all the heads</li>
<li class="L4559" rel="L4559">craned forward that all the eyes might look down at it as it fell. The</li>
<li class="L4560" rel="L4560">tall man called out again with a most unearthly cry, “Dead!”</li>
<li class="L4561" rel="L4561"></li>
<li class="L4562" rel="L4562">He was arrested by the quick arrival of another man, for whom the rest</li>
<li class="L4563" rel="L4563">made way. On seeing him, the miserable creature fell upon his shoulder,</li>
<li class="L4564" rel="L4564">sobbing and crying, and pointing to the fountain, where some women were</li>
<li class="L4565" rel="L4565">stooping over the motionless bundle, and moving gently about it. They</li>
<li class="L4566" rel="L4566">were as silent, however, as the men.</li>
<li class="L4567" rel="L4567"></li>
<li class="L4568" rel="L4568">“I know all, I know all,” said the last comer. “Be a brave man, my</li>
<li class="L4569" rel="L4569">Gaspard! It is better for the poor little plaything to die so, than to</li>
<li class="L4570" rel="L4570">live. It has died in a moment without pain. Could it have lived an hour</li>
<li class="L4571" rel="L4571">as happily?”</li>
<li class="L4572" rel="L4572"></li>
<li class="L4573" rel="L4573">“You are a philosopher, you there,” said the Marquis, smiling. “How do</li>
<li class="L4574" rel="L4574">they call you?”</li>
<li class="L4575" rel="L4575"></li>
<li class="L4576" rel="L4576">“They call me Defarge.”</li>
<li class="L4577" rel="L4577"></li>
<li class="L4578" rel="L4578">“Of what trade?”</li>
<li class="L4579" rel="L4579"></li>
<li class="L4580" rel="L4580">“Monsieur the Marquis, vendor of wine.”</li>
<li class="L4581" rel="L4581"></li>
<li class="L4582" rel="L4582">“Pick up that, philosopher and vendor of wine,” said the Marquis,</li>
<li class="L4583" rel="L4583">throwing him another gold coin, “and spend it as you will. The horses</li>
<li class="L4584" rel="L4584">there; are they right?”</li>
<li class="L4585" rel="L4585"></li>
<li class="L4586" rel="L4586">Without deigning to look at the assemblage a second time, Monsieur the</li>
<li class="L4587" rel="L4587">Marquis leaned back in his seat, and was just being driven away with the</li>
<li class="L4588" rel="L4588">air of a gentleman who had accidentally broke some common thing, and had</li>
<li class="L4589" rel="L4589">paid for it, and could afford to pay for it; when his ease was suddenly</li>
<li class="L4590" rel="L4590">disturbed by a coin flying into his carriage, and ringing on its floor.</li>
<li class="L4591" rel="L4591"></li>
<li class="L4592" rel="L4592">“Hold!” said Monsieur the Marquis. “Hold the horses! Who threw that?”</li>
<li class="L4593" rel="L4593"></li>
<li class="L4594" rel="L4594">He looked to the spot where Defarge the vendor of wine had stood, a</li>
<li class="L4595" rel="L4595">moment before; but the wretched father was grovelling on his face on</li>
<li class="L4596" rel="L4596">the pavement in that spot, and the figure that stood beside him was the</li>
<li class="L4597" rel="L4597">figure of a dark stout woman, knitting.</li>
<li class="L4598" rel="L4598"></li>
<li class="L4599" rel="L4599">“You dogs!” said the Marquis, but smoothly, and with an unchanged front,</li>
<li class="L4600" rel="L4600">except as to the spots on his nose: “I would ride over any of you very</li>
<li class="L4601" rel="L4601">willingly, and exterminate you from the earth. If I knew which rascal</li>
<li class="L4602" rel="L4602">threw at the carriage, and if that brigand were sufficiently near it, he</li>
<li class="L4603" rel="L4603">should be crushed under the wheels.”</li>
<li class="L4604" rel="L4604"></li>
<li class="L4605" rel="L4605">So cowed was their condition, and so long and hard their experience of</li>
<li class="L4606" rel="L4606">what such a man could do to them, within the law and beyond it, that not</li>
<li class="L4607" rel="L4607">a voice, or a hand, or even an eye was raised. Among the men, not one.</li>
<li class="L4608" rel="L4608">But the woman who stood knitting looked up steadily, and looked the</li>
<li class="L4609" rel="L4609">Marquis in the face. It was not for his dignity to notice it; his</li>
<li class="L4610" rel="L4610">contemptuous eyes passed over her, and over all the other rats; and he</li>
<li class="L4611" rel="L4611">leaned back in his seat again, and gave the word “Go on!”</li>
<li class="L4612" rel="L4612"></li>
<li class="L4613" rel="L4613">He was driven on, and other carriages came whirling by in quick</li>
<li class="L4614" rel="L4614">succession; the Minister, the State-Projector, the Farmer-General, the</li>
<li class="L4615" rel="L4615">Doctor, the Lawyer, the Ecclesiastic, the Grand Opera, the Comedy, the</li>
<li class="L4616" rel="L4616">whole Fancy Ball in a bright continuous flow, came whirling by. The rats</li>
<li class="L4617" rel="L4617">had crept out of their holes to look on, and they remained looking</li>
<li class="L4618" rel="L4618">on for hours; soldiers and police often passing between them and the</li>
<li class="L4619" rel="L4619">spectacle, and making a barrier behind which they slunk, and through</li>
<li class="L4620" rel="L4620">which they peeped. The father had long ago taken up his bundle and</li>
<li class="L4621" rel="L4621">bidden himself away with it, when the women who had tended the bundle</li>
<li class="L4622" rel="L4622">while it lay on the base of the fountain, sat there watching the running</li>
<li class="L4623" rel="L4623">of the water and the rolling of the Fancy Ball--when the one woman who</li>
<li class="L4624" rel="L4624">had stood conspicuous, knitting, still knitted on with the steadfastness</li>
<li class="L4625" rel="L4625">of Fate. The water of the fountain ran, the swift river ran, the day ran</li>
<li class="L4626" rel="L4626">into evening, so much life in the city ran into death according to rule,</li>
<li class="L4627" rel="L4627">time and tide waited for no man, the rats were sleeping close together</li>
<li class="L4628" rel="L4628">in their dark holes again, the Fancy Ball was lighted up at supper, all</li>
<li class="L4629" rel="L4629">things ran their course.</li>
<li class="L4630" rel="L4630"></li>
<li class="L4631" rel="L4631"></li>
<li class="L4632" rel="L4632"></li>
<li class="L4633" rel="L4633"></li>
<li class="L4634" rel="L4634">VIII. Monseigneur in the Country</li>
<li class="L4635" rel="L4635"></li>
<li class="L4636" rel="L4636"></li>
<li class="L4637" rel="L4637">A beautiful landscape, with the corn bright in it, but not abundant.</li>
<li class="L4638" rel="L4638">Patches of poor rye where corn should have been, patches of poor peas</li>
<li class="L4639" rel="L4639">and beans, patches of most coarse vegetable substitutes for wheat. On</li>
<li class="L4640" rel="L4640">inanimate nature, as on the men and women who cultivated it, a prevalent</li>
<li class="L4641" rel="L4641">tendency towards an appearance of vegetating unwillingly--a dejected</li>
<li class="L4642" rel="L4642">disposition to give up, and wither away.</li>
<li class="L4643" rel="L4643"></li>
<li class="L4644" rel="L4644">Monsieur the Marquis in his travelling carriage (which might have been</li>
<li class="L4645" rel="L4645">lighter), conducted by four post-horses and two postilions, fagged up</li>
<li class="L4646" rel="L4646">a steep hill. A blush on the countenance of Monsieur the Marquis was</li>
<li class="L4647" rel="L4647">no impeachment of his high breeding; it was not from within; it was</li>
<li class="L4648" rel="L4648">occasioned by an external circumstance beyond his control--the setting</li>
<li class="L4649" rel="L4649">sun.</li>
<li class="L4650" rel="L4650"></li>
<li class="L4651" rel="L4651">The sunset struck so brilliantly into the travelling carriage when it</li>
<li class="L4652" rel="L4652">gained the hill-top, that its occupant was steeped in crimson. “It will</li>
<li class="L4653" rel="L4653">die out,” said Monsieur the Marquis, glancing at his hands, “directly.”</li>
<li class="L4654" rel="L4654"></li>
<li class="L4655" rel="L4655">In effect, the sun was so low that it dipped at the moment. When the</li>
<li class="L4656" rel="L4656">heavy drag had been adjusted to the wheel, and the carriage slid down</li>
<li class="L4657" rel="L4657">hill, with a cinderous smell, in a cloud of dust, the red glow departed</li>
<li class="L4658" rel="L4658">quickly; the sun and the Marquis going down together, there was no glow</li>
<li class="L4659" rel="L4659">left when the drag was taken off.</li>
<li class="L4660" rel="L4660"></li>
<li class="L4661" rel="L4661">But, there remained a broken country, bold and open, a little village</li>
<li class="L4662" rel="L4662">at the bottom of the hill, a broad sweep and rise beyond it, a</li>
<li class="L4663" rel="L4663">church-tower, a windmill, a forest for the chase, and a crag with a</li>
<li class="L4664" rel="L4664">fortress on it used as a prison. Round upon all these darkening objects</li>
<li class="L4665" rel="L4665">as the night drew on, the Marquis looked, with the air of one who was</li>
<li class="L4666" rel="L4666">coming near home.</li>
<li class="L4667" rel="L4667"></li>
<li class="L4668" rel="L4668">The village had its one poor street, with its poor brewery, poor</li>
<li class="L4669" rel="L4669">tannery, poor tavern, poor stable-yard for relays of post-horses, poor</li>
<li class="L4670" rel="L4670">fountain, all usual poor appointments. It had its poor people too. All</li>
<li class="L4671" rel="L4671">its people were poor, and many of them were sitting at their doors,</li>
<li class="L4672" rel="L4672">shredding spare onions and the like for supper, while many were at the</li>
<li class="L4673" rel="L4673">fountain, washing leaves, and grasses, and any such small yieldings of</li>
<li class="L4674" rel="L4674">the earth that could be eaten. Expressive signs of what made them poor,</li>
<li class="L4675" rel="L4675">were not wanting; the tax for the state, the tax for the church, the tax</li>
<li class="L4676" rel="L4676">for the lord, tax local and tax general, were to be paid here and to be</li>
<li class="L4677" rel="L4677">paid there, according to solemn inscription in the little village, until</li>
<li class="L4678" rel="L4678">the wonder was, that there was any village left unswallowed.</li>
<li class="L4679" rel="L4679"></li>
<li class="L4680" rel="L4680">Few children were to be seen, and no dogs. As to the men and women,</li>
<li class="L4681" rel="L4681">their choice on earth was stated in the prospect--Life on the lowest</li>
<li class="L4682" rel="L4682">terms that could sustain it, down in the little village under the mill;</li>
<li class="L4683" rel="L4683">or captivity and Death in the dominant prison on the crag.</li>
<li class="L4684" rel="L4684"></li>
<li class="L4685" rel="L4685">Heralded by a courier in advance, and by the cracking of his postilions&#39;</li>
<li class="L4686" rel="L4686">whips, which twined snake-like about their heads in the evening air, as</li>
<li class="L4687" rel="L4687">if he came attended by the Furies, Monsieur the Marquis drew up in</li>
<li class="L4688" rel="L4688">his travelling carriage at the posting-house gate. It was hard by the</li>
<li class="L4689" rel="L4689">fountain, and the peasants suspended their operations to look at him.</li>
<li class="L4690" rel="L4690">He looked at them, and saw in them, without knowing it, the slow</li>
<li class="L4691" rel="L4691">sure filing down of misery-worn face and figure, that was to make the</li>
<li class="L4692" rel="L4692">meagreness of Frenchmen an English superstition which should survive the</li>
<li class="L4693" rel="L4693">truth through the best part of a hundred years.</li>
<li class="L4694" rel="L4694"></li>
<li class="L4695" rel="L4695">Monsieur the Marquis cast his eyes over the submissive faces that</li>
<li class="L4696" rel="L4696">drooped before him, as the like of himself had drooped before</li>
<li class="L4697" rel="L4697">Monseigneur of the Court--only the difference was, that these faces</li>
<li class="L4698" rel="L4698">drooped merely to suffer and not to propitiate--when a grizzled mender</li>
<li class="L4699" rel="L4699">of the roads joined the group.</li>
<li class="L4700" rel="L4700"></li>
<li class="L4701" rel="L4701">“Bring me hither that fellow!” said the Marquis to the courier.</li>
<li class="L4702" rel="L4702"></li>
<li class="L4703" rel="L4703">The fellow was brought, cap in hand, and the other fellows closed round</li>
<li class="L4704" rel="L4704">to look and listen, in the manner of the people at the Paris fountain.</li>
<li class="L4705" rel="L4705"></li>
<li class="L4706" rel="L4706">“I passed you on the road?”</li>
<li class="L4707" rel="L4707"></li>
<li class="L4708" rel="L4708">“Monseigneur, it is true. I had the honour of being passed on the road.”</li>
<li class="L4709" rel="L4709"></li>
<li class="L4710" rel="L4710">“Coming up the hill, and at the top of the hill, both?”</li>
<li class="L4711" rel="L4711"></li>
<li class="L4712" rel="L4712">“Monseigneur, it is true.”</li>
<li class="L4713" rel="L4713"></li>
<li class="L4714" rel="L4714">“What did you look at, so fixedly?”</li>
<li class="L4715" rel="L4715"></li>
<li class="L4716" rel="L4716">“Monseigneur, I looked at the man.”</li>
<li class="L4717" rel="L4717"></li>
<li class="L4718" rel="L4718">He stooped a little, and with his tattered blue cap pointed under the</li>
<li class="L4719" rel="L4719">carriage. All his fellows stooped to look under the carriage.</li>
<li class="L4720" rel="L4720"></li>
<li class="L4721" rel="L4721">“What man, pig? And why look there?”</li>
<li class="L4722" rel="L4722"></li>
<li class="L4723" rel="L4723">“Pardon, Monseigneur; he swung by the chain of the shoe--the drag.”</li>
<li class="L4724" rel="L4724"></li>
<li class="L4725" rel="L4725">“Who?” demanded the traveller.</li>
<li class="L4726" rel="L4726"></li>
<li class="L4727" rel="L4727">“Monseigneur, the man.”</li>
<li class="L4728" rel="L4728"></li>
<li class="L4729" rel="L4729">“May the Devil carry away these idiots! How do you call the man? You</li>
<li class="L4730" rel="L4730">know all the men of this part of the country. Who was he?”</li>
<li class="L4731" rel="L4731"></li>
<li class="L4732" rel="L4732">“Your clemency, Monseigneur! He was not of this part of the country. Of</li>
<li class="L4733" rel="L4733">all the days of my life, I never saw him.”</li>
<li class="L4734" rel="L4734"></li>
<li class="L4735" rel="L4735">“Swinging by the chain? To be suffocated?”</li>
<li class="L4736" rel="L4736"></li>
<li class="L4737" rel="L4737">“With your gracious permission, that was the wonder of it, Monseigneur.</li>
<li class="L4738" rel="L4738">His head hanging over--like this!”</li>
<li class="L4739" rel="L4739"></li>
<li class="L4740" rel="L4740">He turned himself sideways to the carriage, and leaned back, with his</li>
<li class="L4741" rel="L4741">face thrown up to the sky, and his head hanging down; then recovered</li>
<li class="L4742" rel="L4742">himself, fumbled with his cap, and made a bow.</li>
<li class="L4743" rel="L4743"></li>
<li class="L4744" rel="L4744">“What was he like?”</li>
<li class="L4745" rel="L4745"></li>
<li class="L4746" rel="L4746">“Monseigneur, he was whiter than the miller. All covered with dust,</li>
<li class="L4747" rel="L4747">white as a spectre, tall as a spectre!”</li>
<li class="L4748" rel="L4748"></li>
<li class="L4749" rel="L4749">The picture produced an immense sensation in the little crowd; but all</li>
<li class="L4750" rel="L4750">eyes, without comparing notes with other eyes, looked at Monsieur</li>
<li class="L4751" rel="L4751">the Marquis. Perhaps, to observe whether he had any spectre on his</li>
<li class="L4752" rel="L4752">conscience.</li>
<li class="L4753" rel="L4753"></li>
<li class="L4754" rel="L4754">“Truly, you did well,” said the Marquis, felicitously sensible that such</li>
<li class="L4755" rel="L4755">vermin were not to ruffle him, “to see a thief accompanying my carriage,</li>
<li class="L4756" rel="L4756">and not open that great mouth of yours. Bah! Put him aside, Monsieur</li>
<li class="L4757" rel="L4757">Gabelle!”</li>
<li class="L4758" rel="L4758"></li>
<li class="L4759" rel="L4759">Monsieur Gabelle was the Postmaster, and some other taxing functionary</li>
<li class="L4760" rel="L4760">united; he had come out with great obsequiousness to assist at this</li>
<li class="L4761" rel="L4761">examination, and had held the examined by the drapery of his arm in an</li>
<li class="L4762" rel="L4762">official manner.</li>
<li class="L4763" rel="L4763"></li>
<li class="L4764" rel="L4764">“Bah! Go aside!” said Monsieur Gabelle.</li>
<li class="L4765" rel="L4765"></li>
<li class="L4766" rel="L4766">“Lay hands on this stranger if he seeks to lodge in your village</li>
<li class="L4767" rel="L4767">to-night, and be sure that his business is honest, Gabelle.”</li>
<li class="L4768" rel="L4768"></li>
<li class="L4769" rel="L4769">“Monseigneur, I am flattered to devote myself to your orders.”</li>
<li class="L4770" rel="L4770"></li>
<li class="L4771" rel="L4771">“Did he run away, fellow?--where is that Accursed?”</li>
<li class="L4772" rel="L4772"></li>
<li class="L4773" rel="L4773">The accursed was already under the carriage with some half-dozen</li>
<li class="L4774" rel="L4774">particular friends, pointing out the chain with his blue cap. Some</li>
<li class="L4775" rel="L4775">half-dozen other particular friends promptly hauled him out, and</li>
<li class="L4776" rel="L4776">presented him breathless to Monsieur the Marquis.</li>
<li class="L4777" rel="L4777"></li>
<li class="L4778" rel="L4778">“Did the man run away, Dolt, when we stopped for the drag?”</li>
<li class="L4779" rel="L4779"></li>
<li class="L4780" rel="L4780">“Monseigneur, he precipitated himself over the hill-side, head first, as</li>
<li class="L4781" rel="L4781">a person plunges into the river.”</li>
<li class="L4782" rel="L4782"></li>
<li class="L4783" rel="L4783">“See to it, Gabelle. Go on!”</li>
<li class="L4784" rel="L4784"></li>
<li class="L4785" rel="L4785">The half-dozen who were peering at the chain were still among the</li>
<li class="L4786" rel="L4786">wheels, like sheep; the wheels turned so suddenly that they were lucky</li>
<li class="L4787" rel="L4787">to save their skins and bones; they had very little else to save, or</li>
<li class="L4788" rel="L4788">they might not have been so fortunate.</li>
<li class="L4789" rel="L4789"></li>
<li class="L4790" rel="L4790">The burst with which the carriage started out of the village and up the</li>
<li class="L4791" rel="L4791">rise beyond, was soon checked by the steepness of the hill. Gradually,</li>
<li class="L4792" rel="L4792">it subsided to a foot pace, swinging and lumbering upward among the many</li>
<li class="L4793" rel="L4793">sweet scents of a summer night. The postilions, with a thousand gossamer</li>
<li class="L4794" rel="L4794">gnats circling about them in lieu of the Furies, quietly mended the</li>
<li class="L4795" rel="L4795">points to the lashes of their whips; the valet walked by the horses; the</li>
<li class="L4796" rel="L4796">courier was audible, trotting on ahead into the dull distance.</li>
<li class="L4797" rel="L4797"></li>
<li class="L4798" rel="L4798">At the steepest point of the hill there was a little burial-ground,</li>
<li class="L4799" rel="L4799">with a Cross and a new large figure of Our Saviour on it; it was a poor</li>
<li class="L4800" rel="L4800">figure in wood, done by some inexperienced rustic carver, but he had</li>
<li class="L4801" rel="L4801">studied the figure from the life--his own life, maybe--for it was</li>
<li class="L4802" rel="L4802">dreadfully spare and thin.</li>
<li class="L4803" rel="L4803"></li>
<li class="L4804" rel="L4804">To this distressful emblem of a great distress that had long been</li>
<li class="L4805" rel="L4805">growing worse, and was not at its worst, a woman was kneeling. She</li>
<li class="L4806" rel="L4806">turned her head as the carriage came up to her, rose quickly, and</li>
<li class="L4807" rel="L4807">presented herself at the carriage-door.</li>
<li class="L4808" rel="L4808"></li>
<li class="L4809" rel="L4809">“It is you, Monseigneur! Monseigneur, a petition.”</li>
<li class="L4810" rel="L4810"></li>
<li class="L4811" rel="L4811">With an exclamation of impatience, but with his unchangeable face,</li>
<li class="L4812" rel="L4812">Monseigneur looked out.</li>
<li class="L4813" rel="L4813"></li>
<li class="L4814" rel="L4814">“How, then! What is it? Always petitions!”</li>
<li class="L4815" rel="L4815"></li>
<li class="L4816" rel="L4816">“Monseigneur. For the love of the great God! My husband, the forester.”</li>
<li class="L4817" rel="L4817"></li>
<li class="L4818" rel="L4818">“What of your husband, the forester? Always the same with you people. He</li>
<li class="L4819" rel="L4819">cannot pay something?”</li>
<li class="L4820" rel="L4820"></li>
<li class="L4821" rel="L4821">“He has paid all, Monseigneur. He is dead.”</li>
<li class="L4822" rel="L4822"></li>
<li class="L4823" rel="L4823">“Well! He is quiet. Can I restore him to you?”</li>
<li class="L4824" rel="L4824"></li>
<li class="L4825" rel="L4825">“Alas, no, Monseigneur! But he lies yonder, under a little heap of poor</li>
<li class="L4826" rel="L4826">grass.”</li>
<li class="L4827" rel="L4827"></li>
<li class="L4828" rel="L4828">“Well?”</li>
<li class="L4829" rel="L4829"></li>
<li class="L4830" rel="L4830">“Monseigneur, there are so many little heaps of poor grass?”</li>
<li class="L4831" rel="L4831"></li>
<li class="L4832" rel="L4832">“Again, well?”</li>
<li class="L4833" rel="L4833"></li>
<li class="L4834" rel="L4834">She looked an old woman, but was young. Her manner was one of passionate</li>
<li class="L4835" rel="L4835">grief; by turns she clasped her veinous and knotted hands together</li>
<li class="L4836" rel="L4836">with wild energy, and laid one of them on the carriage-door--tenderly,</li>
<li class="L4837" rel="L4837">caressingly, as if it had been a human breast, and could be expected to</li>
<li class="L4838" rel="L4838">feel the appealing touch.</li>
<li class="L4839" rel="L4839"></li>
<li class="L4840" rel="L4840">“Monseigneur, hear me! Monseigneur, hear my petition! My husband died of</li>
<li class="L4841" rel="L4841">want; so many die of want; so many more will die of want.”</li>
<li class="L4842" rel="L4842"></li>
<li class="L4843" rel="L4843">“Again, well? Can I feed them?”</li>
<li class="L4844" rel="L4844"></li>
<li class="L4845" rel="L4845">“Monseigneur, the good God knows; but I don&#39;t ask it. My petition is,</li>
<li class="L4846" rel="L4846">that a morsel of stone or wood, with my husband&#39;s name, may be placed</li>
