<li class="L4847" rel="L4847">over him to show where he lies. Otherwise, the place will be quickly</li>
<li class="L4848" rel="L4848">forgotten, it will never be found when I am dead of the same malady, I</li>
<li class="L4849" rel="L4849">shall be laid under some other heap of poor grass. Monseigneur, they</li>
<li class="L4850" rel="L4850">are so many, they increase so fast, there is so much want. Monseigneur!</li>
<li class="L4851" rel="L4851">Monseigneur!”</li>
<li class="L4852" rel="L4852"></li>
<li class="L4853" rel="L4853">The valet had put her away from the door, the carriage had broken into</li>
<li class="L4854" rel="L4854">a brisk trot, the postilions had quickened the pace, she was left far</li>
<li class="L4855" rel="L4855">behind, and Monseigneur, again escorted by the Furies, was rapidly</li>
<li class="L4856" rel="L4856">diminishing the league or two of distance that remained between him and</li>
<li class="L4857" rel="L4857">his chateau.</li>
<li class="L4858" rel="L4858"></li>
<li class="L4859" rel="L4859">The sweet scents of the summer night rose all around him, and rose, as</li>
<li class="L4860" rel="L4860">the rain falls, impartially, on the dusty, ragged, and toil-worn group</li>
<li class="L4861" rel="L4861">at the fountain not far away; to whom the mender of roads, with the aid</li>
<li class="L4862" rel="L4862">of the blue cap without which he was nothing, still enlarged upon his</li>
<li class="L4863" rel="L4863">man like a spectre, as long as they could bear it. By degrees, as they</li>
<li class="L4864" rel="L4864">could bear no more, they dropped off one by one, and lights twinkled</li>
<li class="L4865" rel="L4865">in little casements; which lights, as the casements darkened, and more</li>
<li class="L4866" rel="L4866">stars came out, seemed to have shot up into the sky instead of having</li>
<li class="L4867" rel="L4867">been extinguished.</li>
<li class="L4868" rel="L4868"></li>
<li class="L4869" rel="L4869">The shadow of a large high-roofed house, and of many over-hanging trees,</li>
<li class="L4870" rel="L4870">was upon Monsieur the Marquis by that time; and the shadow was exchanged</li>
<li class="L4871" rel="L4871">for the light of a flambeau, as his carriage stopped, and the great door</li>
<li class="L4872" rel="L4872">of his chateau was opened to him.</li>
<li class="L4873" rel="L4873"></li>
<li class="L4874" rel="L4874">“Monsieur Charles, whom I expect; is he arrived from England?”</li>
<li class="L4875" rel="L4875"></li>
<li class="L4876" rel="L4876">“Monseigneur, not yet.”</li>
<li class="L4877" rel="L4877"></li>
<li class="L4878" rel="L4878"></li>
<li class="L4879" rel="L4879"></li>
<li class="L4880" rel="L4880"></li>
<li class="L4881" rel="L4881">IX. The Gorgon&#39;s Head</li>
<li class="L4882" rel="L4882"></li>
<li class="L4883" rel="L4883"></li>
<li class="L4884" rel="L4884">It was a heavy mass of building, that chateau of Monsieur the Marquis,</li>
<li class="L4885" rel="L4885">with a large stone courtyard before it, and two stone sweeps of</li>
<li class="L4886" rel="L4886">staircase meeting in a stone terrace before the principal door. A stony</li>
<li class="L4887" rel="L4887">business altogether, with heavy stone balustrades, and stone urns, and</li>
<li class="L4888" rel="L4888">stone flowers, and stone faces of men, and stone heads of lions, in</li>
<li class="L4889" rel="L4889">all directions. As if the Gorgon&#39;s head had surveyed it, when it was</li>
<li class="L4890" rel="L4890">finished, two centuries ago.</li>
<li class="L4891" rel="L4891"></li>
<li class="L4892" rel="L4892">Up the broad flight of shallow steps, Monsieur the Marquis, flambeau</li>
<li class="L4893" rel="L4893">preceded, went from his carriage, sufficiently disturbing the darkness</li>
<li class="L4894" rel="L4894">to elicit loud remonstrance from an owl in the roof of the great pile</li>
<li class="L4895" rel="L4895">of stable building away among the trees. All else was so quiet, that the</li>
<li class="L4896" rel="L4896">flambeau carried up the steps, and the other flambeau held at the great</li>
<li class="L4897" rel="L4897">door, burnt as if they were in a close room of state, instead of being</li>
<li class="L4898" rel="L4898">in the open night-air. Other sound than the owl&#39;s voice there was none,</li>
<li class="L4899" rel="L4899">save the falling of a fountain into its stone basin; for, it was one of</li>
<li class="L4900" rel="L4900">those dark nights that hold their breath by the hour together, and then</li>
<li class="L4901" rel="L4901">heave a long low sigh, and hold their breath again.</li>
<li class="L4902" rel="L4902"></li>
<li class="L4903" rel="L4903">The great door clanged behind him, and Monsieur the Marquis crossed a</li>
<li class="L4904" rel="L4904">hall grim with certain old boar-spears, swords, and knives of the chase;</li>
<li class="L4905" rel="L4905">grimmer with certain heavy riding-rods and riding-whips, of which many a</li>
<li class="L4906" rel="L4906">peasant, gone to his benefactor Death, had felt the weight when his lord</li>
<li class="L4907" rel="L4907">was angry.</li>
<li class="L4908" rel="L4908"></li>
<li class="L4909" rel="L4909">Avoiding the larger rooms, which were dark and made fast for the night,</li>
<li class="L4910" rel="L4910">Monsieur the Marquis, with his flambeau-bearer going on before, went up</li>
<li class="L4911" rel="L4911">the staircase to a door in a corridor. This thrown open, admitted him</li>
<li class="L4912" rel="L4912">to his own private apartment of three rooms: his bed-chamber and two</li>
<li class="L4913" rel="L4913">others. High vaulted rooms with cool uncarpeted floors, great dogs upon</li>
<li class="L4914" rel="L4914">the hearths for the burning of wood in winter time, and all luxuries</li>
<li class="L4915" rel="L4915">befitting the state of a marquis in a luxurious age and country.</li>
<li class="L4916" rel="L4916">The fashion of the last Louis but one, of the line that was never to</li>
<li class="L4917" rel="L4917">break--the fourteenth Louis--was conspicuous in their rich furniture;</li>
<li class="L4918" rel="L4918">but, it was diversified by many objects that were illustrations of old</li>
<li class="L4919" rel="L4919">pages in the history of France.</li>
<li class="L4920" rel="L4920"></li>
<li class="L4921" rel="L4921">A supper-table was laid for two, in the third of the rooms; a round</li>
<li class="L4922" rel="L4922">room, in one of the chateau&#39;s four extinguisher-topped towers. A small</li>
<li class="L4923" rel="L4923">lofty room, with its window wide open, and the wooden jalousie-blinds</li>
<li class="L4924" rel="L4924">closed, so that the dark night only showed in slight horizontal lines of</li>
<li class="L4925" rel="L4925">black, alternating with their broad lines of stone colour.</li>
<li class="L4926" rel="L4926"></li>
<li class="L4927" rel="L4927">“My nephew,” said the Marquis, glancing at the supper preparation; “they</li>
<li class="L4928" rel="L4928">said he was not arrived.”</li>
<li class="L4929" rel="L4929"></li>
<li class="L4930" rel="L4930">Nor was he; but, he had been expected with Monseigneur.</li>
<li class="L4931" rel="L4931"></li>
<li class="L4932" rel="L4932">“Ah! It is not probable he will arrive to-night; nevertheless, leave the</li>
<li class="L4933" rel="L4933">table as it is. I shall be ready in a quarter of an hour.”</li>
<li class="L4934" rel="L4934"></li>
<li class="L4935" rel="L4935">In a quarter of an hour Monseigneur was ready, and sat down alone to his</li>
<li class="L4936" rel="L4936">sumptuous and choice supper. His chair was opposite to the window, and</li>
<li class="L4937" rel="L4937">he had taken his soup, and was raising his glass of Bordeaux to his</li>
<li class="L4938" rel="L4938">lips, when he put it down.</li>
<li class="L4939" rel="L4939"></li>
<li class="L4940" rel="L4940">“What is that?” he calmly asked, looking with attention at the</li>
<li class="L4941" rel="L4941">horizontal lines of black and stone colour.</li>
<li class="L4942" rel="L4942"></li>
<li class="L4943" rel="L4943">“Monseigneur? That?”</li>
<li class="L4944" rel="L4944"></li>
<li class="L4945" rel="L4945">“Outside the blinds. Open the blinds.”</li>
<li class="L4946" rel="L4946"></li>
<li class="L4947" rel="L4947">It was done.</li>
<li class="L4948" rel="L4948"></li>
<li class="L4949" rel="L4949">“Well?”</li>
<li class="L4950" rel="L4950"></li>
<li class="L4951" rel="L4951">“Monseigneur, it is nothing. The trees and the night are all that are</li>
<li class="L4952" rel="L4952">here.”</li>
<li class="L4953" rel="L4953"></li>
<li class="L4954" rel="L4954">The servant who spoke, had thrown the blinds wide, had looked out into</li>
<li class="L4955" rel="L4955">the vacant darkness, and stood with that blank behind him, looking round</li>
<li class="L4956" rel="L4956">for instructions.</li>
<li class="L4957" rel="L4957"></li>
<li class="L4958" rel="L4958">“Good,” said the imperturbable master. “Close them again.”</li>
<li class="L4959" rel="L4959"></li>
<li class="L4960" rel="L4960">That was done too, and the Marquis went on with his supper. He was</li>
<li class="L4961" rel="L4961">half way through it, when he again stopped with his glass in his hand,</li>
<li class="L4962" rel="L4962">hearing the sound of wheels. It came on briskly, and came up to the</li>
<li class="L4963" rel="L4963">front of the chateau.</li>
<li class="L4964" rel="L4964"></li>
<li class="L4965" rel="L4965">“Ask who is arrived.”</li>
<li class="L4966" rel="L4966"></li>
<li class="L4967" rel="L4967">It was the nephew of Monseigneur. He had been some few leagues behind</li>
<li class="L4968" rel="L4968">Monseigneur, early in the afternoon. He had diminished the distance</li>
<li class="L4969" rel="L4969">rapidly, but not so rapidly as to come up with Monseigneur on the road.</li>
<li class="L4970" rel="L4970">He had heard of Monseigneur, at the posting-houses, as being before him.</li>
<li class="L4971" rel="L4971"></li>
<li class="L4972" rel="L4972">He was to be told (said Monseigneur) that supper awaited him then and</li>
<li class="L4973" rel="L4973">there, and that he was prayed to come to it. In a little while he came.</li>
<li class="L4974" rel="L4974">He had been known in England as Charles Darnay.</li>
<li class="L4975" rel="L4975"></li>
<li class="L4976" rel="L4976">Monseigneur received him in a courtly manner, but they did not shake</li>
<li class="L4977" rel="L4977">hands.</li>
<li class="L4978" rel="L4978"></li>
<li class="L4979" rel="L4979">“You left Paris yesterday, sir?” he said to Monseigneur, as he took his</li>
<li class="L4980" rel="L4980">seat at table.</li>
<li class="L4981" rel="L4981"></li>
<li class="L4982" rel="L4982">“Yesterday. And you?”</li>
<li class="L4983" rel="L4983"></li>
<li class="L4984" rel="L4984">“I come direct.”</li>
<li class="L4985" rel="L4985"></li>
<li class="L4986" rel="L4986">“From London?”</li>
<li class="L4987" rel="L4987"></li>
<li class="L4988" rel="L4988">“Yes.”</li>
<li class="L4989" rel="L4989"></li>
<li class="L4990" rel="L4990">“You have been a long time coming,” said the Marquis, with a smile.</li>
<li class="L4991" rel="L4991"></li>
<li class="L4992" rel="L4992">“On the contrary; I come direct.”</li>
<li class="L4993" rel="L4993"></li>
<li class="L4994" rel="L4994">“Pardon me! I mean, not a long time on the journey; a long time</li>
<li class="L4995" rel="L4995">intending the journey.”</li>
<li class="L4996" rel="L4996"></li>
<li class="L4997" rel="L4997">“I have been detained by”--the nephew stopped a moment in his</li>
<li class="L4998" rel="L4998">answer--“various business.”</li>
<li class="L4999" rel="L4999"></li>
<li class="L5000" rel="L5000">“Without doubt,” said the polished uncle.</li>
<li class="L5001" rel="L5001"></li>
<li class="L5002" rel="L5002">So long as a servant was present, no other words passed between them.</li>
<li class="L5003" rel="L5003">When coffee had been served and they were alone together, the nephew,</li>
<li class="L5004" rel="L5004">looking at the uncle and meeting the eyes of the face that was like a</li>
<li class="L5005" rel="L5005">fine mask, opened a conversation.</li>
<li class="L5006" rel="L5006"></li>
<li class="L5007" rel="L5007">“I have come back, sir, as you anticipate, pursuing the object that</li>
<li class="L5008" rel="L5008">took me away. It carried me into great and unexpected peril; but it is</li>
<li class="L5009" rel="L5009">a sacred object, and if it had carried me to death I hope it would have</li>
<li class="L5010" rel="L5010">sustained me.”</li>
<li class="L5011" rel="L5011"></li>
<li class="L5012" rel="L5012">“Not to death,” said the uncle; “it is not necessary to say, to death.”</li>
<li class="L5013" rel="L5013"></li>
<li class="L5014" rel="L5014">“I doubt, sir,” returned the nephew, “whether, if it had carried me to</li>
<li class="L5015" rel="L5015">the utmost brink of death, you would have cared to stop me there.”</li>
<li class="L5016" rel="L5016"></li>
<li class="L5017" rel="L5017">The deepened marks in the nose, and the lengthening of the fine straight</li>
<li class="L5018" rel="L5018">lines in the cruel face, looked ominous as to that; the uncle made a</li>
<li class="L5019" rel="L5019">graceful gesture of protest, which was so clearly a slight form of good</li>
<li class="L5020" rel="L5020">breeding that it was not reassuring.</li>
<li class="L5021" rel="L5021"></li>
<li class="L5022" rel="L5022">“Indeed, sir,” pursued the nephew, “for anything I know, you may have</li>
<li class="L5023" rel="L5023">expressly worked to give a more suspicious appearance to the suspicious</li>
<li class="L5024" rel="L5024">circumstances that surrounded me.”</li>
<li class="L5025" rel="L5025"></li>
<li class="L5026" rel="L5026">“No, no, no,” said the uncle, pleasantly.</li>
<li class="L5027" rel="L5027"></li>
<li class="L5028" rel="L5028">“But, however that may be,” resumed the nephew, glancing at him with</li>
<li class="L5029" rel="L5029">deep distrust, “I know that your diplomacy would stop me by any means,</li>
<li class="L5030" rel="L5030">and would know no scruple as to means.”</li>
<li class="L5031" rel="L5031"></li>
<li class="L5032" rel="L5032">“My friend, I told you so,” said the uncle, with a fine pulsation in the</li>
<li class="L5033" rel="L5033">two marks. “Do me the favour to recall that I told you so, long ago.”</li>
<li class="L5034" rel="L5034"></li>
<li class="L5035" rel="L5035">“I recall it.”</li>
<li class="L5036" rel="L5036"></li>
<li class="L5037" rel="L5037">“Thank you,” said the Marquis--very sweetly indeed.</li>
<li class="L5038" rel="L5038"></li>
<li class="L5039" rel="L5039">His tone lingered in the air, almost like the tone of a musical</li>
<li class="L5040" rel="L5040">instrument.</li>
<li class="L5041" rel="L5041"></li>
<li class="L5042" rel="L5042">“In effect, sir,” pursued the nephew, “I believe it to be at once your</li>
<li class="L5043" rel="L5043">bad fortune, and my good fortune, that has kept me out of a prison in</li>
<li class="L5044" rel="L5044">France here.”</li>
<li class="L5045" rel="L5045"></li>
<li class="L5046" rel="L5046">“I do not quite understand,” returned the uncle, sipping his coffee.</li>
<li class="L5047" rel="L5047">“Dare I ask you to explain?”</li>
<li class="L5048" rel="L5048"></li>
<li class="L5049" rel="L5049">“I believe that if you were not in disgrace with the Court, and had not</li>
<li class="L5050" rel="L5050">been overshadowed by that cloud for years past, a letter de cachet would</li>
<li class="L5051" rel="L5051">have sent me to some fortress indefinitely.”</li>
<li class="L5052" rel="L5052"></li>
<li class="L5053" rel="L5053">“It is possible,” said the uncle, with great calmness. “For the honour</li>
<li class="L5054" rel="L5054">of the family, I could even resolve to incommode you to that extent.</li>
<li class="L5055" rel="L5055">Pray excuse me!”</li>
<li class="L5056" rel="L5056"></li>
<li class="L5057" rel="L5057">“I perceive that, happily for me, the Reception of the day before</li>
<li class="L5058" rel="L5058">yesterday was, as usual, a cold one,” observed the nephew.</li>
<li class="L5059" rel="L5059"></li>
<li class="L5060" rel="L5060">“I would not say happily, my friend,” returned the uncle, with refined</li>
<li class="L5061" rel="L5061">politeness; “I would not be sure of that. A good opportunity for</li>
<li class="L5062" rel="L5062">consideration, surrounded by the advantages of solitude, might influence</li>
<li class="L5063" rel="L5063">your destiny to far greater advantage than you influence it for</li>
<li class="L5064" rel="L5064">yourself. But it is useless to discuss the question. I am, as you say,</li>
<li class="L5065" rel="L5065">at a disadvantage. These little instruments of correction, these gentle</li>
<li class="L5066" rel="L5066">aids to the power and honour of families, these slight favours that</li>
<li class="L5067" rel="L5067">might so incommode you, are only to be obtained now by interest</li>
<li class="L5068" rel="L5068">and importunity. They are sought by so many, and they are granted</li>
<li class="L5069" rel="L5069">(comparatively) to so few! It used not to be so, but France in all such</li>
<li class="L5070" rel="L5070">things is changed for the worse. Our not remote ancestors held the right</li>
<li class="L5071" rel="L5071">of life and death over the surrounding vulgar. From this room, many such</li>
<li class="L5072" rel="L5072">dogs have been taken out to be hanged; in the next room (my bedroom),</li>
<li class="L5073" rel="L5073">one fellow, to our knowledge, was poniarded on the spot for professing</li>
<li class="L5074" rel="L5074">some insolent delicacy respecting his daughter--_his_ daughter? We have</li>
<li class="L5075" rel="L5075">lost many privileges; a new philosophy has become the mode; and the</li>
<li class="L5076" rel="L5076">assertion of our station, in these days, might (I do not go so far as</li>
<li class="L5077" rel="L5077">to say would, but might) cause us real inconvenience. All very bad, very</li>
<li class="L5078" rel="L5078">bad!”</li>
<li class="L5079" rel="L5079"></li>
<li class="L5080" rel="L5080">The Marquis took a gentle little pinch of snuff, and shook his head;</li>
<li class="L5081" rel="L5081">as elegantly despondent as he could becomingly be of a country still</li>
<li class="L5082" rel="L5082">containing himself, that great means of regeneration.</li>
<li class="L5083" rel="L5083"></li>
<li class="L5084" rel="L5084">“We have so asserted our station, both in the old time and in the modern</li>
<li class="L5085" rel="L5085">time also,” said the nephew, gloomily, “that I believe our name to be</li>
<li class="L5086" rel="L5086">more detested than any name in France.”</li>
<li class="L5087" rel="L5087"></li>
<li class="L5088" rel="L5088">“Let us hope so,” said the uncle. “Detestation of the high is the</li>
<li class="L5089" rel="L5089">involuntary homage of the low.”</li>
<li class="L5090" rel="L5090"></li>
<li class="L5091" rel="L5091">“There is not,” pursued the nephew, in his former tone, “a face I can</li>
<li class="L5092" rel="L5092">look at, in all this country round about us, which looks at me with any</li>
<li class="L5093" rel="L5093">deference on it but the dark deference of fear and slavery.”</li>
<li class="L5094" rel="L5094"></li>
<li class="L5095" rel="L5095">“A compliment,” said the Marquis, “to the grandeur of the family,</li>
<li class="L5096" rel="L5096">merited by the manner in which the family has sustained its grandeur.</li>
<li class="L5097" rel="L5097">Hah!” And he took another gentle little pinch of snuff, and lightly</li>
<li class="L5098" rel="L5098">crossed his legs.</li>
<li class="L5099" rel="L5099"></li>
<li class="L5100" rel="L5100">But, when his nephew, leaning an elbow on the table, covered his eyes</li>
<li class="L5101" rel="L5101">thoughtfully and dejectedly with his hand, the fine mask looked at</li>
<li class="L5102" rel="L5102">him sideways with a stronger concentration of keenness, closeness,</li>
<li class="L5103" rel="L5103">and dislike, than was comportable with its wearer&#39;s assumption of</li>
<li class="L5104" rel="L5104">indifference.</li>
<li class="L5105" rel="L5105"></li>
<li class="L5106" rel="L5106">“Repression is the only lasting philosophy. The dark deference of fear</li>
<li class="L5107" rel="L5107">and slavery, my friend,” observed the Marquis, “will keep the dogs</li>
<li class="L5108" rel="L5108">obedient to the whip, as long as this roof,” looking up to it, “shuts</li>
<li class="L5109" rel="L5109">out the sky.”</li>
<li class="L5110" rel="L5110"></li>
<li class="L5111" rel="L5111">That might not be so long as the Marquis supposed. If a picture of the</li>
<li class="L5112" rel="L5112">chateau as it was to be a very few years hence, and of fifty like it as</li>
<li class="L5113" rel="L5113">they too were to be a very few years hence, could have been shown to</li>
<li class="L5114" rel="L5114">him that night, he might have been at a loss to claim his own from</li>
<li class="L5115" rel="L5115">the ghastly, fire-charred, plunder-wrecked rains. As for the roof</li>
<li class="L5116" rel="L5116">he vaunted, he might have found _that_ shutting out the sky in a new</li>
<li class="L5117" rel="L5117">way--to wit, for ever, from the eyes of the bodies into which its lead</li>
<li class="L5118" rel="L5118">was fired, out of the barrels of a hundred thousand muskets.</li>
<li class="L5119" rel="L5119"></li>
<li class="L5120" rel="L5120">“Meanwhile,” said the Marquis, “I will preserve the honour and repose</li>
<li class="L5121" rel="L5121">of the family, if you will not. But you must be fatigued. Shall we</li>
<li class="L5122" rel="L5122">terminate our conference for the night?”</li>
<li class="L5123" rel="L5123"></li>
<li class="L5124" rel="L5124">“A moment more.”</li>
<li class="L5125" rel="L5125"></li>
<li class="L5126" rel="L5126">“An hour, if you please.”</li>
<li class="L5127" rel="L5127"></li>
<li class="L5128" rel="L5128">“Sir,” said the nephew, “we have done wrong, and are reaping the fruits</li>
<li class="L5129" rel="L5129">of wrong.”</li>
<li class="L5130" rel="L5130"></li>
<li class="L5131" rel="L5131">“_We_ have done wrong?” repeated the Marquis, with an inquiring smile,</li>
<li class="L5132" rel="L5132">and delicately pointing, first to his nephew, then to himself.</li>
<li class="L5133" rel="L5133"></li>
<li class="L5134" rel="L5134">“Our family; our honourable family, whose honour is of so much account</li>
<li class="L5135" rel="L5135">to both of us, in such different ways. Even in my father&#39;s time, we did</li>
<li class="L5136" rel="L5136">a world of wrong, injuring every human creature who came between us and</li>
<li class="L5137" rel="L5137">our pleasure, whatever it was. Why need I speak of my father&#39;s time,</li>
<li class="L5138" rel="L5138">when it is equally yours? Can I separate my father&#39;s twin-brother, joint</li>
<li class="L5139" rel="L5139">inheritor, and next successor, from himself?”</li>
<li class="L5140" rel="L5140"></li>
<li class="L5141" rel="L5141">“Death has done that!” said the Marquis.</li>
<li class="L5142" rel="L5142"></li>
<li class="L5143" rel="L5143">“And has left me,” answered the nephew, “bound to a system that is</li>
<li class="L5144" rel="L5144">frightful to me, responsible for it, but powerless in it; seeking to</li>
<li class="L5145" rel="L5145">execute the last request of my dear mother&#39;s lips, and obey the last</li>
<li class="L5146" rel="L5146">look of my dear mother&#39;s eyes, which implored me to have mercy and to</li>
<li class="L5147" rel="L5147">redress; and tortured by seeking assistance and power in vain.”</li>
<li class="L5148" rel="L5148"></li>
<li class="L5149" rel="L5149">“Seeking them from me, my nephew,” said the Marquis, touching him on the</li>
<li class="L5150" rel="L5150">breast with his forefinger--they were now standing by the hearth--“you</li>
<li class="L5151" rel="L5151">will for ever seek them in vain, be assured.”</li>
<li class="L5152" rel="L5152"></li>
<li class="L5153" rel="L5153">Every fine straight line in the clear whiteness of his face, was</li>
<li class="L5154" rel="L5154">cruelly, craftily, and closely compressed, while he stood looking</li>
<li class="L5155" rel="L5155">quietly at his nephew, with his snuff-box in his hand. Once again he</li>
<li class="L5156" rel="L5156">touched him on the breast, as though his finger were the fine point of</li>
<li class="L5157" rel="L5157">a small sword, with which, in delicate finesse, he ran him through the</li>
<li class="L5158" rel="L5158">body, and said,</li>
<li class="L5159" rel="L5159"></li>
<li class="L5160" rel="L5160">“My friend, I will die, perpetuating the system under which I have</li>
<li class="L5161" rel="L5161">lived.”</li>
<li class="L5162" rel="L5162"></li>
<li class="L5163" rel="L5163">When he had said it, he took a culminating pinch of snuff, and put his</li>
<li class="L5164" rel="L5164">box in his pocket.</li>
<li class="L5165" rel="L5165"></li>
<li class="L5166" rel="L5166">“Better to be a rational creature,” he added then, after ringing a small</li>
<li class="L5167" rel="L5167">bell on the table, “and accept your natural destiny. But you are lost,</li>
<li class="L5168" rel="L5168">Monsieur Charles, I see.”</li>
<li class="L5169" rel="L5169"></li>
<li class="L5170" rel="L5170">“This property and France are lost to me,” said the nephew, sadly; “I</li>
<li class="L5171" rel="L5171">renounce them.”</li>
<li class="L5172" rel="L5172"></li>
<li class="L5173" rel="L5173">“Are they both yours to renounce? France may be, but is the property? It</li>
<li class="L5174" rel="L5174">is scarcely worth mentioning; but, is it yet?”</li>
<li class="L5175" rel="L5175"></li>
<li class="L5176" rel="L5176">“I had no intention, in the words I used, to claim it yet. If it passed</li>
<li class="L5177" rel="L5177">to me from you, to-morrow--”</li>
<li class="L5178" rel="L5178"></li>
<li class="L5179" rel="L5179">“Which I have the vanity to hope is not probable.”</li>
<li class="L5180" rel="L5180"></li>
<li class="L5181" rel="L5181">“--or twenty years hence--”</li>
<li class="L5182" rel="L5182"></li>
<li class="L5183" rel="L5183">“You do me too much honour,” said the Marquis; “still, I prefer that</li>
<li class="L5184" rel="L5184">supposition.”</li>
<li class="L5185" rel="L5185"></li>
<li class="L5186" rel="L5186">“--I would abandon it, and live otherwise and elsewhere. It is little to</li>
<li class="L5187" rel="L5187">relinquish. What is it but a wilderness of misery and ruin!”</li>
<li class="L5188" rel="L5188"></li>
<li class="L5189" rel="L5189">“Hah!” said the Marquis, glancing round the luxurious room.</li>
<li class="L5190" rel="L5190"></li>
<li class="L5191" rel="L5191">“To the eye it is fair enough, here; but seen in its integrity,</li>
<li class="L5192" rel="L5192">under the sky, and by the daylight, it is a crumbling tower of waste,</li>
<li class="L5193" rel="L5193">mismanagement, extortion, debt, mortgage, oppression, hunger, nakedness,</li>
<li class="L5194" rel="L5194">and suffering.”</li>
<li class="L5195" rel="L5195"></li>
<li class="L5196" rel="L5196">“Hah!” said the Marquis again, in a well-satisfied manner.</li>
<li class="L5197" rel="L5197"></li>
<li class="L5198" rel="L5198">“If it ever becomes mine, it shall be put into some hands better</li>
<li class="L5199" rel="L5199">qualified to free it slowly (if such a thing is possible) from the</li>
<li class="L5200" rel="L5200">weight that drags it down, so that the miserable people who cannot leave</li>
<li class="L5201" rel="L5201">it and who have been long wrung to the last point of endurance, may, in</li>
<li class="L5202" rel="L5202">another generation, suffer less; but it is not for me. There is a curse</li>
<li class="L5203" rel="L5203">on it, and on all this land.”</li>
<li class="L5204" rel="L5204"></li>
<li class="L5205" rel="L5205">“And you?” said the uncle. “Forgive my curiosity; do you, under your new</li>
<li class="L5206" rel="L5206">philosophy, graciously intend to live?”</li>
<li class="L5207" rel="L5207"></li>
<li class="L5208" rel="L5208">“I must do, to live, what others of my countrymen, even with nobility at</li>
<li class="L5209" rel="L5209">their backs, may have to do some day--work.”</li>
<li class="L5210" rel="L5210"></li>
<li class="L5211" rel="L5211">“In England, for example?”</li>
<li class="L5212" rel="L5212"></li>
<li class="L5213" rel="L5213">“Yes. The family honour, sir, is safe from me in this country. The</li>
<li class="L5214" rel="L5214">family name can suffer from me in no other, for I bear it in no other.”</li>
<li class="L5215" rel="L5215"></li>
<li class="L5216" rel="L5216">The ringing of the bell had caused the adjoining bed-chamber to be</li>
<li class="L5217" rel="L5217">lighted. It now shone brightly, through the door of communication. The</li>
<li class="L5218" rel="L5218">Marquis looked that way, and listened for the retreating step of his</li>
<li class="L5219" rel="L5219">valet.</li>
<li class="L5220" rel="L5220"></li>
<li class="L5221" rel="L5221">“England is very attractive to you, seeing how indifferently you have</li>
<li class="L5222" rel="L5222">prospered there,” he observed then, turning his calm face to his nephew</li>
<li class="L5223" rel="L5223">with a smile.</li>
<li class="L5224" rel="L5224"></li>
<li class="L5225" rel="L5225">“I have already said, that for my prospering there, I am sensible I may</li>
<li class="L5226" rel="L5226">be indebted to you, sir. For the rest, it is my Refuge.”</li>
<li class="L5227" rel="L5227"></li>
<li class="L5228" rel="L5228">“They say, those boastful English, that it is the Refuge of many. You</li>
<li class="L5229" rel="L5229">know a compatriot who has found a Refuge there? A Doctor?”</li>
<li class="L5230" rel="L5230"></li>
<li class="L5231" rel="L5231">“Yes.”</li>
<li class="L5232" rel="L5232"></li>
<li class="L5233" rel="L5233">“With a daughter?”</li>
<li class="L5234" rel="L5234"></li>
<li class="L5235" rel="L5235">“Yes.”</li>
<li class="L5236" rel="L5236"></li>
<li class="L5237" rel="L5237">“Yes,” said the Marquis. “You are fatigued. Good night!”</li>
<li class="L5238" rel="L5238"></li>
<li class="L5239" rel="L5239">As he bent his head in his most courtly manner, there was a secrecy</li>
<li class="L5240" rel="L5240">in his smiling face, and he conveyed an air of mystery to those words,</li>
<li class="L5241" rel="L5241">which struck the eyes and ears of his nephew forcibly. At the same</li>
<li class="L5242" rel="L5242">time, the thin straight lines of the setting of the eyes, and the thin</li>
<li class="L5243" rel="L5243">straight lips, and the markings in the nose, curved with a sarcasm that</li>
<li class="L5244" rel="L5244">looked handsomely diabolic.</li>
<li class="L5245" rel="L5245"></li>
<li class="L5246" rel="L5246">“Yes,” repeated the Marquis. “A Doctor with a daughter. Yes. So</li>
<li class="L5247" rel="L5247">commences the new philosophy! You are fatigued. Good night!”</li>
<li class="L5248" rel="L5248"></li>
<li class="L5249" rel="L5249">It would have been of as much avail to interrogate any stone face</li>
<li class="L5250" rel="L5250">outside the chateau as to interrogate that face of his. The nephew</li>
<li class="L5251" rel="L5251">looked at him, in vain, in passing on to the door.</li>
<li class="L5252" rel="L5252"></li>
<li class="L5253" rel="L5253">“Good night!” said the uncle. “I look to the pleasure of seeing you</li>
<li class="L5254" rel="L5254">again in the morning. Good repose! Light Monsieur my nephew to his</li>
<li class="L5255" rel="L5255">chamber there!--And burn Monsieur my nephew in his bed, if you will,” he</li>
<li class="L5256" rel="L5256">added to himself, before he rang his little bell again, and summoned his</li>
<li class="L5257" rel="L5257">valet to his own bedroom.</li>
<li class="L5258" rel="L5258"></li>
<li class="L5259" rel="L5259">The valet come and gone, Monsieur the Marquis walked to and fro in his</li>
<li class="L5260" rel="L5260">loose chamber-robe, to prepare himself gently for sleep, that hot still</li>
<li class="L5261" rel="L5261">night. Rustling about the room, his softly-slippered feet making no</li>
<li class="L5262" rel="L5262">noise on the floor, he moved like a refined tiger:--looked like some</li>
<li class="L5263" rel="L5263">enchanted marquis of the impenitently wicked sort, in story, whose</li>
<li class="L5264" rel="L5264">periodical change into tiger form was either just going off, or just</li>
<li class="L5265" rel="L5265">coming on.</li>
<li class="L5266" rel="L5266"></li>
<li class="L5267" rel="L5267">He moved from end to end of his voluptuous bedroom, looking again at the</li>
<li class="L5268" rel="L5268">scraps of the day&#39;s journey that came unbidden into his mind; the slow</li>
<li class="L5269" rel="L5269">toil up the hill at sunset, the setting sun, the descent, the mill, the</li>
<li class="L5270" rel="L5270">prison on the crag, the little village in the hollow, the peasants at</li>
<li class="L5271" rel="L5271">the fountain, and the mender of roads with his blue cap pointing out the</li>
<li class="L5272" rel="L5272">chain under the carriage. That fountain suggested the Paris fountain,</li>
<li class="L5273" rel="L5273">the little bundle lying on the step, the women bending over it, and the</li>
<li class="L5274" rel="L5274">tall man with his arms up, crying, “Dead!”</li>
<li class="L5275" rel="L5275"></li>
<li class="L5276" rel="L5276">“I am cool now,” said Monsieur the Marquis, “and may go to bed.”</li>
<li class="L5277" rel="L5277"></li>
<li class="L5278" rel="L5278">So, leaving only one light burning on the large hearth, he let his thin</li>
<li class="L5279" rel="L5279">gauze curtains fall around him, and heard the night break its silence</li>
<li class="L5280" rel="L5280">with a long sigh as he composed himself to sleep.</li>
<li class="L5281" rel="L5281"></li>
<li class="L5282" rel="L5282">The stone faces on the outer walls stared blindly at the black night</li>
<li class="L5283" rel="L5283">for three heavy hours; for three heavy hours, the horses in the stables</li>
<li class="L5284" rel="L5284">rattled at their racks, the dogs barked, and the owl made a noise with</li>
<li class="L5285" rel="L5285">very little resemblance in it to the noise conventionally assigned to</li>
<li class="L5286" rel="L5286">the owl by men-poets. But it is the obstinate custom of such creatures</li>
<li class="L5287" rel="L5287">hardly ever to say what is set down for them.</li>
<li class="L5288" rel="L5288"></li>
<li class="L5289" rel="L5289">For three heavy hours, the stone faces of the chateau, lion and human,</li>
<li class="L5290" rel="L5290">stared blindly at the night. Dead darkness lay on all the landscape,</li>
<li class="L5291" rel="L5291">dead darkness added its own hush to the hushing dust on all the roads.</li>
<li class="L5292" rel="L5292">The burial-place had got to the pass that its little heaps of poor grass</li>
<li class="L5293" rel="L5293">were undistinguishable from one another; the figure on the Cross might</li>
<li class="L5294" rel="L5294">have come down, for anything that could be seen of it. In the village,</li>
<li class="L5295" rel="L5295">taxers and taxed were fast asleep. Dreaming, perhaps, of banquets, as</li>
<li class="L5296" rel="L5296">the starved usually do, and of ease and rest, as the driven slave and</li>
<li class="L5297" rel="L5297">the yoked ox may, its lean inhabitants slept soundly, and were fed and</li>
<li class="L5298" rel="L5298">freed.</li>
<li class="L5299" rel="L5299"></li>
<li class="L5300" rel="L5300">The fountain in the village flowed unseen and unheard, and the fountain</li>
<li class="L5301" rel="L5301">at the chateau dropped unseen and unheard--both melting away, like the</li>
<li class="L5302" rel="L5302">minutes that were falling from the spring of Time--through three dark</li>
<li class="L5303" rel="L5303">hours. Then, the grey water of both began to be ghostly in the light,</li>
<li class="L5304" rel="L5304">and the eyes of the stone faces of the chateau were opened.</li>
<li class="L5305" rel="L5305"></li>
<li class="L5306" rel="L5306">Lighter and lighter, until at last the sun touched the tops of the still</li>
<li class="L5307" rel="L5307">trees, and poured its radiance over the hill. In the glow, the water</li>
<li class="L5308" rel="L5308">of the chateau fountain seemed to turn to blood, and the stone faces</li>
<li class="L5309" rel="L5309">crimsoned. The carol of the birds was loud and high, and, on the</li>
<li class="L5310" rel="L5310">weather-beaten sill of the great window of the bed-chamber of Monsieur</li>
<li class="L5311" rel="L5311">the Marquis, one little bird sang its sweetest song with all its might.</li>
<li class="L5312" rel="L5312">At this, the nearest stone face seemed to stare amazed, and, with open</li>
<li class="L5313" rel="L5313">mouth and dropped under-jaw, looked awe-stricken.</li>
<li class="L5314" rel="L5314"></li>
<li class="L5315" rel="L5315">Now, the sun was full up, and movement began in the village. Casement</li>
<li class="L5316" rel="L5316">windows opened, crazy doors were unbarred, and people came forth</li>
<li class="L5317" rel="L5317">shivering--chilled, as yet, by the new sweet air. Then began the rarely</li>
<li class="L5318" rel="L5318">lightened toil of the day among the village population. Some, to the</li>
<li class="L5319" rel="L5319">fountain; some, to the fields; men and women here, to dig and delve; men</li>
<li class="L5320" rel="L5320">and women there, to see to the poor live stock, and lead the bony cows</li>
<li class="L5321" rel="L5321">out, to such pasture as could be found by the roadside. In the church</li>
<li class="L5322" rel="L5322">and at the Cross, a kneeling figure or two; attendant on the latter</li>
<li class="L5323" rel="L5323">prayers, the led cow, trying for a breakfast among the weeds at its</li>
<li class="L5324" rel="L5324">foot.</li>
<li class="L5325" rel="L5325"></li>
<li class="L5326" rel="L5326">The chateau awoke later, as became its quality, but awoke gradually and</li>
<li class="L5327" rel="L5327">surely. First, the lonely boar-spears and knives of the chase had been</li>
<li class="L5328" rel="L5328">reddened as of old; then, had gleamed trenchant in the morning sunshine;</li>
<li class="L5329" rel="L5329">now, doors and windows were thrown open, horses in their stables looked</li>
<li class="L5330" rel="L5330">round over their shoulders at the light and freshness pouring in at</li>
<li class="L5331" rel="L5331">doorways, leaves sparkled and rustled at iron-grated windows, dogs</li>
<li class="L5332" rel="L5332">pulled hard at their chains, and reared impatient to be loosed.</li>
<li class="L5333" rel="L5333"></li>
<li class="L5334" rel="L5334">All these trivial incidents belonged to the routine of life, and the</li>
<li class="L5335" rel="L5335">return of morning. Surely, not so the ringing of the great bell of the</li>
<li class="L5336" rel="L5336">chateau, nor the running up and down the stairs; nor the hurried</li>
<li class="L5337" rel="L5337">figures on the terrace; nor the booting and tramping here and there and</li>
<li class="L5338" rel="L5338">everywhere, nor the quick saddling of horses and riding away?</li>
<li class="L5339" rel="L5339"></li>
<li class="L5340" rel="L5340">What winds conveyed this hurry to the grizzled mender of roads, already</li>
<li class="L5341" rel="L5341">at work on the hill-top beyond the village, with his day&#39;s dinner (not</li>
<li class="L5342" rel="L5342">much to carry) lying in a bundle that it was worth no crow&#39;s while to</li>
<li class="L5343" rel="L5343">peck at, on a heap of stones? Had the birds, carrying some grains of it</li>
<li class="L5344" rel="L5344">to a distance, dropped one over him as they sow chance seeds? Whether or</li>
<li class="L5345" rel="L5345">no, the mender of roads ran, on the sultry morning, as if for his life,</li>
<li class="L5346" rel="L5346">down the hill, knee-high in dust, and never stopped till he got to the</li>
<li class="L5347" rel="L5347">fountain.</li>
<li class="L5348" rel="L5348"></li>
<li class="L5349" rel="L5349">All the people of the village were at the fountain, standing about</li>
<li class="L5350" rel="L5350">in their depressed manner, and whispering low, but showing no other</li>
<li class="L5351" rel="L5351">emotions than grim curiosity and surprise. The led cows, hastily brought</li>
<li class="L5352" rel="L5352">in and tethered to anything that would hold them, were looking stupidly</li>
<li class="L5353" rel="L5353">on, or lying down chewing the cud of nothing particularly repaying their</li>
<li class="L5354" rel="L5354">trouble, which they had picked up in their interrupted saunter. Some of</li>
<li class="L5355" rel="L5355">the people of the chateau, and some of those of the posting-house, and</li>
<li class="L5356" rel="L5356">all the taxing authorities, were armed more or less, and were crowded</li>
<li class="L5357" rel="L5357">on the other side of the little street in a purposeless way, that was</li>
<li class="L5358" rel="L5358">highly fraught with nothing. Already, the mender of roads had penetrated</li>
<li class="L5359" rel="L5359">into the midst of a group of fifty particular friends, and was smiting</li>
<li class="L5360" rel="L5360">himself in the breast with his blue cap. What did all this portend,</li>
<li class="L5361" rel="L5361">and what portended the swift hoisting-up of Monsieur Gabelle behind</li>
<li class="L5362" rel="L5362">a servant on horseback, and the conveying away of the said Gabelle</li>
<li class="L5363" rel="L5363">(double-laden though the horse was), at a gallop, like a new version of</li>
<li class="L5364" rel="L5364">the German ballad of Leonora?</li>
<li class="L5365" rel="L5365"></li>
<li class="L5366" rel="L5366">It portended that there was one stone face too many, up at the chateau.</li>
<li class="L5367" rel="L5367"></li>
<li class="L5368" rel="L5368">The Gorgon had surveyed the building again in the night, and had added</li>
<li class="L5369" rel="L5369">the one stone face wanting; the stone face for which it had waited</li>
<li class="L5370" rel="L5370">through about two hundred years.</li>
<li class="L5371" rel="L5371"></li>
<li class="L5372" rel="L5372">It lay back on the pillow of Monsieur the Marquis. It was like a fine</li>
<li class="L5373" rel="L5373">mask, suddenly startled, made angry, and petrified. Driven home into the</li>
<li class="L5374" rel="L5374">heart of the stone figure attached to it, was a knife. Round its hilt</li>
<li class="L5375" rel="L5375">was a frill of paper, on which was scrawled:</li>
<li class="L5376" rel="L5376"></li>
<li class="L5377" rel="L5377">“Drive him fast to his tomb. This, from Jacques.”</li>
<li class="L5378" rel="L5378"></li>
<li class="L5379" rel="L5379"></li>
<li class="L5380" rel="L5380"></li>
<li class="L5381" rel="L5381"></li>
<li class="L5382" rel="L5382">X. Two Promises</li>
<li class="L5383" rel="L5383"></li>
<li class="L5384" rel="L5384"></li>
<li class="L5385" rel="L5385">More months, to the number of twelve, had come and gone, and Mr. Charles</li>
<li class="L5386" rel="L5386">Darnay was established in England as a higher teacher of the French</li>
<li class="L5387" rel="L5387">language who was conversant with French literature. In this age, he</li>
<li class="L5388" rel="L5388">would have been a Professor; in that age, he was a Tutor. He read with</li>
<li class="L5389" rel="L5389">young men who could find any leisure and interest for the study of a</li>
<li class="L5390" rel="L5390">living tongue spoken all over the world, and he cultivated a taste for</li>
<li class="L5391" rel="L5391">its stores of knowledge and fancy. He could write of them, besides, in</li>
<li class="L5392" rel="L5392">sound English, and render them into sound English. Such masters were not</li>
<li class="L5393" rel="L5393">at that time easily found; Princes that had been, and Kings that were</li>
<li class="L5394" rel="L5394">to be, were not yet of the Teacher class, and no ruined nobility had</li>
<li class="L5395" rel="L5395">dropped out of Tellson&#39;s ledgers, to turn cooks and carpenters. As a</li>
<li class="L5396" rel="L5396">tutor, whose attainments made the student&#39;s way unusually pleasant and</li>
<li class="L5397" rel="L5397">profitable, and as an elegant translator who brought something to his</li>
<li class="L5398" rel="L5398">work besides mere dictionary knowledge, young Mr. Darnay soon became</li>
<li class="L5399" rel="L5399">known and encouraged. He was well acquainted, more-over, with the</li>
<li class="L5400" rel="L5400">circumstances of his country, and those were of ever-growing interest.</li>
<li class="L5401" rel="L5401">So, with great perseverance and untiring industry, he prospered.</li>
<li class="L5402" rel="L5402"></li>
<li class="L5403" rel="L5403">In London, he had expected neither to walk on pavements of gold, nor</li>
<li class="L5404" rel="L5404">to lie on beds of roses; if he had had any such exalted expectation, he</li>
<li class="L5405" rel="L5405">would not have prospered. He had expected labour, and he found it, and</li>
<li class="L5406" rel="L5406">did it and made the best of it. In this, his prosperity consisted.</li>
<li class="L5407" rel="L5407"></li>
<li class="L5408" rel="L5408">A certain portion of his time was passed at Cambridge, where he</li>
<li class="L5409" rel="L5409">read with undergraduates as a sort of tolerated smuggler who drove a</li>
<li class="L5410" rel="L5410">contraband trade in European languages, instead of conveying Greek</li>
<li class="L5411" rel="L5411">and Latin through the Custom-house. The rest of his time he passed in</li>
<li class="L5412" rel="L5412">London.</li>
<li class="L5413" rel="L5413"></li>
<li class="L5414" rel="L5414">Now, from the days when it was always summer in Eden, to these days</li>
<li class="L5415" rel="L5415">when it is mostly winter in fallen latitudes, the world of a man has</li>
<li class="L5416" rel="L5416">invariably gone one way--Charles Darnay&#39;s way--the way of the love of a</li>
<li class="L5417" rel="L5417">woman.</li>
<li class="L5418" rel="L5418"></li>
<li class="L5419" rel="L5419">He had loved Lucie Manette from the hour of his danger. He had never</li>
<li class="L5420" rel="L5420">heard a sound so sweet and dear as the sound of her compassionate voice;</li>
<li class="L5421" rel="L5421">he had never seen a face so tenderly beautiful, as hers when it was</li>
<li class="L5422" rel="L5422">confronted with his own on the edge of the grave that had been dug for</li>
<li class="L5423" rel="L5423">him. But, he had not yet spoken to her on the subject; the assassination</li>
<li class="L5424" rel="L5424">at the deserted chateau far away beyond the heaving water and the long,</li>
<li class="L5425" rel="L5425">long, dusty roads--the solid stone chateau which had itself become the</li>
<li class="L5426" rel="L5426">mere mist of a dream--had been done a year, and he had never yet, by so</li>
<li class="L5427" rel="L5427">much as a single spoken word, disclosed to her the state of his heart.</li>
<li class="L5428" rel="L5428"></li>
<li class="L5429" rel="L5429">That he had his reasons for this, he knew full well. It was again a</li>
<li class="L5430" rel="L5430">summer day when, lately arrived in London from his college occupation,</li>
<li class="L5431" rel="L5431">he turned into the quiet corner in Soho, bent on seeking an opportunity</li>
<li class="L5432" rel="L5432">of opening his mind to Doctor Manette. It was the close of the summer</li>
<li class="L5433" rel="L5433">day, and he knew Lucie to be out with Miss Pross.</li>
<li class="L5434" rel="L5434"></li>
<li class="L5435" rel="L5435">He found the Doctor reading in his arm-chair at a window. The energy</li>
<li class="L5436" rel="L5436">which had at once supported him under his old sufferings and aggravated</li>
<li class="L5437" rel="L5437">their sharpness, had been gradually restored to him. He was now a</li>
<li class="L5438" rel="L5438">very energetic man indeed, with great firmness of purpose, strength</li>
<li class="L5439" rel="L5439">of resolution, and vigour of action. In his recovered energy he was</li>
<li class="L5440" rel="L5440">sometimes a little fitful and sudden, as he had at first been in the</li>
<li class="L5441" rel="L5441">exercise of his other recovered faculties; but, this had never been</li>
<li class="L5442" rel="L5442">frequently observable, and had grown more and more rare.</li>
<li class="L5443" rel="L5443"></li>
<li class="L5444" rel="L5444">He studied much, slept little, sustained a great deal of fatigue with</li>
<li class="L5445" rel="L5445">ease, and was equably cheerful. To him, now entered Charles Darnay, at</li>
<li class="L5446" rel="L5446">sight of whom he laid aside his book and held out his hand.</li>
<li class="L5447" rel="L5447"></li>
<li class="L5448" rel="L5448">“Charles Darnay! I rejoice to see you. We have been counting on your</li>
<li class="L5449" rel="L5449">return these three or four days past. Mr. Stryver and Sydney Carton were</li>
<li class="L5450" rel="L5450">both here yesterday, and both made you out to be more than due.”</li>
<li class="L5451" rel="L5451"></li>
<li class="L5452" rel="L5452">“I am obliged to them for their interest in the matter,” he answered,</li>
<li class="L5453" rel="L5453">a little coldly as to them, though very warmly as to the Doctor. “Miss</li>
<li class="L5454" rel="L5454">Manette--”</li>
<li class="L5455" rel="L5455"></li>
<li class="L5456" rel="L5456">“Is well,” said the Doctor, as he stopped short, “and your return will</li>
<li class="L5457" rel="L5457">delight us all. She has gone out on some household matters, but will</li>
<li class="L5458" rel="L5458">soon be home.”</li>
<li class="L5459" rel="L5459"></li>
<li class="L5460" rel="L5460">“Doctor Manette, I knew she was from home. I took the opportunity of her</li>
<li class="L5461" rel="L5461">being from home, to beg to speak to you.”</li>
<li class="L5462" rel="L5462"></li>
<li class="L5463" rel="L5463">There was a blank silence.</li>
<li class="L5464" rel="L5464"></li>
<li class="L5465" rel="L5465">“Yes?” said the Doctor, with evident constraint. “Bring your chair here,</li>
<li class="L5466" rel="L5466">and speak on.”</li>
<li class="L5467" rel="L5467"></li>
<li class="L5468" rel="L5468">He complied as to the chair, but appeared to find the speaking on less</li>
<li class="L5469" rel="L5469">easy.</li>
<li class="L5470" rel="L5470"></li>
<li class="L5471" rel="L5471">“I have had the happiness, Doctor Manette, of being so intimate here,”</li>
<li class="L5472" rel="L5472"> so he at length began, “for some year and a half, that I hope the topic</li>
<li class="L5473" rel="L5473">on which I am about to touch may not--”</li>
<li class="L5474" rel="L5474"></li>
<li class="L5475" rel="L5475">He was stayed by the Doctor&#39;s putting out his hand to stop him. When he</li>
<li class="L5476" rel="L5476">had kept it so a little while, he said, drawing it back:</li>
<li class="L5477" rel="L5477"></li>
<li class="L5478" rel="L5478">“Is Lucie the topic?”</li>
<li class="L5479" rel="L5479"></li>
<li class="L5480" rel="L5480">“She is.”</li>
<li class="L5481" rel="L5481"></li>
<li class="L5482" rel="L5482">“It is hard for me to speak of her at any time. It is very hard for me</li>
<li class="L5483" rel="L5483">to hear her spoken of in that tone of yours, Charles Darnay.”</li>
<li class="L5484" rel="L5484"></li>
<li class="L5485" rel="L5485">“It is a tone of fervent admiration, true homage, and deep love, Doctor</li>
<li class="L5486" rel="L5486">Manette!” he said deferentially.</li>
<li class="L5487" rel="L5487"></li>
<li class="L5488" rel="L5488">There was another blank silence before her father rejoined:</li>
<li class="L5489" rel="L5489"></li>
<li class="L5490" rel="L5490">“I believe it. I do you justice; I believe it.”</li>
<li class="L5491" rel="L5491"></li>
<li class="L5492" rel="L5492">His constraint was so manifest, and it was so manifest, too, that it</li>
<li class="L5493" rel="L5493">originated in an unwillingness to approach the subject, that Charles</li>
<li class="L5494" rel="L5494">Darnay hesitated.</li>
<li class="L5495" rel="L5495"></li>
<li class="L5496" rel="L5496">“Shall I go on, sir?”</li>
<li class="L5497" rel="L5497"></li>
<li class="L5498" rel="L5498">Another blank.</li>
<li class="L5499" rel="L5499"></li>
<li class="L5500" rel="L5500">“Yes, go on.”</li>
<li class="L5501" rel="L5501"></li>
<li class="L5502" rel="L5502">“You anticipate what I would say, though you cannot know how earnestly</li>
<li class="L5503" rel="L5503">I say it, how earnestly I feel it, without knowing my secret heart, and</li>
<li class="L5504" rel="L5504">the hopes and fears and anxieties with which it has long been</li>
<li class="L5505" rel="L5505">laden. Dear Doctor Manette, I love your daughter fondly, dearly,</li>
<li class="L5506" rel="L5506">disinterestedly, devotedly. If ever there were love in the world, I love</li>
<li class="L5507" rel="L5507">her. You have loved yourself; let your old love speak for me!”</li>
<li class="L5508" rel="L5508"></li>
<li class="L5509" rel="L5509">The Doctor sat with his face turned away, and his eyes bent on the</li>
<li class="L5510" rel="L5510">ground. At the last words, he stretched out his hand again, hurriedly,</li>
<li class="L5511" rel="L5511">and cried:</li>
<li class="L5512" rel="L5512"></li>
<li class="L5513" rel="L5513">“Not that, sir! Let that be! I adjure you, do not recall that!”</li>
<li class="L5514" rel="L5514"></li>
<li class="L5515" rel="L5515">His cry was so like a cry of actual pain, that it rang in Charles</li>
<li class="L5516" rel="L5516">Darnay&#39;s ears long after he had ceased. He motioned with the hand he had</li>
<li class="L5517" rel="L5517">extended, and it seemed to be an appeal to Darnay to pause. The latter</li>
<li class="L5518" rel="L5518">so received it, and remained silent.</li>
<li class="L5519" rel="L5519"></li>
<li class="L5520" rel="L5520">“I ask your pardon,” said the Doctor, in a subdued tone, after some</li>
<li class="L5521" rel="L5521">moments. “I do not doubt your loving Lucie; you may be satisfied of it.”</li>
<li class="L5522" rel="L5522"></li>
<li class="L5523" rel="L5523">He turned towards him in his chair, but did not look at him, or</li>
<li class="L5524" rel="L5524">raise his eyes. His chin dropped upon his hand, and his white hair</li>
<li class="L5525" rel="L5525">overshadowed his face:</li>
<li class="L5526" rel="L5526"></li>
<li class="L5527" rel="L5527">“Have you spoken to Lucie?”</li>
<li class="L5528" rel="L5528"></li>
<li class="L5529" rel="L5529">“No.”</li>
<li class="L5530" rel="L5530"></li>
<li class="L5531" rel="L5531">“Nor written?”</li>
<li class="L5532" rel="L5532"></li>
<li class="L5533" rel="L5533">“Never.”</li>
<li class="L5534" rel="L5534"></li>
<li class="L5535" rel="L5535">“It would be ungenerous to affect not to know that your self-denial is</li>
<li class="L5536" rel="L5536">to be referred to your consideration for her father. Her father thanks</li>
<li class="L5537" rel="L5537">you.”</li>
<li class="L5538" rel="L5538"></li>
<li class="L5539" rel="L5539">He offered his hand; but his eyes did not go with it.</li>
<li class="L5540" rel="L5540"></li>
<li class="L5541" rel="L5541">“I know,” said Darnay, respectfully, “how can I fail to know, Doctor</li>
<li class="L5542" rel="L5542">Manette, I who have seen you together from day to day, that between</li>
<li class="L5543" rel="L5543">you and Miss Manette there is an affection so unusual, so touching, so</li>
<li class="L5544" rel="L5544">belonging to the circumstances in which it has been nurtured, that it</li>
<li class="L5545" rel="L5545">can have few parallels, even in the tenderness between a father and</li>
<li class="L5546" rel="L5546">child. I know, Doctor Manette--how can I fail to know--that, mingled</li>
<li class="L5547" rel="L5547">with the affection and duty of a daughter who has become a woman, there</li>
<li class="L5548" rel="L5548">is, in her heart, towards you, all the love and reliance of infancy</li>
<li class="L5549" rel="L5549">itself. I know that, as in her childhood she had no parent, so she is</li>
<li class="L5550" rel="L5550">now devoted to you with all the constancy and fervour of her present</li>
<li class="L5551" rel="L5551">years and character, united to the trustfulness and attachment of the</li>
<li class="L5552" rel="L5552">early days in which you were lost to her. I know perfectly well that if</li>
<li class="L5553" rel="L5553">you had been restored to her from the world beyond this life, you could</li>
<li class="L5554" rel="L5554">hardly be invested, in her sight, with a more sacred character than that</li>
<li class="L5555" rel="L5555">in which you are always with her. I know that when she is clinging to</li>
<li class="L5556" rel="L5556">you, the hands of baby, girl, and woman, all in one, are round your</li>
<li class="L5557" rel="L5557">neck. I know that in loving you she sees and loves her mother at her</li>
<li class="L5558" rel="L5558">own age, sees and loves you at my age, loves her mother broken-hearted,</li>
<li class="L5559" rel="L5559">loves you through your dreadful trial and in your blessed restoration. I</li>
<li class="L5560" rel="L5560">have known this, night and day, since I have known you in your home.”</li>
<li class="L5561" rel="L5561"></li>
<li class="L5562" rel="L5562">Her father sat silent, with his face bent down. His breathing was a</li>
<li class="L5563" rel="L5563">little quickened; but he repressed all other signs of agitation.</li>
<li class="L5564" rel="L5564"></li>
<li class="L5565" rel="L5565">“Dear Doctor Manette, always knowing this, always seeing her and you</li>
<li class="L5566" rel="L5566">with this hallowed light about you, I have forborne, and forborne, as</li>
<li class="L5567" rel="L5567">long as it was in the nature of man to do it. I have felt, and do even</li>
<li class="L5568" rel="L5568">now feel, that to bring my love--even mine--between you, is to touch</li>
<li class="L5569" rel="L5569">your history with something not quite so good as itself. But I love her.</li>
<li class="L5570" rel="L5570">Heaven is my witness that I love her!”</li>
<li class="L5571" rel="L5571"></li>
<li class="L5572" rel="L5572">“I believe it,” answered her father, mournfully. “I have thought so</li>
<li class="L5573" rel="L5573">before now. I believe it.”</li>
<li class="L5574" rel="L5574"></li>
<li class="L5575" rel="L5575">“But, do not believe,” said Darnay, upon whose ear the mournful voice</li>
<li class="L5576" rel="L5576">struck with a reproachful sound, “that if my fortune were so cast as</li>
<li class="L5577" rel="L5577">that, being one day so happy as to make her my wife, I must at any time</li>
<li class="L5578" rel="L5578">put any separation between her and you, I could or would breathe a</li>
<li class="L5579" rel="L5579">word of what I now say. Besides that I should know it to be hopeless, I</li>
<li class="L5580" rel="L5580">should know it to be a baseness. If I had any such possibility, even at</li>
<li class="L5581" rel="L5581">a remote distance of years, harboured in my thoughts, and hidden in my</li>
<li class="L5582" rel="L5582">heart--if it ever had been there--if it ever could be there--I could not</li>
<li class="L5583" rel="L5583">now touch this honoured hand.”</li>
<li class="L5584" rel="L5584"></li>
<li class="L5585" rel="L5585">He laid his own upon it as he spoke.</li>
<li class="L5586" rel="L5586"></li>
<li class="L5587" rel="L5587">“No, dear Doctor Manette. Like you, a voluntary exile from France; like</li>
<li class="L5588" rel="L5588">you, driven from it by its distractions, oppressions, and miseries; like</li>
<li class="L5589" rel="L5589">you, striving to live away from it by my own exertions, and trusting</li>
<li class="L5590" rel="L5590">in a happier future; I look only to sharing your fortunes, sharing your</li>
<li class="L5591" rel="L5591">life and home, and being faithful to you to the death. Not to divide</li>
<li class="L5592" rel="L5592">with Lucie her privilege as your child, companion, and friend; but to</li>
<li class="L5593" rel="L5593">come in aid of it, and bind her closer to you, if such a thing can be.”</li>
<li class="L5594" rel="L5594"></li>
<li class="L5595" rel="L5595">His touch still lingered on her father&#39;s hand. Answering the touch for a</li>
<li class="L5596" rel="L5596">moment, but not coldly, her father rested his hands upon the arms of</li>
<li class="L5597" rel="L5597">his chair, and looked up for the first time since the beginning of the</li>
<li class="L5598" rel="L5598">conference. A struggle was evidently in his face; a struggle with that</li>
<li class="L5599" rel="L5599">occasional look which had a tendency in it to dark doubt and dread.</li>
<li class="L5600" rel="L5600"></li>
<li class="L5601" rel="L5601">“You speak so feelingly and so manfully, Charles Darnay, that I thank</li>
<li class="L5602" rel="L5602">you with all my heart, and will open all my heart--or nearly so. Have</li>
<li class="L5603" rel="L5603">you any reason to believe that Lucie loves you?”</li>
<li class="L5604" rel="L5604"></li>
<li class="L5605" rel="L5605">“None. As yet, none.”</li>
<li class="L5606" rel="L5606"></li>
<li class="L5607" rel="L5607">“Is it the immediate object of this confidence, that you may at once</li>
<li class="L5608" rel="L5608">ascertain that, with my knowledge?”</li>
<li class="L5609" rel="L5609"></li>
<li class="L5610" rel="L5610">“Not even so. I might not have the hopefulness to do it for weeks; I</li>
<li class="L5611" rel="L5611">might (mistaken or not mistaken) have that hopefulness to-morrow.”</li>
<li class="L5612" rel="L5612"></li>
<li class="L5613" rel="L5613">“Do you seek any guidance from me?”</li>
<li class="L5614" rel="L5614"></li>
<li class="L5615" rel="L5615">“I ask none, sir. But I have thought it possible that you might have it</li>
<li class="L5616" rel="L5616">in your power, if you should deem it right, to give me some.”</li>
<li class="L5617" rel="L5617"></li>
<li class="L5618" rel="L5618">“Do you seek any promise from me?”</li>
<li class="L5619" rel="L5619"></li>
<li class="L5620" rel="L5620">“I do seek that.”</li>
<li class="L5621" rel="L5621"></li>
<li class="L5622" rel="L5622">“What is it?”</li>
<li class="L5623" rel="L5623"></li>
<li class="L5624" rel="L5624">“I well understand that, without you, I could have no hope. I well</li>
<li class="L5625" rel="L5625">understand that, even if Miss Manette held me at this moment in her</li>
<li class="L5626" rel="L5626">innocent heart--do not think I have the presumption to assume so much--I</li>
<li class="L5627" rel="L5627">could retain no place in it against her love for her father.”</li>
<li class="L5628" rel="L5628"></li>
<li class="L5629" rel="L5629">“If that be so, do you see what, on the other hand, is involved in it?”</li>
<li class="L5630" rel="L5630"></li>
<li class="L5631" rel="L5631">“I understand equally well, that a word from her father in any suitor&#39;s</li>
<li class="L5632" rel="L5632">favour, would outweigh herself and all the world. For which reason,</li>
<li class="L5633" rel="L5633">Doctor Manette,” said Darnay, modestly but firmly, “I would not ask that</li>
<li class="L5634" rel="L5634">word, to save my life.”</li>
<li class="L5635" rel="L5635"></li>
<li class="L5636" rel="L5636">“I am sure of it. Charles Darnay, mysteries arise out of close love, as</li>
<li class="L5637" rel="L5637">well as out of wide division; in the former case, they are subtle and</li>
<li class="L5638" rel="L5638">delicate, and difficult to penetrate. My daughter Lucie is, in this one</li>
<li class="L5639" rel="L5639">respect, such a mystery to me; I can make no guess at the state of her</li>
<li class="L5640" rel="L5640">heart.”</li>
<li class="L5641" rel="L5641"></li>
<li class="L5642" rel="L5642">“May I ask, sir, if you think she is--” As he hesitated, her father</li>
<li class="L5643" rel="L5643">supplied the rest.</li>
<li class="L5644" rel="L5644"></li>
<li class="L5645" rel="L5645">“Is sought by any other suitor?”</li>
<li class="L5646" rel="L5646"></li>
<li class="L5647" rel="L5647">“It is what I meant to say.”</li>
<li class="L5648" rel="L5648"></li>
<li class="L5649" rel="L5649">Her father considered a little before he answered:</li>
<li class="L5650" rel="L5650"></li>
<li class="L5651" rel="L5651">“You have seen Mr. Carton here, yourself. Mr. Stryver is here too,</li>
<li class="L5652" rel="L5652">occasionally. If it be at all, it can only be by one of these.”</li>
<li class="L5653" rel="L5653"></li>
<li class="L5654" rel="L5654">“Or both,” said Darnay.</li>
<li class="L5655" rel="L5655"></li>
<li class="L5656" rel="L5656">“I had not thought of both; I should not think either, likely. You want</li>
<li class="L5657" rel="L5657">a promise from me. Tell me what it is.”</li>
<li class="L5658" rel="L5658"></li>
<li class="L5659" rel="L5659">“It is, that if Miss Manette should bring to you at any time, on her own</li>
<li class="L5660" rel="L5660">part, such a confidence as I have ventured to lay before you, you will</li>
<li class="L5661" rel="L5661">bear testimony to what I have said, and to your belief in it. I hope you</li>
<li class="L5662" rel="L5662">may be able to think so well of me, as to urge no influence against</li>
<li class="L5663" rel="L5663">me. I say nothing more of my stake in this; this is what I ask. The</li>
<li class="L5664" rel="L5664">condition on which I ask it, and which you have an undoubted right to</li>
<li class="L5665" rel="L5665">require, I will observe immediately.”</li>
<li class="L5666" rel="L5666"></li>
<li class="L5667" rel="L5667">“I give the promise,” said the Doctor, “without any condition. I believe</li>
<li class="L5668" rel="L5668">your object to be, purely and truthfully, as you have stated it. I</li>
<li class="L5669" rel="L5669">believe your intention is to perpetuate, and not to weaken, the ties</li>
<li class="L5670" rel="L5670">between me and my other and far dearer self. If she should ever tell me</li>
<li class="L5671" rel="L5671">that you are essential to her perfect happiness, I will give her to you.</li>
<li class="L5672" rel="L5672">If there were--Charles Darnay, if there were--”</li>
<li class="L5673" rel="L5673"></li>
<li class="L5674" rel="L5674">The young man had taken his hand gratefully; their hands were joined as</li>
<li class="L5675" rel="L5675">the Doctor spoke:</li>
<li class="L5676" rel="L5676"></li>
<li class="L5677" rel="L5677">“--any fancies, any reasons, any apprehensions, anything whatsoever,</li>
<li class="L5678" rel="L5678">new or old, against the man she really loved--the direct responsibility</li>
<li class="L5679" rel="L5679">thereof not lying on his head--they should all be obliterated for her</li>
<li class="L5680" rel="L5680">sake. She is everything to me; more to me than suffering, more to me</li>
<li class="L5681" rel="L5681">than wrong, more to me--Well! This is idle talk.”</li>
<li class="L5682" rel="L5682"></li>
<li class="L5683" rel="L5683">So strange was the way in which he faded into silence, and so strange</li>
<li class="L5684" rel="L5684">his fixed look when he had ceased to speak, that Darnay felt his own</li>
<li class="L5685" rel="L5685">hand turn cold in the hand that slowly released and dropped it.</li>
<li class="L5686" rel="L5686"></li>
<li class="L5687" rel="L5687">“You said something to me,” said Doctor Manette, breaking into a smile.</li>
<li class="L5688" rel="L5688">“What was it you said to me?”</li>
<li class="L5689" rel="L5689"></li>
<li class="L5690" rel="L5690">He was at a loss how to answer, until he remembered having spoken of a</li>
<li class="L5691" rel="L5691">condition. Relieved as his mind reverted to that, he answered:</li>
<li class="L5692" rel="L5692"></li>
<li class="L5693" rel="L5693">“Your confidence in me ought to be returned with full confidence on my</li>
<li class="L5694" rel="L5694">part. My present name, though but slightly changed from my mother&#39;s, is</li>
<li class="L5695" rel="L5695">not, as you will remember, my own. I wish to tell you what that is, and</li>
<li class="L5696" rel="L5696">why I am in England.”</li>
<li class="L5697" rel="L5697"></li>
<li class="L5698" rel="L5698">“Stop!” said the Doctor of Beauvais.</li>
<li class="L5699" rel="L5699"></li>
<li class="L5700" rel="L5700">“I wish it, that I may the better deserve your confidence, and have no</li>
<li class="L5701" rel="L5701">secret from you.”</li>
<li class="L5702" rel="L5702"></li>
<li class="L5703" rel="L5703">“Stop!”</li>
<li class="L5704" rel="L5704"></li>
<li class="L5705" rel="L5705">For an instant, the Doctor even had his two hands at his ears; for</li>
<li class="L5706" rel="L5706">another instant, even had his two hands laid on Darnay&#39;s lips.</li>
<li class="L5707" rel="L5707"></li>
<li class="L5708" rel="L5708">“Tell me when I ask you, not now. If your suit should prosper, if Lucie</li>
<li class="L5709" rel="L5709">should love you, you shall tell me on your marriage morning. Do you</li>
<li class="L5710" rel="L5710">promise?”</li>
<li class="L5711" rel="L5711"></li>
<li class="L5712" rel="L5712">“Willingly.</li>
<li class="L5713" rel="L5713"></li>
<li class="L5714" rel="L5714">“Give me your hand. She will be home directly, and it is better she</li>
<li class="L5715" rel="L5715">should not see us together to-night. Go! God bless you!”</li>
<li class="L5716" rel="L5716"></li>
<li class="L5717" rel="L5717">It was dark when Charles Darnay left him, and it was an hour later and</li>
<li class="L5718" rel="L5718">darker when Lucie came home; she hurried into the room alone--for</li>
<li class="L5719" rel="L5719">Miss Pross had gone straight up-stairs--and was surprised to find his</li>
<li class="L5720" rel="L5720">reading-chair empty.</li>
<li class="L5721" rel="L5721"></li>
<li class="L5722" rel="L5722">“My father!” she called to him. “Father dear!”</li>
<li class="L5723" rel="L5723"></li>
<li class="L5724" rel="L5724">Nothing was said in answer, but she heard a low hammering sound in his</li>
<li class="L5725" rel="L5725">bedroom. Passing lightly across the intermediate room, she looked in at</li>
<li class="L5726" rel="L5726">his door and came running back frightened, crying to herself, with her</li>
<li class="L5727" rel="L5727">blood all chilled, “What shall I do! What shall I do!”</li>
<li class="L5728" rel="L5728"></li>
<li class="L5729" rel="L5729">Her uncertainty lasted but a moment; she hurried back, and tapped at</li>
<li class="L5730" rel="L5730">his door, and softly called to him. The noise ceased at the sound of</li>
<li class="L5731" rel="L5731">her voice, and he presently came out to her, and they walked up and down</li>
<li class="L5732" rel="L5732">together for a long time.</li>
<li class="L5733" rel="L5733"></li>
<li class="L5734" rel="L5734">She came down from her bed, to look at him in his sleep that night. He</li>
<li class="L5735" rel="L5735">slept heavily, and his tray of shoemaking tools, and his old unfinished</li>
<li class="L5736" rel="L5736">work, were all as usual.</li>
<li class="L5737" rel="L5737"></li>
<li class="L5738" rel="L5738"></li>
<li class="L5739" rel="L5739"></li>
<li class="L5740" rel="L5740"></li>
<li class="L5741" rel="L5741">XI. A Companion Picture</li>
<li class="L5742" rel="L5742"></li>
<li class="L5743" rel="L5743"></li>
<li class="L5744" rel="L5744">“Sydney,” said Mr. Stryver, on that self-same night, or morning, to his</li>
<li class="L5745" rel="L5745">jackal; “mix another bowl of punch; I have something to say to you.”</li>
<li class="L5746" rel="L5746"></li>
<li class="L5747" rel="L5747">Sydney had been working double tides that night, and the night before,</li>
<li class="L5748" rel="L5748">and the night before that, and a good many nights in succession, making</li>
<li class="L5749" rel="L5749">a grand clearance among Mr. Stryver&#39;s papers before the setting in</li>
<li class="L5750" rel="L5750">of the long vacation. The clearance was effected at last; the Stryver</li>
<li class="L5751" rel="L5751">arrears were handsomely fetched up; everything was got rid of until</li>
<li class="L5752" rel="L5752">November should come with its fogs atmospheric, and fogs legal, and</li>
<li class="L5753" rel="L5753">bring grist to the mill again.</li>
<li class="L5754" rel="L5754"></li>
<li class="L5755" rel="L5755">Sydney was none the livelier and none the soberer for so much</li>
<li class="L5756" rel="L5756">application. It had taken a deal of extra wet-towelling to pull him</li>
<li class="L5757" rel="L5757">through the night; a correspondingly extra quantity of wine had preceded</li>
<li class="L5758" rel="L5758">the towelling; and he was in a very damaged condition, as he now pulled</li>
<li class="L5759" rel="L5759">his turban off and threw it into the basin in which he had steeped it at</li>
<li class="L5760" rel="L5760">intervals for the last six hours.</li>
<li class="L5761" rel="L5761"></li>
<li class="L5762" rel="L5762">“Are you mixing that other bowl of punch?” said Stryver the portly, with</li>
<li class="L5763" rel="L5763">his hands in his waistband, glancing round from the sofa where he lay on</li>
<li class="L5764" rel="L5764">his back.</li>
<li class="L5765" rel="L5765"></li>
<li class="L5766" rel="L5766">“I am.”</li>
<li class="L5767" rel="L5767"></li>
<li class="L5768" rel="L5768">“Now, look here! I am going to tell you something that will rather</li>
<li class="L5769" rel="L5769">surprise you, and that perhaps will make you think me not quite as</li>
<li class="L5770" rel="L5770">shrewd as you usually do think me. I intend to marry.”</li>
<li class="L5771" rel="L5771"></li>
<li class="L5772" rel="L5772">“_Do_ you?”</li>
<li class="L5773" rel="L5773"></li>
<li class="L5774" rel="L5774">“Yes. And not for money. What do you say now?”</li>
<li class="L5775" rel="L5775"></li>
<li class="L5776" rel="L5776">“I don&#39;t feel disposed to say much. Who is she?”</li>
<li class="L5777" rel="L5777"></li>
<li class="L5778" rel="L5778">“Guess.”</li>
<li class="L5779" rel="L5779"></li>
<li class="L5780" rel="L5780">“Do I know her?”</li>
<li class="L5781" rel="L5781"></li>
<li class="L5782" rel="L5782">“Guess.”</li>
<li class="L5783" rel="L5783"></li>
<li class="L5784" rel="L5784">“I am not going to guess, at five o&#39;clock in the morning, with my brains</li>
<li class="L5785" rel="L5785">frying and sputtering in my head. If you want me to guess, you must ask</li>
<li class="L5786" rel="L5786">me to dinner.”</li>
<li class="L5787" rel="L5787"></li>
<li class="L5788" rel="L5788">“Well then, I&#39;ll tell you,” said Stryver, coming slowly into a sitting</li>
<li class="L5789" rel="L5789">posture. “Sydney, I rather despair of making myself intelligible to you,</li>
<li class="L5790" rel="L5790">because you are such an insensible dog.”</li>
<li class="L5791" rel="L5791"></li>
<li class="L5792" rel="L5792">“And you,” returned Sydney, busy concocting the punch, “are such a</li>
<li class="L5793" rel="L5793">sensitive and poetical spirit--”</li>
<li class="L5794" rel="L5794"></li>
<li class="L5795" rel="L5795">“Come!” rejoined Stryver, laughing boastfully, “though I don&#39;t prefer</li>
<li class="L5796" rel="L5796">any claim to being the soul of Romance (for I hope I know better), still</li>
<li class="L5797" rel="L5797">I am a tenderer sort of fellow than _you_.”</li>
<li class="L5798" rel="L5798"></li>
<li class="L5799" rel="L5799">“You are a luckier, if you mean that.”</li>
<li class="L5800" rel="L5800"></li>
<li class="L5801" rel="L5801">“I don&#39;t mean that. I mean I am a man of more--more--”</li>
<li class="L5802" rel="L5802"></li>
<li class="L5803" rel="L5803">“Say gallantry, while you are about it,” suggested Carton.</li>
<li class="L5804" rel="L5804"></li>
<li class="L5805" rel="L5805">“Well! I&#39;ll say gallantry. My meaning is that I am a man,” said Stryver,</li>
<li class="L5806" rel="L5806">inflating himself at his friend as he made the punch, “who cares more to</li>
<li class="L5807" rel="L5807">be agreeable, who takes more pains to be agreeable, who knows better how</li>
<li class="L5808" rel="L5808">to be agreeable, in a woman&#39;s society, than you do.”</li>
<li class="L5809" rel="L5809"></li>
<li class="L5810" rel="L5810">“Go on,” said Sydney Carton.</li>
<li class="L5811" rel="L5811"></li>
<li class="L5812" rel="L5812">“No; but before I go on,” said Stryver, shaking his head in his bullying</li>
<li class="L5813" rel="L5813">way, “I&#39;ll have this out with you. You&#39;ve been at Doctor Manette&#39;s house</li>
<li class="L5814" rel="L5814">as much as I have, or more than I have. Why, I have been ashamed of your</li>
<li class="L5815" rel="L5815">moroseness there! Your manners have been of that silent and sullen and</li>
<li class="L5816" rel="L5816">hangdog kind, that, upon my life and soul, I have been ashamed of you,</li>
<li class="L5817" rel="L5817">Sydney!”</li>
<li class="L5818" rel="L5818"></li>
<li class="L5819" rel="L5819">“It should be very beneficial to a man in your practice at the bar, to</li>
<li class="L5820" rel="L5820">be ashamed of anything,” returned Sydney; “you ought to be much obliged</li>
<li class="L5821" rel="L5821">to me.”</li>
<li class="L5822" rel="L5822"></li>
<li class="L5823" rel="L5823">“You shall not get off in that way,” rejoined Stryver, shouldering the</li>
<li class="L5824" rel="L5824">rejoinder at him; “no, Sydney, it&#39;s my duty to tell you--and I tell you</li>
<li class="L5825" rel="L5825">to your face to do you good--that you are a devilish ill-conditioned</li>
<li class="L5826" rel="L5826">fellow in that sort of society. You are a disagreeable fellow.”</li>
<li class="L5827" rel="L5827"></li>
<li class="L5828" rel="L5828">Sydney drank a bumper of the punch he had made, and laughed.</li>
<li class="L5829" rel="L5829"></li>
<li class="L5830" rel="L5830">“Look at me!” said Stryver, squaring himself; “I have less need to make</li>
<li class="L5831" rel="L5831">myself agreeable than you have, being more independent in circumstances.</li>
<li class="L5832" rel="L5832">Why do I do it?”</li>
<li class="L5833" rel="L5833"></li>
<li class="L5834" rel="L5834">“I never saw you do it yet,” muttered Carton.</li>
<li class="L5835" rel="L5835"></li>
<li class="L5836" rel="L5836">“I do it because it&#39;s politic; I do it on principle. And look at me! I</li>
<li class="L5837" rel="L5837">get on.”</li>
<li class="L5838" rel="L5838"></li>
<li class="L5839" rel="L5839">“You don&#39;t get on with your account of your matrimonial intentions,”</li>
<li class="L5840" rel="L5840"> answered Carton, with a careless air; “I wish you would keep to that. As</li>
<li class="L5841" rel="L5841">to me--will you never understand that I am incorrigible?”</li>
<li class="L5842" rel="L5842"></li>
<li class="L5843" rel="L5843">He asked the question with some appearance of scorn.</li>
<li class="L5844" rel="L5844"></li>
<li class="L5845" rel="L5845">“You have no business to be incorrigible,” was his friend&#39;s answer,</li>
<li class="L5846" rel="L5846">delivered in no very soothing tone.</li>
<li class="L5847" rel="L5847"></li>
<li class="L5848" rel="L5848">“I have no business to be, at all, that I know of,” said Sydney Carton.</li>
<li class="L5849" rel="L5849">“Who is the lady?”</li>
<li class="L5850" rel="L5850"></li>
<li class="L5851" rel="L5851">“Now, don&#39;t let my announcement of the name make you uncomfortable,</li>
<li class="L5852" rel="L5852">Sydney,” said Mr. Stryver, preparing him with ostentatious friendliness</li>
