<li class="L5853" rel="L5853">for the disclosure he was about to make, “because I know you don&#39;t mean</li>
<li class="L5854" rel="L5854">half you say; and if you meant it all, it would be of no importance. I</li>
<li class="L5855" rel="L5855">make this little preface, because you once mentioned the young lady to</li>
<li class="L5856" rel="L5856">me in slighting terms.”</li>
<li class="L5857" rel="L5857"></li>
<li class="L5858" rel="L5858">“I did?”</li>
<li class="L5859" rel="L5859"></li>
<li class="L5860" rel="L5860">“Certainly; and in these chambers.”</li>
<li class="L5861" rel="L5861"></li>
<li class="L5862" rel="L5862">Sydney Carton looked at his punch and looked at his complacent friend;</li>
<li class="L5863" rel="L5863">drank his punch and looked at his complacent friend.</li>
<li class="L5864" rel="L5864"></li>
<li class="L5865" rel="L5865">“You made mention of the young lady as a golden-haired doll. The young</li>
<li class="L5866" rel="L5866">lady is Miss Manette. If you had been a fellow of any sensitiveness or</li>
<li class="L5867" rel="L5867">delicacy of feeling in that kind of way, Sydney, I might have been a</li>
<li class="L5868" rel="L5868">little resentful of your employing such a designation; but you are not.</li>
<li class="L5869" rel="L5869">You want that sense altogether; therefore I am no more annoyed when I</li>
<li class="L5870" rel="L5870">think of the expression, than I should be annoyed by a man&#39;s opinion of</li>
<li class="L5871" rel="L5871">a picture of mine, who had no eye for pictures: or of a piece of music</li>
<li class="L5872" rel="L5872">of mine, who had no ear for music.”</li>
<li class="L5873" rel="L5873"></li>
<li class="L5874" rel="L5874">Sydney Carton drank the punch at a great rate; drank it by bumpers,</li>
<li class="L5875" rel="L5875">looking at his friend.</li>
<li class="L5876" rel="L5876"></li>
<li class="L5877" rel="L5877">“Now you know all about it, Syd,” said Mr. Stryver. “I don&#39;t care about</li>
<li class="L5878" rel="L5878">fortune: she is a charming creature, and I have made up my mind to</li>
<li class="L5879" rel="L5879">please myself: on the whole, I think I can afford to please myself. She</li>
<li class="L5880" rel="L5880">will have in me a man already pretty well off, and a rapidly rising man,</li>
<li class="L5881" rel="L5881">and a man of some distinction: it is a piece of good fortune for her,</li>
<li class="L5882" rel="L5882">but she is worthy of good fortune. Are you astonished?”</li>
<li class="L5883" rel="L5883"></li>
<li class="L5884" rel="L5884">Carton, still drinking the punch, rejoined, “Why should I be</li>
<li class="L5885" rel="L5885">astonished?”</li>
<li class="L5886" rel="L5886"></li>
<li class="L5887" rel="L5887">“You approve?”</li>
<li class="L5888" rel="L5888"></li>
<li class="L5889" rel="L5889">Carton, still drinking the punch, rejoined, “Why should I not approve?”</li>
<li class="L5890" rel="L5890"></li>
<li class="L5891" rel="L5891">“Well!” said his friend Stryver, “you take it more easily than I fancied</li>
<li class="L5892" rel="L5892">you would, and are less mercenary on my behalf than I thought you would</li>
<li class="L5893" rel="L5893">be; though, to be sure, you know well enough by this time that your</li>
<li class="L5894" rel="L5894">ancient chum is a man of a pretty strong will. Yes, Sydney, I have had</li>
<li class="L5895" rel="L5895">enough of this style of life, with no other as a change from it; I</li>
<li class="L5896" rel="L5896">feel that it is a pleasant thing for a man to have a home when he feels</li>
<li class="L5897" rel="L5897">inclined to go to it (when he doesn&#39;t, he can stay away), and I feel</li>
<li class="L5898" rel="L5898">that Miss Manette will tell well in any station, and will always do me</li>
<li class="L5899" rel="L5899">credit. So I have made up my mind. And now, Sydney, old boy, I want to</li>
<li class="L5900" rel="L5900">say a word to _you_ about _your_ prospects. You are in a bad way, you</li>
<li class="L5901" rel="L5901">know; you really are in a bad way. You don&#39;t know the value of money,</li>
<li class="L5902" rel="L5902">you live hard, you&#39;ll knock up one of these days, and be ill and poor;</li>
<li class="L5903" rel="L5903">you really ought to think about a nurse.”</li>
<li class="L5904" rel="L5904"></li>
<li class="L5905" rel="L5905">The prosperous patronage with which he said it, made him look twice as</li>
<li class="L5906" rel="L5906">big as he was, and four times as offensive.</li>
<li class="L5907" rel="L5907"></li>
<li class="L5908" rel="L5908">“Now, let me recommend you,” pursued Stryver, “to look it in the face.</li>
<li class="L5909" rel="L5909">I have looked it in the face, in my different way; look it in the face,</li>
<li class="L5910" rel="L5910">you, in your different way. Marry. Provide somebody to take care of</li>
<li class="L5911" rel="L5911">you. Never mind your having no enjoyment of women&#39;s society, nor</li>
<li class="L5912" rel="L5912">understanding of it, nor tact for it. Find out somebody. Find out some</li>
<li class="L5913" rel="L5913">respectable woman with a little property--somebody in the landlady way,</li>
<li class="L5914" rel="L5914">or lodging-letting way--and marry her, against a rainy day. That&#39;s the</li>
<li class="L5915" rel="L5915">kind of thing for _you_. Now think of it, Sydney.”</li>
<li class="L5916" rel="L5916"></li>
<li class="L5917" rel="L5917">“I&#39;ll think of it,” said Sydney.</li>
<li class="L5918" rel="L5918"></li>
<li class="L5919" rel="L5919"></li>
<li class="L5920" rel="L5920"></li>
<li class="L5921" rel="L5921"></li>
<li class="L5922" rel="L5922">XII. The Fellow of Delicacy</li>
<li class="L5923" rel="L5923"></li>
<li class="L5924" rel="L5924"></li>
<li class="L5925" rel="L5925">Mr. Stryver having made up his mind to that magnanimous bestowal of good</li>
<li class="L5926" rel="L5926">fortune on the Doctor&#39;s daughter, resolved to make her happiness known</li>
<li class="L5927" rel="L5927">to her before he left town for the Long Vacation. After some mental</li>
<li class="L5928" rel="L5928">debating of the point, he came to the conclusion that it would be as</li>
<li class="L5929" rel="L5929">well to get all the preliminaries done with, and they could then arrange</li>
<li class="L5930" rel="L5930">at their leisure whether he should give her his hand a week or two</li>
<li class="L5931" rel="L5931">before Michaelmas Term, or in the little Christmas vacation between it</li>
<li class="L5932" rel="L5932">and Hilary.</li>
<li class="L5933" rel="L5933"></li>
<li class="L5934" rel="L5934">As to the strength of his case, he had not a doubt about it, but clearly</li>
<li class="L5935" rel="L5935">saw his way to the verdict. Argued with the jury on substantial worldly</li>
<li class="L5936" rel="L5936">grounds--the only grounds ever worth taking into account--it was a</li>
<li class="L5937" rel="L5937">plain case, and had not a weak spot in it. He called himself for the</li>
<li class="L5938" rel="L5938">plaintiff, there was no getting over his evidence, the counsel for</li>
<li class="L5939" rel="L5939">the defendant threw up his brief, and the jury did not even turn to</li>
<li class="L5940" rel="L5940">consider. After trying it, Stryver, C. J., was satisfied that no plainer</li>
<li class="L5941" rel="L5941">case could be.</li>
<li class="L5942" rel="L5942"></li>
<li class="L5943" rel="L5943">Accordingly, Mr. Stryver inaugurated the Long Vacation with a formal</li>
<li class="L5944" rel="L5944">proposal to take Miss Manette to Vauxhall Gardens; that failing, to</li>
<li class="L5945" rel="L5945">Ranelagh; that unaccountably failing too, it behoved him to present</li>
<li class="L5946" rel="L5946">himself in Soho, and there declare his noble mind.</li>
<li class="L5947" rel="L5947"></li>
<li class="L5948" rel="L5948">Towards Soho, therefore, Mr. Stryver shouldered his way from the Temple,</li>
<li class="L5949" rel="L5949">while the bloom of the Long Vacation&#39;s infancy was still upon it.</li>
<li class="L5950" rel="L5950">Anybody who had seen him projecting himself into Soho while he was yet</li>
<li class="L5951" rel="L5951">on Saint Dunstan&#39;s side of Temple Bar, bursting in his full-blown way</li>
<li class="L5952" rel="L5952">along the pavement, to the jostlement of all weaker people, might have</li>
<li class="L5953" rel="L5953">seen how safe and strong he was.</li>
<li class="L5954" rel="L5954"></li>
<li class="L5955" rel="L5955">His way taking him past Tellson&#39;s, and he both banking at Tellson&#39;s and</li>
<li class="L5956" rel="L5956">knowing Mr. Lorry as the intimate friend of the Manettes, it entered Mr.</li>
<li class="L5957" rel="L5957">Stryver&#39;s mind to enter the bank, and reveal to Mr. Lorry the brightness</li>
<li class="L5958" rel="L5958">of the Soho horizon. So, he pushed open the door with the weak rattle</li>
<li class="L5959" rel="L5959">in its throat, stumbled down the two steps, got past the two ancient</li>
<li class="L5960" rel="L5960">cashiers, and shouldered himself into the musty back closet where Mr.</li>
<li class="L5961" rel="L5961">Lorry sat at great books ruled for figures, with perpendicular iron</li>
<li class="L5962" rel="L5962">bars to his window as if that were ruled for figures too, and everything</li>
<li class="L5963" rel="L5963">under the clouds were a sum.</li>
<li class="L5964" rel="L5964"></li>
<li class="L5965" rel="L5965">“Halloa!” said Mr. Stryver. “How do you do? I hope you are well!”</li>
<li class="L5966" rel="L5966"></li>
<li class="L5967" rel="L5967">It was Stryver&#39;s grand peculiarity that he always seemed too big for any</li>
<li class="L5968" rel="L5968">place, or space. He was so much too big for Tellson&#39;s, that old clerks</li>
<li class="L5969" rel="L5969">in distant corners looked up with looks of remonstrance, as though he</li>
<li class="L5970" rel="L5970">squeezed them against the wall. The House itself, magnificently reading</li>
<li class="L5971" rel="L5971">the paper quite in the far-off perspective, lowered displeased, as if</li>
<li class="L5972" rel="L5972">the Stryver head had been butted into its responsible waistcoat.</li>
<li class="L5973" rel="L5973"></li>
<li class="L5974" rel="L5974">The discreet Mr. Lorry said, in a sample tone of the voice he would</li>
<li class="L5975" rel="L5975">recommend under the circumstances, “How do you do, Mr. Stryver? How do</li>
<li class="L5976" rel="L5976">you do, sir?” and shook hands. There was a peculiarity in his manner</li>
<li class="L5977" rel="L5977">of shaking hands, always to be seen in any clerk at Tellson&#39;s who shook</li>
<li class="L5978" rel="L5978">hands with a customer when the House pervaded the air. He shook in a</li>
<li class="L5979" rel="L5979">self-abnegating way, as one who shook for Tellson and Co.</li>
<li class="L5980" rel="L5980"></li>
<li class="L5981" rel="L5981">“Can I do anything for you, Mr. Stryver?” asked Mr. Lorry, in his</li>
<li class="L5982" rel="L5982">business character.</li>
<li class="L5983" rel="L5983"></li>
<li class="L5984" rel="L5984">“Why, no, thank you; this is a private visit to yourself, Mr. Lorry; I</li>
<li class="L5985" rel="L5985">have come for a private word.”</li>
<li class="L5986" rel="L5986"></li>
<li class="L5987" rel="L5987">“Oh indeed!” said Mr. Lorry, bending down his ear, while his eye strayed</li>
<li class="L5988" rel="L5988">to the House afar off.</li>
<li class="L5989" rel="L5989"></li>
<li class="L5990" rel="L5990">“I am going,” said Mr. Stryver, leaning his arms confidentially on the</li>
<li class="L5991" rel="L5991">desk: whereupon, although it was a large double one, there appeared to</li>
<li class="L5992" rel="L5992">be not half desk enough for him: “I am going to make an offer of myself</li>
<li class="L5993" rel="L5993">in marriage to your agreeable little friend, Miss Manette, Mr. Lorry.”</li>
<li class="L5994" rel="L5994"></li>
<li class="L5995" rel="L5995">“Oh dear me!” cried Mr. Lorry, rubbing his chin, and looking at his</li>
<li class="L5996" rel="L5996">visitor dubiously.</li>
<li class="L5997" rel="L5997"></li>
<li class="L5998" rel="L5998">“Oh dear me, sir?” repeated Stryver, drawing back. “Oh dear you, sir?</li>
<li class="L5999" rel="L5999">What may your meaning be, Mr. Lorry?”</li>
<li class="L6000" rel="L6000"></li>
<li class="L6001" rel="L6001">“My meaning,” answered the man of business, “is, of course, friendly and</li>
<li class="L6002" rel="L6002">appreciative, and that it does you the greatest credit, and--in short,</li>
<li class="L6003" rel="L6003">my meaning is everything you could desire. But--really, you know, Mr.</li>
<li class="L6004" rel="L6004">Stryver--” Mr. Lorry paused, and shook his head at him in the oddest</li>
<li class="L6005" rel="L6005">manner, as if he were compelled against his will to add, internally,</li>
<li class="L6006" rel="L6006">“you know there really is so much too much of you!”</li>
<li class="L6007" rel="L6007"></li>
<li class="L6008" rel="L6008">“Well!” said Stryver, slapping the desk with his contentious hand,</li>
<li class="L6009" rel="L6009">opening his eyes wider, and taking a long breath, “if I understand you,</li>
<li class="L6010" rel="L6010">Mr. Lorry, I&#39;ll be hanged!”</li>
<li class="L6011" rel="L6011"></li>
<li class="L6012" rel="L6012">Mr. Lorry adjusted his little wig at both ears as a means towards that</li>
<li class="L6013" rel="L6013">end, and bit the feather of a pen.</li>
<li class="L6014" rel="L6014"></li>
<li class="L6015" rel="L6015">“D--n it all, sir!” said Stryver, staring at him, “am I not eligible?”</li>
<li class="L6016" rel="L6016"></li>
<li class="L6017" rel="L6017">“Oh dear yes! Yes. Oh yes, you&#39;re eligible!” said Mr. Lorry. “If you say</li>
<li class="L6018" rel="L6018">eligible, you are eligible.”</li>
<li class="L6019" rel="L6019"></li>
<li class="L6020" rel="L6020">“Am I not prosperous?” asked Stryver.</li>
<li class="L6021" rel="L6021"></li>
<li class="L6022" rel="L6022">“Oh! if you come to prosperous, you are prosperous,” said Mr. Lorry.</li>
<li class="L6023" rel="L6023"></li>
<li class="L6024" rel="L6024">“And advancing?”</li>
<li class="L6025" rel="L6025"></li>
<li class="L6026" rel="L6026">“If you come to advancing you know,” said Mr. Lorry, delighted to be</li>
<li class="L6027" rel="L6027">able to make another admission, “nobody can doubt that.”</li>
<li class="L6028" rel="L6028"></li>
<li class="L6029" rel="L6029">“Then what on earth is your meaning, Mr. Lorry?” demanded Stryver,</li>
<li class="L6030" rel="L6030">perceptibly crestfallen.</li>
<li class="L6031" rel="L6031"></li>
<li class="L6032" rel="L6032">“Well! I--Were you going there now?” asked Mr. Lorry.</li>
<li class="L6033" rel="L6033"></li>
<li class="L6034" rel="L6034">“Straight!” said Stryver, with a plump of his fist on the desk.</li>
<li class="L6035" rel="L6035"></li>
<li class="L6036" rel="L6036">“Then I think I wouldn&#39;t, if I was you.”</li>
<li class="L6037" rel="L6037"></li>
<li class="L6038" rel="L6038">“Why?” said Stryver. “Now, I&#39;ll put you in a corner,” forensically</li>
<li class="L6039" rel="L6039">shaking a forefinger at him. “You are a man of business and bound to</li>
<li class="L6040" rel="L6040">have a reason. State your reason. Why wouldn&#39;t you go?”</li>
<li class="L6041" rel="L6041"></li>
<li class="L6042" rel="L6042">“Because,” said Mr. Lorry, “I wouldn&#39;t go on such an object without</li>
<li class="L6043" rel="L6043">having some cause to believe that I should succeed.”</li>
<li class="L6044" rel="L6044"></li>
<li class="L6045" rel="L6045">“D--n _me_!” cried Stryver, “but this beats everything.”</li>
<li class="L6046" rel="L6046"></li>
<li class="L6047" rel="L6047">Mr. Lorry glanced at the distant House, and glanced at the angry</li>
<li class="L6048" rel="L6048">Stryver.</li>
<li class="L6049" rel="L6049"></li>
<li class="L6050" rel="L6050">“Here&#39;s a man of business--a man of years--a man of experience--_in_</li>
<li class="L6051" rel="L6051">a Bank,” said Stryver; “and having summed up three leading reasons for</li>
<li class="L6052" rel="L6052">complete success, he says there&#39;s no reason at all! Says it with his</li>
<li class="L6053" rel="L6053">head on!” Mr. Stryver remarked upon the peculiarity as if it would have</li>
<li class="L6054" rel="L6054">been infinitely less remarkable if he had said it with his head off.</li>
<li class="L6055" rel="L6055"></li>
<li class="L6056" rel="L6056">“When I speak of success, I speak of success with the young lady; and</li>
<li class="L6057" rel="L6057">when I speak of causes and reasons to make success probable, I speak of</li>
<li class="L6058" rel="L6058">causes and reasons that will tell as such with the young lady. The young</li>
<li class="L6059" rel="L6059">lady, my good sir,” said Mr. Lorry, mildly tapping the Stryver arm, “the</li>
<li class="L6060" rel="L6060">young lady. The young lady goes before all.”</li>
<li class="L6061" rel="L6061"></li>
<li class="L6062" rel="L6062">“Then you mean to tell me, Mr. Lorry,” said Stryver, squaring his</li>
<li class="L6063" rel="L6063">elbows, “that it is your deliberate opinion that the young lady at</li>
<li class="L6064" rel="L6064">present in question is a mincing Fool?”</li>
<li class="L6065" rel="L6065"></li>
<li class="L6066" rel="L6066">“Not exactly so. I mean to tell you, Mr. Stryver,” said Mr. Lorry,</li>
<li class="L6067" rel="L6067">reddening, “that I will hear no disrespectful word of that young lady</li>
<li class="L6068" rel="L6068">from any lips; and that if I knew any man--which I hope I do not--whose</li>
<li class="L6069" rel="L6069">taste was so coarse, and whose temper was so overbearing, that he could</li>
<li class="L6070" rel="L6070">not restrain himself from speaking disrespectfully of that young lady at</li>
<li class="L6071" rel="L6071">this desk, not even Tellson&#39;s should prevent my giving him a piece of my</li>
<li class="L6072" rel="L6072">mind.”</li>
<li class="L6073" rel="L6073"></li>
<li class="L6074" rel="L6074">The necessity of being angry in a suppressed tone had put Mr. Stryver&#39;s</li>
<li class="L6075" rel="L6075">blood-vessels into a dangerous state when it was his turn to be angry;</li>
<li class="L6076" rel="L6076">Mr. Lorry&#39;s veins, methodical as their courses could usually be, were in</li>
<li class="L6077" rel="L6077">no better state now it was his turn.</li>
<li class="L6078" rel="L6078"></li>
<li class="L6079" rel="L6079">“That is what I mean to tell you, sir,” said Mr. Lorry. “Pray let there</li>
<li class="L6080" rel="L6080">be no mistake about it.”</li>
<li class="L6081" rel="L6081"></li>
<li class="L6082" rel="L6082">Mr. Stryver sucked the end of a ruler for a little while, and then stood</li>
<li class="L6083" rel="L6083">hitting a tune out of his teeth with it, which probably gave him the</li>
<li class="L6084" rel="L6084">toothache. He broke the awkward silence by saying:</li>
<li class="L6085" rel="L6085"></li>
<li class="L6086" rel="L6086">“This is something new to me, Mr. Lorry. You deliberately advise me not</li>
<li class="L6087" rel="L6087">to go up to Soho and offer myself--_my_self, Stryver of the King&#39;s Bench</li>
<li class="L6088" rel="L6088">bar?”</li>
<li class="L6089" rel="L6089"></li>
<li class="L6090" rel="L6090">“Do you ask me for my advice, Mr. Stryver?”</li>
<li class="L6091" rel="L6091"></li>
<li class="L6092" rel="L6092">“Yes, I do.”</li>
<li class="L6093" rel="L6093"></li>
<li class="L6094" rel="L6094">“Very good. Then I give it, and you have repeated it correctly.”</li>
<li class="L6095" rel="L6095"></li>
<li class="L6096" rel="L6096">“And all I can say of it is,” laughed Stryver with a vexed laugh, “that</li>
<li class="L6097" rel="L6097">this--ha, ha!--beats everything past, present, and to come.”</li>
<li class="L6098" rel="L6098"></li>
<li class="L6099" rel="L6099">“Now understand me,” pursued Mr. Lorry. “As a man of business, I am</li>
<li class="L6100" rel="L6100">not justified in saying anything about this matter, for, as a man of</li>
<li class="L6101" rel="L6101">business, I know nothing of it. But, as an old fellow, who has carried</li>
<li class="L6102" rel="L6102">Miss Manette in his arms, who is the trusted friend of Miss Manette and</li>
<li class="L6103" rel="L6103">of her father too, and who has a great affection for them both, I have</li>
<li class="L6104" rel="L6104">spoken. The confidence is not of my seeking, recollect. Now, you think I</li>
<li class="L6105" rel="L6105">may not be right?”</li>
<li class="L6106" rel="L6106"></li>
<li class="L6107" rel="L6107">“Not I!” said Stryver, whistling. “I can&#39;t undertake to find third</li>
<li class="L6108" rel="L6108">parties in common sense; I can only find it for myself. I suppose sense</li>
<li class="L6109" rel="L6109">in certain quarters; you suppose mincing bread-and-butter nonsense. It&#39;s</li>
<li class="L6110" rel="L6110">new to me, but you are right, I dare say.”</li>
<li class="L6111" rel="L6111"></li>
<li class="L6112" rel="L6112">“What I suppose, Mr. Stryver, I claim to characterise for myself--And</li>
<li class="L6113" rel="L6113">understand me, sir,” said Mr. Lorry, quickly flushing again, “I</li>
<li class="L6114" rel="L6114">will not--not even at Tellson&#39;s--have it characterised for me by any</li>
<li class="L6115" rel="L6115">gentleman breathing.”</li>
<li class="L6116" rel="L6116"></li>
<li class="L6117" rel="L6117">“There! I beg your pardon!” said Stryver.</li>
<li class="L6118" rel="L6118"></li>
<li class="L6119" rel="L6119">“Granted. Thank you. Well, Mr. Stryver, I was about to say:--it might be</li>
<li class="L6120" rel="L6120">painful to you to find yourself mistaken, it might be painful to Doctor</li>
<li class="L6121" rel="L6121">Manette to have the task of being explicit with you, it might be very</li>
<li class="L6122" rel="L6122">painful to Miss Manette to have the task of being explicit with you. You</li>
<li class="L6123" rel="L6123">know the terms upon which I have the honour and happiness to stand with</li>
<li class="L6124" rel="L6124">the family. If you please, committing you in no way, representing you</li>
<li class="L6125" rel="L6125">in no way, I will undertake to correct my advice by the exercise of a</li>
<li class="L6126" rel="L6126">little new observation and judgment expressly brought to bear upon</li>
<li class="L6127" rel="L6127">it. If you should then be dissatisfied with it, you can but test its</li>
<li class="L6128" rel="L6128">soundness for yourself; if, on the other hand, you should be satisfied</li>
<li class="L6129" rel="L6129">with it, and it should be what it now is, it may spare all sides what is</li>
<li class="L6130" rel="L6130">best spared. What do you say?”</li>
<li class="L6131" rel="L6131"></li>
<li class="L6132" rel="L6132">“How long would you keep me in town?”</li>
<li class="L6133" rel="L6133"></li>
<li class="L6134" rel="L6134">“Oh! It is only a question of a few hours. I could go to Soho in the</li>
<li class="L6135" rel="L6135">evening, and come to your chambers afterwards.”</li>
<li class="L6136" rel="L6136"></li>
<li class="L6137" rel="L6137">“Then I say yes,” said Stryver: “I won&#39;t go up there now, I am not so</li>
<li class="L6138" rel="L6138">hot upon it as that comes to; I say yes, and I shall expect you to look</li>
<li class="L6139" rel="L6139">in to-night. Good morning.”</li>
<li class="L6140" rel="L6140"></li>
<li class="L6141" rel="L6141">Then Mr. Stryver turned and burst out of the Bank, causing such a</li>
<li class="L6142" rel="L6142">concussion of air on his passage through, that to stand up against it</li>
<li class="L6143" rel="L6143">bowing behind the two counters, required the utmost remaining strength</li>
<li class="L6144" rel="L6144">of the two ancient clerks. Those venerable and feeble persons were</li>
<li class="L6145" rel="L6145">always seen by the public in the act of bowing, and were popularly</li>
<li class="L6146" rel="L6146">believed, when they had bowed a customer out, still to keep on bowing in</li>
<li class="L6147" rel="L6147">the empty office until they bowed another customer in.</li>
<li class="L6148" rel="L6148"></li>
<li class="L6149" rel="L6149">The barrister was keen enough to divine that the banker would not have</li>
<li class="L6150" rel="L6150">gone so far in his expression of opinion on any less solid ground than</li>
<li class="L6151" rel="L6151">moral certainty. Unprepared as he was for the large pill he had to</li>
<li class="L6152" rel="L6152">swallow, he got it down. “And now,” said Mr. Stryver, shaking his</li>
<li class="L6153" rel="L6153">forensic forefinger at the Temple in general, when it was down, “my way</li>
<li class="L6154" rel="L6154">out of this, is, to put you all in the wrong.”</li>
<li class="L6155" rel="L6155"></li>
<li class="L6156" rel="L6156">It was a bit of the art of an Old Bailey tactician, in which he found</li>
<li class="L6157" rel="L6157">great relief. “You shall not put me in the wrong, young lady,” said Mr.</li>
<li class="L6158" rel="L6158">Stryver; “I&#39;ll do that for you.”</li>
<li class="L6159" rel="L6159"></li>
<li class="L6160" rel="L6160">Accordingly, when Mr. Lorry called that night as late as ten o&#39;clock,</li>
<li class="L6161" rel="L6161">Mr. Stryver, among a quantity of books and papers littered out for the</li>
<li class="L6162" rel="L6162">purpose, seemed to have nothing less on his mind than the subject of</li>
<li class="L6163" rel="L6163">the morning. He even showed surprise when he saw Mr. Lorry, and was</li>
<li class="L6164" rel="L6164">altogether in an absent and preoccupied state.</li>
<li class="L6165" rel="L6165"></li>
<li class="L6166" rel="L6166">“Well!” said that good-natured emissary, after a full half-hour of</li>
<li class="L6167" rel="L6167">bootless attempts to bring him round to the question. “I have been to</li>
<li class="L6168" rel="L6168">Soho.”</li>
<li class="L6169" rel="L6169"></li>
<li class="L6170" rel="L6170">“To Soho?” repeated Mr. Stryver, coldly. “Oh, to be sure! What am I</li>
<li class="L6171" rel="L6171">thinking of!”</li>
<li class="L6172" rel="L6172"></li>
<li class="L6173" rel="L6173">“And I have no doubt,” said Mr. Lorry, “that I was right in the</li>
<li class="L6174" rel="L6174">conversation we had. My opinion is confirmed, and I reiterate my</li>
<li class="L6175" rel="L6175">advice.”</li>
<li class="L6176" rel="L6176"></li>
<li class="L6177" rel="L6177">“I assure you,” returned Mr. Stryver, in the friendliest way, “that I</li>
<li class="L6178" rel="L6178">am sorry for it on your account, and sorry for it on the poor father&#39;s</li>
<li class="L6179" rel="L6179">account. I know this must always be a sore subject with the family; let</li>
<li class="L6180" rel="L6180">us say no more about it.”</li>
<li class="L6181" rel="L6181"></li>
<li class="L6182" rel="L6182">“I don&#39;t understand you,” said Mr. Lorry.</li>
<li class="L6183" rel="L6183"></li>
<li class="L6184" rel="L6184">“I dare say not,” rejoined Stryver, nodding his head in a smoothing and</li>
<li class="L6185" rel="L6185">final way; “no matter, no matter.”</li>
<li class="L6186" rel="L6186"></li>
<li class="L6187" rel="L6187">“But it does matter,” Mr. Lorry urged.</li>
<li class="L6188" rel="L6188"></li>
<li class="L6189" rel="L6189">“No it doesn&#39;t; I assure you it doesn&#39;t. Having supposed that there was</li>
<li class="L6190" rel="L6190">sense where there is no sense, and a laudable ambition where there is</li>
<li class="L6191" rel="L6191">not a laudable ambition, I am well out of my mistake, and no harm is</li>
<li class="L6192" rel="L6192">done. Young women have committed similar follies often before, and have</li>
<li class="L6193" rel="L6193">repented them in poverty and obscurity often before. In an unselfish</li>
<li class="L6194" rel="L6194">aspect, I am sorry that the thing is dropped, because it would have been</li>
<li class="L6195" rel="L6195">a bad thing for me in a worldly point of view; in a selfish aspect, I am</li>
<li class="L6196" rel="L6196">glad that the thing has dropped, because it would have been a bad thing</li>
<li class="L6197" rel="L6197">for me in a worldly point of view--it is hardly necessary to say I could</li>
<li class="L6198" rel="L6198">have gained nothing by it. There is no harm at all done. I have not</li>
<li class="L6199" rel="L6199">proposed to the young lady, and, between ourselves, I am by no means</li>
<li class="L6200" rel="L6200">certain, on reflection, that I ever should have committed myself to</li>
<li class="L6201" rel="L6201">that extent. Mr. Lorry, you cannot control the mincing vanities and</li>
<li class="L6202" rel="L6202">giddinesses of empty-headed girls; you must not expect to do it, or you</li>
<li class="L6203" rel="L6203">will always be disappointed. Now, pray say no more about it. I tell you,</li>
<li class="L6204" rel="L6204">I regret it on account of others, but I am satisfied on my own account.</li>
<li class="L6205" rel="L6205">And I am really very much obliged to you for allowing me to sound you,</li>
<li class="L6206" rel="L6206">and for giving me your advice; you know the young lady better than I do;</li>
<li class="L6207" rel="L6207">you were right, it never would have done.”</li>
<li class="L6208" rel="L6208"></li>
<li class="L6209" rel="L6209">Mr. Lorry was so taken aback, that he looked quite stupidly at Mr.</li>
<li class="L6210" rel="L6210">Stryver shouldering him towards the door, with an appearance of</li>
<li class="L6211" rel="L6211">showering generosity, forbearance, and goodwill, on his erring head.</li>
<li class="L6212" rel="L6212">“Make the best of it, my dear sir,” said Stryver; “say no more about it;</li>
<li class="L6213" rel="L6213">thank you again for allowing me to sound you; good night!”</li>
<li class="L6214" rel="L6214"></li>
<li class="L6215" rel="L6215">Mr. Lorry was out in the night, before he knew where he was. Mr. Stryver</li>
<li class="L6216" rel="L6216">was lying back on his sofa, winking at his ceiling.</li>
<li class="L6217" rel="L6217"></li>
<li class="L6218" rel="L6218"></li>
<li class="L6219" rel="L6219"></li>
<li class="L6220" rel="L6220"></li>
<li class="L6221" rel="L6221">XIII. The Fellow of No Delicacy</li>
<li class="L6222" rel="L6222"></li>
<li class="L6223" rel="L6223"></li>
<li class="L6224" rel="L6224">If Sydney Carton ever shone anywhere, he certainly never shone in the</li>
<li class="L6225" rel="L6225">house of Doctor Manette. He had been there often, during a whole year,</li>
<li class="L6226" rel="L6226">and had always been the same moody and morose lounger there. When he</li>
<li class="L6227" rel="L6227">cared to talk, he talked well; but, the cloud of caring for nothing,</li>
<li class="L6228" rel="L6228">which overshadowed him with such a fatal darkness, was very rarely</li>
<li class="L6229" rel="L6229">pierced by the light within him.</li>
<li class="L6230" rel="L6230"></li>
<li class="L6231" rel="L6231">And yet he did care something for the streets that environed that house,</li>
<li class="L6232" rel="L6232">and for the senseless stones that made their pavements. Many a night</li>
<li class="L6233" rel="L6233">he vaguely and unhappily wandered there, when wine had brought no</li>
<li class="L6234" rel="L6234">transitory gladness to him; many a dreary daybreak revealed his solitary</li>
<li class="L6235" rel="L6235">figure lingering there, and still lingering there when the first beams</li>
<li class="L6236" rel="L6236">of the sun brought into strong relief, removed beauties of architecture</li>
<li class="L6237" rel="L6237">in spires of churches and lofty buildings, as perhaps the quiet time</li>
<li class="L6238" rel="L6238">brought some sense of better things, else forgotten and unattainable,</li>
<li class="L6239" rel="L6239">into his mind. Of late, the neglected bed in the Temple Court had known</li>
<li class="L6240" rel="L6240">him more scantily than ever; and often when he had thrown himself upon</li>
<li class="L6241" rel="L6241">it no longer than a few minutes, he had got up again, and haunted that</li>
<li class="L6242" rel="L6242">neighbourhood.</li>
<li class="L6243" rel="L6243"></li>
<li class="L6244" rel="L6244">On a day in August, when Mr. Stryver (after notifying to his jackal</li>
<li class="L6245" rel="L6245">that “he had thought better of that marrying matter”) had carried his</li>
<li class="L6246" rel="L6246">delicacy into Devonshire, and when the sight and scent of flowers in the</li>
<li class="L6247" rel="L6247">City streets had some waifs of goodness in them for the worst, of health</li>
<li class="L6248" rel="L6248">for the sickliest, and of youth for the oldest, Sydney&#39;s feet still trod</li>
<li class="L6249" rel="L6249">those stones. From being irresolute and purposeless, his feet became</li>
<li class="L6250" rel="L6250">animated by an intention, and, in the working out of that intention,</li>
<li class="L6251" rel="L6251">they took him to the Doctor&#39;s door.</li>
<li class="L6252" rel="L6252"></li>
<li class="L6253" rel="L6253">He was shown up-stairs, and found Lucie at her work, alone. She had</li>
<li class="L6254" rel="L6254">never been quite at her ease with him, and received him with some little</li>
<li class="L6255" rel="L6255">embarrassment as he seated himself near her table. But, looking up at</li>
<li class="L6256" rel="L6256">his face in the interchange of the first few common-places, she observed</li>
<li class="L6257" rel="L6257">a change in it.</li>
<li class="L6258" rel="L6258"></li>
<li class="L6259" rel="L6259">“I fear you are not well, Mr. Carton!”</li>
<li class="L6260" rel="L6260"></li>
<li class="L6261" rel="L6261">“No. But the life I lead, Miss Manette, is not conducive to health. What</li>
<li class="L6262" rel="L6262">is to be expected of, or by, such profligates?”</li>
<li class="L6263" rel="L6263"></li>
<li class="L6264" rel="L6264">“Is it not--forgive me; I have begun the question on my lips--a pity to</li>
<li class="L6265" rel="L6265">live no better life?”</li>
<li class="L6266" rel="L6266"></li>
<li class="L6267" rel="L6267">“God knows it is a shame!”</li>
<li class="L6268" rel="L6268"></li>
<li class="L6269" rel="L6269">“Then why not change it?”</li>
<li class="L6270" rel="L6270"></li>
<li class="L6271" rel="L6271">Looking gently at him again, she was surprised and saddened to see that</li>
<li class="L6272" rel="L6272">there were tears in his eyes. There were tears in his voice too, as he</li>
<li class="L6273" rel="L6273">answered:</li>
<li class="L6274" rel="L6274"></li>
<li class="L6275" rel="L6275">“It is too late for that. I shall never be better than I am. I shall</li>
<li class="L6276" rel="L6276">sink lower, and be worse.”</li>
<li class="L6277" rel="L6277"></li>
<li class="L6278" rel="L6278">He leaned an elbow on her table, and covered his eyes with his hand. The</li>
<li class="L6279" rel="L6279">table trembled in the silence that followed.</li>
<li class="L6280" rel="L6280"></li>
<li class="L6281" rel="L6281">She had never seen him softened, and was much distressed. He knew her to</li>
<li class="L6282" rel="L6282">be so, without looking at her, and said:</li>
<li class="L6283" rel="L6283"></li>
<li class="L6284" rel="L6284">“Pray forgive me, Miss Manette. I break down before the knowledge of</li>
<li class="L6285" rel="L6285">what I want to say to you. Will you hear me?”</li>
<li class="L6286" rel="L6286"></li>
<li class="L6287" rel="L6287">“If it will do you any good, Mr. Carton, if it would make you happier,</li>
<li class="L6288" rel="L6288">it would make me very glad!”</li>
<li class="L6289" rel="L6289"></li>
<li class="L6290" rel="L6290">“God bless you for your sweet compassion!”</li>
<li class="L6291" rel="L6291"></li>
<li class="L6292" rel="L6292">He unshaded his face after a little while, and spoke steadily.</li>
<li class="L6293" rel="L6293"></li>
<li class="L6294" rel="L6294">“Don&#39;t be afraid to hear me. Don&#39;t shrink from anything I say. I am like</li>
<li class="L6295" rel="L6295">one who died young. All my life might have been.”</li>
<li class="L6296" rel="L6296"></li>
<li class="L6297" rel="L6297">“No, Mr. Carton. I am sure that the best part of it might still be; I am</li>
<li class="L6298" rel="L6298">sure that you might be much, much worthier of yourself.”</li>
<li class="L6299" rel="L6299"></li>
<li class="L6300" rel="L6300">“Say of you, Miss Manette, and although I know better--although in the</li>
<li class="L6301" rel="L6301">mystery of my own wretched heart I know better--I shall never forget</li>
<li class="L6302" rel="L6302">it!”</li>
<li class="L6303" rel="L6303"></li>
<li class="L6304" rel="L6304">She was pale and trembling. He came to her relief with a fixed despair</li>
<li class="L6305" rel="L6305">of himself which made the interview unlike any other that could have</li>
<li class="L6306" rel="L6306">been holden.</li>
<li class="L6307" rel="L6307"></li>
<li class="L6308" rel="L6308">“If it had been possible, Miss Manette, that you could have returned the</li>
<li class="L6309" rel="L6309">love of the man you see before yourself--flung away, wasted, drunken,</li>
<li class="L6310" rel="L6310">poor creature of misuse as you know him to be--he would have been</li>
<li class="L6311" rel="L6311">conscious this day and hour, in spite of his happiness, that he would</li>
<li class="L6312" rel="L6312">bring you to misery, bring you to sorrow and repentance, blight you,</li>
<li class="L6313" rel="L6313">disgrace you, pull you down with him. I know very well that you can have</li>
<li class="L6314" rel="L6314">no tenderness for me; I ask for none; I am even thankful that it cannot</li>
<li class="L6315" rel="L6315">be.”</li>
<li class="L6316" rel="L6316"></li>
<li class="L6317" rel="L6317">“Without it, can I not save you, Mr. Carton? Can I not recall</li>
<li class="L6318" rel="L6318">you--forgive me again!--to a better course? Can I in no way repay your</li>
<li class="L6319" rel="L6319">confidence? I know this is a confidence,” she modestly said, after a</li>
<li class="L6320" rel="L6320">little hesitation, and in earnest tears, “I know you would say this to</li>
<li class="L6321" rel="L6321">no one else. Can I turn it to no good account for yourself, Mr. Carton?”</li>
<li class="L6322" rel="L6322"></li>
<li class="L6323" rel="L6323">He shook his head.</li>
<li class="L6324" rel="L6324"></li>
<li class="L6325" rel="L6325">“To none. No, Miss Manette, to none. If you will hear me through a very</li>
<li class="L6326" rel="L6326">little more, all you can ever do for me is done. I wish you to know that</li>
<li class="L6327" rel="L6327">you have been the last dream of my soul. In my degradation I have not</li>
<li class="L6328" rel="L6328">been so degraded but that the sight of you with your father, and of this</li>
<li class="L6329" rel="L6329">home made such a home by you, has stirred old shadows that I thought had</li>
<li class="L6330" rel="L6330">died out of me. Since I knew you, I have been troubled by a remorse that</li>
<li class="L6331" rel="L6331">I thought would never reproach me again, and have heard whispers from</li>
<li class="L6332" rel="L6332">old voices impelling me upward, that I thought were silent for ever. I</li>
<li class="L6333" rel="L6333">have had unformed ideas of striving afresh, beginning anew, shaking off</li>
<li class="L6334" rel="L6334">sloth and sensuality, and fighting out the abandoned fight. A dream, all</li>
<li class="L6335" rel="L6335">a dream, that ends in nothing, and leaves the sleeper where he lay down,</li>
<li class="L6336" rel="L6336">but I wish you to know that you inspired it.”</li>
<li class="L6337" rel="L6337"></li>
<li class="L6338" rel="L6338">“Will nothing of it remain? O Mr. Carton, think again! Try again!”</li>
<li class="L6339" rel="L6339"></li>
<li class="L6340" rel="L6340">“No, Miss Manette; all through it, I have known myself to be quite</li>
<li class="L6341" rel="L6341">undeserving. And yet I have had the weakness, and have still the</li>
<li class="L6342" rel="L6342">weakness, to wish you to know with what a sudden mastery you kindled me,</li>
<li class="L6343" rel="L6343">heap of ashes that I am, into fire--a fire, however, inseparable in</li>
<li class="L6344" rel="L6344">its nature from myself, quickening nothing, lighting nothing, doing no</li>
<li class="L6345" rel="L6345">service, idly burning away.”</li>
<li class="L6346" rel="L6346"></li>
<li class="L6347" rel="L6347">“Since it is my misfortune, Mr. Carton, to have made you more unhappy</li>
<li class="L6348" rel="L6348">than you were before you knew me--”</li>
<li class="L6349" rel="L6349"></li>
<li class="L6350" rel="L6350">“Don&#39;t say that, Miss Manette, for you would have reclaimed me, if</li>
<li class="L6351" rel="L6351">anything could. You will not be the cause of my becoming worse.”</li>
<li class="L6352" rel="L6352"></li>
<li class="L6353" rel="L6353">“Since the state of your mind that you describe, is, at all events,</li>
<li class="L6354" rel="L6354">attributable to some influence of mine--this is what I mean, if I can</li>
<li class="L6355" rel="L6355">make it plain--can I use no influence to serve you? Have I no power for</li>
<li class="L6356" rel="L6356">good, with you, at all?”</li>
<li class="L6357" rel="L6357"></li>
<li class="L6358" rel="L6358">“The utmost good that I am capable of now, Miss Manette, I have come</li>
<li class="L6359" rel="L6359">here to realise. Let me carry through the rest of my misdirected life,</li>
<li class="L6360" rel="L6360">the remembrance that I opened my heart to you, last of all the world;</li>
<li class="L6361" rel="L6361">and that there was something left in me at this time which you could</li>
<li class="L6362" rel="L6362">deplore and pity.”</li>
<li class="L6363" rel="L6363"></li>
<li class="L6364" rel="L6364">“Which I entreated you to believe, again and again, most fervently, with</li>
<li class="L6365" rel="L6365">all my heart, was capable of better things, Mr. Carton!”</li>
<li class="L6366" rel="L6366"></li>
<li class="L6367" rel="L6367">“Entreat me to believe it no more, Miss Manette. I have proved myself,</li>
<li class="L6368" rel="L6368">and I know better. I distress you; I draw fast to an end. Will you let</li>
<li class="L6369" rel="L6369">me believe, when I recall this day, that the last confidence of my life</li>
<li class="L6370" rel="L6370">was reposed in your pure and innocent breast, and that it lies there</li>
<li class="L6371" rel="L6371">alone, and will be shared by no one?”</li>
<li class="L6372" rel="L6372"></li>
<li class="L6373" rel="L6373">“If that will be a consolation to you, yes.”</li>
<li class="L6374" rel="L6374"></li>
<li class="L6375" rel="L6375">“Not even by the dearest one ever to be known to you?”</li>
<li class="L6376" rel="L6376"></li>
<li class="L6377" rel="L6377">“Mr. Carton,” she answered, after an agitated pause, “the secret is</li>
<li class="L6378" rel="L6378">yours, not mine; and I promise to respect it.”</li>
<li class="L6379" rel="L6379"></li>
<li class="L6380" rel="L6380">“Thank you. And again, God bless you.”</li>
<li class="L6381" rel="L6381"></li>
<li class="L6382" rel="L6382">He put her hand to his lips, and moved towards the door.</li>
<li class="L6383" rel="L6383"></li>
<li class="L6384" rel="L6384">“Be under no apprehension, Miss Manette, of my ever resuming this</li>
<li class="L6385" rel="L6385">conversation by so much as a passing word. I will never refer to it</li>
<li class="L6386" rel="L6386">again. If I were dead, that could not be surer than it is henceforth. In</li>
<li class="L6387" rel="L6387">the hour of my death, I shall hold sacred the one good remembrance--and</li>
<li class="L6388" rel="L6388">shall thank and bless you for it--that my last avowal of myself was made</li>
<li class="L6389" rel="L6389">to you, and that my name, and faults, and miseries were gently carried</li>
<li class="L6390" rel="L6390">in your heart. May it otherwise be light and happy!”</li>
<li class="L6391" rel="L6391"></li>
<li class="L6392" rel="L6392">He was so unlike what he had ever shown himself to be, and it was so</li>
<li class="L6393" rel="L6393">sad to think how much he had thrown away, and how much he every day kept</li>
<li class="L6394" rel="L6394">down and perverted, that Lucie Manette wept mournfully for him as he</li>
<li class="L6395" rel="L6395">stood looking back at her.</li>
<li class="L6396" rel="L6396"></li>
<li class="L6397" rel="L6397">“Be comforted!” he said, “I am not worth such feeling, Miss Manette. An</li>
<li class="L6398" rel="L6398">hour or two hence, and the low companions and low habits that I scorn</li>
<li class="L6399" rel="L6399">but yield to, will render me less worth such tears as those, than any</li>
<li class="L6400" rel="L6400">wretch who creeps along the streets. Be comforted! But, within myself, I</li>
<li class="L6401" rel="L6401">shall always be, towards you, what I am now, though outwardly I shall be</li>
<li class="L6402" rel="L6402">what you have heretofore seen me. The last supplication but one I make</li>
<li class="L6403" rel="L6403">to you, is, that you will believe this of me.”</li>
<li class="L6404" rel="L6404"></li>
<li class="L6405" rel="L6405">“I will, Mr. Carton.”</li>
<li class="L6406" rel="L6406"></li>
<li class="L6407" rel="L6407">“My last supplication of all, is this; and with it, I will relieve</li>
<li class="L6408" rel="L6408">you of a visitor with whom I well know you have nothing in unison, and</li>
<li class="L6409" rel="L6409">between whom and you there is an impassable space. It is useless to say</li>
<li class="L6410" rel="L6410">it, I know, but it rises out of my soul. For you, and for any dear to</li>
<li class="L6411" rel="L6411">you, I would do anything. If my career were of that better kind that</li>
<li class="L6412" rel="L6412">there was any opportunity or capacity of sacrifice in it, I would</li>
<li class="L6413" rel="L6413">embrace any sacrifice for you and for those dear to you. Try to hold</li>
<li class="L6414" rel="L6414">me in your mind, at some quiet times, as ardent and sincere in this one</li>
<li class="L6415" rel="L6415">thing. The time will come, the time will not be long in coming, when new</li>
<li class="L6416" rel="L6416">ties will be formed about you--ties that will bind you yet more tenderly</li>
<li class="L6417" rel="L6417">and strongly to the home you so adorn--the dearest ties that will ever</li>
<li class="L6418" rel="L6418">grace and gladden you. O Miss Manette, when the little picture of a</li>
<li class="L6419" rel="L6419">happy father&#39;s face looks up in yours, when you see your own bright</li>
<li class="L6420" rel="L6420">beauty springing up anew at your feet, think now and then that there is</li>
<li class="L6421" rel="L6421">a man who would give his life, to keep a life you love beside you!”</li>
<li class="L6422" rel="L6422"></li>
<li class="L6423" rel="L6423">He said, “Farewell!” said a last “God bless you!” and left her.</li>
<li class="L6424" rel="L6424"></li>
<li class="L6425" rel="L6425"></li>
<li class="L6426" rel="L6426"></li>
<li class="L6427" rel="L6427"></li>
<li class="L6428" rel="L6428">XIV. The Honest Tradesman</li>
<li class="L6429" rel="L6429"></li>
<li class="L6430" rel="L6430"></li>
<li class="L6431" rel="L6431">To the eyes of Mr. Jeremiah Cruncher, sitting on his stool in</li>
<li class="L6432" rel="L6432">Fleet-street with his grisly urchin beside him, a vast number and</li>
<li class="L6433" rel="L6433">variety of objects in movement were every day presented. Who could sit</li>
<li class="L6434" rel="L6434">upon anything in Fleet-street during the busy hours of the day, and</li>
<li class="L6435" rel="L6435">not be dazed and deafened by two immense processions, one ever tending</li>
<li class="L6436" rel="L6436">westward with the sun, the other ever tending eastward from the sun,</li>
<li class="L6437" rel="L6437">both ever tending to the plains beyond the range of red and purple where</li>
<li class="L6438" rel="L6438">the sun goes down!</li>
<li class="L6439" rel="L6439"></li>
<li class="L6440" rel="L6440">With his straw in his mouth, Mr. Cruncher sat watching the two streams,</li>
<li class="L6441" rel="L6441">like the heathen rustic who has for several centuries been on duty</li>
<li class="L6442" rel="L6442">watching one stream--saving that Jerry had no expectation of their ever</li>
<li class="L6443" rel="L6443">running dry. Nor would it have been an expectation of a hopeful kind,</li>
<li class="L6444" rel="L6444">since a small part of his income was derived from the pilotage of timid</li>
<li class="L6445" rel="L6445">women (mostly of a full habit and past the middle term of life) from</li>
<li class="L6446" rel="L6446">Tellson&#39;s side of the tides to the opposite shore. Brief as such</li>
<li class="L6447" rel="L6447">companionship was in every separate instance, Mr. Cruncher never failed</li>
<li class="L6448" rel="L6448">to become so interested in the lady as to express a strong desire to</li>
<li class="L6449" rel="L6449">have the honour of drinking her very good health. And it was from</li>
<li class="L6450" rel="L6450">the gifts bestowed upon him towards the execution of this benevolent</li>
<li class="L6451" rel="L6451">purpose, that he recruited his finances, as just now observed.</li>
<li class="L6452" rel="L6452"></li>
<li class="L6453" rel="L6453">Time was, when a poet sat upon a stool in a public place, and mused in</li>
<li class="L6454" rel="L6454">the sight of men. Mr. Cruncher, sitting on a stool in a public place,</li>
<li class="L6455" rel="L6455">but not being a poet, mused as little as possible, and looked about him.</li>
<li class="L6456" rel="L6456"></li>
<li class="L6457" rel="L6457">It fell out that he was thus engaged in a season when crowds were</li>
<li class="L6458" rel="L6458">few, and belated women few, and when his affairs in general were so</li>
<li class="L6459" rel="L6459">unprosperous as to awaken a strong suspicion in his breast that Mrs.</li>
<li class="L6460" rel="L6460">Cruncher must have been “flopping” in some pointed manner, when an</li>
<li class="L6461" rel="L6461">unusual concourse pouring down Fleet-street westward, attracted his</li>
<li class="L6462" rel="L6462">attention. Looking that way, Mr. Cruncher made out that some kind of</li>
<li class="L6463" rel="L6463">funeral was coming along, and that there was popular objection to this</li>
<li class="L6464" rel="L6464">funeral, which engendered uproar.</li>
<li class="L6465" rel="L6465"></li>
<li class="L6466" rel="L6466">“Young Jerry,” said Mr. Cruncher, turning to his offspring, “it&#39;s a</li>
<li class="L6467" rel="L6467">buryin&#39;.”</li>
<li class="L6468" rel="L6468"></li>
<li class="L6469" rel="L6469">“Hooroar, father!” cried Young Jerry.</li>
<li class="L6470" rel="L6470"></li>
<li class="L6471" rel="L6471">The young gentleman uttered this exultant sound with mysterious</li>
<li class="L6472" rel="L6472">significance. The elder gentleman took the cry so ill, that he watched</li>
<li class="L6473" rel="L6473">his opportunity, and smote the young gentleman on the ear.</li>
<li class="L6474" rel="L6474"></li>
<li class="L6475" rel="L6475">“What d&#39;ye mean? What are you hooroaring at? What do you want to conwey</li>
<li class="L6476" rel="L6476">to your own father, you young Rip? This boy is a getting too many for</li>
<li class="L6477" rel="L6477">_me_!” said Mr. Cruncher, surveying him. “Him and his hooroars! Don&#39;t</li>
<li class="L6478" rel="L6478">let me hear no more of you, or you shall feel some more of me. D&#39;ye</li>
<li class="L6479" rel="L6479">hear?”</li>
<li class="L6480" rel="L6480"></li>
<li class="L6481" rel="L6481">“I warn&#39;t doing no harm,” Young Jerry protested, rubbing his cheek.</li>
<li class="L6482" rel="L6482"></li>
<li class="L6483" rel="L6483">“Drop it then,” said Mr. Cruncher; “I won&#39;t have none of _your_ no</li>
<li class="L6484" rel="L6484">harms. Get a top of that there seat, and look at the crowd.”</li>
<li class="L6485" rel="L6485"></li>
<li class="L6486" rel="L6486">His son obeyed, and the crowd approached; they were bawling and hissing</li>
<li class="L6487" rel="L6487">round a dingy hearse and dingy mourning coach, in which mourning coach</li>
<li class="L6488" rel="L6488">there was only one mourner, dressed in the dingy trappings that were</li>
<li class="L6489" rel="L6489">considered essential to the dignity of the position. The position</li>
<li class="L6490" rel="L6490">appeared by no means to please him, however, with an increasing rabble</li>
<li class="L6491" rel="L6491">surrounding the coach, deriding him, making grimaces at him, and</li>
<li class="L6492" rel="L6492">incessantly groaning and calling out: “Yah! Spies! Tst! Yaha! Spies!”</li>
<li class="L6493" rel="L6493"> with many compliments too numerous and forcible to repeat.</li>
<li class="L6494" rel="L6494"></li>
<li class="L6495" rel="L6495">Funerals had at all times a remarkable attraction for Mr. Cruncher; he</li>
<li class="L6496" rel="L6496">always pricked up his senses, and became excited, when a funeral passed</li>
<li class="L6497" rel="L6497">Tellson&#39;s. Naturally, therefore, a funeral with this uncommon attendance</li>
<li class="L6498" rel="L6498">excited him greatly, and he asked of the first man who ran against him:</li>
<li class="L6499" rel="L6499"></li>
<li class="L6500" rel="L6500">“What is it, brother? What&#39;s it about?”</li>
<li class="L6501" rel="L6501"></li>
<li class="L6502" rel="L6502">“_I_ don&#39;t know,” said the man. “Spies! Yaha! Tst! Spies!”</li>
<li class="L6503" rel="L6503"></li>
<li class="L6504" rel="L6504">He asked another man. “Who is it?”</li>
<li class="L6505" rel="L6505"></li>
<li class="L6506" rel="L6506">“_I_ don&#39;t know,” returned the man, clapping his hands to his mouth</li>
<li class="L6507" rel="L6507">nevertheless, and vociferating in a surprising heat and with the</li>
<li class="L6508" rel="L6508">greatest ardour, “Spies! Yaha! Tst, tst! Spi--ies!”</li>
<li class="L6509" rel="L6509"></li>
<li class="L6510" rel="L6510">At length, a person better informed on the merits of the case, tumbled</li>
<li class="L6511" rel="L6511">against him, and from this person he learned that the funeral was the</li>
<li class="L6512" rel="L6512">funeral of one Roger Cly.</li>
<li class="L6513" rel="L6513"></li>
<li class="L6514" rel="L6514">“Was he a spy?” asked Mr. Cruncher.</li>
<li class="L6515" rel="L6515"></li>
<li class="L6516" rel="L6516">“Old Bailey spy,” returned his informant. “Yaha! Tst! Yah! Old Bailey</li>
<li class="L6517" rel="L6517">Spi--i--ies!”</li>
<li class="L6518" rel="L6518"></li>
<li class="L6519" rel="L6519">“Why, to be sure!” exclaimed Jerry, recalling the Trial at which he had</li>
<li class="L6520" rel="L6520">assisted. “I&#39;ve seen him. Dead, is he?”</li>
<li class="L6521" rel="L6521"></li>
<li class="L6522" rel="L6522">“Dead as mutton,” returned the other, “and can&#39;t be too dead. Have &#39;em</li>
<li class="L6523" rel="L6523">out, there! Spies! Pull &#39;em out, there! Spies!”</li>
<li class="L6524" rel="L6524"></li>
<li class="L6525" rel="L6525">The idea was so acceptable in the prevalent absence of any idea,</li>
<li class="L6526" rel="L6526">that the crowd caught it up with eagerness, and loudly repeating the</li>
<li class="L6527" rel="L6527">suggestion to have &#39;em out, and to pull &#39;em out, mobbed the two vehicles</li>
<li class="L6528" rel="L6528">so closely that they came to a stop. On the crowd&#39;s opening the coach</li>
<li class="L6529" rel="L6529">doors, the one mourner scuffled out by himself and was in their hands</li>
<li class="L6530" rel="L6530">for a moment; but he was so alert, and made such good use of his time,</li>
<li class="L6531" rel="L6531">that in another moment he was scouring away up a bye-street, after</li>
<li class="L6532" rel="L6532">shedding his cloak, hat, long hatband, white pocket-handkerchief, and</li>
<li class="L6533" rel="L6533">other symbolical tears.</li>
<li class="L6534" rel="L6534"></li>
<li class="L6535" rel="L6535">These, the people tore to pieces and scattered far and wide with great</li>
<li class="L6536" rel="L6536">enjoyment, while the tradesmen hurriedly shut up their shops; for a</li>
<li class="L6537" rel="L6537">crowd in those times stopped at nothing, and was a monster much dreaded.</li>
<li class="L6538" rel="L6538">They had already got the length of opening the hearse to take the coffin</li>
<li class="L6539" rel="L6539">out, when some brighter genius proposed instead, its being escorted to</li>
<li class="L6540" rel="L6540">its destination amidst general rejoicing. Practical suggestions being</li>
<li class="L6541" rel="L6541">much needed, this suggestion, too, was received with acclamation, and</li>
<li class="L6542" rel="L6542">the coach was immediately filled with eight inside and a dozen out,</li>
<li class="L6543" rel="L6543">while as many people got on the roof of the hearse as could by any</li>
<li class="L6544" rel="L6544">exercise of ingenuity stick upon it. Among the first of these volunteers</li>
<li class="L6545" rel="L6545">was Jerry Cruncher himself, who modestly concealed his spiky head from</li>
<li class="L6546" rel="L6546">the observation of Tellson&#39;s, in the further corner of the mourning</li>
<li class="L6547" rel="L6547">coach.</li>
<li class="L6548" rel="L6548"></li>
<li class="L6549" rel="L6549">The officiating undertakers made some protest against these changes in</li>
<li class="L6550" rel="L6550">the ceremonies; but, the river being alarmingly near, and several voices</li>
<li class="L6551" rel="L6551">remarking on the efficacy of cold immersion in bringing refractory</li>
<li class="L6552" rel="L6552">members of the profession to reason, the protest was faint and brief.</li>
<li class="L6553" rel="L6553">The remodelled procession started, with a chimney-sweep driving the</li>
<li class="L6554" rel="L6554">hearse--advised by the regular driver, who was perched beside him, under</li>
<li class="L6555" rel="L6555">close inspection, for the purpose--and with a pieman, also attended</li>
<li class="L6556" rel="L6556">by his cabinet minister, driving the mourning coach. A bear-leader, a</li>
<li class="L6557" rel="L6557">popular street character of the time, was impressed as an additional</li>
<li class="L6558" rel="L6558">ornament, before the cavalcade had gone far down the Strand; and his</li>
<li class="L6559" rel="L6559">bear, who was black and very mangy, gave quite an Undertaking air to</li>
<li class="L6560" rel="L6560">that part of the procession in which he walked.</li>
<li class="L6561" rel="L6561"></li>
<li class="L6562" rel="L6562">Thus, with beer-drinking, pipe-smoking, song-roaring, and infinite</li>
<li class="L6563" rel="L6563">caricaturing of woe, the disorderly procession went its way, recruiting</li>
<li class="L6564" rel="L6564">at every step, and all the shops shutting up before it. Its destination</li>
<li class="L6565" rel="L6565">was the old church of Saint Pancras, far off in the fields. It got there</li>
<li class="L6566" rel="L6566">in course of time; insisted on pouring into the burial-ground; finally,</li>
<li class="L6567" rel="L6567">accomplished the interment of the deceased Roger Cly in its own way, and</li>
<li class="L6568" rel="L6568">highly to its own satisfaction.</li>
<li class="L6569" rel="L6569"></li>
<li class="L6570" rel="L6570">The dead man disposed of, and the crowd being under the necessity of</li>
<li class="L6571" rel="L6571">providing some other entertainment for itself, another brighter</li>
<li class="L6572" rel="L6572">genius (or perhaps the same) conceived the humour of impeaching casual</li>
<li class="L6573" rel="L6573">passers-by, as Old Bailey spies, and wreaking vengeance on them. Chase</li>
<li class="L6574" rel="L6574">was given to some scores of inoffensive persons who had never been near</li>
<li class="L6575" rel="L6575">the Old Bailey in their lives, in the realisation of this fancy, and</li>
<li class="L6576" rel="L6576">they were roughly hustled and maltreated. The transition to the sport of</li>
<li class="L6577" rel="L6577">window-breaking, and thence to the plundering of public-houses, was easy</li>
<li class="L6578" rel="L6578">and natural. At last, after several hours, when sundry summer-houses had</li>
<li class="L6579" rel="L6579">been pulled down, and some area-railings had been torn up, to arm</li>
<li class="L6580" rel="L6580">the more belligerent spirits, a rumour got about that the Guards were</li>
<li class="L6581" rel="L6581">coming. Before this rumour, the crowd gradually melted away, and perhaps</li>
<li class="L6582" rel="L6582">the Guards came, and perhaps they never came, and this was the usual</li>
<li class="L6583" rel="L6583">progress of a mob.</li>
<li class="L6584" rel="L6584"></li>
<li class="L6585" rel="L6585">Mr. Cruncher did not assist at the closing sports, but had remained</li>
<li class="L6586" rel="L6586">behind in the churchyard, to confer and condole with the undertakers.</li>
<li class="L6587" rel="L6587">The place had a soothing influence on him. He procured a pipe from a</li>
<li class="L6588" rel="L6588">neighbouring public-house, and smoked it, looking in at the railings and</li>
<li class="L6589" rel="L6589">maturely considering the spot.</li>
<li class="L6590" rel="L6590"></li>
<li class="L6591" rel="L6591">“Jerry,” said Mr. Cruncher, apostrophising himself in his usual way,</li>
<li class="L6592" rel="L6592">“you see that there Cly that day, and you see with your own eyes that he</li>
<li class="L6593" rel="L6593">was a young &#39;un and a straight made &#39;un.”</li>
<li class="L6594" rel="L6594"></li>
<li class="L6595" rel="L6595">Having smoked his pipe out, and ruminated a little longer, he turned</li>
<li class="L6596" rel="L6596">himself about, that he might appear, before the hour of closing, on his</li>
<li class="L6597" rel="L6597">station at Tellson&#39;s. Whether his meditations on mortality had touched</li>
<li class="L6598" rel="L6598">his liver, or whether his general health had been previously at all</li>
<li class="L6599" rel="L6599">amiss, or whether he desired to show a little attention to an eminent</li>
<li class="L6600" rel="L6600">man, is not so much to the purpose, as that he made a short call upon</li>
<li class="L6601" rel="L6601">his medical adviser--a distinguished surgeon--on his way back.</li>
<li class="L6602" rel="L6602"></li>
<li class="L6603" rel="L6603">Young Jerry relieved his father with dutiful interest, and reported No</li>
<li class="L6604" rel="L6604">job in his absence. The bank closed, the ancient clerks came out, the</li>
<li class="L6605" rel="L6605">usual watch was set, and Mr. Cruncher and his son went home to tea.</li>
<li class="L6606" rel="L6606"></li>
<li class="L6607" rel="L6607">“Now, I tell you where it is!” said Mr. Cruncher to his wife, on</li>
<li class="L6608" rel="L6608">entering. “If, as a honest tradesman, my wenturs goes wrong to-night, I</li>
<li class="L6609" rel="L6609">shall make sure that you&#39;ve been praying again me, and I shall work you</li>
<li class="L6610" rel="L6610">for it just the same as if I seen you do it.”</li>
<li class="L6611" rel="L6611"></li>
<li class="L6612" rel="L6612">The dejected Mrs. Cruncher shook her head.</li>
<li class="L6613" rel="L6613"></li>
<li class="L6614" rel="L6614">“Why, you&#39;re at it afore my face!” said Mr. Cruncher, with signs of</li>
<li class="L6615" rel="L6615">angry apprehension.</li>
<li class="L6616" rel="L6616"></li>
<li class="L6617" rel="L6617">“I am saying nothing.”</li>
<li class="L6618" rel="L6618"></li>
<li class="L6619" rel="L6619">“Well, then; don&#39;t meditate nothing. You might as well flop as meditate.</li>
<li class="L6620" rel="L6620">You may as well go again me one way as another. Drop it altogether.”</li>
<li class="L6621" rel="L6621"></li>
<li class="L6622" rel="L6622">“Yes, Jerry.”</li>
<li class="L6623" rel="L6623"></li>
<li class="L6624" rel="L6624">“Yes, Jerry,” repeated Mr. Cruncher sitting down to tea. “Ah! It _is_</li>
<li class="L6625" rel="L6625">yes, Jerry. That&#39;s about it. You may say yes, Jerry.”</li>
<li class="L6626" rel="L6626"></li>
<li class="L6627" rel="L6627">Mr. Cruncher had no particular meaning in these sulky corroborations,</li>
<li class="L6628" rel="L6628">but made use of them, as people not unfrequently do, to express general</li>
<li class="L6629" rel="L6629">ironical dissatisfaction.</li>
<li class="L6630" rel="L6630"></li>
<li class="L6631" rel="L6631">“You and your yes, Jerry,” said Mr. Cruncher, taking a bite out of his</li>
<li class="L6632" rel="L6632">bread-and-butter, and seeming to help it down with a large invisible</li>
<li class="L6633" rel="L6633">oyster out of his saucer. “Ah! I think so. I believe you.”</li>
<li class="L6634" rel="L6634"></li>
<li class="L6635" rel="L6635">“You are going out to-night?” asked his decent wife, when he took</li>
<li class="L6636" rel="L6636">another bite.</li>
<li class="L6637" rel="L6637"></li>
<li class="L6638" rel="L6638">“Yes, I am.”</li>
<li class="L6639" rel="L6639"></li>
<li class="L6640" rel="L6640">“May I go with you, father?” asked his son, briskly.</li>
<li class="L6641" rel="L6641"></li>
<li class="L6642" rel="L6642">“No, you mayn&#39;t. I&#39;m a going--as your mother knows--a fishing. That&#39;s</li>
<li class="L6643" rel="L6643">where I&#39;m going to. Going a fishing.”</li>
<li class="L6644" rel="L6644"></li>
<li class="L6645" rel="L6645">“Your fishing-rod gets rayther rusty; don&#39;t it, father?”</li>
<li class="L6646" rel="L6646"></li>
<li class="L6647" rel="L6647">“Never you mind.”</li>
<li class="L6648" rel="L6648"></li>
<li class="L6649" rel="L6649">“Shall you bring any fish home, father?”</li>
<li class="L6650" rel="L6650"></li>
<li class="L6651" rel="L6651">“If I don&#39;t, you&#39;ll have short commons, to-morrow,” returned that</li>
<li class="L6652" rel="L6652">gentleman, shaking his head; “that&#39;s questions enough for you; I ain&#39;t a</li>
<li class="L6653" rel="L6653">going out, till you&#39;ve been long abed.”</li>
<li class="L6654" rel="L6654"></li>
<li class="L6655" rel="L6655">He devoted himself during the remainder of the evening to keeping a</li>
<li class="L6656" rel="L6656">most vigilant watch on Mrs. Cruncher, and sullenly holding her in</li>
<li class="L6657" rel="L6657">conversation that she might be prevented from meditating any petitions</li>
<li class="L6658" rel="L6658">to his disadvantage. With this view, he urged his son to hold her in</li>
<li class="L6659" rel="L6659">conversation also, and led the unfortunate woman a hard life by dwelling</li>
<li class="L6660" rel="L6660">on any causes of complaint he could bring against her, rather than</li>
<li class="L6661" rel="L6661">he would leave her for a moment to her own reflections. The devoutest</li>
<li class="L6662" rel="L6662">person could have rendered no greater homage to the efficacy of an</li>
<li class="L6663" rel="L6663">honest prayer than he did in this distrust of his wife. It was as if a</li>
<li class="L6664" rel="L6664">professed unbeliever in ghosts should be frightened by a ghost story.</li>
<li class="L6665" rel="L6665"></li>
<li class="L6666" rel="L6666">“And mind you!” said Mr. Cruncher. “No games to-morrow! If I, as a</li>
<li class="L6667" rel="L6667">honest tradesman, succeed in providing a jinte of meat or two, none</li>
<li class="L6668" rel="L6668">of your not touching of it, and sticking to bread. If I, as a honest</li>
<li class="L6669" rel="L6669">tradesman, am able to provide a little beer, none of your declaring</li>
<li class="L6670" rel="L6670">on water. When you go to Rome, do as Rome does. Rome will be a ugly</li>
<li class="L6671" rel="L6671">customer to you, if you don&#39;t. _I_&#39;m your Rome, you know.”</li>
<li class="L6672" rel="L6672"></li>
<li class="L6673" rel="L6673">Then he began grumbling again:</li>
<li class="L6674" rel="L6674"></li>
<li class="L6675" rel="L6675">“With your flying into the face of your own wittles and drink! I don&#39;t</li>
<li class="L6676" rel="L6676">know how scarce you mayn&#39;t make the wittles and drink here, by your</li>
<li class="L6677" rel="L6677">flopping tricks and your unfeeling conduct. Look at your boy: he _is_</li>
<li class="L6678" rel="L6678">your&#39;n, ain&#39;t he? He&#39;s as thin as a lath. Do you call yourself a mother,</li>
<li class="L6679" rel="L6679">and not know that a mother&#39;s first duty is to blow her boy out?”</li>
<li class="L6680" rel="L6680"></li>
<li class="L6681" rel="L6681">This touched Young Jerry on a tender place; who adjured his mother to</li>
<li class="L6682" rel="L6682">perform her first duty, and, whatever else she did or neglected, above</li>
<li class="L6683" rel="L6683">all things to lay especial stress on the discharge of that maternal</li>
<li class="L6684" rel="L6684">function so affectingly and delicately indicated by his other parent.</li>
<li class="L6685" rel="L6685"></li>
<li class="L6686" rel="L6686">Thus the evening wore away with the Cruncher family, until Young Jerry</li>
<li class="L6687" rel="L6687">was ordered to bed, and his mother, laid under similar injunctions,</li>
<li class="L6688" rel="L6688">obeyed them. Mr. Cruncher beguiled the earlier watches of the night with</li>
<li class="L6689" rel="L6689">solitary pipes, and did not start upon his excursion until nearly one</li>
<li class="L6690" rel="L6690">o&#39;clock. Towards that small and ghostly hour, he rose up from his chair,</li>
<li class="L6691" rel="L6691">took a key out of his pocket, opened a locked cupboard, and brought</li>
<li class="L6692" rel="L6692">forth a sack, a crowbar of convenient size, a rope and chain, and other</li>
<li class="L6693" rel="L6693">fishing tackle of that nature. Disposing these articles about him</li>
<li class="L6694" rel="L6694">in skilful manner, he bestowed a parting defiance on Mrs. Cruncher,</li>
<li class="L6695" rel="L6695">extinguished the light, and went out.</li>
<li class="L6696" rel="L6696"></li>
<li class="L6697" rel="L6697">Young Jerry, who had only made a feint of undressing when he went to</li>
<li class="L6698" rel="L6698">bed, was not long after his father. Under cover of the darkness he</li>
<li class="L6699" rel="L6699">followed out of the room, followed down the stairs, followed down the</li>
<li class="L6700" rel="L6700">court, followed out into the streets. He was in no uneasiness concerning</li>
<li class="L6701" rel="L6701">his getting into the house again, for it was full of lodgers, and the</li>
<li class="L6702" rel="L6702">door stood ajar all night.</li>
<li class="L6703" rel="L6703"></li>
<li class="L6704" rel="L6704">Impelled by a laudable ambition to study the art and mystery of his</li>
<li class="L6705" rel="L6705">father&#39;s honest calling, Young Jerry, keeping as close to house fronts,</li>
<li class="L6706" rel="L6706">walls, and doorways, as his eyes were close to one another, held his</li>
<li class="L6707" rel="L6707">honoured parent in view. The honoured parent steering Northward, had not</li>
<li class="L6708" rel="L6708">gone far, when he was joined by another disciple of Izaak Walton, and</li>
<li class="L6709" rel="L6709">the two trudged on together.</li>
<li class="L6710" rel="L6710"></li>
<li class="L6711" rel="L6711">Within half an hour from the first starting, they were beyond the</li>
<li class="L6712" rel="L6712">winking lamps, and the more than winking watchmen, and were out upon a</li>
<li class="L6713" rel="L6713">lonely road. Another fisherman was picked up here--and that so silently,</li>
<li class="L6714" rel="L6714">that if Young Jerry had been superstitious, he might have supposed the</li>
<li class="L6715" rel="L6715">second follower of the gentle craft to have, all of a sudden, split</li>
<li class="L6716" rel="L6716">himself into two.</li>
<li class="L6717" rel="L6717"></li>
<li class="L6718" rel="L6718">The three went on, and Young Jerry went on, until the three stopped</li>
<li class="L6719" rel="L6719">under a bank overhanging the road. Upon the top of the bank was a low</li>
<li class="L6720" rel="L6720">brick wall, surmounted by an iron railing. In the shadow of bank and</li>
<li class="L6721" rel="L6721">wall the three turned out of the road, and up a blind lane, of which</li>
<li class="L6722" rel="L6722">the wall--there, risen to some eight or ten feet high--formed one side.</li>
<li class="L6723" rel="L6723">Crouching down in a corner, peeping up the lane, the next object that</li>
<li class="L6724" rel="L6724">Young Jerry saw, was the form of his honoured parent, pretty well</li>
<li class="L6725" rel="L6725">defined against a watery and clouded moon, nimbly scaling an iron gate.</li>
<li class="L6726" rel="L6726">He was soon over, and then the second fisherman got over, and then the</li>
<li class="L6727" rel="L6727">third. They all dropped softly on the ground within the gate, and lay</li>
<li class="L6728" rel="L6728">there a little--listening perhaps. Then, they moved away on their hands</li>
<li class="L6729" rel="L6729">and knees.</li>
<li class="L6730" rel="L6730"></li>
<li class="L6731" rel="L6731">It was now Young Jerry&#39;s turn to approach the gate: which he did,</li>
<li class="L6732" rel="L6732">holding his breath. Crouching down again in a corner there, and looking</li>
<li class="L6733" rel="L6733">in, he made out the three fishermen creeping through some rank grass!</li>
<li class="L6734" rel="L6734">and all the gravestones in the churchyard--it was a large churchyard</li>
<li class="L6735" rel="L6735">that they were in--looking on like ghosts in white, while the church</li>
<li class="L6736" rel="L6736">tower itself looked on like the ghost of a monstrous giant. They did not</li>
<li class="L6737" rel="L6737">creep far, before they stopped and stood upright. And then they began to</li>
<li class="L6738" rel="L6738">fish.</li>
<li class="L6739" rel="L6739"></li>
<li class="L6740" rel="L6740">They fished with a spade, at first. Presently the honoured parent</li>
<li class="L6741" rel="L6741">appeared to be adjusting some instrument like a great corkscrew.</li>
<li class="L6742" rel="L6742">Whatever tools they worked with, they worked hard, until the awful</li>
<li class="L6743" rel="L6743">striking of the church clock so terrified Young Jerry, that he made off,</li>
<li class="L6744" rel="L6744">with his hair as stiff as his father&#39;s.</li>
<li class="L6745" rel="L6745"></li>
<li class="L6746" rel="L6746">But, his long-cherished desire to know more about these matters, not</li>
<li class="L6747" rel="L6747">only stopped him in his running away, but lured him back again. They</li>
<li class="L6748" rel="L6748">were still fishing perseveringly, when he peeped in at the gate for</li>
<li class="L6749" rel="L6749">the second time; but, now they seemed to have got a bite. There was a</li>
<li class="L6750" rel="L6750">screwing and complaining sound down below, and their bent figures were</li>
<li class="L6751" rel="L6751">strained, as if by a weight. By slow degrees the weight broke away the</li>
<li class="L6752" rel="L6752">earth upon it, and came to the surface. Young Jerry very well knew what</li>
<li class="L6753" rel="L6753">it would be; but, when he saw it, and saw his honoured parent about to</li>
<li class="L6754" rel="L6754">wrench it open, he was so frightened, being new to the sight, that he</li>
<li class="L6755" rel="L6755">made off again, and never stopped until he had run a mile or more.</li>
<li class="L6756" rel="L6756"></li>
<li class="L6757" rel="L6757">He would not have stopped then, for anything less necessary than breath,</li>
<li class="L6758" rel="L6758">it being a spectral sort of race that he ran, and one highly desirable</li>
<li class="L6759" rel="L6759">to get to the end of. He had a strong idea that the coffin he had seen</li>
<li class="L6760" rel="L6760">was running after him; and, pictured as hopping on behind him, bolt</li>
<li class="L6761" rel="L6761">upright, upon its narrow end, always on the point of overtaking him</li>
<li class="L6762" rel="L6762">and hopping on at his side--perhaps taking his arm--it was a pursuer to</li>
<li class="L6763" rel="L6763">shun. It was an inconsistent and ubiquitous fiend too, for, while it</li>
<li class="L6764" rel="L6764">was making the whole night behind him dreadful, he darted out into the</li>
<li class="L6765" rel="L6765">roadway to avoid dark alleys, fearful of its coming hopping out of them</li>
<li class="L6766" rel="L6766">like a dropsical boy&#39;s kite without tail and wings. It hid in doorways</li>
<li class="L6767" rel="L6767">too, rubbing its horrible shoulders against doors, and drawing them up</li>
<li class="L6768" rel="L6768">to its ears, as if it were laughing. It got into shadows on the road,</li>
<li class="L6769" rel="L6769">and lay cunningly on its back to trip him up. All this time it was</li>
<li class="L6770" rel="L6770">incessantly hopping on behind and gaining on him, so that when the boy</li>
<li class="L6771" rel="L6771">got to his own door he had reason for being half dead. And even then</li>
<li class="L6772" rel="L6772">it would not leave him, but followed him upstairs with a bump on every</li>
<li class="L6773" rel="L6773">stair, scrambled into bed with him, and bumped down, dead and heavy, on</li>
<li class="L6774" rel="L6774">his breast when he fell asleep.</li>
<li class="L6775" rel="L6775"></li>
<li class="L6776" rel="L6776">From his oppressed slumber, Young Jerry in his closet was awakened after</li>
<li class="L6777" rel="L6777">daybreak and before sunrise, by the presence of his father in the</li>
<li class="L6778" rel="L6778">family room. Something had gone wrong with him; at least, so Young Jerry</li>
<li class="L6779" rel="L6779">inferred, from the circumstance of his holding Mrs. Cruncher by the</li>
<li class="L6780" rel="L6780">ears, and knocking the back of her head against the head-board of the</li>
<li class="L6781" rel="L6781">bed.</li>
<li class="L6782" rel="L6782"></li>
<li class="L6783" rel="L6783">“I told you I would,” said Mr. Cruncher, “and I did.”</li>
<li class="L6784" rel="L6784"></li>
<li class="L6785" rel="L6785">“Jerry, Jerry, Jerry!” his wife implored.</li>
<li class="L6786" rel="L6786"></li>
<li class="L6787" rel="L6787">“You oppose yourself to the profit of the business,” said Jerry, “and me</li>
<li class="L6788" rel="L6788">and my partners suffer. You was to honour and obey; why the devil don&#39;t</li>
<li class="L6789" rel="L6789">you?”</li>
<li class="L6790" rel="L6790"></li>
<li class="L6791" rel="L6791">“I try to be a good wife, Jerry,” the poor woman protested, with tears.</li>
<li class="L6792" rel="L6792"></li>
<li class="L6793" rel="L6793">“Is it being a good wife to oppose your husband&#39;s business? Is it</li>
<li class="L6794" rel="L6794">honouring your husband to dishonour his business? Is it obeying your</li>
<li class="L6795" rel="L6795">husband to disobey him on the wital subject of his business?”</li>
<li class="L6796" rel="L6796"></li>
<li class="L6797" rel="L6797">“You hadn&#39;t taken to the dreadful business then, Jerry.”</li>
<li class="L6798" rel="L6798"></li>
<li class="L6799" rel="L6799">“It&#39;s enough for you,” retorted Mr. Cruncher, “to be the wife of a</li>
<li class="L6800" rel="L6800">honest tradesman, and not to occupy your female mind with calculations</li>
<li class="L6801" rel="L6801">when he took to his trade or when he didn&#39;t. A honouring and obeying</li>
<li class="L6802" rel="L6802">wife would let his trade alone altogether. Call yourself a religious</li>
