<li class="L6803" rel="L6803">woman? If you&#39;re a religious woman, give me a irreligious one! You have</li>
<li class="L6804" rel="L6804">no more nat&#39;ral sense of duty than the bed of this here Thames river has</li>
<li class="L6805" rel="L6805">of a pile, and similarly it must be knocked into you.”</li>
<li class="L6806" rel="L6806"></li>
<li class="L6807" rel="L6807">The altercation was conducted in a low tone of voice, and terminated in</li>
<li class="L6808" rel="L6808">the honest tradesman&#39;s kicking off his clay-soiled boots, and lying down</li>
<li class="L6809" rel="L6809">at his length on the floor. After taking a timid peep at him lying on</li>
<li class="L6810" rel="L6810">his back, with his rusty hands under his head for a pillow, his son lay</li>
<li class="L6811" rel="L6811">down too, and fell asleep again.</li>
<li class="L6812" rel="L6812"></li>
<li class="L6813" rel="L6813">There was no fish for breakfast, and not much of anything else. Mr.</li>
<li class="L6814" rel="L6814">Cruncher was out of spirits, and out of temper, and kept an iron pot-lid</li>
<li class="L6815" rel="L6815">by him as a projectile for the correction of Mrs. Cruncher, in case</li>
<li class="L6816" rel="L6816">he should observe any symptoms of her saying Grace. He was brushed</li>
<li class="L6817" rel="L6817">and washed at the usual hour, and set off with his son to pursue his</li>
<li class="L6818" rel="L6818">ostensible calling.</li>
<li class="L6819" rel="L6819"></li>
<li class="L6820" rel="L6820">Young Jerry, walking with the stool under his arm at his father&#39;s side</li>
<li class="L6821" rel="L6821">along sunny and crowded Fleet-street, was a very different Young Jerry</li>
<li class="L6822" rel="L6822">from him of the previous night, running home through darkness and</li>
<li class="L6823" rel="L6823">solitude from his grim pursuer. His cunning was fresh with the day,</li>
<li class="L6824" rel="L6824">and his qualms were gone with the night--in which particulars it is not</li>
<li class="L6825" rel="L6825">improbable that he had compeers in Fleet-street and the City of London,</li>
<li class="L6826" rel="L6826">that fine morning.</li>
<li class="L6827" rel="L6827"></li>
<li class="L6828" rel="L6828">“Father,” said Young Jerry, as they walked along: taking care to keep</li>
<li class="L6829" rel="L6829">at arm&#39;s length and to have the stool well between them: “what&#39;s a</li>
<li class="L6830" rel="L6830">Resurrection-Man?”</li>
<li class="L6831" rel="L6831"></li>
<li class="L6832" rel="L6832">Mr. Cruncher came to a stop on the pavement before he answered, “How</li>
<li class="L6833" rel="L6833">should I know?”</li>
<li class="L6834" rel="L6834"></li>
<li class="L6835" rel="L6835">“I thought you knowed everything, father,” said the artless boy.</li>
<li class="L6836" rel="L6836"></li>
<li class="L6837" rel="L6837">“Hem! Well,” returned Mr. Cruncher, going on again, and lifting off his</li>
<li class="L6838" rel="L6838">hat to give his spikes free play, “he&#39;s a tradesman.”</li>
<li class="L6839" rel="L6839"></li>
<li class="L6840" rel="L6840">“What&#39;s his goods, father?” asked the brisk Young Jerry.</li>
<li class="L6841" rel="L6841"></li>
<li class="L6842" rel="L6842">“His goods,” said Mr. Cruncher, after turning it over in his mind, “is a</li>
<li class="L6843" rel="L6843">branch of Scientific goods.”</li>
<li class="L6844" rel="L6844"></li>
<li class="L6845" rel="L6845">“Persons&#39; bodies, ain&#39;t it, father?” asked the lively boy.</li>
<li class="L6846" rel="L6846"></li>
<li class="L6847" rel="L6847">“I believe it is something of that sort,” said Mr. Cruncher.</li>
<li class="L6848" rel="L6848"></li>
<li class="L6849" rel="L6849">“Oh, father, I should so like to be a Resurrection-Man when I&#39;m quite</li>
<li class="L6850" rel="L6850">growed up!”</li>
<li class="L6851" rel="L6851"></li>
<li class="L6852" rel="L6852">Mr. Cruncher was soothed, but shook his head in a dubious and moral way.</li>
<li class="L6853" rel="L6853">“It depends upon how you dewelop your talents. Be careful to dewelop</li>
<li class="L6854" rel="L6854">your talents, and never to say no more than you can help to nobody, and</li>
<li class="L6855" rel="L6855">there&#39;s no telling at the present time what you may not come to be fit</li>
<li class="L6856" rel="L6856">for.” As Young Jerry, thus encouraged, went on a few yards in advance,</li>
<li class="L6857" rel="L6857">to plant the stool in the shadow of the Bar, Mr. Cruncher added to</li>
<li class="L6858" rel="L6858">himself: “Jerry, you honest tradesman, there&#39;s hopes wot that boy will</li>
<li class="L6859" rel="L6859">yet be a blessing to you, and a recompense to you for his mother!”</li>
<li class="L6860" rel="L6860"></li>
<li class="L6861" rel="L6861"></li>
<li class="L6862" rel="L6862"></li>
<li class="L6863" rel="L6863"></li>
<li class="L6864" rel="L6864">XV. Knitting</li>
<li class="L6865" rel="L6865"></li>
<li class="L6866" rel="L6866"></li>
<li class="L6867" rel="L6867">There had been earlier drinking than usual in the wine-shop of Monsieur</li>
<li class="L6868" rel="L6868">Defarge. As early as six o&#39;clock in the morning, sallow faces peeping</li>
<li class="L6869" rel="L6869">through its barred windows had descried other faces within, bending over</li>
<li class="L6870" rel="L6870">measures of wine. Monsieur Defarge sold a very thin wine at the best</li>
<li class="L6871" rel="L6871">of times, but it would seem to have been an unusually thin wine that</li>
<li class="L6872" rel="L6872">he sold at this time. A sour wine, moreover, or a souring, for its</li>
<li class="L6873" rel="L6873">influence on the mood of those who drank it was to make them gloomy. No</li>
<li class="L6874" rel="L6874">vivacious Bacchanalian flame leaped out of the pressed grape of Monsieur</li>
<li class="L6875" rel="L6875">Defarge: but, a smouldering fire that burnt in the dark, lay hidden in</li>
<li class="L6876" rel="L6876">the dregs of it.</li>
<li class="L6877" rel="L6877"></li>
<li class="L6878" rel="L6878">This had been the third morning in succession, on which there had been</li>
<li class="L6879" rel="L6879">early drinking at the wine-shop of Monsieur Defarge. It had begun</li>
<li class="L6880" rel="L6880">on Monday, and here was Wednesday come. There had been more of early</li>
<li class="L6881" rel="L6881">brooding than drinking; for, many men had listened and whispered and</li>
<li class="L6882" rel="L6882">slunk about there from the time of the opening of the door, who could</li>
<li class="L6883" rel="L6883">not have laid a piece of money on the counter to save their souls. These</li>
<li class="L6884" rel="L6884">were to the full as interested in the place, however, as if they could</li>
<li class="L6885" rel="L6885">have commanded whole barrels of wine; and they glided from seat to seat,</li>
<li class="L6886" rel="L6886">and from corner to corner, swallowing talk in lieu of drink, with greedy</li>
<li class="L6887" rel="L6887">looks.</li>
<li class="L6888" rel="L6888"></li>
<li class="L6889" rel="L6889">Notwithstanding an unusual flow of company, the master of the wine-shop</li>
<li class="L6890" rel="L6890">was not visible. He was not missed; for, nobody who crossed the</li>
<li class="L6891" rel="L6891">threshold looked for him, nobody asked for him, nobody wondered to see</li>
<li class="L6892" rel="L6892">only Madame Defarge in her seat, presiding over the distribution of</li>
<li class="L6893" rel="L6893">wine, with a bowl of battered small coins before her, as much defaced</li>
<li class="L6894" rel="L6894">and beaten out of their original impress as the small coinage of</li>
<li class="L6895" rel="L6895">humanity from whose ragged pockets they had come.</li>
<li class="L6896" rel="L6896"></li>
<li class="L6897" rel="L6897">A suspended interest and a prevalent absence of mind, were perhaps</li>
<li class="L6898" rel="L6898">observed by the spies who looked in at the wine-shop, as they looked in</li>
<li class="L6899" rel="L6899">at every place, high and low, from the king&#39;s palace to the criminal&#39;s</li>
<li class="L6900" rel="L6900">gaol. Games at cards languished, players at dominoes musingly built</li>
<li class="L6901" rel="L6901">towers with them, drinkers drew figures on the tables with spilt drops</li>
<li class="L6902" rel="L6902">of wine, Madame Defarge herself picked out the pattern on her sleeve</li>
<li class="L6903" rel="L6903">with her toothpick, and saw and heard something inaudible and invisible</li>
<li class="L6904" rel="L6904">a long way off.</li>
<li class="L6905" rel="L6905"></li>
<li class="L6906" rel="L6906">Thus, Saint Antoine in this vinous feature of his, until midday. It was</li>
<li class="L6907" rel="L6907">high noontide, when two dusty men passed through his streets and under</li>
<li class="L6908" rel="L6908">his swinging lamps: of whom, one was Monsieur Defarge: the other a</li>
<li class="L6909" rel="L6909">mender of roads in a blue cap. All adust and athirst, the two entered</li>
<li class="L6910" rel="L6910">the wine-shop. Their arrival had lighted a kind of fire in the breast</li>
<li class="L6911" rel="L6911">of Saint Antoine, fast spreading as they came along, which stirred and</li>
<li class="L6912" rel="L6912">flickered in flames of faces at most doors and windows. Yet, no one had</li>
<li class="L6913" rel="L6913">followed them, and no man spoke when they entered the wine-shop, though</li>
<li class="L6914" rel="L6914">the eyes of every man there were turned upon them.</li>
<li class="L6915" rel="L6915"></li>
<li class="L6916" rel="L6916">“Good day, gentlemen!” said Monsieur Defarge.</li>
<li class="L6917" rel="L6917"></li>
<li class="L6918" rel="L6918">It may have been a signal for loosening the general tongue. It elicited</li>
<li class="L6919" rel="L6919">an answering chorus of “Good day!”</li>
<li class="L6920" rel="L6920"></li>
<li class="L6921" rel="L6921">“It is bad weather, gentlemen,” said Defarge, shaking his head.</li>
<li class="L6922" rel="L6922"></li>
<li class="L6923" rel="L6923">Upon which, every man looked at his neighbour, and then all cast down</li>
<li class="L6924" rel="L6924">their eyes and sat silent. Except one man, who got up and went out.</li>
<li class="L6925" rel="L6925"></li>
<li class="L6926" rel="L6926">“My wife,” said Defarge aloud, addressing Madame Defarge: “I have</li>
<li class="L6927" rel="L6927">travelled certain leagues with this good mender of roads, called</li>
<li class="L6928" rel="L6928">Jacques. I met him--by accident--a day and half&#39;s journey out of Paris.</li>
<li class="L6929" rel="L6929">He is a good child, this mender of roads, called Jacques. Give him to</li>
<li class="L6930" rel="L6930">drink, my wife!”</li>
<li class="L6931" rel="L6931"></li>
<li class="L6932" rel="L6932">A second man got up and went out. Madame Defarge set wine before the</li>
<li class="L6933" rel="L6933">mender of roads called Jacques, who doffed his blue cap to the company,</li>
<li class="L6934" rel="L6934">and drank. In the breast of his blouse he carried some coarse dark</li>
<li class="L6935" rel="L6935">bread; he ate of this between whiles, and sat munching and drinking near</li>
<li class="L6936" rel="L6936">Madame Defarge&#39;s counter. A third man got up and went out.</li>
<li class="L6937" rel="L6937"></li>
<li class="L6938" rel="L6938">Defarge refreshed himself with a draught of wine--but, he took less</li>
<li class="L6939" rel="L6939">than was given to the stranger, as being himself a man to whom it was no</li>
<li class="L6940" rel="L6940">rarity--and stood waiting until the countryman had made his breakfast.</li>
<li class="L6941" rel="L6941">He looked at no one present, and no one now looked at him; not even</li>
<li class="L6942" rel="L6942">Madame Defarge, who had taken up her knitting, and was at work.</li>
<li class="L6943" rel="L6943"></li>
<li class="L6944" rel="L6944">“Have you finished your repast, friend?” he asked, in due season.</li>
<li class="L6945" rel="L6945"></li>
<li class="L6946" rel="L6946">“Yes, thank you.”</li>
<li class="L6947" rel="L6947"></li>
<li class="L6948" rel="L6948">“Come, then! You shall see the apartment that I told you you could</li>
<li class="L6949" rel="L6949">occupy. It will suit you to a marvel.”</li>
<li class="L6950" rel="L6950"></li>
<li class="L6951" rel="L6951">Out of the wine-shop into the street, out of the street into a</li>
<li class="L6952" rel="L6952">courtyard, out of the courtyard up a steep staircase, out of the</li>
<li class="L6953" rel="L6953">staircase into a garret--formerly the garret where a white-haired man</li>
<li class="L6954" rel="L6954">sat on a low bench, stooping forward and very busy, making shoes.</li>
<li class="L6955" rel="L6955"></li>
<li class="L6956" rel="L6956">No white-haired man was there now; but, the three men were there who had</li>
<li class="L6957" rel="L6957">gone out of the wine-shop singly. And between them and the white-haired</li>
<li class="L6958" rel="L6958">man afar off, was the one small link, that they had once looked in at</li>
<li class="L6959" rel="L6959">him through the chinks in the wall.</li>
<li class="L6960" rel="L6960"></li>
<li class="L6961" rel="L6961">Defarge closed the door carefully, and spoke in a subdued voice:</li>
<li class="L6962" rel="L6962"></li>
<li class="L6963" rel="L6963">“Jacques One, Jacques Two, Jacques Three! This is the witness</li>
<li class="L6964" rel="L6964">encountered by appointment, by me, Jacques Four. He will tell you all.</li>
<li class="L6965" rel="L6965">Speak, Jacques Five!”</li>
<li class="L6966" rel="L6966"></li>
<li class="L6967" rel="L6967">The mender of roads, blue cap in hand, wiped his swarthy forehead with</li>
<li class="L6968" rel="L6968">it, and said, “Where shall I commence, monsieur?”</li>
<li class="L6969" rel="L6969"></li>
<li class="L6970" rel="L6970">“Commence,” was Monsieur Defarge&#39;s not unreasonable reply, “at the</li>
<li class="L6971" rel="L6971">commencement.”</li>
<li class="L6972" rel="L6972"></li>
<li class="L6973" rel="L6973">“I saw him then, messieurs,” began the mender of roads, “a year ago this</li>
<li class="L6974" rel="L6974">running summer, underneath the carriage of the Marquis, hanging by the</li>
<li class="L6975" rel="L6975">chain. Behold the manner of it. I leaving my work on the road, the sun</li>
<li class="L6976" rel="L6976">going to bed, the carriage of the Marquis slowly ascending the hill, he</li>
<li class="L6977" rel="L6977">hanging by the chain--like this.”</li>
<li class="L6978" rel="L6978"></li>
<li class="L6979" rel="L6979">Again the mender of roads went through the whole performance; in which</li>
<li class="L6980" rel="L6980">he ought to have been perfect by that time, seeing that it had been</li>
<li class="L6981" rel="L6981">the infallible resource and indispensable entertainment of his village</li>
<li class="L6982" rel="L6982">during a whole year.</li>
<li class="L6983" rel="L6983"></li>
<li class="L6984" rel="L6984">Jacques One struck in, and asked if he had ever seen the man before?</li>
<li class="L6985" rel="L6985"></li>
<li class="L6986" rel="L6986">“Never,” answered the mender of roads, recovering his perpendicular.</li>
<li class="L6987" rel="L6987"></li>
<li class="L6988" rel="L6988">Jacques Three demanded how he afterwards recognised him then?</li>
<li class="L6989" rel="L6989"></li>
<li class="L6990" rel="L6990">“By his tall figure,” said the mender of roads, softly, and with his</li>
<li class="L6991" rel="L6991">finger at his nose. “When Monsieur the Marquis demands that evening,</li>
<li class="L6992" rel="L6992">&#39;Say, what is he like?&#39; I make response, &#39;Tall as a spectre.&#39;”</li>
<li class="L6993" rel="L6993"></li>
<li class="L6994" rel="L6994">“You should have said, short as a dwarf,” returned Jacques Two.</li>
<li class="L6995" rel="L6995"></li>
<li class="L6996" rel="L6996">“But what did I know? The deed was not then accomplished, neither did he</li>
<li class="L6997" rel="L6997">confide in me. Observe! Under those circumstances even, I do not</li>
<li class="L6998" rel="L6998">offer my testimony. Monsieur the Marquis indicates me with his finger,</li>
<li class="L6999" rel="L6999">standing near our little fountain, and says, &#39;To me! Bring that rascal!&#39;</li>
<li class="L7000" rel="L7000">My faith, messieurs, I offer nothing.”</li>
<li class="L7001" rel="L7001"></li>
<li class="L7002" rel="L7002">“He is right there, Jacques,” murmured Defarge, to him who had</li>
<li class="L7003" rel="L7003">interrupted. “Go on!”</li>
<li class="L7004" rel="L7004"></li>
<li class="L7005" rel="L7005">“Good!” said the mender of roads, with an air of mystery. “The tall man</li>
<li class="L7006" rel="L7006">is lost, and he is sought--how many months? Nine, ten, eleven?”</li>
<li class="L7007" rel="L7007"></li>
<li class="L7008" rel="L7008">“No matter, the number,” said Defarge. “He is well hidden, but at last</li>
<li class="L7009" rel="L7009">he is unluckily found. Go on!”</li>
<li class="L7010" rel="L7010"></li>
<li class="L7011" rel="L7011">“I am again at work upon the hill-side, and the sun is again about to</li>
<li class="L7012" rel="L7012">go to bed. I am collecting my tools to descend to my cottage down in the</li>
<li class="L7013" rel="L7013">village below, where it is already dark, when I raise my eyes, and see</li>
<li class="L7014" rel="L7014">coming over the hill six soldiers. In the midst of them is a tall man</li>
<li class="L7015" rel="L7015">with his arms bound--tied to his sides--like this!”</li>
<li class="L7016" rel="L7016"></li>
<li class="L7017" rel="L7017">With the aid of his indispensable cap, he represented a man with his</li>
<li class="L7018" rel="L7018">elbows bound fast at his hips, with cords that were knotted behind him.</li>
<li class="L7019" rel="L7019"></li>
<li class="L7020" rel="L7020">“I stand aside, messieurs, by my heap of stones, to see the soldiers</li>
<li class="L7021" rel="L7021">and their prisoner pass (for it is a solitary road, that, where any</li>
<li class="L7022" rel="L7022">spectacle is well worth looking at), and at first, as they approach, I</li>
<li class="L7023" rel="L7023">see no more than that they are six soldiers with a tall man bound, and</li>
<li class="L7024" rel="L7024">that they are almost black to my sight--except on the side of the sun</li>
<li class="L7025" rel="L7025">going to bed, where they have a red edge, messieurs. Also, I see that</li>
<li class="L7026" rel="L7026">their long shadows are on the hollow ridge on the opposite side of the</li>
<li class="L7027" rel="L7027">road, and are on the hill above it, and are like the shadows of giants.</li>
<li class="L7028" rel="L7028">Also, I see that they are covered with dust, and that the dust moves</li>
<li class="L7029" rel="L7029">with them as they come, tramp, tramp! But when they advance quite near</li>
<li class="L7030" rel="L7030">to me, I recognise the tall man, and he recognises me. Ah, but he would</li>
<li class="L7031" rel="L7031">be well content to precipitate himself over the hill-side once again, as</li>
<li class="L7032" rel="L7032">on the evening when he and I first encountered, close to the same spot!”</li>
<li class="L7033" rel="L7033"></li>
<li class="L7034" rel="L7034">He described it as if he were there, and it was evident that he saw it</li>
<li class="L7035" rel="L7035">vividly; perhaps he had not seen much in his life.</li>
<li class="L7036" rel="L7036"></li>
<li class="L7037" rel="L7037">“I do not show the soldiers that I recognise the tall man; he does not</li>
<li class="L7038" rel="L7038">show the soldiers that he recognises me; we do it, and we know it, with</li>
<li class="L7039" rel="L7039">our eyes. &#39;Come on!&#39; says the chief of that company, pointing to the</li>
<li class="L7040" rel="L7040">village, &#39;bring him fast to his tomb!&#39; and they bring him faster. I</li>
<li class="L7041" rel="L7041">follow. His arms are swelled because of being bound so tight, his wooden</li>
<li class="L7042" rel="L7042">shoes are large and clumsy, and he is lame. Because he is lame, and</li>
<li class="L7043" rel="L7043">consequently slow, they drive him with their guns--like this!”</li>
<li class="L7044" rel="L7044"></li>
<li class="L7045" rel="L7045">He imitated the action of a man&#39;s being impelled forward by the</li>
<li class="L7046" rel="L7046">butt-ends of muskets.</li>
<li class="L7047" rel="L7047"></li>
<li class="L7048" rel="L7048">“As they descend the hill like madmen running a race, he falls. They</li>
<li class="L7049" rel="L7049">laugh and pick him up again. His face is bleeding and covered with dust,</li>
<li class="L7050" rel="L7050">but he cannot touch it; thereupon they laugh again. They bring him into</li>
<li class="L7051" rel="L7051">the village; all the village runs to look; they take him past the mill,</li>
<li class="L7052" rel="L7052">and up to the prison; all the village sees the prison gate open in the</li>
<li class="L7053" rel="L7053">darkness of the night, and swallow him--like this!”</li>
<li class="L7054" rel="L7054"></li>
<li class="L7055" rel="L7055">He opened his mouth as wide as he could, and shut it with a sounding</li>
<li class="L7056" rel="L7056">snap of his teeth. Observant of his unwillingness to mar the effect by</li>
<li class="L7057" rel="L7057">opening it again, Defarge said, “Go on, Jacques.”</li>
<li class="L7058" rel="L7058"></li>
<li class="L7059" rel="L7059">“All the village,” pursued the mender of roads, on tiptoe and in a low</li>
<li class="L7060" rel="L7060">voice, “withdraws; all the village whispers by the fountain; all the</li>
<li class="L7061" rel="L7061">village sleeps; all the village dreams of that unhappy one, within the</li>
<li class="L7062" rel="L7062">locks and bars of the prison on the crag, and never to come out of it,</li>
<li class="L7063" rel="L7063">except to perish. In the morning, with my tools upon my shoulder, eating</li>
<li class="L7064" rel="L7064">my morsel of black bread as I go, I make a circuit by the prison, on</li>
<li class="L7065" rel="L7065">my way to my work. There I see him, high up, behind the bars of a lofty</li>
<li class="L7066" rel="L7066">iron cage, bloody and dusty as last night, looking through. He has no</li>
<li class="L7067" rel="L7067">hand free, to wave to me; I dare not call to him; he regards me like a</li>
<li class="L7068" rel="L7068">dead man.”</li>
<li class="L7069" rel="L7069"></li>
<li class="L7070" rel="L7070">Defarge and the three glanced darkly at one another. The looks of all</li>
<li class="L7071" rel="L7071">of them were dark, repressed, and revengeful, as they listened to the</li>
<li class="L7072" rel="L7072">countryman&#39;s story; the manner of all of them, while it was secret, was</li>
<li class="L7073" rel="L7073">authoritative too. They had the air of a rough tribunal; Jacques One</li>
<li class="L7074" rel="L7074">and Two sitting on the old pallet-bed, each with his chin resting on</li>
<li class="L7075" rel="L7075">his hand, and his eyes intent on the road-mender; Jacques Three, equally</li>
<li class="L7076" rel="L7076">intent, on one knee behind them, with his agitated hand always gliding</li>
<li class="L7077" rel="L7077">over the network of fine nerves about his mouth and nose; Defarge</li>
<li class="L7078" rel="L7078">standing between them and the narrator, whom he had stationed in the</li>
<li class="L7079" rel="L7079">light of the window, by turns looking from him to them, and from them to</li>
<li class="L7080" rel="L7080">him.</li>
<li class="L7081" rel="L7081"></li>
<li class="L7082" rel="L7082">“Go on, Jacques,” said Defarge.</li>
<li class="L7083" rel="L7083"></li>
<li class="L7084" rel="L7084">“He remains up there in his iron cage some days. The village looks</li>
<li class="L7085" rel="L7085">at him by stealth, for it is afraid. But it always looks up, from a</li>
<li class="L7086" rel="L7086">distance, at the prison on the crag; and in the evening, when the work</li>
<li class="L7087" rel="L7087">of the day is achieved and it assembles to gossip at the fountain, all</li>
<li class="L7088" rel="L7088">faces are turned towards the prison. Formerly, they were turned towards</li>
<li class="L7089" rel="L7089">the posting-house; now, they are turned towards the prison. They</li>
<li class="L7090" rel="L7090">whisper at the fountain, that although condemned to death he will not be</li>
<li class="L7091" rel="L7091">executed; they say that petitions have been presented in Paris, showing</li>
<li class="L7092" rel="L7092">that he was enraged and made mad by the death of his child; they say</li>
<li class="L7093" rel="L7093">that a petition has been presented to the King himself. What do I know?</li>
<li class="L7094" rel="L7094">It is possible. Perhaps yes, perhaps no.”</li>
<li class="L7095" rel="L7095"></li>
<li class="L7096" rel="L7096">“Listen then, Jacques,” Number One of that name sternly interposed.</li>
<li class="L7097" rel="L7097">“Know that a petition was presented to the King and Queen. All here,</li>
<li class="L7098" rel="L7098">yourself excepted, saw the King take it, in his carriage in the street,</li>
<li class="L7099" rel="L7099">sitting beside the Queen. It is Defarge whom you see here, who, at the</li>
<li class="L7100" rel="L7100">hazard of his life, darted out before the horses, with the petition in</li>
<li class="L7101" rel="L7101">his hand.”</li>
<li class="L7102" rel="L7102"></li>
<li class="L7103" rel="L7103">“And once again listen, Jacques!” said the kneeling Number Three:</li>
<li class="L7104" rel="L7104">his fingers ever wandering over and over those fine nerves, with a</li>
<li class="L7105" rel="L7105">strikingly greedy air, as if he hungered for something--that was neither</li>
<li class="L7106" rel="L7106">food nor drink; “the guard, horse and foot, surrounded the petitioner,</li>
<li class="L7107" rel="L7107">and struck him blows. You hear?”</li>
<li class="L7108" rel="L7108"></li>
<li class="L7109" rel="L7109">“I hear, messieurs.”</li>
<li class="L7110" rel="L7110"></li>
<li class="L7111" rel="L7111">“Go on then,” said Defarge.</li>
<li class="L7112" rel="L7112"></li>
<li class="L7113" rel="L7113">“Again; on the other hand, they whisper at the fountain,” resumed the</li>
<li class="L7114" rel="L7114">countryman, “that he is brought down into our country to be executed on</li>
<li class="L7115" rel="L7115">the spot, and that he will very certainly be executed. They even whisper</li>
<li class="L7116" rel="L7116">that because he has slain Monseigneur, and because Monseigneur was the</li>
<li class="L7117" rel="L7117">father of his tenants--serfs--what you will--he will be executed as a</li>
<li class="L7118" rel="L7118">parricide. One old man says at the fountain, that his right hand, armed</li>
<li class="L7119" rel="L7119">with the knife, will be burnt off before his face; that, into wounds</li>
<li class="L7120" rel="L7120">which will be made in his arms, his breast, and his legs, there will be</li>
<li class="L7121" rel="L7121">poured boiling oil, melted lead, hot resin, wax, and sulphur; finally,</li>
<li class="L7122" rel="L7122">that he will be torn limb from limb by four strong horses. That old man</li>
<li class="L7123" rel="L7123">says, all this was actually done to a prisoner who made an attempt on</li>
<li class="L7124" rel="L7124">the life of the late King, Louis Fifteen. But how do I know if he lies?</li>
<li class="L7125" rel="L7125">I am not a scholar.”</li>
<li class="L7126" rel="L7126"></li>
<li class="L7127" rel="L7127">“Listen once again then, Jacques!” said the man with the restless hand</li>
<li class="L7128" rel="L7128">and the craving air. “The name of that prisoner was Damiens, and it was</li>
<li class="L7129" rel="L7129">all done in open day, in the open streets of this city of Paris; and</li>
<li class="L7130" rel="L7130">nothing was more noticed in the vast concourse that saw it done, than</li>
<li class="L7131" rel="L7131">the crowd of ladies of quality and fashion, who were full of eager</li>
<li class="L7132" rel="L7132">attention to the last--to the last, Jacques, prolonged until nightfall,</li>
<li class="L7133" rel="L7133">when he had lost two legs and an arm, and still breathed! And it was</li>
<li class="L7134" rel="L7134">done--why, how old are you?”</li>
<li class="L7135" rel="L7135"></li>
<li class="L7136" rel="L7136">“Thirty-five,” said the mender of roads, who looked sixty.</li>
<li class="L7137" rel="L7137"></li>
<li class="L7138" rel="L7138">“It was done when you were more than ten years old; you might have seen</li>
<li class="L7139" rel="L7139">it.”</li>
<li class="L7140" rel="L7140"></li>
<li class="L7141" rel="L7141">“Enough!” said Defarge, with grim impatience. “Long live the Devil! Go</li>
<li class="L7142" rel="L7142">on.”</li>
<li class="L7143" rel="L7143"></li>
<li class="L7144" rel="L7144">“Well! Some whisper this, some whisper that; they speak of nothing else;</li>
<li class="L7145" rel="L7145">even the fountain appears to fall to that tune. At length, on Sunday</li>
<li class="L7146" rel="L7146">night when all the village is asleep, come soldiers, winding down from</li>
<li class="L7147" rel="L7147">the prison, and their guns ring on the stones of the little street.</li>
<li class="L7148" rel="L7148">Workmen dig, workmen hammer, soldiers laugh and sing; in the morning, by</li>
<li class="L7149" rel="L7149">the fountain, there is raised a gallows forty feet high, poisoning the</li>
<li class="L7150" rel="L7150">water.”</li>
<li class="L7151" rel="L7151"></li>
<li class="L7152" rel="L7152">The mender of roads looked _through_ rather than _at_ the low ceiling,</li>
<li class="L7153" rel="L7153">and pointed as if he saw the gallows somewhere in the sky.</li>
<li class="L7154" rel="L7154"></li>
<li class="L7155" rel="L7155">“All work is stopped, all assemble there, nobody leads the cows out,</li>
<li class="L7156" rel="L7156">the cows are there with the rest. At midday, the roll of drums. Soldiers</li>
<li class="L7157" rel="L7157">have marched into the prison in the night, and he is in the midst</li>
<li class="L7158" rel="L7158">of many soldiers. He is bound as before, and in his mouth there is</li>
<li class="L7159" rel="L7159">a gag--tied so, with a tight string, making him look almost as if he</li>
<li class="L7160" rel="L7160">laughed.” He suggested it, by creasing his face with his two thumbs,</li>
<li class="L7161" rel="L7161">from the corners of his mouth to his ears. “On the top of the gallows is</li>
<li class="L7162" rel="L7162">fixed the knife, blade upwards, with its point in the air. He is hanged</li>
<li class="L7163" rel="L7163">there forty feet high--and is left hanging, poisoning the water.”</li>
<li class="L7164" rel="L7164"></li>
<li class="L7165" rel="L7165">They looked at one another, as he used his blue cap to wipe his face,</li>
<li class="L7166" rel="L7166">on which the perspiration had started afresh while he recalled the</li>
<li class="L7167" rel="L7167">spectacle.</li>
<li class="L7168" rel="L7168"></li>
<li class="L7169" rel="L7169">“It is frightful, messieurs. How can the women and the children draw</li>
<li class="L7170" rel="L7170">water! Who can gossip of an evening, under that shadow! Under it, have</li>
<li class="L7171" rel="L7171">I said? When I left the village, Monday evening as the sun was going to</li>
<li class="L7172" rel="L7172">bed, and looked back from the hill, the shadow struck across the church,</li>
<li class="L7173" rel="L7173">across the mill, across the prison--seemed to strike across the earth,</li>
<li class="L7174" rel="L7174">messieurs, to where the sky rests upon it!”</li>
<li class="L7175" rel="L7175"></li>
<li class="L7176" rel="L7176">The hungry man gnawed one of his fingers as he looked at the other</li>
<li class="L7177" rel="L7177">three, and his finger quivered with the craving that was on him.</li>
<li class="L7178" rel="L7178"></li>
<li class="L7179" rel="L7179">“That&#39;s all, messieurs. I left at sunset (as I had been warned to do),</li>
<li class="L7180" rel="L7180">and I walked on, that night and half next day, until I met (as I was</li>
<li class="L7181" rel="L7181">warned I should) this comrade. With him, I came on, now riding and now</li>
<li class="L7182" rel="L7182">walking, through the rest of yesterday and through last night. And here</li>
<li class="L7183" rel="L7183">you see me!”</li>
<li class="L7184" rel="L7184"></li>
<li class="L7185" rel="L7185">After a gloomy silence, the first Jacques said, “Good! You have acted</li>
<li class="L7186" rel="L7186">and recounted faithfully. Will you wait for us a little, outside the</li>
<li class="L7187" rel="L7187">door?”</li>
<li class="L7188" rel="L7188"></li>
<li class="L7189" rel="L7189">“Very willingly,” said the mender of roads. Whom Defarge escorted to the</li>
<li class="L7190" rel="L7190">top of the stairs, and, leaving seated there, returned.</li>
<li class="L7191" rel="L7191"></li>
<li class="L7192" rel="L7192">The three had risen, and their heads were together when he came back to</li>
<li class="L7193" rel="L7193">the garret.</li>
<li class="L7194" rel="L7194"></li>
<li class="L7195" rel="L7195">“How say you, Jacques?” demanded Number One. “To be registered?”</li>
<li class="L7196" rel="L7196"></li>
<li class="L7197" rel="L7197">“To be registered, as doomed to destruction,” returned Defarge.</li>
<li class="L7198" rel="L7198"></li>
<li class="L7199" rel="L7199">“Magnificent!” croaked the man with the craving.</li>
<li class="L7200" rel="L7200"></li>
<li class="L7201" rel="L7201">“The chateau, and all the race?” inquired the first.</li>
<li class="L7202" rel="L7202"></li>
<li class="L7203" rel="L7203">“The chateau and all the race,” returned Defarge. “Extermination.”</li>
<li class="L7204" rel="L7204"></li>
<li class="L7205" rel="L7205">The hungry man repeated, in a rapturous croak, “Magnificent!” and began</li>
<li class="L7206" rel="L7206">gnawing another finger.</li>
<li class="L7207" rel="L7207"></li>
<li class="L7208" rel="L7208">“Are you sure,” asked Jacques Two, of Defarge, “that no embarrassment</li>
<li class="L7209" rel="L7209">can arise from our manner of keeping the register? Without doubt it is</li>
<li class="L7210" rel="L7210">safe, for no one beyond ourselves can decipher it; but shall we always</li>
<li class="L7211" rel="L7211">be able to decipher it--or, I ought to say, will she?”</li>
<li class="L7212" rel="L7212"></li>
<li class="L7213" rel="L7213">“Jacques,” returned Defarge, drawing himself up, “if madame my wife</li>
<li class="L7214" rel="L7214">undertook to keep the register in her memory alone, she would not lose</li>
<li class="L7215" rel="L7215">a word of it--not a syllable of it. Knitted, in her own stitches and her</li>
<li class="L7216" rel="L7216">own symbols, it will always be as plain to her as the sun. Confide in</li>
<li class="L7217" rel="L7217">Madame Defarge. It would be easier for the weakest poltroon that lives,</li>
<li class="L7218" rel="L7218">to erase himself from existence, than to erase one letter of his name or</li>
<li class="L7219" rel="L7219">crimes from the knitted register of Madame Defarge.”</li>
<li class="L7220" rel="L7220"></li>
<li class="L7221" rel="L7221">There was a murmur of confidence and approval, and then the man who</li>
<li class="L7222" rel="L7222">hungered, asked: “Is this rustic to be sent back soon? I hope so. He is</li>
<li class="L7223" rel="L7223">very simple; is he not a little dangerous?”</li>
<li class="L7224" rel="L7224"></li>
<li class="L7225" rel="L7225">“He knows nothing,” said Defarge; “at least nothing more than would</li>
<li class="L7226" rel="L7226">easily elevate himself to a gallows of the same height. I charge myself</li>
<li class="L7227" rel="L7227">with him; let him remain with me; I will take care of him, and set him</li>
<li class="L7228" rel="L7228">on his road. He wishes to see the fine world--the King, the Queen, and</li>
<li class="L7229" rel="L7229">Court; let him see them on Sunday.”</li>
<li class="L7230" rel="L7230"></li>
<li class="L7231" rel="L7231">“What?” exclaimed the hungry man, staring. “Is it a good sign, that he</li>
<li class="L7232" rel="L7232">wishes to see Royalty and Nobility?”</li>
<li class="L7233" rel="L7233"></li>
<li class="L7234" rel="L7234">“Jacques,” said Defarge; “judiciously show a cat milk, if you wish her</li>
<li class="L7235" rel="L7235">to thirst for it. Judiciously show a dog his natural prey, if you wish</li>
<li class="L7236" rel="L7236">him to bring it down one day.”</li>
<li class="L7237" rel="L7237"></li>
<li class="L7238" rel="L7238">Nothing more was said, and the mender of roads, being found already</li>
<li class="L7239" rel="L7239">dozing on the topmost stair, was advised to lay himself down on the</li>
<li class="L7240" rel="L7240">pallet-bed and take some rest. He needed no persuasion, and was soon</li>
<li class="L7241" rel="L7241">asleep.</li>
<li class="L7242" rel="L7242"></li>
<li class="L7243" rel="L7243">Worse quarters than Defarge&#39;s wine-shop, could easily have been found</li>
<li class="L7244" rel="L7244">in Paris for a provincial slave of that degree. Saving for a mysterious</li>
<li class="L7245" rel="L7245">dread of madame by which he was constantly haunted, his life was very</li>
<li class="L7246" rel="L7246">new and agreeable. But, madame sat all day at her counter, so expressly</li>
<li class="L7247" rel="L7247">unconscious of him, and so particularly determined not to perceive that</li>
<li class="L7248" rel="L7248">his being there had any connection with anything below the surface, that</li>
<li class="L7249" rel="L7249">he shook in his wooden shoes whenever his eye lighted on her. For, he</li>
<li class="L7250" rel="L7250">contended with himself that it was impossible to foresee what that lady</li>
<li class="L7251" rel="L7251">might pretend next; and he felt assured that if she should take it</li>
<li class="L7252" rel="L7252">into her brightly ornamented head to pretend that she had seen him do a</li>
<li class="L7253" rel="L7253">murder and afterwards flay the victim, she would infallibly go through</li>
<li class="L7254" rel="L7254">with it until the play was played out.</li>
<li class="L7255" rel="L7255"></li>
<li class="L7256" rel="L7256">Therefore, when Sunday came, the mender of roads was not enchanted</li>
<li class="L7257" rel="L7257">(though he said he was) to find that madame was to accompany monsieur</li>
<li class="L7258" rel="L7258">and himself to Versailles. It was additionally disconcerting to have</li>
<li class="L7259" rel="L7259">madame knitting all the way there, in a public conveyance; it was</li>
<li class="L7260" rel="L7260">additionally disconcerting yet, to have madame in the crowd in the</li>
<li class="L7261" rel="L7261">afternoon, still with her knitting in her hands as the crowd waited to</li>
<li class="L7262" rel="L7262">see the carriage of the King and Queen.</li>
<li class="L7263" rel="L7263"></li>
<li class="L7264" rel="L7264">“You work hard, madame,” said a man near her.</li>
<li class="L7265" rel="L7265"></li>
<li class="L7266" rel="L7266">“Yes,” answered Madame Defarge; “I have a good deal to do.”</li>
<li class="L7267" rel="L7267"></li>
<li class="L7268" rel="L7268">“What do you make, madame?”</li>
<li class="L7269" rel="L7269"></li>
<li class="L7270" rel="L7270">“Many things.”</li>
<li class="L7271" rel="L7271"></li>
<li class="L7272" rel="L7272">“For instance--”</li>
<li class="L7273" rel="L7273"></li>
<li class="L7274" rel="L7274">“For instance,” returned Madame Defarge, composedly, “shrouds.”</li>
<li class="L7275" rel="L7275"></li>
<li class="L7276" rel="L7276">The man moved a little further away, as soon as he could, and the mender</li>
<li class="L7277" rel="L7277">of roads fanned himself with his blue cap: feeling it mightily close</li>
<li class="L7278" rel="L7278">and oppressive. If he needed a King and Queen to restore him, he was</li>
<li class="L7279" rel="L7279">fortunate in having his remedy at hand; for, soon the large-faced King</li>
<li class="L7280" rel="L7280">and the fair-faced Queen came in their golden coach, attended by the</li>
<li class="L7281" rel="L7281">shining Bull&#39;s Eye of their Court, a glittering multitude of laughing</li>
<li class="L7282" rel="L7282">ladies and fine lords; and in jewels and silks and powder and splendour</li>
<li class="L7283" rel="L7283">and elegantly spurning figures and handsomely disdainful faces of both</li>
<li class="L7284" rel="L7284">sexes, the mender of roads bathed himself, so much to his temporary</li>
<li class="L7285" rel="L7285">intoxication, that he cried Long live the King, Long live the Queen,</li>
<li class="L7286" rel="L7286">Long live everybody and everything! as if he had never heard of</li>
<li class="L7287" rel="L7287">ubiquitous Jacques in his time. Then, there were gardens, courtyards,</li>
<li class="L7288" rel="L7288">terraces, fountains, green banks, more King and Queen, more Bull&#39;s Eye,</li>
<li class="L7289" rel="L7289">more lords and ladies, more Long live they all! until he absolutely wept</li>
<li class="L7290" rel="L7290">with sentiment. During the whole of this scene, which lasted some three</li>
<li class="L7291" rel="L7291">hours, he had plenty of shouting and weeping and sentimental company,</li>
<li class="L7292" rel="L7292">and throughout Defarge held him by the collar, as if to restrain him</li>
<li class="L7293" rel="L7293">from flying at the objects of his brief devotion and tearing them to</li>
<li class="L7294" rel="L7294">pieces.</li>
<li class="L7295" rel="L7295"></li>
<li class="L7296" rel="L7296">“Bravo!” said Defarge, clapping him on the back when it was over, like a</li>
<li class="L7297" rel="L7297">patron; “you are a good boy!”</li>
<li class="L7298" rel="L7298"></li>
<li class="L7299" rel="L7299">The mender of roads was now coming to himself, and was mistrustful of</li>
<li class="L7300" rel="L7300">having made a mistake in his late demonstrations; but no.</li>
<li class="L7301" rel="L7301"></li>
<li class="L7302" rel="L7302">“You are the fellow we want,” said Defarge, in his ear; “you make</li>
<li class="L7303" rel="L7303">these fools believe that it will last for ever. Then, they are the more</li>
<li class="L7304" rel="L7304">insolent, and it is the nearer ended.”</li>
<li class="L7305" rel="L7305"></li>
<li class="L7306" rel="L7306">“Hey!” cried the mender of roads, reflectively; “that&#39;s true.”</li>
<li class="L7307" rel="L7307"></li>
<li class="L7308" rel="L7308">“These fools know nothing. While they despise your breath, and would</li>
<li class="L7309" rel="L7309">stop it for ever and ever, in you or in a hundred like you rather than</li>
<li class="L7310" rel="L7310">in one of their own horses or dogs, they only know what your breath</li>
<li class="L7311" rel="L7311">tells them. Let it deceive them, then, a little longer; it cannot</li>
<li class="L7312" rel="L7312">deceive them too much.”</li>
<li class="L7313" rel="L7313"></li>
<li class="L7314" rel="L7314">Madame Defarge looked superciliously at the client, and nodded in</li>
<li class="L7315" rel="L7315">confirmation.</li>
<li class="L7316" rel="L7316"></li>
<li class="L7317" rel="L7317">“As to you,” said she, “you would shout and shed tears for anything, if</li>
<li class="L7318" rel="L7318">it made a show and a noise. Say! Would you not?”</li>
<li class="L7319" rel="L7319"></li>
<li class="L7320" rel="L7320">“Truly, madame, I think so. For the moment.”</li>
<li class="L7321" rel="L7321"></li>
<li class="L7322" rel="L7322">“If you were shown a great heap of dolls, and were set upon them to</li>
<li class="L7323" rel="L7323">pluck them to pieces and despoil them for your own advantage, you would</li>
<li class="L7324" rel="L7324">pick out the richest and gayest. Say! Would you not?”</li>
<li class="L7325" rel="L7325"></li>
<li class="L7326" rel="L7326">“Truly yes, madame.”</li>
<li class="L7327" rel="L7327"></li>
<li class="L7328" rel="L7328">“Yes. And if you were shown a flock of birds, unable to fly, and were</li>
<li class="L7329" rel="L7329">set upon them to strip them of their feathers for your own advantage,</li>
<li class="L7330" rel="L7330">you would set upon the birds of the finest feathers; would you not?”</li>
<li class="L7331" rel="L7331"></li>
<li class="L7332" rel="L7332">“It is true, madame.”</li>
<li class="L7333" rel="L7333"></li>
<li class="L7334" rel="L7334">“You have seen both dolls and birds to-day,” said Madame Defarge, with</li>
<li class="L7335" rel="L7335">a wave of her hand towards the place where they had last been apparent;</li>
<li class="L7336" rel="L7336">“now, go home!”</li>
<li class="L7337" rel="L7337"></li>
<li class="L7338" rel="L7338"></li>
<li class="L7339" rel="L7339"></li>
<li class="L7340" rel="L7340"></li>
<li class="L7341" rel="L7341">XVI. Still Knitting</li>
<li class="L7342" rel="L7342"></li>
<li class="L7343" rel="L7343"></li>
<li class="L7344" rel="L7344">Madame Defarge and monsieur her husband returned amicably to the</li>
<li class="L7345" rel="L7345">bosom of Saint Antoine, while a speck in a blue cap toiled through the</li>
<li class="L7346" rel="L7346">darkness, and through the dust, and down the weary miles of avenue by</li>
<li class="L7347" rel="L7347">the wayside, slowly tending towards that point of the compass where</li>
<li class="L7348" rel="L7348">the chateau of Monsieur the Marquis, now in his grave, listened to</li>
<li class="L7349" rel="L7349">the whispering trees. Such ample leisure had the stone faces, now,</li>
<li class="L7350" rel="L7350">for listening to the trees and to the fountain, that the few village</li>
<li class="L7351" rel="L7351">scarecrows who, in their quest for herbs to eat and fragments of dead</li>
<li class="L7352" rel="L7352">stick to burn, strayed within sight of the great stone courtyard and</li>
<li class="L7353" rel="L7353">terrace staircase, had it borne in upon their starved fancy that</li>
<li class="L7354" rel="L7354">the expression of the faces was altered. A rumour just lived in the</li>
<li class="L7355" rel="L7355">village--had a faint and bare existence there, as its people had--that</li>
<li class="L7356" rel="L7356">when the knife struck home, the faces changed, from faces of pride to</li>
<li class="L7357" rel="L7357">faces of anger and pain; also, that when that dangling figure was hauled</li>
<li class="L7358" rel="L7358">up forty feet above the fountain, they changed again, and bore a cruel</li>
<li class="L7359" rel="L7359">look of being avenged, which they would henceforth bear for ever. In the</li>
<li class="L7360" rel="L7360">stone face over the great window of the bed-chamber where the murder</li>
<li class="L7361" rel="L7361">was done, two fine dints were pointed out in the sculptured nose, which</li>
<li class="L7362" rel="L7362">everybody recognised, and which nobody had seen of old; and on the</li>
<li class="L7363" rel="L7363">scarce occasions when two or three ragged peasants emerged from the</li>
<li class="L7364" rel="L7364">crowd to take a hurried peep at Monsieur the Marquis petrified, a</li>
<li class="L7365" rel="L7365">skinny finger would not have pointed to it for a minute, before they all</li>
<li class="L7366" rel="L7366">started away among the moss and leaves, like the more fortunate hares</li>
<li class="L7367" rel="L7367">who could find a living there.</li>
<li class="L7368" rel="L7368"></li>
<li class="L7369" rel="L7369">Chateau and hut, stone face and dangling figure, the red stain on the</li>
<li class="L7370" rel="L7370">stone floor, and the pure water in the village well--thousands of acres</li>
<li class="L7371" rel="L7371">of land--a whole province of France--all France itself--lay under the</li>
<li class="L7372" rel="L7372">night sky, concentrated into a faint hair-breadth line. So does a whole</li>
<li class="L7373" rel="L7373">world, with all its greatnesses and littlenesses, lie in a twinkling</li>
<li class="L7374" rel="L7374">star. And as mere human knowledge can split a ray of light and analyse</li>
<li class="L7375" rel="L7375">the manner of its composition, so, sublimer intelligences may read in</li>
<li class="L7376" rel="L7376">the feeble shining of this earth of ours, every thought and act, every</li>
<li class="L7377" rel="L7377">vice and virtue, of every responsible creature on it.</li>
<li class="L7378" rel="L7378"></li>
<li class="L7379" rel="L7379">The Defarges, husband and wife, came lumbering under the starlight,</li>
<li class="L7380" rel="L7380">in their public vehicle, to that gate of Paris whereunto their</li>
<li class="L7381" rel="L7381">journey naturally tended. There was the usual stoppage at the barrier</li>
<li class="L7382" rel="L7382">guardhouse, and the usual lanterns came glancing forth for the usual</li>
<li class="L7383" rel="L7383">examination and inquiry. Monsieur Defarge alighted; knowing one or two</li>
<li class="L7384" rel="L7384">of the soldiery there, and one of the police. The latter he was intimate</li>
<li class="L7385" rel="L7385">with, and affectionately embraced.</li>
<li class="L7386" rel="L7386"></li>
<li class="L7387" rel="L7387">When Saint Antoine had again enfolded the Defarges in his dusky wings,</li>
<li class="L7388" rel="L7388">and they, having finally alighted near the Saint&#39;s boundaries, were</li>
<li class="L7389" rel="L7389">picking their way on foot through the black mud and offal of his</li>
<li class="L7390" rel="L7390">streets, Madame Defarge spoke to her husband:</li>
<li class="L7391" rel="L7391"></li>
<li class="L7392" rel="L7392">“Say then, my friend; what did Jacques of the police tell thee?”</li>
<li class="L7393" rel="L7393"></li>
<li class="L7394" rel="L7394">“Very little to-night, but all he knows. There is another spy</li>
<li class="L7395" rel="L7395">commissioned for our quarter. There may be many more, for all that he</li>
<li class="L7396" rel="L7396">can say, but he knows of one.”</li>
<li class="L7397" rel="L7397"></li>
<li class="L7398" rel="L7398">“Eh well!” said Madame Defarge, raising her eyebrows with a cool</li>
<li class="L7399" rel="L7399">business air. “It is necessary to register him. How do they call that</li>
<li class="L7400" rel="L7400">man?”</li>
<li class="L7401" rel="L7401"></li>
<li class="L7402" rel="L7402">“He is English.”</li>
<li class="L7403" rel="L7403"></li>
<li class="L7404" rel="L7404">“So much the better. His name?”</li>
<li class="L7405" rel="L7405"></li>
<li class="L7406" rel="L7406">“Barsad,” said Defarge, making it French by pronunciation. But, he had</li>
<li class="L7407" rel="L7407">been so careful to get it accurately, that he then spelt it with perfect</li>
<li class="L7408" rel="L7408">correctness.</li>
<li class="L7409" rel="L7409"></li>
<li class="L7410" rel="L7410">“Barsad,” repeated madame. “Good. Christian name?”</li>
<li class="L7411" rel="L7411"></li>
<li class="L7412" rel="L7412">“John.”</li>
<li class="L7413" rel="L7413"></li>
<li class="L7414" rel="L7414">“John Barsad,” repeated madame, after murmuring it once to herself.</li>
<li class="L7415" rel="L7415">“Good. His appearance; is it known?”</li>
<li class="L7416" rel="L7416"></li>
<li class="L7417" rel="L7417">“Age, about forty years; height, about five feet nine; black hair;</li>
<li class="L7418" rel="L7418">complexion dark; generally, rather handsome visage; eyes dark, face</li>
<li class="L7419" rel="L7419">thin, long, and sallow; nose aquiline, but not straight, having a</li>
<li class="L7420" rel="L7420">peculiar inclination towards the left cheek; expression, therefore,</li>
<li class="L7421" rel="L7421">sinister.”</li>
<li class="L7422" rel="L7422"></li>
<li class="L7423" rel="L7423">“Eh my faith. It is a portrait!” said madame, laughing. “He shall be</li>
<li class="L7424" rel="L7424">registered to-morrow.”</li>
<li class="L7425" rel="L7425"></li>
<li class="L7426" rel="L7426">They turned into the wine-shop, which was closed (for it was midnight),</li>
<li class="L7427" rel="L7427">and where Madame Defarge immediately took her post at her desk, counted</li>
<li class="L7428" rel="L7428">the small moneys that had been taken during her absence, examined the</li>
<li class="L7429" rel="L7429">stock, went through the entries in the book, made other entries of</li>
<li class="L7430" rel="L7430">her own, checked the serving man in every possible way, and finally</li>
<li class="L7431" rel="L7431">dismissed him to bed. Then she turned out the contents of the bowl</li>
<li class="L7432" rel="L7432">of money for the second time, and began knotting them up in her</li>
<li class="L7433" rel="L7433">handkerchief, in a chain of separate knots, for safe keeping through the</li>
<li class="L7434" rel="L7434">night. All this while, Defarge, with his pipe in his mouth, walked</li>
<li class="L7435" rel="L7435">up and down, complacently admiring, but never interfering; in which</li>
<li class="L7436" rel="L7436">condition, indeed, as to the business and his domestic affairs, he</li>
<li class="L7437" rel="L7437">walked up and down through life.</li>
<li class="L7438" rel="L7438"></li>
<li class="L7439" rel="L7439">The night was hot, and the shop, close shut and surrounded by so foul a</li>
<li class="L7440" rel="L7440">neighbourhood, was ill-smelling. Monsieur Defarge&#39;s olfactory sense was</li>
<li class="L7441" rel="L7441">by no means delicate, but the stock of wine smelt much stronger than</li>
<li class="L7442" rel="L7442">it ever tasted, and so did the stock of rum and brandy and aniseed. He</li>
<li class="L7443" rel="L7443">whiffed the compound of scents away, as he put down his smoked-out pipe.</li>
<li class="L7444" rel="L7444"></li>
<li class="L7445" rel="L7445">“You are fatigued,” said madame, raising her glance as she knotted the</li>
<li class="L7446" rel="L7446">money. “There are only the usual odours.”</li>
<li class="L7447" rel="L7447"></li>
<li class="L7448" rel="L7448">“I am a little tired,” her husband acknowledged.</li>
<li class="L7449" rel="L7449"></li>
<li class="L7450" rel="L7450">“You are a little depressed, too,” said madame, whose quick eyes had</li>
<li class="L7451" rel="L7451">never been so intent on the accounts, but they had had a ray or two for</li>
<li class="L7452" rel="L7452">him. “Oh, the men, the men!”</li>
<li class="L7453" rel="L7453"></li>
<li class="L7454" rel="L7454">“But my dear!” began Defarge.</li>
<li class="L7455" rel="L7455"></li>
<li class="L7456" rel="L7456">“But my dear!” repeated madame, nodding firmly; “but my dear! You are</li>
<li class="L7457" rel="L7457">faint of heart to-night, my dear!”</li>
<li class="L7458" rel="L7458"></li>
<li class="L7459" rel="L7459">“Well, then,” said Defarge, as if a thought were wrung out of his</li>
<li class="L7460" rel="L7460">breast, “it _is_ a long time.”</li>
<li class="L7461" rel="L7461"></li>
<li class="L7462" rel="L7462">“It is a long time,” repeated his wife; “and when is it not a long time?</li>
<li class="L7463" rel="L7463">Vengeance and retribution require a long time; it is the rule.”</li>
<li class="L7464" rel="L7464"></li>
<li class="L7465" rel="L7465">“It does not take a long time to strike a man with Lightning,” said</li>
<li class="L7466" rel="L7466">Defarge.</li>
<li class="L7467" rel="L7467"></li>
<li class="L7468" rel="L7468">“How long,” demanded madame, composedly, “does it take to make and store</li>
<li class="L7469" rel="L7469">the lightning? Tell me.”</li>
<li class="L7470" rel="L7470"></li>
<li class="L7471" rel="L7471">Defarge raised his head thoughtfully, as if there were something in that</li>
<li class="L7472" rel="L7472">too.</li>
<li class="L7473" rel="L7473"></li>
<li class="L7474" rel="L7474">“It does not take a long time,” said madame, “for an earthquake to</li>
<li class="L7475" rel="L7475">swallow a town. Eh well! Tell me how long it takes to prepare the</li>
<li class="L7476" rel="L7476">earthquake?”</li>
<li class="L7477" rel="L7477"></li>
<li class="L7478" rel="L7478">“A long time, I suppose,” said Defarge.</li>
<li class="L7479" rel="L7479"></li>
<li class="L7480" rel="L7480">“But when it is ready, it takes place, and grinds to pieces everything</li>
<li class="L7481" rel="L7481">before it. In the meantime, it is always preparing, though it is not</li>
<li class="L7482" rel="L7482">seen or heard. That is your consolation. Keep it.”</li>
<li class="L7483" rel="L7483"></li>
<li class="L7484" rel="L7484">She tied a knot with flashing eyes, as if it throttled a foe.</li>
<li class="L7485" rel="L7485"></li>
<li class="L7486" rel="L7486">“I tell thee,” said madame, extending her right hand, for emphasis,</li>
<li class="L7487" rel="L7487">“that although it is a long time on the road, it is on the road and</li>
<li class="L7488" rel="L7488">coming. I tell thee it never retreats, and never stops. I tell thee it</li>
<li class="L7489" rel="L7489">is always advancing. Look around and consider the lives of all the world</li>
<li class="L7490" rel="L7490">that we know, consider the faces of all the world that we know, consider</li>
<li class="L7491" rel="L7491">the rage and discontent to which the Jacquerie addresses itself with</li>
<li class="L7492" rel="L7492">more and more of certainty every hour. Can such things last? Bah! I mock</li>
<li class="L7493" rel="L7493">you.”</li>
<li class="L7494" rel="L7494"></li>
<li class="L7495" rel="L7495">“My brave wife,” returned Defarge, standing before her with his head</li>
<li class="L7496" rel="L7496">a little bent, and his hands clasped at his back, like a docile and</li>
<li class="L7497" rel="L7497">attentive pupil before his catechist, “I do not question all this. But</li>
<li class="L7498" rel="L7498">it has lasted a long time, and it is possible--you know well, my wife,</li>
<li class="L7499" rel="L7499">it is possible--that it may not come, during our lives.”</li>
<li class="L7500" rel="L7500"></li>
<li class="L7501" rel="L7501">“Eh well! How then?” demanded madame, tying another knot, as if there</li>
<li class="L7502" rel="L7502">were another enemy strangled.</li>
<li class="L7503" rel="L7503"></li>
<li class="L7504" rel="L7504">“Well!” said Defarge, with a half complaining and half apologetic shrug.</li>
<li class="L7505" rel="L7505">“We shall not see the triumph.”</li>
<li class="L7506" rel="L7506"></li>
<li class="L7507" rel="L7507">“We shall have helped it,” returned madame, with her extended hand in</li>
<li class="L7508" rel="L7508">strong action. “Nothing that we do, is done in vain. I believe, with all</li>
<li class="L7509" rel="L7509">my soul, that we shall see the triumph. But even if not, even if I knew</li>
<li class="L7510" rel="L7510">certainly not, show me the neck of an aristocrat and tyrant, and still I</li>
<li class="L7511" rel="L7511">would--”</li>
<li class="L7512" rel="L7512"></li>
<li class="L7513" rel="L7513">Then madame, with her teeth set, tied a very terrible knot indeed.</li>
<li class="L7514" rel="L7514"></li>
<li class="L7515" rel="L7515">“Hold!” cried Defarge, reddening a little as if he felt charged with</li>
<li class="L7516" rel="L7516">cowardice; “I too, my dear, will stop at nothing.”</li>
<li class="L7517" rel="L7517"></li>
<li class="L7518" rel="L7518">“Yes! But it is your weakness that you sometimes need to see your victim</li>
<li class="L7519" rel="L7519">and your opportunity, to sustain you. Sustain yourself without that.</li>
<li class="L7520" rel="L7520">When the time comes, let loose a tiger and a devil; but wait for the</li>
<li class="L7521" rel="L7521">time with the tiger and the devil chained--not shown--yet always ready.”</li>
<li class="L7522" rel="L7522"></li>
<li class="L7523" rel="L7523">Madame enforced the conclusion of this piece of advice by striking her</li>
<li class="L7524" rel="L7524">little counter with her chain of money as if she knocked its brains</li>
<li class="L7525" rel="L7525">out, and then gathering the heavy handkerchief under her arm in a serene</li>
<li class="L7526" rel="L7526">manner, and observing that it was time to go to bed.</li>
<li class="L7527" rel="L7527"></li>
<li class="L7528" rel="L7528">Next noontide saw the admirable woman in her usual place in the</li>
<li class="L7529" rel="L7529">wine-shop, knitting away assiduously. A rose lay beside her, and if she</li>
<li class="L7530" rel="L7530">now and then glanced at the flower, it was with no infraction of her</li>
<li class="L7531" rel="L7531">usual preoccupied air. There were a few customers, drinking or not</li>
<li class="L7532" rel="L7532">drinking, standing or seated, sprinkled about. The day was very hot,</li>
<li class="L7533" rel="L7533">and heaps of flies, who were extending their inquisitive and adventurous</li>
<li class="L7534" rel="L7534">perquisitions into all the glutinous little glasses near madame, fell</li>
<li class="L7535" rel="L7535">dead at the bottom. Their decease made no impression on the other flies</li>
<li class="L7536" rel="L7536">out promenading, who looked at them in the coolest manner (as if they</li>
<li class="L7537" rel="L7537">themselves were elephants, or something as far removed), until they met</li>
<li class="L7538" rel="L7538">the same fate. Curious to consider how heedless flies are!--perhaps they</li>
<li class="L7539" rel="L7539">thought as much at Court that sunny summer day.</li>
<li class="L7540" rel="L7540"></li>
<li class="L7541" rel="L7541">A figure entering at the door threw a shadow on Madame Defarge which she</li>
<li class="L7542" rel="L7542">felt to be a new one. She laid down her knitting, and began to pin her</li>
<li class="L7543" rel="L7543">rose in her head-dress, before she looked at the figure.</li>
<li class="L7544" rel="L7544"></li>
<li class="L7545" rel="L7545">It was curious. The moment Madame Defarge took up the rose, the</li>
<li class="L7546" rel="L7546">customers ceased talking, and began gradually to drop out of the</li>
<li class="L7547" rel="L7547">wine-shop.</li>
<li class="L7548" rel="L7548"></li>
<li class="L7549" rel="L7549">“Good day, madame,” said the new-comer.</li>
<li class="L7550" rel="L7550"></li>
<li class="L7551" rel="L7551">“Good day, monsieur.”</li>
<li class="L7552" rel="L7552"></li>
<li class="L7553" rel="L7553">She said it aloud, but added to herself, as she resumed her knitting:</li>
<li class="L7554" rel="L7554">“Hah! Good day, age about forty, height about five feet nine, black</li>
<li class="L7555" rel="L7555">hair, generally rather handsome visage, complexion dark, eyes dark,</li>
<li class="L7556" rel="L7556">thin, long and sallow face, aquiline nose but not straight, having a</li>
<li class="L7557" rel="L7557">peculiar inclination towards the left cheek which imparts a sinister</li>
<li class="L7558" rel="L7558">expression! Good day, one and all!”</li>
<li class="L7559" rel="L7559"></li>
<li class="L7560" rel="L7560">“Have the goodness to give me a little glass of old cognac, and a</li>
<li class="L7561" rel="L7561">mouthful of cool fresh water, madame.”</li>
<li class="L7562" rel="L7562"></li>
<li class="L7563" rel="L7563">Madame complied with a polite air.</li>
<li class="L7564" rel="L7564"></li>
<li class="L7565" rel="L7565">“Marvellous cognac this, madame!”</li>
<li class="L7566" rel="L7566"></li>
<li class="L7567" rel="L7567">It was the first time it had ever been so complimented, and Madame</li>
<li class="L7568" rel="L7568">Defarge knew enough of its antecedents to know better. She said,</li>
<li class="L7569" rel="L7569">however, that the cognac was flattered, and took up her knitting. The</li>
<li class="L7570" rel="L7570">visitor watched her fingers for a few moments, and took the opportunity</li>
<li class="L7571" rel="L7571">of observing the place in general.</li>
<li class="L7572" rel="L7572"></li>
<li class="L7573" rel="L7573">“You knit with great skill, madame.”</li>
<li class="L7574" rel="L7574"></li>
<li class="L7575" rel="L7575">“I am accustomed to it.”</li>
<li class="L7576" rel="L7576"></li>
<li class="L7577" rel="L7577">“A pretty pattern too!”</li>
<li class="L7578" rel="L7578"></li>
<li class="L7579" rel="L7579">“_You_ think so?” said madame, looking at him with a smile.</li>
<li class="L7580" rel="L7580"></li>
<li class="L7581" rel="L7581">“Decidedly. May one ask what it is for?”</li>
<li class="L7582" rel="L7582"></li>
<li class="L7583" rel="L7583">“Pastime,” said madame, still looking at him with a smile while her</li>
<li class="L7584" rel="L7584">fingers moved nimbly.</li>
<li class="L7585" rel="L7585"></li>
<li class="L7586" rel="L7586">“Not for use?”</li>
<li class="L7587" rel="L7587"></li>
<li class="L7588" rel="L7588">“That depends. I may find a use for it one day. If I do--Well,” said</li>
<li class="L7589" rel="L7589">madame, drawing a breath and nodding her head with a stern kind of</li>
<li class="L7590" rel="L7590">coquetry, “I&#39;ll use it!”</li>
<li class="L7591" rel="L7591"></li>
<li class="L7592" rel="L7592">It was remarkable; but, the taste of Saint Antoine seemed to be</li>
<li class="L7593" rel="L7593">decidedly opposed to a rose on the head-dress of Madame Defarge. Two</li>
<li class="L7594" rel="L7594">men had entered separately, and had been about to order drink, when,</li>
<li class="L7595" rel="L7595">catching sight of that novelty, they faltered, made a pretence of</li>
<li class="L7596" rel="L7596">looking about as if for some friend who was not there, and went away.</li>
<li class="L7597" rel="L7597">Nor, of those who had been there when this visitor entered, was there</li>
<li class="L7598" rel="L7598">one left. They had all dropped off. The spy had kept his eyes open,</li>
<li class="L7599" rel="L7599">but had been able to detect no sign. They had lounged away in a</li>
<li class="L7600" rel="L7600">poverty-stricken, purposeless, accidental manner, quite natural and</li>
<li class="L7601" rel="L7601">unimpeachable.</li>
<li class="L7602" rel="L7602"></li>
<li class="L7603" rel="L7603">“_John_,” thought madame, checking off her work as her fingers knitted,</li>
<li class="L7604" rel="L7604">and her eyes looked at the stranger. “Stay long enough, and I shall knit</li>
<li class="L7605" rel="L7605">&#39;BARSAD&#39; before you go.”</li>
<li class="L7606" rel="L7606"></li>
<li class="L7607" rel="L7607">“You have a husband, madame?”</li>
<li class="L7608" rel="L7608"></li>
<li class="L7609" rel="L7609">“I have.”</li>
<li class="L7610" rel="L7610"></li>
<li class="L7611" rel="L7611">“Children?”</li>
<li class="L7612" rel="L7612"></li>
<li class="L7613" rel="L7613">“No children.”</li>
<li class="L7614" rel="L7614"></li>
<li class="L7615" rel="L7615">“Business seems bad?”</li>
<li class="L7616" rel="L7616"></li>
<li class="L7617" rel="L7617">“Business is very bad; the people are so poor.”</li>
<li class="L7618" rel="L7618"></li>
<li class="L7619" rel="L7619">“Ah, the unfortunate, miserable people! So oppressed, too--as you say.”</li>
<li class="L7620" rel="L7620"></li>
<li class="L7621" rel="L7621">“As _you_ say,” madame retorted, correcting him, and deftly knitting an</li>
<li class="L7622" rel="L7622">extra something into his name that boded him no good.</li>
<li class="L7623" rel="L7623"></li>
<li class="L7624" rel="L7624">“Pardon me; certainly it was I who said so, but you naturally think so.</li>
<li class="L7625" rel="L7625">Of course.”</li>
<li class="L7626" rel="L7626"></li>
<li class="L7627" rel="L7627">“_I_ think?” returned madame, in a high voice. “I and my husband have</li>
<li class="L7628" rel="L7628">enough to do to keep this wine-shop open, without thinking. All we</li>
<li class="L7629" rel="L7629">think, here, is how to live. That is the subject _we_ think of, and</li>
<li class="L7630" rel="L7630">it gives us, from morning to night, enough to think about, without</li>
<li class="L7631" rel="L7631">embarrassing our heads concerning others. _I_ think for others? No, no.”</li>
<li class="L7632" rel="L7632"></li>
<li class="L7633" rel="L7633">The spy, who was there to pick up any crumbs he could find or make, did</li>
<li class="L7634" rel="L7634">not allow his baffled state to express itself in his sinister face; but,</li>
<li class="L7635" rel="L7635">stood with an air of gossiping gallantry, leaning his elbow on Madame</li>
<li class="L7636" rel="L7636">Defarge&#39;s little counter, and occasionally sipping his cognac.</li>
<li class="L7637" rel="L7637"></li>
<li class="L7638" rel="L7638">“A bad business this, madame, of Gaspard&#39;s execution. Ah! the poor</li>
<li class="L7639" rel="L7639">Gaspard!” With a sigh of great compassion.</li>
<li class="L7640" rel="L7640"></li>
<li class="L7641" rel="L7641">“My faith!” returned madame, coolly and lightly, “if people use knives</li>
<li class="L7642" rel="L7642">for such purposes, they have to pay for it. He knew beforehand what the</li>
<li class="L7643" rel="L7643">price of his luxury was; he has paid the price.”</li>
<li class="L7644" rel="L7644"></li>
<li class="L7645" rel="L7645">“I believe,” said the spy, dropping his soft voice to a tone</li>
<li class="L7646" rel="L7646">that invited confidence, and expressing an injured revolutionary</li>
<li class="L7647" rel="L7647">susceptibility in every muscle of his wicked face: “I believe there</li>
<li class="L7648" rel="L7648">is much compassion and anger in this neighbourhood, touching the poor</li>
<li class="L7649" rel="L7649">fellow? Between ourselves.”</li>
<li class="L7650" rel="L7650"></li>
<li class="L7651" rel="L7651">“Is there?” asked madame, vacantly.</li>
<li class="L7652" rel="L7652"></li>
<li class="L7653" rel="L7653">“Is there not?”</li>
<li class="L7654" rel="L7654"></li>
<li class="L7655" rel="L7655">“--Here is my husband!” said Madame Defarge.</li>
<li class="L7656" rel="L7656"></li>
<li class="L7657" rel="L7657">As the keeper of the wine-shop entered at the door, the spy saluted</li>
<li class="L7658" rel="L7658">him by touching his hat, and saying, with an engaging smile, “Good day,</li>
<li class="L7659" rel="L7659">Jacques!” Defarge stopped short, and stared at him.</li>
<li class="L7660" rel="L7660"></li>
<li class="L7661" rel="L7661">“Good day, Jacques!” the spy repeated; with not quite so much</li>
<li class="L7662" rel="L7662">confidence, or quite so easy a smile under the stare.</li>
<li class="L7663" rel="L7663"></li>
<li class="L7664" rel="L7664">“You deceive yourself, monsieur,” returned the keeper of the wine-shop.</li>
<li class="L7665" rel="L7665">“You mistake me for another. That is not my name. I am Ernest Defarge.”</li>
<li class="L7666" rel="L7666"></li>
<li class="L7667" rel="L7667">“It is all the same,” said the spy, airily, but discomfited too: “good</li>
<li class="L7668" rel="L7668">day!”</li>
<li class="L7669" rel="L7669"></li>
<li class="L7670" rel="L7670">“Good day!” answered Defarge, drily.</li>
<li class="L7671" rel="L7671"></li>
<li class="L7672" rel="L7672">“I was saying to madame, with whom I had the pleasure of chatting when</li>
<li class="L7673" rel="L7673">you entered, that they tell me there is--and no wonder!--much sympathy</li>
<li class="L7674" rel="L7674">and anger in Saint Antoine, touching the unhappy fate of poor Gaspard.”</li>
<li class="L7675" rel="L7675"></li>
<li class="L7676" rel="L7676">“No one has told me so,” said Defarge, shaking his head. “I know nothing</li>
<li class="L7677" rel="L7677">of it.”</li>
<li class="L7678" rel="L7678"></li>
<li class="L7679" rel="L7679">Having said it, he passed behind the little counter, and stood with his</li>
<li class="L7680" rel="L7680">hand on the back of his wife&#39;s chair, looking over that barrier at the</li>
<li class="L7681" rel="L7681">person to whom they were both opposed, and whom either of them would</li>
<li class="L7682" rel="L7682">have shot with the greatest satisfaction.</li>
<li class="L7683" rel="L7683"></li>
<li class="L7684" rel="L7684">The spy, well used to his business, did not change his unconscious</li>
<li class="L7685" rel="L7685">attitude, but drained his little glass of cognac, took a sip of fresh</li>
<li class="L7686" rel="L7686">water, and asked for another glass of cognac. Madame Defarge poured it</li>
<li class="L7687" rel="L7687">out for him, took to her knitting again, and hummed a little song over</li>
<li class="L7688" rel="L7688">it.</li>
<li class="L7689" rel="L7689"></li>
<li class="L7690" rel="L7690">“You seem to know this quarter well; that is to say, better than I do?”</li>
<li class="L7691" rel="L7691"> observed Defarge.</li>
<li class="L7692" rel="L7692"></li>
<li class="L7693" rel="L7693">“Not at all, but I hope to know it better. I am so profoundly interested</li>
<li class="L7694" rel="L7694">in its miserable inhabitants.”</li>
<li class="L7695" rel="L7695"></li>
<li class="L7696" rel="L7696">“Hah!” muttered Defarge.</li>
<li class="L7697" rel="L7697"></li>
<li class="L7698" rel="L7698">“The pleasure of conversing with you, Monsieur Defarge, recalls to me,”</li>
<li class="L7699" rel="L7699"> pursued the spy, “that I have the honour of cherishing some interesting</li>
<li class="L7700" rel="L7700">associations with your name.”</li>
<li class="L7701" rel="L7701"></li>
<li class="L7702" rel="L7702">“Indeed!” said Defarge, with much indifference.</li>
<li class="L7703" rel="L7703"></li>
<li class="L7704" rel="L7704">“Yes, indeed. When Doctor Manette was released, you, his old domestic,</li>
<li class="L7705" rel="L7705">had the charge of him, I know. He was delivered to you. You see I am</li>
<li class="L7706" rel="L7706">informed of the circumstances?”</li>
<li class="L7707" rel="L7707"></li>
<li class="L7708" rel="L7708">“Such is the fact, certainly,” said Defarge. He had had it conveyed</li>
<li class="L7709" rel="L7709">to him, in an accidental touch of his wife&#39;s elbow as she knitted and</li>
<li class="L7710" rel="L7710">warbled, that he would do best to answer, but always with brevity.</li>
<li class="L7711" rel="L7711"></li>
<li class="L7712" rel="L7712">“It was to you,” said the spy, “that his daughter came; and it was</li>
<li class="L7713" rel="L7713">from your care that his daughter took him, accompanied by a neat brown</li>
<li class="L7714" rel="L7714">monsieur; how is he called?--in a little wig--Lorry--of the bank of</li>
<li class="L7715" rel="L7715">Tellson and Company--over to England.”</li>
<li class="L7716" rel="L7716"></li>
<li class="L7717" rel="L7717">“Such is the fact,” repeated Defarge.</li>
<li class="L7718" rel="L7718"></li>
<li class="L7719" rel="L7719">“Very interesting remembrances!” said the spy. “I have known Doctor</li>
<li class="L7720" rel="L7720">Manette and his daughter, in England.”</li>
<li class="L7721" rel="L7721"></li>
<li class="L7722" rel="L7722">“Yes?” said Defarge.</li>
<li class="L7723" rel="L7723"></li>
<li class="L7724" rel="L7724">“You don&#39;t hear much about them now?” said the spy.</li>
<li class="L7725" rel="L7725"></li>
<li class="L7726" rel="L7726">“No,” said Defarge.</li>
<li class="L7727" rel="L7727"></li>
<li class="L7728" rel="L7728">“In effect,” madame struck in, looking up from her work and her little</li>
<li class="L7729" rel="L7729">song, “we never hear about them. We received the news of their safe</li>
<li class="L7730" rel="L7730">arrival, and perhaps another letter, or perhaps two; but, since then,</li>
<li class="L7731" rel="L7731">they have gradually taken their road in life--we, ours--and we have held</li>
<li class="L7732" rel="L7732">no correspondence.”</li>
<li class="L7733" rel="L7733"></li>
<li class="L7734" rel="L7734">“Perfectly so, madame,” replied the spy. “She is going to be married.”</li>
<li class="L7735" rel="L7735"></li>
<li class="L7736" rel="L7736">“Going?” echoed madame. “She was pretty enough to have been married long</li>
<li class="L7737" rel="L7737">ago. You English are cold, it seems to me.”</li>
<li class="L7738" rel="L7738"></li>
<li class="L7739" rel="L7739">“Oh! You know I am English.”</li>
<li class="L7740" rel="L7740"></li>
<li class="L7741" rel="L7741">“I perceive your tongue is,” returned madame; “and what the tongue is, I</li>
<li class="L7742" rel="L7742">suppose the man is.”</li>
<li class="L7743" rel="L7743"></li>
<li class="L7744" rel="L7744">He did not take the identification as a compliment; but he made the best</li>
<li class="L7745" rel="L7745">of it, and turned it off with a laugh. After sipping his cognac to the</li>
<li class="L7746" rel="L7746">end, he added:</li>
<li class="L7747" rel="L7747"></li>
<li class="L7748" rel="L7748">“Yes, Miss Manette is going to be married. But not to an Englishman; to</li>
<li class="L7749" rel="L7749">one who, like herself, is French by birth. And speaking of Gaspard (ah,</li>
<li class="L7750" rel="L7750">poor Gaspard! It was cruel, cruel!), it is a curious thing that she is</li>
<li class="L7751" rel="L7751">going to marry the nephew of Monsieur the Marquis, for whom Gaspard</li>
<li class="L7752" rel="L7752">was exalted to that height of so many feet; in other words, the present</li>
<li class="L7753" rel="L7753">Marquis. But he lives unknown in England, he is no Marquis there; he is</li>
<li class="L7754" rel="L7754">Mr. Charles Darnay. D&#39;Aulnais is the name of his mother&#39;s family.”</li>
<li class="L7755" rel="L7755"></li>
<li class="L7756" rel="L7756">Madame Defarge knitted steadily, but the intelligence had a palpable</li>
<li class="L7757" rel="L7757">effect upon her husband. Do what he would, behind the little counter,</li>
<li class="L7758" rel="L7758">as to the striking of a light and the lighting of his pipe, he was</li>
<li class="L7759" rel="L7759">troubled, and his hand was not trustworthy. The spy would have been no</li>
<li class="L7760" rel="L7760">spy if he had failed to see it, or to record it in his mind.</li>
<li class="L7761" rel="L7761"></li>
<li class="L7762" rel="L7762">Having made, at least, this one hit, whatever it might prove to be</li>
<li class="L7763" rel="L7763">worth, and no customers coming in to help him to any other, Mr. Barsad</li>
<li class="L7764" rel="L7764">paid for what he had drunk, and took his leave: taking occasion to say,</li>
<li class="L7765" rel="L7765">in a genteel manner, before he departed, that he looked forward to the</li>
<li class="L7766" rel="L7766">pleasure of seeing Monsieur and Madame Defarge again. For some minutes</li>
<li class="L7767" rel="L7767">after he had emerged into the outer presence of Saint Antoine, the</li>
<li class="L7768" rel="L7768">husband and wife remained exactly as he had left them, lest he should</li>
<li class="L7769" rel="L7769">come back.</li>
<li class="L7770" rel="L7770"></li>
<li class="L7771" rel="L7771">“Can it be true,” said Defarge, in a low voice, looking down at his wife</li>
<li class="L7772" rel="L7772">as he stood smoking with his hand on the back of her chair: “what he has</li>
<li class="L7773" rel="L7773">said of Ma&#39;amselle Manette?”</li>
<li class="L7774" rel="L7774"></li>
<li class="L7775" rel="L7775">“As he has said it,” returned madame, lifting her eyebrows a little, “it</li>
<li class="L7776" rel="L7776">is probably false. But it may be true.”</li>
<li class="L7777" rel="L7777"></li>
<li class="L7778" rel="L7778">“If it is--” Defarge began, and stopped.</li>
<li class="L7779" rel="L7779"></li>
<li class="L7780" rel="L7780">“If it is?” repeated his wife.</li>
<li class="L7781" rel="L7781"></li>
<li class="L7782" rel="L7782">“--And if it does come, while we live to see it triumph--I hope, for her</li>
<li class="L7783" rel="L7783">sake, Destiny will keep her husband out of France.”</li>
<li class="L7784" rel="L7784"></li>
<li class="L7785" rel="L7785">“Her husband&#39;s destiny,” said Madame Defarge, with her usual composure,</li>
<li class="L7786" rel="L7786">“will take him where he is to go, and will lead him to the end that is</li>
