<li class="L7787" rel="L7787">to end him. That is all I know.”</li>
<li class="L7788" rel="L7788"></li>
<li class="L7789" rel="L7789">“But it is very strange--now, at least, is it not very strange”--said</li>
<li class="L7790" rel="L7790">Defarge, rather pleading with his wife to induce her to admit it,</li>
<li class="L7791" rel="L7791">“that, after all our sympathy for Monsieur her father, and herself, her</li>
<li class="L7792" rel="L7792">husband&#39;s name should be proscribed under your hand at this moment, by</li>
<li class="L7793" rel="L7793">the side of that infernal dog&#39;s who has just left us?”</li>
<li class="L7794" rel="L7794"></li>
<li class="L7795" rel="L7795">“Stranger things than that will happen when it does come,” answered</li>
<li class="L7796" rel="L7796">madame. “I have them both here, of a certainty; and they are both here</li>
<li class="L7797" rel="L7797">for their merits; that is enough.”</li>
<li class="L7798" rel="L7798"></li>
<li class="L7799" rel="L7799">She rolled up her knitting when she had said those words, and presently</li>
<li class="L7800" rel="L7800">took the rose out of the handkerchief that was wound about her head.</li>
<li class="L7801" rel="L7801">Either Saint Antoine had an instinctive sense that the objectionable</li>
<li class="L7802" rel="L7802">decoration was gone, or Saint Antoine was on the watch for its</li>
<li class="L7803" rel="L7803">disappearance; howbeit, the Saint took courage to lounge in, very</li>
<li class="L7804" rel="L7804">shortly afterwards, and the wine-shop recovered its habitual aspect.</li>
<li class="L7805" rel="L7805"></li>
<li class="L7806" rel="L7806">In the evening, at which season of all others Saint Antoine turned</li>
<li class="L7807" rel="L7807">himself inside out, and sat on door-steps and window-ledges, and came</li>
<li class="L7808" rel="L7808">to the corners of vile streets and courts, for a breath of air, Madame</li>
<li class="L7809" rel="L7809">Defarge with her work in her hand was accustomed to pass from place</li>
<li class="L7810" rel="L7810">to place and from group to group: a Missionary--there were many like</li>
<li class="L7811" rel="L7811">her--such as the world will do well never to breed again. All the women</li>
<li class="L7812" rel="L7812">knitted. They knitted worthless things; but, the mechanical work was a</li>
<li class="L7813" rel="L7813">mechanical substitute for eating and drinking; the hands moved for the</li>
<li class="L7814" rel="L7814">jaws and the digestive apparatus: if the bony fingers had been still,</li>
<li class="L7815" rel="L7815">the stomachs would have been more famine-pinched.</li>
<li class="L7816" rel="L7816"></li>
<li class="L7817" rel="L7817">But, as the fingers went, the eyes went, and the thoughts. And as Madame</li>
<li class="L7818" rel="L7818">Defarge moved on from group to group, all three went quicker and fiercer</li>
<li class="L7819" rel="L7819">among every little knot of women that she had spoken with, and left</li>
<li class="L7820" rel="L7820">behind.</li>
<li class="L7821" rel="L7821"></li>
<li class="L7822" rel="L7822">Her husband smoked at his door, looking after her with admiration. “A</li>
<li class="L7823" rel="L7823">great woman,” said he, “a strong woman, a grand woman, a frightfully</li>
<li class="L7824" rel="L7824">grand woman!”</li>
<li class="L7825" rel="L7825"></li>
<li class="L7826" rel="L7826">Darkness closed around, and then came the ringing of church bells and</li>
<li class="L7827" rel="L7827">the distant beating of the military drums in the Palace Courtyard, as</li>
<li class="L7828" rel="L7828">the women sat knitting, knitting. Darkness encompassed them. Another</li>
<li class="L7829" rel="L7829">darkness was closing in as surely, when the church bells, then ringing</li>
<li class="L7830" rel="L7830">pleasantly in many an airy steeple over France, should be melted into</li>
<li class="L7831" rel="L7831">thundering cannon; when the military drums should be beating to drown a</li>
<li class="L7832" rel="L7832">wretched voice, that night all potent as the voice of Power and Plenty,</li>
<li class="L7833" rel="L7833">Freedom and Life. So much was closing in about the women who sat</li>
<li class="L7834" rel="L7834">knitting, knitting, that they their very selves were closing in around</li>
<li class="L7835" rel="L7835">a structure yet unbuilt, where they were to sit knitting, knitting,</li>
<li class="L7836" rel="L7836">counting dropping heads.</li>
<li class="L7837" rel="L7837"></li>
<li class="L7838" rel="L7838"></li>
<li class="L7839" rel="L7839"></li>
<li class="L7840" rel="L7840"></li>
<li class="L7841" rel="L7841">XVII. One Night</li>
<li class="L7842" rel="L7842"></li>
<li class="L7843" rel="L7843"></li>
<li class="L7844" rel="L7844">Never did the sun go down with a brighter glory on the quiet corner in</li>
<li class="L7845" rel="L7845">Soho, than one memorable evening when the Doctor and his daughter sat</li>
<li class="L7846" rel="L7846">under the plane-tree together. Never did the moon rise with a milder</li>
<li class="L7847" rel="L7847">radiance over great London, than on that night when it found them still</li>
<li class="L7848" rel="L7848">seated under the tree, and shone upon their faces through its leaves.</li>
<li class="L7849" rel="L7849"></li>
<li class="L7850" rel="L7850">Lucie was to be married to-morrow. She had reserved this last evening</li>
<li class="L7851" rel="L7851">for her father, and they sat alone under the plane-tree.</li>
<li class="L7852" rel="L7852"></li>
<li class="L7853" rel="L7853">“You are happy, my dear father?”</li>
<li class="L7854" rel="L7854"></li>
<li class="L7855" rel="L7855">“Quite, my child.”</li>
<li class="L7856" rel="L7856"></li>
<li class="L7857" rel="L7857">They had said little, though they had been there a long time. When it</li>
<li class="L7858" rel="L7858">was yet light enough to work and read, she had neither engaged herself</li>
<li class="L7859" rel="L7859">in her usual work, nor had she read to him. She had employed herself in</li>
<li class="L7860" rel="L7860">both ways, at his side under the tree, many and many a time; but, this</li>
<li class="L7861" rel="L7861">time was not quite like any other, and nothing could make it so.</li>
<li class="L7862" rel="L7862"></li>
<li class="L7863" rel="L7863">“And I am very happy to-night, dear father. I am deeply happy in the</li>
<li class="L7864" rel="L7864">love that Heaven has so blessed--my love for Charles, and Charles&#39;s love</li>
<li class="L7865" rel="L7865">for me. But, if my life were not to be still consecrated to you, or</li>
<li class="L7866" rel="L7866">if my marriage were so arranged as that it would part us, even by</li>
<li class="L7867" rel="L7867">the length of a few of these streets, I should be more unhappy and</li>
<li class="L7868" rel="L7868">self-reproachful now than I can tell you. Even as it is--”</li>
<li class="L7869" rel="L7869"></li>
<li class="L7870" rel="L7870">Even as it was, she could not command her voice.</li>
<li class="L7871" rel="L7871"></li>
<li class="L7872" rel="L7872">In the sad moonlight, she clasped him by the neck, and laid her face</li>
<li class="L7873" rel="L7873">upon his breast. In the moonlight which is always sad, as the light of</li>
<li class="L7874" rel="L7874">the sun itself is--as the light called human life is--at its coming and</li>
<li class="L7875" rel="L7875">its going.</li>
<li class="L7876" rel="L7876"></li>
<li class="L7877" rel="L7877">“Dearest dear! Can you tell me, this last time, that you feel quite,</li>
<li class="L7878" rel="L7878">quite sure, no new affections of mine, and no new duties of mine, will</li>
<li class="L7879" rel="L7879">ever interpose between us? _I_ know it well, but do you know it? In your</li>
<li class="L7880" rel="L7880">own heart, do you feel quite certain?”</li>
<li class="L7881" rel="L7881"></li>
<li class="L7882" rel="L7882">Her father answered, with a cheerful firmness of conviction he could</li>
<li class="L7883" rel="L7883">scarcely have assumed, “Quite sure, my darling! More than that,” he</li>
<li class="L7884" rel="L7884">added, as he tenderly kissed her: “my future is far brighter, Lucie,</li>
<li class="L7885" rel="L7885">seen through your marriage, than it could have been--nay, than it ever</li>
<li class="L7886" rel="L7886">was--without it.”</li>
<li class="L7887" rel="L7887"></li>
<li class="L7888" rel="L7888">“If I could hope _that_, my father!--”</li>
<li class="L7889" rel="L7889"></li>
<li class="L7890" rel="L7890">“Believe it, love! Indeed it is so. Consider how natural and how plain</li>
<li class="L7891" rel="L7891">it is, my dear, that it should be so. You, devoted and young, cannot</li>
<li class="L7892" rel="L7892">fully appreciate the anxiety I have felt that your life should not be</li>
<li class="L7893" rel="L7893">wasted--”</li>
<li class="L7894" rel="L7894"></li>
<li class="L7895" rel="L7895">She moved her hand towards his lips, but he took it in his, and repeated</li>
<li class="L7896" rel="L7896">the word.</li>
<li class="L7897" rel="L7897"></li>
<li class="L7898" rel="L7898">“--wasted, my child--should not be wasted, struck aside from the</li>
<li class="L7899" rel="L7899">natural order of things--for my sake. Your unselfishness cannot entirely</li>
<li class="L7900" rel="L7900">comprehend how much my mind has gone on this; but, only ask yourself,</li>
<li class="L7901" rel="L7901">how could my happiness be perfect, while yours was incomplete?”</li>
<li class="L7902" rel="L7902"></li>
<li class="L7903" rel="L7903">“If I had never seen Charles, my father, I should have been quite happy</li>
<li class="L7904" rel="L7904">with you.”</li>
<li class="L7905" rel="L7905"></li>
<li class="L7906" rel="L7906">He smiled at her unconscious admission that she would have been unhappy</li>
<li class="L7907" rel="L7907">without Charles, having seen him; and replied:</li>
<li class="L7908" rel="L7908"></li>
<li class="L7909" rel="L7909">“My child, you did see him, and it is Charles. If it had not been</li>
<li class="L7910" rel="L7910">Charles, it would have been another. Or, if it had been no other, I</li>
<li class="L7911" rel="L7911">should have been the cause, and then the dark part of my life would have</li>
<li class="L7912" rel="L7912">cast its shadow beyond myself, and would have fallen on you.”</li>
<li class="L7913" rel="L7913"></li>
<li class="L7914" rel="L7914">It was the first time, except at the trial, of her ever hearing him</li>
<li class="L7915" rel="L7915">refer to the period of his suffering. It gave her a strange and new</li>
<li class="L7916" rel="L7916">sensation while his words were in her ears; and she remembered it long</li>
<li class="L7917" rel="L7917">afterwards.</li>
<li class="L7918" rel="L7918"></li>
<li class="L7919" rel="L7919">“See!” said the Doctor of Beauvais, raising his hand towards the moon.</li>
<li class="L7920" rel="L7920">“I have looked at her from my prison-window, when I could not bear her</li>
<li class="L7921" rel="L7921">light. I have looked at her when it has been such torture to me to think</li>
<li class="L7922" rel="L7922">of her shining upon what I had lost, that I have beaten my head against</li>
<li class="L7923" rel="L7923">my prison-walls. I have looked at her, in a state so dull and lethargic,</li>
<li class="L7924" rel="L7924">that I have thought of nothing but the number of horizontal lines I</li>
<li class="L7925" rel="L7925">could draw across her at the full, and the number of perpendicular lines</li>
<li class="L7926" rel="L7926">with which I could intersect them.” He added in his inward and pondering</li>
<li class="L7927" rel="L7927">manner, as he looked at the moon, “It was twenty either way, I remember,</li>
<li class="L7928" rel="L7928">and the twentieth was difficult to squeeze in.”</li>
<li class="L7929" rel="L7929"></li>
<li class="L7930" rel="L7930">The strange thrill with which she heard him go back to that time,</li>
<li class="L7931" rel="L7931">deepened as he dwelt upon it; but, there was nothing to shock her in</li>
<li class="L7932" rel="L7932">the manner of his reference. He only seemed to contrast his present</li>
<li class="L7933" rel="L7933">cheerfulness and felicity with the dire endurance that was over.</li>
<li class="L7934" rel="L7934"></li>
<li class="L7935" rel="L7935">“I have looked at her, speculating thousands of times upon the unborn</li>
<li class="L7936" rel="L7936">child from whom I had been rent. Whether it was alive. Whether it had</li>
<li class="L7937" rel="L7937">been born alive, or the poor mother&#39;s shock had killed it. Whether it</li>
<li class="L7938" rel="L7938">was a son who would some day avenge his father. (There was a time in my</li>
<li class="L7939" rel="L7939">imprisonment, when my desire for vengeance was unbearable.) Whether it</li>
<li class="L7940" rel="L7940">was a son who would never know his father&#39;s story; who might even live</li>
<li class="L7941" rel="L7941">to weigh the possibility of his father&#39;s having disappeared of his own</li>
<li class="L7942" rel="L7942">will and act. Whether it was a daughter who would grow to be a woman.”</li>
<li class="L7943" rel="L7943"></li>
<li class="L7944" rel="L7944">She drew closer to him, and kissed his cheek and his hand.</li>
<li class="L7945" rel="L7945"></li>
<li class="L7946" rel="L7946">“I have pictured my daughter, to myself, as perfectly forgetful of</li>
<li class="L7947" rel="L7947">me--rather, altogether ignorant of me, and unconscious of me. I have</li>
<li class="L7948" rel="L7948">cast up the years of her age, year after year. I have seen her married</li>
<li class="L7949" rel="L7949">to a man who knew nothing of my fate. I have altogether perished from</li>
<li class="L7950" rel="L7950">the remembrance of the living, and in the next generation my place was a</li>
<li class="L7951" rel="L7951">blank.”</li>
<li class="L7952" rel="L7952"></li>
<li class="L7953" rel="L7953">“My father! Even to hear that you had such thoughts of a daughter who</li>
<li class="L7954" rel="L7954">never existed, strikes to my heart as if I had been that child.”</li>
<li class="L7955" rel="L7955"></li>
<li class="L7956" rel="L7956">“You, Lucie? It is out of the Consolation and restoration you have</li>
<li class="L7957" rel="L7957">brought to me, that these remembrances arise, and pass between us and</li>
<li class="L7958" rel="L7958">the moon on this last night.--What did I say just now?”</li>
<li class="L7959" rel="L7959"></li>
<li class="L7960" rel="L7960">“She knew nothing of you. She cared nothing for you.”</li>
<li class="L7961" rel="L7961"></li>
<li class="L7962" rel="L7962">“So! But on other moonlight nights, when the sadness and the silence</li>
<li class="L7963" rel="L7963">have touched me in a different way--have affected me with something as</li>
<li class="L7964" rel="L7964">like a sorrowful sense of peace, as any emotion that had pain for its</li>
<li class="L7965" rel="L7965">foundations could--I have imagined her as coming to me in my cell, and</li>
<li class="L7966" rel="L7966">leading me out into the freedom beyond the fortress. I have seen her</li>
<li class="L7967" rel="L7967">image in the moonlight often, as I now see you; except that I never held</li>
<li class="L7968" rel="L7968">her in my arms; it stood between the little grated window and the door.</li>
<li class="L7969" rel="L7969">But, you understand that that was not the child I am speaking of?”</li>
<li class="L7970" rel="L7970"></li>
<li class="L7971" rel="L7971">“The figure was not; the--the--image; the fancy?”</li>
<li class="L7972" rel="L7972"></li>
<li class="L7973" rel="L7973">“No. That was another thing. It stood before my disturbed sense of</li>
<li class="L7974" rel="L7974">sight, but it never moved. The phantom that my mind pursued, was another</li>
<li class="L7975" rel="L7975">and more real child. Of her outward appearance I know no more than</li>
<li class="L7976" rel="L7976">that she was like her mother. The other had that likeness too--as you</li>
<li class="L7977" rel="L7977">have--but was not the same. Can you follow me, Lucie? Hardly, I think?</li>
<li class="L7978" rel="L7978">I doubt you must have been a solitary prisoner to understand these</li>
<li class="L7979" rel="L7979">perplexed distinctions.”</li>
<li class="L7980" rel="L7980"></li>
<li class="L7981" rel="L7981">His collected and calm manner could not prevent her blood from running</li>
<li class="L7982" rel="L7982">cold, as he thus tried to anatomise his old condition.</li>
<li class="L7983" rel="L7983"></li>
<li class="L7984" rel="L7984">“In that more peaceful state, I have imagined her, in the moonlight,</li>
<li class="L7985" rel="L7985">coming to me and taking me out to show me that the home of her married</li>
<li class="L7986" rel="L7986">life was full of her loving remembrance of her lost father. My picture</li>
<li class="L7987" rel="L7987">was in her room, and I was in her prayers. Her life was active,</li>
<li class="L7988" rel="L7988">cheerful, useful; but my poor history pervaded it all.”</li>
<li class="L7989" rel="L7989"></li>
<li class="L7990" rel="L7990">“I was that child, my father, I was not half so good, but in my love</li>
<li class="L7991" rel="L7991">that was I.”</li>
<li class="L7992" rel="L7992"></li>
<li class="L7993" rel="L7993">“And she showed me her children,” said the Doctor of Beauvais, “and</li>
<li class="L7994" rel="L7994">they had heard of me, and had been taught to pity me. When they passed</li>
<li class="L7995" rel="L7995">a prison of the State, they kept far from its frowning walls, and looked</li>
<li class="L7996" rel="L7996">up at its bars, and spoke in whispers. She could never deliver me; I</li>
<li class="L7997" rel="L7997">imagined that she always brought me back after showing me such things.</li>
<li class="L7998" rel="L7998">But then, blessed with the relief of tears, I fell upon my knees, and</li>
<li class="L7999" rel="L7999">blessed her.”</li>
<li class="L8000" rel="L8000"></li>
<li class="L8001" rel="L8001">“I am that child, I hope, my father. O my dear, my dear, will you bless</li>
<li class="L8002" rel="L8002">me as fervently to-morrow?”</li>
<li class="L8003" rel="L8003"></li>
<li class="L8004" rel="L8004">“Lucie, I recall these old troubles in the reason that I have to-night</li>
<li class="L8005" rel="L8005">for loving you better than words can tell, and thanking God for my great</li>
<li class="L8006" rel="L8006">happiness. My thoughts, when they were wildest, never rose near the</li>
<li class="L8007" rel="L8007">happiness that I have known with you, and that we have before us.”</li>
<li class="L8008" rel="L8008"></li>
<li class="L8009" rel="L8009">He embraced her, solemnly commended her to Heaven, and humbly thanked</li>
<li class="L8010" rel="L8010">Heaven for having bestowed her on him. By-and-bye, they went into the</li>
<li class="L8011" rel="L8011">house.</li>
<li class="L8012" rel="L8012"></li>
<li class="L8013" rel="L8013">There was no one bidden to the marriage but Mr. Lorry; there was even to</li>
<li class="L8014" rel="L8014">be no bridesmaid but the gaunt Miss Pross. The marriage was to make no</li>
<li class="L8015" rel="L8015">change in their place of residence; they had been able to extend it,</li>
<li class="L8016" rel="L8016">by taking to themselves the upper rooms formerly belonging to the</li>
<li class="L8017" rel="L8017">apocryphal invisible lodger, and they desired nothing more.</li>
<li class="L8018" rel="L8018"></li>
<li class="L8019" rel="L8019">Doctor Manette was very cheerful at the little supper. They were only</li>
<li class="L8020" rel="L8020">three at table, and Miss Pross made the third. He regretted that Charles</li>
<li class="L8021" rel="L8021">was not there; was more than half disposed to object to the loving</li>
<li class="L8022" rel="L8022">little plot that kept him away; and drank to him affectionately.</li>
<li class="L8023" rel="L8023"></li>
<li class="L8024" rel="L8024">So, the time came for him to bid Lucie good night, and they separated.</li>
<li class="L8025" rel="L8025">But, in the stillness of the third hour of the morning, Lucie came</li>
<li class="L8026" rel="L8026">downstairs again, and stole into his room; not free from unshaped fears,</li>
<li class="L8027" rel="L8027">beforehand.</li>
<li class="L8028" rel="L8028"></li>
<li class="L8029" rel="L8029">All things, however, were in their places; all was quiet; and he lay</li>
<li class="L8030" rel="L8030">asleep, his white hair picturesque on the untroubled pillow, and his</li>
<li class="L8031" rel="L8031">hands lying quiet on the coverlet. She put her needless candle in the</li>
<li class="L8032" rel="L8032">shadow at a distance, crept up to his bed, and put her lips to his;</li>
<li class="L8033" rel="L8033">then, leaned over him, and looked at him.</li>
<li class="L8034" rel="L8034"></li>
<li class="L8035" rel="L8035">Into his handsome face, the bitter waters of captivity had worn; but, he</li>
<li class="L8036" rel="L8036">covered up their tracks with a determination so strong, that he held the</li>
<li class="L8037" rel="L8037">mastery of them even in his sleep. A more remarkable face in its quiet,</li>
<li class="L8038" rel="L8038">resolute, and guarded struggle with an unseen assailant, was not to be</li>
<li class="L8039" rel="L8039">beheld in all the wide dominions of sleep, that night.</li>
<li class="L8040" rel="L8040"></li>
<li class="L8041" rel="L8041">She timidly laid her hand on his dear breast, and put up a prayer that</li>
<li class="L8042" rel="L8042">she might ever be as true to him as her love aspired to be, and as his</li>
<li class="L8043" rel="L8043">sorrows deserved. Then, she withdrew her hand, and kissed his lips once</li>
<li class="L8044" rel="L8044">more, and went away. So, the sunrise came, and the shadows of the leaves</li>
<li class="L8045" rel="L8045">of the plane-tree moved upon his face, as softly as her lips had moved</li>
<li class="L8046" rel="L8046">in praying for him.</li>
<li class="L8047" rel="L8047"></li>
<li class="L8048" rel="L8048"></li>
<li class="L8049" rel="L8049"></li>
<li class="L8050" rel="L8050"></li>
<li class="L8051" rel="L8051">XVIII. Nine Days</li>
<li class="L8052" rel="L8052"></li>
<li class="L8053" rel="L8053"></li>
<li class="L8054" rel="L8054">The marriage-day was shining brightly, and they were ready outside the</li>
<li class="L8055" rel="L8055">closed door of the Doctor&#39;s room, where he was speaking with Charles</li>
<li class="L8056" rel="L8056">Darnay. They were ready to go to church; the beautiful bride, Mr.</li>
<li class="L8057" rel="L8057">Lorry, and Miss Pross--to whom the event, through a gradual process of</li>
<li class="L8058" rel="L8058">reconcilement to the inevitable, would have been one of absolute bliss,</li>
<li class="L8059" rel="L8059">but for the yet lingering consideration that her brother Solomon should</li>
<li class="L8060" rel="L8060">have been the bridegroom.</li>
<li class="L8061" rel="L8061"></li>
<li class="L8062" rel="L8062">“And so,” said Mr. Lorry, who could not sufficiently admire the bride,</li>
<li class="L8063" rel="L8063">and who had been moving round her to take in every point of her quiet,</li>
<li class="L8064" rel="L8064">pretty dress; “and so it was for this, my sweet Lucie, that I brought</li>
<li class="L8065" rel="L8065">you across the Channel, such a baby! Lord bless me! How little I thought</li>
<li class="L8066" rel="L8066">what I was doing! How lightly I valued the obligation I was conferring</li>
<li class="L8067" rel="L8067">on my friend Mr. Charles!”</li>
<li class="L8068" rel="L8068"></li>
<li class="L8069" rel="L8069">“You didn&#39;t mean it,” remarked the matter-of-fact Miss Pross, “and</li>
<li class="L8070" rel="L8070">therefore how could you know it? Nonsense!”</li>
<li class="L8071" rel="L8071"></li>
<li class="L8072" rel="L8072">“Really? Well; but don&#39;t cry,” said the gentle Mr. Lorry.</li>
<li class="L8073" rel="L8073"></li>
<li class="L8074" rel="L8074">“I am not crying,” said Miss Pross; “_you_ are.”</li>
<li class="L8075" rel="L8075"></li>
<li class="L8076" rel="L8076">“I, my Pross?” (By this time, Mr. Lorry dared to be pleasant with her,</li>
<li class="L8077" rel="L8077">on occasion.)</li>
<li class="L8078" rel="L8078"></li>
<li class="L8079" rel="L8079">“You were, just now; I saw you do it, and I don&#39;t wonder at it. Such</li>
<li class="L8080" rel="L8080">a present of plate as you have made &#39;em, is enough to bring tears into</li>
<li class="L8081" rel="L8081">anybody&#39;s eyes. There&#39;s not a fork or a spoon in the collection,” said</li>
<li class="L8082" rel="L8082">Miss Pross, “that I didn&#39;t cry over, last night after the box came, till</li>
<li class="L8083" rel="L8083">I couldn&#39;t see it.”</li>
<li class="L8084" rel="L8084"></li>
<li class="L8085" rel="L8085">“I am highly gratified,” said Mr. Lorry, “though, upon my honour, I</li>
<li class="L8086" rel="L8086">had no intention of rendering those trifling articles of remembrance</li>
<li class="L8087" rel="L8087">invisible to any one. Dear me! This is an occasion that makes a man</li>
<li class="L8088" rel="L8088">speculate on all he has lost. Dear, dear, dear! To think that there</li>
<li class="L8089" rel="L8089">might have been a Mrs. Lorry, any time these fifty years almost!”</li>
<li class="L8090" rel="L8090"></li>
<li class="L8091" rel="L8091">“Not at all!” From Miss Pross.</li>
<li class="L8092" rel="L8092"></li>
<li class="L8093" rel="L8093">“You think there never might have been a Mrs. Lorry?” asked the</li>
<li class="L8094" rel="L8094">gentleman of that name.</li>
<li class="L8095" rel="L8095"></li>
<li class="L8096" rel="L8096">“Pooh!” rejoined Miss Pross; “you were a bachelor in your cradle.”</li>
<li class="L8097" rel="L8097"></li>
<li class="L8098" rel="L8098">“Well!” observed Mr. Lorry, beamingly adjusting his little wig, “that</li>
<li class="L8099" rel="L8099">seems probable, too.”</li>
<li class="L8100" rel="L8100"></li>
<li class="L8101" rel="L8101">“And you were cut out for a bachelor,” pursued Miss Pross, “before you</li>
<li class="L8102" rel="L8102">were put in your cradle.”</li>
<li class="L8103" rel="L8103"></li>
<li class="L8104" rel="L8104">“Then, I think,” said Mr. Lorry, “that I was very unhandsomely dealt</li>
<li class="L8105" rel="L8105">with, and that I ought to have had a voice in the selection of my</li>
<li class="L8106" rel="L8106">pattern. Enough! Now, my dear Lucie,” drawing his arm soothingly round</li>
<li class="L8107" rel="L8107">her waist, “I hear them moving in the next room, and Miss Pross and</li>
<li class="L8108" rel="L8108">I, as two formal folks of business, are anxious not to lose the final</li>
<li class="L8109" rel="L8109">opportunity of saying something to you that you wish to hear. You leave</li>
<li class="L8110" rel="L8110">your good father, my dear, in hands as earnest and as loving as your</li>
<li class="L8111" rel="L8111">own; he shall be taken every conceivable care of; during the next</li>
<li class="L8112" rel="L8112">fortnight, while you are in Warwickshire and thereabouts, even Tellson&#39;s</li>
<li class="L8113" rel="L8113">shall go to the wall (comparatively speaking) before him. And when, at</li>
<li class="L8114" rel="L8114">the fortnight&#39;s end, he comes to join you and your beloved husband, on</li>
<li class="L8115" rel="L8115">your other fortnight&#39;s trip in Wales, you shall say that we have sent</li>
<li class="L8116" rel="L8116">him to you in the best health and in the happiest frame. Now, I hear</li>
<li class="L8117" rel="L8117">Somebody&#39;s step coming to the door. Let me kiss my dear girl with an</li>
<li class="L8118" rel="L8118">old-fashioned bachelor blessing, before Somebody comes to claim his</li>
<li class="L8119" rel="L8119">own.”</li>
<li class="L8120" rel="L8120"></li>
<li class="L8121" rel="L8121">For a moment, he held the fair face from him to look at the</li>
<li class="L8122" rel="L8122">well-remembered expression on the forehead, and then laid the bright</li>
<li class="L8123" rel="L8123">golden hair against his little brown wig, with a genuine tenderness and</li>
<li class="L8124" rel="L8124">delicacy which, if such things be old-fashioned, were as old as Adam.</li>
<li class="L8125" rel="L8125"></li>
<li class="L8126" rel="L8126">The door of the Doctor&#39;s room opened, and he came out with Charles</li>
<li class="L8127" rel="L8127">Darnay. He was so deadly pale--which had not been the case when they</li>
<li class="L8128" rel="L8128">went in together--that no vestige of colour was to be seen in his face.</li>
<li class="L8129" rel="L8129">But, in the composure of his manner he was unaltered, except that to the</li>
<li class="L8130" rel="L8130">shrewd glance of Mr. Lorry it disclosed some shadowy indication that the</li>
<li class="L8131" rel="L8131">old air of avoidance and dread had lately passed over him, like a cold</li>
<li class="L8132" rel="L8132">wind.</li>
<li class="L8133" rel="L8133"></li>
<li class="L8134" rel="L8134">He gave his arm to his daughter, and took her down-stairs to the chariot</li>
<li class="L8135" rel="L8135">which Mr. Lorry had hired in honour of the day. The rest followed in</li>
<li class="L8136" rel="L8136">another carriage, and soon, in a neighbouring church, where no strange</li>
<li class="L8137" rel="L8137">eyes looked on, Charles Darnay and Lucie Manette were happily married.</li>
<li class="L8138" rel="L8138"></li>
<li class="L8139" rel="L8139">Besides the glancing tears that shone among the smiles of the little</li>
<li class="L8140" rel="L8140">group when it was done, some diamonds, very bright and sparkling,</li>
<li class="L8141" rel="L8141">glanced on the bride&#39;s hand, which were newly released from the</li>
<li class="L8142" rel="L8142">dark obscurity of one of Mr. Lorry&#39;s pockets. They returned home to</li>
<li class="L8143" rel="L8143">breakfast, and all went well, and in due course the golden hair that had</li>
<li class="L8144" rel="L8144">mingled with the poor shoemaker&#39;s white locks in the Paris garret, were</li>
<li class="L8145" rel="L8145">mingled with them again in the morning sunlight, on the threshold of the</li>
<li class="L8146" rel="L8146">door at parting.</li>
<li class="L8147" rel="L8147"></li>
<li class="L8148" rel="L8148">It was a hard parting, though it was not for long. But her father</li>
<li class="L8149" rel="L8149">cheered her, and said at last, gently disengaging himself from her</li>
<li class="L8150" rel="L8150">enfolding arms, “Take her, Charles! She is yours!”</li>
<li class="L8151" rel="L8151"></li>
<li class="L8152" rel="L8152">And her agitated hand waved to them from a chaise window, and she was</li>
<li class="L8153" rel="L8153">gone.</li>
<li class="L8154" rel="L8154"></li>
<li class="L8155" rel="L8155">The corner being out of the way of the idle and curious, and the</li>
<li class="L8156" rel="L8156">preparations having been very simple and few, the Doctor, Mr. Lorry,</li>
<li class="L8157" rel="L8157">and Miss Pross, were left quite alone. It was when they turned into</li>
<li class="L8158" rel="L8158">the welcome shade of the cool old hall, that Mr. Lorry observed a great</li>
<li class="L8159" rel="L8159">change to have come over the Doctor; as if the golden arm uplifted</li>
<li class="L8160" rel="L8160">there, had struck him a poisoned blow.</li>
<li class="L8161" rel="L8161"></li>
<li class="L8162" rel="L8162">He had naturally repressed much, and some revulsion might have been</li>
<li class="L8163" rel="L8163">expected in him when the occasion for repression was gone. But, it was</li>
<li class="L8164" rel="L8164">the old scared lost look that troubled Mr. Lorry; and through his absent</li>
<li class="L8165" rel="L8165">manner of clasping his head and drearily wandering away into his own</li>
<li class="L8166" rel="L8166">room when they got up-stairs, Mr. Lorry was reminded of Defarge the</li>
<li class="L8167" rel="L8167">wine-shop keeper, and the starlight ride.</li>
<li class="L8168" rel="L8168"></li>
<li class="L8169" rel="L8169">“I think,” he whispered to Miss Pross, after anxious consideration, “I</li>
<li class="L8170" rel="L8170">think we had best not speak to him just now, or at all disturb him.</li>
<li class="L8171" rel="L8171">I must look in at Tellson&#39;s; so I will go there at once and come back</li>
<li class="L8172" rel="L8172">presently. Then, we will take him a ride into the country, and dine</li>
<li class="L8173" rel="L8173">there, and all will be well.”</li>
<li class="L8174" rel="L8174"></li>
<li class="L8175" rel="L8175">It was easier for Mr. Lorry to look in at Tellson&#39;s, than to look out of</li>
<li class="L8176" rel="L8176">Tellson&#39;s. He was detained two hours. When he came back, he ascended the</li>
<li class="L8177" rel="L8177">old staircase alone, having asked no question of the servant; going thus</li>
<li class="L8178" rel="L8178">into the Doctor&#39;s rooms, he was stopped by a low sound of knocking.</li>
<li class="L8179" rel="L8179"></li>
<li class="L8180" rel="L8180">“Good God!” he said, with a start. “What&#39;s that?”</li>
<li class="L8181" rel="L8181"></li>
<li class="L8182" rel="L8182">Miss Pross, with a terrified face, was at his ear. “O me, O me! All is</li>
<li class="L8183" rel="L8183">lost!” cried she, wringing her hands. “What is to be told to Ladybird?</li>
<li class="L8184" rel="L8184">He doesn&#39;t know me, and is making shoes!”</li>
<li class="L8185" rel="L8185"></li>
<li class="L8186" rel="L8186">Mr. Lorry said what he could to calm her, and went himself into the</li>
<li class="L8187" rel="L8187">Doctor&#39;s room. The bench was turned towards the light, as it had been</li>
<li class="L8188" rel="L8188">when he had seen the shoemaker at his work before, and his head was bent</li>
<li class="L8189" rel="L8189">down, and he was very busy.</li>
<li class="L8190" rel="L8190"></li>
<li class="L8191" rel="L8191">“Doctor Manette. My dear friend, Doctor Manette!”</li>
<li class="L8192" rel="L8192"></li>
<li class="L8193" rel="L8193">The Doctor looked at him for a moment--half inquiringly, half as if he</li>
<li class="L8194" rel="L8194">were angry at being spoken to--and bent over his work again.</li>
<li class="L8195" rel="L8195"></li>
<li class="L8196" rel="L8196">He had laid aside his coat and waistcoat; his shirt was open at the</li>
<li class="L8197" rel="L8197">throat, as it used to be when he did that work; and even the old</li>
<li class="L8198" rel="L8198">haggard, faded surface of face had come back to him. He worked</li>
<li class="L8199" rel="L8199">hard--impatiently--as if in some sense of having been interrupted.</li>
<li class="L8200" rel="L8200"></li>
<li class="L8201" rel="L8201">Mr. Lorry glanced at the work in his hand, and observed that it was a</li>
<li class="L8202" rel="L8202">shoe of the old size and shape. He took up another that was lying by</li>
<li class="L8203" rel="L8203">him, and asked what it was.</li>
<li class="L8204" rel="L8204"></li>
<li class="L8205" rel="L8205">“A young lady&#39;s walking shoe,” he muttered, without looking up. “It</li>
<li class="L8206" rel="L8206">ought to have been finished long ago. Let it be.”</li>
<li class="L8207" rel="L8207"></li>
<li class="L8208" rel="L8208">“But, Doctor Manette. Look at me!”</li>
<li class="L8209" rel="L8209"></li>
<li class="L8210" rel="L8210">He obeyed, in the old mechanically submissive manner, without pausing in</li>
<li class="L8211" rel="L8211">his work.</li>
<li class="L8212" rel="L8212"></li>
<li class="L8213" rel="L8213">“You know me, my dear friend? Think again. This is not your proper</li>
<li class="L8214" rel="L8214">occupation. Think, dear friend!”</li>
<li class="L8215" rel="L8215"></li>
<li class="L8216" rel="L8216">Nothing would induce him to speak more. He looked up, for an instant at</li>
<li class="L8217" rel="L8217">a time, when he was requested to do so; but, no persuasion would extract</li>
<li class="L8218" rel="L8218">a word from him. He worked, and worked, and worked, in silence, and</li>
<li class="L8219" rel="L8219">words fell on him as they would have fallen on an echoless wall, or on</li>
<li class="L8220" rel="L8220">the air. The only ray of hope that Mr. Lorry could discover, was, that</li>
<li class="L8221" rel="L8221">he sometimes furtively looked up without being asked. In that, there</li>
<li class="L8222" rel="L8222">seemed a faint expression of curiosity or perplexity--as though he were</li>
<li class="L8223" rel="L8223">trying to reconcile some doubts in his mind.</li>
<li class="L8224" rel="L8224"></li>
<li class="L8225" rel="L8225">Two things at once impressed themselves on Mr. Lorry, as important above</li>
<li class="L8226" rel="L8226">all others; the first, that this must be kept secret from Lucie;</li>
<li class="L8227" rel="L8227">the second, that it must be kept secret from all who knew him. In</li>
<li class="L8228" rel="L8228">conjunction with Miss Pross, he took immediate steps towards the latter</li>
<li class="L8229" rel="L8229">precaution, by giving out that the Doctor was not well, and required a</li>
<li class="L8230" rel="L8230">few days of complete rest. In aid of the kind deception to be practised</li>
<li class="L8231" rel="L8231">on his daughter, Miss Pross was to write, describing his having been</li>
<li class="L8232" rel="L8232">called away professionally, and referring to an imaginary letter of</li>
<li class="L8233" rel="L8233">two or three hurried lines in his own hand, represented to have been</li>
<li class="L8234" rel="L8234">addressed to her by the same post.</li>
<li class="L8235" rel="L8235"></li>
<li class="L8236" rel="L8236">These measures, advisable to be taken in any case, Mr. Lorry took in</li>
<li class="L8237" rel="L8237">the hope of his coming to himself. If that should happen soon, he kept</li>
<li class="L8238" rel="L8238">another course in reserve; which was, to have a certain opinion that he</li>
<li class="L8239" rel="L8239">thought the best, on the Doctor&#39;s case.</li>
<li class="L8240" rel="L8240"></li>
<li class="L8241" rel="L8241">In the hope of his recovery, and of resort to this third course</li>
<li class="L8242" rel="L8242">being thereby rendered practicable, Mr. Lorry resolved to watch him</li>
<li class="L8243" rel="L8243">attentively, with as little appearance as possible of doing so. He</li>
<li class="L8244" rel="L8244">therefore made arrangements to absent himself from Tellson&#39;s for the</li>
<li class="L8245" rel="L8245">first time in his life, and took his post by the window in the same</li>
<li class="L8246" rel="L8246">room.</li>
<li class="L8247" rel="L8247"></li>
<li class="L8248" rel="L8248">He was not long in discovering that it was worse than useless to speak</li>
<li class="L8249" rel="L8249">to him, since, on being pressed, he became worried. He abandoned that</li>
<li class="L8250" rel="L8250">attempt on the first day, and resolved merely to keep himself always</li>
<li class="L8251" rel="L8251">before him, as a silent protest against the delusion into which he had</li>
<li class="L8252" rel="L8252">fallen, or was falling. He remained, therefore, in his seat near the</li>
<li class="L8253" rel="L8253">window, reading and writing, and expressing in as many pleasant and</li>
<li class="L8254" rel="L8254">natural ways as he could think of, that it was a free place.</li>
<li class="L8255" rel="L8255"></li>
<li class="L8256" rel="L8256">Doctor Manette took what was given him to eat and drink, and worked on,</li>
<li class="L8257" rel="L8257">that first day, until it was too dark to see--worked on, half an hour</li>
<li class="L8258" rel="L8258">after Mr. Lorry could not have seen, for his life, to read or write.</li>
<li class="L8259" rel="L8259">When he put his tools aside as useless, until morning, Mr. Lorry rose</li>
<li class="L8260" rel="L8260">and said to him:</li>
<li class="L8261" rel="L8261"></li>
<li class="L8262" rel="L8262">“Will you go out?”</li>
<li class="L8263" rel="L8263"></li>
<li class="L8264" rel="L8264">He looked down at the floor on either side of him in the old manner,</li>
<li class="L8265" rel="L8265">looked up in the old manner, and repeated in the old low voice:</li>
<li class="L8266" rel="L8266"></li>
<li class="L8267" rel="L8267">“Out?”</li>
<li class="L8268" rel="L8268"></li>
<li class="L8269" rel="L8269">“Yes; for a walk with me. Why not?”</li>
<li class="L8270" rel="L8270"></li>
<li class="L8271" rel="L8271">He made no effort to say why not, and said not a word more. But, Mr.</li>
<li class="L8272" rel="L8272">Lorry thought he saw, as he leaned forward on his bench in the dusk,</li>
<li class="L8273" rel="L8273">with his elbows on his knees and his head in his hands, that he was in</li>
<li class="L8274" rel="L8274">some misty way asking himself, “Why not?” The sagacity of the man of</li>
<li class="L8275" rel="L8275">business perceived an advantage here, and determined to hold it.</li>
<li class="L8276" rel="L8276"></li>
<li class="L8277" rel="L8277">Miss Pross and he divided the night into two watches, and observed him</li>
<li class="L8278" rel="L8278">at intervals from the adjoining room. He paced up and down for a long</li>
<li class="L8279" rel="L8279">time before he lay down; but, when he did finally lay himself down, he</li>
<li class="L8280" rel="L8280">fell asleep. In the morning, he was up betimes, and went straight to his</li>
<li class="L8281" rel="L8281">bench and to work.</li>
<li class="L8282" rel="L8282"></li>
<li class="L8283" rel="L8283">On this second day, Mr. Lorry saluted him cheerfully by his name,</li>
<li class="L8284" rel="L8284">and spoke to him on topics that had been of late familiar to them. He</li>
<li class="L8285" rel="L8285">returned no reply, but it was evident that he heard what was said, and</li>
<li class="L8286" rel="L8286">that he thought about it, however confusedly. This encouraged Mr. Lorry</li>
<li class="L8287" rel="L8287">to have Miss Pross in with her work, several times during the day;</li>
<li class="L8288" rel="L8288">at those times, they quietly spoke of Lucie, and of her father then</li>
<li class="L8289" rel="L8289">present, precisely in the usual manner, and as if there were nothing</li>
<li class="L8290" rel="L8290">amiss. This was done without any demonstrative accompaniment, not long</li>
<li class="L8291" rel="L8291">enough, or often enough to harass him; and it lightened Mr. Lorry&#39;s</li>
<li class="L8292" rel="L8292">friendly heart to believe that he looked up oftener, and that he</li>
<li class="L8293" rel="L8293">appeared to be stirred by some perception of inconsistencies surrounding</li>
<li class="L8294" rel="L8294">him.</li>
<li class="L8295" rel="L8295"></li>
<li class="L8296" rel="L8296">When it fell dark again, Mr. Lorry asked him as before:</li>
<li class="L8297" rel="L8297"></li>
<li class="L8298" rel="L8298">“Dear Doctor, will you go out?”</li>
<li class="L8299" rel="L8299"></li>
<li class="L8300" rel="L8300">As before, he repeated, “Out?”</li>
<li class="L8301" rel="L8301"></li>
<li class="L8302" rel="L8302">“Yes; for a walk with me. Why not?”</li>
<li class="L8303" rel="L8303"></li>
<li class="L8304" rel="L8304">This time, Mr. Lorry feigned to go out when he could extract no answer</li>
<li class="L8305" rel="L8305">from him, and, after remaining absent for an hour, returned. In the</li>
<li class="L8306" rel="L8306">meanwhile, the Doctor had removed to the seat in the window, and had</li>
<li class="L8307" rel="L8307">sat there looking down at the plane-tree; but, on Mr. Lorry&#39;s return, he</li>
<li class="L8308" rel="L8308">slipped away to his bench.</li>
<li class="L8309" rel="L8309"></li>
<li class="L8310" rel="L8310">The time went very slowly on, and Mr. Lorry&#39;s hope darkened, and his</li>
<li class="L8311" rel="L8311">heart grew heavier again, and grew yet heavier and heavier every day.</li>
<li class="L8312" rel="L8312">The third day came and went, the fourth, the fifth. Five days, six days,</li>
<li class="L8313" rel="L8313">seven days, eight days, nine days.</li>
<li class="L8314" rel="L8314"></li>
<li class="L8315" rel="L8315">With a hope ever darkening, and with a heart always growing heavier and</li>
<li class="L8316" rel="L8316">heavier, Mr. Lorry passed through this anxious time. The secret was</li>
<li class="L8317" rel="L8317">well kept, and Lucie was unconscious and happy; but he could not fail to</li>
<li class="L8318" rel="L8318">observe that the shoemaker, whose hand had been a little out at first,</li>
<li class="L8319" rel="L8319">was growing dreadfully skilful, and that he had never been so intent on</li>
<li class="L8320" rel="L8320">his work, and that his hands had never been so nimble and expert, as in</li>
<li class="L8321" rel="L8321">the dusk of the ninth evening.</li>
<li class="L8322" rel="L8322"></li>
<li class="L8323" rel="L8323"></li>
<li class="L8324" rel="L8324"></li>
<li class="L8325" rel="L8325"></li>
<li class="L8326" rel="L8326">XIX. An Opinion</li>
<li class="L8327" rel="L8327"></li>
<li class="L8328" rel="L8328"></li>
<li class="L8329" rel="L8329">Worn out by anxious watching, Mr. Lorry fell asleep at his post. On the</li>
<li class="L8330" rel="L8330">tenth morning of his suspense, he was startled by the shining of the sun</li>
<li class="L8331" rel="L8331">into the room where a heavy slumber had overtaken him when it was dark</li>
<li class="L8332" rel="L8332">night.</li>
<li class="L8333" rel="L8333"></li>
<li class="L8334" rel="L8334">He rubbed his eyes and roused himself; but he doubted, when he had</li>
<li class="L8335" rel="L8335">done so, whether he was not still asleep. For, going to the door of the</li>
<li class="L8336" rel="L8336">Doctor&#39;s room and looking in, he perceived that the shoemaker&#39;s bench</li>
<li class="L8337" rel="L8337">and tools were put aside again, and that the Doctor himself sat reading</li>
<li class="L8338" rel="L8338">at the window. He was in his usual morning dress, and his face (which</li>
<li class="L8339" rel="L8339">Mr. Lorry could distinctly see), though still very pale, was calmly</li>
<li class="L8340" rel="L8340">studious and attentive.</li>
<li class="L8341" rel="L8341"></li>
<li class="L8342" rel="L8342">Even when he had satisfied himself that he was awake, Mr. Lorry felt</li>
<li class="L8343" rel="L8343">giddily uncertain for some few moments whether the late shoemaking might</li>
<li class="L8344" rel="L8344">not be a disturbed dream of his own; for, did not his eyes show him his</li>
<li class="L8345" rel="L8345">friend before him in his accustomed clothing and aspect, and employed</li>
<li class="L8346" rel="L8346">as usual; and was there any sign within their range, that the change of</li>
<li class="L8347" rel="L8347">which he had so strong an impression had actually happened?</li>
<li class="L8348" rel="L8348"></li>
<li class="L8349" rel="L8349">It was but the inquiry of his first confusion and astonishment, the</li>
<li class="L8350" rel="L8350">answer being obvious. If the impression were not produced by a real</li>
<li class="L8351" rel="L8351">corresponding and sufficient cause, how came he, Jarvis Lorry, there?</li>
<li class="L8352" rel="L8352">How came he to have fallen asleep, in his clothes, on the sofa in Doctor</li>
<li class="L8353" rel="L8353">Manette&#39;s consulting-room, and to be debating these points outside the</li>
<li class="L8354" rel="L8354">Doctor&#39;s bedroom door in the early morning?</li>
<li class="L8355" rel="L8355"></li>
<li class="L8356" rel="L8356">Within a few minutes, Miss Pross stood whispering at his side. If he</li>
<li class="L8357" rel="L8357">had had any particle of doubt left, her talk would of necessity have</li>
<li class="L8358" rel="L8358">resolved it; but he was by that time clear-headed, and had none.</li>
<li class="L8359" rel="L8359">He advised that they should let the time go by until the regular</li>
<li class="L8360" rel="L8360">breakfast-hour, and should then meet the Doctor as if nothing unusual</li>
<li class="L8361" rel="L8361">had occurred. If he appeared to be in his customary state of mind, Mr.</li>
<li class="L8362" rel="L8362">Lorry would then cautiously proceed to seek direction and guidance from</li>
<li class="L8363" rel="L8363">the opinion he had been, in his anxiety, so anxious to obtain.</li>
<li class="L8364" rel="L8364"></li>
<li class="L8365" rel="L8365">Miss Pross, submitting herself to his judgment, the scheme was worked</li>
<li class="L8366" rel="L8366">out with care. Having abundance of time for his usual methodical</li>
<li class="L8367" rel="L8367">toilette, Mr. Lorry presented himself at the breakfast-hour in his usual</li>
<li class="L8368" rel="L8368">white linen, and with his usual neat leg. The Doctor was summoned in the</li>
<li class="L8369" rel="L8369">usual way, and came to breakfast.</li>
<li class="L8370" rel="L8370"></li>
<li class="L8371" rel="L8371">So far as it was possible to comprehend him without overstepping those</li>
<li class="L8372" rel="L8372">delicate and gradual approaches which Mr. Lorry felt to be the only safe</li>
<li class="L8373" rel="L8373">advance, he at first supposed that his daughter&#39;s marriage had taken</li>
<li class="L8374" rel="L8374">place yesterday. An incidental allusion, purposely thrown out, to</li>
<li class="L8375" rel="L8375">the day of the week, and the day of the month, set him thinking and</li>
<li class="L8376" rel="L8376">counting, and evidently made him uneasy. In all other respects, however,</li>
<li class="L8377" rel="L8377">he was so composedly himself, that Mr. Lorry determined to have the aid</li>
<li class="L8378" rel="L8378">he sought. And that aid was his own.</li>
<li class="L8379" rel="L8379"></li>
<li class="L8380" rel="L8380">Therefore, when the breakfast was done and cleared away, and he and the</li>
<li class="L8381" rel="L8381">Doctor were left together, Mr. Lorry said, feelingly:</li>
<li class="L8382" rel="L8382"></li>
<li class="L8383" rel="L8383">“My dear Manette, I am anxious to have your opinion, in confidence, on a</li>
<li class="L8384" rel="L8384">very curious case in which I am deeply interested; that is to say, it is</li>
<li class="L8385" rel="L8385">very curious to me; perhaps, to your better information it may be less</li>
<li class="L8386" rel="L8386">so.”</li>
<li class="L8387" rel="L8387"></li>
<li class="L8388" rel="L8388">Glancing at his hands, which were discoloured by his late work, the</li>
<li class="L8389" rel="L8389">Doctor looked troubled, and listened attentively. He had already glanced</li>
<li class="L8390" rel="L8390">at his hands more than once.</li>
<li class="L8391" rel="L8391"></li>
<li class="L8392" rel="L8392">“Doctor Manette,” said Mr. Lorry, touching him affectionately on the</li>
<li class="L8393" rel="L8393">arm, “the case is the case of a particularly dear friend of mine. Pray</li>
<li class="L8394" rel="L8394">give your mind to it, and advise me well for his sake--and above all,</li>
<li class="L8395" rel="L8395">for his daughter&#39;s--his daughter&#39;s, my dear Manette.”</li>
<li class="L8396" rel="L8396"></li>
<li class="L8397" rel="L8397">“If I understand,” said the Doctor, in a subdued tone, “some mental</li>
<li class="L8398" rel="L8398">shock--?”</li>
<li class="L8399" rel="L8399"></li>
<li class="L8400" rel="L8400">“Yes!”</li>
<li class="L8401" rel="L8401"></li>
<li class="L8402" rel="L8402">“Be explicit,” said the Doctor. “Spare no detail.”</li>
<li class="L8403" rel="L8403"></li>
<li class="L8404" rel="L8404">Mr. Lorry saw that they understood one another, and proceeded.</li>
<li class="L8405" rel="L8405"></li>
<li class="L8406" rel="L8406">“My dear Manette, it is the case of an old and a prolonged shock,</li>
<li class="L8407" rel="L8407">of great acuteness and severity to the affections, the feelings,</li>
<li class="L8408" rel="L8408">the--the--as you express it--the mind. The mind. It is the case of a</li>
<li class="L8409" rel="L8409">shock under which the sufferer was borne down, one cannot say for how</li>
<li class="L8410" rel="L8410">long, because I believe he cannot calculate the time himself, and there</li>
<li class="L8411" rel="L8411">are no other means of getting at it. It is the case of a shock from</li>
<li class="L8412" rel="L8412">which the sufferer recovered, by a process that he cannot trace</li>
<li class="L8413" rel="L8413">himself--as I once heard him publicly relate in a striking manner. It is</li>
<li class="L8414" rel="L8414">the case of a shock from which he has recovered, so completely, as to</li>
<li class="L8415" rel="L8415">be a highly intelligent man, capable of close application of mind, and</li>
<li class="L8416" rel="L8416">great exertion of body, and of constantly making fresh additions to his</li>
<li class="L8417" rel="L8417">stock of knowledge, which was already very large. But, unfortunately,</li>
<li class="L8418" rel="L8418">there has been,” he paused and took a deep breath--“a slight relapse.”</li>
<li class="L8419" rel="L8419"></li>
<li class="L8420" rel="L8420">The Doctor, in a low voice, asked, “Of how long duration?”</li>
<li class="L8421" rel="L8421"></li>
<li class="L8422" rel="L8422">“Nine days and nights.”</li>
<li class="L8423" rel="L8423"></li>
<li class="L8424" rel="L8424">“How did it show itself? I infer,” glancing at his hands again, “in the</li>
<li class="L8425" rel="L8425">resumption of some old pursuit connected with the shock?”</li>
<li class="L8426" rel="L8426"></li>
<li class="L8427" rel="L8427">“That is the fact.”</li>
<li class="L8428" rel="L8428"></li>
<li class="L8429" rel="L8429">“Now, did you ever see him,” asked the Doctor, distinctly and</li>
<li class="L8430" rel="L8430">collectedly, though in the same low voice, “engaged in that pursuit</li>
<li class="L8431" rel="L8431">originally?”</li>
<li class="L8432" rel="L8432"></li>
<li class="L8433" rel="L8433">“Once.”</li>
<li class="L8434" rel="L8434"></li>
<li class="L8435" rel="L8435">“And when the relapse fell on him, was he in most respects--or in all</li>
<li class="L8436" rel="L8436">respects--as he was then?”</li>
<li class="L8437" rel="L8437"></li>
<li class="L8438" rel="L8438">“I think in all respects.”</li>
<li class="L8439" rel="L8439"></li>
<li class="L8440" rel="L8440">“You spoke of his daughter. Does his daughter know of the relapse?”</li>
<li class="L8441" rel="L8441"></li>
<li class="L8442" rel="L8442">“No. It has been kept from her, and I hope will always be kept from her.</li>
<li class="L8443" rel="L8443">It is known only to myself, and to one other who may be trusted.”</li>
<li class="L8444" rel="L8444"></li>
<li class="L8445" rel="L8445">The Doctor grasped his hand, and murmured, “That was very kind. That was</li>
<li class="L8446" rel="L8446">very thoughtful!” Mr. Lorry grasped his hand in return, and neither of</li>
<li class="L8447" rel="L8447">the two spoke for a little while.</li>
<li class="L8448" rel="L8448"></li>
<li class="L8449" rel="L8449">“Now, my dear Manette,” said Mr. Lorry, at length, in his most</li>
<li class="L8450" rel="L8450">considerate and most affectionate way, “I am a mere man of business,</li>
<li class="L8451" rel="L8451">and unfit to cope with such intricate and difficult matters. I do not</li>
<li class="L8452" rel="L8452">possess the kind of information necessary; I do not possess the kind of</li>
<li class="L8453" rel="L8453">intelligence; I want guiding. There is no man in this world on whom</li>
<li class="L8454" rel="L8454">I could so rely for right guidance, as on you. Tell me, how does this</li>
<li class="L8455" rel="L8455">relapse come about? Is there danger of another? Could a repetition of it</li>
<li class="L8456" rel="L8456">be prevented? How should a repetition of it be treated? How does it come</li>
<li class="L8457" rel="L8457">about at all? What can I do for my friend? No man ever can have been</li>
<li class="L8458" rel="L8458">more desirous in his heart to serve a friend, than I am to serve mine,</li>
<li class="L8459" rel="L8459">if I knew how.</li>
<li class="L8460" rel="L8460"></li>
<li class="L8461" rel="L8461">“But I don&#39;t know how to originate, in such a case. If your sagacity,</li>
<li class="L8462" rel="L8462">knowledge, and experience, could put me on the right track, I might be</li>
<li class="L8463" rel="L8463">able to do so much; unenlightened and undirected, I can do so little.</li>
<li class="L8464" rel="L8464">Pray discuss it with me; pray enable me to see it a little more clearly,</li>
<li class="L8465" rel="L8465">and teach me how to be a little more useful.”</li>
<li class="L8466" rel="L8466"></li>
<li class="L8467" rel="L8467">Doctor Manette sat meditating after these earnest words were spoken, and</li>
<li class="L8468" rel="L8468">Mr. Lorry did not press him.</li>
<li class="L8469" rel="L8469"></li>
<li class="L8470" rel="L8470">“I think it probable,” said the Doctor, breaking silence with an effort,</li>
<li class="L8471" rel="L8471">“that the relapse you have described, my dear friend, was not quite</li>
<li class="L8472" rel="L8472">unforeseen by its subject.”</li>
<li class="L8473" rel="L8473"></li>
<li class="L8474" rel="L8474">“Was it dreaded by him?” Mr. Lorry ventured to ask.</li>
<li class="L8475" rel="L8475"></li>
<li class="L8476" rel="L8476">“Very much.” He said it with an involuntary shudder.</li>
<li class="L8477" rel="L8477"></li>
<li class="L8478" rel="L8478">“You have no idea how such an apprehension weighs on the sufferer&#39;s</li>
<li class="L8479" rel="L8479">mind, and how difficult--how almost impossible--it is, for him to force</li>
<li class="L8480" rel="L8480">himself to utter a word upon the topic that oppresses him.”</li>
<li class="L8481" rel="L8481"></li>
<li class="L8482" rel="L8482">“Would he,” asked Mr. Lorry, “be sensibly relieved if he could prevail</li>
<li class="L8483" rel="L8483">upon himself to impart that secret brooding to any one, when it is on</li>
<li class="L8484" rel="L8484">him?”</li>
<li class="L8485" rel="L8485"></li>
<li class="L8486" rel="L8486">“I think so. But it is, as I have told you, next to impossible. I even</li>
<li class="L8487" rel="L8487">believe it--in some cases--to be quite impossible.”</li>
<li class="L8488" rel="L8488"></li>
<li class="L8489" rel="L8489">“Now,” said Mr. Lorry, gently laying his hand on the Doctor&#39;s arm again,</li>
<li class="L8490" rel="L8490">after a short silence on both sides, “to what would you refer this</li>
<li class="L8491" rel="L8491">attack?”</li>
<li class="L8492" rel="L8492"></li>
<li class="L8493" rel="L8493">“I believe,” returned Doctor Manette, “that there had been a strong and</li>
<li class="L8494" rel="L8494">extraordinary revival of the train of thought and remembrance that</li>
<li class="L8495" rel="L8495">was the first cause of the malady. Some intense associations of a most</li>
<li class="L8496" rel="L8496">distressing nature were vividly recalled, I think. It is probable that</li>
<li class="L8497" rel="L8497">there had long been a dread lurking in his mind, that those associations</li>
<li class="L8498" rel="L8498">would be recalled--say, under certain circumstances--say, on a</li>
<li class="L8499" rel="L8499">particular occasion. He tried to prepare himself in vain; perhaps the</li>
<li class="L8500" rel="L8500">effort to prepare himself made him less able to bear it.”</li>
<li class="L8501" rel="L8501"></li>
<li class="L8502" rel="L8502">“Would he remember what took place in the relapse?” asked Mr. Lorry,</li>
<li class="L8503" rel="L8503">with natural hesitation.</li>
<li class="L8504" rel="L8504"></li>
<li class="L8505" rel="L8505">The Doctor looked desolately round the room, shook his head, and</li>
<li class="L8506" rel="L8506">answered, in a low voice, “Not at all.”</li>
<li class="L8507" rel="L8507"></li>
<li class="L8508" rel="L8508">“Now, as to the future,” hinted Mr. Lorry.</li>
<li class="L8509" rel="L8509"></li>
<li class="L8510" rel="L8510">“As to the future,” said the Doctor, recovering firmness, “I should have</li>
<li class="L8511" rel="L8511">great hope. As it pleased Heaven in its mercy to restore him so soon, I</li>
<li class="L8512" rel="L8512">should have great hope. He, yielding under the pressure of a complicated</li>
<li class="L8513" rel="L8513">something, long dreaded and long vaguely foreseen and contended against,</li>
<li class="L8514" rel="L8514">and recovering after the cloud had burst and passed, I should hope that</li>
<li class="L8515" rel="L8515">the worst was over.”</li>
<li class="L8516" rel="L8516"></li>
<li class="L8517" rel="L8517">“Well, well! That&#39;s good comfort. I am thankful!” said Mr. Lorry.</li>
<li class="L8518" rel="L8518"></li>
<li class="L8519" rel="L8519">“I am thankful!” repeated the Doctor, bending his head with reverence.</li>
<li class="L8520" rel="L8520"></li>
<li class="L8521" rel="L8521">“There are two other points,” said Mr. Lorry, “on which I am anxious to</li>
<li class="L8522" rel="L8522">be instructed. I may go on?”</li>
<li class="L8523" rel="L8523"></li>
<li class="L8524" rel="L8524">“You cannot do your friend a better service.” The Doctor gave him his</li>
<li class="L8525" rel="L8525">hand.</li>
<li class="L8526" rel="L8526"></li>
<li class="L8527" rel="L8527">“To the first, then. He is of a studious habit, and unusually energetic;</li>
<li class="L8528" rel="L8528">he applies himself with great ardour to the acquisition of professional</li>
<li class="L8529" rel="L8529">knowledge, to the conducting of experiments, to many things. Now, does</li>
<li class="L8530" rel="L8530">he do too much?”</li>
<li class="L8531" rel="L8531"></li>
<li class="L8532" rel="L8532">“I think not. It may be the character of his mind, to be always in</li>
<li class="L8533" rel="L8533">singular need of occupation. That may be, in part, natural to it; in</li>
<li class="L8534" rel="L8534">part, the result of affliction. The less it was occupied with healthy</li>
<li class="L8535" rel="L8535">things, the more it would be in danger of turning in the unhealthy</li>
<li class="L8536" rel="L8536">direction. He may have observed himself, and made the discovery.”</li>
<li class="L8537" rel="L8537"></li>
<li class="L8538" rel="L8538">“You are sure that he is not under too great a strain?”</li>
<li class="L8539" rel="L8539"></li>
<li class="L8540" rel="L8540">“I think I am quite sure of it.”</li>
<li class="L8541" rel="L8541"></li>
<li class="L8542" rel="L8542">“My dear Manette, if he were overworked now--”</li>
<li class="L8543" rel="L8543"></li>
<li class="L8544" rel="L8544">“My dear Lorry, I doubt if that could easily be. There has been a</li>
<li class="L8545" rel="L8545">violent stress in one direction, and it needs a counterweight.”</li>
<li class="L8546" rel="L8546"></li>
<li class="L8547" rel="L8547">“Excuse me, as a persistent man of business. Assuming for a moment,</li>
<li class="L8548" rel="L8548">that he _was_ overworked; it would show itself in some renewal of this</li>
<li class="L8549" rel="L8549">disorder?”</li>
<li class="L8550" rel="L8550"></li>
<li class="L8551" rel="L8551">“I do not think so. I do not think,” said Doctor Manette with the</li>
<li class="L8552" rel="L8552">firmness of self-conviction, “that anything but the one train of</li>
<li class="L8553" rel="L8553">association would renew it. I think that, henceforth, nothing but some</li>
<li class="L8554" rel="L8554">extraordinary jarring of that chord could renew it. After what has</li>
<li class="L8555" rel="L8555">happened, and after his recovery, I find it difficult to imagine any</li>
<li class="L8556" rel="L8556">such violent sounding of that string again. I trust, and I almost</li>
<li class="L8557" rel="L8557">believe, that the circumstances likely to renew it are exhausted.”</li>
<li class="L8558" rel="L8558"></li>
<li class="L8559" rel="L8559">He spoke with the diffidence of a man who knew how slight a thing</li>
<li class="L8560" rel="L8560">would overset the delicate organisation of the mind, and yet with the</li>
<li class="L8561" rel="L8561">confidence of a man who had slowly won his assurance out of personal</li>
<li class="L8562" rel="L8562">endurance and distress. It was not for his friend to abate that</li>
<li class="L8563" rel="L8563">confidence. He professed himself more relieved and encouraged than he</li>
<li class="L8564" rel="L8564">really was, and approached his second and last point. He felt it to</li>
<li class="L8565" rel="L8565">be the most difficult of all; but, remembering his old Sunday morning</li>
<li class="L8566" rel="L8566">conversation with Miss Pross, and remembering what he had seen in the</li>
<li class="L8567" rel="L8567">last nine days, he knew that he must face it.</li>
<li class="L8568" rel="L8568"></li>
<li class="L8569" rel="L8569">“The occupation resumed under the influence of this passing affliction</li>
<li class="L8570" rel="L8570">so happily recovered from,” said Mr. Lorry, clearing his throat, “we</li>
<li class="L8571" rel="L8571">will call--Blacksmith&#39;s work, Blacksmith&#39;s work. We will say, to put a</li>
<li class="L8572" rel="L8572">case and for the sake of illustration, that he had been used, in his bad</li>
<li class="L8573" rel="L8573">time, to work at a little forge. We will say that he was unexpectedly</li>
<li class="L8574" rel="L8574">found at his forge again. Is it not a pity that he should keep it by</li>
<li class="L8575" rel="L8575">him?”</li>
<li class="L8576" rel="L8576"></li>
<li class="L8577" rel="L8577">The Doctor shaded his forehead with his hand, and beat his foot</li>
<li class="L8578" rel="L8578">nervously on the ground.</li>
<li class="L8579" rel="L8579"></li>
<li class="L8580" rel="L8580">“He has always kept it by him,” said Mr. Lorry, with an anxious look at</li>
<li class="L8581" rel="L8581">his friend. “Now, would it not be better that he should let it go?”</li>
<li class="L8582" rel="L8582"></li>
<li class="L8583" rel="L8583">Still, the Doctor, with shaded forehead, beat his foot nervously on the</li>
<li class="L8584" rel="L8584">ground.</li>
<li class="L8585" rel="L8585"></li>
<li class="L8586" rel="L8586">“You do not find it easy to advise me?” said Mr. Lorry. “I quite</li>
<li class="L8587" rel="L8587">understand it to be a nice question. And yet I think--” And there he</li>
<li class="L8588" rel="L8588">shook his head, and stopped.</li>
<li class="L8589" rel="L8589"></li>
<li class="L8590" rel="L8590">“You see,” said Doctor Manette, turning to him after an uneasy pause,</li>
<li class="L8591" rel="L8591">“it is very hard to explain, consistently, the innermost workings</li>
<li class="L8592" rel="L8592">of this poor man&#39;s mind. He once yearned so frightfully for that</li>
<li class="L8593" rel="L8593">occupation, and it was so welcome when it came; no doubt it relieved</li>
<li class="L8594" rel="L8594">his pain so much, by substituting the perplexity of the fingers for</li>
<li class="L8595" rel="L8595">the perplexity of the brain, and by substituting, as he became more</li>
<li class="L8596" rel="L8596">practised, the ingenuity of the hands, for the ingenuity of the mental</li>
<li class="L8597" rel="L8597">torture; that he has never been able to bear the thought of putting it</li>
<li class="L8598" rel="L8598">quite out of his reach. Even now, when I believe he is more hopeful of</li>
<li class="L8599" rel="L8599">himself than he has ever been, and even speaks of himself with a kind</li>
<li class="L8600" rel="L8600">of confidence, the idea that he might need that old employment, and not</li>
<li class="L8601" rel="L8601">find it, gives him a sudden sense of terror, like that which one may</li>
<li class="L8602" rel="L8602">fancy strikes to the heart of a lost child.”</li>
<li class="L8603" rel="L8603"></li>
<li class="L8604" rel="L8604">He looked like his illustration, as he raised his eyes to Mr. Lorry&#39;s</li>
<li class="L8605" rel="L8605">face.</li>
<li class="L8606" rel="L8606"></li>
<li class="L8607" rel="L8607">“But may not--mind! I ask for information, as a plodding man of business</li>
<li class="L8608" rel="L8608">who only deals with such material objects as guineas, shillings, and</li>
<li class="L8609" rel="L8609">bank-notes--may not the retention of the thing involve the retention of</li>
<li class="L8610" rel="L8610">the idea? If the thing were gone, my dear Manette, might not the fear go</li>
<li class="L8611" rel="L8611">with it? In short, is it not a concession to the misgiving, to keep the</li>
<li class="L8612" rel="L8612">forge?”</li>
<li class="L8613" rel="L8613"></li>
<li class="L8614" rel="L8614">There was another silence.</li>
<li class="L8615" rel="L8615"></li>
<li class="L8616" rel="L8616">“You see, too,” said the Doctor, tremulously, “it is such an old</li>
<li class="L8617" rel="L8617">companion.”</li>
<li class="L8618" rel="L8618"></li>
<li class="L8619" rel="L8619">“I would not keep it,” said Mr. Lorry, shaking his head; for he gained</li>
<li class="L8620" rel="L8620">in firmness as he saw the Doctor disquieted. “I would recommend him to</li>
<li class="L8621" rel="L8621">sacrifice it. I only want your authority. I am sure it does no good.</li>
<li class="L8622" rel="L8622">Come! Give me your authority, like a dear good man. For his daughter&#39;s</li>
<li class="L8623" rel="L8623">sake, my dear Manette!”</li>
<li class="L8624" rel="L8624"></li>
<li class="L8625" rel="L8625">Very strange to see what a struggle there was within him!</li>
<li class="L8626" rel="L8626"></li>
<li class="L8627" rel="L8627">“In her name, then, let it be done; I sanction it. But, I would not take</li>
<li class="L8628" rel="L8628">it away while he was present. Let it be removed when he is not there;</li>
<li class="L8629" rel="L8629">let him miss his old companion after an absence.”</li>
<li class="L8630" rel="L8630"></li>
<li class="L8631" rel="L8631">Mr. Lorry readily engaged for that, and the conference was ended. They</li>
<li class="L8632" rel="L8632">passed the day in the country, and the Doctor was quite restored. On the</li>
<li class="L8633" rel="L8633">three following days he remained perfectly well, and on the fourteenth</li>
<li class="L8634" rel="L8634">day he went away to join Lucie and her husband. The precaution that</li>
<li class="L8635" rel="L8635">had been taken to account for his silence, Mr. Lorry had previously</li>
<li class="L8636" rel="L8636">explained to him, and he had written to Lucie in accordance with it, and</li>
<li class="L8637" rel="L8637">she had no suspicions.</li>
<li class="L8638" rel="L8638"></li>
<li class="L8639" rel="L8639">On the night of the day on which he left the house, Mr. Lorry went into</li>
<li class="L8640" rel="L8640">his room with a chopper, saw, chisel, and hammer, attended by Miss Pross</li>
<li class="L8641" rel="L8641">carrying a light. There, with closed doors, and in a mysterious and</li>
<li class="L8642" rel="L8642">guilty manner, Mr. Lorry hacked the shoemaker&#39;s bench to pieces, while</li>
<li class="L8643" rel="L8643">Miss Pross held the candle as if she were assisting at a murder--for</li>
<li class="L8644" rel="L8644">which, indeed, in her grimness, she was no unsuitable figure. The</li>
<li class="L8645" rel="L8645">burning of the body (previously reduced to pieces convenient for the</li>
<li class="L8646" rel="L8646">purpose) was commenced without delay in the kitchen fire; and the tools,</li>
<li class="L8647" rel="L8647">shoes, and leather, were buried in the garden. So wicked do destruction</li>
<li class="L8648" rel="L8648">and secrecy appear to honest minds, that Mr. Lorry and Miss Pross,</li>
<li class="L8649" rel="L8649">while engaged in the commission of their deed and in the removal of its</li>
<li class="L8650" rel="L8650">traces, almost felt, and almost looked, like accomplices in a horrible</li>
<li class="L8651" rel="L8651">crime.</li>
<li class="L8652" rel="L8652"></li>
<li class="L8653" rel="L8653"></li>
<li class="L8654" rel="L8654"></li>
<li class="L8655" rel="L8655"></li>
<li class="L8656" rel="L8656">XX. A Plea</li>
<li class="L8657" rel="L8657"></li>
<li class="L8658" rel="L8658"></li>
<li class="L8659" rel="L8659">When the newly-married pair came home, the first person who appeared, to</li>
<li class="L8660" rel="L8660">offer his congratulations, was Sydney Carton. They had not been at home</li>
<li class="L8661" rel="L8661">many hours, when he presented himself. He was not improved in habits, or</li>
<li class="L8662" rel="L8662">in looks, or in manner; but there was a certain rugged air of fidelity</li>
<li class="L8663" rel="L8663">about him, which was new to the observation of Charles Darnay.</li>
<li class="L8664" rel="L8664"></li>
<li class="L8665" rel="L8665">He watched his opportunity of taking Darnay aside into a window, and of</li>
<li class="L8666" rel="L8666">speaking to him when no one overheard.</li>
<li class="L8667" rel="L8667"></li>
<li class="L8668" rel="L8668">“Mr. Darnay,” said Carton, “I wish we might be friends.”</li>
<li class="L8669" rel="L8669"></li>
<li class="L8670" rel="L8670">“We are already friends, I hope.”</li>
<li class="L8671" rel="L8671"></li>
<li class="L8672" rel="L8672">“You are good enough to say so, as a fashion of speech; but, I don&#39;t</li>
<li class="L8673" rel="L8673">mean any fashion of speech. Indeed, when I say I wish we might be</li>
<li class="L8674" rel="L8674">friends, I scarcely mean quite that, either.”</li>
<li class="L8675" rel="L8675"></li>
<li class="L8676" rel="L8676">Charles Darnay--as was natural--asked him, in all good-humour and</li>
<li class="L8677" rel="L8677">good-fellowship, what he did mean?</li>
<li class="L8678" rel="L8678"></li>
<li class="L8679" rel="L8679">“Upon my life,” said Carton, smiling, “I find that easier to comprehend</li>
<li class="L8680" rel="L8680">in my own mind, than to convey to yours. However, let me try. You</li>
<li class="L8681" rel="L8681">remember a certain famous occasion when I was more drunk than--than</li>
<li class="L8682" rel="L8682">usual?”</li>
<li class="L8683" rel="L8683"></li>
<li class="L8684" rel="L8684">“I remember a certain famous occasion when you forced me to confess that</li>
<li class="L8685" rel="L8685">you had been drinking.”</li>
<li class="L8686" rel="L8686"></li>
<li class="L8687" rel="L8687">“I remember it too. The curse of those occasions is heavy upon me, for I</li>
<li class="L8688" rel="L8688">always remember them. I hope it may be taken into account one day,</li>
<li class="L8689" rel="L8689">when all days are at an end for me! Don&#39;t be alarmed; I am not going to</li>
<li class="L8690" rel="L8690">preach.”</li>
<li class="L8691" rel="L8691"></li>
<li class="L8692" rel="L8692">“I am not at all alarmed. Earnestness in you, is anything but alarming</li>
<li class="L8693" rel="L8693">to me.”</li>
<li class="L8694" rel="L8694"></li>
<li class="L8695" rel="L8695">“Ah!” said Carton, with a careless wave of his hand, as if he waved that</li>
<li class="L8696" rel="L8696">away. “On the drunken occasion in question (one of a large number, as</li>
<li class="L8697" rel="L8697">you know), I was insufferable about liking you, and not liking you. I</li>
<li class="L8698" rel="L8698">wish you would forget it.”</li>
<li class="L8699" rel="L8699"></li>
<li class="L8700" rel="L8700">“I forgot it long ago.”</li>
<li class="L8701" rel="L8701"></li>
<li class="L8702" rel="L8702">“Fashion of speech again! But, Mr. Darnay, oblivion is not so easy to</li>
<li class="L8703" rel="L8703">me, as you represent it to be to you. I have by no means forgotten it,</li>
<li class="L8704" rel="L8704">and a light answer does not help me to forget it.”</li>
<li class="L8705" rel="L8705"></li>
<li class="L8706" rel="L8706">“If it was a light answer,” returned Darnay, “I beg your forgiveness</li>
<li class="L8707" rel="L8707">for it. I had no other object than to turn a slight thing, which, to my</li>
<li class="L8708" rel="L8708">surprise, seems to trouble you too much, aside. I declare to you, on the</li>
<li class="L8709" rel="L8709">faith of a gentleman, that I have long dismissed it from my mind. Good</li>
<li class="L8710" rel="L8710">Heaven, what was there to dismiss! Have I had nothing more important to</li>
<li class="L8711" rel="L8711">remember, in the great service you rendered me that day?”</li>
<li class="L8712" rel="L8712"></li>
<li class="L8713" rel="L8713">“As to the great service,” said Carton, “I am bound to avow to you, when</li>
<li class="L8714" rel="L8714">you speak of it in that way, that it was mere professional claptrap, I</li>
<li class="L8715" rel="L8715">don&#39;t know that I cared what became of you, when I rendered it.--Mind! I</li>
<li class="L8716" rel="L8716">say when I rendered it; I am speaking of the past.”</li>
<li class="L8717" rel="L8717"></li>
<li class="L8718" rel="L8718">“You make light of the obligation,” returned Darnay, “but I will not</li>
<li class="L8719" rel="L8719">quarrel with _your_ light answer.”</li>
<li class="L8720" rel="L8720"></li>
<li class="L8721" rel="L8721">“Genuine truth, Mr. Darnay, trust me! I have gone aside from my purpose;</li>
<li class="L8722" rel="L8722">I was speaking about our being friends. Now, you know me; you know I am</li>
<li class="L8723" rel="L8723">incapable of all the higher and better flights of men. If you doubt it,</li>
<li class="L8724" rel="L8724">ask Stryver, and he&#39;ll tell you so.”</li>
<li class="L8725" rel="L8725"></li>
<li class="L8726" rel="L8726">“I prefer to form my own opinion, without the aid of his.”</li>
<li class="L8727" rel="L8727"></li>
<li class="L8728" rel="L8728">“Well! At any rate you know me as a dissolute dog, who has never done</li>
<li class="L8729" rel="L8729">any good, and never will.”</li>
<li class="L8730" rel="L8730"></li>
<li class="L8731" rel="L8731">“I don&#39;t know that you &#39;never will.&#39;”</li>
<li class="L8732" rel="L8732"></li>
<li class="L8733" rel="L8733">“But I do, and you must take my word for it. Well! If you could endure</li>
<li class="L8734" rel="L8734">to have such a worthless fellow, and a fellow of such indifferent</li>
<li class="L8735" rel="L8735">reputation, coming and going at odd times, I should ask that I might be</li>
<li class="L8736" rel="L8736">permitted to come and go as a privileged person here; that I might</li>
<li class="L8737" rel="L8737">be regarded as an useless (and I would add, if it were not for the</li>
<li class="L8738" rel="L8738">resemblance I detected between you and me, an unornamental) piece of</li>
<li class="L8739" rel="L8739">furniture, tolerated for its old service, and taken no notice of. I</li>
<li class="L8740" rel="L8740">doubt if I should abuse the permission. It is a hundred to one if I</li>
<li class="L8741" rel="L8741">should avail myself of it four times in a year. It would satisfy me, I</li>
<li class="L8742" rel="L8742">dare say, to know that I had it.”</li>
<li class="L8743" rel="L8743"></li>
<li class="L8744" rel="L8744">“Will you try?”</li>
<li class="L8745" rel="L8745"></li>
<li class="L8746" rel="L8746">“That is another way of saying that I am placed on the footing I have</li>
<li class="L8747" rel="L8747">indicated. I thank you, Darnay. I may use that freedom with your name?”</li>
<li class="L8748" rel="L8748"></li>
<li class="L8749" rel="L8749">“I think so, Carton, by this time.”</li>
<li class="L8750" rel="L8750"></li>
<li class="L8751" rel="L8751">They shook hands upon it, and Sydney turned away. Within a minute</li>
<li class="L8752" rel="L8752">afterwards, he was, to all outward appearance, as unsubstantial as ever.</li>
<li class="L8753" rel="L8753"></li>
<li class="L8754" rel="L8754">When he was gone, and in the course of an evening passed with Miss</li>
