<li class="L8755" rel="L8755">Pross, the Doctor, and Mr. Lorry, Charles Darnay made some mention of</li>
<li class="L8756" rel="L8756">this conversation in general terms, and spoke of Sydney Carton as a</li>
<li class="L8757" rel="L8757">problem of carelessness and recklessness. He spoke of him, in short, not</li>
<li class="L8758" rel="L8758">bitterly or meaning to bear hard upon him, but as anybody might who saw</li>
<li class="L8759" rel="L8759">him as he showed himself.</li>
<li class="L8760" rel="L8760"></li>
<li class="L8761" rel="L8761">He had no idea that this could dwell in the thoughts of his fair young</li>
<li class="L8762" rel="L8762">wife; but, when he afterwards joined her in their own rooms, he found</li>
<li class="L8763" rel="L8763">her waiting for him with the old pretty lifting of the forehead strongly</li>
<li class="L8764" rel="L8764">marked.</li>
<li class="L8765" rel="L8765"></li>
<li class="L8766" rel="L8766">“We are thoughtful to-night!” said Darnay, drawing his arm about her.</li>
<li class="L8767" rel="L8767"></li>
<li class="L8768" rel="L8768">“Yes, dearest Charles,” with her hands on his breast, and the inquiring</li>
<li class="L8769" rel="L8769">and attentive expression fixed upon him; “we are rather thoughtful</li>
<li class="L8770" rel="L8770">to-night, for we have something on our mind to-night.”</li>
<li class="L8771" rel="L8771"></li>
<li class="L8772" rel="L8772">“What is it, my Lucie?”</li>
<li class="L8773" rel="L8773"></li>
<li class="L8774" rel="L8774">“Will you promise not to press one question on me, if I beg you not to</li>
<li class="L8775" rel="L8775">ask it?”</li>
<li class="L8776" rel="L8776"></li>
<li class="L8777" rel="L8777">“Will I promise? What will I not promise to my Love?”</li>
<li class="L8778" rel="L8778"></li>
<li class="L8779" rel="L8779">What, indeed, with his hand putting aside the golden hair from the</li>
<li class="L8780" rel="L8780">cheek, and his other hand against the heart that beat for him!</li>
<li class="L8781" rel="L8781"></li>
<li class="L8782" rel="L8782">“I think, Charles, poor Mr. Carton deserves more consideration and</li>
<li class="L8783" rel="L8783">respect than you expressed for him to-night.”</li>
<li class="L8784" rel="L8784"></li>
<li class="L8785" rel="L8785">“Indeed, my own? Why so?”</li>
<li class="L8786" rel="L8786"></li>
<li class="L8787" rel="L8787">“That is what you are not to ask me. But I think--I know--he does.”</li>
<li class="L8788" rel="L8788"></li>
<li class="L8789" rel="L8789">“If you know it, it is enough. What would you have me do, my Life?”</li>
<li class="L8790" rel="L8790"></li>
<li class="L8791" rel="L8791">“I would ask you, dearest, to be very generous with him always, and very</li>
<li class="L8792" rel="L8792">lenient on his faults when he is not by. I would ask you to believe that</li>
<li class="L8793" rel="L8793">he has a heart he very, very seldom reveals, and that there are deep</li>
<li class="L8794" rel="L8794">wounds in it. My dear, I have seen it bleeding.”</li>
<li class="L8795" rel="L8795"></li>
<li class="L8796" rel="L8796">“It is a painful reflection to me,” said Charles Darnay, quite</li>
<li class="L8797" rel="L8797">astounded, “that I should have done him any wrong. I never thought this</li>
<li class="L8798" rel="L8798">of him.”</li>
<li class="L8799" rel="L8799"></li>
<li class="L8800" rel="L8800">“My husband, it is so. I fear he is not to be reclaimed; there is</li>
<li class="L8801" rel="L8801">scarcely a hope that anything in his character or fortunes is reparable</li>
<li class="L8802" rel="L8802">now. But, I am sure that he is capable of good things, gentle things,</li>
<li class="L8803" rel="L8803">even magnanimous things.”</li>
<li class="L8804" rel="L8804"></li>
<li class="L8805" rel="L8805">She looked so beautiful in the purity of her faith in this lost man,</li>
<li class="L8806" rel="L8806">that her husband could have looked at her as she was for hours.</li>
<li class="L8807" rel="L8807"></li>
<li class="L8808" rel="L8808">“And, O my dearest Love!” she urged, clinging nearer to him, laying her</li>
<li class="L8809" rel="L8809">head upon his breast, and raising her eyes to his, “remember how strong</li>
<li class="L8810" rel="L8810">we are in our happiness, and how weak he is in his misery!”</li>
<li class="L8811" rel="L8811"></li>
<li class="L8812" rel="L8812">The supplication touched him home. “I will always remember it, dear</li>
<li class="L8813" rel="L8813">Heart! I will remember it as long as I live.”</li>
<li class="L8814" rel="L8814"></li>
<li class="L8815" rel="L8815">He bent over the golden head, and put the rosy lips to his, and folded</li>
<li class="L8816" rel="L8816">her in his arms. If one forlorn wanderer then pacing the dark streets,</li>
<li class="L8817" rel="L8817">could have heard her innocent disclosure, and could have seen the drops</li>
<li class="L8818" rel="L8818">of pity kissed away by her husband from the soft blue eyes so loving of</li>
<li class="L8819" rel="L8819">that husband, he might have cried to the night--and the words would not</li>
<li class="L8820" rel="L8820">have parted from his lips for the first time--</li>
<li class="L8821" rel="L8821"></li>
<li class="L8822" rel="L8822">“God bless her for her sweet compassion!”</li>
<li class="L8823" rel="L8823"></li>
<li class="L8824" rel="L8824"></li>
<li class="L8825" rel="L8825"></li>
<li class="L8826" rel="L8826"></li>
<li class="L8827" rel="L8827">XXI. Echoing Footsteps</li>
<li class="L8828" rel="L8828"></li>
<li class="L8829" rel="L8829"></li>
<li class="L8830" rel="L8830">A wonderful corner for echoes, it has been remarked, that corner where</li>
<li class="L8831" rel="L8831">the Doctor lived. Ever busily winding the golden thread which bound</li>
<li class="L8832" rel="L8832">her husband, and her father, and herself, and her old directress and</li>
<li class="L8833" rel="L8833">companion, in a life of quiet bliss, Lucie sat in the still house in</li>
<li class="L8834" rel="L8834">the tranquilly resounding corner, listening to the echoing footsteps of</li>
<li class="L8835" rel="L8835">years.</li>
<li class="L8836" rel="L8836"></li>
<li class="L8837" rel="L8837">At first, there were times, though she was a perfectly happy young wife,</li>
<li class="L8838" rel="L8838">when her work would slowly fall from her hands, and her eyes would be</li>
<li class="L8839" rel="L8839">dimmed. For, there was something coming in the echoes, something light,</li>
<li class="L8840" rel="L8840">afar off, and scarcely audible yet, that stirred her heart too much.</li>
<li class="L8841" rel="L8841">Fluttering hopes and doubts--hopes, of a love as yet unknown to her:</li>
<li class="L8842" rel="L8842">doubts, of her remaining upon earth, to enjoy that new delight--divided</li>
<li class="L8843" rel="L8843">her breast. Among the echoes then, there would arise the sound of</li>
<li class="L8844" rel="L8844">footsteps at her own early grave; and thoughts of the husband who would</li>
<li class="L8845" rel="L8845">be left so desolate, and who would mourn for her so much, swelled to her</li>
<li class="L8846" rel="L8846">eyes, and broke like waves.</li>
<li class="L8847" rel="L8847"></li>
<li class="L8848" rel="L8848">That time passed, and her little Lucie lay on her bosom. Then, among the</li>
<li class="L8849" rel="L8849">advancing echoes, there was the tread of her tiny feet and the sound of</li>
<li class="L8850" rel="L8850">her prattling words. Let greater echoes resound as they would, the young</li>
<li class="L8851" rel="L8851">mother at the cradle side could always hear those coming. They came, and</li>
<li class="L8852" rel="L8852">the shady house was sunny with a child&#39;s laugh, and the Divine friend of</li>
<li class="L8853" rel="L8853">children, to whom in her trouble she had confided hers, seemed to take</li>
<li class="L8854" rel="L8854">her child in his arms, as He took the child of old, and made it a sacred</li>
<li class="L8855" rel="L8855">joy to her.</li>
<li class="L8856" rel="L8856"></li>
<li class="L8857" rel="L8857">Ever busily winding the golden thread that bound them all together,</li>
<li class="L8858" rel="L8858">weaving the service of her happy influence through the tissue of all</li>
<li class="L8859" rel="L8859">their lives, and making it predominate nowhere, Lucie heard in the</li>
<li class="L8860" rel="L8860">echoes of years none but friendly and soothing sounds. Her husband&#39;s</li>
<li class="L8861" rel="L8861">step was strong and prosperous among them; her father&#39;s firm and equal.</li>
<li class="L8862" rel="L8862">Lo, Miss Pross, in harness of string, awakening the echoes, as an</li>
<li class="L8863" rel="L8863">unruly charger, whip-corrected, snorting and pawing the earth under the</li>
<li class="L8864" rel="L8864">plane-tree in the garden!</li>
<li class="L8865" rel="L8865"></li>
<li class="L8866" rel="L8866">Even when there were sounds of sorrow among the rest, they were not</li>
<li class="L8867" rel="L8867">harsh nor cruel. Even when golden hair, like her own, lay in a halo on a</li>
<li class="L8868" rel="L8868">pillow round the worn face of a little boy, and he said, with a radiant</li>
<li class="L8869" rel="L8869">smile, “Dear papa and mamma, I am very sorry to leave you both, and to</li>
<li class="L8870" rel="L8870">leave my pretty sister; but I am called, and I must go!” those were not</li>
<li class="L8871" rel="L8871">tears all of agony that wetted his young mother&#39;s cheek, as the spirit</li>
<li class="L8872" rel="L8872">departed from her embrace that had been entrusted to it. Suffer them and</li>
<li class="L8873" rel="L8873">forbid them not. They see my Father&#39;s face. O Father, blessed words!</li>
<li class="L8874" rel="L8874"></li>
<li class="L8875" rel="L8875">Thus, the rustling of an Angel&#39;s wings got blended with the other</li>
<li class="L8876" rel="L8876">echoes, and they were not wholly of earth, but had in them that breath</li>
<li class="L8877" rel="L8877">of Heaven. Sighs of the winds that blew over a little garden-tomb were</li>
<li class="L8878" rel="L8878">mingled with them also, and both were audible to Lucie, in a hushed</li>
<li class="L8879" rel="L8879">murmur--like the breathing of a summer sea asleep upon a sandy shore--as</li>
<li class="L8880" rel="L8880">the little Lucie, comically studious at the task of the morning, or</li>
<li class="L8881" rel="L8881">dressing a doll at her mother&#39;s footstool, chattered in the tongues of</li>
<li class="L8882" rel="L8882">the Two Cities that were blended in her life.</li>
<li class="L8883" rel="L8883"></li>
<li class="L8884" rel="L8884">The Echoes rarely answered to the actual tread of Sydney Carton. Some</li>
<li class="L8885" rel="L8885">half-dozen times a year, at most, he claimed his privilege of coming in</li>
<li class="L8886" rel="L8886">uninvited, and would sit among them through the evening, as he had once</li>
<li class="L8887" rel="L8887">done often. He never came there heated with wine. And one other thing</li>
<li class="L8888" rel="L8888">regarding him was whispered in the echoes, which has been whispered by</li>
<li class="L8889" rel="L8889">all true echoes for ages and ages.</li>
<li class="L8890" rel="L8890"></li>
<li class="L8891" rel="L8891">No man ever really loved a woman, lost her, and knew her with a</li>
<li class="L8892" rel="L8892">blameless though an unchanged mind, when she was a wife and a mother,</li>
<li class="L8893" rel="L8893">but her children had a strange sympathy with him--an instinctive</li>
<li class="L8894" rel="L8894">delicacy of pity for him. What fine hidden sensibilities are touched in</li>
<li class="L8895" rel="L8895">such a case, no echoes tell; but it is so, and it was so here. Carton</li>
<li class="L8896" rel="L8896">was the first stranger to whom little Lucie held out her chubby arms,</li>
<li class="L8897" rel="L8897">and he kept his place with her as she grew. The little boy had spoken of</li>
<li class="L8898" rel="L8898">him, almost at the last. “Poor Carton! Kiss him for me!”</li>
<li class="L8899" rel="L8899"></li>
<li class="L8900" rel="L8900">Mr. Stryver shouldered his way through the law, like some great engine</li>
<li class="L8901" rel="L8901">forcing itself through turbid water, and dragged his useful friend in</li>
<li class="L8902" rel="L8902">his wake, like a boat towed astern. As the boat so favoured is usually</li>
<li class="L8903" rel="L8903">in a rough plight, and mostly under water, so, Sydney had a swamped</li>
<li class="L8904" rel="L8904">life of it. But, easy and strong custom, unhappily so much easier and</li>
<li class="L8905" rel="L8905">stronger in him than any stimulating sense of desert or disgrace, made</li>
<li class="L8906" rel="L8906">it the life he was to lead; and he no more thought of emerging from his</li>
<li class="L8907" rel="L8907">state of lion&#39;s jackal, than any real jackal may be supposed to think of</li>
<li class="L8908" rel="L8908">rising to be a lion. Stryver was rich; had married a florid widow with</li>
<li class="L8909" rel="L8909">property and three boys, who had nothing particularly shining about them</li>
<li class="L8910" rel="L8910">but the straight hair of their dumpling heads.</li>
<li class="L8911" rel="L8911"></li>
<li class="L8912" rel="L8912">These three young gentlemen, Mr. Stryver, exuding patronage of the most</li>
<li class="L8913" rel="L8913">offensive quality from every pore, had walked before him like three</li>
<li class="L8914" rel="L8914">sheep to the quiet corner in Soho, and had offered as pupils to</li>
<li class="L8915" rel="L8915">Lucie&#39;s husband: delicately saying “Halloa! here are three lumps of</li>
<li class="L8916" rel="L8916">bread-and-cheese towards your matrimonial picnic, Darnay!” The polite</li>
<li class="L8917" rel="L8917">rejection of the three lumps of bread-and-cheese had quite bloated Mr.</li>
<li class="L8918" rel="L8918">Stryver with indignation, which he afterwards turned to account in the</li>
<li class="L8919" rel="L8919">training of the young gentlemen, by directing them to beware of the</li>
<li class="L8920" rel="L8920">pride of Beggars, like that tutor-fellow. He was also in the habit of</li>
<li class="L8921" rel="L8921">declaiming to Mrs. Stryver, over his full-bodied wine, on the arts</li>
<li class="L8922" rel="L8922">Mrs. Darnay had once put in practice to “catch” him, and on the</li>
<li class="L8923" rel="L8923">diamond-cut-diamond arts in himself, madam, which had rendered him “not</li>
<li class="L8924" rel="L8924">to be caught.” Some of his King&#39;s Bench familiars, who were occasionally</li>
<li class="L8925" rel="L8925">parties to the full-bodied wine and the lie, excused him for the</li>
<li class="L8926" rel="L8926">latter by saying that he had told it so often, that he believed</li>
<li class="L8927" rel="L8927">it himself--which is surely such an incorrigible aggravation of an</li>
<li class="L8928" rel="L8928">originally bad offence, as to justify any such offender&#39;s being carried</li>
<li class="L8929" rel="L8929">off to some suitably retired spot, and there hanged out of the way.</li>
<li class="L8930" rel="L8930"></li>
<li class="L8931" rel="L8931">These were among the echoes to which Lucie, sometimes pensive, sometimes</li>
<li class="L8932" rel="L8932">amused and laughing, listened in the echoing corner, until her little</li>
<li class="L8933" rel="L8933">daughter was six years old. How near to her heart the echoes of her</li>
<li class="L8934" rel="L8934">child&#39;s tread came, and those of her own dear father&#39;s, always active</li>
<li class="L8935" rel="L8935">and self-possessed, and those of her dear husband&#39;s, need not be told.</li>
<li class="L8936" rel="L8936">Nor, how the lightest echo of their united home, directed by herself</li>
<li class="L8937" rel="L8937">with such a wise and elegant thrift that it was more abundant than any</li>
<li class="L8938" rel="L8938">waste, was music to her. Nor, how there were echoes all about her, sweet</li>
<li class="L8939" rel="L8939">in her ears, of the many times her father had told her that he found her</li>
<li class="L8940" rel="L8940">more devoted to him married (if that could be) than single, and of the</li>
<li class="L8941" rel="L8941">many times her husband had said to her that no cares and duties seemed</li>
<li class="L8942" rel="L8942">to divide her love for him or her help to him, and asked her “What is</li>
<li class="L8943" rel="L8943">the magic secret, my darling, of your being everything to all of us,</li>
<li class="L8944" rel="L8944">as if there were only one of us, yet never seeming to be hurried, or to</li>
<li class="L8945" rel="L8945">have too much to do?”</li>
<li class="L8946" rel="L8946"></li>
<li class="L8947" rel="L8947">But, there were other echoes, from a distance, that rumbled menacingly</li>
<li class="L8948" rel="L8948">in the corner all through this space of time. And it was now, about</li>
<li class="L8949" rel="L8949">little Lucie&#39;s sixth birthday, that they began to have an awful sound,</li>
<li class="L8950" rel="L8950">as of a great storm in France with a dreadful sea rising.</li>
<li class="L8951" rel="L8951"></li>
<li class="L8952" rel="L8952">On a night in mid-July, one thousand seven hundred and eighty-nine, Mr.</li>
<li class="L8953" rel="L8953">Lorry came in late, from Tellson&#39;s, and sat himself down by Lucie and</li>
<li class="L8954" rel="L8954">her husband in the dark window. It was a hot, wild night, and they were</li>
<li class="L8955" rel="L8955">all three reminded of the old Sunday night when they had looked at the</li>
<li class="L8956" rel="L8956">lightning from the same place.</li>
<li class="L8957" rel="L8957"></li>
<li class="L8958" rel="L8958">“I began to think,” said Mr. Lorry, pushing his brown wig back, “that</li>
<li class="L8959" rel="L8959">I should have to pass the night at Tellson&#39;s. We have been so full of</li>
<li class="L8960" rel="L8960">business all day, that we have not known what to do first, or which way</li>
<li class="L8961" rel="L8961">to turn. There is such an uneasiness in Paris, that we have actually a</li>
<li class="L8962" rel="L8962">run of confidence upon us! Our customers over there, seem not to be able</li>
<li class="L8963" rel="L8963">to confide their property to us fast enough. There is positively a mania</li>
<li class="L8964" rel="L8964">among some of them for sending it to England.”</li>
<li class="L8965" rel="L8965"></li>
<li class="L8966" rel="L8966">“That has a bad look,” said Darnay--</li>
<li class="L8967" rel="L8967"></li>
<li class="L8968" rel="L8968">“A bad look, you say, my dear Darnay? Yes, but we don&#39;t know what reason</li>
<li class="L8969" rel="L8969">there is in it. People are so unreasonable! Some of us at Tellson&#39;s are</li>
<li class="L8970" rel="L8970">getting old, and we really can&#39;t be troubled out of the ordinary course</li>
<li class="L8971" rel="L8971">without due occasion.”</li>
<li class="L8972" rel="L8972"></li>
<li class="L8973" rel="L8973">“Still,” said Darnay, “you know how gloomy and threatening the sky is.”</li>
<li class="L8974" rel="L8974"></li>
<li class="L8975" rel="L8975">“I know that, to be sure,” assented Mr. Lorry, trying to persuade</li>
<li class="L8976" rel="L8976">himself that his sweet temper was soured, and that he grumbled, “but I</li>
<li class="L8977" rel="L8977">am determined to be peevish after my long day&#39;s botheration. Where is</li>
<li class="L8978" rel="L8978">Manette?”</li>
<li class="L8979" rel="L8979"></li>
<li class="L8980" rel="L8980">“Here he is,” said the Doctor, entering the dark room at the moment.</li>
<li class="L8981" rel="L8981"></li>
<li class="L8982" rel="L8982">“I am quite glad you are at home; for these hurries and forebodings by</li>
<li class="L8983" rel="L8983">which I have been surrounded all day long, have made me nervous without</li>
<li class="L8984" rel="L8984">reason. You are not going out, I hope?”</li>
<li class="L8985" rel="L8985"></li>
<li class="L8986" rel="L8986">“No; I am going to play backgammon with you, if you like,” said the</li>
<li class="L8987" rel="L8987">Doctor.</li>
<li class="L8988" rel="L8988"></li>
<li class="L8989" rel="L8989">“I don&#39;t think I do like, if I may speak my mind. I am not fit to be</li>
<li class="L8990" rel="L8990">pitted against you to-night. Is the teaboard still there, Lucie? I can&#39;t</li>
<li class="L8991" rel="L8991">see.”</li>
<li class="L8992" rel="L8992"></li>
<li class="L8993" rel="L8993">“Of course, it has been kept for you.”</li>
<li class="L8994" rel="L8994"></li>
<li class="L8995" rel="L8995">“Thank ye, my dear. The precious child is safe in bed?”</li>
<li class="L8996" rel="L8996"></li>
<li class="L8997" rel="L8997">“And sleeping soundly.”</li>
<li class="L8998" rel="L8998"></li>
<li class="L8999" rel="L8999">“That&#39;s right; all safe and well! I don&#39;t know why anything should be</li>
<li class="L9000" rel="L9000">otherwise than safe and well here, thank God; but I have been so put out</li>
<li class="L9001" rel="L9001">all day, and I am not as young as I was! My tea, my dear! Thank ye. Now,</li>
<li class="L9002" rel="L9002">come and take your place in the circle, and let us sit quiet, and hear</li>
<li class="L9003" rel="L9003">the echoes about which you have your theory.”</li>
<li class="L9004" rel="L9004"></li>
<li class="L9005" rel="L9005">“Not a theory; it was a fancy.”</li>
<li class="L9006" rel="L9006"></li>
<li class="L9007" rel="L9007">“A fancy, then, my wise pet,” said Mr. Lorry, patting her hand. “They</li>
<li class="L9008" rel="L9008">are very numerous and very loud, though, are they not? Only hear them!”</li>
<li class="L9009" rel="L9009"></li>
<li class="L9010" rel="L9010">Headlong, mad, and dangerous footsteps to force their way into anybody&#39;s</li>
<li class="L9011" rel="L9011">life, footsteps not easily made clean again if once stained red, the</li>
<li class="L9012" rel="L9012">footsteps raging in Saint Antoine afar off, as the little circle sat in</li>
<li class="L9013" rel="L9013">the dark London window.</li>
<li class="L9014" rel="L9014"></li>
<li class="L9015" rel="L9015">Saint Antoine had been, that morning, a vast dusky mass of scarecrows</li>
<li class="L9016" rel="L9016">heaving to and fro, with frequent gleams of light above the billowy</li>
<li class="L9017" rel="L9017">heads, where steel blades and bayonets shone in the sun. A tremendous</li>
<li class="L9018" rel="L9018">roar arose from the throat of Saint Antoine, and a forest of naked arms</li>
<li class="L9019" rel="L9019">struggled in the air like shrivelled branches of trees in a winter wind:</li>
<li class="L9020" rel="L9020">all the fingers convulsively clutching at every weapon or semblance of a</li>
<li class="L9021" rel="L9021">weapon that was thrown up from the depths below, no matter how far off.</li>
<li class="L9022" rel="L9022"></li>
<li class="L9023" rel="L9023">Who gave them out, whence they last came, where they began, through what</li>
<li class="L9024" rel="L9024">agency they crookedly quivered and jerked, scores at a time, over the</li>
<li class="L9025" rel="L9025">heads of the crowd, like a kind of lightning, no eye in the throng could</li>
<li class="L9026" rel="L9026">have told; but, muskets were being distributed--so were cartridges,</li>
<li class="L9027" rel="L9027">powder, and ball, bars of iron and wood, knives, axes, pikes, every</li>
<li class="L9028" rel="L9028">weapon that distracted ingenuity could discover or devise. People who</li>
<li class="L9029" rel="L9029">could lay hold of nothing else, set themselves with bleeding hands to</li>
<li class="L9030" rel="L9030">force stones and bricks out of their places in walls. Every pulse and</li>
<li class="L9031" rel="L9031">heart in Saint Antoine was on high-fever strain and at high-fever heat.</li>
<li class="L9032" rel="L9032">Every living creature there held life as of no account, and was demented</li>
<li class="L9033" rel="L9033">with a passionate readiness to sacrifice it.</li>
<li class="L9034" rel="L9034"></li>
<li class="L9035" rel="L9035">As a whirlpool of boiling waters has a centre point, so, all this raging</li>
<li class="L9036" rel="L9036">circled round Defarge&#39;s wine-shop, and every human drop in the caldron</li>
<li class="L9037" rel="L9037">had a tendency to be sucked towards the vortex where Defarge himself,</li>
<li class="L9038" rel="L9038">already begrimed with gunpowder and sweat, issued orders, issued arms,</li>
<li class="L9039" rel="L9039">thrust this man back, dragged this man forward, disarmed one to arm</li>
<li class="L9040" rel="L9040">another, laboured and strove in the thickest of the uproar.</li>
<li class="L9041" rel="L9041"></li>
<li class="L9042" rel="L9042">“Keep near to me, Jacques Three,” cried Defarge; “and do you, Jacques</li>
<li class="L9043" rel="L9043">One and Two, separate and put yourselves at the head of as many of these</li>
<li class="L9044" rel="L9044">patriots as you can. Where is my wife?”</li>
<li class="L9045" rel="L9045"></li>
<li class="L9046" rel="L9046">“Eh, well! Here you see me!” said madame, composed as ever, but not</li>
<li class="L9047" rel="L9047">knitting to-day. Madame&#39;s resolute right hand was occupied with an axe,</li>
<li class="L9048" rel="L9048">in place of the usual softer implements, and in her girdle were a pistol</li>
<li class="L9049" rel="L9049">and a cruel knife.</li>
<li class="L9050" rel="L9050"></li>
<li class="L9051" rel="L9051">“Where do you go, my wife?”</li>
<li class="L9052" rel="L9052"></li>
<li class="L9053" rel="L9053">“I go,” said madame, “with you at present. You shall see me at the head</li>
<li class="L9054" rel="L9054">of women, by-and-bye.”</li>
<li class="L9055" rel="L9055"></li>
<li class="L9056" rel="L9056">“Come, then!” cried Defarge, in a resounding voice. “Patriots and</li>
<li class="L9057" rel="L9057">friends, we are ready! The Bastille!”</li>
<li class="L9058" rel="L9058"></li>
<li class="L9059" rel="L9059">With a roar that sounded as if all the breath in France had been shaped</li>
<li class="L9060" rel="L9060">into the detested word, the living sea rose, wave on wave, depth on</li>
<li class="L9061" rel="L9061">depth, and overflowed the city to that point. Alarm-bells ringing, drums</li>
<li class="L9062" rel="L9062">beating, the sea raging and thundering on its new beach, the attack</li>
<li class="L9063" rel="L9063">began.</li>
<li class="L9064" rel="L9064"></li>
<li class="L9065" rel="L9065">Deep ditches, double drawbridge, massive stone walls, eight great</li>
<li class="L9066" rel="L9066">towers, cannon, muskets, fire and smoke. Through the fire and through</li>
<li class="L9067" rel="L9067">the smoke--in the fire and in the smoke, for the sea cast him up against</li>
<li class="L9068" rel="L9068">a cannon, and on the instant he became a cannonier--Defarge of the</li>
<li class="L9069" rel="L9069">wine-shop worked like a manful soldier, Two fierce hours.</li>
<li class="L9070" rel="L9070"></li>
<li class="L9071" rel="L9071">Deep ditch, single drawbridge, massive stone walls, eight great towers,</li>
<li class="L9072" rel="L9072">cannon, muskets, fire and smoke. One drawbridge down! “Work, comrades</li>
<li class="L9073" rel="L9073">all, work! Work, Jacques One, Jacques Two, Jacques One Thousand, Jacques</li>
<li class="L9074" rel="L9074">Two Thousand, Jacques Five-and-Twenty Thousand; in the name of all</li>
<li class="L9075" rel="L9075">the Angels or the Devils--which you prefer--work!” Thus Defarge of the</li>
<li class="L9076" rel="L9076">wine-shop, still at his gun, which had long grown hot.</li>
<li class="L9077" rel="L9077"></li>
<li class="L9078" rel="L9078">“To me, women!” cried madame his wife. “What! We can kill as well as</li>
<li class="L9079" rel="L9079">the men when the place is taken!” And to her, with a shrill thirsty</li>
<li class="L9080" rel="L9080">cry, trooping women variously armed, but all armed alike in hunger and</li>
<li class="L9081" rel="L9081">revenge.</li>
<li class="L9082" rel="L9082"></li>
<li class="L9083" rel="L9083">Cannon, muskets, fire and smoke; but, still the deep ditch, the single</li>
<li class="L9084" rel="L9084">drawbridge, the massive stone walls, and the eight great towers. Slight</li>
<li class="L9085" rel="L9085">displacements of the raging sea, made by the falling wounded. Flashing</li>
<li class="L9086" rel="L9086">weapons, blazing torches, smoking waggonloads of wet straw, hard work</li>
<li class="L9087" rel="L9087">at neighbouring barricades in all directions, shrieks, volleys,</li>
<li class="L9088" rel="L9088">execrations, bravery without stint, boom smash and rattle, and the</li>
<li class="L9089" rel="L9089">furious sounding of the living sea; but, still the deep ditch, and the</li>
<li class="L9090" rel="L9090">single drawbridge, and the massive stone walls, and the eight great</li>
<li class="L9091" rel="L9091">towers, and still Defarge of the wine-shop at his gun, grown doubly hot</li>
<li class="L9092" rel="L9092">by the service of Four fierce hours.</li>
<li class="L9093" rel="L9093"></li>
<li class="L9094" rel="L9094">A white flag from within the fortress, and a parley--this dimly</li>
<li class="L9095" rel="L9095">perceptible through the raging storm, nothing audible in it--suddenly</li>
<li class="L9096" rel="L9096">the sea rose immeasurably wider and higher, and swept Defarge of the</li>
<li class="L9097" rel="L9097">wine-shop over the lowered drawbridge, past the massive stone outer</li>
<li class="L9098" rel="L9098">walls, in among the eight great towers surrendered!</li>
<li class="L9099" rel="L9099"></li>
<li class="L9100" rel="L9100">So resistless was the force of the ocean bearing him on, that even to</li>
<li class="L9101" rel="L9101">draw his breath or turn his head was as impracticable as if he had been</li>
<li class="L9102" rel="L9102">struggling in the surf at the South Sea, until he was landed in the</li>
<li class="L9103" rel="L9103">outer courtyard of the Bastille. There, against an angle of a wall, he</li>
<li class="L9104" rel="L9104">made a struggle to look about him. Jacques Three was nearly at his side;</li>
<li class="L9105" rel="L9105">Madame Defarge, still heading some of her women, was visible in the</li>
<li class="L9106" rel="L9106">inner distance, and her knife was in her hand. Everywhere was tumult,</li>
<li class="L9107" rel="L9107">exultation, deafening and maniacal bewilderment, astounding noise, yet</li>
<li class="L9108" rel="L9108">furious dumb-show.</li>
<li class="L9109" rel="L9109"></li>
<li class="L9110" rel="L9110">“The Prisoners!”</li>
<li class="L9111" rel="L9111"></li>
<li class="L9112" rel="L9112">“The Records!”</li>
<li class="L9113" rel="L9113"></li>
<li class="L9114" rel="L9114">“The secret cells!”</li>
<li class="L9115" rel="L9115"></li>
<li class="L9116" rel="L9116">“The instruments of torture!”</li>
<li class="L9117" rel="L9117"></li>
<li class="L9118" rel="L9118">“The Prisoners!”</li>
<li class="L9119" rel="L9119"></li>
<li class="L9120" rel="L9120">Of all these cries, and ten thousand incoherences, “The Prisoners!” was</li>
<li class="L9121" rel="L9121">the cry most taken up by the sea that rushed in, as if there were an</li>
<li class="L9122" rel="L9122">eternity of people, as well as of time and space. When the foremost</li>
<li class="L9123" rel="L9123">billows rolled past, bearing the prison officers with them, and</li>
<li class="L9124" rel="L9124">threatening them all with instant death if any secret nook remained</li>
<li class="L9125" rel="L9125">undisclosed, Defarge laid his strong hand on the breast of one of</li>
<li class="L9126" rel="L9126">these men--a man with a grey head, who had a lighted torch in his</li>
<li class="L9127" rel="L9127">hand--separated him from the rest, and got him between himself and the</li>
<li class="L9128" rel="L9128">wall.</li>
<li class="L9129" rel="L9129"></li>
<li class="L9130" rel="L9130">“Show me the North Tower!” said Defarge. “Quick!”</li>
<li class="L9131" rel="L9131"></li>
<li class="L9132" rel="L9132">“I will faithfully,” replied the man, “if you will come with me. But</li>
<li class="L9133" rel="L9133">there is no one there.”</li>
<li class="L9134" rel="L9134"></li>
<li class="L9135" rel="L9135">“What is the meaning of One Hundred and Five, North Tower?” asked</li>
<li class="L9136" rel="L9136">Defarge. “Quick!”</li>
<li class="L9137" rel="L9137"></li>
<li class="L9138" rel="L9138">“The meaning, monsieur?”</li>
<li class="L9139" rel="L9139"></li>
<li class="L9140" rel="L9140">“Does it mean a captive, or a place of captivity? Or do you mean that I</li>
<li class="L9141" rel="L9141">shall strike you dead?”</li>
<li class="L9142" rel="L9142"></li>
<li class="L9143" rel="L9143">“Kill him!” croaked Jacques Three, who had come close up.</li>
<li class="L9144" rel="L9144"></li>
<li class="L9145" rel="L9145">“Monsieur, it is a cell.”</li>
<li class="L9146" rel="L9146"></li>
<li class="L9147" rel="L9147">“Show it me!”</li>
<li class="L9148" rel="L9148"></li>
<li class="L9149" rel="L9149">“Pass this way, then.”</li>
<li class="L9150" rel="L9150"></li>
<li class="L9151" rel="L9151">Jacques Three, with his usual craving on him, and evidently disappointed</li>
<li class="L9152" rel="L9152">by the dialogue taking a turn that did not seem to promise bloodshed,</li>
<li class="L9153" rel="L9153">held by Defarge&#39;s arm as he held by the turnkey&#39;s. Their three heads had</li>
<li class="L9154" rel="L9154">been close together during this brief discourse, and it had been as much</li>
<li class="L9155" rel="L9155">as they could do to hear one another, even then: so tremendous was the</li>
<li class="L9156" rel="L9156">noise of the living ocean, in its irruption into the Fortress, and</li>
<li class="L9157" rel="L9157">its inundation of the courts and passages and staircases. All around</li>
<li class="L9158" rel="L9158">outside, too, it beat the walls with a deep, hoarse roar, from which,</li>
<li class="L9159" rel="L9159">occasionally, some partial shouts of tumult broke and leaped into the</li>
<li class="L9160" rel="L9160">air like spray.</li>
<li class="L9161" rel="L9161"></li>
<li class="L9162" rel="L9162">Through gloomy vaults where the light of day had never shone, past</li>
<li class="L9163" rel="L9163">hideous doors of dark dens and cages, down cavernous flights of steps,</li>
<li class="L9164" rel="L9164">and again up steep rugged ascents of stone and brick, more like dry</li>
<li class="L9165" rel="L9165">waterfalls than staircases, Defarge, the turnkey, and Jacques Three,</li>
<li class="L9166" rel="L9166">linked hand and arm, went with all the speed they could make. Here and</li>
<li class="L9167" rel="L9167">there, especially at first, the inundation started on them and swept by;</li>
<li class="L9168" rel="L9168">but when they had done descending, and were winding and climbing up a</li>
<li class="L9169" rel="L9169">tower, they were alone. Hemmed in here by the massive thickness of walls</li>
<li class="L9170" rel="L9170">and arches, the storm within the fortress and without was only audible</li>
<li class="L9171" rel="L9171">to them in a dull, subdued way, as if the noise out of which they had</li>
<li class="L9172" rel="L9172">come had almost destroyed their sense of hearing.</li>
<li class="L9173" rel="L9173"></li>
<li class="L9174" rel="L9174">The turnkey stopped at a low door, put a key in a clashing lock, swung</li>
<li class="L9175" rel="L9175">the door slowly open, and said, as they all bent their heads and passed</li>
<li class="L9176" rel="L9176">in:</li>
<li class="L9177" rel="L9177"></li>
<li class="L9178" rel="L9178">“One hundred and five, North Tower!”</li>
<li class="L9179" rel="L9179"></li>
<li class="L9180" rel="L9180">There was a small, heavily-grated, unglazed window high in the wall,</li>
<li class="L9181" rel="L9181">with a stone screen before it, so that the sky could be only seen by</li>
<li class="L9182" rel="L9182">stooping low and looking up. There was a small chimney, heavily barred</li>
<li class="L9183" rel="L9183">across, a few feet within. There was a heap of old feathery wood-ashes</li>
<li class="L9184" rel="L9184">on the hearth. There was a stool, and table, and a straw bed. There were</li>
<li class="L9185" rel="L9185">the four blackened walls, and a rusted iron ring in one of them.</li>
<li class="L9186" rel="L9186"></li>
<li class="L9187" rel="L9187">“Pass that torch slowly along these walls, that I may see them,” said</li>
<li class="L9188" rel="L9188">Defarge to the turnkey.</li>
<li class="L9189" rel="L9189"></li>
<li class="L9190" rel="L9190">The man obeyed, and Defarge followed the light closely with his eyes.</li>
<li class="L9191" rel="L9191"></li>
<li class="L9192" rel="L9192">“Stop!--Look here, Jacques!”</li>
<li class="L9193" rel="L9193"></li>
<li class="L9194" rel="L9194">“A. M.!” croaked Jacques Three, as he read greedily.</li>
<li class="L9195" rel="L9195"></li>
<li class="L9196" rel="L9196">“Alexandre Manette,” said Defarge in his ear, following the letters</li>
<li class="L9197" rel="L9197">with his swart forefinger, deeply engrained with gunpowder. “And here he</li>
<li class="L9198" rel="L9198">wrote &#39;a poor physician.&#39; And it was he, without doubt, who scratched</li>
<li class="L9199" rel="L9199">a calendar on this stone. What is that in your hand? A crowbar? Give it</li>
<li class="L9200" rel="L9200">me!”</li>
<li class="L9201" rel="L9201"></li>
<li class="L9202" rel="L9202">He had still the linstock of his gun in his own hand. He made a sudden</li>
<li class="L9203" rel="L9203">exchange of the two instruments, and turning on the worm-eaten stool and</li>
<li class="L9204" rel="L9204">table, beat them to pieces in a few blows.</li>
<li class="L9205" rel="L9205"></li>
<li class="L9206" rel="L9206">“Hold the light higher!” he said, wrathfully, to the turnkey. “Look</li>
<li class="L9207" rel="L9207">among those fragments with care, Jacques. And see! Here is my knife,”</li>
<li class="L9208" rel="L9208"> throwing it to him; “rip open that bed, and search the straw. Hold the</li>
<li class="L9209" rel="L9209">light higher, you!”</li>
<li class="L9210" rel="L9210"></li>
<li class="L9211" rel="L9211">With a menacing look at the turnkey he crawled upon the hearth, and,</li>
<li class="L9212" rel="L9212">peering up the chimney, struck and prised at its sides with the crowbar,</li>
<li class="L9213" rel="L9213">and worked at the iron grating across it. In a few minutes, some mortar</li>
<li class="L9214" rel="L9214">and dust came dropping down, which he averted his face to avoid; and</li>
<li class="L9215" rel="L9215">in it, and in the old wood-ashes, and in a crevice in the chimney</li>
<li class="L9216" rel="L9216">into which his weapon had slipped or wrought itself, he groped with a</li>
<li class="L9217" rel="L9217">cautious touch.</li>
<li class="L9218" rel="L9218"></li>
<li class="L9219" rel="L9219">“Nothing in the wood, and nothing in the straw, Jacques?”</li>
<li class="L9220" rel="L9220"></li>
<li class="L9221" rel="L9221">“Nothing.”</li>
<li class="L9222" rel="L9222"></li>
<li class="L9223" rel="L9223">“Let us collect them together, in the middle of the cell. So! Light</li>
<li class="L9224" rel="L9224">them, you!”</li>
<li class="L9225" rel="L9225"></li>
<li class="L9226" rel="L9226">The turnkey fired the little pile, which blazed high and hot. Stooping</li>
<li class="L9227" rel="L9227">again to come out at the low-arched door, they left it burning, and</li>
<li class="L9228" rel="L9228">retraced their way to the courtyard; seeming to recover their sense</li>
<li class="L9229" rel="L9229">of hearing as they came down, until they were in the raging flood once</li>
<li class="L9230" rel="L9230">more.</li>
<li class="L9231" rel="L9231"></li>
<li class="L9232" rel="L9232">They found it surging and tossing, in quest of Defarge himself. Saint</li>
<li class="L9233" rel="L9233">Antoine was clamorous to have its wine-shop keeper foremost in the guard</li>
<li class="L9234" rel="L9234">upon the governor who had defended the Bastille and shot the people.</li>
<li class="L9235" rel="L9235">Otherwise, the governor would not be marched to the Hotel de Ville for</li>
<li class="L9236" rel="L9236">judgment. Otherwise, the governor would escape, and the people&#39;s</li>
<li class="L9237" rel="L9237">blood (suddenly of some value, after many years of worthlessness) be</li>
<li class="L9238" rel="L9238">unavenged.</li>
<li class="L9239" rel="L9239"></li>
<li class="L9240" rel="L9240">In the howling universe of passion and contention that seemed to</li>
<li class="L9241" rel="L9241">encompass this grim old officer conspicuous in his grey coat and red</li>
<li class="L9242" rel="L9242">decoration, there was but one quite steady figure, and that was a</li>
<li class="L9243" rel="L9243">woman&#39;s. “See, there is my husband!” she cried, pointing him out.</li>
<li class="L9244" rel="L9244">“See Defarge!” She stood immovable close to the grim old officer, and</li>
<li class="L9245" rel="L9245">remained immovable close to him; remained immovable close to him through</li>
<li class="L9246" rel="L9246">the streets, as Defarge and the rest bore him along; remained immovable</li>
<li class="L9247" rel="L9247">close to him when he was got near his destination, and began to</li>
<li class="L9248" rel="L9248">be struck at from behind; remained immovable close to him when the</li>
<li class="L9249" rel="L9249">long-gathering rain of stabs and blows fell heavy; was so close to him</li>
<li class="L9250" rel="L9250">when he dropped dead under it, that, suddenly animated, she put her foot</li>
<li class="L9251" rel="L9251">upon his neck, and with her cruel knife--long ready--hewed off his head.</li>
<li class="L9252" rel="L9252"></li>
<li class="L9253" rel="L9253">The hour was come, when Saint Antoine was to execute his horrible idea</li>
<li class="L9254" rel="L9254">of hoisting up men for lamps to show what he could be and do. Saint</li>
<li class="L9255" rel="L9255">Antoine&#39;s blood was up, and the blood of tyranny and domination by the</li>
<li class="L9256" rel="L9256">iron hand was down--down on the steps of the Hotel de Ville where the</li>
<li class="L9257" rel="L9257">governor&#39;s body lay--down on the sole of the shoe of Madame Defarge</li>
<li class="L9258" rel="L9258">where she had trodden on the body to steady it for mutilation. “Lower</li>
<li class="L9259" rel="L9259">the lamp yonder!” cried Saint Antoine, after glaring round for a new</li>
<li class="L9260" rel="L9260">means of death; “here is one of his soldiers to be left on guard!” The</li>
<li class="L9261" rel="L9261">swinging sentinel was posted, and the sea rushed on.</li>
<li class="L9262" rel="L9262"></li>
<li class="L9263" rel="L9263">The sea of black and threatening waters, and of destructive upheaving</li>
<li class="L9264" rel="L9264">of wave against wave, whose depths were yet unfathomed and whose forces</li>
<li class="L9265" rel="L9265">were yet unknown. The remorseless sea of turbulently swaying shapes,</li>
<li class="L9266" rel="L9266">voices of vengeance, and faces hardened in the furnaces of suffering</li>
<li class="L9267" rel="L9267">until the touch of pity could make no mark on them.</li>
<li class="L9268" rel="L9268"></li>
<li class="L9269" rel="L9269">But, in the ocean of faces where every fierce and furious expression was</li>
<li class="L9270" rel="L9270">in vivid life, there were two groups of faces--each seven in number--so</li>
<li class="L9271" rel="L9271">fixedly contrasting with the rest, that never did sea roll which bore</li>
<li class="L9272" rel="L9272">more memorable wrecks with it. Seven faces of prisoners, suddenly</li>
<li class="L9273" rel="L9273">released by the storm that had burst their tomb, were carried high</li>
<li class="L9274" rel="L9274">overhead: all scared, all lost, all wondering and amazed, as if the Last</li>
<li class="L9275" rel="L9275">Day were come, and those who rejoiced around them were lost spirits.</li>
<li class="L9276" rel="L9276">Other seven faces there were, carried higher, seven dead faces, whose</li>
<li class="L9277" rel="L9277">drooping eyelids and half-seen eyes awaited the Last Day. Impassive</li>
<li class="L9278" rel="L9278">faces, yet with a suspended--not an abolished--expression on them;</li>
<li class="L9279" rel="L9279">faces, rather, in a fearful pause, as having yet to raise the dropped</li>
<li class="L9280" rel="L9280">lids of the eyes, and bear witness with the bloodless lips, “THOU DIDST</li>
<li class="L9281" rel="L9281">IT!”</li>
<li class="L9282" rel="L9282"></li>
<li class="L9283" rel="L9283">Seven prisoners released, seven gory heads on pikes, the keys of the</li>
<li class="L9284" rel="L9284">accursed fortress of the eight strong towers, some discovered letters</li>
<li class="L9285" rel="L9285">and other memorials of prisoners of old time, long dead of broken</li>
<li class="L9286" rel="L9286">hearts,--such, and such--like, the loudly echoing footsteps of Saint</li>
<li class="L9287" rel="L9287">Antoine escort through the Paris streets in mid-July, one thousand seven</li>
<li class="L9288" rel="L9288">hundred and eighty-nine. Now, Heaven defeat the fancy of Lucie Darnay,</li>
<li class="L9289" rel="L9289">and keep these feet far out of her life! For, they are headlong, mad,</li>
<li class="L9290" rel="L9290">and dangerous; and in the years so long after the breaking of the cask</li>
<li class="L9291" rel="L9291">at Defarge&#39;s wine-shop door, they are not easily purified when once</li>
<li class="L9292" rel="L9292">stained red.</li>
<li class="L9293" rel="L9293"></li>
<li class="L9294" rel="L9294"></li>
<li class="L9295" rel="L9295"></li>
<li class="L9296" rel="L9296"></li>
<li class="L9297" rel="L9297">XXII. The Sea Still Rises</li>
<li class="L9298" rel="L9298"></li>
<li class="L9299" rel="L9299"></li>
<li class="L9300" rel="L9300">Haggard Saint Antoine had had only one exultant week, in which to soften</li>
<li class="L9301" rel="L9301">his modicum of hard and bitter bread to such extent as he could, with</li>
<li class="L9302" rel="L9302">the relish of fraternal embraces and congratulations, when Madame</li>
<li class="L9303" rel="L9303">Defarge sat at her counter, as usual, presiding over the customers.</li>
<li class="L9304" rel="L9304">Madame Defarge wore no rose in her head, for the great brotherhood of</li>
<li class="L9305" rel="L9305">Spies had become, even in one short week, extremely chary of trusting</li>
<li class="L9306" rel="L9306">themselves to the saint&#39;s mercies. The lamps across his streets had a</li>
<li class="L9307" rel="L9307">portentously elastic swing with them.</li>
<li class="L9308" rel="L9308"></li>
<li class="L9309" rel="L9309">Madame Defarge, with her arms folded, sat in the morning light and heat,</li>
<li class="L9310" rel="L9310">contemplating the wine-shop and the street. In both, there were several</li>
<li class="L9311" rel="L9311">knots of loungers, squalid and miserable, but now with a manifest sense</li>
<li class="L9312" rel="L9312">of power enthroned on their distress. The raggedest nightcap, awry on</li>
<li class="L9313" rel="L9313">the wretchedest head, had this crooked significance in it: “I know how</li>
<li class="L9314" rel="L9314">hard it has grown for me, the wearer of this, to support life in myself;</li>
<li class="L9315" rel="L9315">but do you know how easy it has grown for me, the wearer of this, to</li>
<li class="L9316" rel="L9316">destroy life in you?” Every lean bare arm, that had been without work</li>
<li class="L9317" rel="L9317">before, had this work always ready for it now, that it could strike.</li>
<li class="L9318" rel="L9318">The fingers of the knitting women were vicious, with the experience that</li>
<li class="L9319" rel="L9319">they could tear. There was a change in the appearance of Saint Antoine;</li>
<li class="L9320" rel="L9320">the image had been hammering into this for hundreds of years, and the</li>
<li class="L9321" rel="L9321">last finishing blows had told mightily on the expression.</li>
<li class="L9322" rel="L9322"></li>
<li class="L9323" rel="L9323">Madame Defarge sat observing it, with such suppressed approval as was</li>
<li class="L9324" rel="L9324">to be desired in the leader of the Saint Antoine women. One of her</li>
<li class="L9325" rel="L9325">sisterhood knitted beside her. The short, rather plump wife of a starved</li>
<li class="L9326" rel="L9326">grocer, and the mother of two children withal, this lieutenant had</li>
<li class="L9327" rel="L9327">already earned the complimentary name of The Vengeance.</li>
<li class="L9328" rel="L9328"></li>
<li class="L9329" rel="L9329">“Hark!” said The Vengeance. “Listen, then! Who comes?”</li>
<li class="L9330" rel="L9330"></li>
<li class="L9331" rel="L9331">As if a train of powder laid from the outermost bound of Saint Antoine</li>
<li class="L9332" rel="L9332">Quarter to the wine-shop door, had been suddenly fired, a fast-spreading</li>
<li class="L9333" rel="L9333">murmur came rushing along.</li>
<li class="L9334" rel="L9334"></li>
<li class="L9335" rel="L9335">“It is Defarge,” said madame. “Silence, patriots!”</li>
<li class="L9336" rel="L9336"></li>
<li class="L9337" rel="L9337">Defarge came in breathless, pulled off a red cap he wore, and looked</li>
<li class="L9338" rel="L9338">around him! “Listen, everywhere!” said madame again. “Listen to him!”</li>
<li class="L9339" rel="L9339"> Defarge stood, panting, against a background of eager eyes and open</li>
<li class="L9340" rel="L9340">mouths, formed outside the door; all those within the wine-shop had</li>
<li class="L9341" rel="L9341">sprung to their feet.</li>
<li class="L9342" rel="L9342"></li>
<li class="L9343" rel="L9343">“Say then, my husband. What is it?”</li>
<li class="L9344" rel="L9344"></li>
<li class="L9345" rel="L9345">“News from the other world!”</li>
<li class="L9346" rel="L9346"></li>
<li class="L9347" rel="L9347">“How, then?” cried madame, contemptuously. “The other world?”</li>
<li class="L9348" rel="L9348"></li>
<li class="L9349" rel="L9349">“Does everybody here recall old Foulon, who told the famished people</li>
<li class="L9350" rel="L9350">that they might eat grass, and who died, and went to Hell?”</li>
<li class="L9351" rel="L9351"></li>
<li class="L9352" rel="L9352">“Everybody!” from all throats.</li>
<li class="L9353" rel="L9353"></li>
<li class="L9354" rel="L9354">“The news is of him. He is among us!”</li>
<li class="L9355" rel="L9355"></li>
<li class="L9356" rel="L9356">“Among us!” from the universal throat again. “And dead?”</li>
<li class="L9357" rel="L9357"></li>
<li class="L9358" rel="L9358">“Not dead! He feared us so much--and with reason--that he caused himself</li>
<li class="L9359" rel="L9359">to be represented as dead, and had a grand mock-funeral. But they have</li>
<li class="L9360" rel="L9360">found him alive, hiding in the country, and have brought him in. I have</li>
<li class="L9361" rel="L9361">seen him but now, on his way to the Hotel de Ville, a prisoner. I have</li>
<li class="L9362" rel="L9362">said that he had reason to fear us. Say all! _Had_ he reason?”</li>
<li class="L9363" rel="L9363"></li>
<li class="L9364" rel="L9364">Wretched old sinner of more than threescore years and ten, if he had</li>
<li class="L9365" rel="L9365">never known it yet, he would have known it in his heart of hearts if he</li>
<li class="L9366" rel="L9366">could have heard the answering cry.</li>
<li class="L9367" rel="L9367"></li>
<li class="L9368" rel="L9368">A moment of profound silence followed. Defarge and his wife looked</li>
<li class="L9369" rel="L9369">steadfastly at one another. The Vengeance stooped, and the jar of a drum</li>
<li class="L9370" rel="L9370">was heard as she moved it at her feet behind the counter.</li>
<li class="L9371" rel="L9371"></li>
<li class="L9372" rel="L9372">“Patriots!” said Defarge, in a determined voice, “are we ready?”</li>
<li class="L9373" rel="L9373"></li>
<li class="L9374" rel="L9374">Instantly Madame Defarge&#39;s knife was in her girdle; the drum was beating</li>
<li class="L9375" rel="L9375">in the streets, as if it and a drummer had flown together by magic; and</li>
<li class="L9376" rel="L9376">The Vengeance, uttering terrific shrieks, and flinging her arms about</li>
<li class="L9377" rel="L9377">her head like all the forty Furies at once, was tearing from house to</li>
<li class="L9378" rel="L9378">house, rousing the women.</li>
<li class="L9379" rel="L9379"></li>
<li class="L9380" rel="L9380">The men were terrible, in the bloody-minded anger with which they looked</li>
<li class="L9381" rel="L9381">from windows, caught up what arms they had, and came pouring down into</li>
<li class="L9382" rel="L9382">the streets; but, the women were a sight to chill the boldest. From</li>
<li class="L9383" rel="L9383">such household occupations as their bare poverty yielded, from their</li>
<li class="L9384" rel="L9384">children, from their aged and their sick crouching on the bare ground</li>
<li class="L9385" rel="L9385">famished and naked, they ran out with streaming hair, urging one</li>
<li class="L9386" rel="L9386">another, and themselves, to madness with the wildest cries and actions.</li>
<li class="L9387" rel="L9387">Villain Foulon taken, my sister! Old Foulon taken, my mother! Miscreant</li>
<li class="L9388" rel="L9388">Foulon taken, my daughter! Then, a score of others ran into the midst of</li>
<li class="L9389" rel="L9389">these, beating their breasts, tearing their hair, and screaming, Foulon</li>
<li class="L9390" rel="L9390">alive! Foulon who told the starving people they might eat grass! Foulon</li>
<li class="L9391" rel="L9391">who told my old father that he might eat grass, when I had no bread</li>
<li class="L9392" rel="L9392">to give him! Foulon who told my baby it might suck grass, when these</li>
<li class="L9393" rel="L9393">breasts were dry with want! O mother of God, this Foulon! O Heaven our</li>
<li class="L9394" rel="L9394">suffering! Hear me, my dead baby and my withered father: I swear on my</li>
<li class="L9395" rel="L9395">knees, on these stones, to avenge you on Foulon! Husbands, and brothers,</li>
<li class="L9396" rel="L9396">and young men, Give us the blood of Foulon, Give us the head of Foulon,</li>
<li class="L9397" rel="L9397">Give us the heart of Foulon, Give us the body and soul of Foulon, Rend</li>
<li class="L9398" rel="L9398">Foulon to pieces, and dig him into the ground, that grass may grow from</li>
<li class="L9399" rel="L9399">him! With these cries, numbers of the women, lashed into blind frenzy,</li>
<li class="L9400" rel="L9400">whirled about, striking and tearing at their own friends until they</li>
<li class="L9401" rel="L9401">dropped into a passionate swoon, and were only saved by the men</li>
<li class="L9402" rel="L9402">belonging to them from being trampled under foot.</li>
<li class="L9403" rel="L9403"></li>
<li class="L9404" rel="L9404">Nevertheless, not a moment was lost; not a moment! This Foulon was at</li>
<li class="L9405" rel="L9405">the Hotel de Ville, and might be loosed. Never, if Saint Antoine knew</li>
<li class="L9406" rel="L9406">his own sufferings, insults, and wrongs! Armed men and women flocked out</li>
<li class="L9407" rel="L9407">of the Quarter so fast, and drew even these last dregs after them with</li>
<li class="L9408" rel="L9408">such a force of suction, that within a quarter of an hour there was not</li>
<li class="L9409" rel="L9409">a human creature in Saint Antoine&#39;s bosom but a few old crones and the</li>
<li class="L9410" rel="L9410">wailing children.</li>
<li class="L9411" rel="L9411"></li>
<li class="L9412" rel="L9412">No. They were all by that time choking the Hall of Examination where</li>
<li class="L9413" rel="L9413">this old man, ugly and wicked, was, and overflowing into the adjacent</li>
<li class="L9414" rel="L9414">open space and streets. The Defarges, husband and wife, The Vengeance,</li>
<li class="L9415" rel="L9415">and Jacques Three, were in the first press, and at no great distance</li>
<li class="L9416" rel="L9416">from him in the Hall.</li>
<li class="L9417" rel="L9417"></li>
<li class="L9418" rel="L9418">“See!” cried madame, pointing with her knife. “See the old villain bound</li>
<li class="L9419" rel="L9419">with ropes. That was well done to tie a bunch of grass upon his back.</li>
<li class="L9420" rel="L9420">Ha, ha! That was well done. Let him eat it now!” Madame put her knife</li>
<li class="L9421" rel="L9421">under her arm, and clapped her hands as at a play.</li>
<li class="L9422" rel="L9422"></li>
<li class="L9423" rel="L9423">The people immediately behind Madame Defarge, explaining the cause of</li>
<li class="L9424" rel="L9424">her satisfaction to those behind them, and those again explaining to</li>
<li class="L9425" rel="L9425">others, and those to others, the neighbouring streets resounded with the</li>
<li class="L9426" rel="L9426">clapping of hands. Similarly, during two or three hours of drawl,</li>
<li class="L9427" rel="L9427">and the winnowing of many bushels of words, Madame Defarge&#39;s frequent</li>
<li class="L9428" rel="L9428">expressions of impatience were taken up, with marvellous quickness, at</li>
<li class="L9429" rel="L9429">a distance: the more readily, because certain men who had by some</li>
<li class="L9430" rel="L9430">wonderful exercise of agility climbed up the external architecture</li>
<li class="L9431" rel="L9431">to look in from the windows, knew Madame Defarge well, and acted as a</li>
<li class="L9432" rel="L9432">telegraph between her and the crowd outside the building.</li>
<li class="L9433" rel="L9433"></li>
<li class="L9434" rel="L9434">At length the sun rose so high that it struck a kindly ray as of hope or</li>
<li class="L9435" rel="L9435">protection, directly down upon the old prisoner&#39;s head. The favour was</li>
<li class="L9436" rel="L9436">too much to bear; in an instant the barrier of dust and chaff that had</li>
<li class="L9437" rel="L9437">stood surprisingly long, went to the winds, and Saint Antoine had got</li>
<li class="L9438" rel="L9438">him!</li>
<li class="L9439" rel="L9439"></li>
<li class="L9440" rel="L9440">It was known directly, to the furthest confines of the crowd. Defarge</li>
<li class="L9441" rel="L9441">had but sprung over a railing and a table, and folded the miserable</li>
<li class="L9442" rel="L9442">wretch in a deadly embrace--Madame Defarge had but followed and turned</li>
<li class="L9443" rel="L9443">her hand in one of the ropes with which he was tied--The Vengeance and</li>
<li class="L9444" rel="L9444">Jacques Three were not yet up with them, and the men at the windows</li>
<li class="L9445" rel="L9445">had not yet swooped into the Hall, like birds of prey from their high</li>
<li class="L9446" rel="L9446">perches--when the cry seemed to go up, all over the city, “Bring him</li>
<li class="L9447" rel="L9447">out! Bring him to the lamp!”</li>
<li class="L9448" rel="L9448"></li>
<li class="L9449" rel="L9449">Down, and up, and head foremost on the steps of the building; now, on</li>
<li class="L9450" rel="L9450">his knees; now, on his feet; now, on his back; dragged, and struck at,</li>
<li class="L9451" rel="L9451">and stifled by the bunches of grass and straw that were thrust into his</li>
<li class="L9452" rel="L9452">face by hundreds of hands; torn, bruised, panting, bleeding, yet always</li>
<li class="L9453" rel="L9453">entreating and beseeching for mercy; now full of vehement agony of</li>
<li class="L9454" rel="L9454">action, with a small clear space about him as the people drew one</li>
<li class="L9455" rel="L9455">another back that they might see; now, a log of dead wood drawn through</li>
<li class="L9456" rel="L9456">a forest of legs; he was hauled to the nearest street corner where one</li>
<li class="L9457" rel="L9457">of the fatal lamps swung, and there Madame Defarge let him go--as a cat</li>
<li class="L9458" rel="L9458">might have done to a mouse--and silently and composedly looked at him</li>
<li class="L9459" rel="L9459">while they made ready, and while he besought her: the women passionately</li>
<li class="L9460" rel="L9460">screeching at him all the time, and the men sternly calling out to have</li>
<li class="L9461" rel="L9461">him killed with grass in his mouth. Once, he went aloft, and the rope</li>
<li class="L9462" rel="L9462">broke, and they caught him shrieking; twice, he went aloft, and the rope</li>
<li class="L9463" rel="L9463">broke, and they caught him shrieking; then, the rope was merciful, and</li>
<li class="L9464" rel="L9464">held him, and his head was soon upon a pike, with grass enough in the</li>
<li class="L9465" rel="L9465">mouth for all Saint Antoine to dance at the sight of.</li>
<li class="L9466" rel="L9466"></li>
<li class="L9467" rel="L9467">Nor was this the end of the day&#39;s bad work, for Saint Antoine so shouted</li>
<li class="L9468" rel="L9468">and danced his angry blood up, that it boiled again, on hearing when</li>
<li class="L9469" rel="L9469">the day closed in that the son-in-law of the despatched, another of the</li>
<li class="L9470" rel="L9470">people&#39;s enemies and insulters, was coming into Paris under a guard</li>
<li class="L9471" rel="L9471">five hundred strong, in cavalry alone. Saint Antoine wrote his crimes</li>
<li class="L9472" rel="L9472">on flaring sheets of paper, seized him--would have torn him out of the</li>
<li class="L9473" rel="L9473">breast of an army to bear Foulon company--set his head and heart on</li>
<li class="L9474" rel="L9474">pikes, and carried the three spoils of the day, in Wolf-procession</li>
<li class="L9475" rel="L9475">through the streets.</li>
<li class="L9476" rel="L9476"></li>
<li class="L9477" rel="L9477">Not before dark night did the men and women come back to the children,</li>
<li class="L9478" rel="L9478">wailing and breadless. Then, the miserable bakers&#39; shops were beset by</li>
<li class="L9479" rel="L9479">long files of them, patiently waiting to buy bad bread; and while</li>
<li class="L9480" rel="L9480">they waited with stomachs faint and empty, they beguiled the time by</li>
<li class="L9481" rel="L9481">embracing one another on the triumphs of the day, and achieving them</li>
<li class="L9482" rel="L9482">again in gossip. Gradually, these strings of ragged people shortened and</li>
<li class="L9483" rel="L9483">frayed away; and then poor lights began to shine in high windows, and</li>
<li class="L9484" rel="L9484">slender fires were made in the streets, at which neighbours cooked in</li>
<li class="L9485" rel="L9485">common, afterwards supping at their doors.</li>
<li class="L9486" rel="L9486"></li>
<li class="L9487" rel="L9487">Scanty and insufficient suppers those, and innocent of meat, as of</li>
<li class="L9488" rel="L9488">most other sauce to wretched bread. Yet, human fellowship infused</li>
<li class="L9489" rel="L9489">some nourishment into the flinty viands, and struck some sparks of</li>
<li class="L9490" rel="L9490">cheerfulness out of them. Fathers and mothers who had had their full</li>
<li class="L9491" rel="L9491">share in the worst of the day, played gently with their meagre children;</li>
<li class="L9492" rel="L9492">and lovers, with such a world around them and before them, loved and</li>
<li class="L9493" rel="L9493">hoped.</li>
<li class="L9494" rel="L9494"></li>
<li class="L9495" rel="L9495">It was almost morning, when Defarge&#39;s wine-shop parted with its last</li>
<li class="L9496" rel="L9496">knot of customers, and Monsieur Defarge said to madame his wife, in</li>
<li class="L9497" rel="L9497">husky tones, while fastening the door:</li>
<li class="L9498" rel="L9498"></li>
<li class="L9499" rel="L9499">“At last it is come, my dear!”</li>
<li class="L9500" rel="L9500"></li>
<li class="L9501" rel="L9501">“Eh well!” returned madame. “Almost.”</li>
<li class="L9502" rel="L9502"></li>
<li class="L9503" rel="L9503">Saint Antoine slept, the Defarges slept: even The Vengeance slept with</li>
<li class="L9504" rel="L9504">her starved grocer, and the drum was at rest. The drum&#39;s was the</li>
<li class="L9505" rel="L9505">only voice in Saint Antoine that blood and hurry had not changed. The</li>
<li class="L9506" rel="L9506">Vengeance, as custodian of the drum, could have wakened him up and had</li>
<li class="L9507" rel="L9507">the same speech out of him as before the Bastille fell, or old Foulon</li>
<li class="L9508" rel="L9508">was seized; not so with the hoarse tones of the men and women in Saint</li>
<li class="L9509" rel="L9509">Antoine&#39;s bosom.</li>
<li class="L9510" rel="L9510"></li>
<li class="L9511" rel="L9511"></li>
<li class="L9512" rel="L9512"></li>
<li class="L9513" rel="L9513"></li>
<li class="L9514" rel="L9514">XXIII. Fire Rises</li>
<li class="L9515" rel="L9515"></li>
<li class="L9516" rel="L9516"></li>
<li class="L9517" rel="L9517">There was a change on the village where the fountain fell, and where</li>
<li class="L9518" rel="L9518">the mender of roads went forth daily to hammer out of the stones on the</li>
<li class="L9519" rel="L9519">highway such morsels of bread as might serve for patches to hold his</li>
<li class="L9520" rel="L9520">poor ignorant soul and his poor reduced body together. The prison on the</li>
<li class="L9521" rel="L9521">crag was not so dominant as of yore; there were soldiers to guard it,</li>
<li class="L9522" rel="L9522">but not many; there were officers to guard the soldiers, but not one of</li>
<li class="L9523" rel="L9523">them knew what his men would do--beyond this: that it would probably not</li>
<li class="L9524" rel="L9524">be what he was ordered.</li>
<li class="L9525" rel="L9525"></li>
<li class="L9526" rel="L9526">Far and wide lay a ruined country, yielding nothing but desolation.</li>
<li class="L9527" rel="L9527">Every green leaf, every blade of grass and blade of grain, was as</li>
<li class="L9528" rel="L9528">shrivelled and poor as the miserable people. Everything was bowed down,</li>
<li class="L9529" rel="L9529">dejected, oppressed, and broken. Habitations, fences, domesticated</li>
<li class="L9530" rel="L9530">animals, men, women, children, and the soil that bore them--all worn</li>
<li class="L9531" rel="L9531">out.</li>
<li class="L9532" rel="L9532"></li>
<li class="L9533" rel="L9533">Monseigneur (often a most worthy individual gentleman) was a national</li>
<li class="L9534" rel="L9534">blessing, gave a chivalrous tone to things, was a polite example of</li>
<li class="L9535" rel="L9535">luxurious and shining life, and a great deal more to equal purpose;</li>
<li class="L9536" rel="L9536">nevertheless, Monseigneur as a class had, somehow or other, brought</li>
<li class="L9537" rel="L9537">things to this. Strange that Creation, designed expressly for</li>
<li class="L9538" rel="L9538">Monseigneur, should be so soon wrung dry and squeezed out! There must</li>
<li class="L9539" rel="L9539">be something short-sighted in the eternal arrangements, surely! Thus it</li>
<li class="L9540" rel="L9540">was, however; and the last drop of blood having been extracted from the</li>
<li class="L9541" rel="L9541">flints, and the last screw of the rack having been turned so often that</li>
<li class="L9542" rel="L9542">its purchase crumbled, and it now turned and turned with nothing</li>
<li class="L9543" rel="L9543">to bite, Monseigneur began to run away from a phenomenon so low and</li>
<li class="L9544" rel="L9544">unaccountable.</li>
<li class="L9545" rel="L9545"></li>
<li class="L9546" rel="L9546">But, this was not the change on the village, and on many a village like</li>
<li class="L9547" rel="L9547">it. For scores of years gone by, Monseigneur had squeezed it and wrung</li>
<li class="L9548" rel="L9548">it, and had seldom graced it with his presence except for the pleasures</li>
<li class="L9549" rel="L9549">of the chase--now, found in hunting the people; now, found in hunting</li>
<li class="L9550" rel="L9550">the beasts, for whose preservation Monseigneur made edifying spaces</li>
<li class="L9551" rel="L9551">of barbarous and barren wilderness. No. The change consisted in</li>
<li class="L9552" rel="L9552">the appearance of strange faces of low caste, rather than in the</li>
<li class="L9553" rel="L9553">disappearance of the high caste, chiselled, and otherwise beautified and</li>
<li class="L9554" rel="L9554">beautifying features of Monseigneur.</li>
<li class="L9555" rel="L9555"></li>
<li class="L9556" rel="L9556">For, in these times, as the mender of roads worked, solitary, in the</li>
<li class="L9557" rel="L9557">dust, not often troubling himself to reflect that dust he was and</li>
<li class="L9558" rel="L9558">to dust he must return, being for the most part too much occupied in</li>
<li class="L9559" rel="L9559">thinking how little he had for supper and how much more he would eat if</li>
<li class="L9560" rel="L9560">he had it--in these times, as he raised his eyes from his lonely labour,</li>
<li class="L9561" rel="L9561">and viewed the prospect, he would see some rough figure approaching on</li>
<li class="L9562" rel="L9562">foot, the like of which was once a rarity in those parts, but was now</li>
<li class="L9563" rel="L9563">a frequent presence. As it advanced, the mender of roads would discern</li>
<li class="L9564" rel="L9564">without surprise, that it was a shaggy-haired man, of almost barbarian</li>
<li class="L9565" rel="L9565">aspect, tall, in wooden shoes that were clumsy even to the eyes of a</li>
<li class="L9566" rel="L9566">mender of roads, grim, rough, swart, steeped in the mud and dust of many</li>
<li class="L9567" rel="L9567">highways, dank with the marshy moisture of many low grounds, sprinkled</li>
<li class="L9568" rel="L9568">with the thorns and leaves and moss of many byways through woods.</li>
<li class="L9569" rel="L9569"></li>
<li class="L9570" rel="L9570">Such a man came upon him, like a ghost, at noon in the July weather,</li>
<li class="L9571" rel="L9571">as he sat on his heap of stones under a bank, taking such shelter as he</li>
<li class="L9572" rel="L9572">could get from a shower of hail.</li>
<li class="L9573" rel="L9573"></li>
<li class="L9574" rel="L9574">The man looked at him, looked at the village in the hollow, at the mill,</li>
<li class="L9575" rel="L9575">and at the prison on the crag. When he had identified these objects</li>
<li class="L9576" rel="L9576">in what benighted mind he had, he said, in a dialect that was just</li>
<li class="L9577" rel="L9577">intelligible:</li>
<li class="L9578" rel="L9578"></li>
<li class="L9579" rel="L9579">“How goes it, Jacques?”</li>
<li class="L9580" rel="L9580"></li>
<li class="L9581" rel="L9581">“All well, Jacques.”</li>
<li class="L9582" rel="L9582"></li>
<li class="L9583" rel="L9583">“Touch then!”</li>
<li class="L9584" rel="L9584"></li>
<li class="L9585" rel="L9585">They joined hands, and the man sat down on the heap of stones.</li>
<li class="L9586" rel="L9586"></li>
<li class="L9587" rel="L9587">“No dinner?”</li>
<li class="L9588" rel="L9588"></li>
<li class="L9589" rel="L9589">“Nothing but supper now,” said the mender of roads, with a hungry face.</li>
<li class="L9590" rel="L9590"></li>
<li class="L9591" rel="L9591">“It is the fashion,” growled the man. “I meet no dinner anywhere.”</li>
<li class="L9592" rel="L9592"></li>
<li class="L9593" rel="L9593">He took out a blackened pipe, filled it, lighted it with flint and</li>
<li class="L9594" rel="L9594">steel, pulled at it until it was in a bright glow: then, suddenly held</li>
<li class="L9595" rel="L9595">it from him and dropped something into it from between his finger and</li>
<li class="L9596" rel="L9596">thumb, that blazed and went out in a puff of smoke.</li>
<li class="L9597" rel="L9597"></li>
<li class="L9598" rel="L9598">“Touch then.” It was the turn of the mender of roads to say it this</li>
<li class="L9599" rel="L9599">time, after observing these operations. They again joined hands.</li>
<li class="L9600" rel="L9600"></li>
<li class="L9601" rel="L9601">“To-night?” said the mender of roads.</li>
<li class="L9602" rel="L9602"></li>
<li class="L9603" rel="L9603">“To-night,” said the man, putting the pipe in his mouth.</li>
<li class="L9604" rel="L9604"></li>
<li class="L9605" rel="L9605">“Where?”</li>
<li class="L9606" rel="L9606"></li>
<li class="L9607" rel="L9607">“Here.”</li>
<li class="L9608" rel="L9608"></li>
<li class="L9609" rel="L9609">He and the mender of roads sat on the heap of stones looking silently at</li>
<li class="L9610" rel="L9610">one another, with the hail driving in between them like a pigmy charge</li>
<li class="L9611" rel="L9611">of bayonets, until the sky began to clear over the village.</li>
<li class="L9612" rel="L9612"></li>
<li class="L9613" rel="L9613">“Show me!” said the traveller then, moving to the brow of the hill.</li>
<li class="L9614" rel="L9614"></li>
<li class="L9615" rel="L9615">“See!” returned the mender of roads, with extended finger. “You go down</li>
<li class="L9616" rel="L9616">here, and straight through the street, and past the fountain--”</li>
<li class="L9617" rel="L9617"></li>
<li class="L9618" rel="L9618">“To the Devil with all that!” interrupted the other, rolling his eye</li>
<li class="L9619" rel="L9619">over the landscape. “_I_ go through no streets and past no fountains.</li>
<li class="L9620" rel="L9620">Well?”</li>
<li class="L9621" rel="L9621"></li>
<li class="L9622" rel="L9622">“Well! About two leagues beyond the summit of that hill above the</li>
<li class="L9623" rel="L9623">village.”</li>
<li class="L9624" rel="L9624"></li>
<li class="L9625" rel="L9625">“Good. When do you cease to work?”</li>
<li class="L9626" rel="L9626"></li>
<li class="L9627" rel="L9627">“At sunset.”</li>
<li class="L9628" rel="L9628"></li>
<li class="L9629" rel="L9629">“Will you wake me, before departing? I have walked two nights without</li>
<li class="L9630" rel="L9630">resting. Let me finish my pipe, and I shall sleep like a child. Will you</li>
<li class="L9631" rel="L9631">wake me?”</li>
<li class="L9632" rel="L9632"></li>
<li class="L9633" rel="L9633">“Surely.”</li>
<li class="L9634" rel="L9634"></li>
<li class="L9635" rel="L9635">The wayfarer smoked his pipe out, put it in his breast, slipped off his</li>
<li class="L9636" rel="L9636">great wooden shoes, and lay down on his back on the heap of stones. He</li>
<li class="L9637" rel="L9637">was fast asleep directly.</li>
<li class="L9638" rel="L9638"></li>
<li class="L9639" rel="L9639">As the road-mender plied his dusty labour, and the hail-clouds, rolling</li>
<li class="L9640" rel="L9640">away, revealed bright bars and streaks of sky which were responded to</li>
<li class="L9641" rel="L9641">by silver gleams upon the landscape, the little man (who wore a red cap</li>
<li class="L9642" rel="L9642">now, in place of his blue one) seemed fascinated by the figure on the</li>
<li class="L9643" rel="L9643">heap of stones. His eyes were so often turned towards it, that he used</li>
<li class="L9644" rel="L9644">his tools mechanically, and, one would have said, to very poor account.</li>
<li class="L9645" rel="L9645">The bronze face, the shaggy black hair and beard, the coarse woollen</li>
<li class="L9646" rel="L9646">red cap, the rough medley dress of home-spun stuff and hairy skins of</li>
<li class="L9647" rel="L9647">beasts, the powerful frame attenuated by spare living, and the sullen</li>
<li class="L9648" rel="L9648">and desperate compression of the lips in sleep, inspired the mender</li>
<li class="L9649" rel="L9649">of roads with awe. The traveller had travelled far, and his feet were</li>
<li class="L9650" rel="L9650">footsore, and his ankles chafed and bleeding; his great shoes, stuffed</li>
<li class="L9651" rel="L9651">with leaves and grass, had been heavy to drag over the many long</li>
<li class="L9652" rel="L9652">leagues, and his clothes were chafed into holes, as he himself was into</li>
<li class="L9653" rel="L9653">sores. Stooping down beside him, the road-mender tried to get a peep at</li>
<li class="L9654" rel="L9654">secret weapons in his breast or where not; but, in vain, for he slept</li>
<li class="L9655" rel="L9655">with his arms crossed upon him, and set as resolutely as his lips.</li>
<li class="L9656" rel="L9656">Fortified towns with their stockades, guard-houses, gates, trenches, and</li>
<li class="L9657" rel="L9657">drawbridges, seemed to the mender of roads, to be so much air as against</li>
<li class="L9658" rel="L9658">this figure. And when he lifted his eyes from it to the horizon and</li>
<li class="L9659" rel="L9659">looked around, he saw in his small fancy similar figures, stopped by no</li>
<li class="L9660" rel="L9660">obstacle, tending to centres all over France.</li>
<li class="L9661" rel="L9661"></li>
<li class="L9662" rel="L9662">The man slept on, indifferent to showers of hail and intervals of</li>
<li class="L9663" rel="L9663">brightness, to sunshine on his face and shadow, to the paltering lumps</li>
<li class="L9664" rel="L9664">of dull ice on his body and the diamonds into which the sun changed</li>
<li class="L9665" rel="L9665">them, until the sun was low in the west, and the sky was glowing. Then,</li>
<li class="L9666" rel="L9666">the mender of roads having got his tools together and all things ready</li>
<li class="L9667" rel="L9667">to go down into the village, roused him.</li>
<li class="L9668" rel="L9668"></li>
<li class="L9669" rel="L9669">“Good!” said the sleeper, rising on his elbow. “Two leagues beyond the</li>
<li class="L9670" rel="L9670">summit of the hill?”</li>
<li class="L9671" rel="L9671"></li>
<li class="L9672" rel="L9672">“About.”</li>
<li class="L9673" rel="L9673"></li>
<li class="L9674" rel="L9674">“About. Good!”</li>
<li class="L9675" rel="L9675"></li>
<li class="L9676" rel="L9676">The mender of roads went home, with the dust going on before him</li>
<li class="L9677" rel="L9677">according to the set of the wind, and was soon at the fountain,</li>
<li class="L9678" rel="L9678">squeezing himself in among the lean kine brought there to drink, and</li>
<li class="L9679" rel="L9679">appearing even to whisper to them in his whispering to all the village.</li>
<li class="L9680" rel="L9680">When the village had taken its poor supper, it did not creep to bed,</li>
<li class="L9681" rel="L9681">as it usually did, but came out of doors again, and remained there. A</li>
<li class="L9682" rel="L9682">curious contagion of whispering was upon it, and also, when it gathered</li>
<li class="L9683" rel="L9683">together at the fountain in the dark, another curious contagion of</li>
<li class="L9684" rel="L9684">looking expectantly at the sky in one direction only. Monsieur Gabelle,</li>
<li class="L9685" rel="L9685">chief functionary of the place, became uneasy; went out on his house-top</li>
<li class="L9686" rel="L9686">alone, and looked in that direction too; glanced down from behind his</li>
<li class="L9687" rel="L9687">chimneys at the darkening faces by the fountain below, and sent word to</li>
<li class="L9688" rel="L9688">the sacristan who kept the keys of the church, that there might be need</li>
<li class="L9689" rel="L9689">to ring the tocsin by-and-bye.</li>
<li class="L9690" rel="L9690"></li>
<li class="L9691" rel="L9691">The night deepened. The trees environing the old chateau, keeping its</li>
<li class="L9692" rel="L9692">solitary state apart, moved in a rising wind, as though they threatened</li>
<li class="L9693" rel="L9693">the pile of building massive and dark in the gloom. Up the two terrace</li>
