<li class="L9694" rel="L9694">flights of steps the rain ran wildly, and beat at the great door, like a</li>
<li class="L9695" rel="L9695">swift messenger rousing those within; uneasy rushes of wind went through</li>
<li class="L9696" rel="L9696">the hall, among the old spears and knives, and passed lamenting up the</li>
<li class="L9697" rel="L9697">stairs, and shook the curtains of the bed where the last Marquis</li>
<li class="L9698" rel="L9698">had slept. East, West, North, and South, through the woods, four</li>
<li class="L9699" rel="L9699">heavy-treading, unkempt figures crushed the high grass and cracked the</li>
<li class="L9700" rel="L9700">branches, striding on cautiously to come together in the courtyard. Four</li>
<li class="L9701" rel="L9701">lights broke out there, and moved away in different directions, and all</li>
<li class="L9702" rel="L9702">was black again.</li>
<li class="L9703" rel="L9703"></li>
<li class="L9704" rel="L9704">But, not for long. Presently, the chateau began to make itself strangely</li>
<li class="L9705" rel="L9705">visible by some light of its own, as though it were growing luminous.</li>
<li class="L9706" rel="L9706">Then, a flickering streak played behind the architecture of the front,</li>
<li class="L9707" rel="L9707">picking out transparent places, and showing where balustrades, arches,</li>
<li class="L9708" rel="L9708">and windows were. Then it soared higher, and grew broader and brighter.</li>
<li class="L9709" rel="L9709">Soon, from a score of the great windows, flames burst forth, and the</li>
<li class="L9710" rel="L9710">stone faces awakened, stared out of fire.</li>
<li class="L9711" rel="L9711"></li>
<li class="L9712" rel="L9712">A faint murmur arose about the house from the few people who were left</li>
<li class="L9713" rel="L9713">there, and there was a saddling of a horse and riding away. There was</li>
<li class="L9714" rel="L9714">spurring and splashing through the darkness, and bridle was drawn in the</li>
<li class="L9715" rel="L9715">space by the village fountain, and the horse in a foam stood at Monsieur</li>
<li class="L9716" rel="L9716">Gabelle&#39;s door. “Help, Gabelle! Help, every one!” The tocsin rang</li>
<li class="L9717" rel="L9717">impatiently, but other help (if that were any) there was none. The</li>
<li class="L9718" rel="L9718">mender of roads, and two hundred and fifty particular friends, stood</li>
<li class="L9719" rel="L9719">with folded arms at the fountain, looking at the pillar of fire in the</li>
<li class="L9720" rel="L9720">sky. “It must be forty feet high,” said they, grimly; and never moved.</li>
<li class="L9721" rel="L9721"></li>
<li class="L9722" rel="L9722">The rider from the chateau, and the horse in a foam, clattered away</li>
<li class="L9723" rel="L9723">through the village, and galloped up the stony steep, to the prison on</li>
<li class="L9724" rel="L9724">the crag. At the gate, a group of officers were looking at the fire;</li>
<li class="L9725" rel="L9725">removed from them, a group of soldiers. “Help, gentlemen--officers! The</li>
<li class="L9726" rel="L9726">chateau is on fire; valuable objects may be saved from the flames by</li>
<li class="L9727" rel="L9727">timely aid! Help, help!” The officers looked towards the soldiers who</li>
<li class="L9728" rel="L9728">looked at the fire; gave no orders; and answered, with shrugs and biting</li>
<li class="L9729" rel="L9729">of lips, “It must burn.”</li>
<li class="L9730" rel="L9730"></li>
<li class="L9731" rel="L9731">As the rider rattled down the hill again and through the street, the</li>
<li class="L9732" rel="L9732">village was illuminating. The mender of roads, and the two hundred and</li>
<li class="L9733" rel="L9733">fifty particular friends, inspired as one man and woman by the idea of</li>
<li class="L9734" rel="L9734">lighting up, had darted into their houses, and were putting candles in</li>
<li class="L9735" rel="L9735">every dull little pane of glass. The general scarcity of everything,</li>
<li class="L9736" rel="L9736">occasioned candles to be borrowed in a rather peremptory manner of</li>
<li class="L9737" rel="L9737">Monsieur Gabelle; and in a moment of reluctance and hesitation on</li>
<li class="L9738" rel="L9738">that functionary&#39;s part, the mender of roads, once so submissive to</li>
<li class="L9739" rel="L9739">authority, had remarked that carriages were good to make bonfires with,</li>
<li class="L9740" rel="L9740">and that post-horses would roast.</li>
<li class="L9741" rel="L9741"></li>
<li class="L9742" rel="L9742">The chateau was left to itself to flame and burn. In the roaring and</li>
<li class="L9743" rel="L9743">raging of the conflagration, a red-hot wind, driving straight from the</li>
<li class="L9744" rel="L9744">infernal regions, seemed to be blowing the edifice away. With the rising</li>
<li class="L9745" rel="L9745">and falling of the blaze, the stone faces showed as if they were in</li>
<li class="L9746" rel="L9746">torment. When great masses of stone and timber fell, the face with the</li>
<li class="L9747" rel="L9747">two dints in the nose became obscured: anon struggled out of the smoke</li>
<li class="L9748" rel="L9748">again, as if it were the face of the cruel Marquis, burning at the stake</li>
<li class="L9749" rel="L9749">and contending with the fire.</li>
<li class="L9750" rel="L9750"></li>
<li class="L9751" rel="L9751">The chateau burned; the nearest trees, laid hold of by the fire,</li>
<li class="L9752" rel="L9752">scorched and shrivelled; trees at a distance, fired by the four fierce</li>
<li class="L9753" rel="L9753">figures, begirt the blazing edifice with a new forest of smoke. Molten</li>
<li class="L9754" rel="L9754">lead and iron boiled in the marble basin of the fountain; the water ran</li>
<li class="L9755" rel="L9755">dry; the extinguisher tops of the towers vanished like ice before the</li>
<li class="L9756" rel="L9756">heat, and trickled down into four rugged wells of flame. Great rents and</li>
<li class="L9757" rel="L9757">splits branched out in the solid walls, like crystallisation; stupefied</li>
<li class="L9758" rel="L9758">birds wheeled about and dropped into the furnace; four fierce figures</li>
<li class="L9759" rel="L9759">trudged away, East, West, North, and South, along the night-enshrouded</li>
<li class="L9760" rel="L9760">roads, guided by the beacon they had lighted, towards their next</li>
<li class="L9761" rel="L9761">destination. The illuminated village had seized hold of the tocsin, and,</li>
<li class="L9762" rel="L9762">abolishing the lawful ringer, rang for joy.</li>
<li class="L9763" rel="L9763"></li>
<li class="L9764" rel="L9764">Not only that; but the village, light-headed with famine, fire, and</li>
<li class="L9765" rel="L9765">bell-ringing, and bethinking itself that Monsieur Gabelle had to do with</li>
<li class="L9766" rel="L9766">the collection of rent and taxes--though it was but a small instalment</li>
<li class="L9767" rel="L9767">of taxes, and no rent at all, that Gabelle had got in those latter</li>
<li class="L9768" rel="L9768">days--became impatient for an interview with him, and, surrounding his</li>
<li class="L9769" rel="L9769">house, summoned him to come forth for personal conference. Whereupon,</li>
<li class="L9770" rel="L9770">Monsieur Gabelle did heavily bar his door, and retire to hold counsel</li>
<li class="L9771" rel="L9771">with himself. The result of that conference was, that Gabelle again</li>
<li class="L9772" rel="L9772">withdrew himself to his housetop behind his stack of chimneys; this time</li>
<li class="L9773" rel="L9773">resolved, if his door were broken in (he was a small Southern man</li>
<li class="L9774" rel="L9774">of retaliative temperament), to pitch himself head foremost over the</li>
<li class="L9775" rel="L9775">parapet, and crush a man or two below.</li>
<li class="L9776" rel="L9776"></li>
<li class="L9777" rel="L9777">Probably, Monsieur Gabelle passed a long night up there, with the</li>
<li class="L9778" rel="L9778">distant chateau for fire and candle, and the beating at his door,</li>
<li class="L9779" rel="L9779">combined with the joy-ringing, for music; not to mention his having an</li>
<li class="L9780" rel="L9780">ill-omened lamp slung across the road before his posting-house gate,</li>
<li class="L9781" rel="L9781">which the village showed a lively inclination to displace in his favour.</li>
<li class="L9782" rel="L9782">A trying suspense, to be passing a whole summer night on the brink of</li>
<li class="L9783" rel="L9783">the black ocean, ready to take that plunge into it upon which Monsieur</li>
<li class="L9784" rel="L9784">Gabelle had resolved! But, the friendly dawn appearing at last, and the</li>
<li class="L9785" rel="L9785">rush-candles of the village guttering out, the people happily dispersed,</li>
<li class="L9786" rel="L9786">and Monsieur Gabelle came down bringing his life with him for that</li>
<li class="L9787" rel="L9787">while.</li>
<li class="L9788" rel="L9788"></li>
<li class="L9789" rel="L9789">Within a hundred miles, and in the light of other fires, there were</li>
<li class="L9790" rel="L9790">other functionaries less fortunate, that night and other nights, whom</li>
<li class="L9791" rel="L9791">the rising sun found hanging across once-peaceful streets, where they</li>
<li class="L9792" rel="L9792">had been born and bred; also, there were other villagers and townspeople</li>
<li class="L9793" rel="L9793">less fortunate than the mender of roads and his fellows, upon whom the</li>
<li class="L9794" rel="L9794">functionaries and soldiery turned with success, and whom they strung up</li>
<li class="L9795" rel="L9795">in their turn. But, the fierce figures were steadily wending East, West,</li>
<li class="L9796" rel="L9796">North, and South, be that as it would; and whosoever hung, fire burned.</li>
<li class="L9797" rel="L9797">The altitude of the gallows that would turn to water and quench it,</li>
<li class="L9798" rel="L9798">no functionary, by any stretch of mathematics, was able to calculate</li>
<li class="L9799" rel="L9799">successfully.</li>
<li class="L9800" rel="L9800"></li>
<li class="L9801" rel="L9801"></li>
<li class="L9802" rel="L9802"></li>
<li class="L9803" rel="L9803"></li>
<li class="L9804" rel="L9804">XXIV. Drawn to the Loadstone Rock</li>
<li class="L9805" rel="L9805"></li>
<li class="L9806" rel="L9806"></li>
<li class="L9807" rel="L9807">In such risings of fire and risings of sea--the firm earth shaken by</li>
<li class="L9808" rel="L9808">the rushes of an angry ocean which had now no ebb, but was always on the</li>
<li class="L9809" rel="L9809">flow, higher and higher, to the terror and wonder of the beholders on</li>
<li class="L9810" rel="L9810">the shore--three years of tempest were consumed. Three more birthdays</li>
<li class="L9811" rel="L9811">of little Lucie had been woven by the golden thread into the peaceful</li>
<li class="L9812" rel="L9812">tissue of the life of her home.</li>
<li class="L9813" rel="L9813"></li>
<li class="L9814" rel="L9814">Many a night and many a day had its inmates listened to the echoes in</li>
<li class="L9815" rel="L9815">the corner, with hearts that failed them when they heard the thronging</li>
<li class="L9816" rel="L9816">feet. For, the footsteps had become to their minds as the footsteps of</li>
<li class="L9817" rel="L9817">a people, tumultuous under a red flag and with their country declared in</li>
<li class="L9818" rel="L9818">danger, changed into wild beasts, by terrible enchantment long persisted</li>
<li class="L9819" rel="L9819">in.</li>
<li class="L9820" rel="L9820"></li>
<li class="L9821" rel="L9821">Monseigneur, as a class, had dissociated himself from the phenomenon of</li>
<li class="L9822" rel="L9822">his not being appreciated: of his being so little wanted in France, as</li>
<li class="L9823" rel="L9823">to incur considerable danger of receiving his dismissal from it, and</li>
<li class="L9824" rel="L9824">this life together. Like the fabled rustic who raised the Devil with</li>
<li class="L9825" rel="L9825">infinite pains, and was so terrified at the sight of him that he could</li>
<li class="L9826" rel="L9826">ask the Enemy no question, but immediately fled; so, Monseigneur, after</li>
<li class="L9827" rel="L9827">boldly reading the Lord&#39;s Prayer backwards for a great number of years,</li>
<li class="L9828" rel="L9828">and performing many other potent spells for compelling the Evil One, no</li>
<li class="L9829" rel="L9829">sooner beheld him in his terrors than he took to his noble heels.</li>
<li class="L9830" rel="L9830"></li>
<li class="L9831" rel="L9831">The shining Bull&#39;s Eye of the Court was gone, or it would have been the</li>
<li class="L9832" rel="L9832">mark for a hurricane of national bullets. It had never been a good</li>
<li class="L9833" rel="L9833">eye to see with--had long had the mote in it of Lucifer&#39;s pride,</li>
<li class="L9834" rel="L9834">Sardanapalus&#39;s luxury, and a mole&#39;s blindness--but it had dropped</li>
<li class="L9835" rel="L9835">out and was gone. The Court, from that exclusive inner circle to its</li>
<li class="L9836" rel="L9836">outermost rotten ring of intrigue, corruption, and dissimulation, was</li>
<li class="L9837" rel="L9837">all gone together. Royalty was gone; had been besieged in its Palace and</li>
<li class="L9838" rel="L9838">“suspended,” when the last tidings came over.</li>
<li class="L9839" rel="L9839"></li>
<li class="L9840" rel="L9840">The August of the year one thousand seven hundred and ninety-two was</li>
<li class="L9841" rel="L9841">come, and Monseigneur was by this time scattered far and wide.</li>
<li class="L9842" rel="L9842"></li>
<li class="L9843" rel="L9843">As was natural, the head-quarters and great gathering-place of</li>
<li class="L9844" rel="L9844">Monseigneur, in London, was Tellson&#39;s Bank. Spirits are supposed to</li>
<li class="L9845" rel="L9845">haunt the places where their bodies most resorted, and Monseigneur</li>
<li class="L9846" rel="L9846">without a guinea haunted the spot where his guineas used to be.</li>
<li class="L9847" rel="L9847">Moreover, it was the spot to which such French intelligence as was most</li>
<li class="L9848" rel="L9848">to be relied upon, came quickest. Again: Tellson&#39;s was a munificent</li>
<li class="L9849" rel="L9849">house, and extended great liberality to old customers who had fallen</li>
<li class="L9850" rel="L9850">from their high estate. Again: those nobles who had seen the coming</li>
<li class="L9851" rel="L9851">storm in time, and anticipating plunder or confiscation, had made</li>
<li class="L9852" rel="L9852">provident remittances to Tellson&#39;s, were always to be heard of there</li>
<li class="L9853" rel="L9853">by their needy brethren. To which it must be added that every new-comer</li>
<li class="L9854" rel="L9854">from France reported himself and his tidings at Tellson&#39;s, almost as</li>
<li class="L9855" rel="L9855">a matter of course. For such variety of reasons, Tellson&#39;s was at that</li>
<li class="L9856" rel="L9856">time, as to French intelligence, a kind of High Exchange; and this</li>
<li class="L9857" rel="L9857">was so well known to the public, and the inquiries made there were in</li>
<li class="L9858" rel="L9858">consequence so numerous, that Tellson&#39;s sometimes wrote the latest news</li>
<li class="L9859" rel="L9859">out in a line or so and posted it in the Bank windows, for all who ran</li>
<li class="L9860" rel="L9860">through Temple Bar to read.</li>
<li class="L9861" rel="L9861"></li>
<li class="L9862" rel="L9862">On a steaming, misty afternoon, Mr. Lorry sat at his desk, and Charles</li>
<li class="L9863" rel="L9863">Darnay stood leaning on it, talking with him in a low voice. The</li>
<li class="L9864" rel="L9864">penitential den once set apart for interviews with the House, was now</li>
<li class="L9865" rel="L9865">the news-Exchange, and was filled to overflowing. It was within half an</li>
<li class="L9866" rel="L9866">hour or so of the time of closing.</li>
<li class="L9867" rel="L9867"></li>
<li class="L9868" rel="L9868">“But, although you are the youngest man that ever lived,” said Charles</li>
<li class="L9869" rel="L9869">Darnay, rather hesitating, “I must still suggest to you--”</li>
<li class="L9870" rel="L9870"></li>
<li class="L9871" rel="L9871">“I understand. That I am too old?” said Mr. Lorry.</li>
<li class="L9872" rel="L9872"></li>
<li class="L9873" rel="L9873">“Unsettled weather, a long journey, uncertain means of travelling, a</li>
<li class="L9874" rel="L9874">disorganised country, a city that may not be even safe for you.”</li>
<li class="L9875" rel="L9875"></li>
<li class="L9876" rel="L9876">“My dear Charles,” said Mr. Lorry, with cheerful confidence, “you touch</li>
<li class="L9877" rel="L9877">some of the reasons for my going: not for my staying away. It is safe</li>
<li class="L9878" rel="L9878">enough for me; nobody will care to interfere with an old fellow of hard</li>
<li class="L9879" rel="L9879">upon fourscore when there are so many people there much better worth</li>
<li class="L9880" rel="L9880">interfering with. As to its being a disorganised city, if it were not a</li>
<li class="L9881" rel="L9881">disorganised city there would be no occasion to send somebody from our</li>
<li class="L9882" rel="L9882">House here to our House there, who knows the city and the business, of</li>
<li class="L9883" rel="L9883">old, and is in Tellson&#39;s confidence. As to the uncertain travelling, the</li>
<li class="L9884" rel="L9884">long journey, and the winter weather, if I were not prepared to submit</li>
<li class="L9885" rel="L9885">myself to a few inconveniences for the sake of Tellson&#39;s, after all</li>
<li class="L9886" rel="L9886">these years, who ought to be?”</li>
<li class="L9887" rel="L9887"></li>
<li class="L9888" rel="L9888">“I wish I were going myself,” said Charles Darnay, somewhat restlessly,</li>
<li class="L9889" rel="L9889">and like one thinking aloud.</li>
<li class="L9890" rel="L9890"></li>
<li class="L9891" rel="L9891">“Indeed! You are a pretty fellow to object and advise!” exclaimed Mr.</li>
<li class="L9892" rel="L9892">Lorry. “You wish you were going yourself? And you a Frenchman born? You</li>
<li class="L9893" rel="L9893">are a wise counsellor.”</li>
<li class="L9894" rel="L9894"></li>
<li class="L9895" rel="L9895">“My dear Mr. Lorry, it is because I am a Frenchman born, that the</li>
<li class="L9896" rel="L9896">thought (which I did not mean to utter here, however) has passed through</li>
<li class="L9897" rel="L9897">my mind often. One cannot help thinking, having had some sympathy for</li>
<li class="L9898" rel="L9898">the miserable people, and having abandoned something to them,” he spoke</li>
<li class="L9899" rel="L9899">here in his former thoughtful manner, “that one might be listened to,</li>
<li class="L9900" rel="L9900">and might have the power to persuade to some restraint. Only last night,</li>
<li class="L9901" rel="L9901">after you had left us, when I was talking to Lucie--”</li>
<li class="L9902" rel="L9902"></li>
<li class="L9903" rel="L9903">“When you were talking to Lucie,” Mr. Lorry repeated. “Yes. I wonder you</li>
<li class="L9904" rel="L9904">are not ashamed to mention the name of Lucie! Wishing you were going to</li>
<li class="L9905" rel="L9905">France at this time of day!”</li>
<li class="L9906" rel="L9906"></li>
<li class="L9907" rel="L9907">“However, I am not going,” said Charles Darnay, with a smile. “It is</li>
<li class="L9908" rel="L9908">more to the purpose that you say you are.”</li>
<li class="L9909" rel="L9909"></li>
<li class="L9910" rel="L9910">“And I am, in plain reality. The truth is, my dear Charles,” Mr. Lorry</li>
<li class="L9911" rel="L9911">glanced at the distant House, and lowered his voice, “you can have no</li>
<li class="L9912" rel="L9912">conception of the difficulty with which our business is transacted, and</li>
<li class="L9913" rel="L9913">of the peril in which our books and papers over yonder are involved. The</li>
<li class="L9914" rel="L9914">Lord above knows what the compromising consequences would be to numbers</li>
<li class="L9915" rel="L9915">of people, if some of our documents were seized or destroyed; and they</li>
<li class="L9916" rel="L9916">might be, at any time, you know, for who can say that Paris is not set</li>
<li class="L9917" rel="L9917">afire to-day, or sacked to-morrow! Now, a judicious selection from these</li>
<li class="L9918" rel="L9918">with the least possible delay, and the burying of them, or otherwise</li>
<li class="L9919" rel="L9919">getting of them out of harm&#39;s way, is within the power (without loss of</li>
<li class="L9920" rel="L9920">precious time) of scarcely any one but myself, if any one. And shall</li>
<li class="L9921" rel="L9921">I hang back, when Tellson&#39;s knows this and says this--Tellson&#39;s, whose</li>
<li class="L9922" rel="L9922">bread I have eaten these sixty years--because I am a little stiff about</li>
<li class="L9923" rel="L9923">the joints? Why, I am a boy, sir, to half a dozen old codgers here!”</li>
<li class="L9924" rel="L9924"></li>
<li class="L9925" rel="L9925">“How I admire the gallantry of your youthful spirit, Mr. Lorry.”</li>
<li class="L9926" rel="L9926"></li>
<li class="L9927" rel="L9927">“Tut! Nonsense, sir!--And, my dear Charles,” said Mr. Lorry, glancing at</li>
<li class="L9928" rel="L9928">the House again, “you are to remember, that getting things out of</li>
<li class="L9929" rel="L9929">Paris at this present time, no matter what things, is next to an</li>
<li class="L9930" rel="L9930">impossibility. Papers and precious matters were this very day brought</li>
<li class="L9931" rel="L9931">to us here (I speak in strict confidence; it is not business-like to</li>
<li class="L9932" rel="L9932">whisper it, even to you), by the strangest bearers you can imagine,</li>
<li class="L9933" rel="L9933">every one of whom had his head hanging on by a single hair as he passed</li>
<li class="L9934" rel="L9934">the Barriers. At another time, our parcels would come and go, as easily</li>
<li class="L9935" rel="L9935">as in business-like Old England; but now, everything is stopped.”</li>
<li class="L9936" rel="L9936"></li>
<li class="L9937" rel="L9937">“And do you really go to-night?”</li>
<li class="L9938" rel="L9938"></li>
<li class="L9939" rel="L9939">“I really go to-night, for the case has become too pressing to admit of</li>
<li class="L9940" rel="L9940">delay.”</li>
<li class="L9941" rel="L9941"></li>
<li class="L9942" rel="L9942">“And do you take no one with you?”</li>
<li class="L9943" rel="L9943"></li>
<li class="L9944" rel="L9944">“All sorts of people have been proposed to me, but I will have nothing</li>
<li class="L9945" rel="L9945">to say to any of them. I intend to take Jerry. Jerry has been my</li>
<li class="L9946" rel="L9946">bodyguard on Sunday nights for a long time past and I am used to him.</li>
<li class="L9947" rel="L9947">Nobody will suspect Jerry of being anything but an English bull-dog, or</li>
<li class="L9948" rel="L9948">of having any design in his head but to fly at anybody who touches his</li>
<li class="L9949" rel="L9949">master.”</li>
<li class="L9950" rel="L9950"></li>
<li class="L9951" rel="L9951">“I must say again that I heartily admire your gallantry and</li>
<li class="L9952" rel="L9952">youthfulness.”</li>
<li class="L9953" rel="L9953"></li>
<li class="L9954" rel="L9954">“I must say again, nonsense, nonsense! When I have executed this little</li>
<li class="L9955" rel="L9955">commission, I shall, perhaps, accept Tellson&#39;s proposal to retire and</li>
<li class="L9956" rel="L9956">live at my ease. Time enough, then, to think about growing old.”</li>
<li class="L9957" rel="L9957"></li>
<li class="L9958" rel="L9958">This dialogue had taken place at Mr. Lorry&#39;s usual desk, with</li>
<li class="L9959" rel="L9959">Monseigneur swarming within a yard or two of it, boastful of what he</li>
<li class="L9960" rel="L9960">would do to avenge himself on the rascal-people before long. It was too</li>
<li class="L9961" rel="L9961">much the way of Monseigneur under his reverses as a refugee, and it</li>
<li class="L9962" rel="L9962">was much too much the way of native British orthodoxy, to talk of this</li>
<li class="L9963" rel="L9963">terrible Revolution as if it were the only harvest ever known under</li>
<li class="L9964" rel="L9964">the skies that had not been sown--as if nothing had ever been done, or</li>
<li class="L9965" rel="L9965">omitted to be done, that had led to it--as if observers of the wretched</li>
<li class="L9966" rel="L9966">millions in France, and of the misused and perverted resources that</li>
<li class="L9967" rel="L9967">should have made them prosperous, had not seen it inevitably coming,</li>
<li class="L9968" rel="L9968">years before, and had not in plain words recorded what they saw. Such</li>
<li class="L9969" rel="L9969">vapouring, combined with the extravagant plots of Monseigneur for the</li>
<li class="L9970" rel="L9970">restoration of a state of things that had utterly exhausted itself,</li>
<li class="L9971" rel="L9971">and worn out Heaven and earth as well as itself, was hard to be endured</li>
<li class="L9972" rel="L9972">without some remonstrance by any sane man who knew the truth. And it was</li>
<li class="L9973" rel="L9973">such vapouring all about his ears, like a troublesome confusion of blood</li>
<li class="L9974" rel="L9974">in his own head, added to a latent uneasiness in his mind, which had</li>
<li class="L9975" rel="L9975">already made Charles Darnay restless, and which still kept him so.</li>
<li class="L9976" rel="L9976"></li>
<li class="L9977" rel="L9977">Among the talkers, was Stryver, of the King&#39;s Bench Bar, far on his</li>
<li class="L9978" rel="L9978">way to state promotion, and, therefore, loud on the theme: broaching</li>
<li class="L9979" rel="L9979">to Monseigneur, his devices for blowing the people up and exterminating</li>
<li class="L9980" rel="L9980">them from the face of the earth, and doing without them: and for</li>
<li class="L9981" rel="L9981">accomplishing many similar objects akin in their nature to the abolition</li>
<li class="L9982" rel="L9982">of eagles by sprinkling salt on the tails of the race. Him, Darnay heard</li>
<li class="L9983" rel="L9983">with a particular feeling of objection; and Darnay stood divided between</li>
<li class="L9984" rel="L9984">going away that he might hear no more, and remaining to interpose his</li>
<li class="L9985" rel="L9985">word, when the thing that was to be, went on to shape itself out.</li>
<li class="L9986" rel="L9986"></li>
<li class="L9987" rel="L9987">The House approached Mr. Lorry, and laying a soiled and unopened letter</li>
<li class="L9988" rel="L9988">before him, asked if he had yet discovered any traces of the person to</li>
<li class="L9989" rel="L9989">whom it was addressed? The House laid the letter down so close to Darnay</li>
<li class="L9990" rel="L9990">that he saw the direction--the more quickly because it was his own right</li>
<li class="L9991" rel="L9991">name. The address, turned into English, ran:</li>
<li class="L9992" rel="L9992"></li>
<li class="L9993" rel="L9993">“Very pressing. To Monsieur heretofore the Marquis St. Evremonde, of</li>
<li class="L9994" rel="L9994">France. Confided to the cares of Messrs. Tellson and Co., Bankers,</li>
<li class="L9995" rel="L9995">London, England.”</li>
<li class="L9996" rel="L9996"></li>
<li class="L9997" rel="L9997">On the marriage morning, Doctor Manette had made it his one urgent and</li>
<li class="L9998" rel="L9998">express request to Charles Darnay, that the secret of this name should</li>
<li class="L9999" rel="L9999">be--unless he, the Doctor, dissolved the obligation--kept inviolate</li>
<li class="L10000" rel="L10000">between them. Nobody else knew it to be his name; his own wife had no</li>
<li class="L10001" rel="L10001">suspicion of the fact; Mr. Lorry could have none.</li>
<li class="L10002" rel="L10002"></li>
<li class="L10003" rel="L10003">“No,” said Mr. Lorry, in reply to the House; “I have referred it,</li>
<li class="L10004" rel="L10004">I think, to everybody now here, and no one can tell me where this</li>
<li class="L10005" rel="L10005">gentleman is to be found.”</li>
<li class="L10006" rel="L10006"></li>
<li class="L10007" rel="L10007">The hands of the clock verging upon the hour of closing the Bank, there</li>
<li class="L10008" rel="L10008">was a general set of the current of talkers past Mr. Lorry&#39;s desk. He</li>
<li class="L10009" rel="L10009">held the letter out inquiringly; and Monseigneur looked at it, in the</li>
<li class="L10010" rel="L10010">person of this plotting and indignant refugee; and Monseigneur looked at</li>
<li class="L10011" rel="L10011">it in the person of that plotting and indignant refugee; and This, That,</li>
<li class="L10012" rel="L10012">and The Other, all had something disparaging to say, in French or in</li>
<li class="L10013" rel="L10013">English, concerning the Marquis who was not to be found.</li>
<li class="L10014" rel="L10014"></li>
<li class="L10015" rel="L10015">“Nephew, I believe--but in any case degenerate successor--of the</li>
<li class="L10016" rel="L10016">polished Marquis who was murdered,” said one. “Happy to say, I never</li>
<li class="L10017" rel="L10017">knew him.”</li>
<li class="L10018" rel="L10018"></li>
<li class="L10019" rel="L10019">“A craven who abandoned his post,” said another--this Monseigneur had</li>
<li class="L10020" rel="L10020">been got out of Paris, legs uppermost and half suffocated, in a load of</li>
<li class="L10021" rel="L10021">hay--“some years ago.”</li>
<li class="L10022" rel="L10022"></li>
<li class="L10023" rel="L10023">“Infected with the new doctrines,” said a third, eyeing the direction</li>
<li class="L10024" rel="L10024">through his glass in passing; “set himself in opposition to the last</li>
<li class="L10025" rel="L10025">Marquis, abandoned the estates when he inherited them, and left them to</li>
<li class="L10026" rel="L10026">the ruffian herd. They will recompense him now, I hope, as he deserves.”</li>
<li class="L10027" rel="L10027"></li>
<li class="L10028" rel="L10028">“Hey?” cried the blatant Stryver. “Did he though? Is that the sort of</li>
<li class="L10029" rel="L10029">fellow? Let us look at his infamous name. D--n the fellow!”</li>
<li class="L10030" rel="L10030"></li>
<li class="L10031" rel="L10031">Darnay, unable to restrain himself any longer, touched Mr. Stryver on</li>
<li class="L10032" rel="L10032">the shoulder, and said:</li>
<li class="L10033" rel="L10033"></li>
<li class="L10034" rel="L10034">“I know the fellow.”</li>
<li class="L10035" rel="L10035"></li>
<li class="L10036" rel="L10036">“Do you, by Jupiter?” said Stryver. “I am sorry for it.”</li>
<li class="L10037" rel="L10037"></li>
<li class="L10038" rel="L10038">“Why?”</li>
<li class="L10039" rel="L10039"></li>
<li class="L10040" rel="L10040">“Why, Mr. Darnay? D&#39;ye hear what he did? Don&#39;t ask, why, in these</li>
<li class="L10041" rel="L10041">times.”</li>
<li class="L10042" rel="L10042"></li>
<li class="L10043" rel="L10043">“But I do ask why?”</li>
<li class="L10044" rel="L10044"></li>
<li class="L10045" rel="L10045">“Then I tell you again, Mr. Darnay, I am sorry for it. I am sorry to</li>
<li class="L10046" rel="L10046">hear you putting any such extraordinary questions. Here is a fellow,</li>
<li class="L10047" rel="L10047">who, infected by the most pestilent and blasphemous code of devilry that</li>
<li class="L10048" rel="L10048">ever was known, abandoned his property to the vilest scum of the earth</li>
<li class="L10049" rel="L10049">that ever did murder by wholesale, and you ask me why I am sorry that a</li>
<li class="L10050" rel="L10050">man who instructs youth knows him? Well, but I&#39;ll answer you. I am sorry</li>
<li class="L10051" rel="L10051">because I believe there is contamination in such a scoundrel. That&#39;s</li>
<li class="L10052" rel="L10052">why.”</li>
<li class="L10053" rel="L10053"></li>
<li class="L10054" rel="L10054">Mindful of the secret, Darnay with great difficulty checked himself, and</li>
<li class="L10055" rel="L10055">said: “You may not understand the gentleman.”</li>
<li class="L10056" rel="L10056"></li>
<li class="L10057" rel="L10057">“I understand how to put _you_ in a corner, Mr. Darnay,” said Bully</li>
<li class="L10058" rel="L10058">Stryver, “and I&#39;ll do it. If this fellow is a gentleman, I _don&#39;t_</li>
<li class="L10059" rel="L10059">understand him. You may tell him so, with my compliments. You may also</li>
<li class="L10060" rel="L10060">tell him, from me, that after abandoning his worldly goods and position</li>
<li class="L10061" rel="L10061">to this butcherly mob, I wonder he is not at the head of them. But, no,</li>
<li class="L10062" rel="L10062">gentlemen,” said Stryver, looking all round, and snapping his fingers,</li>
<li class="L10063" rel="L10063">“I know something of human nature, and I tell you that you&#39;ll never</li>
<li class="L10064" rel="L10064">find a fellow like this fellow, trusting himself to the mercies of such</li>
<li class="L10065" rel="L10065">precious _protégés_. No, gentlemen; he&#39;ll always show &#39;em a clean pair</li>
<li class="L10066" rel="L10066">of heels very early in the scuffle, and sneak away.”</li>
<li class="L10067" rel="L10067"></li>
<li class="L10068" rel="L10068">With those words, and a final snap of his fingers, Mr. Stryver</li>
<li class="L10069" rel="L10069">shouldered himself into Fleet-street, amidst the general approbation of</li>
<li class="L10070" rel="L10070">his hearers. Mr. Lorry and Charles Darnay were left alone at the desk,</li>
<li class="L10071" rel="L10071">in the general departure from the Bank.</li>
<li class="L10072" rel="L10072"></li>
<li class="L10073" rel="L10073">“Will you take charge of the letter?” said Mr. Lorry. “You know where to</li>
<li class="L10074" rel="L10074">deliver it?”</li>
<li class="L10075" rel="L10075"></li>
<li class="L10076" rel="L10076">“I do.”</li>
<li class="L10077" rel="L10077"></li>
<li class="L10078" rel="L10078">“Will you undertake to explain, that we suppose it to have been</li>
<li class="L10079" rel="L10079">addressed here, on the chance of our knowing where to forward it, and</li>
<li class="L10080" rel="L10080">that it has been here some time?”</li>
<li class="L10081" rel="L10081"></li>
<li class="L10082" rel="L10082">“I will do so. Do you start for Paris from here?”</li>
<li class="L10083" rel="L10083"></li>
<li class="L10084" rel="L10084">“From here, at eight.”</li>
<li class="L10085" rel="L10085"></li>
<li class="L10086" rel="L10086">“I will come back, to see you off.”</li>
<li class="L10087" rel="L10087"></li>
<li class="L10088" rel="L10088">Very ill at ease with himself, and with Stryver and most other men,</li>
<li class="L10089" rel="L10089">Darnay made the best of his way into the quiet of the Temple, opened the</li>
<li class="L10090" rel="L10090">letter, and read it. These were its contents:</li>
<li class="L10091" rel="L10091"></li>
<li class="L10092" rel="L10092"></li>
<li class="L10093" rel="L10093">“Prison of the Abbaye, Paris.</li>
<li class="L10094" rel="L10094"></li>
<li class="L10095" rel="L10095">“June 21, 1792. “MONSIEUR HERETOFORE THE MARQUIS.</li>
<li class="L10096" rel="L10096"></li>
<li class="L10097" rel="L10097">“After having long been in danger of my life at the hands of the</li>
<li class="L10098" rel="L10098">village, I have been seized, with great violence and indignity, and</li>
<li class="L10099" rel="L10099">brought a long journey on foot to Paris. On the road I have suffered a</li>
<li class="L10100" rel="L10100">great deal. Nor is that all; my house has been destroyed--razed to the</li>
<li class="L10101" rel="L10101">ground.</li>
<li class="L10102" rel="L10102"></li>
<li class="L10103" rel="L10103">“The crime for which I am imprisoned, Monsieur heretofore the Marquis,</li>
<li class="L10104" rel="L10104">and for which I shall be summoned before the tribunal, and shall lose my</li>
<li class="L10105" rel="L10105">life (without your so generous help), is, they tell me, treason against</li>
<li class="L10106" rel="L10106">the majesty of the people, in that I have acted against them for an</li>
<li class="L10107" rel="L10107">emigrant. It is in vain I represent that I have acted for them, and not</li>
<li class="L10108" rel="L10108">against, according to your commands. It is in vain I represent that,</li>
<li class="L10109" rel="L10109">before the sequestration of emigrant property, I had remitted the</li>
<li class="L10110" rel="L10110">imposts they had ceased to pay; that I had collected no rent; that I had</li>
<li class="L10111" rel="L10111">had recourse to no process. The only response is, that I have acted for</li>
<li class="L10112" rel="L10112">an emigrant, and where is that emigrant?</li>
<li class="L10113" rel="L10113"></li>
<li class="L10114" rel="L10114">“Ah! most gracious Monsieur heretofore the Marquis, where is that</li>
<li class="L10115" rel="L10115">emigrant? I cry in my sleep where is he? I demand of Heaven, will he</li>
<li class="L10116" rel="L10116">not come to deliver me? No answer. Ah Monsieur heretofore the Marquis,</li>
<li class="L10117" rel="L10117">I send my desolate cry across the sea, hoping it may perhaps reach your</li>
<li class="L10118" rel="L10118">ears through the great bank of Tilson known at Paris!</li>
<li class="L10119" rel="L10119"></li>
<li class="L10120" rel="L10120">“For the love of Heaven, of justice, of generosity, of the honour of</li>
<li class="L10121" rel="L10121">your noble name, I supplicate you, Monsieur heretofore the Marquis, to</li>
<li class="L10122" rel="L10122">succour and release me. My fault is, that I have been true to you. Oh</li>
<li class="L10123" rel="L10123">Monsieur heretofore the Marquis, I pray you be you true to me!</li>
<li class="L10124" rel="L10124"></li>
<li class="L10125" rel="L10125">“From this prison here of horror, whence I every hour tend nearer and</li>
<li class="L10126" rel="L10126">nearer to destruction, I send you, Monsieur heretofore the Marquis, the</li>
<li class="L10127" rel="L10127">assurance of my dolorous and unhappy service.</li>
<li class="L10128" rel="L10128"></li>
<li class="L10129" rel="L10129">“Your afflicted,</li>
<li class="L10130" rel="L10130"></li>
<li class="L10131" rel="L10131">“Gabelle.”</li>
<li class="L10132" rel="L10132"></li>
<li class="L10133" rel="L10133"></li>
<li class="L10134" rel="L10134">The latent uneasiness in Darnay&#39;s mind was roused to vigourous life</li>
<li class="L10135" rel="L10135">by this letter. The peril of an old servant and a good one, whose</li>
<li class="L10136" rel="L10136">only crime was fidelity to himself and his family, stared him so</li>
<li class="L10137" rel="L10137">reproachfully in the face, that, as he walked to and fro in the Temple</li>
<li class="L10138" rel="L10138">considering what to do, he almost hid his face from the passersby.</li>
<li class="L10139" rel="L10139"></li>
<li class="L10140" rel="L10140">He knew very well, that in his horror of the deed which had culminated</li>
<li class="L10141" rel="L10141">the bad deeds and bad reputation of the old family house, in his</li>
<li class="L10142" rel="L10142">resentful suspicions of his uncle, and in the aversion with which his</li>
<li class="L10143" rel="L10143">conscience regarded the crumbling fabric that he was supposed to uphold,</li>
<li class="L10144" rel="L10144">he had acted imperfectly. He knew very well, that in his love for Lucie,</li>
<li class="L10145" rel="L10145">his renunciation of his social place, though by no means new to his own</li>
<li class="L10146" rel="L10146">mind, had been hurried and incomplete. He knew that he ought to have</li>
<li class="L10147" rel="L10147">systematically worked it out and supervised it, and that he had meant to</li>
<li class="L10148" rel="L10148">do it, and that it had never been done.</li>
<li class="L10149" rel="L10149"></li>
<li class="L10150" rel="L10150">The happiness of his own chosen English home, the necessity of being</li>
<li class="L10151" rel="L10151">always actively employed, the swift changes and troubles of the time</li>
<li class="L10152" rel="L10152">which had followed on one another so fast, that the events of this week</li>
<li class="L10153" rel="L10153">annihilated the immature plans of last week, and the events of the week</li>
<li class="L10154" rel="L10154">following made all new again; he knew very well, that to the force of</li>
<li class="L10155" rel="L10155">these circumstances he had yielded:--not without disquiet, but still</li>
<li class="L10156" rel="L10156">without continuous and accumulating resistance. That he had watched</li>
<li class="L10157" rel="L10157">the times for a time of action, and that they had shifted and struggled</li>
<li class="L10158" rel="L10158">until the time had gone by, and the nobility were trooping from</li>
<li class="L10159" rel="L10159">France by every highway and byway, and their property was in course of</li>
<li class="L10160" rel="L10160">confiscation and destruction, and their very names were blotting out,</li>
<li class="L10161" rel="L10161">was as well known to himself as it could be to any new authority in</li>
<li class="L10162" rel="L10162">France that might impeach him for it.</li>
<li class="L10163" rel="L10163"></li>
<li class="L10164" rel="L10164">But, he had oppressed no man, he had imprisoned no man; he was so</li>
<li class="L10165" rel="L10165">far from having harshly exacted payment of his dues, that he had</li>
<li class="L10166" rel="L10166">relinquished them of his own will, thrown himself on a world with no</li>
<li class="L10167" rel="L10167">favour in it, won his own private place there, and earned his own</li>
<li class="L10168" rel="L10168">bread. Monsieur Gabelle had held the impoverished and involved estate</li>
<li class="L10169" rel="L10169">on written instructions, to spare the people, to give them what little</li>
<li class="L10170" rel="L10170">there was to give--such fuel as the heavy creditors would let them have</li>
<li class="L10171" rel="L10171">in the winter, and such produce as could be saved from the same grip in</li>
<li class="L10172" rel="L10172">the summer--and no doubt he had put the fact in plea and proof, for his</li>
<li class="L10173" rel="L10173">own safety, so that it could not but appear now.</li>
<li class="L10174" rel="L10174"></li>
<li class="L10175" rel="L10175">This favoured the desperate resolution Charles Darnay had begun to make,</li>
<li class="L10176" rel="L10176">that he would go to Paris.</li>
<li class="L10177" rel="L10177"></li>
<li class="L10178" rel="L10178">Yes. Like the mariner in the old story, the winds and streams had driven</li>
<li class="L10179" rel="L10179">him within the influence of the Loadstone Rock, and it was drawing him</li>
<li class="L10180" rel="L10180">to itself, and he must go. Everything that arose before his mind drifted</li>
<li class="L10181" rel="L10181">him on, faster and faster, more and more steadily, to the terrible</li>
<li class="L10182" rel="L10182">attraction. His latent uneasiness had been, that bad aims were being</li>
<li class="L10183" rel="L10183">worked out in his own unhappy land by bad instruments, and that he who</li>
<li class="L10184" rel="L10184">could not fail to know that he was better than they, was not there,</li>
<li class="L10185" rel="L10185">trying to do something to stay bloodshed, and assert the claims of mercy</li>
<li class="L10186" rel="L10186">and humanity. With this uneasiness half stifled, and half reproaching</li>
<li class="L10187" rel="L10187">him, he had been brought to the pointed comparison of himself with the</li>
<li class="L10188" rel="L10188">brave old gentleman in whom duty was so strong; upon that comparison</li>
<li class="L10189" rel="L10189">(injurious to himself) had instantly followed the sneers of Monseigneur,</li>
<li class="L10190" rel="L10190">which had stung him bitterly, and those of Stryver, which above all were</li>
<li class="L10191" rel="L10191">coarse and galling, for old reasons. Upon those, had followed Gabelle&#39;s</li>
<li class="L10192" rel="L10192">letter: the appeal of an innocent prisoner, in danger of death, to his</li>
<li class="L10193" rel="L10193">justice, honour, and good name.</li>
<li class="L10194" rel="L10194"></li>
<li class="L10195" rel="L10195">His resolution was made. He must go to Paris.</li>
<li class="L10196" rel="L10196"></li>
<li class="L10197" rel="L10197">Yes. The Loadstone Rock was drawing him, and he must sail on, until he</li>
<li class="L10198" rel="L10198">struck. He knew of no rock; he saw hardly any danger. The intention</li>
<li class="L10199" rel="L10199">with which he had done what he had done, even although he had left</li>
<li class="L10200" rel="L10200">it incomplete, presented it before him in an aspect that would be</li>
<li class="L10201" rel="L10201">gratefully acknowledged in France on his presenting himself to assert</li>
<li class="L10202" rel="L10202">it. Then, that glorious vision of doing good, which is so often the</li>
<li class="L10203" rel="L10203">sanguine mirage of so many good minds, arose before him, and he even</li>
<li class="L10204" rel="L10204">saw himself in the illusion with some influence to guide this raging</li>
<li class="L10205" rel="L10205">Revolution that was running so fearfully wild.</li>
<li class="L10206" rel="L10206"></li>
<li class="L10207" rel="L10207">As he walked to and fro with his resolution made, he considered that</li>
<li class="L10208" rel="L10208">neither Lucie nor her father must know of it until he was gone.</li>
<li class="L10209" rel="L10209">Lucie should be spared the pain of separation; and her father, always</li>
<li class="L10210" rel="L10210">reluctant to turn his thoughts towards the dangerous ground of old,</li>
<li class="L10211" rel="L10211">should come to the knowledge of the step, as a step taken, and not in</li>
<li class="L10212" rel="L10212">the balance of suspense and doubt. How much of the incompleteness of his</li>
<li class="L10213" rel="L10213">situation was referable to her father, through the painful anxiety</li>
<li class="L10214" rel="L10214">to avoid reviving old associations of France in his mind, he did not</li>
<li class="L10215" rel="L10215">discuss with himself. But, that circumstance too, had had its influence</li>
<li class="L10216" rel="L10216">in his course.</li>
<li class="L10217" rel="L10217"></li>
<li class="L10218" rel="L10218">He walked to and fro, with thoughts very busy, until it was time to</li>
<li class="L10219" rel="L10219">return to Tellson&#39;s and take leave of Mr. Lorry. As soon as he arrived</li>
<li class="L10220" rel="L10220">in Paris he would present himself to this old friend, but he must say</li>
<li class="L10221" rel="L10221">nothing of his intention now.</li>
<li class="L10222" rel="L10222"></li>
<li class="L10223" rel="L10223">A carriage with post-horses was ready at the Bank door, and Jerry was</li>
<li class="L10224" rel="L10224">booted and equipped.</li>
<li class="L10225" rel="L10225"></li>
<li class="L10226" rel="L10226">“I have delivered that letter,” said Charles Darnay to Mr. Lorry. “I</li>
<li class="L10227" rel="L10227">would not consent to your being charged with any written answer, but</li>
<li class="L10228" rel="L10228">perhaps you will take a verbal one?”</li>
<li class="L10229" rel="L10229"></li>
<li class="L10230" rel="L10230">“That I will, and readily,” said Mr. Lorry, “if it is not dangerous.”</li>
<li class="L10231" rel="L10231"></li>
<li class="L10232" rel="L10232">“Not at all. Though it is to a prisoner in the Abbaye.”</li>
<li class="L10233" rel="L10233"></li>
<li class="L10234" rel="L10234">“What is his name?” said Mr. Lorry, with his open pocket-book in his</li>
<li class="L10235" rel="L10235">hand.</li>
<li class="L10236" rel="L10236"></li>
<li class="L10237" rel="L10237">“Gabelle.”</li>
<li class="L10238" rel="L10238"></li>
<li class="L10239" rel="L10239">“Gabelle. And what is the message to the unfortunate Gabelle in prison?”</li>
<li class="L10240" rel="L10240"></li>
<li class="L10241" rel="L10241">“Simply, &#39;that he has received the letter, and will come.&#39;”</li>
<li class="L10242" rel="L10242"></li>
<li class="L10243" rel="L10243">“Any time mentioned?”</li>
<li class="L10244" rel="L10244"></li>
<li class="L10245" rel="L10245">“He will start upon his journey to-morrow night.”</li>
<li class="L10246" rel="L10246"></li>
<li class="L10247" rel="L10247">“Any person mentioned?”</li>
<li class="L10248" rel="L10248"></li>
<li class="L10249" rel="L10249">“No.”</li>
<li class="L10250" rel="L10250"></li>
<li class="L10251" rel="L10251">He helped Mr. Lorry to wrap himself in a number of coats and cloaks,</li>
<li class="L10252" rel="L10252">and went out with him from the warm atmosphere of the old Bank, into the</li>
<li class="L10253" rel="L10253">misty air of Fleet-street. “My love to Lucie, and to little Lucie,” said</li>
<li class="L10254" rel="L10254">Mr. Lorry at parting, “and take precious care of them till I come back.”</li>
<li class="L10255" rel="L10255"> Charles Darnay shook his head and doubtfully smiled, as the carriage</li>
<li class="L10256" rel="L10256">rolled away.</li>
<li class="L10257" rel="L10257"></li>
<li class="L10258" rel="L10258">That night--it was the fourteenth of August--he sat up late, and wrote</li>
<li class="L10259" rel="L10259">two fervent letters; one was to Lucie, explaining the strong obligation</li>
<li class="L10260" rel="L10260">he was under to go to Paris, and showing her, at length, the reasons</li>
<li class="L10261" rel="L10261">that he had, for feeling confident that he could become involved in no</li>
<li class="L10262" rel="L10262">personal danger there; the other was to the Doctor, confiding Lucie and</li>
<li class="L10263" rel="L10263">their dear child to his care, and dwelling on the same topics with the</li>
<li class="L10264" rel="L10264">strongest assurances. To both, he wrote that he would despatch letters</li>
<li class="L10265" rel="L10265">in proof of his safety, immediately after his arrival.</li>
<li class="L10266" rel="L10266"></li>
<li class="L10267" rel="L10267">It was a hard day, that day of being among them, with the first</li>
<li class="L10268" rel="L10268">reservation of their joint lives on his mind. It was a hard matter to</li>
<li class="L10269" rel="L10269">preserve the innocent deceit of which they were profoundly unsuspicious.</li>
<li class="L10270" rel="L10270">But, an affectionate glance at his wife, so happy and busy, made him</li>
<li class="L10271" rel="L10271">resolute not to tell her what impended (he had been half moved to do it,</li>
<li class="L10272" rel="L10272">so strange it was to him to act in anything without her quiet aid), and</li>
<li class="L10273" rel="L10273">the day passed quickly. Early in the evening he embraced her, and her</li>
<li class="L10274" rel="L10274">scarcely less dear namesake, pretending that he would return by-and-bye</li>
<li class="L10275" rel="L10275">(an imaginary engagement took him out, and he had secreted a valise</li>
<li class="L10276" rel="L10276">of clothes ready), and so he emerged into the heavy mist of the heavy</li>
<li class="L10277" rel="L10277">streets, with a heavier heart.</li>
<li class="L10278" rel="L10278"></li>
<li class="L10279" rel="L10279">The unseen force was drawing him fast to itself, now, and all the tides</li>
<li class="L10280" rel="L10280">and winds were setting straight and strong towards it. He left his</li>
<li class="L10281" rel="L10281">two letters with a trusty porter, to be delivered half an hour before</li>
<li class="L10282" rel="L10282">midnight, and no sooner; took horse for Dover; and began his journey.</li>
<li class="L10283" rel="L10283">“For the love of Heaven, of justice, of generosity, of the honour of</li>
<li class="L10284" rel="L10284">your noble name!” was the poor prisoner&#39;s cry with which he strengthened</li>
<li class="L10285" rel="L10285">his sinking heart, as he left all that was dear on earth behind him, and</li>
<li class="L10286" rel="L10286">floated away for the Loadstone Rock.</li>
<li class="L10287" rel="L10287"></li>
<li class="L10288" rel="L10288"></li>
<li class="L10289" rel="L10289">The end of the second book.</li>
<li class="L10290" rel="L10290"></li>
<li class="L10291" rel="L10291"></li>
<li class="L10292" rel="L10292"></li>
<li class="L10293" rel="L10293"></li>
<li class="L10294" rel="L10294"></li>
<li class="L10295" rel="L10295">Book the Third--the Track of a Storm</li>
<li class="L10296" rel="L10296"></li>
<li class="L10297" rel="L10297"></li>
<li class="L10298" rel="L10298"></li>
<li class="L10299" rel="L10299"></li>
<li class="L10300" rel="L10300">I. In Secret</li>
<li class="L10301" rel="L10301"></li>
<li class="L10302" rel="L10302"></li>
<li class="L10303" rel="L10303">The traveller fared slowly on his way, who fared towards Paris from</li>
<li class="L10304" rel="L10304">England in the autumn of the year one thousand seven hundred and</li>
<li class="L10305" rel="L10305">ninety-two. More than enough of bad roads, bad equipages, and bad</li>
<li class="L10306" rel="L10306">horses, he would have encountered to delay him, though the fallen and</li>
<li class="L10307" rel="L10307">unfortunate King of France had been upon his throne in all his glory;</li>
<li class="L10308" rel="L10308">but, the changed times were fraught with other obstacles than</li>
<li class="L10309" rel="L10309">these. Every town-gate and village taxing-house had its band of</li>
<li class="L10310" rel="L10310">citizen-patriots, with their national muskets in a most explosive state</li>
<li class="L10311" rel="L10311">of readiness, who stopped all comers and goers, cross-questioned them,</li>
<li class="L10312" rel="L10312">inspected their papers, looked for their names in lists of their own,</li>
<li class="L10313" rel="L10313">turned them back, or sent them on, or stopped them and laid them in</li>
<li class="L10314" rel="L10314">hold, as their capricious judgment or fancy deemed best for the dawning</li>
<li class="L10315" rel="L10315">Republic One and Indivisible, of Liberty, Equality, Fraternity, or</li>
<li class="L10316" rel="L10316">Death.</li>
<li class="L10317" rel="L10317"></li>
<li class="L10318" rel="L10318">A very few French leagues of his journey were accomplished, when Charles</li>
<li class="L10319" rel="L10319">Darnay began to perceive that for him along these country roads there</li>
<li class="L10320" rel="L10320">was no hope of return until he should have been declared a good citizen</li>
<li class="L10321" rel="L10321">at Paris. Whatever might befall now, he must on to his journey&#39;s end.</li>
<li class="L10322" rel="L10322">Not a mean village closed upon him, not a common barrier dropped across</li>
<li class="L10323" rel="L10323">the road behind him, but he knew it to be another iron door in</li>
<li class="L10324" rel="L10324">the series that was barred between him and England. The universal</li>
<li class="L10325" rel="L10325">watchfulness so encompassed him, that if he had been taken in a net,</li>
<li class="L10326" rel="L10326">or were being forwarded to his destination in a cage, he could not have</li>
<li class="L10327" rel="L10327">felt his freedom more completely gone.</li>
<li class="L10328" rel="L10328"></li>
<li class="L10329" rel="L10329">This universal watchfulness not only stopped him on the highway twenty</li>
<li class="L10330" rel="L10330">times in a stage, but retarded his progress twenty times in a day, by</li>
<li class="L10331" rel="L10331">riding after him and taking him back, riding before him and stopping him</li>
<li class="L10332" rel="L10332">by anticipation, riding with him and keeping him in charge. He had been</li>
<li class="L10333" rel="L10333">days upon his journey in France alone, when he went to bed tired out, in</li>
<li class="L10334" rel="L10334">a little town on the high road, still a long way from Paris.</li>
<li class="L10335" rel="L10335"></li>
<li class="L10336" rel="L10336">Nothing but the production of the afflicted Gabelle&#39;s letter from his</li>
<li class="L10337" rel="L10337">prison of the Abbaye would have got him on so far. His difficulty at the</li>
<li class="L10338" rel="L10338">guard-house in this small place had been such, that he felt his journey</li>
<li class="L10339" rel="L10339">to have come to a crisis. And he was, therefore, as little surprised as</li>
<li class="L10340" rel="L10340">a man could be, to find himself awakened at the small inn to which he</li>
<li class="L10341" rel="L10341">had been remitted until morning, in the middle of the night.</li>
<li class="L10342" rel="L10342"></li>
<li class="L10343" rel="L10343">Awakened by a timid local functionary and three armed patriots in rough</li>
<li class="L10344" rel="L10344">red caps and with pipes in their mouths, who sat down on the bed.</li>
<li class="L10345" rel="L10345"></li>
<li class="L10346" rel="L10346">“Emigrant,” said the functionary, “I am going to send you on to Paris,</li>
<li class="L10347" rel="L10347">under an escort.”</li>
<li class="L10348" rel="L10348"></li>
<li class="L10349" rel="L10349">“Citizen, I desire nothing more than to get to Paris, though I could</li>
<li class="L10350" rel="L10350">dispense with the escort.”</li>
<li class="L10351" rel="L10351"></li>
<li class="L10352" rel="L10352">“Silence!” growled a red-cap, striking at the coverlet with the butt-end</li>
<li class="L10353" rel="L10353">of his musket. “Peace, aristocrat!”</li>
<li class="L10354" rel="L10354"></li>
<li class="L10355" rel="L10355">“It is as the good patriot says,” observed the timid functionary. “You</li>
<li class="L10356" rel="L10356">are an aristocrat, and must have an escort--and must pay for it.”</li>
<li class="L10357" rel="L10357"></li>
<li class="L10358" rel="L10358">“I have no choice,” said Charles Darnay.</li>
<li class="L10359" rel="L10359"></li>
<li class="L10360" rel="L10360">“Choice! Listen to him!” cried the same scowling red-cap. “As if it was</li>
<li class="L10361" rel="L10361">not a favour to be protected from the lamp-iron!”</li>
<li class="L10362" rel="L10362"></li>
<li class="L10363" rel="L10363">“It is always as the good patriot says,” observed the functionary. “Rise</li>
<li class="L10364" rel="L10364">and dress yourself, emigrant.”</li>
<li class="L10365" rel="L10365"></li>
<li class="L10366" rel="L10366">Darnay complied, and was taken back to the guard-house, where other</li>
<li class="L10367" rel="L10367">patriots in rough red caps were smoking, drinking, and sleeping, by</li>
<li class="L10368" rel="L10368">a watch-fire. Here he paid a heavy price for his escort, and hence he</li>
<li class="L10369" rel="L10369">started with it on the wet, wet roads at three o&#39;clock in the morning.</li>
<li class="L10370" rel="L10370"></li>
<li class="L10371" rel="L10371">The escort were two mounted patriots in red caps and tri-coloured</li>
<li class="L10372" rel="L10372">cockades, armed with national muskets and sabres, who rode one on either</li>
<li class="L10373" rel="L10373">side of him.</li>
<li class="L10374" rel="L10374"></li>
<li class="L10375" rel="L10375">The escorted governed his own horse, but a loose line was attached to</li>
<li class="L10376" rel="L10376">his bridle, the end of which one of the patriots kept girded round his</li>
<li class="L10377" rel="L10377">wrist. In this state they set forth with the sharp rain driving in their</li>
<li class="L10378" rel="L10378">faces: clattering at a heavy dragoon trot over the uneven town pavement,</li>
<li class="L10379" rel="L10379">and out upon the mire-deep roads. In this state they traversed without</li>
<li class="L10380" rel="L10380">change, except of horses and pace, all the mire-deep leagues that lay</li>
<li class="L10381" rel="L10381">between them and the capital.</li>
<li class="L10382" rel="L10382"></li>
<li class="L10383" rel="L10383">They travelled in the night, halting an hour or two after daybreak, and</li>
<li class="L10384" rel="L10384">lying by until the twilight fell. The escort were so wretchedly clothed,</li>
<li class="L10385" rel="L10385">that they twisted straw round their bare legs, and thatched their ragged</li>
<li class="L10386" rel="L10386">shoulders to keep the wet off. Apart from the personal discomfort of</li>
<li class="L10387" rel="L10387">being so attended, and apart from such considerations of present danger</li>
<li class="L10388" rel="L10388">as arose from one of the patriots being chronically drunk, and carrying</li>
<li class="L10389" rel="L10389">his musket very recklessly, Charles Darnay did not allow the restraint</li>
<li class="L10390" rel="L10390">that was laid upon him to awaken any serious fears in his breast; for,</li>
<li class="L10391" rel="L10391">he reasoned with himself that it could have no reference to the merits</li>
<li class="L10392" rel="L10392">of an individual case that was not yet stated, and of representations,</li>
<li class="L10393" rel="L10393">confirmable by the prisoner in the Abbaye, that were not yet made.</li>
<li class="L10394" rel="L10394"></li>
<li class="L10395" rel="L10395">But when they came to the town of Beauvais--which they did at eventide,</li>
<li class="L10396" rel="L10396">when the streets were filled with people--he could not conceal from</li>
<li class="L10397" rel="L10397">himself that the aspect of affairs was very alarming. An ominous crowd</li>
<li class="L10398" rel="L10398">gathered to see him dismount of the posting-yard, and many voices called</li>
<li class="L10399" rel="L10399">out loudly, “Down with the emigrant!”</li>
<li class="L10400" rel="L10400"></li>
<li class="L10401" rel="L10401">He stopped in the act of swinging himself out of his saddle, and,</li>
<li class="L10402" rel="L10402">resuming it as his safest place, said:</li>
<li class="L10403" rel="L10403"></li>
<li class="L10404" rel="L10404">“Emigrant, my friends! Do you not see me here, in France, of my own</li>
<li class="L10405" rel="L10405">will?”</li>
<li class="L10406" rel="L10406"></li>
<li class="L10407" rel="L10407">“You are a cursed emigrant,” cried a farrier, making at him in a</li>
<li class="L10408" rel="L10408">furious manner through the press, hammer in hand; “and you are a cursed</li>
<li class="L10409" rel="L10409">aristocrat!”</li>
<li class="L10410" rel="L10410"></li>
<li class="L10411" rel="L10411">The postmaster interposed himself between this man and the rider&#39;s</li>
<li class="L10412" rel="L10412">bridle (at which he was evidently making), and soothingly said, “Let him</li>
<li class="L10413" rel="L10413">be; let him be! He will be judged at Paris.”</li>
<li class="L10414" rel="L10414"></li>
<li class="L10415" rel="L10415">“Judged!” repeated the farrier, swinging his hammer. “Ay! and condemned</li>
<li class="L10416" rel="L10416">as a traitor.” At this the crowd roared approval.</li>
<li class="L10417" rel="L10417"></li>
<li class="L10418" rel="L10418">Checking the postmaster, who was for turning his horse&#39;s head to the</li>
<li class="L10419" rel="L10419">yard (the drunken patriot sat composedly in his saddle looking on, with</li>
<li class="L10420" rel="L10420">the line round his wrist), Darnay said, as soon as he could make his</li>
<li class="L10421" rel="L10421">voice heard:</li>
<li class="L10422" rel="L10422"></li>
<li class="L10423" rel="L10423">“Friends, you deceive yourselves, or you are deceived. I am not a</li>
<li class="L10424" rel="L10424">traitor.”</li>
<li class="L10425" rel="L10425"></li>
<li class="L10426" rel="L10426">“He lies!” cried the smith. “He is a traitor since the decree. His life</li>
<li class="L10427" rel="L10427">is forfeit to the people. His cursed life is not his own!”</li>
<li class="L10428" rel="L10428"></li>
<li class="L10429" rel="L10429">At the instant when Darnay saw a rush in the eyes of the crowd, which</li>
<li class="L10430" rel="L10430">another instant would have brought upon him, the postmaster turned his</li>
<li class="L10431" rel="L10431">horse into the yard, the escort rode in close upon his horse&#39;s flanks,</li>
<li class="L10432" rel="L10432">and the postmaster shut and barred the crazy double gates. The farrier</li>
<li class="L10433" rel="L10433">struck a blow upon them with his hammer, and the crowd groaned; but, no</li>
<li class="L10434" rel="L10434">more was done.</li>
<li class="L10435" rel="L10435"></li>
<li class="L10436" rel="L10436">“What is this decree that the smith spoke of?” Darnay asked the</li>
<li class="L10437" rel="L10437">postmaster, when he had thanked him, and stood beside him in the yard.</li>
<li class="L10438" rel="L10438"></li>
<li class="L10439" rel="L10439">“Truly, a decree for selling the property of emigrants.”</li>
<li class="L10440" rel="L10440"></li>
<li class="L10441" rel="L10441">“When passed?”</li>
<li class="L10442" rel="L10442"></li>
<li class="L10443" rel="L10443">“On the fourteenth.”</li>
<li class="L10444" rel="L10444"></li>
<li class="L10445" rel="L10445">“The day I left England!”</li>
<li class="L10446" rel="L10446"></li>
<li class="L10447" rel="L10447">“Everybody says it is but one of several, and that there will be</li>
<li class="L10448" rel="L10448">others--if there are not already--banishing all emigrants, and</li>
<li class="L10449" rel="L10449">condemning all to death who return. That is what he meant when he said</li>
<li class="L10450" rel="L10450">your life was not your own.”</li>
<li class="L10451" rel="L10451"></li>
<li class="L10452" rel="L10452">“But there are no such decrees yet?”</li>
<li class="L10453" rel="L10453"></li>
<li class="L10454" rel="L10454">“What do I know!” said the postmaster, shrugging his shoulders; “there</li>
<li class="L10455" rel="L10455">may be, or there will be. It is all the same. What would you have?”</li>
<li class="L10456" rel="L10456"></li>
<li class="L10457" rel="L10457">They rested on some straw in a loft until the middle of the night, and</li>
<li class="L10458" rel="L10458">then rode forward again when all the town was asleep. Among the many</li>
<li class="L10459" rel="L10459">wild changes observable on familiar things which made this wild ride</li>
<li class="L10460" rel="L10460">unreal, not the least was the seeming rarity of sleep. After long and</li>
<li class="L10461" rel="L10461">lonely spurring over dreary roads, they would come to a cluster of poor</li>
<li class="L10462" rel="L10462">cottages, not steeped in darkness, but all glittering with lights, and</li>
<li class="L10463" rel="L10463">would find the people, in a ghostly manner in the dead of the night,</li>
<li class="L10464" rel="L10464">circling hand in hand round a shrivelled tree of Liberty, or all drawn</li>
<li class="L10465" rel="L10465">up together singing a Liberty song. Happily, however, there was sleep in</li>
<li class="L10466" rel="L10466">Beauvais that night to help them out of it and they passed on once more</li>
<li class="L10467" rel="L10467">into solitude and loneliness: jingling through the untimely cold and</li>
<li class="L10468" rel="L10468">wet, among impoverished fields that had yielded no fruits of the earth</li>
<li class="L10469" rel="L10469">that year, diversified by the blackened remains of burnt houses, and by</li>
<li class="L10470" rel="L10470">the sudden emergence from ambuscade, and sharp reining up across their</li>
<li class="L10471" rel="L10471">way, of patriot patrols on the watch on all the roads.</li>
<li class="L10472" rel="L10472"></li>
<li class="L10473" rel="L10473">Daylight at last found them before the wall of Paris. The barrier was</li>
<li class="L10474" rel="L10474">closed and strongly guarded when they rode up to it.</li>
<li class="L10475" rel="L10475"></li>
<li class="L10476" rel="L10476">“Where are the papers of this prisoner?” demanded a resolute-looking man</li>
<li class="L10477" rel="L10477">in authority, who was summoned out by the guard.</li>
<li class="L10478" rel="L10478"></li>
<li class="L10479" rel="L10479">Naturally struck by the disagreeable word, Charles Darnay requested the</li>
<li class="L10480" rel="L10480">speaker to take notice that he was a free traveller and French citizen,</li>
<li class="L10481" rel="L10481">in charge of an escort which the disturbed state of the country had</li>
<li class="L10482" rel="L10482">imposed upon him, and which he had paid for.</li>
<li class="L10483" rel="L10483"></li>
<li class="L10484" rel="L10484">“Where,” repeated the same personage, without taking any heed of him</li>
<li class="L10485" rel="L10485">whatever, “are the papers of this prisoner?”</li>
<li class="L10486" rel="L10486"></li>
<li class="L10487" rel="L10487">The drunken patriot had them in his cap, and produced them. Casting his</li>
<li class="L10488" rel="L10488">eyes over Gabelle&#39;s letter, the same personage in authority showed some</li>
<li class="L10489" rel="L10489">disorder and surprise, and looked at Darnay with a close attention.</li>
<li class="L10490" rel="L10490"></li>
<li class="L10491" rel="L10491">He left escort and escorted without saying a word, however, and went</li>
<li class="L10492" rel="L10492">into the guard-room; meanwhile, they sat upon their horses outside the</li>
<li class="L10493" rel="L10493">gate. Looking about him while in this state of suspense, Charles</li>
<li class="L10494" rel="L10494">Darnay observed that the gate was held by a mixed guard of soldiers and</li>
<li class="L10495" rel="L10495">patriots, the latter far outnumbering the former; and that while ingress</li>
<li class="L10496" rel="L10496">into the city for peasants&#39; carts bringing in supplies, and for similar</li>
<li class="L10497" rel="L10497">traffic and traffickers, was easy enough, egress, even for the homeliest</li>
<li class="L10498" rel="L10498">people, was very difficult. A numerous medley of men and women, not</li>
<li class="L10499" rel="L10499">to mention beasts and vehicles of various sorts, was waiting to issue</li>
<li class="L10500" rel="L10500">forth; but, the previous identification was so strict, that they</li>
<li class="L10501" rel="L10501">filtered through the barrier very slowly. Some of these people knew</li>
<li class="L10502" rel="L10502">their turn for examination to be so far off, that they lay down on the</li>
<li class="L10503" rel="L10503">ground to sleep or smoke, while others talked together, or loitered</li>
<li class="L10504" rel="L10504">about. The red cap and tri-colour cockade were universal, both among men</li>
<li class="L10505" rel="L10505">and women.</li>
<li class="L10506" rel="L10506"></li>
<li class="L10507" rel="L10507">When he had sat in his saddle some half-hour, taking note of these</li>
<li class="L10508" rel="L10508">things, Darnay found himself confronted by the same man in authority,</li>
<li class="L10509" rel="L10509">who directed the guard to open the barrier. Then he delivered to the</li>
<li class="L10510" rel="L10510">escort, drunk and sober, a receipt for the escorted, and requested him</li>
<li class="L10511" rel="L10511">to dismount. He did so, and the two patriots, leading his tired horse,</li>
<li class="L10512" rel="L10512">turned and rode away without entering the city.</li>
<li class="L10513" rel="L10513"></li>
<li class="L10514" rel="L10514">He accompanied his conductor into a guard-room, smelling of common wine</li>
<li class="L10515" rel="L10515">and tobacco, where certain soldiers and patriots, asleep and awake,</li>
<li class="L10516" rel="L10516">drunk and sober, and in various neutral states between sleeping and</li>
<li class="L10517" rel="L10517">waking, drunkenness and sobriety, were standing and lying about. The</li>
<li class="L10518" rel="L10518">light in the guard-house, half derived from the waning oil-lamps of</li>
<li class="L10519" rel="L10519">the night, and half from the overcast day, was in a correspondingly</li>
<li class="L10520" rel="L10520">uncertain condition. Some registers were lying open on a desk, and an</li>
<li class="L10521" rel="L10521">officer of a coarse, dark aspect, presided over these.</li>
<li class="L10522" rel="L10522"></li>
<li class="L10523" rel="L10523">“Citizen Defarge,” said he to Darnay&#39;s conductor, as he took a slip of</li>
<li class="L10524" rel="L10524">paper to write on. “Is this the emigrant Evremonde?”</li>
<li class="L10525" rel="L10525"></li>
<li class="L10526" rel="L10526">“This is the man.”</li>
<li class="L10527" rel="L10527"></li>
<li class="L10528" rel="L10528">“Your age, Evremonde?”</li>
<li class="L10529" rel="L10529"></li>
<li class="L10530" rel="L10530">“Thirty-seven.”</li>
<li class="L10531" rel="L10531"></li>
<li class="L10532" rel="L10532">“Married, Evremonde?”</li>
<li class="L10533" rel="L10533"></li>
<li class="L10534" rel="L10534">“Yes.”</li>
<li class="L10535" rel="L10535"></li>
<li class="L10536" rel="L10536">“Where married?”</li>
<li class="L10537" rel="L10537"></li>
<li class="L10538" rel="L10538">“In England.”</li>
<li class="L10539" rel="L10539"></li>
<li class="L10540" rel="L10540">“Without doubt. Where is your wife, Evremonde?”</li>
<li class="L10541" rel="L10541"></li>
<li class="L10542" rel="L10542">“In England.”</li>
<li class="L10543" rel="L10543"></li>
<li class="L10544" rel="L10544">“Without doubt. You are consigned, Evremonde, to the prison of La</li>
<li class="L10545" rel="L10545">Force.”</li>
<li class="L10546" rel="L10546"></li>
<li class="L10547" rel="L10547">“Just Heaven!” exclaimed Darnay. “Under what law, and for what offence?”</li>
<li class="L10548" rel="L10548"></li>
<li class="L10549" rel="L10549">The officer looked up from his slip of paper for a moment.</li>
<li class="L10550" rel="L10550"></li>
<li class="L10551" rel="L10551">“We have new laws, Evremonde, and new offences, since you were here.” He</li>
<li class="L10552" rel="L10552">said it with a hard smile, and went on writing.</li>
<li class="L10553" rel="L10553"></li>
<li class="L10554" rel="L10554">“I entreat you to observe that I have come here voluntarily, in response</li>
<li class="L10555" rel="L10555">to that written appeal of a fellow-countryman which lies before you. I</li>
<li class="L10556" rel="L10556">demand no more than the opportunity to do so without delay. Is not that</li>
<li class="L10557" rel="L10557">my right?”</li>
<li class="L10558" rel="L10558"></li>
<li class="L10559" rel="L10559">“Emigrants have no rights, Evremonde,” was the stolid reply. The officer</li>
<li class="L10560" rel="L10560">wrote until he had finished, read over to himself what he had written,</li>
<li class="L10561" rel="L10561">sanded it, and handed it to Defarge, with the words “In secret.”</li>
<li class="L10562" rel="L10562"></li>
<li class="L10563" rel="L10563">Defarge motioned with the paper to the prisoner that he must accompany</li>
<li class="L10564" rel="L10564">him. The prisoner obeyed, and a guard of two armed patriots attended</li>
<li class="L10565" rel="L10565">them.</li>
<li class="L10566" rel="L10566"></li>
<li class="L10567" rel="L10567">“Is it you,” said Defarge, in a low voice, as they went down the</li>
<li class="L10568" rel="L10568">guardhouse steps and turned into Paris, “who married the daughter of</li>
<li class="L10569" rel="L10569">Doctor Manette, once a prisoner in the Bastille that is no more?”</li>
<li class="L10570" rel="L10570"></li>
<li class="L10571" rel="L10571">“Yes,” replied Darnay, looking at him with surprise.</li>
<li class="L10572" rel="L10572"></li>
<li class="L10573" rel="L10573">“My name is Defarge, and I keep a wine-shop in the Quarter Saint</li>
<li class="L10574" rel="L10574">Antoine. Possibly you have heard of me.”</li>
<li class="L10575" rel="L10575"></li>
<li class="L10576" rel="L10576">“My wife came to your house to reclaim her father? Yes!”</li>
<li class="L10577" rel="L10577"></li>
<li class="L10578" rel="L10578">The word “wife” seemed to serve as a gloomy reminder to Defarge, to say</li>
<li class="L10579" rel="L10579">with sudden impatience, “In the name of that sharp female newly-born,</li>
<li class="L10580" rel="L10580">and called La Guillotine, why did you come to France?”</li>
<li class="L10581" rel="L10581"></li>
<li class="L10582" rel="L10582">“You heard me say why, a minute ago. Do you not believe it is the</li>
<li class="L10583" rel="L10583">truth?”</li>
<li class="L10584" rel="L10584"></li>
<li class="L10585" rel="L10585">“A bad truth for you,” said Defarge, speaking with knitted brows, and</li>
<li class="L10586" rel="L10586">looking straight before him.</li>
<li class="L10587" rel="L10587"></li>
<li class="L10588" rel="L10588">“Indeed I am lost here. All here is so unprecedented, so changed, so</li>
<li class="L10589" rel="L10589">sudden and unfair, that I am absolutely lost. Will you render me a</li>
<li class="L10590" rel="L10590">little help?”</li>
<li class="L10591" rel="L10591"></li>
<li class="L10592" rel="L10592">“None.” Defarge spoke, always looking straight before him.</li>
<li class="L10593" rel="L10593"></li>
<li class="L10594" rel="L10594">“Will you answer me a single question?”</li>
<li class="L10595" rel="L10595"></li>
<li class="L10596" rel="L10596">“Perhaps. According to its nature. You can say what it is.”</li>
<li class="L10597" rel="L10597"></li>
<li class="L10598" rel="L10598">“In this prison that I am going to so unjustly, shall I have some free</li>
<li class="L10599" rel="L10599">communication with the world outside?”</li>
<li class="L10600" rel="L10600"></li>
<li class="L10601" rel="L10601">“You will see.”</li>
<li class="L10602" rel="L10602"></li>
<li class="L10603" rel="L10603">“I am not to be buried there, prejudged, and without any means of</li>
<li class="L10604" rel="L10604">presenting my case?”</li>
<li class="L10605" rel="L10605"></li>
<li class="L10606" rel="L10606">“You will see. But, what then? Other people have been similarly buried</li>
<li class="L10607" rel="L10607">in worse prisons, before now.”</li>
<li class="L10608" rel="L10608"></li>
<li class="L10609" rel="L10609">“But never by me, Citizen Defarge.”</li>
<li class="L10610" rel="L10610"></li>
<li class="L10611" rel="L10611">Defarge glanced darkly at him for answer, and walked on in a steady</li>
<li class="L10612" rel="L10612">and set silence. The deeper he sank into this silence, the fainter hope</li>
<li class="L10613" rel="L10613">there was--or so Darnay thought--of his softening in any slight degree.</li>
<li class="L10614" rel="L10614">He, therefore, made haste to say:</li>
<li class="L10615" rel="L10615"></li>
<li class="L10616" rel="L10616">“It is of the utmost importance to me (you know, Citizen, even better</li>
<li class="L10617" rel="L10617">than I, of how much importance), that I should be able to communicate to</li>
<li class="L10618" rel="L10618">Mr. Lorry of Tellson&#39;s Bank, an English gentleman who is now in Paris,</li>
<li class="L10619" rel="L10619">the simple fact, without comment, that I have been thrown into the</li>
<li class="L10620" rel="L10620">prison of La Force. Will you cause that to be done for me?”</li>
<li class="L10621" rel="L10621"></li>
<li class="L10622" rel="L10622">“I will do,” Defarge doggedly rejoined, “nothing for you. My duty is to</li>
<li class="L10623" rel="L10623">my country and the People. I am the sworn servant of both, against you.</li>
<li class="L10624" rel="L10624">I will do nothing for you.”</li>
<li class="L10625" rel="L10625"></li>
<li class="L10626" rel="L10626">Charles Darnay felt it hopeless to entreat him further, and his pride</li>
