<li class="L10627" rel="L10627">was touched besides. As they walked on in silence, he could not but see</li>
<li class="L10628" rel="L10628">how used the people were to the spectacle of prisoners passing along the</li>
<li class="L10629" rel="L10629">streets. The very children scarcely noticed him. A few passers turned</li>
<li class="L10630" rel="L10630">their heads, and a few shook their fingers at him as an aristocrat;</li>
<li class="L10631" rel="L10631">otherwise, that a man in good clothes should be going to prison, was no</li>
<li class="L10632" rel="L10632">more remarkable than that a labourer in working clothes should be</li>
<li class="L10633" rel="L10633">going to work. In one narrow, dark, and dirty street through which they</li>
<li class="L10634" rel="L10634">passed, an excited orator, mounted on a stool, was addressing an excited</li>
<li class="L10635" rel="L10635">audience on the crimes against the people, of the king and the royal</li>
<li class="L10636" rel="L10636">family. The few words that he caught from this man&#39;s lips, first made</li>
<li class="L10637" rel="L10637">it known to Charles Darnay that the king was in prison, and that the</li>
<li class="L10638" rel="L10638">foreign ambassadors had one and all left Paris. On the road (except at</li>
<li class="L10639" rel="L10639">Beauvais) he had heard absolutely nothing. The escort and the universal</li>
<li class="L10640" rel="L10640">watchfulness had completely isolated him.</li>
<li class="L10641" rel="L10641"></li>
<li class="L10642" rel="L10642">That he had fallen among far greater dangers than those which had</li>
<li class="L10643" rel="L10643">developed themselves when he left England, he of course knew now. That</li>
<li class="L10644" rel="L10644">perils had thickened about him fast, and might thicken faster and faster</li>
<li class="L10645" rel="L10645">yet, he of course knew now. He could not but admit to himself that he</li>
<li class="L10646" rel="L10646">might not have made this journey, if he could have foreseen the events</li>
<li class="L10647" rel="L10647">of a few days. And yet his misgivings were not so dark as, imagined by</li>
<li class="L10648" rel="L10648">the light of this later time, they would appear. Troubled as the future</li>
<li class="L10649" rel="L10649">was, it was the unknown future, and in its obscurity there was ignorant</li>
<li class="L10650" rel="L10650">hope. The horrible massacre, days and nights long, which, within a few</li>
<li class="L10651" rel="L10651">rounds of the clock, was to set a great mark of blood upon the blessed</li>
<li class="L10652" rel="L10652">garnering time of harvest, was as far out of his knowledge as if it had</li>
<li class="L10653" rel="L10653">been a hundred thousand years away. The “sharp female newly-born, and</li>
<li class="L10654" rel="L10654">called La Guillotine,” was hardly known to him, or to the generality</li>
<li class="L10655" rel="L10655">of people, by name. The frightful deeds that were to be soon done, were</li>
<li class="L10656" rel="L10656">probably unimagined at that time in the brains of the doers. How could</li>
<li class="L10657" rel="L10657">they have a place in the shadowy conceptions of a gentle mind?</li>
<li class="L10658" rel="L10658"></li>
<li class="L10659" rel="L10659">Of unjust treatment in detention and hardship, and in cruel separation</li>
<li class="L10660" rel="L10660">from his wife and child, he foreshadowed the likelihood, or the</li>
<li class="L10661" rel="L10661">certainty; but, beyond this, he dreaded nothing distinctly. With this on</li>
<li class="L10662" rel="L10662">his mind, which was enough to carry into a dreary prison courtyard, he</li>
<li class="L10663" rel="L10663">arrived at the prison of La Force.</li>
<li class="L10664" rel="L10664"></li>
<li class="L10665" rel="L10665">A man with a bloated face opened the strong wicket, to whom Defarge</li>
<li class="L10666" rel="L10666">presented “The Emigrant Evremonde.”</li>
<li class="L10667" rel="L10667"></li>
<li class="L10668" rel="L10668">“What the Devil! How many more of them!” exclaimed the man with the</li>
<li class="L10669" rel="L10669">bloated face.</li>
<li class="L10670" rel="L10670"></li>
<li class="L10671" rel="L10671">Defarge took his receipt without noticing the exclamation, and withdrew,</li>
<li class="L10672" rel="L10672">with his two fellow-patriots.</li>
<li class="L10673" rel="L10673"></li>
<li class="L10674" rel="L10674">“What the Devil, I say again!” exclaimed the gaoler, left with his wife.</li>
<li class="L10675" rel="L10675">“How many more!”</li>
<li class="L10676" rel="L10676"></li>
<li class="L10677" rel="L10677">The gaoler&#39;s wife, being provided with no answer to the question, merely</li>
<li class="L10678" rel="L10678">replied, “One must have patience, my dear!” Three turnkeys who entered</li>
<li class="L10679" rel="L10679">responsive to a bell she rang, echoed the sentiment, and one added, “For</li>
<li class="L10680" rel="L10680">the love of Liberty;” which sounded in that place like an inappropriate</li>
<li class="L10681" rel="L10681">conclusion.</li>
<li class="L10682" rel="L10682"></li>
<li class="L10683" rel="L10683">The prison of La Force was a gloomy prison, dark and filthy, and with a</li>
<li class="L10684" rel="L10684">horrible smell of foul sleep in it. Extraordinary how soon the noisome</li>
<li class="L10685" rel="L10685">flavour of imprisoned sleep, becomes manifest in all such places that</li>
<li class="L10686" rel="L10686">are ill cared for!</li>
<li class="L10687" rel="L10687"></li>
<li class="L10688" rel="L10688">“In secret, too,” grumbled the gaoler, looking at the written paper. “As</li>
<li class="L10689" rel="L10689">if I was not already full to bursting!”</li>
<li class="L10690" rel="L10690"></li>
<li class="L10691" rel="L10691">He stuck the paper on a file, in an ill-humour, and Charles Darnay</li>
<li class="L10692" rel="L10692">awaited his further pleasure for half an hour: sometimes, pacing to and</li>
<li class="L10693" rel="L10693">fro in the strong arched room: sometimes, resting on a stone seat: in</li>
<li class="L10694" rel="L10694">either case detained to be imprinted on the memory of the chief and his</li>
<li class="L10695" rel="L10695">subordinates.</li>
<li class="L10696" rel="L10696"></li>
<li class="L10697" rel="L10697">“Come!” said the chief, at length taking up his keys, “come with me,</li>
<li class="L10698" rel="L10698">emigrant.”</li>
<li class="L10699" rel="L10699"></li>
<li class="L10700" rel="L10700">Through the dismal prison twilight, his new charge accompanied him by</li>
<li class="L10701" rel="L10701">corridor and staircase, many doors clanging and locking behind them,</li>
<li class="L10702" rel="L10702">until they came into a large, low, vaulted chamber, crowded with</li>
<li class="L10703" rel="L10703">prisoners of both sexes. The women were seated at a long table, reading</li>
<li class="L10704" rel="L10704">and writing, knitting, sewing, and embroidering; the men were for the</li>
<li class="L10705" rel="L10705">most part standing behind their chairs, or lingering up and down the</li>
<li class="L10706" rel="L10706">room.</li>
<li class="L10707" rel="L10707"></li>
<li class="L10708" rel="L10708">In the instinctive association of prisoners with shameful crime and</li>
<li class="L10709" rel="L10709">disgrace, the new-comer recoiled from this company. But the crowning</li>
<li class="L10710" rel="L10710">unreality of his long unreal ride, was, their all at once rising to</li>
<li class="L10711" rel="L10711">receive him, with every refinement of manner known to the time, and with</li>
<li class="L10712" rel="L10712">all the engaging graces and courtesies of life.</li>
<li class="L10713" rel="L10713"></li>
<li class="L10714" rel="L10714">So strangely clouded were these refinements by the prison manners and</li>
<li class="L10715" rel="L10715">gloom, so spectral did they become in the inappropriate squalor and</li>
<li class="L10716" rel="L10716">misery through which they were seen, that Charles Darnay seemed to stand</li>
<li class="L10717" rel="L10717">in a company of the dead. Ghosts all! The ghost of beauty, the ghost</li>
<li class="L10718" rel="L10718">of stateliness, the ghost of elegance, the ghost of pride, the ghost of</li>
<li class="L10719" rel="L10719">frivolity, the ghost of wit, the ghost of youth, the ghost of age, all</li>
<li class="L10720" rel="L10720">waiting their dismissal from the desolate shore, all turning on him eyes</li>
<li class="L10721" rel="L10721">that were changed by the death they had died in coming there.</li>
<li class="L10722" rel="L10722"></li>
<li class="L10723" rel="L10723">It struck him motionless. The gaoler standing at his side, and the other</li>
<li class="L10724" rel="L10724">gaolers moving about, who would have been well enough as to appearance</li>
<li class="L10725" rel="L10725">in the ordinary exercise of their functions, looked so extravagantly</li>
<li class="L10726" rel="L10726">coarse contrasted with sorrowing mothers and blooming daughters who were</li>
<li class="L10727" rel="L10727">there--with the apparitions of the coquette, the young beauty, and the</li>
<li class="L10728" rel="L10728">mature woman delicately bred--that the inversion of all experience and</li>
<li class="L10729" rel="L10729">likelihood which the scene of shadows presented, was heightened to its</li>
<li class="L10730" rel="L10730">utmost. Surely, ghosts all. Surely, the long unreal ride some progress</li>
<li class="L10731" rel="L10731">of disease that had brought him to these gloomy shades!</li>
<li class="L10732" rel="L10732"></li>
<li class="L10733" rel="L10733">“In the name of the assembled companions in misfortune,” said a</li>
<li class="L10734" rel="L10734">gentleman of courtly appearance and address, coming forward, “I have the</li>
<li class="L10735" rel="L10735">honour of giving you welcome to La Force, and of condoling with you</li>
<li class="L10736" rel="L10736">on the calamity that has brought you among us. May it soon terminate</li>
<li class="L10737" rel="L10737">happily! It would be an impertinence elsewhere, but it is not so here,</li>
<li class="L10738" rel="L10738">to ask your name and condition?”</li>
<li class="L10739" rel="L10739"></li>
<li class="L10740" rel="L10740">Charles Darnay roused himself, and gave the required information, in</li>
<li class="L10741" rel="L10741">words as suitable as he could find.</li>
<li class="L10742" rel="L10742"></li>
<li class="L10743" rel="L10743">“But I hope,” said the gentleman, following the chief gaoler with his</li>
<li class="L10744" rel="L10744">eyes, who moved across the room, “that you are not in secret?”</li>
<li class="L10745" rel="L10745"></li>
<li class="L10746" rel="L10746">“I do not understand the meaning of the term, but I have heard them say</li>
<li class="L10747" rel="L10747">so.”</li>
<li class="L10748" rel="L10748"></li>
<li class="L10749" rel="L10749">“Ah, what a pity! We so much regret it! But take courage; several</li>
<li class="L10750" rel="L10750">members of our society have been in secret, at first, and it has lasted</li>
<li class="L10751" rel="L10751">but a short time.” Then he added, raising his voice, “I grieve to inform</li>
<li class="L10752" rel="L10752">the society--in secret.”</li>
<li class="L10753" rel="L10753"></li>
<li class="L10754" rel="L10754">There was a murmur of commiseration as Charles Darnay crossed the room</li>
<li class="L10755" rel="L10755">to a grated door where the gaoler awaited him, and many voices--among</li>
<li class="L10756" rel="L10756">which, the soft and compassionate voices of women were conspicuous--gave</li>
<li class="L10757" rel="L10757">him good wishes and encouragement. He turned at the grated door, to</li>
<li class="L10758" rel="L10758">render the thanks of his heart; it closed under the gaoler&#39;s hand; and</li>
<li class="L10759" rel="L10759">the apparitions vanished from his sight forever.</li>
<li class="L10760" rel="L10760"></li>
<li class="L10761" rel="L10761">The wicket opened on a stone staircase, leading upward. When they had</li>
<li class="L10762" rel="L10762">ascended forty steps (the prisoner of half an hour already counted</li>
<li class="L10763" rel="L10763">them), the gaoler opened a low black door, and they passed into a</li>
<li class="L10764" rel="L10764">solitary cell. It struck cold and damp, but was not dark.</li>
<li class="L10765" rel="L10765"></li>
<li class="L10766" rel="L10766">“Yours,” said the gaoler.</li>
<li class="L10767" rel="L10767"></li>
<li class="L10768" rel="L10768">“Why am I confined alone?”</li>
<li class="L10769" rel="L10769"></li>
<li class="L10770" rel="L10770">“How do I know!”</li>
<li class="L10771" rel="L10771"></li>
<li class="L10772" rel="L10772">“I can buy pen, ink, and paper?”</li>
<li class="L10773" rel="L10773"></li>
<li class="L10774" rel="L10774">“Such are not my orders. You will be visited, and can ask then. At</li>
<li class="L10775" rel="L10775">present, you may buy your food, and nothing more.”</li>
<li class="L10776" rel="L10776"></li>
<li class="L10777" rel="L10777">There were in the cell, a chair, a table, and a straw mattress. As</li>
<li class="L10778" rel="L10778">the gaoler made a general inspection of these objects, and of the four</li>
<li class="L10779" rel="L10779">walls, before going out, a wandering fancy wandered through the mind of</li>
<li class="L10780" rel="L10780">the prisoner leaning against the wall opposite to him, that this gaoler</li>
<li class="L10781" rel="L10781">was so unwholesomely bloated, both in face and person, as to look like</li>
<li class="L10782" rel="L10782">a man who had been drowned and filled with water. When the gaoler was</li>
<li class="L10783" rel="L10783">gone, he thought in the same wandering way, “Now am I left, as if I were</li>
<li class="L10784" rel="L10784">dead.” Stopping then, to look down at the mattress, he turned from it</li>
<li class="L10785" rel="L10785">with a sick feeling, and thought, “And here in these crawling creatures</li>
<li class="L10786" rel="L10786">is the first condition of the body after death.”</li>
<li class="L10787" rel="L10787"></li>
<li class="L10788" rel="L10788">“Five paces by four and a half, five paces by four and a half, five</li>
<li class="L10789" rel="L10789">paces by four and a half.” The prisoner walked to and fro in his cell,</li>
<li class="L10790" rel="L10790">counting its measurement, and the roar of the city arose like muffled</li>
<li class="L10791" rel="L10791">drums with a wild swell of voices added to them. “He made shoes, he made</li>
<li class="L10792" rel="L10792">shoes, he made shoes.” The prisoner counted the measurement again, and</li>
<li class="L10793" rel="L10793">paced faster, to draw his mind with him from that latter repetition.</li>
<li class="L10794" rel="L10794">“The ghosts that vanished when the wicket closed. There was one among</li>
<li class="L10795" rel="L10795">them, the appearance of a lady dressed in black, who was leaning in the</li>
<li class="L10796" rel="L10796">embrasure of a window, and she had a light shining upon her golden</li>
<li class="L10797" rel="L10797">hair, and she looked like * * * * Let us ride on again, for God&#39;s sake,</li>
<li class="L10798" rel="L10798">through the illuminated villages with the people all awake! * * * * He</li>
<li class="L10799" rel="L10799">made shoes, he made shoes, he made shoes. * * * * Five paces by four and</li>
<li class="L10800" rel="L10800">a half.” With such scraps tossing and rolling upward from the depths of</li>
<li class="L10801" rel="L10801">his mind, the prisoner walked faster and faster, obstinately counting</li>
<li class="L10802" rel="L10802">and counting; and the roar of the city changed to this extent--that it</li>
<li class="L10803" rel="L10803">still rolled in like muffled drums, but with the wail of voices that he</li>
<li class="L10804" rel="L10804">knew, in the swell that rose above them.</li>
<li class="L10805" rel="L10805"></li>
<li class="L10806" rel="L10806"></li>
<li class="L10807" rel="L10807"></li>
<li class="L10808" rel="L10808"></li>
<li class="L10809" rel="L10809">II. The Grindstone</li>
<li class="L10810" rel="L10810"></li>
<li class="L10811" rel="L10811"></li>
<li class="L10812" rel="L10812">Tellson&#39;s Bank, established in the Saint Germain Quarter of Paris, was</li>
<li class="L10813" rel="L10813">in a wing of a large house, approached by a courtyard and shut off from</li>
<li class="L10814" rel="L10814">the street by a high wall and a strong gate. The house belonged to</li>
<li class="L10815" rel="L10815">a great nobleman who had lived in it until he made a flight from the</li>
<li class="L10816" rel="L10816">troubles, in his own cook&#39;s dress, and got across the borders. A</li>
<li class="L10817" rel="L10817">mere beast of the chase flying from hunters, he was still in his</li>
<li class="L10818" rel="L10818">metempsychosis no other than the same Monseigneur, the preparation</li>
<li class="L10819" rel="L10819">of whose chocolate for whose lips had once occupied three strong men</li>
<li class="L10820" rel="L10820">besides the cook in question.</li>
<li class="L10821" rel="L10821"></li>
<li class="L10822" rel="L10822">Monseigneur gone, and the three strong men absolving themselves from the</li>
<li class="L10823" rel="L10823">sin of having drawn his high wages, by being more than ready and</li>
<li class="L10824" rel="L10824">willing to cut his throat on the altar of the dawning Republic one and</li>
<li class="L10825" rel="L10825">indivisible of Liberty, Equality, Fraternity, or Death, Monseigneur&#39;s</li>
<li class="L10826" rel="L10826">house had been first sequestrated, and then confiscated. For, all</li>
<li class="L10827" rel="L10827">things moved so fast, and decree followed decree with that fierce</li>
<li class="L10828" rel="L10828">precipitation, that now upon the third night of the autumn month</li>
<li class="L10829" rel="L10829">of September, patriot emissaries of the law were in possession of</li>
<li class="L10830" rel="L10830">Monseigneur&#39;s house, and had marked it with the tri-colour, and were</li>
<li class="L10831" rel="L10831">drinking brandy in its state apartments.</li>
<li class="L10832" rel="L10832"></li>
<li class="L10833" rel="L10833">A place of business in London like Tellson&#39;s place of business in Paris,</li>
<li class="L10834" rel="L10834">would soon have driven the House out of its mind and into the Gazette.</li>
<li class="L10835" rel="L10835">For, what would staid British responsibility and respectability have</li>
<li class="L10836" rel="L10836">said to orange-trees in boxes in a Bank courtyard, and even to a Cupid</li>
<li class="L10837" rel="L10837">over the counter? Yet such things were. Tellson&#39;s had whitewashed the</li>
<li class="L10838" rel="L10838">Cupid, but he was still to be seen on the ceiling, in the coolest</li>
<li class="L10839" rel="L10839">linen, aiming (as he very often does) at money from morning to</li>
<li class="L10840" rel="L10840">night. Bankruptcy must inevitably have come of this young Pagan, in</li>
<li class="L10841" rel="L10841">Lombard-street, London, and also of a curtained alcove in the rear of</li>
<li class="L10842" rel="L10842">the immortal boy, and also of a looking-glass let into the wall, and</li>
<li class="L10843" rel="L10843">also of clerks not at all old, who danced in public on the slightest</li>
<li class="L10844" rel="L10844">provocation. Yet, a French Tellson&#39;s could get on with these things</li>
<li class="L10845" rel="L10845">exceedingly well, and, as long as the times held together, no man had</li>
<li class="L10846" rel="L10846">taken fright at them, and drawn out his money.</li>
<li class="L10847" rel="L10847"></li>
<li class="L10848" rel="L10848">What money would be drawn out of Tellson&#39;s henceforth, and what would</li>
<li class="L10849" rel="L10849">lie there, lost and forgotten; what plate and jewels would tarnish in</li>
<li class="L10850" rel="L10850">Tellson&#39;s hiding-places, while the depositors rusted in prisons,</li>
<li class="L10851" rel="L10851">and when they should have violently perished; how many accounts with</li>
<li class="L10852" rel="L10852">Tellson&#39;s never to be balanced in this world, must be carried over into</li>
<li class="L10853" rel="L10853">the next; no man could have said, that night, any more than Mr. Jarvis</li>
<li class="L10854" rel="L10854">Lorry could, though he thought heavily of these questions. He sat by</li>
<li class="L10855" rel="L10855">a newly-lighted wood fire (the blighted and unfruitful year was</li>
<li class="L10856" rel="L10856">prematurely cold), and on his honest and courageous face there was a</li>
<li class="L10857" rel="L10857">deeper shade than the pendent lamp could throw, or any object in the</li>
<li class="L10858" rel="L10858">room distortedly reflect--a shade of horror.</li>
<li class="L10859" rel="L10859"></li>
<li class="L10860" rel="L10860">He occupied rooms in the Bank, in his fidelity to the House of which</li>
<li class="L10861" rel="L10861">he had grown to be a part, like strong root-ivy. It chanced that they</li>
<li class="L10862" rel="L10862">derived a kind of security from the patriotic occupation of the main</li>
<li class="L10863" rel="L10863">building, but the true-hearted old gentleman never calculated about</li>
<li class="L10864" rel="L10864">that. All such circumstances were indifferent to him, so that he did</li>
<li class="L10865" rel="L10865">his duty. On the opposite side of the courtyard, under a colonnade,</li>
<li class="L10866" rel="L10866">was extensive standing--for carriages--where, indeed, some carriages</li>
<li class="L10867" rel="L10867">of Monseigneur yet stood. Against two of the pillars were fastened two</li>
<li class="L10868" rel="L10868">great flaring flambeaux, and in the light of these, standing out in the</li>
<li class="L10869" rel="L10869">open air, was a large grindstone: a roughly mounted thing which appeared</li>
<li class="L10870" rel="L10870">to have hurriedly been brought there from some neighbouring smithy,</li>
<li class="L10871" rel="L10871">or other workshop. Rising and looking out of window at these harmless</li>
<li class="L10872" rel="L10872">objects, Mr. Lorry shivered, and retired to his seat by the fire. He had</li>
<li class="L10873" rel="L10873">opened, not only the glass window, but the lattice blind outside it, and</li>
<li class="L10874" rel="L10874">he had closed both again, and he shivered through his frame.</li>
<li class="L10875" rel="L10875"></li>
<li class="L10876" rel="L10876">From the streets beyond the high wall and the strong gate, there came</li>
<li class="L10877" rel="L10877">the usual night hum of the city, with now and then an indescribable ring</li>
<li class="L10878" rel="L10878">in it, weird and unearthly, as if some unwonted sounds of a terrible</li>
<li class="L10879" rel="L10879">nature were going up to Heaven.</li>
<li class="L10880" rel="L10880"></li>
<li class="L10881" rel="L10881">“Thank God,” said Mr. Lorry, clasping his hands, “that no one near and</li>
<li class="L10882" rel="L10882">dear to me is in this dreadful town to-night. May He have mercy on all</li>
<li class="L10883" rel="L10883">who are in danger!”</li>
<li class="L10884" rel="L10884"></li>
<li class="L10885" rel="L10885">Soon afterwards, the bell at the great gate sounded, and he thought,</li>
<li class="L10886" rel="L10886">“They have come back!” and sat listening. But, there was no loud</li>
<li class="L10887" rel="L10887">irruption into the courtyard, as he had expected, and he heard the gate</li>
<li class="L10888" rel="L10888">clash again, and all was quiet.</li>
<li class="L10889" rel="L10889"></li>
<li class="L10890" rel="L10890">The nervousness and dread that were upon him inspired that vague</li>
<li class="L10891" rel="L10891">uneasiness respecting the Bank, which a great change would naturally</li>
<li class="L10892" rel="L10892">awaken, with such feelings roused. It was well guarded, and he got up to</li>
<li class="L10893" rel="L10893">go among the trusty people who were watching it, when his door suddenly</li>
<li class="L10894" rel="L10894">opened, and two figures rushed in, at sight of which he fell back in</li>
<li class="L10895" rel="L10895">amazement.</li>
<li class="L10896" rel="L10896"></li>
<li class="L10897" rel="L10897">Lucie and her father! Lucie with her arms stretched out to him, and with</li>
<li class="L10898" rel="L10898">that old look of earnestness so concentrated and intensified, that it</li>
<li class="L10899" rel="L10899">seemed as though it had been stamped upon her face expressly to give</li>
<li class="L10900" rel="L10900">force and power to it in this one passage of her life.</li>
<li class="L10901" rel="L10901"></li>
<li class="L10902" rel="L10902">“What is this?” cried Mr. Lorry, breathless and confused. “What is the</li>
<li class="L10903" rel="L10903">matter? Lucie! Manette! What has happened? What has brought you here?</li>
<li class="L10904" rel="L10904">What is it?”</li>
<li class="L10905" rel="L10905"></li>
<li class="L10906" rel="L10906">With the look fixed upon him, in her paleness and wildness, she panted</li>
<li class="L10907" rel="L10907">out in his arms, imploringly, “O my dear friend! My husband!”</li>
<li class="L10908" rel="L10908"></li>
<li class="L10909" rel="L10909">“Your husband, Lucie?”</li>
<li class="L10910" rel="L10910"></li>
<li class="L10911" rel="L10911">“Charles.”</li>
<li class="L10912" rel="L10912"></li>
<li class="L10913" rel="L10913">“What of Charles?”</li>
<li class="L10914" rel="L10914"></li>
<li class="L10915" rel="L10915">“Here.</li>
<li class="L10916" rel="L10916"></li>
<li class="L10917" rel="L10917">“Here, in Paris?”</li>
<li class="L10918" rel="L10918"></li>
<li class="L10919" rel="L10919">“Has been here some days--three or four--I don&#39;t know how many--I can&#39;t</li>
<li class="L10920" rel="L10920">collect my thoughts. An errand of generosity brought him here unknown to</li>
<li class="L10921" rel="L10921">us; he was stopped at the barrier, and sent to prison.”</li>
<li class="L10922" rel="L10922"></li>
<li class="L10923" rel="L10923">The old man uttered an irrepressible cry. Almost at the same moment, the</li>
<li class="L10924" rel="L10924">bell of the great gate rang again, and a loud noise of feet and voices</li>
<li class="L10925" rel="L10925">came pouring into the courtyard.</li>
<li class="L10926" rel="L10926"></li>
<li class="L10927" rel="L10927">“What is that noise?” said the Doctor, turning towards the window.</li>
<li class="L10928" rel="L10928"></li>
<li class="L10929" rel="L10929">“Don&#39;t look!” cried Mr. Lorry. “Don&#39;t look out! Manette, for your life,</li>
<li class="L10930" rel="L10930">don&#39;t touch the blind!”</li>
<li class="L10931" rel="L10931"></li>
<li class="L10932" rel="L10932">The Doctor turned, with his hand upon the fastening of the window, and</li>
<li class="L10933" rel="L10933">said, with a cool, bold smile:</li>
<li class="L10934" rel="L10934"></li>
<li class="L10935" rel="L10935">“My dear friend, I have a charmed life in this city. I have been</li>
<li class="L10936" rel="L10936">a Bastille prisoner. There is no patriot in Paris--in Paris? In</li>
<li class="L10937" rel="L10937">France--who, knowing me to have been a prisoner in the Bastille, would</li>
<li class="L10938" rel="L10938">touch me, except to overwhelm me with embraces, or carry me in triumph.</li>
<li class="L10939" rel="L10939">My old pain has given me a power that has brought us through the</li>
<li class="L10940" rel="L10940">barrier, and gained us news of Charles there, and brought us here. I</li>
<li class="L10941" rel="L10941">knew it would be so; I knew I could help Charles out of all danger; I</li>
<li class="L10942" rel="L10942">told Lucie so.--What is that noise?” His hand was again upon the window.</li>
<li class="L10943" rel="L10943"></li>
<li class="L10944" rel="L10944">“Don&#39;t look!” cried Mr. Lorry, absolutely desperate. “No, Lucie, my</li>
<li class="L10945" rel="L10945">dear, nor you!” He got his arm round her, and held her. “Don&#39;t be so</li>
<li class="L10946" rel="L10946">terrified, my love. I solemnly swear to you that I know of no harm</li>
<li class="L10947" rel="L10947">having happened to Charles; that I had no suspicion even of his being in</li>
<li class="L10948" rel="L10948">this fatal place. What prison is he in?”</li>
<li class="L10949" rel="L10949"></li>
<li class="L10950" rel="L10950">“La Force!”</li>
<li class="L10951" rel="L10951"></li>
<li class="L10952" rel="L10952">“La Force! Lucie, my child, if ever you were brave and serviceable in</li>
<li class="L10953" rel="L10953">your life--and you were always both--you will compose yourself now, to</li>
<li class="L10954" rel="L10954">do exactly as I bid you; for more depends upon it than you can think, or</li>
<li class="L10955" rel="L10955">I can say. There is no help for you in any action on your part to-night;</li>
<li class="L10956" rel="L10956">you cannot possibly stir out. I say this, because what I must bid you</li>
<li class="L10957" rel="L10957">to do for Charles&#39;s sake, is the hardest thing to do of all. You must</li>
<li class="L10958" rel="L10958">instantly be obedient, still, and quiet. You must let me put you in a</li>
<li class="L10959" rel="L10959">room at the back here. You must leave your father and me alone for</li>
<li class="L10960" rel="L10960">two minutes, and as there are Life and Death in the world you must not</li>
<li class="L10961" rel="L10961">delay.”</li>
<li class="L10962" rel="L10962"></li>
<li class="L10963" rel="L10963">“I will be submissive to you. I see in your face that you know I can do</li>
<li class="L10964" rel="L10964">nothing else than this. I know you are true.”</li>
<li class="L10965" rel="L10965"></li>
<li class="L10966" rel="L10966">The old man kissed her, and hurried her into his room, and turned the</li>
<li class="L10967" rel="L10967">key; then, came hurrying back to the Doctor, and opened the window and</li>
<li class="L10968" rel="L10968">partly opened the blind, and put his hand upon the Doctor&#39;s arm, and</li>
<li class="L10969" rel="L10969">looked out with him into the courtyard.</li>
<li class="L10970" rel="L10970"></li>
<li class="L10971" rel="L10971">Looked out upon a throng of men and women: not enough in number, or near</li>
<li class="L10972" rel="L10972">enough, to fill the courtyard: not more than forty or fifty in all. The</li>
<li class="L10973" rel="L10973">people in possession of the house had let them in at the gate, and they</li>
<li class="L10974" rel="L10974">had rushed in to work at the grindstone; it had evidently been set up</li>
<li class="L10975" rel="L10975">there for their purpose, as in a convenient and retired spot.</li>
<li class="L10976" rel="L10976"></li>
<li class="L10977" rel="L10977">But, such awful workers, and such awful work!</li>
<li class="L10978" rel="L10978"></li>
<li class="L10979" rel="L10979">The grindstone had a double handle, and, turning at it madly were two</li>
<li class="L10980" rel="L10980">men, whose faces, as their long hair flapped back when the whirlings of</li>
<li class="L10981" rel="L10981">the grindstone brought their faces up, were more horrible and cruel than</li>
<li class="L10982" rel="L10982">the visages of the wildest savages in their most barbarous disguise.</li>
<li class="L10983" rel="L10983">False eyebrows and false moustaches were stuck upon them, and their</li>
<li class="L10984" rel="L10984">hideous countenances were all bloody and sweaty, and all awry with</li>
<li class="L10985" rel="L10985">howling, and all staring and glaring with beastly excitement and want of</li>
<li class="L10986" rel="L10986">sleep. As these ruffians turned and turned, their matted locks now flung</li>
<li class="L10987" rel="L10987">forward over their eyes, now flung backward over their necks, some women</li>
<li class="L10988" rel="L10988">held wine to their mouths that they might drink; and what with dropping</li>
<li class="L10989" rel="L10989">blood, and what with dropping wine, and what with the stream of sparks</li>
<li class="L10990" rel="L10990">struck out of the stone, all their wicked atmosphere seemed gore and</li>
<li class="L10991" rel="L10991">fire. The eye could not detect one creature in the group free from</li>
<li class="L10992" rel="L10992">the smear of blood. Shouldering one another to get next at the</li>
<li class="L10993" rel="L10993">sharpening-stone, were men stripped to the waist, with the stain all</li>
<li class="L10994" rel="L10994">over their limbs and bodies; men in all sorts of rags, with the stain</li>
<li class="L10995" rel="L10995">upon those rags; men devilishly set off with spoils of women&#39;s lace</li>
<li class="L10996" rel="L10996">and silk and ribbon, with the stain dyeing those trifles through</li>
<li class="L10997" rel="L10997">and through. Hatchets, knives, bayonets, swords, all brought to be</li>
<li class="L10998" rel="L10998">sharpened, were all red with it. Some of the hacked swords were tied to</li>
<li class="L10999" rel="L10999">the wrists of those who carried them, with strips of linen and fragments</li>
<li class="L11000" rel="L11000">of dress: ligatures various in kind, but all deep of the one colour. And</li>
<li class="L11001" rel="L11001">as the frantic wielders of these weapons snatched them from the stream</li>
<li class="L11002" rel="L11002">of sparks and tore away into the streets, the same red hue was red in</li>
<li class="L11003" rel="L11003">their frenzied eyes;--eyes which any unbrutalised beholder would have</li>
<li class="L11004" rel="L11004">given twenty years of life, to petrify with a well-directed gun.</li>
<li class="L11005" rel="L11005"></li>
<li class="L11006" rel="L11006">All this was seen in a moment, as the vision of a drowning man, or of</li>
<li class="L11007" rel="L11007">any human creature at any very great pass, could see a world if it</li>
<li class="L11008" rel="L11008">were there. They drew back from the window, and the Doctor looked for</li>
<li class="L11009" rel="L11009">explanation in his friend&#39;s ashy face.</li>
<li class="L11010" rel="L11010"></li>
<li class="L11011" rel="L11011">“They are,” Mr. Lorry whispered the words, glancing fearfully round at</li>
<li class="L11012" rel="L11012">the locked room, “murdering the prisoners. If you are sure of what you</li>
<li class="L11013" rel="L11013">say; if you really have the power you think you have--as I believe you</li>
<li class="L11014" rel="L11014">have--make yourself known to these devils, and get taken to La Force. It</li>
<li class="L11015" rel="L11015">may be too late, I don&#39;t know, but let it not be a minute later!”</li>
<li class="L11016" rel="L11016"></li>
<li class="L11017" rel="L11017">Doctor Manette pressed his hand, hastened bareheaded out of the room,</li>
<li class="L11018" rel="L11018">and was in the courtyard when Mr. Lorry regained the blind.</li>
<li class="L11019" rel="L11019"></li>
<li class="L11020" rel="L11020">His streaming white hair, his remarkable face, and the impetuous</li>
<li class="L11021" rel="L11021">confidence of his manner, as he put the weapons aside like water,</li>
<li class="L11022" rel="L11022">carried him in an instant to the heart of the concourse at the stone.</li>
<li class="L11023" rel="L11023">For a few moments there was a pause, and a hurry, and a murmur, and</li>
<li class="L11024" rel="L11024">the unintelligible sound of his voice; and then Mr. Lorry saw him,</li>
<li class="L11025" rel="L11025">surrounded by all, and in the midst of a line of twenty men long, all</li>
<li class="L11026" rel="L11026">linked shoulder to shoulder, and hand to shoulder, hurried out with</li>
<li class="L11027" rel="L11027">cries of--“Live the Bastille prisoner! Help for the Bastille prisoner&#39;s</li>
<li class="L11028" rel="L11028">kindred in La Force! Room for the Bastille prisoner in front there! Save</li>
<li class="L11029" rel="L11029">the prisoner Evremonde at La Force!” and a thousand answering shouts.</li>
<li class="L11030" rel="L11030"></li>
<li class="L11031" rel="L11031">He closed the lattice again with a fluttering heart, closed the window</li>
<li class="L11032" rel="L11032">and the curtain, hastened to Lucie, and told her that her father was</li>
<li class="L11033" rel="L11033">assisted by the people, and gone in search of her husband. He found</li>
<li class="L11034" rel="L11034">her child and Miss Pross with her; but, it never occurred to him to be</li>
<li class="L11035" rel="L11035">surprised by their appearance until a long time afterwards, when he sat</li>
<li class="L11036" rel="L11036">watching them in such quiet as the night knew.</li>
<li class="L11037" rel="L11037"></li>
<li class="L11038" rel="L11038">Lucie had, by that time, fallen into a stupor on the floor at his feet,</li>
<li class="L11039" rel="L11039">clinging to his hand. Miss Pross had laid the child down on his own</li>
<li class="L11040" rel="L11040">bed, and her head had gradually fallen on the pillow beside her pretty</li>
<li class="L11041" rel="L11041">charge. O the long, long night, with the moans of the poor wife! And O</li>
<li class="L11042" rel="L11042">the long, long night, with no return of her father and no tidings!</li>
<li class="L11043" rel="L11043"></li>
<li class="L11044" rel="L11044">Twice more in the darkness the bell at the great gate sounded, and the</li>
<li class="L11045" rel="L11045">irruption was repeated, and the grindstone whirled and spluttered.</li>
<li class="L11046" rel="L11046">“What is it?” cried Lucie, affrighted. “Hush! The soldiers&#39; swords are</li>
<li class="L11047" rel="L11047">sharpened there,” said Mr. Lorry. “The place is national property now,</li>
<li class="L11048" rel="L11048">and used as a kind of armoury, my love.”</li>
<li class="L11049" rel="L11049"></li>
<li class="L11050" rel="L11050">Twice more in all; but, the last spell of work was feeble and fitful.</li>
<li class="L11051" rel="L11051">Soon afterwards the day began to dawn, and he softly detached himself</li>
<li class="L11052" rel="L11052">from the clasping hand, and cautiously looked out again. A man, so</li>
<li class="L11053" rel="L11053">besmeared that he might have been a sorely wounded soldier creeping back</li>
<li class="L11054" rel="L11054">to consciousness on a field of slain, was rising from the pavement by</li>
<li class="L11055" rel="L11055">the side of the grindstone, and looking about him with a vacant air.</li>
<li class="L11056" rel="L11056">Shortly, this worn-out murderer descried in the imperfect light one of</li>
<li class="L11057" rel="L11057">the carriages of Monseigneur, and, staggering to that gorgeous vehicle,</li>
<li class="L11058" rel="L11058">climbed in at the door, and shut himself up to take his rest on its</li>
<li class="L11059" rel="L11059">dainty cushions.</li>
<li class="L11060" rel="L11060"></li>
<li class="L11061" rel="L11061">The great grindstone, Earth, had turned when Mr. Lorry looked out again,</li>
<li class="L11062" rel="L11062">and the sun was red on the courtyard. But, the lesser grindstone stood</li>
<li class="L11063" rel="L11063">alone there in the calm morning air, with a red upon it that the sun had</li>
<li class="L11064" rel="L11064">never given, and would never take away.</li>
<li class="L11065" rel="L11065"></li>
<li class="L11066" rel="L11066"></li>
<li class="L11067" rel="L11067"></li>
<li class="L11068" rel="L11068"></li>
<li class="L11069" rel="L11069">III. The Shadow</li>
<li class="L11070" rel="L11070"></li>
<li class="L11071" rel="L11071"></li>
<li class="L11072" rel="L11072">One of the first considerations which arose in the business mind of Mr.</li>
<li class="L11073" rel="L11073">Lorry when business hours came round, was this:--that he had no right to</li>
<li class="L11074" rel="L11074">imperil Tellson&#39;s by sheltering the wife of an emigrant prisoner under</li>
<li class="L11075" rel="L11075">the Bank roof. His own possessions, safety, life, he would have hazarded</li>
<li class="L11076" rel="L11076">for Lucie and her child, without a moment&#39;s demur; but the great trust</li>
<li class="L11077" rel="L11077">he held was not his own, and as to that business charge he was a strict</li>
<li class="L11078" rel="L11078">man of business.</li>
<li class="L11079" rel="L11079"></li>
<li class="L11080" rel="L11080">At first, his mind reverted to Defarge, and he thought of finding out</li>
<li class="L11081" rel="L11081">the wine-shop again and taking counsel with its master in reference to</li>
<li class="L11082" rel="L11082">the safest dwelling-place in the distracted state of the city. But, the</li>
<li class="L11083" rel="L11083">same consideration that suggested him, repudiated him; he lived in the</li>
<li class="L11084" rel="L11084">most violent Quarter, and doubtless was influential there, and deep in</li>
<li class="L11085" rel="L11085">its dangerous workings.</li>
<li class="L11086" rel="L11086"></li>
<li class="L11087" rel="L11087">Noon coming, and the Doctor not returning, and every minute&#39;s delay</li>
<li class="L11088" rel="L11088">tending to compromise Tellson&#39;s, Mr. Lorry advised with Lucie. She said</li>
<li class="L11089" rel="L11089">that her father had spoken of hiring a lodging for a short term, in that</li>
<li class="L11090" rel="L11090">Quarter, near the Banking-house. As there was no business objection to</li>
<li class="L11091" rel="L11091">this, and as he foresaw that even if it were all well with Charles, and</li>
<li class="L11092" rel="L11092">he were to be released, he could not hope to leave the city, Mr. Lorry</li>
<li class="L11093" rel="L11093">went out in quest of such a lodging, and found a suitable one, high up</li>
<li class="L11094" rel="L11094">in a removed by-street where the closed blinds in all the other windows</li>
<li class="L11095" rel="L11095">of a high melancholy square of buildings marked deserted homes.</li>
<li class="L11096" rel="L11096"></li>
<li class="L11097" rel="L11097">To this lodging he at once removed Lucie and her child, and Miss Pross:</li>
<li class="L11098" rel="L11098">giving them what comfort he could, and much more than he had himself.</li>
<li class="L11099" rel="L11099">He left Jerry with them, as a figure to fill a doorway that would bear</li>
<li class="L11100" rel="L11100">considerable knocking on the head, and returned to his own occupations.</li>
<li class="L11101" rel="L11101">A disturbed and doleful mind he brought to bear upon them, and slowly</li>
<li class="L11102" rel="L11102">and heavily the day lagged on with him.</li>
<li class="L11103" rel="L11103"></li>
<li class="L11104" rel="L11104">It wore itself out, and wore him out with it, until the Bank closed. He</li>
<li class="L11105" rel="L11105">was again alone in his room of the previous night, considering what to</li>
<li class="L11106" rel="L11106">do next, when he heard a foot upon the stair. In a few moments, a</li>
<li class="L11107" rel="L11107">man stood in his presence, who, with a keenly observant look at him,</li>
<li class="L11108" rel="L11108">addressed him by his name.</li>
<li class="L11109" rel="L11109"></li>
<li class="L11110" rel="L11110">“Your servant,” said Mr. Lorry. “Do you know me?”</li>
<li class="L11111" rel="L11111"></li>
<li class="L11112" rel="L11112">He was a strongly made man with dark curling hair, from forty-five</li>
<li class="L11113" rel="L11113">to fifty years of age. For answer he repeated, without any change of</li>
<li class="L11114" rel="L11114">emphasis, the words:</li>
<li class="L11115" rel="L11115"></li>
<li class="L11116" rel="L11116">“Do you know me?”</li>
<li class="L11117" rel="L11117"></li>
<li class="L11118" rel="L11118">“I have seen you somewhere.”</li>
<li class="L11119" rel="L11119"></li>
<li class="L11120" rel="L11120">“Perhaps at my wine-shop?”</li>
<li class="L11121" rel="L11121"></li>
<li class="L11122" rel="L11122">Much interested and agitated, Mr. Lorry said: “You come from Doctor</li>
<li class="L11123" rel="L11123">Manette?”</li>
<li class="L11124" rel="L11124"></li>
<li class="L11125" rel="L11125">“Yes. I come from Doctor Manette.”</li>
<li class="L11126" rel="L11126"></li>
<li class="L11127" rel="L11127">“And what says he? What does he send me?”</li>
<li class="L11128" rel="L11128"></li>
<li class="L11129" rel="L11129">Defarge gave into his anxious hand, an open scrap of paper. It bore the</li>
<li class="L11130" rel="L11130">words in the Doctor&#39;s writing:</li>
<li class="L11131" rel="L11131"></li>
<li class="L11132" rel="L11132">    “Charles is safe, but I cannot safely leave this place yet.</li>
<li class="L11133" rel="L11133">     I have obtained the favour that the bearer has a short note</li>
<li class="L11134" rel="L11134">     from Charles to his wife.  Let the bearer see his wife.”</li>
<li class="L11135" rel="L11135"></li>
<li class="L11136" rel="L11136">It was dated from La Force, within an hour.</li>
<li class="L11137" rel="L11137"></li>
<li class="L11138" rel="L11138">“Will you accompany me,” said Mr. Lorry, joyfully relieved after reading</li>
<li class="L11139" rel="L11139">this note aloud, “to where his wife resides?”</li>
<li class="L11140" rel="L11140"></li>
<li class="L11141" rel="L11141">“Yes,” returned Defarge.</li>
<li class="L11142" rel="L11142"></li>
<li class="L11143" rel="L11143">Scarcely noticing as yet, in what a curiously reserved and mechanical</li>
<li class="L11144" rel="L11144">way Defarge spoke, Mr. Lorry put on his hat and they went down into the</li>
<li class="L11145" rel="L11145">courtyard. There, they found two women; one, knitting.</li>
<li class="L11146" rel="L11146"></li>
<li class="L11147" rel="L11147">“Madame Defarge, surely!” said Mr. Lorry, who had left her in exactly</li>
<li class="L11148" rel="L11148">the same attitude some seventeen years ago.</li>
<li class="L11149" rel="L11149"></li>
<li class="L11150" rel="L11150">“It is she,” observed her husband.</li>
<li class="L11151" rel="L11151"></li>
<li class="L11152" rel="L11152">“Does Madame go with us?” inquired Mr. Lorry, seeing that she moved as</li>
<li class="L11153" rel="L11153">they moved.</li>
<li class="L11154" rel="L11154"></li>
<li class="L11155" rel="L11155">“Yes. That she may be able to recognise the faces and know the persons.</li>
<li class="L11156" rel="L11156">It is for their safety.”</li>
<li class="L11157" rel="L11157"></li>
<li class="L11158" rel="L11158">Beginning to be struck by Defarge&#39;s manner, Mr. Lorry looked dubiously</li>
<li class="L11159" rel="L11159">at him, and led the way. Both the women followed; the second woman being</li>
<li class="L11160" rel="L11160">The Vengeance.</li>
<li class="L11161" rel="L11161"></li>
<li class="L11162" rel="L11162">They passed through the intervening streets as quickly as they might,</li>
<li class="L11163" rel="L11163">ascended the staircase of the new domicile, were admitted by Jerry,</li>
<li class="L11164" rel="L11164">and found Lucie weeping, alone. She was thrown into a transport by the</li>
<li class="L11165" rel="L11165">tidings Mr. Lorry gave her of her husband, and clasped the hand that</li>
<li class="L11166" rel="L11166">delivered his note--little thinking what it had been doing near him in</li>
<li class="L11167" rel="L11167">the night, and might, but for a chance, have done to him.</li>
<li class="L11168" rel="L11168"></li>
<li class="L11169" rel="L11169">     “DEAREST,--Take courage.  I am well, and your father has</li>
<li class="L11170" rel="L11170">      influence around me.  You cannot answer this.</li>
<li class="L11171" rel="L11171">      Kiss our child for me.”</li>
<li class="L11172" rel="L11172"></li>
<li class="L11173" rel="L11173">That was all the writing. It was so much, however, to her who received</li>
<li class="L11174" rel="L11174">it, that she turned from Defarge to his wife, and kissed one of the</li>
<li class="L11175" rel="L11175">hands that knitted. It was a passionate, loving, thankful, womanly</li>
<li class="L11176" rel="L11176">action, but the hand made no response--dropped cold and heavy, and took</li>
<li class="L11177" rel="L11177">to its knitting again.</li>
<li class="L11178" rel="L11178"></li>
<li class="L11179" rel="L11179">There was something in its touch that gave Lucie a check. She stopped in</li>
<li class="L11180" rel="L11180">the act of putting the note in her bosom, and, with her hands yet at her</li>
<li class="L11181" rel="L11181">neck, looked terrified at Madame Defarge. Madame Defarge met the lifted</li>
<li class="L11182" rel="L11182">eyebrows and forehead with a cold, impassive stare.</li>
<li class="L11183" rel="L11183"></li>
<li class="L11184" rel="L11184">“My dear,” said Mr. Lorry, striking in to explain; “there are frequent</li>
<li class="L11185" rel="L11185">risings in the streets; and, although it is not likely they will ever</li>
<li class="L11186" rel="L11186">trouble you, Madame Defarge wishes to see those whom she has the power</li>
<li class="L11187" rel="L11187">to protect at such times, to the end that she may know them--that she</li>
<li class="L11188" rel="L11188">may identify them. I believe,” said Mr. Lorry, rather halting in his</li>
<li class="L11189" rel="L11189">reassuring words, as the stony manner of all the three impressed itself</li>
<li class="L11190" rel="L11190">upon him more and more, “I state the case, Citizen Defarge?”</li>
<li class="L11191" rel="L11191"></li>
<li class="L11192" rel="L11192">Defarge looked gloomily at his wife, and gave no other answer than a</li>
<li class="L11193" rel="L11193">gruff sound of acquiescence.</li>
<li class="L11194" rel="L11194"></li>
<li class="L11195" rel="L11195">“You had better, Lucie,” said Mr. Lorry, doing all he could to</li>
<li class="L11196" rel="L11196">propitiate, by tone and manner, “have the dear child here, and our</li>
<li class="L11197" rel="L11197">good Pross. Our good Pross, Defarge, is an English lady, and knows no</li>
<li class="L11198" rel="L11198">French.”</li>
<li class="L11199" rel="L11199"></li>
<li class="L11200" rel="L11200">The lady in question, whose rooted conviction that she was more than a</li>
<li class="L11201" rel="L11201">match for any foreigner, was not to be shaken by distress and, danger,</li>
<li class="L11202" rel="L11202">appeared with folded arms, and observed in English to The Vengeance,</li>
<li class="L11203" rel="L11203">whom her eyes first encountered, “Well, I am sure, Boldface! I hope</li>
<li class="L11204" rel="L11204">_you_ are pretty well!” She also bestowed a British cough on Madame</li>
<li class="L11205" rel="L11205">Defarge; but, neither of the two took much heed of her.</li>
<li class="L11206" rel="L11206"></li>
<li class="L11207" rel="L11207">“Is that his child?” said Madame Defarge, stopping in her work for the</li>
<li class="L11208" rel="L11208">first time, and pointing her knitting-needle at little Lucie as if it</li>
<li class="L11209" rel="L11209">were the finger of Fate.</li>
<li class="L11210" rel="L11210"></li>
<li class="L11211" rel="L11211">“Yes, madame,” answered Mr. Lorry; “this is our poor prisoner&#39;s darling</li>
<li class="L11212" rel="L11212">daughter, and only child.”</li>
<li class="L11213" rel="L11213"></li>
<li class="L11214" rel="L11214">The shadow attendant on Madame Defarge and her party seemed to fall so</li>
<li class="L11215" rel="L11215">threatening and dark on the child, that her mother instinctively</li>
<li class="L11216" rel="L11216">kneeled on the ground beside her, and held her to her breast. The</li>
<li class="L11217" rel="L11217">shadow attendant on Madame Defarge and her party seemed then to fall,</li>
<li class="L11218" rel="L11218">threatening and dark, on both the mother and the child.</li>
<li class="L11219" rel="L11219"></li>
<li class="L11220" rel="L11220">“It is enough, my husband,” said Madame Defarge. “I have seen them. We</li>
<li class="L11221" rel="L11221">may go.”</li>
<li class="L11222" rel="L11222"></li>
<li class="L11223" rel="L11223">But, the suppressed manner had enough of menace in it--not visible and</li>
<li class="L11224" rel="L11224">presented, but indistinct and withheld--to alarm Lucie into saying, as</li>
<li class="L11225" rel="L11225">she laid her appealing hand on Madame Defarge&#39;s dress:</li>
<li class="L11226" rel="L11226"></li>
<li class="L11227" rel="L11227">“You will be good to my poor husband. You will do him no harm. You will</li>
<li class="L11228" rel="L11228">help me to see him if you can?”</li>
<li class="L11229" rel="L11229"></li>
<li class="L11230" rel="L11230">“Your husband is not my business here,” returned Madame Defarge, looking</li>
<li class="L11231" rel="L11231">down at her with perfect composure. “It is the daughter of your father</li>
<li class="L11232" rel="L11232">who is my business here.”</li>
<li class="L11233" rel="L11233"></li>
<li class="L11234" rel="L11234">“For my sake, then, be merciful to my husband. For my child&#39;s sake! She</li>
<li class="L11235" rel="L11235">will put her hands together and pray you to be merciful. We are more</li>
<li class="L11236" rel="L11236">afraid of you than of these others.”</li>
<li class="L11237" rel="L11237"></li>
<li class="L11238" rel="L11238">Madame Defarge received it as a compliment, and looked at her husband.</li>
<li class="L11239" rel="L11239">Defarge, who had been uneasily biting his thumb-nail and looking at her,</li>
<li class="L11240" rel="L11240">collected his face into a sterner expression.</li>
<li class="L11241" rel="L11241"></li>
<li class="L11242" rel="L11242">“What is it that your husband says in that little letter?” asked Madame</li>
<li class="L11243" rel="L11243">Defarge, with a lowering smile. “Influence; he says something touching</li>
<li class="L11244" rel="L11244">influence?”</li>
<li class="L11245" rel="L11245"></li>
<li class="L11246" rel="L11246">“That my father,” said Lucie, hurriedly taking the paper from her</li>
<li class="L11247" rel="L11247">breast, but with her alarmed eyes on her questioner and not on it, “has</li>
<li class="L11248" rel="L11248">much influence around him.”</li>
<li class="L11249" rel="L11249"></li>
<li class="L11250" rel="L11250">“Surely it will release him!” said Madame Defarge. “Let it do so.”</li>
<li class="L11251" rel="L11251"></li>
<li class="L11252" rel="L11252">“As a wife and mother,” cried Lucie, most earnestly, “I implore you to</li>
<li class="L11253" rel="L11253">have pity on me and not to exercise any power that you possess, against</li>
<li class="L11254" rel="L11254">my innocent husband, but to use it in his behalf. O sister-woman, think</li>
<li class="L11255" rel="L11255">of me. As a wife and mother!”</li>
<li class="L11256" rel="L11256"></li>
<li class="L11257" rel="L11257">Madame Defarge looked, coldly as ever, at the suppliant, and said,</li>
<li class="L11258" rel="L11258">turning to her friend The Vengeance:</li>
<li class="L11259" rel="L11259"></li>
<li class="L11260" rel="L11260">“The wives and mothers we have been used to see, since we were as little</li>
<li class="L11261" rel="L11261">as this child, and much less, have not been greatly considered? We have</li>
<li class="L11262" rel="L11262">known _their_ husbands and fathers laid in prison and kept from them,</li>
<li class="L11263" rel="L11263">often enough? All our lives, we have seen our sister-women suffer, in</li>
<li class="L11264" rel="L11264">themselves and in their children, poverty, nakedness, hunger, thirst,</li>
<li class="L11265" rel="L11265">sickness, misery, oppression and neglect of all kinds?”</li>
<li class="L11266" rel="L11266"></li>
<li class="L11267" rel="L11267">“We have seen nothing else,” returned The Vengeance.</li>
<li class="L11268" rel="L11268"></li>
<li class="L11269" rel="L11269">“We have borne this a long time,” said Madame Defarge, turning her eyes</li>
<li class="L11270" rel="L11270">again upon Lucie. “Judge you! Is it likely that the trouble of one wife</li>
<li class="L11271" rel="L11271">and mother would be much to us now?”</li>
<li class="L11272" rel="L11272"></li>
<li class="L11273" rel="L11273">She resumed her knitting and went out. The Vengeance followed. Defarge</li>
<li class="L11274" rel="L11274">went last, and closed the door.</li>
<li class="L11275" rel="L11275"></li>
<li class="L11276" rel="L11276">“Courage, my dear Lucie,” said Mr. Lorry, as he raised her. “Courage,</li>
<li class="L11277" rel="L11277">courage! So far all goes well with us--much, much better than it has of</li>
<li class="L11278" rel="L11278">late gone with many poor souls. Cheer up, and have a thankful heart.”</li>
<li class="L11279" rel="L11279"></li>
<li class="L11280" rel="L11280">“I am not thankless, I hope, but that dreadful woman seems to throw a</li>
<li class="L11281" rel="L11281">shadow on me and on all my hopes.”</li>
<li class="L11282" rel="L11282"></li>
<li class="L11283" rel="L11283">“Tut, tut!” said Mr. Lorry; “what is this despondency in the brave</li>
<li class="L11284" rel="L11284">little breast? A shadow indeed! No substance in it, Lucie.”</li>
<li class="L11285" rel="L11285"></li>
<li class="L11286" rel="L11286">But the shadow of the manner of these Defarges was dark upon himself,</li>
<li class="L11287" rel="L11287">for all that, and in his secret mind it troubled him greatly.</li>
<li class="L11288" rel="L11288"></li>
<li class="L11289" rel="L11289"></li>
<li class="L11290" rel="L11290"></li>
<li class="L11291" rel="L11291"></li>
<li class="L11292" rel="L11292">IV. Calm in Storm</li>
<li class="L11293" rel="L11293"></li>
<li class="L11294" rel="L11294"></li>
<li class="L11295" rel="L11295">Doctor Manette did not return until the morning of the fourth day of his</li>
<li class="L11296" rel="L11296">absence. So much of what had happened in that dreadful time as could be</li>
<li class="L11297" rel="L11297">kept from the knowledge of Lucie was so well concealed from her, that</li>
<li class="L11298" rel="L11298">not until long afterwards, when France and she were far apart, did she</li>
<li class="L11299" rel="L11299">know that eleven hundred defenceless prisoners of both sexes and all</li>
<li class="L11300" rel="L11300">ages had been killed by the populace; that four days and nights had been</li>
<li class="L11301" rel="L11301">darkened by this deed of horror; and that the air around her had been</li>
<li class="L11302" rel="L11302">tainted by the slain. She only knew that there had been an attack upon</li>
<li class="L11303" rel="L11303">the prisons, that all political prisoners had been in danger, and that</li>
<li class="L11304" rel="L11304">some had been dragged out by the crowd and murdered.</li>
<li class="L11305" rel="L11305"></li>
<li class="L11306" rel="L11306">To Mr. Lorry, the Doctor communicated under an injunction of secrecy on</li>
<li class="L11307" rel="L11307">which he had no need to dwell, that the crowd had taken him through a</li>
<li class="L11308" rel="L11308">scene of carnage to the prison of La Force. That, in the prison he had</li>
<li class="L11309" rel="L11309">found a self-appointed Tribunal sitting, before which the prisoners were</li>
<li class="L11310" rel="L11310">brought singly, and by which they were rapidly ordered to be put forth</li>
<li class="L11311" rel="L11311">to be massacred, or to be released, or (in a few cases) to be sent back</li>
<li class="L11312" rel="L11312">to their cells. That, presented by his conductors to this Tribunal, he</li>
<li class="L11313" rel="L11313">had announced himself by name and profession as having been for eighteen</li>
<li class="L11314" rel="L11314">years a secret and unaccused prisoner in the Bastille; that, one of the</li>
<li class="L11315" rel="L11315">body so sitting in judgment had risen and identified him, and that this</li>
<li class="L11316" rel="L11316">man was Defarge.</li>
<li class="L11317" rel="L11317"></li>
<li class="L11318" rel="L11318">That, hereupon he had ascertained, through the registers on the table,</li>
<li class="L11319" rel="L11319">that his son-in-law was among the living prisoners, and had pleaded hard</li>
<li class="L11320" rel="L11320">to the Tribunal--of whom some members were asleep and some awake, some</li>
<li class="L11321" rel="L11321">dirty with murder and some clean, some sober and some not--for his life</li>
<li class="L11322" rel="L11322">and liberty. That, in the first frantic greetings lavished on himself as</li>
<li class="L11323" rel="L11323">a notable sufferer under the overthrown system, it had been accorded</li>
<li class="L11324" rel="L11324">to him to have Charles Darnay brought before the lawless Court, and</li>
<li class="L11325" rel="L11325">examined. That, he seemed on the point of being at once released, when</li>
<li class="L11326" rel="L11326">the tide in his favour met with some unexplained check (not intelligible</li>
<li class="L11327" rel="L11327">to the Doctor), which led to a few words of secret conference. That,</li>
<li class="L11328" rel="L11328">the man sitting as President had then informed Doctor Manette that</li>
<li class="L11329" rel="L11329">the prisoner must remain in custody, but should, for his sake, be held</li>
<li class="L11330" rel="L11330">inviolate in safe custody. That, immediately, on a signal, the prisoner</li>
<li class="L11331" rel="L11331">was removed to the interior of the prison again; but, that he, the</li>
<li class="L11332" rel="L11332">Doctor, had then so strongly pleaded for permission to remain and</li>
<li class="L11333" rel="L11333">assure himself that his son-in-law was, through no malice or mischance,</li>
<li class="L11334" rel="L11334">delivered to the concourse whose murderous yells outside the gate had</li>
<li class="L11335" rel="L11335">often drowned the proceedings, that he had obtained the permission, and</li>
<li class="L11336" rel="L11336">had remained in that Hall of Blood until the danger was over.</li>
<li class="L11337" rel="L11337"></li>
<li class="L11338" rel="L11338">The sights he had seen there, with brief snatches of food and sleep by</li>
<li class="L11339" rel="L11339">intervals, shall remain untold. The mad joy over the prisoners who were</li>
<li class="L11340" rel="L11340">saved, had astounded him scarcely less than the mad ferocity against</li>
<li class="L11341" rel="L11341">those who were cut to pieces. One prisoner there was, he said, who had</li>
<li class="L11342" rel="L11342">been discharged into the street free, but at whom a mistaken savage had</li>
<li class="L11343" rel="L11343">thrust a pike as he passed out. Being besought to go to him and dress</li>
<li class="L11344" rel="L11344">the wound, the Doctor had passed out at the same gate, and had found him</li>
<li class="L11345" rel="L11345">in the arms of a company of Samaritans, who were seated on the bodies</li>
<li class="L11346" rel="L11346">of their victims. With an inconsistency as monstrous as anything in this</li>
<li class="L11347" rel="L11347">awful nightmare, they had helped the healer, and tended the wounded man</li>
<li class="L11348" rel="L11348">with the gentlest solicitude--had made a litter for him and escorted him</li>
<li class="L11349" rel="L11349">carefully from the spot--had then caught up their weapons and plunged</li>
<li class="L11350" rel="L11350">anew into a butchery so dreadful, that the Doctor had covered his eyes</li>
<li class="L11351" rel="L11351">with his hands, and swooned away in the midst of it.</li>
<li class="L11352" rel="L11352"></li>
<li class="L11353" rel="L11353">As Mr. Lorry received these confidences, and as he watched the face of</li>
<li class="L11354" rel="L11354">his friend now sixty-two years of age, a misgiving arose within him that</li>
<li class="L11355" rel="L11355">such dread experiences would revive the old danger.</li>
<li class="L11356" rel="L11356"></li>
<li class="L11357" rel="L11357">But, he had never seen his friend in his present aspect: he had never</li>
<li class="L11358" rel="L11358">at all known him in his present character. For the first time the Doctor</li>
<li class="L11359" rel="L11359">felt, now, that his suffering was strength and power. For the first time</li>
<li class="L11360" rel="L11360">he felt that in that sharp fire, he had slowly forged the iron which</li>
<li class="L11361" rel="L11361">could break the prison door of his daughter&#39;s husband, and deliver him.</li>
<li class="L11362" rel="L11362">“It all tended to a good end, my friend; it was not mere waste and ruin.</li>
<li class="L11363" rel="L11363">As my beloved child was helpful in restoring me to myself, I will be</li>
<li class="L11364" rel="L11364">helpful now in restoring the dearest part of herself to her; by the aid</li>
<li class="L11365" rel="L11365">of Heaven I will do it!” Thus, Doctor Manette. And when Jarvis Lorry saw</li>
<li class="L11366" rel="L11366">the kindled eyes, the resolute face, the calm strong look and bearing</li>
<li class="L11367" rel="L11367">of the man whose life always seemed to him to have been stopped, like a</li>
<li class="L11368" rel="L11368">clock, for so many years, and then set going again with an energy which</li>
<li class="L11369" rel="L11369">had lain dormant during the cessation of its usefulness, he believed.</li>
<li class="L11370" rel="L11370"></li>
<li class="L11371" rel="L11371">Greater things than the Doctor had at that time to contend with, would</li>
<li class="L11372" rel="L11372">have yielded before his persevering purpose. While he kept himself</li>
<li class="L11373" rel="L11373">in his place, as a physician, whose business was with all degrees</li>
<li class="L11374" rel="L11374">of mankind, bond and free, rich and poor, bad and good, he used his</li>
<li class="L11375" rel="L11375">personal influence so wisely, that he was soon the inspecting physician</li>
<li class="L11376" rel="L11376">of three prisons, and among them of La Force. He could now assure Lucie</li>
<li class="L11377" rel="L11377">that her husband was no longer confined alone, but was mixed with the</li>
<li class="L11378" rel="L11378">general body of prisoners; he saw her husband weekly, and brought sweet</li>
<li class="L11379" rel="L11379">messages to her, straight from his lips; sometimes her husband himself</li>
<li class="L11380" rel="L11380">sent a letter to her (though never by the Doctor&#39;s hand), but she was</li>
<li class="L11381" rel="L11381">not permitted to write to him: for, among the many wild suspicions of</li>
<li class="L11382" rel="L11382">plots in the prisons, the wildest of all pointed at emigrants who were</li>
<li class="L11383" rel="L11383">known to have made friends or permanent connections abroad.</li>
<li class="L11384" rel="L11384"></li>
<li class="L11385" rel="L11385">This new life of the Doctor&#39;s was an anxious life, no doubt; still, the</li>
<li class="L11386" rel="L11386">sagacious Mr. Lorry saw that there was a new sustaining pride in it.</li>
<li class="L11387" rel="L11387">Nothing unbecoming tinged the pride; it was a natural and worthy one;</li>
<li class="L11388" rel="L11388">but he observed it as a curiosity. The Doctor knew, that up to that</li>
<li class="L11389" rel="L11389">time, his imprisonment had been associated in the minds of his daughter</li>
<li class="L11390" rel="L11390">and his friend, with his personal affliction, deprivation, and weakness.</li>
<li class="L11391" rel="L11391">Now that this was changed, and he knew himself to be invested through</li>
<li class="L11392" rel="L11392">that old trial with forces to which they both looked for Charles&#39;s</li>
<li class="L11393" rel="L11393">ultimate safety and deliverance, he became so far exalted by the change,</li>
<li class="L11394" rel="L11394">that he took the lead and direction, and required them as the weak, to</li>
<li class="L11395" rel="L11395">trust to him as the strong. The preceding relative positions of himself</li>
<li class="L11396" rel="L11396">and Lucie were reversed, yet only as the liveliest gratitude and</li>
<li class="L11397" rel="L11397">affection could reverse them, for he could have had no pride but in</li>
<li class="L11398" rel="L11398">rendering some service to her who had rendered so much to him. “All</li>
<li class="L11399" rel="L11399">curious to see,” thought Mr. Lorry, in his amiably shrewd way, “but all</li>
<li class="L11400" rel="L11400">natural and right; so, take the lead, my dear friend, and keep it; it</li>
<li class="L11401" rel="L11401">couldn&#39;t be in better hands.”</li>
<li class="L11402" rel="L11402"></li>
<li class="L11403" rel="L11403">But, though the Doctor tried hard, and never ceased trying, to get</li>
<li class="L11404" rel="L11404">Charles Darnay set at liberty, or at least to get him brought to trial,</li>
<li class="L11405" rel="L11405">the public current of the time set too strong and fast for him. The new</li>
<li class="L11406" rel="L11406">era began; the king was tried, doomed, and beheaded; the Republic of</li>
<li class="L11407" rel="L11407">Liberty, Equality, Fraternity, or Death, declared for victory or death</li>
<li class="L11408" rel="L11408">against the world in arms; the black flag waved night and day from the</li>
<li class="L11409" rel="L11409">great towers of Notre Dame; three hundred thousand men, summoned to rise</li>
<li class="L11410" rel="L11410">against the tyrants of the earth, rose from all the varying soils</li>
<li class="L11411" rel="L11411">of France, as if the dragon&#39;s teeth had been sown broadcast, and</li>
<li class="L11412" rel="L11412">had yielded fruit equally on hill and plain, on rock, in gravel, and</li>
<li class="L11413" rel="L11413">alluvial mud, under the bright sky of the South and under the clouds of</li>
<li class="L11414" rel="L11414">the North, in fell and forest, in the vineyards and the olive-grounds</li>
<li class="L11415" rel="L11415">and among the cropped grass and the stubble of the corn, along the</li>
<li class="L11416" rel="L11416">fruitful banks of the broad rivers, and in the sand of the sea-shore.</li>
<li class="L11417" rel="L11417">What private solicitude could rear itself against the deluge of the Year</li>
<li class="L11418" rel="L11418">One of Liberty--the deluge rising from below, not falling from above,</li>
<li class="L11419" rel="L11419">and with the windows of Heaven shut, not opened!</li>
<li class="L11420" rel="L11420"></li>
<li class="L11421" rel="L11421">There was no pause, no pity, no peace, no interval of relenting rest, no</li>
<li class="L11422" rel="L11422">measurement of time. Though days and nights circled as regularly as when</li>
<li class="L11423" rel="L11423">time was young, and the evening and morning were the first day, other</li>
<li class="L11424" rel="L11424">count of time there was none. Hold of it was lost in the raging fever</li>
<li class="L11425" rel="L11425">of a nation, as it is in the fever of one patient. Now, breaking the</li>
<li class="L11426" rel="L11426">unnatural silence of a whole city, the executioner showed the people the</li>
<li class="L11427" rel="L11427">head of the king--and now, it seemed almost in the same breath, the</li>
<li class="L11428" rel="L11428">head of his fair wife which had had eight weary months of imprisoned</li>
<li class="L11429" rel="L11429">widowhood and misery, to turn it grey.</li>
<li class="L11430" rel="L11430"></li>
<li class="L11431" rel="L11431">And yet, observing the strange law of contradiction which obtains in</li>
<li class="L11432" rel="L11432">all such cases, the time was long, while it flamed by so fast. A</li>
<li class="L11433" rel="L11433">revolutionary tribunal in the capital, and forty or fifty thousand</li>
<li class="L11434" rel="L11434">revolutionary committees all over the land; a law of the Suspected,</li>
<li class="L11435" rel="L11435">which struck away all security for liberty or life, and delivered over</li>
<li class="L11436" rel="L11436">any good and innocent person to any bad and guilty one; prisons gorged</li>
<li class="L11437" rel="L11437">with people who had committed no offence, and could obtain no hearing;</li>
<li class="L11438" rel="L11438">these things became the established order and nature of appointed</li>
<li class="L11439" rel="L11439">things, and seemed to be ancient usage before they were many weeks old.</li>
<li class="L11440" rel="L11440">Above all, one hideous figure grew as familiar as if it had been before</li>
<li class="L11441" rel="L11441">the general gaze from the foundations of the world--the figure of the</li>
<li class="L11442" rel="L11442">sharp female called La Guillotine.</li>
<li class="L11443" rel="L11443"></li>
<li class="L11444" rel="L11444">It was the popular theme for jests; it was the best cure for headache,</li>
<li class="L11445" rel="L11445">it infallibly prevented the hair from turning grey, it imparted a</li>
<li class="L11446" rel="L11446">peculiar delicacy to the complexion, it was the National Razor which</li>
<li class="L11447" rel="L11447">shaved close: who kissed La Guillotine, looked through the little window</li>
<li class="L11448" rel="L11448">and sneezed into the sack. It was the sign of the regeneration of the</li>
<li class="L11449" rel="L11449">human race. It superseded the Cross. Models of it were worn on breasts</li>
<li class="L11450" rel="L11450">from which the Cross was discarded, and it was bowed down to and</li>
<li class="L11451" rel="L11451">believed in where the Cross was denied.</li>
<li class="L11452" rel="L11452"></li>
<li class="L11453" rel="L11453">It sheared off heads so many, that it, and the ground it most polluted,</li>
<li class="L11454" rel="L11454">were a rotten red. It was taken to pieces, like a toy-puzzle for a young</li>
<li class="L11455" rel="L11455">Devil, and was put together again when the occasion wanted it. It hushed</li>
<li class="L11456" rel="L11456">the eloquent, struck down the powerful, abolished the beautiful and</li>
<li class="L11457" rel="L11457">good. Twenty-two friends of high public mark, twenty-one living and one</li>
<li class="L11458" rel="L11458">dead, it had lopped the heads off, in one morning, in as many minutes.</li>
<li class="L11459" rel="L11459">The name of the strong man of Old Scripture had descended to the chief</li>
<li class="L11460" rel="L11460">functionary who worked it; but, so armed, he was stronger than his</li>
<li class="L11461" rel="L11461">namesake, and blinder, and tore away the gates of God&#39;s own Temple every</li>
<li class="L11462" rel="L11462">day.</li>
<li class="L11463" rel="L11463"></li>
<li class="L11464" rel="L11464">Among these terrors, and the brood belonging to them, the Doctor walked</li>
<li class="L11465" rel="L11465">with a steady head: confident in his power, cautiously persistent in his</li>
<li class="L11466" rel="L11466">end, never doubting that he would save Lucie&#39;s husband at last. Yet the</li>
<li class="L11467" rel="L11467">current of the time swept by, so strong and deep, and carried the time</li>
<li class="L11468" rel="L11468">away so fiercely, that Charles had lain in prison one year and three</li>
<li class="L11469" rel="L11469">months when the Doctor was thus steady and confident. So much more</li>
<li class="L11470" rel="L11470">wicked and distracted had the Revolution grown in that December month,</li>
<li class="L11471" rel="L11471">that the rivers of the South were encumbered with the bodies of the</li>
<li class="L11472" rel="L11472">violently drowned by night, and prisoners were shot in lines and squares</li>
<li class="L11473" rel="L11473">under the southern wintry sun. Still, the Doctor walked among the</li>
<li class="L11474" rel="L11474">terrors with a steady head. No man better known than he, in Paris at</li>
<li class="L11475" rel="L11475">that day; no man in a stranger situation. Silent, humane, indispensable</li>
<li class="L11476" rel="L11476">in hospital and prison, using his art equally among assassins and</li>
<li class="L11477" rel="L11477">victims, he was a man apart. In the exercise of his skill, the</li>
<li class="L11478" rel="L11478">appearance and the story of the Bastille Captive removed him from all</li>
<li class="L11479" rel="L11479">other men. He was not suspected or brought in question, any more than if</li>
<li class="L11480" rel="L11480">he had indeed been recalled to life some eighteen years before, or were</li>
<li class="L11481" rel="L11481">a Spirit moving among mortals.</li>
<li class="L11482" rel="L11482"></li>
<li class="L11483" rel="L11483"></li>
<li class="L11484" rel="L11484"></li>
<li class="L11485" rel="L11485"></li>
<li class="L11486" rel="L11486">V. The Wood-Sawyer</li>
<li class="L11487" rel="L11487"></li>
<li class="L11488" rel="L11488"></li>
<li class="L11489" rel="L11489">One year and three months. During all that time Lucie was never</li>
<li class="L11490" rel="L11490">sure, from hour to hour, but that the Guillotine would strike off her</li>
<li class="L11491" rel="L11491">husband&#39;s head next day. Every day, through the stony streets, the</li>
<li class="L11492" rel="L11492">tumbrils now jolted heavily, filled with Condemned. Lovely girls; bright</li>
<li class="L11493" rel="L11493">women, brown-haired, black-haired, and grey; youths; stalwart men and</li>
<li class="L11494" rel="L11494">old; gentle born and peasant born; all red wine for La Guillotine, all</li>
<li class="L11495" rel="L11495">daily brought into light from the dark cellars of the loathsome prisons,</li>
<li class="L11496" rel="L11496">and carried to her through the streets to slake her devouring thirst.</li>
<li class="L11497" rel="L11497">Liberty, equality, fraternity, or death;--the last, much the easiest to</li>
<li class="L11498" rel="L11498">bestow, O Guillotine!</li>
<li class="L11499" rel="L11499"></li>
<li class="L11500" rel="L11500">If the suddenness of her calamity, and the whirling wheels of the time,</li>
<li class="L11501" rel="L11501">had stunned the Doctor&#39;s daughter into awaiting the result in idle</li>
<li class="L11502" rel="L11502">despair, it would but have been with her as it was with many. But, from</li>
<li class="L11503" rel="L11503">the hour when she had taken the white head to her fresh young bosom in</li>
<li class="L11504" rel="L11504">the garret of Saint Antoine, she had been true to her duties. She was</li>
<li class="L11505" rel="L11505">truest to them in the season of trial, as all the quietly loyal and good</li>
<li class="L11506" rel="L11506">will always be.</li>
<li class="L11507" rel="L11507"></li>
<li class="L11508" rel="L11508">As soon as they were established in their new residence, and her father</li>
<li class="L11509" rel="L11509">had entered on the routine of his avocations, she arranged the little</li>
<li class="L11510" rel="L11510">household as exactly as if her husband had been there. Everything had</li>
<li class="L11511" rel="L11511">its appointed place and its appointed time. Little Lucie she taught,</li>
<li class="L11512" rel="L11512">as regularly, as if they had all been united in their English home. The</li>
<li class="L11513" rel="L11513">slight devices with which she cheated herself into the show of a belief</li>
<li class="L11514" rel="L11514">that they would soon be reunited--the little preparations for his speedy</li>
<li class="L11515" rel="L11515">return, the setting aside of his chair and his books--these, and the</li>
<li class="L11516" rel="L11516">solemn prayer at night for one dear prisoner especially, among the many</li>
<li class="L11517" rel="L11517">unhappy souls in prison and the shadow of death--were almost the only</li>
<li class="L11518" rel="L11518">outspoken reliefs of her heavy mind.</li>
<li class="L11519" rel="L11519"></li>
