<li class="L11520" rel="L11520">She did not greatly alter in appearance. The plain dark dresses, akin to</li>
<li class="L11521" rel="L11521">mourning dresses, which she and her child wore, were as neat and as well</li>
<li class="L11522" rel="L11522">attended to as the brighter clothes of happy days. She lost her colour,</li>
<li class="L11523" rel="L11523">and the old and intent expression was a constant, not an occasional,</li>
<li class="L11524" rel="L11524">thing; otherwise, she remained very pretty and comely. Sometimes, at</li>
<li class="L11525" rel="L11525">night on kissing her father, she would burst into the grief she had</li>
<li class="L11526" rel="L11526">repressed all day, and would say that her sole reliance, under Heaven,</li>
<li class="L11527" rel="L11527">was on him. He always resolutely answered: “Nothing can happen to him</li>
<li class="L11528" rel="L11528">without my knowledge, and I know that I can save him, Lucie.”</li>
<li class="L11529" rel="L11529"></li>
<li class="L11530" rel="L11530">They had not made the round of their changed life many weeks, when her</li>
<li class="L11531" rel="L11531">father said to her, on coming home one evening:</li>
<li class="L11532" rel="L11532"></li>
<li class="L11533" rel="L11533">“My dear, there is an upper window in the prison, to which Charles can</li>
<li class="L11534" rel="L11534">sometimes gain access at three in the afternoon. When he can get to</li>
<li class="L11535" rel="L11535">it--which depends on many uncertainties and incidents--he might see you</li>
<li class="L11536" rel="L11536">in the street, he thinks, if you stood in a certain place that I can</li>
<li class="L11537" rel="L11537">show you. But you will not be able to see him, my poor child, and even</li>
<li class="L11538" rel="L11538">if you could, it would be unsafe for you to make a sign of recognition.”</li>
<li class="L11539" rel="L11539"></li>
<li class="L11540" rel="L11540">“O show me the place, my father, and I will go there every day.”</li>
<li class="L11541" rel="L11541"></li>
<li class="L11542" rel="L11542">From that time, in all weathers, she waited there two hours. As the</li>
<li class="L11543" rel="L11543">clock struck two, she was there, and at four she turned resignedly away.</li>
<li class="L11544" rel="L11544">When it was not too wet or inclement for her child to be with her, they</li>
<li class="L11545" rel="L11545">went together; at other times she was alone; but, she never missed a</li>
<li class="L11546" rel="L11546">single day.</li>
<li class="L11547" rel="L11547"></li>
<li class="L11548" rel="L11548">It was the dark and dirty corner of a small winding street. The hovel</li>
<li class="L11549" rel="L11549">of a cutter of wood into lengths for burning, was the only house at that</li>
<li class="L11550" rel="L11550">end; all else was wall. On the third day of her being there, he noticed</li>
<li class="L11551" rel="L11551">her.</li>
<li class="L11552" rel="L11552"></li>
<li class="L11553" rel="L11553">“Good day, citizeness.”</li>
<li class="L11554" rel="L11554"></li>
<li class="L11555" rel="L11555">“Good day, citizen.”</li>
<li class="L11556" rel="L11556"></li>
<li class="L11557" rel="L11557">This mode of address was now prescribed by decree. It had been</li>
<li class="L11558" rel="L11558">established voluntarily some time ago, among the more thorough patriots;</li>
<li class="L11559" rel="L11559">but, was now law for everybody.</li>
<li class="L11560" rel="L11560"></li>
<li class="L11561" rel="L11561">“Walking here again, citizeness?”</li>
<li class="L11562" rel="L11562"></li>
<li class="L11563" rel="L11563">“You see me, citizen!”</li>
<li class="L11564" rel="L11564"></li>
<li class="L11565" rel="L11565">The wood-sawyer, who was a little man with a redundancy of gesture (he</li>
<li class="L11566" rel="L11566">had once been a mender of roads), cast a glance at the prison, pointed</li>
<li class="L11567" rel="L11567">at the prison, and putting his ten fingers before his face to represent</li>
<li class="L11568" rel="L11568">bars, peeped through them jocosely.</li>
<li class="L11569" rel="L11569"></li>
<li class="L11570" rel="L11570">“But it&#39;s not my business,” said he. And went on sawing his wood.</li>
<li class="L11571" rel="L11571"></li>
<li class="L11572" rel="L11572">Next day he was looking out for her, and accosted her the moment she</li>
<li class="L11573" rel="L11573">appeared.</li>
<li class="L11574" rel="L11574"></li>
<li class="L11575" rel="L11575">“What? Walking here again, citizeness?”</li>
<li class="L11576" rel="L11576"></li>
<li class="L11577" rel="L11577">“Yes, citizen.”</li>
<li class="L11578" rel="L11578"></li>
<li class="L11579" rel="L11579">“Ah! A child too! Your mother, is it not, my little citizeness?”</li>
<li class="L11580" rel="L11580"></li>
<li class="L11581" rel="L11581">“Do I say yes, mamma?” whispered little Lucie, drawing close to her.</li>
<li class="L11582" rel="L11582"></li>
<li class="L11583" rel="L11583">“Yes, dearest.”</li>
<li class="L11584" rel="L11584"></li>
<li class="L11585" rel="L11585">“Yes, citizen.”</li>
<li class="L11586" rel="L11586"></li>
<li class="L11587" rel="L11587">“Ah! But it&#39;s not my business. My work is my business. See my saw! I</li>
<li class="L11588" rel="L11588">call it my Little Guillotine. La, la, la; La, la, la! And off his head</li>
<li class="L11589" rel="L11589">comes!”</li>
<li class="L11590" rel="L11590"></li>
<li class="L11591" rel="L11591">The billet fell as he spoke, and he threw it into a basket.</li>
<li class="L11592" rel="L11592"></li>
<li class="L11593" rel="L11593">“I call myself the Samson of the firewood guillotine. See here again!</li>
<li class="L11594" rel="L11594">Loo, loo, loo; Loo, loo, loo! And off _her_ head comes! Now, a child.</li>
<li class="L11595" rel="L11595">Tickle, tickle; Pickle, pickle! And off _its_ head comes. All the</li>
<li class="L11596" rel="L11596">family!”</li>
<li class="L11597" rel="L11597"></li>
<li class="L11598" rel="L11598">Lucie shuddered as he threw two more billets into his basket, but it was</li>
<li class="L11599" rel="L11599">impossible to be there while the wood-sawyer was at work, and not be in</li>
<li class="L11600" rel="L11600">his sight. Thenceforth, to secure his good will, she always spoke to him</li>
<li class="L11601" rel="L11601">first, and often gave him drink-money, which he readily received.</li>
<li class="L11602" rel="L11602"></li>
<li class="L11603" rel="L11603">He was an inquisitive fellow, and sometimes when she had quite forgotten</li>
<li class="L11604" rel="L11604">him in gazing at the prison roof and grates, and in lifting her heart</li>
<li class="L11605" rel="L11605">up to her husband, she would come to herself to find him looking at her,</li>
<li class="L11606" rel="L11606">with his knee on his bench and his saw stopped in its work. “But it&#39;s</li>
<li class="L11607" rel="L11607">not my business!” he would generally say at those times, and would</li>
<li class="L11608" rel="L11608">briskly fall to his sawing again.</li>
<li class="L11609" rel="L11609"></li>
<li class="L11610" rel="L11610">In all weathers, in the snow and frost of winter, in the bitter winds of</li>
<li class="L11611" rel="L11611">spring, in the hot sunshine of summer, in the rains of autumn, and again</li>
<li class="L11612" rel="L11612">in the snow and frost of winter, Lucie passed two hours of every day at</li>
<li class="L11613" rel="L11613">this place; and every day on leaving it, she kissed the prison wall.</li>
<li class="L11614" rel="L11614">Her husband saw her (so she learned from her father) it might be once in</li>
<li class="L11615" rel="L11615">five or six times: it might be twice or thrice running: it might be, not</li>
<li class="L11616" rel="L11616">for a week or a fortnight together. It was enough that he could and did</li>
<li class="L11617" rel="L11617">see her when the chances served, and on that possibility she would have</li>
<li class="L11618" rel="L11618">waited out the day, seven days a week.</li>
<li class="L11619" rel="L11619"></li>
<li class="L11620" rel="L11620">These occupations brought her round to the December month, wherein her</li>
<li class="L11621" rel="L11621">father walked among the terrors with a steady head. On a lightly-snowing</li>
<li class="L11622" rel="L11622">afternoon she arrived at the usual corner. It was a day of some wild</li>
<li class="L11623" rel="L11623">rejoicing, and a festival. She had seen the houses, as she came along,</li>
<li class="L11624" rel="L11624">decorated with little pikes, and with little red caps stuck upon them;</li>
<li class="L11625" rel="L11625">also, with tricoloured ribbons; also, with the standard inscription</li>
<li class="L11626" rel="L11626">(tricoloured letters were the favourite), Republic One and Indivisible.</li>
<li class="L11627" rel="L11627">Liberty, Equality, Fraternity, or Death!</li>
<li class="L11628" rel="L11628"></li>
<li class="L11629" rel="L11629">The miserable shop of the wood-sawyer was so small, that its whole</li>
<li class="L11630" rel="L11630">surface furnished very indifferent space for this legend. He had got</li>
<li class="L11631" rel="L11631">somebody to scrawl it up for him, however, who had squeezed Death in</li>
<li class="L11632" rel="L11632">with most inappropriate difficulty. On his house-top, he displayed pike</li>
<li class="L11633" rel="L11633">and cap, as a good citizen must, and in a window he had stationed his</li>
<li class="L11634" rel="L11634">saw inscribed as his “Little Sainte Guillotine”--for the great sharp</li>
<li class="L11635" rel="L11635">female was by that time popularly canonised. His shop was shut and he</li>
<li class="L11636" rel="L11636">was not there, which was a relief to Lucie, and left her quite alone.</li>
<li class="L11637" rel="L11637"></li>
<li class="L11638" rel="L11638">But, he was not far off, for presently she heard a troubled movement</li>
<li class="L11639" rel="L11639">and a shouting coming along, which filled her with fear. A moment</li>
<li class="L11640" rel="L11640">afterwards, and a throng of people came pouring round the corner by the</li>
<li class="L11641" rel="L11641">prison wall, in the midst of whom was the wood-sawyer hand in hand with</li>
<li class="L11642" rel="L11642">The Vengeance. There could not be fewer than five hundred people, and</li>
<li class="L11643" rel="L11643">they were dancing like five thousand demons. There was no other music</li>
<li class="L11644" rel="L11644">than their own singing. They danced to the popular Revolution song,</li>
<li class="L11645" rel="L11645">keeping a ferocious time that was like a gnashing of teeth in unison.</li>
<li class="L11646" rel="L11646">Men and women danced together, women danced together, men danced</li>
<li class="L11647" rel="L11647">together, as hazard had brought them together. At first, they were a</li>
<li class="L11648" rel="L11648">mere storm of coarse red caps and coarse woollen rags; but, as they</li>
<li class="L11649" rel="L11649">filled the place, and stopped to dance about Lucie, some ghastly</li>
<li class="L11650" rel="L11650">apparition of a dance-figure gone raving mad arose among them. They</li>
<li class="L11651" rel="L11651">advanced, retreated, struck at one another&#39;s hands, clutched at one</li>
<li class="L11652" rel="L11652">another&#39;s heads, spun round alone, caught one another and spun round</li>
<li class="L11653" rel="L11653">in pairs, until many of them dropped. While those were down, the rest</li>
<li class="L11654" rel="L11654">linked hand in hand, and all spun round together: then the ring broke,</li>
<li class="L11655" rel="L11655">and in separate rings of two and four they turned and turned until they</li>
<li class="L11656" rel="L11656">all stopped at once, began again, struck, clutched, and tore, and then</li>
<li class="L11657" rel="L11657">reversed the spin, and all spun round another way. Suddenly they stopped</li>
<li class="L11658" rel="L11658">again, paused, struck out the time afresh, formed into lines the width</li>
<li class="L11659" rel="L11659">of the public way, and, with their heads low down and their hands high</li>
<li class="L11660" rel="L11660">up, swooped screaming off. No fight could have been half so terrible</li>
<li class="L11661" rel="L11661">as this dance. It was so emphatically a fallen sport--a something, once</li>
<li class="L11662" rel="L11662">innocent, delivered over to all devilry--a healthy pastime changed into</li>
<li class="L11663" rel="L11663">a means of angering the blood, bewildering the senses, and steeling the</li>
<li class="L11664" rel="L11664">heart. Such grace as was visible in it, made it the uglier, showing how</li>
<li class="L11665" rel="L11665">warped and perverted all things good by nature were become. The maidenly</li>
<li class="L11666" rel="L11666">bosom bared to this, the pretty almost-child&#39;s head thus distracted, the</li>
<li class="L11667" rel="L11667">delicate foot mincing in this slough of blood and dirt, were types of</li>
<li class="L11668" rel="L11668">the disjointed time.</li>
<li class="L11669" rel="L11669"></li>
<li class="L11670" rel="L11670">This was the Carmagnole. As it passed, leaving Lucie frightened and</li>
<li class="L11671" rel="L11671">bewildered in the doorway of the wood-sawyer&#39;s house, the feathery snow</li>
<li class="L11672" rel="L11672">fell as quietly and lay as white and soft, as if it had never been.</li>
<li class="L11673" rel="L11673"></li>
<li class="L11674" rel="L11674">“O my father!” for he stood before her when she lifted up the eyes she</li>
<li class="L11675" rel="L11675">had momentarily darkened with her hand; “such a cruel, bad sight.”</li>
<li class="L11676" rel="L11676"></li>
<li class="L11677" rel="L11677">“I know, my dear, I know. I have seen it many times. Don&#39;t be</li>
<li class="L11678" rel="L11678">frightened! Not one of them would harm you.”</li>
<li class="L11679" rel="L11679"></li>
<li class="L11680" rel="L11680">“I am not frightened for myself, my father. But when I think of my</li>
<li class="L11681" rel="L11681">husband, and the mercies of these people--”</li>
<li class="L11682" rel="L11682"></li>
<li class="L11683" rel="L11683">“We will set him above their mercies very soon. I left him climbing to</li>
<li class="L11684" rel="L11684">the window, and I came to tell you. There is no one here to see. You may</li>
<li class="L11685" rel="L11685">kiss your hand towards that highest shelving roof.”</li>
<li class="L11686" rel="L11686"></li>
<li class="L11687" rel="L11687">“I do so, father, and I send him my Soul with it!”</li>
<li class="L11688" rel="L11688"></li>
<li class="L11689" rel="L11689">“You cannot see him, my poor dear?”</li>
<li class="L11690" rel="L11690"></li>
<li class="L11691" rel="L11691">“No, father,” said Lucie, yearning and weeping as she kissed her hand,</li>
<li class="L11692" rel="L11692">“no.”</li>
<li class="L11693" rel="L11693"></li>
<li class="L11694" rel="L11694">A footstep in the snow. Madame Defarge. “I salute you, citizeness,”</li>
<li class="L11695" rel="L11695"> from the Doctor. “I salute you, citizen.” This in passing. Nothing more.</li>
<li class="L11696" rel="L11696">Madame Defarge gone, like a shadow over the white road.</li>
<li class="L11697" rel="L11697"></li>
<li class="L11698" rel="L11698">“Give me your arm, my love. Pass from here with an air of cheerfulness</li>
<li class="L11699" rel="L11699">and courage, for his sake. That was well done;” they had left the spot;</li>
<li class="L11700" rel="L11700">“it shall not be in vain. Charles is summoned for to-morrow.”</li>
<li class="L11701" rel="L11701"></li>
<li class="L11702" rel="L11702">“For to-morrow!”</li>
<li class="L11703" rel="L11703"></li>
<li class="L11704" rel="L11704">“There is no time to lose. I am well prepared, but there are precautions</li>
<li class="L11705" rel="L11705">to be taken, that could not be taken until he was actually summoned</li>
<li class="L11706" rel="L11706">before the Tribunal. He has not received the notice yet, but I know</li>
<li class="L11707" rel="L11707">that he will presently be summoned for to-morrow, and removed to the</li>
<li class="L11708" rel="L11708">Conciergerie; I have timely information. You are not afraid?”</li>
<li class="L11709" rel="L11709"></li>
<li class="L11710" rel="L11710">She could scarcely answer, “I trust in you.”</li>
<li class="L11711" rel="L11711"></li>
<li class="L11712" rel="L11712">“Do so, implicitly. Your suspense is nearly ended, my darling; he shall</li>
<li class="L11713" rel="L11713">be restored to you within a few hours; I have encompassed him with every</li>
<li class="L11714" rel="L11714">protection. I must see Lorry.”</li>
<li class="L11715" rel="L11715"></li>
<li class="L11716" rel="L11716">He stopped. There was a heavy lumbering of wheels within hearing. They</li>
<li class="L11717" rel="L11717">both knew too well what it meant. One. Two. Three. Three tumbrils faring</li>
<li class="L11718" rel="L11718">away with their dread loads over the hushing snow.</li>
<li class="L11719" rel="L11719"></li>
<li class="L11720" rel="L11720">“I must see Lorry,” the Doctor repeated, turning her another way.</li>
<li class="L11721" rel="L11721"></li>
<li class="L11722" rel="L11722">The staunch old gentleman was still in his trust; had never left it. He</li>
<li class="L11723" rel="L11723">and his books were in frequent requisition as to property confiscated</li>
<li class="L11724" rel="L11724">and made national. What he could save for the owners, he saved. No</li>
<li class="L11725" rel="L11725">better man living to hold fast by what Tellson&#39;s had in keeping, and to</li>
<li class="L11726" rel="L11726">hold his peace.</li>
<li class="L11727" rel="L11727"></li>
<li class="L11728" rel="L11728">A murky red and yellow sky, and a rising mist from the Seine, denoted</li>
<li class="L11729" rel="L11729">the approach of darkness. It was almost dark when they arrived at the</li>
<li class="L11730" rel="L11730">Bank. The stately residence of Monseigneur was altogether blighted and</li>
<li class="L11731" rel="L11731">deserted. Above a heap of dust and ashes in the court, ran the letters:</li>
<li class="L11732" rel="L11732">National Property. Republic One and Indivisible. Liberty, Equality,</li>
<li class="L11733" rel="L11733">Fraternity, or Death!</li>
<li class="L11734" rel="L11734"></li>
<li class="L11735" rel="L11735">Who could that be with Mr. Lorry--the owner of the riding-coat upon the</li>
<li class="L11736" rel="L11736">chair--who must not be seen? From whom newly arrived, did he come out,</li>
<li class="L11737" rel="L11737">agitated and surprised, to take his favourite in his arms? To whom did</li>
<li class="L11738" rel="L11738">he appear to repeat her faltering words, when, raising his voice and</li>
<li class="L11739" rel="L11739">turning his head towards the door of the room from which he had issued,</li>
<li class="L11740" rel="L11740">he said: “Removed to the Conciergerie, and summoned for to-morrow?”</li>
<li class="L11741" rel="L11741"></li>
<li class="L11742" rel="L11742"></li>
<li class="L11743" rel="L11743"></li>
<li class="L11744" rel="L11744"></li>
<li class="L11745" rel="L11745">VI. Triumph</li>
<li class="L11746" rel="L11746"></li>
<li class="L11747" rel="L11747"></li>
<li class="L11748" rel="L11748">The dread tribunal of five Judges, Public Prosecutor, and determined</li>
<li class="L11749" rel="L11749">Jury, sat every day. Their lists went forth every evening, and were</li>
<li class="L11750" rel="L11750">read out by the gaolers of the various prisons to their prisoners. The</li>
<li class="L11751" rel="L11751">standard gaoler-joke was, “Come out and listen to the Evening Paper, you</li>
<li class="L11752" rel="L11752">inside there!”</li>
<li class="L11753" rel="L11753"></li>
<li class="L11754" rel="L11754">“Charles Evremonde, called Darnay!”</li>
<li class="L11755" rel="L11755"></li>
<li class="L11756" rel="L11756">So at last began the Evening Paper at La Force.</li>
<li class="L11757" rel="L11757"></li>
<li class="L11758" rel="L11758">When a name was called, its owner stepped apart into a spot reserved</li>
<li class="L11759" rel="L11759">for those who were announced as being thus fatally recorded. Charles</li>
<li class="L11760" rel="L11760">Evremonde, called Darnay, had reason to know the usage; he had seen</li>
<li class="L11761" rel="L11761">hundreds pass away so.</li>
<li class="L11762" rel="L11762"></li>
<li class="L11763" rel="L11763">His bloated gaoler, who wore spectacles to read with, glanced over them</li>
<li class="L11764" rel="L11764">to assure himself that he had taken his place, and went through the</li>
<li class="L11765" rel="L11765">list, making a similar short pause at each name. There were twenty-three</li>
<li class="L11766" rel="L11766">names, but only twenty were responded to; for one of the prisoners so</li>
<li class="L11767" rel="L11767">summoned had died in gaol and been forgotten, and two had already been</li>
<li class="L11768" rel="L11768">guillotined and forgotten. The list was read, in the vaulted chamber</li>
<li class="L11769" rel="L11769">where Darnay had seen the associated prisoners on the night of his</li>
<li class="L11770" rel="L11770">arrival. Every one of those had perished in the massacre; every human</li>
<li class="L11771" rel="L11771">creature he had since cared for and parted with, had died on the</li>
<li class="L11772" rel="L11772">scaffold.</li>
<li class="L11773" rel="L11773"></li>
<li class="L11774" rel="L11774">There were hurried words of farewell and kindness, but the parting was</li>
<li class="L11775" rel="L11775">soon over. It was the incident of every day, and the society of La Force</li>
<li class="L11776" rel="L11776">were engaged in the preparation of some games of forfeits and a little</li>
<li class="L11777" rel="L11777">concert, for that evening. They crowded to the grates and shed tears</li>
<li class="L11778" rel="L11778">there; but, twenty places in the projected entertainments had to be</li>
<li class="L11779" rel="L11779">refilled, and the time was, at best, short to the lock-up hour, when the</li>
<li class="L11780" rel="L11780">common rooms and corridors would be delivered over to the great dogs</li>
<li class="L11781" rel="L11781">who kept watch there through the night. The prisoners were far from</li>
<li class="L11782" rel="L11782">insensible or unfeeling; their ways arose out of the condition of the</li>
<li class="L11783" rel="L11783">time. Similarly, though with a subtle difference, a species of fervour</li>
<li class="L11784" rel="L11784">or intoxication, known, without doubt, to have led some persons to</li>
<li class="L11785" rel="L11785">brave the guillotine unnecessarily, and to die by it, was not mere</li>
<li class="L11786" rel="L11786">boastfulness, but a wild infection of the wildly shaken public mind. In</li>
<li class="L11787" rel="L11787">seasons of pestilence, some of us will have a secret attraction to the</li>
<li class="L11788" rel="L11788">disease--a terrible passing inclination to die of it. And all of us have</li>
<li class="L11789" rel="L11789">like wonders hidden in our breasts, only needing circumstances to evoke</li>
<li class="L11790" rel="L11790">them.</li>
<li class="L11791" rel="L11791"></li>
<li class="L11792" rel="L11792">The passage to the Conciergerie was short and dark; the night in its</li>
<li class="L11793" rel="L11793">vermin-haunted cells was long and cold. Next day, fifteen prisoners were</li>
<li class="L11794" rel="L11794">put to the bar before Charles Darnay&#39;s name was called. All the fifteen</li>
<li class="L11795" rel="L11795">were condemned, and the trials of the whole occupied an hour and a half.</li>
<li class="L11796" rel="L11796"></li>
<li class="L11797" rel="L11797">“Charles Evremonde, called Darnay,” was at length arraigned.</li>
<li class="L11798" rel="L11798"></li>
<li class="L11799" rel="L11799">His judges sat upon the Bench in feathered hats; but the rough red cap</li>
<li class="L11800" rel="L11800">and tricoloured cockade was the head-dress otherwise prevailing. Looking</li>
<li class="L11801" rel="L11801">at the Jury and the turbulent audience, he might have thought that the</li>
<li class="L11802" rel="L11802">usual order of things was reversed, and that the felons were trying the</li>
<li class="L11803" rel="L11803">honest men. The lowest, cruelest, and worst populace of a city, never</li>
<li class="L11804" rel="L11804">without its quantity of low, cruel, and bad, were the directing</li>
<li class="L11805" rel="L11805">spirits of the scene: noisily commenting, applauding, disapproving,</li>
<li class="L11806" rel="L11806">anticipating, and precipitating the result, without a check. Of the men,</li>
<li class="L11807" rel="L11807">the greater part were armed in various ways; of the women, some wore</li>
<li class="L11808" rel="L11808">knives, some daggers, some ate and drank as they looked on, many</li>
<li class="L11809" rel="L11809">knitted. Among these last, was one, with a spare piece of knitting under</li>
<li class="L11810" rel="L11810">her arm as she worked. She was in a front row, by the side of a man whom</li>
<li class="L11811" rel="L11811">he had never seen since his arrival at the Barrier, but whom he directly</li>
<li class="L11812" rel="L11812">remembered as Defarge. He noticed that she once or twice whispered in</li>
<li class="L11813" rel="L11813">his ear, and that she seemed to be his wife; but, what he most noticed</li>
<li class="L11814" rel="L11814">in the two figures was, that although they were posted as close to</li>
<li class="L11815" rel="L11815">himself as they could be, they never looked towards him. They seemed to</li>
<li class="L11816" rel="L11816">be waiting for something with a dogged determination, and they looked at</li>
<li class="L11817" rel="L11817">the Jury, but at nothing else. Under the President sat Doctor Manette,</li>
<li class="L11818" rel="L11818">in his usual quiet dress. As well as the prisoner could see, he and Mr.</li>
<li class="L11819" rel="L11819">Lorry were the only men there, unconnected with the Tribunal, who</li>
<li class="L11820" rel="L11820">wore their usual clothes, and had not assumed the coarse garb of the</li>
<li class="L11821" rel="L11821">Carmagnole.</li>
<li class="L11822" rel="L11822"></li>
<li class="L11823" rel="L11823">Charles Evremonde, called Darnay, was accused by the public prosecutor</li>
<li class="L11824" rel="L11824">as an emigrant, whose life was forfeit to the Republic, under the decree</li>
<li class="L11825" rel="L11825">which banished all emigrants on pain of Death. It was nothing that the</li>
<li class="L11826" rel="L11826">decree bore date since his return to France. There he was, and there was</li>
<li class="L11827" rel="L11827">the decree; he had been taken in France, and his head was demanded.</li>
<li class="L11828" rel="L11828"></li>
<li class="L11829" rel="L11829">“Take off his head!” cried the audience. “An enemy to the Republic!”</li>
<li class="L11830" rel="L11830"></li>
<li class="L11831" rel="L11831">The President rang his bell to silence those cries, and asked the</li>
<li class="L11832" rel="L11832">prisoner whether it was not true that he had lived many years in</li>
<li class="L11833" rel="L11833">England?</li>
<li class="L11834" rel="L11834"></li>
<li class="L11835" rel="L11835">Undoubtedly it was.</li>
<li class="L11836" rel="L11836"></li>
<li class="L11837" rel="L11837">Was he not an emigrant then? What did he call himself?</li>
<li class="L11838" rel="L11838"></li>
<li class="L11839" rel="L11839">Not an emigrant, he hoped, within the sense and spirit of the law.</li>
<li class="L11840" rel="L11840"></li>
<li class="L11841" rel="L11841">Why not? the President desired to know.</li>
<li class="L11842" rel="L11842"></li>
<li class="L11843" rel="L11843">Because he had voluntarily relinquished a title that was distasteful</li>
<li class="L11844" rel="L11844">to him, and a station that was distasteful to him, and had left</li>
<li class="L11845" rel="L11845">his country--he submitted before the word emigrant in the present</li>
<li class="L11846" rel="L11846">acceptation by the Tribunal was in use--to live by his own industry in</li>
<li class="L11847" rel="L11847">England, rather than on the industry of the overladen people of France.</li>
<li class="L11848" rel="L11848"></li>
<li class="L11849" rel="L11849">What proof had he of this?</li>
<li class="L11850" rel="L11850"></li>
<li class="L11851" rel="L11851">He handed in the names of two witnesses; Theophile Gabelle, and</li>
<li class="L11852" rel="L11852">Alexandre Manette.</li>
<li class="L11853" rel="L11853"></li>
<li class="L11854" rel="L11854">But he had married in England? the President reminded him.</li>
<li class="L11855" rel="L11855"></li>
<li class="L11856" rel="L11856">True, but not an English woman.</li>
<li class="L11857" rel="L11857"></li>
<li class="L11858" rel="L11858">A citizeness of France?</li>
<li class="L11859" rel="L11859"></li>
<li class="L11860" rel="L11860">Yes. By birth.</li>
<li class="L11861" rel="L11861"></li>
<li class="L11862" rel="L11862">Her name and family?</li>
<li class="L11863" rel="L11863"></li>
<li class="L11864" rel="L11864">“Lucie Manette, only daughter of Doctor Manette, the good physician who</li>
<li class="L11865" rel="L11865">sits there.”</li>
<li class="L11866" rel="L11866"></li>
<li class="L11867" rel="L11867">This answer had a happy effect upon the audience. Cries in exaltation</li>
<li class="L11868" rel="L11868">of the well-known good physician rent the hall. So capriciously were</li>
<li class="L11869" rel="L11869">the people moved, that tears immediately rolled down several ferocious</li>
<li class="L11870" rel="L11870">countenances which had been glaring at the prisoner a moment before, as</li>
<li class="L11871" rel="L11871">if with impatience to pluck him out into the streets and kill him.</li>
<li class="L11872" rel="L11872"></li>
<li class="L11873" rel="L11873">On these few steps of his dangerous way, Charles Darnay had set his foot</li>
<li class="L11874" rel="L11874">according to Doctor Manette&#39;s reiterated instructions. The same cautious</li>
<li class="L11875" rel="L11875">counsel directed every step that lay before him, and had prepared every</li>
<li class="L11876" rel="L11876">inch of his road.</li>
<li class="L11877" rel="L11877"></li>
<li class="L11878" rel="L11878">The President asked, why had he returned to France when he did, and not</li>
<li class="L11879" rel="L11879">sooner?</li>
<li class="L11880" rel="L11880"></li>
<li class="L11881" rel="L11881">He had not returned sooner, he replied, simply because he had no means</li>
<li class="L11882" rel="L11882">of living in France, save those he had resigned; whereas, in England,</li>
<li class="L11883" rel="L11883">he lived by giving instruction in the French language and literature.</li>
<li class="L11884" rel="L11884">He had returned when he did, on the pressing and written entreaty of</li>
<li class="L11885" rel="L11885">a French citizen, who represented that his life was endangered by his</li>
<li class="L11886" rel="L11886">absence. He had come back, to save a citizen&#39;s life, and to bear his</li>
<li class="L11887" rel="L11887">testimony, at whatever personal hazard, to the truth. Was that criminal</li>
<li class="L11888" rel="L11888">in the eyes of the Republic?</li>
<li class="L11889" rel="L11889"></li>
<li class="L11890" rel="L11890">The populace cried enthusiastically, “No!” and the President rang his</li>
<li class="L11891" rel="L11891">bell to quiet them. Which it did not, for they continued to cry “No!”</li>
<li class="L11892" rel="L11892"> until they left off, of their own will.</li>
<li class="L11893" rel="L11893"></li>
<li class="L11894" rel="L11894">The President required the name of that citizen. The accused explained</li>
<li class="L11895" rel="L11895">that the citizen was his first witness. He also referred with confidence</li>
<li class="L11896" rel="L11896">to the citizen&#39;s letter, which had been taken from him at the Barrier,</li>
<li class="L11897" rel="L11897">but which he did not doubt would be found among the papers then before</li>
<li class="L11898" rel="L11898">the President.</li>
<li class="L11899" rel="L11899"></li>
<li class="L11900" rel="L11900">The Doctor had taken care that it should be there--had assured him that</li>
<li class="L11901" rel="L11901">it would be there--and at this stage of the proceedings it was produced</li>
<li class="L11902" rel="L11902">and read. Citizen Gabelle was called to confirm it, and did so. Citizen</li>
<li class="L11903" rel="L11903">Gabelle hinted, with infinite delicacy and politeness, that in the</li>
<li class="L11904" rel="L11904">pressure of business imposed on the Tribunal by the multitude of</li>
<li class="L11905" rel="L11905">enemies of the Republic with which it had to deal, he had been slightly</li>
<li class="L11906" rel="L11906">overlooked in his prison of the Abbaye--in fact, had rather passed out</li>
<li class="L11907" rel="L11907">of the Tribunal&#39;s patriotic remembrance--until three days ago; when he</li>
<li class="L11908" rel="L11908">had been summoned before it, and had been set at liberty on the Jury&#39;s</li>
<li class="L11909" rel="L11909">declaring themselves satisfied that the accusation against him was</li>
<li class="L11910" rel="L11910">answered, as to himself, by the surrender of the citizen Evremonde,</li>
<li class="L11911" rel="L11911">called Darnay.</li>
<li class="L11912" rel="L11912"></li>
<li class="L11913" rel="L11913">Doctor Manette was next questioned. His high personal popularity,</li>
<li class="L11914" rel="L11914">and the clearness of his answers, made a great impression; but, as he</li>
<li class="L11915" rel="L11915">proceeded, as he showed that the Accused was his first friend on his</li>
<li class="L11916" rel="L11916">release from his long imprisonment; that, the accused had remained in</li>
<li class="L11917" rel="L11917">England, always faithful and devoted to his daughter and himself in</li>
<li class="L11918" rel="L11918">their exile; that, so far from being in favour with the Aristocrat</li>
<li class="L11919" rel="L11919">government there, he had actually been tried for his life by it, as</li>
<li class="L11920" rel="L11920">the foe of England and friend of the United States--as he brought these</li>
<li class="L11921" rel="L11921">circumstances into view, with the greatest discretion and with the</li>
<li class="L11922" rel="L11922">straightforward force of truth and earnestness, the Jury and the</li>
<li class="L11923" rel="L11923">populace became one. At last, when he appealed by name to Monsieur</li>
<li class="L11924" rel="L11924">Lorry, an English gentleman then and there present, who, like himself,</li>
<li class="L11925" rel="L11925">had been a witness on that English trial and could corroborate his</li>
<li class="L11926" rel="L11926">account of it, the Jury declared that they had heard enough, and that</li>
<li class="L11927" rel="L11927">they were ready with their votes if the President were content to</li>
<li class="L11928" rel="L11928">receive them.</li>
<li class="L11929" rel="L11929"></li>
<li class="L11930" rel="L11930">At every vote (the Jurymen voted aloud and individually), the populace</li>
<li class="L11931" rel="L11931">set up a shout of applause. All the voices were in the prisoner&#39;s</li>
<li class="L11932" rel="L11932">favour, and the President declared him free.</li>
<li class="L11933" rel="L11933"></li>
<li class="L11934" rel="L11934">Then, began one of those extraordinary scenes with which the populace</li>
<li class="L11935" rel="L11935">sometimes gratified their fickleness, or their better impulses towards</li>
<li class="L11936" rel="L11936">generosity and mercy, or which they regarded as some set-off against</li>
<li class="L11937" rel="L11937">their swollen account of cruel rage. No man can decide now to which of</li>
<li class="L11938" rel="L11938">these motives such extraordinary scenes were referable; it is probable,</li>
<li class="L11939" rel="L11939">to a blending of all the three, with the second predominating. No sooner</li>
<li class="L11940" rel="L11940">was the acquittal pronounced, than tears were shed as freely as blood</li>
<li class="L11941" rel="L11941">at another time, and such fraternal embraces were bestowed upon the</li>
<li class="L11942" rel="L11942">prisoner by as many of both sexes as could rush at him, that after</li>
<li class="L11943" rel="L11943">his long and unwholesome confinement he was in danger of fainting from</li>
<li class="L11944" rel="L11944">exhaustion; none the less because he knew very well, that the very same</li>
<li class="L11945" rel="L11945">people, carried by another current, would have rushed at him with</li>
<li class="L11946" rel="L11946">the very same intensity, to rend him to pieces and strew him over the</li>
<li class="L11947" rel="L11947">streets.</li>
<li class="L11948" rel="L11948"></li>
<li class="L11949" rel="L11949">His removal, to make way for other accused persons who were to be tried,</li>
<li class="L11950" rel="L11950">rescued him from these caresses for the moment. Five were to be tried</li>
<li class="L11951" rel="L11951">together, next, as enemies of the Republic, forasmuch as they had not</li>
<li class="L11952" rel="L11952">assisted it by word or deed. So quick was the Tribunal to compensate</li>
<li class="L11953" rel="L11953">itself and the nation for a chance lost, that these five came down to</li>
<li class="L11954" rel="L11954">him before he left the place, condemned to die within twenty-four</li>
<li class="L11955" rel="L11955">hours. The first of them told him so, with the customary prison sign</li>
<li class="L11956" rel="L11956">of Death--a raised finger--and they all added in words, “Long live the</li>
<li class="L11957" rel="L11957">Republic!”</li>
<li class="L11958" rel="L11958"></li>
<li class="L11959" rel="L11959">The five had had, it is true, no audience to lengthen their proceedings,</li>
<li class="L11960" rel="L11960">for when he and Doctor Manette emerged from the gate, there was a great</li>
<li class="L11961" rel="L11961">crowd about it, in which there seemed to be every face he had seen in</li>
<li class="L11962" rel="L11962">Court--except two, for which he looked in vain. On his coming out, the</li>
<li class="L11963" rel="L11963">concourse made at him anew, weeping, embracing, and shouting, all by</li>
<li class="L11964" rel="L11964">turns and all together, until the very tide of the river on the bank of</li>
<li class="L11965" rel="L11965">which the mad scene was acted, seemed to run mad, like the people on the</li>
<li class="L11966" rel="L11966">shore.</li>
<li class="L11967" rel="L11967"></li>
<li class="L11968" rel="L11968">They put him into a great chair they had among them, and which they had</li>
<li class="L11969" rel="L11969">taken either out of the Court itself, or one of its rooms or passages.</li>
<li class="L11970" rel="L11970">Over the chair they had thrown a red flag, and to the back of it they</li>
<li class="L11971" rel="L11971">had bound a pike with a red cap on its top. In this car of triumph, not</li>
<li class="L11972" rel="L11972">even the Doctor&#39;s entreaties could prevent his being carried to his home</li>
<li class="L11973" rel="L11973">on men&#39;s shoulders, with a confused sea of red caps heaving about him,</li>
<li class="L11974" rel="L11974">and casting up to sight from the stormy deep such wrecks of faces, that</li>
<li class="L11975" rel="L11975">he more than once misdoubted his mind being in confusion, and that he</li>
<li class="L11976" rel="L11976">was in the tumbril on his way to the Guillotine.</li>
<li class="L11977" rel="L11977"></li>
<li class="L11978" rel="L11978">In wild dreamlike procession, embracing whom they met and pointing</li>
<li class="L11979" rel="L11979">him out, they carried him on. Reddening the snowy streets with the</li>
<li class="L11980" rel="L11980">prevailing Republican colour, in winding and tramping through them, as</li>
<li class="L11981" rel="L11981">they had reddened them below the snow with a deeper dye, they carried</li>
<li class="L11982" rel="L11982">him thus into the courtyard of the building where he lived. Her father</li>
<li class="L11983" rel="L11983">had gone on before, to prepare her, and when her husband stood upon his</li>
<li class="L11984" rel="L11984">feet, she dropped insensible in his arms.</li>
<li class="L11985" rel="L11985"></li>
<li class="L11986" rel="L11986">As he held her to his heart and turned her beautiful head between his</li>
<li class="L11987" rel="L11987">face and the brawling crowd, so that his tears and her lips might come</li>
<li class="L11988" rel="L11988">together unseen, a few of the people fell to dancing. Instantly, all the</li>
<li class="L11989" rel="L11989">rest fell to dancing, and the courtyard overflowed with the Carmagnole.</li>
<li class="L11990" rel="L11990">Then, they elevated into the vacant chair a young woman from the</li>
<li class="L11991" rel="L11991">crowd to be carried as the Goddess of Liberty, and then swelling and</li>
<li class="L11992" rel="L11992">overflowing out into the adjacent streets, and along the river&#39;s bank,</li>
<li class="L11993" rel="L11993">and over the bridge, the Carmagnole absorbed them every one and whirled</li>
<li class="L11994" rel="L11994">them away.</li>
<li class="L11995" rel="L11995"></li>
<li class="L11996" rel="L11996">After grasping the Doctor&#39;s hand, as he stood victorious and proud</li>
<li class="L11997" rel="L11997">before him; after grasping the hand of Mr. Lorry, who came panting in</li>
<li class="L11998" rel="L11998">breathless from his struggle against the waterspout of the Carmagnole;</li>
<li class="L11999" rel="L11999">after kissing little Lucie, who was lifted up to clasp her arms round</li>
<li class="L12000" rel="L12000">his neck; and after embracing the ever zealous and faithful Pross who</li>
<li class="L12001" rel="L12001">lifted her; he took his wife in his arms, and carried her up to their</li>
<li class="L12002" rel="L12002">rooms.</li>
<li class="L12003" rel="L12003"></li>
<li class="L12004" rel="L12004">“Lucie! My own! I am safe.”</li>
<li class="L12005" rel="L12005"></li>
<li class="L12006" rel="L12006">“O dearest Charles, let me thank God for this on my knees as I have</li>
<li class="L12007" rel="L12007">prayed to Him.”</li>
<li class="L12008" rel="L12008"></li>
<li class="L12009" rel="L12009">They all reverently bowed their heads and hearts. When she was again in</li>
<li class="L12010" rel="L12010">his arms, he said to her:</li>
<li class="L12011" rel="L12011"></li>
<li class="L12012" rel="L12012">“And now speak to your father, dearest. No other man in all this France</li>
<li class="L12013" rel="L12013">could have done what he has done for me.”</li>
<li class="L12014" rel="L12014"></li>
<li class="L12015" rel="L12015">She laid her head upon her father&#39;s breast, as she had laid his poor</li>
<li class="L12016" rel="L12016">head on her own breast, long, long ago. He was happy in the return he</li>
<li class="L12017" rel="L12017">had made her, he was recompensed for his suffering, he was proud of his</li>
<li class="L12018" rel="L12018">strength. “You must not be weak, my darling,” he remonstrated; “don&#39;t</li>
<li class="L12019" rel="L12019">tremble so. I have saved him.”</li>
<li class="L12020" rel="L12020"></li>
<li class="L12021" rel="L12021"></li>
<li class="L12022" rel="L12022"></li>
<li class="L12023" rel="L12023"></li>
<li class="L12024" rel="L12024">VII. A Knock at the Door</li>
<li class="L12025" rel="L12025"></li>
<li class="L12026" rel="L12026"></li>
<li class="L12027" rel="L12027">“I have saved him.” It was not another of the dreams in which he had</li>
<li class="L12028" rel="L12028">often come back; he was really here. And yet his wife trembled, and a</li>
<li class="L12029" rel="L12029">vague but heavy fear was upon her.</li>
<li class="L12030" rel="L12030"></li>
<li class="L12031" rel="L12031">All the air round was so thick and dark, the people were so passionately</li>
<li class="L12032" rel="L12032">revengeful and fitful, the innocent were so constantly put to death on</li>
<li class="L12033" rel="L12033">vague suspicion and black malice, it was so impossible to forget that</li>
<li class="L12034" rel="L12034">many as blameless as her husband and as dear to others as he was to</li>
<li class="L12035" rel="L12035">her, every day shared the fate from which he had been clutched, that her</li>
<li class="L12036" rel="L12036">heart could not be as lightened of its load as she felt it ought to be.</li>
<li class="L12037" rel="L12037">The shadows of the wintry afternoon were beginning to fall, and even now</li>
<li class="L12038" rel="L12038">the dreadful carts were rolling through the streets. Her mind pursued</li>
<li class="L12039" rel="L12039">them, looking for him among the Condemned; and then she clung closer to</li>
<li class="L12040" rel="L12040">his real presence and trembled more.</li>
<li class="L12041" rel="L12041"></li>
<li class="L12042" rel="L12042">Her father, cheering her, showed a compassionate superiority to this</li>
<li class="L12043" rel="L12043">woman&#39;s weakness, which was wonderful to see. No garret, no shoemaking,</li>
<li class="L12044" rel="L12044">no One Hundred and Five, North Tower, now! He had accomplished the task</li>
<li class="L12045" rel="L12045">he had set himself, his promise was redeemed, he had saved Charles. Let</li>
<li class="L12046" rel="L12046">them all lean upon him.</li>
<li class="L12047" rel="L12047"></li>
<li class="L12048" rel="L12048">Their housekeeping was of a very frugal kind: not only because that was</li>
<li class="L12049" rel="L12049">the safest way of life, involving the least offence to the people, but</li>
<li class="L12050" rel="L12050">because they were not rich, and Charles, throughout his imprisonment,</li>
<li class="L12051" rel="L12051">had had to pay heavily for his bad food, and for his guard, and towards</li>
<li class="L12052" rel="L12052">the living of the poorer prisoners. Partly on this account, and</li>
<li class="L12053" rel="L12053">partly to avoid a domestic spy, they kept no servant; the citizen and</li>
<li class="L12054" rel="L12054">citizeness who acted as porters at the courtyard gate, rendered them</li>
<li class="L12055" rel="L12055">occasional service; and Jerry (almost wholly transferred to them by</li>
<li class="L12056" rel="L12056">Mr. Lorry) had become their daily retainer, and had his bed there every</li>
<li class="L12057" rel="L12057">night.</li>
<li class="L12058" rel="L12058"></li>
<li class="L12059" rel="L12059">It was an ordinance of the Republic One and Indivisible of Liberty,</li>
<li class="L12060" rel="L12060">Equality, Fraternity, or Death, that on the door or doorpost of every</li>
<li class="L12061" rel="L12061">house, the name of every inmate must be legibly inscribed in letters</li>
<li class="L12062" rel="L12062">of a certain size, at a certain convenient height from the ground. Mr.</li>
<li class="L12063" rel="L12063">Jerry Cruncher&#39;s name, therefore, duly embellished the doorpost down</li>
<li class="L12064" rel="L12064">below; and, as the afternoon shadows deepened, the owner of that name</li>
<li class="L12065" rel="L12065">himself appeared, from overlooking a painter whom Doctor Manette had</li>
<li class="L12066" rel="L12066">employed to add to the list the name of Charles Evremonde, called</li>
<li class="L12067" rel="L12067">Darnay.</li>
<li class="L12068" rel="L12068"></li>
<li class="L12069" rel="L12069">In the universal fear and distrust that darkened the time, all the usual</li>
<li class="L12070" rel="L12070">harmless ways of life were changed. In the Doctor&#39;s little household, as</li>
<li class="L12071" rel="L12071">in very many others, the articles of daily consumption that were wanted</li>
<li class="L12072" rel="L12072">were purchased every evening, in small quantities and at various small</li>
<li class="L12073" rel="L12073">shops. To avoid attracting notice, and to give as little occasion as</li>
<li class="L12074" rel="L12074">possible for talk and envy, was the general desire.</li>
<li class="L12075" rel="L12075"></li>
<li class="L12076" rel="L12076">For some months past, Miss Pross and Mr. Cruncher had discharged the</li>
<li class="L12077" rel="L12077">office of purveyors; the former carrying the money; the latter, the</li>
<li class="L12078" rel="L12078">basket. Every afternoon at about the time when the public lamps were</li>
<li class="L12079" rel="L12079">lighted, they fared forth on this duty, and made and brought home</li>
<li class="L12080" rel="L12080">such purchases as were needful. Although Miss Pross, through her long</li>
<li class="L12081" rel="L12081">association with a French family, might have known as much of their</li>
<li class="L12082" rel="L12082">language as of her own, if she had had a mind, she had no mind in that</li>
<li class="L12083" rel="L12083">direction; consequently she knew no more of that “nonsense” (as she was</li>
<li class="L12084" rel="L12084">pleased to call it) than Mr. Cruncher did. So her manner of marketing</li>
<li class="L12085" rel="L12085">was to plump a noun-substantive at the head of a shopkeeper without any</li>
<li class="L12086" rel="L12086">introduction in the nature of an article, and, if it happened not to be</li>
<li class="L12087" rel="L12087">the name of the thing she wanted, to look round for that thing, lay hold</li>
<li class="L12088" rel="L12088">of it, and hold on by it until the bargain was concluded. She always</li>
<li class="L12089" rel="L12089">made a bargain for it, by holding up, as a statement of its just price,</li>
<li class="L12090" rel="L12090">one finger less than the merchant held up, whatever his number might be.</li>
<li class="L12091" rel="L12091"></li>
<li class="L12092" rel="L12092">“Now, Mr. Cruncher,” said Miss Pross, whose eyes were red with felicity;</li>
<li class="L12093" rel="L12093">“if you are ready, I am.”</li>
<li class="L12094" rel="L12094"></li>
<li class="L12095" rel="L12095">Jerry hoarsely professed himself at Miss Pross&#39;s service. He had worn</li>
<li class="L12096" rel="L12096">all his rust off long ago, but nothing would file his spiky head down.</li>
<li class="L12097" rel="L12097"></li>
<li class="L12098" rel="L12098">“There&#39;s all manner of things wanted,” said Miss Pross, “and we shall</li>
<li class="L12099" rel="L12099">have a precious time of it. We want wine, among the rest. Nice toasts</li>
<li class="L12100" rel="L12100">these Redheads will be drinking, wherever we buy it.”</li>
<li class="L12101" rel="L12101"></li>
<li class="L12102" rel="L12102">“It will be much the same to your knowledge, miss, I should think,”</li>
<li class="L12103" rel="L12103"> retorted Jerry, “whether they drink your health or the Old Un&#39;s.”</li>
<li class="L12104" rel="L12104"></li>
<li class="L12105" rel="L12105">“Who&#39;s he?” said Miss Pross.</li>
<li class="L12106" rel="L12106"></li>
<li class="L12107" rel="L12107">Mr. Cruncher, with some diffidence, explained himself as meaning “Old</li>
<li class="L12108" rel="L12108">Nick&#39;s.”</li>
<li class="L12109" rel="L12109"></li>
<li class="L12110" rel="L12110">“Ha!” said Miss Pross, “it doesn&#39;t need an interpreter to explain the</li>
<li class="L12111" rel="L12111">meaning of these creatures. They have but one, and it&#39;s Midnight Murder,</li>
<li class="L12112" rel="L12112">and Mischief.”</li>
<li class="L12113" rel="L12113"></li>
<li class="L12114" rel="L12114">“Hush, dear! Pray, pray, be cautious!” cried Lucie.</li>
<li class="L12115" rel="L12115"></li>
<li class="L12116" rel="L12116">“Yes, yes, yes, I&#39;ll be cautious,” said Miss Pross; “but I may say</li>
<li class="L12117" rel="L12117">among ourselves, that I do hope there will be no oniony and tobaccoey</li>
<li class="L12118" rel="L12118">smotherings in the form of embracings all round, going on in the</li>
<li class="L12119" rel="L12119">streets. Now, Ladybird, never you stir from that fire till I come back!</li>
<li class="L12120" rel="L12120">Take care of the dear husband you have recovered, and don&#39;t move your</li>
<li class="L12121" rel="L12121">pretty head from his shoulder as you have it now, till you see me again!</li>
<li class="L12122" rel="L12122">May I ask a question, Doctor Manette, before I go?”</li>
<li class="L12123" rel="L12123"></li>
<li class="L12124" rel="L12124">“I think you may take that liberty,” the Doctor answered, smiling.</li>
<li class="L12125" rel="L12125"></li>
<li class="L12126" rel="L12126">“For gracious sake, don&#39;t talk about Liberty; we have quite enough of</li>
<li class="L12127" rel="L12127">that,” said Miss Pross.</li>
<li class="L12128" rel="L12128"></li>
<li class="L12129" rel="L12129">“Hush, dear! Again?” Lucie remonstrated.</li>
<li class="L12130" rel="L12130"></li>
<li class="L12131" rel="L12131">“Well, my sweet,” said Miss Pross, nodding her head emphatically, “the</li>
<li class="L12132" rel="L12132">short and the long of it is, that I am a subject of His Most Gracious</li>
<li class="L12133" rel="L12133">Majesty King George the Third;” Miss Pross curtseyed at the name; “and</li>
<li class="L12134" rel="L12134">as such, my maxim is, Confound their politics, Frustrate their knavish</li>
<li class="L12135" rel="L12135">tricks, On him our hopes we fix, God save the King!”</li>
<li class="L12136" rel="L12136"></li>
<li class="L12137" rel="L12137">Mr. Cruncher, in an access of loyalty, growlingly repeated the words</li>
<li class="L12138" rel="L12138">after Miss Pross, like somebody at church.</li>
<li class="L12139" rel="L12139"></li>
<li class="L12140" rel="L12140">“I am glad you have so much of the Englishman in you, though I wish you</li>
<li class="L12141" rel="L12141">had never taken that cold in your voice,” said Miss Pross, approvingly.</li>
<li class="L12142" rel="L12142">“But the question, Doctor Manette. Is there”--it was the good creature&#39;s</li>
<li class="L12143" rel="L12143">way to affect to make light of anything that was a great anxiety</li>
<li class="L12144" rel="L12144">with them all, and to come at it in this chance manner--“is there any</li>
<li class="L12145" rel="L12145">prospect yet, of our getting out of this place?”</li>
<li class="L12146" rel="L12146"></li>
<li class="L12147" rel="L12147">“I fear not yet. It would be dangerous for Charles yet.”</li>
<li class="L12148" rel="L12148"></li>
<li class="L12149" rel="L12149">“Heigh-ho-hum!” said Miss Pross, cheerfully repressing a sigh as she</li>
<li class="L12150" rel="L12150">glanced at her darling&#39;s golden hair in the light of the fire, “then we</li>
<li class="L12151" rel="L12151">must have patience and wait: that&#39;s all. We must hold up our heads and</li>
<li class="L12152" rel="L12152">fight low, as my brother Solomon used to say. Now, Mr. Cruncher!--Don&#39;t</li>
<li class="L12153" rel="L12153">you move, Ladybird!”</li>
<li class="L12154" rel="L12154"></li>
<li class="L12155" rel="L12155">They went out, leaving Lucie, and her husband, her father, and the</li>
<li class="L12156" rel="L12156">child, by a bright fire. Mr. Lorry was expected back presently from the</li>
<li class="L12157" rel="L12157">Banking House. Miss Pross had lighted the lamp, but had put it aside in</li>
<li class="L12158" rel="L12158">a corner, that they might enjoy the fire-light undisturbed. Little Lucie</li>
<li class="L12159" rel="L12159">sat by her grandfather with her hands clasped through his arm: and he,</li>
<li class="L12160" rel="L12160">in a tone not rising much above a whisper, began to tell her a story of</li>
<li class="L12161" rel="L12161">a great and powerful Fairy who had opened a prison-wall and let out</li>
<li class="L12162" rel="L12162">a captive who had once done the Fairy a service. All was subdued and</li>
<li class="L12163" rel="L12163">quiet, and Lucie was more at ease than she had been.</li>
<li class="L12164" rel="L12164"></li>
<li class="L12165" rel="L12165">“What is that?” she cried, all at once.</li>
<li class="L12166" rel="L12166"></li>
<li class="L12167" rel="L12167">“My dear!” said her father, stopping in his story, and laying his hand</li>
<li class="L12168" rel="L12168">on hers, “command yourself. What a disordered state you are in! The</li>
<li class="L12169" rel="L12169">least thing--nothing--startles you! _You_, your father&#39;s daughter!”</li>
<li class="L12170" rel="L12170"></li>
<li class="L12171" rel="L12171">“I thought, my father,” said Lucie, excusing herself, with a pale face</li>
<li class="L12172" rel="L12172">and in a faltering voice, “that I heard strange feet upon the stairs.”</li>
<li class="L12173" rel="L12173"></li>
<li class="L12174" rel="L12174">“My love, the staircase is as still as Death.”</li>
<li class="L12175" rel="L12175"></li>
<li class="L12176" rel="L12176">As he said the word, a blow was struck upon the door.</li>
<li class="L12177" rel="L12177"></li>
<li class="L12178" rel="L12178">“Oh father, father. What can this be! Hide Charles. Save him!”</li>
<li class="L12179" rel="L12179"></li>
<li class="L12180" rel="L12180">“My child,” said the Doctor, rising, and laying his hand upon her</li>
<li class="L12181" rel="L12181">shoulder, “I _have_ saved him. What weakness is this, my dear! Let me go</li>
<li class="L12182" rel="L12182">to the door.”</li>
<li class="L12183" rel="L12183"></li>
<li class="L12184" rel="L12184">He took the lamp in his hand, crossed the two intervening outer rooms,</li>
<li class="L12185" rel="L12185">and opened it. A rude clattering of feet over the floor, and four rough</li>
<li class="L12186" rel="L12186">men in red caps, armed with sabres and pistols, entered the room.</li>
<li class="L12187" rel="L12187"></li>
<li class="L12188" rel="L12188">“The Citizen Evremonde, called Darnay,” said the first.</li>
<li class="L12189" rel="L12189"></li>
<li class="L12190" rel="L12190">“Who seeks him?” answered Darnay.</li>
<li class="L12191" rel="L12191"></li>
<li class="L12192" rel="L12192">“I seek him. We seek him. I know you, Evremonde; I saw you before the</li>
<li class="L12193" rel="L12193">Tribunal to-day. You are again the prisoner of the Republic.”</li>
<li class="L12194" rel="L12194"></li>
<li class="L12195" rel="L12195">The four surrounded him, where he stood with his wife and child clinging</li>
<li class="L12196" rel="L12196">to him.</li>
<li class="L12197" rel="L12197"></li>
<li class="L12198" rel="L12198">“Tell me how and why am I again a prisoner?”</li>
<li class="L12199" rel="L12199"></li>
<li class="L12200" rel="L12200">“It is enough that you return straight to the Conciergerie, and will</li>
<li class="L12201" rel="L12201">know to-morrow. You are summoned for to-morrow.”</li>
<li class="L12202" rel="L12202"></li>
<li class="L12203" rel="L12203">Doctor Manette, whom this visitation had so turned into stone, that he</li>
<li class="L12204" rel="L12204">stood with the lamp in his hand, as if he were a statue made to hold it,</li>
<li class="L12205" rel="L12205">moved after these words were spoken, put the lamp down, and confronting</li>
<li class="L12206" rel="L12206">the speaker, and taking him, not ungently, by the loose front of his red</li>
<li class="L12207" rel="L12207">woollen shirt, said:</li>
<li class="L12208" rel="L12208"></li>
<li class="L12209" rel="L12209">“You know him, you have said. Do you know me?”</li>
<li class="L12210" rel="L12210"></li>
<li class="L12211" rel="L12211">“Yes, I know you, Citizen Doctor.”</li>
<li class="L12212" rel="L12212"></li>
<li class="L12213" rel="L12213">“We all know you, Citizen Doctor,” said the other three.</li>
<li class="L12214" rel="L12214"></li>
<li class="L12215" rel="L12215">He looked abstractedly from one to another, and said, in a lower voice,</li>
<li class="L12216" rel="L12216">after a pause:</li>
<li class="L12217" rel="L12217"></li>
<li class="L12218" rel="L12218">“Will you answer his question to me then? How does this happen?”</li>
<li class="L12219" rel="L12219"></li>
<li class="L12220" rel="L12220">“Citizen Doctor,” said the first, reluctantly, “he has been denounced to</li>
<li class="L12221" rel="L12221">the Section of Saint Antoine. This citizen,” pointing out the second who</li>
<li class="L12222" rel="L12222">had entered, “is from Saint Antoine.”</li>
<li class="L12223" rel="L12223"></li>
<li class="L12224" rel="L12224">The citizen here indicated nodded his head, and added:</li>
<li class="L12225" rel="L12225"></li>
<li class="L12226" rel="L12226">“He is accused by Saint Antoine.”</li>
<li class="L12227" rel="L12227"></li>
<li class="L12228" rel="L12228">“Of what?” asked the Doctor.</li>
<li class="L12229" rel="L12229"></li>
<li class="L12230" rel="L12230">“Citizen Doctor,” said the first, with his former reluctance, “ask no</li>
<li class="L12231" rel="L12231">more. If the Republic demands sacrifices from you, without doubt you as</li>
<li class="L12232" rel="L12232">a good patriot will be happy to make them. The Republic goes before all.</li>
<li class="L12233" rel="L12233">The People is supreme. Evremonde, we are pressed.”</li>
<li class="L12234" rel="L12234"></li>
<li class="L12235" rel="L12235">“One word,” the Doctor entreated. “Will you tell me who denounced him?”</li>
<li class="L12236" rel="L12236"></li>
<li class="L12237" rel="L12237">“It is against rule,” answered the first; “but you can ask Him of Saint</li>
<li class="L12238" rel="L12238">Antoine here.”</li>
<li class="L12239" rel="L12239"></li>
<li class="L12240" rel="L12240">The Doctor turned his eyes upon that man. Who moved uneasily on his</li>
<li class="L12241" rel="L12241">feet, rubbed his beard a little, and at length said:</li>
<li class="L12242" rel="L12242"></li>
<li class="L12243" rel="L12243">“Well! Truly it is against rule. But he is denounced--and gravely--by</li>
<li class="L12244" rel="L12244">the Citizen and Citizeness Defarge. And by one other.”</li>
<li class="L12245" rel="L12245"></li>
<li class="L12246" rel="L12246">“What other?”</li>
<li class="L12247" rel="L12247"></li>
<li class="L12248" rel="L12248">“Do _you_ ask, Citizen Doctor?”</li>
<li class="L12249" rel="L12249"></li>
<li class="L12250" rel="L12250">“Yes.”</li>
<li class="L12251" rel="L12251"></li>
<li class="L12252" rel="L12252">“Then,” said he of Saint Antoine, with a strange look, “you will be</li>
<li class="L12253" rel="L12253">answered to-morrow. Now, I am dumb!”</li>
<li class="L12254" rel="L12254"></li>
<li class="L12255" rel="L12255"></li>
<li class="L12256" rel="L12256"></li>
<li class="L12257" rel="L12257"></li>
<li class="L12258" rel="L12258">VIII. A Hand at Cards</li>
<li class="L12259" rel="L12259"></li>
<li class="L12260" rel="L12260"></li>
<li class="L12261" rel="L12261">Happily unconscious of the new calamity at home, Miss Pross threaded her</li>
<li class="L12262" rel="L12262">way along the narrow streets and crossed the river by the bridge of the</li>
<li class="L12263" rel="L12263">Pont-Neuf, reckoning in her mind the number of indispensable purchases</li>
<li class="L12264" rel="L12264">she had to make. Mr. Cruncher, with the basket, walked at her side. They</li>
<li class="L12265" rel="L12265">both looked to the right and to the left into most of the shops they</li>
<li class="L12266" rel="L12266">passed, had a wary eye for all gregarious assemblages of people, and</li>
<li class="L12267" rel="L12267">turned out of their road to avoid any very excited group of talkers. It</li>
<li class="L12268" rel="L12268">was a raw evening, and the misty river, blurred to the eye with blazing</li>
<li class="L12269" rel="L12269">lights and to the ear with harsh noises, showed where the barges were</li>
<li class="L12270" rel="L12270">stationed in which the smiths worked, making guns for the Army of the</li>
<li class="L12271" rel="L12271">Republic. Woe to the man who played tricks with _that_ Army, or got</li>
<li class="L12272" rel="L12272">undeserved promotion in it! Better for him that his beard had never</li>
<li class="L12273" rel="L12273">grown, for the National Razor shaved him close.</li>
<li class="L12274" rel="L12274"></li>
<li class="L12275" rel="L12275">Having purchased a few small articles of grocery, and a measure of oil</li>
<li class="L12276" rel="L12276">for the lamp, Miss Pross bethought herself of the wine they wanted.</li>
<li class="L12277" rel="L12277">After peeping into several wine-shops, she stopped at the sign of the</li>
<li class="L12278" rel="L12278">Good Republican Brutus of Antiquity, not far from the National Palace,</li>
<li class="L12279" rel="L12279">once (and twice) the Tuileries, where the aspect of things rather</li>
<li class="L12280" rel="L12280">took her fancy. It had a quieter look than any other place of the same</li>
<li class="L12281" rel="L12281">description they had passed, and, though red with patriotic caps, was</li>
<li class="L12282" rel="L12282">not so red as the rest. Sounding Mr. Cruncher, and finding him of her</li>
<li class="L12283" rel="L12283">opinion, Miss Pross resorted to the Good Republican Brutus of Antiquity,</li>
<li class="L12284" rel="L12284">attended by her cavalier.</li>
<li class="L12285" rel="L12285"></li>
<li class="L12286" rel="L12286">Slightly observant of the smoky lights; of the people, pipe in mouth,</li>
<li class="L12287" rel="L12287">playing with limp cards and yellow dominoes; of the one bare-breasted,</li>
<li class="L12288" rel="L12288">bare-armed, soot-begrimed workman reading a journal aloud, and of</li>
<li class="L12289" rel="L12289">the others listening to him; of the weapons worn, or laid aside to be</li>
<li class="L12290" rel="L12290">resumed; of the two or three customers fallen forward asleep, who in the</li>
<li class="L12291" rel="L12291">popular high-shouldered shaggy black spencer looked, in that attitude,</li>
<li class="L12292" rel="L12292">like slumbering bears or dogs; the two outlandish customers approached</li>
<li class="L12293" rel="L12293">the counter, and showed what they wanted.</li>
<li class="L12294" rel="L12294"></li>
<li class="L12295" rel="L12295">As their wine was measuring out, a man parted from another man in a</li>
<li class="L12296" rel="L12296">corner, and rose to depart. In going, he had to face Miss Pross. No</li>
<li class="L12297" rel="L12297">sooner did he face her, than Miss Pross uttered a scream, and clapped</li>
<li class="L12298" rel="L12298">her hands.</li>
<li class="L12299" rel="L12299"></li>
<li class="L12300" rel="L12300">In a moment, the whole company were on their feet. That somebody was</li>
<li class="L12301" rel="L12301">assassinated by somebody vindicating a difference of opinion was the</li>
<li class="L12302" rel="L12302">likeliest occurrence. Everybody looked to see somebody fall, but only</li>
<li class="L12303" rel="L12303">saw a man and a woman standing staring at each other; the man with all</li>
<li class="L12304" rel="L12304">the outward aspect of a Frenchman and a thorough Republican; the woman,</li>
<li class="L12305" rel="L12305">evidently English.</li>
<li class="L12306" rel="L12306"></li>
<li class="L12307" rel="L12307">What was said in this disappointing anti-climax, by the disciples of the</li>
<li class="L12308" rel="L12308">Good Republican Brutus of Antiquity, except that it was something very</li>
<li class="L12309" rel="L12309">voluble and loud, would have been as so much Hebrew or Chaldean to Miss</li>
<li class="L12310" rel="L12310">Pross and her protector, though they had been all ears. But, they had no</li>
<li class="L12311" rel="L12311">ears for anything in their surprise. For, it must be recorded, that</li>
<li class="L12312" rel="L12312">not only was Miss Pross lost in amazement and agitation, but,</li>
<li class="L12313" rel="L12313">Mr. Cruncher--though it seemed on his own separate and individual</li>
<li class="L12314" rel="L12314">account--was in a state of the greatest wonder.</li>
<li class="L12315" rel="L12315"></li>
<li class="L12316" rel="L12316">“What is the matter?” said the man who had caused Miss Pross to scream;</li>
<li class="L12317" rel="L12317">speaking in a vexed, abrupt voice (though in a low tone), and in</li>
<li class="L12318" rel="L12318">English.</li>
<li class="L12319" rel="L12319"></li>
<li class="L12320" rel="L12320">“Oh, Solomon, dear Solomon!” cried Miss Pross, clapping her hands again.</li>
<li class="L12321" rel="L12321">“After not setting eyes upon you or hearing of you for so long a time,</li>
<li class="L12322" rel="L12322">do I find you here!”</li>
<li class="L12323" rel="L12323"></li>
<li class="L12324" rel="L12324">“Don&#39;t call me Solomon. Do you want to be the death of me?” asked the</li>
<li class="L12325" rel="L12325">man, in a furtive, frightened way.</li>
<li class="L12326" rel="L12326"></li>
<li class="L12327" rel="L12327">“Brother, brother!” cried Miss Pross, bursting into tears. “Have I ever</li>
<li class="L12328" rel="L12328">been so hard with you that you ask me such a cruel question?”</li>
<li class="L12329" rel="L12329"></li>
<li class="L12330" rel="L12330">“Then hold your meddlesome tongue,” said Solomon, “and come out, if you</li>
<li class="L12331" rel="L12331">want to speak to me. Pay for your wine, and come out. Who&#39;s this man?”</li>
<li class="L12332" rel="L12332"></li>
<li class="L12333" rel="L12333">Miss Pross, shaking her loving and dejected head at her by no means</li>
<li class="L12334" rel="L12334">affectionate brother, said through her tears, “Mr. Cruncher.”</li>
<li class="L12335" rel="L12335"></li>
<li class="L12336" rel="L12336">“Let him come out too,” said Solomon. “Does he think me a ghost?”</li>
<li class="L12337" rel="L12337"></li>
<li class="L12338" rel="L12338">Apparently, Mr. Cruncher did, to judge from his looks. He said not a</li>
<li class="L12339" rel="L12339">word, however, and Miss Pross, exploring the depths of her reticule</li>
<li class="L12340" rel="L12340">through her tears with great difficulty paid for her wine. As she did</li>
<li class="L12341" rel="L12341">so, Solomon turned to the followers of the Good Republican Brutus</li>
<li class="L12342" rel="L12342">of Antiquity, and offered a few words of explanation in the French</li>
<li class="L12343" rel="L12343">language, which caused them all to relapse into their former places and</li>
<li class="L12344" rel="L12344">pursuits.</li>
<li class="L12345" rel="L12345"></li>
<li class="L12346" rel="L12346">“Now,” said Solomon, stopping at the dark street corner, “what do you</li>
<li class="L12347" rel="L12347">want?”</li>
<li class="L12348" rel="L12348"></li>
<li class="L12349" rel="L12349">“How dreadfully unkind in a brother nothing has ever turned my love away</li>
<li class="L12350" rel="L12350">from!” cried Miss Pross, “to give me such a greeting, and show me no</li>
<li class="L12351" rel="L12351">affection.”</li>
<li class="L12352" rel="L12352"></li>
<li class="L12353" rel="L12353">“There. Confound it! There,” said Solomon, making a dab at Miss Pross&#39;s</li>
<li class="L12354" rel="L12354">lips with his own. “Now are you content?”</li>
<li class="L12355" rel="L12355"></li>
<li class="L12356" rel="L12356">Miss Pross only shook her head and wept in silence.</li>
<li class="L12357" rel="L12357"></li>
<li class="L12358" rel="L12358">“If you expect me to be surprised,” said her brother Solomon, “I am not</li>
<li class="L12359" rel="L12359">surprised; I knew you were here; I know of most people who are here. If</li>
<li class="L12360" rel="L12360">you really don&#39;t want to endanger my existence--which I half believe you</li>
<li class="L12361" rel="L12361">do--go your ways as soon as possible, and let me go mine. I am busy. I</li>
<li class="L12362" rel="L12362">am an official.”</li>
<li class="L12363" rel="L12363"></li>
<li class="L12364" rel="L12364">“My English brother Solomon,” mourned Miss Pross, casting up her</li>
<li class="L12365" rel="L12365">tear-fraught eyes, “that had the makings in him of one of the best and</li>
<li class="L12366" rel="L12366">greatest of men in his native country, an official among foreigners, and</li>
<li class="L12367" rel="L12367">such foreigners! I would almost sooner have seen the dear boy lying in</li>
<li class="L12368" rel="L12368">his--”</li>
<li class="L12369" rel="L12369"></li>
<li class="L12370" rel="L12370">“I said so!” cried her brother, interrupting. “I knew it. You want to be</li>
<li class="L12371" rel="L12371">the death of me. I shall be rendered Suspected, by my own sister. Just</li>
<li class="L12372" rel="L12372">as I am getting on!”</li>
<li class="L12373" rel="L12373"></li>
<li class="L12374" rel="L12374">“The gracious and merciful Heavens forbid!” cried Miss Pross. “Far</li>
<li class="L12375" rel="L12375">rather would I never see you again, dear Solomon, though I have ever</li>
<li class="L12376" rel="L12376">loved you truly, and ever shall. Say but one affectionate word to me,</li>
<li class="L12377" rel="L12377">and tell me there is nothing angry or estranged between us, and I will</li>
<li class="L12378" rel="L12378">detain you no longer.”</li>
<li class="L12379" rel="L12379"></li>
<li class="L12380" rel="L12380">Good Miss Pross! As if the estrangement between them had come of any</li>
<li class="L12381" rel="L12381">culpability of hers. As if Mr. Lorry had not known it for a fact, years</li>
<li class="L12382" rel="L12382">ago, in the quiet corner in Soho, that this precious brother had spent</li>
<li class="L12383" rel="L12383">her money and left her!</li>
<li class="L12384" rel="L12384"></li>
<li class="L12385" rel="L12385">He was saying the affectionate word, however, with a far more grudging</li>
<li class="L12386" rel="L12386">condescension and patronage than he could have shown if their relative</li>
<li class="L12387" rel="L12387">merits and positions had been reversed (which is invariably the case,</li>
<li class="L12388" rel="L12388">all the world over), when Mr. Cruncher, touching him on the shoulder,</li>
<li class="L12389" rel="L12389">hoarsely and unexpectedly interposed with the following singular</li>
<li class="L12390" rel="L12390">question:</li>
<li class="L12391" rel="L12391"></li>
<li class="L12392" rel="L12392">“I say! Might I ask the favour? As to whether your name is John Solomon,</li>
<li class="L12393" rel="L12393">or Solomon John?”</li>
<li class="L12394" rel="L12394"></li>
<li class="L12395" rel="L12395">The official turned towards him with sudden distrust. He had not</li>
<li class="L12396" rel="L12396">previously uttered a word.</li>
<li class="L12397" rel="L12397"></li>
<li class="L12398" rel="L12398">“Come!” said Mr. Cruncher. “Speak out, you know.” (Which, by the way,</li>
<li class="L12399" rel="L12399">was more than he could do himself.) “John Solomon, or Solomon John? She</li>
<li class="L12400" rel="L12400">calls you Solomon, and she must know, being your sister. And _I_ know</li>
<li class="L12401" rel="L12401">you&#39;re John, you know. Which of the two goes first? And regarding that</li>
<li class="L12402" rel="L12402">name of Pross, likewise. That warn&#39;t your name over the water.”</li>
<li class="L12403" rel="L12403"></li>
<li class="L12404" rel="L12404">“What do you mean?”</li>
<li class="L12405" rel="L12405"></li>
<li class="L12406" rel="L12406">“Well, I don&#39;t know all I mean, for I can&#39;t call to mind what your name</li>
<li class="L12407" rel="L12407">was, over the water.”</li>
<li class="L12408" rel="L12408"></li>
<li class="L12409" rel="L12409">“No?”</li>
<li class="L12410" rel="L12410"></li>
<li class="L12411" rel="L12411">“No. But I&#39;ll swear it was a name of two syllables.”</li>
<li class="L12412" rel="L12412"></li>
<li class="L12413" rel="L12413">“Indeed?”</li>
<li class="L12414" rel="L12414"></li>
<li class="L12415" rel="L12415">“Yes. T&#39;other one&#39;s was one syllable. I know you. You was a spy--witness</li>
<li class="L12416" rel="L12416">at the Bailey. What, in the name of the Father of Lies, own father to</li>
<li class="L12417" rel="L12417">yourself, was you called at that time?”</li>
<li class="L12418" rel="L12418"></li>
<li class="L12419" rel="L12419">“Barsad,” said another voice, striking in.</li>
<li class="L12420" rel="L12420"></li>
<li class="L12421" rel="L12421">“That&#39;s the name for a thousand pound!” cried Jerry.</li>
<li class="L12422" rel="L12422"></li>
<li class="L12423" rel="L12423">The speaker who struck in, was Sydney Carton. He had his hands behind</li>
<li class="L12424" rel="L12424">him under the skirts of his riding-coat, and he stood at Mr. Cruncher&#39;s</li>
<li class="L12425" rel="L12425">elbow as negligently as he might have stood at the Old Bailey itself.</li>
<li class="L12426" rel="L12426"></li>
<li class="L12427" rel="L12427">“Don&#39;t be alarmed, my dear Miss Pross. I arrived at Mr. Lorry&#39;s, to his</li>
<li class="L12428" rel="L12428">surprise, yesterday evening; we agreed that I would not present myself</li>
<li class="L12429" rel="L12429">elsewhere until all was well, or unless I could be useful; I present</li>
<li class="L12430" rel="L12430">myself here, to beg a little talk with your brother. I wish you had a</li>
<li class="L12431" rel="L12431">better employed brother than Mr. Barsad. I wish for your sake Mr. Barsad</li>
<li class="L12432" rel="L12432">was not a Sheep of the Prisons.”</li>
<li class="L12433" rel="L12433"></li>
<li class="L12434" rel="L12434">Sheep was a cant word of the time for a spy, under the gaolers. The spy,</li>
<li class="L12435" rel="L12435">who was pale, turned paler, and asked him how he dared--</li>
<li class="L12436" rel="L12436"></li>
<li class="L12437" rel="L12437">“I&#39;ll tell you,” said Sydney. “I lighted on you, Mr. Barsad, coming out</li>
<li class="L12438" rel="L12438">of the prison of the Conciergerie while I was contemplating the walls,</li>
<li class="L12439" rel="L12439">an hour or more ago. You have a face to be remembered, and I remember</li>
<li class="L12440" rel="L12440">faces well. Made curious by seeing you in that connection, and having</li>
<li class="L12441" rel="L12441">a reason, to which you are no stranger, for associating you with</li>
<li class="L12442" rel="L12442">the misfortunes of a friend now very unfortunate, I walked in your</li>
<li class="L12443" rel="L12443">direction. I walked into the wine-shop here, close after you, and</li>
<li class="L12444" rel="L12444">sat near you. I had no difficulty in deducing from your unreserved</li>
<li class="L12445" rel="L12445">conversation, and the rumour openly going about among your admirers, the</li>
<li class="L12446" rel="L12446">nature of your calling. And gradually, what I had done at random, seemed</li>
<li class="L12447" rel="L12447">to shape itself into a purpose, Mr. Barsad.”</li>
<li class="L12448" rel="L12448"></li>
<li class="L12449" rel="L12449">“What purpose?” the spy asked.</li>
<li class="L12450" rel="L12450"></li>
<li class="L12451" rel="L12451">“It would be troublesome, and might be dangerous, to explain in the</li>
<li class="L12452" rel="L12452">street. Could you favour me, in confidence, with some minutes of your</li>
<li class="L12453" rel="L12453">company--at the office of Tellson&#39;s Bank, for instance?”</li>
<li class="L12454" rel="L12454"></li>
<li class="L12455" rel="L12455">“Under a threat?”</li>
<li class="L12456" rel="L12456"></li>
<li class="L12457" rel="L12457">“Oh! Did I say that?”</li>
<li class="L12458" rel="L12458"></li>
<li class="L12459" rel="L12459">“Then, why should I go there?”</li>
<li class="L12460" rel="L12460"></li>
<li class="L12461" rel="L12461">“Really, Mr. Barsad, I can&#39;t say, if you can&#39;t.”</li>
