<li class="L12462" rel="L12462"></li>
<li class="L12463" rel="L12463">“Do you mean that you won&#39;t say, sir?” the spy irresolutely asked.</li>
<li class="L12464" rel="L12464"></li>
<li class="L12465" rel="L12465">“You apprehend me very clearly, Mr. Barsad. I won&#39;t.”</li>
<li class="L12466" rel="L12466"></li>
<li class="L12467" rel="L12467">Carton&#39;s negligent recklessness of manner came powerfully in aid of his</li>
<li class="L12468" rel="L12468">quickness and skill, in such a business as he had in his secret mind,</li>
<li class="L12469" rel="L12469">and with such a man as he had to do with. His practised eye saw it, and</li>
<li class="L12470" rel="L12470">made the most of it.</li>
<li class="L12471" rel="L12471"></li>
<li class="L12472" rel="L12472">“Now, I told you so,” said the spy, casting a reproachful look at his</li>
<li class="L12473" rel="L12473">sister; “if any trouble comes of this, it&#39;s your doing.”</li>
<li class="L12474" rel="L12474"></li>
<li class="L12475" rel="L12475">“Come, come, Mr. Barsad!” exclaimed Sydney. “Don&#39;t be ungrateful.</li>
<li class="L12476" rel="L12476">But for my great respect for your sister, I might not have led up so</li>
<li class="L12477" rel="L12477">pleasantly to a little proposal that I wish to make for our mutual</li>
<li class="L12478" rel="L12478">satisfaction. Do you go with me to the Bank?”</li>
<li class="L12479" rel="L12479"></li>
<li class="L12480" rel="L12480">“I&#39;ll hear what you have got to say. Yes, I&#39;ll go with you.”</li>
<li class="L12481" rel="L12481"></li>
<li class="L12482" rel="L12482">“I propose that we first conduct your sister safely to the corner of her</li>
<li class="L12483" rel="L12483">own street. Let me take your arm, Miss Pross. This is not a good city,</li>
<li class="L12484" rel="L12484">at this time, for you to be out in, unprotected; and as your escort</li>
<li class="L12485" rel="L12485">knows Mr. Barsad, I will invite him to Mr. Lorry&#39;s with us. Are we</li>
<li class="L12486" rel="L12486">ready? Come then!”</li>
<li class="L12487" rel="L12487"></li>
<li class="L12488" rel="L12488">Miss Pross recalled soon afterwards, and to the end of her life</li>
<li class="L12489" rel="L12489">remembered, that as she pressed her hands on Sydney&#39;s arm and looked up</li>
<li class="L12490" rel="L12490">in his face, imploring him to do no hurt to Solomon, there was a braced</li>
<li class="L12491" rel="L12491">purpose in the arm and a kind of inspiration in the eyes, which not only</li>
<li class="L12492" rel="L12492">contradicted his light manner, but changed and raised the man. She was</li>
<li class="L12493" rel="L12493">too much occupied then with fears for the brother who so little deserved</li>
<li class="L12494" rel="L12494">her affection, and with Sydney&#39;s friendly reassurances, adequately to</li>
<li class="L12495" rel="L12495">heed what she observed.</li>
<li class="L12496" rel="L12496"></li>
<li class="L12497" rel="L12497">They left her at the corner of the street, and Carton led the way to Mr.</li>
<li class="L12498" rel="L12498">Lorry&#39;s, which was within a few minutes&#39; walk. John Barsad, or Solomon</li>
<li class="L12499" rel="L12499">Pross, walked at his side.</li>
<li class="L12500" rel="L12500"></li>
<li class="L12501" rel="L12501">Mr. Lorry had just finished his dinner, and was sitting before a cheery</li>
<li class="L12502" rel="L12502">little log or two of fire--perhaps looking into their blaze for the</li>
<li class="L12503" rel="L12503">picture of that younger elderly gentleman from Tellson&#39;s, who had looked</li>
<li class="L12504" rel="L12504">into the red coals at the Royal George at Dover, now a good many years</li>
<li class="L12505" rel="L12505">ago. He turned his head as they entered, and showed the surprise with</li>
<li class="L12506" rel="L12506">which he saw a stranger.</li>
<li class="L12507" rel="L12507"></li>
<li class="L12508" rel="L12508">“Miss Pross&#39;s brother, sir,” said Sydney. “Mr. Barsad.”</li>
<li class="L12509" rel="L12509"></li>
<li class="L12510" rel="L12510">“Barsad?” repeated the old gentleman, “Barsad? I have an association</li>
<li class="L12511" rel="L12511">with the name--and with the face.”</li>
<li class="L12512" rel="L12512"></li>
<li class="L12513" rel="L12513">“I told you you had a remarkable face, Mr. Barsad,” observed Carton,</li>
<li class="L12514" rel="L12514">coolly. “Pray sit down.”</li>
<li class="L12515" rel="L12515"></li>
<li class="L12516" rel="L12516">As he took a chair himself, he supplied the link that Mr. Lorry wanted,</li>
<li class="L12517" rel="L12517">by saying to him with a frown, “Witness at that trial.” Mr. Lorry</li>
<li class="L12518" rel="L12518">immediately remembered, and regarded his new visitor with an undisguised</li>
<li class="L12519" rel="L12519">look of abhorrence.</li>
<li class="L12520" rel="L12520"></li>
<li class="L12521" rel="L12521">“Mr. Barsad has been recognised by Miss Pross as the affectionate</li>
<li class="L12522" rel="L12522">brother you have heard of,” said Sydney, “and has acknowledged the</li>
<li class="L12523" rel="L12523">relationship. I pass to worse news. Darnay has been arrested again.”</li>
<li class="L12524" rel="L12524"></li>
<li class="L12525" rel="L12525">Struck with consternation, the old gentleman exclaimed, “What do you</li>
<li class="L12526" rel="L12526">tell me! I left him safe and free within these two hours, and am about</li>
<li class="L12527" rel="L12527">to return to him!”</li>
<li class="L12528" rel="L12528"></li>
<li class="L12529" rel="L12529">“Arrested for all that. When was it done, Mr. Barsad?”</li>
<li class="L12530" rel="L12530"></li>
<li class="L12531" rel="L12531">“Just now, if at all.”</li>
<li class="L12532" rel="L12532"></li>
<li class="L12533" rel="L12533">“Mr. Barsad is the best authority possible, sir,” said Sydney, “and I</li>
<li class="L12534" rel="L12534">have it from Mr. Barsad&#39;s communication to a friend and brother Sheep</li>
<li class="L12535" rel="L12535">over a bottle of wine, that the arrest has taken place. He left the</li>
<li class="L12536" rel="L12536">messengers at the gate, and saw them admitted by the porter. There is no</li>
<li class="L12537" rel="L12537">earthly doubt that he is retaken.”</li>
<li class="L12538" rel="L12538"></li>
<li class="L12539" rel="L12539">Mr. Lorry&#39;s business eye read in the speaker&#39;s face that it was loss</li>
<li class="L12540" rel="L12540">of time to dwell upon the point. Confused, but sensible that something</li>
<li class="L12541" rel="L12541">might depend on his presence of mind, he commanded himself, and was</li>
<li class="L12542" rel="L12542">silently attentive.</li>
<li class="L12543" rel="L12543"></li>
<li class="L12544" rel="L12544">“Now, I trust,” said Sydney to him, “that the name and influence of</li>
<li class="L12545" rel="L12545">Doctor Manette may stand him in as good stead to-morrow--you said he</li>
<li class="L12546" rel="L12546">would be before the Tribunal again to-morrow, Mr. Barsad?--”</li>
<li class="L12547" rel="L12547"></li>
<li class="L12548" rel="L12548">“Yes; I believe so.”</li>
<li class="L12549" rel="L12549"></li>
<li class="L12550" rel="L12550">“--In as good stead to-morrow as to-day. But it may not be so. I own</li>
<li class="L12551" rel="L12551">to you, I am shaken, Mr. Lorry, by Doctor Manette&#39;s not having had the</li>
<li class="L12552" rel="L12552">power to prevent this arrest.”</li>
<li class="L12553" rel="L12553"></li>
<li class="L12554" rel="L12554">“He may not have known of it beforehand,” said Mr. Lorry.</li>
<li class="L12555" rel="L12555"></li>
<li class="L12556" rel="L12556">“But that very circumstance would be alarming, when we remember how</li>
<li class="L12557" rel="L12557">identified he is with his son-in-law.”</li>
<li class="L12558" rel="L12558"></li>
<li class="L12559" rel="L12559">“That&#39;s true,” Mr. Lorry acknowledged, with his troubled hand at his</li>
<li class="L12560" rel="L12560">chin, and his troubled eyes on Carton.</li>
<li class="L12561" rel="L12561"></li>
<li class="L12562" rel="L12562">“In short,” said Sydney, “this is a desperate time, when desperate games</li>
<li class="L12563" rel="L12563">are played for desperate stakes. Let the Doctor play the winning game; I</li>
<li class="L12564" rel="L12564">will play the losing one. No man&#39;s life here is worth purchase. Any one</li>
<li class="L12565" rel="L12565">carried home by the people to-day, may be condemned tomorrow. Now, the</li>
<li class="L12566" rel="L12566">stake I have resolved to play for, in case of the worst, is a friend</li>
<li class="L12567" rel="L12567">in the Conciergerie. And the friend I purpose to myself to win, is Mr.</li>
<li class="L12568" rel="L12568">Barsad.”</li>
<li class="L12569" rel="L12569"></li>
<li class="L12570" rel="L12570">“You need have good cards, sir,” said the spy.</li>
<li class="L12571" rel="L12571"></li>
<li class="L12572" rel="L12572">“I&#39;ll run them over. I&#39;ll see what I hold,--Mr. Lorry, you know what a</li>
<li class="L12573" rel="L12573">brute I am; I wish you&#39;d give me a little brandy.”</li>
<li class="L12574" rel="L12574"></li>
<li class="L12575" rel="L12575">It was put before him, and he drank off a glassful--drank off another</li>
<li class="L12576" rel="L12576">glassful--pushed the bottle thoughtfully away.</li>
<li class="L12577" rel="L12577"></li>
<li class="L12578" rel="L12578">“Mr. Barsad,” he went on, in the tone of one who really was looking</li>
<li class="L12579" rel="L12579">over a hand at cards: “Sheep of the prisons, emissary of Republican</li>
<li class="L12580" rel="L12580">committees, now turnkey, now prisoner, always spy and secret informer,</li>
<li class="L12581" rel="L12581">so much the more valuable here for being English that an Englishman</li>
<li class="L12582" rel="L12582">is less open to suspicion of subornation in those characters than a</li>
<li class="L12583" rel="L12583">Frenchman, represents himself to his employers under a false name.</li>
<li class="L12584" rel="L12584">That&#39;s a very good card. Mr. Barsad, now in the employ of the republican</li>
<li class="L12585" rel="L12585">French government, was formerly in the employ of the aristocratic</li>
<li class="L12586" rel="L12586">English government, the enemy of France and freedom. That&#39;s an excellent</li>
<li class="L12587" rel="L12587">card. Inference clear as day in this region of suspicion, that Mr.</li>
<li class="L12588" rel="L12588">Barsad, still in the pay of the aristocratic English government, is the</li>
<li class="L12589" rel="L12589">spy of Pitt, the treacherous foe of the Republic crouching in its bosom,</li>
<li class="L12590" rel="L12590">the English traitor and agent of all mischief so much spoken of and so</li>
<li class="L12591" rel="L12591">difficult to find. That&#39;s a card not to be beaten. Have you followed my</li>
<li class="L12592" rel="L12592">hand, Mr. Barsad?”</li>
<li class="L12593" rel="L12593"></li>
<li class="L12594" rel="L12594">“Not to understand your play,” returned the spy, somewhat uneasily.</li>
<li class="L12595" rel="L12595"></li>
<li class="L12596" rel="L12596">“I play my Ace, Denunciation of Mr. Barsad to the nearest Section</li>
<li class="L12597" rel="L12597">Committee. Look over your hand, Mr. Barsad, and see what you have. Don&#39;t</li>
<li class="L12598" rel="L12598">hurry.”</li>
<li class="L12599" rel="L12599"></li>
<li class="L12600" rel="L12600">He drew the bottle near, poured out another glassful of brandy, and</li>
<li class="L12601" rel="L12601">drank it off. He saw that the spy was fearful of his drinking himself</li>
<li class="L12602" rel="L12602">into a fit state for the immediate denunciation of him. Seeing it, he</li>
<li class="L12603" rel="L12603">poured out and drank another glassful.</li>
<li class="L12604" rel="L12604"></li>
<li class="L12605" rel="L12605">“Look over your hand carefully, Mr. Barsad. Take time.”</li>
<li class="L12606" rel="L12606"></li>
<li class="L12607" rel="L12607">It was a poorer hand than he suspected. Mr. Barsad saw losing cards</li>
<li class="L12608" rel="L12608">in it that Sydney Carton knew nothing of. Thrown out of his honourable</li>
<li class="L12609" rel="L12609">employment in England, through too much unsuccessful hard swearing</li>
<li class="L12610" rel="L12610">there--not because he was not wanted there; our English reasons for</li>
<li class="L12611" rel="L12611">vaunting our superiority to secrecy and spies are of very modern</li>
<li class="L12612" rel="L12612">date--he knew that he had crossed the Channel, and accepted service in</li>
<li class="L12613" rel="L12613">France: first, as a tempter and an eavesdropper among his own countrymen</li>
<li class="L12614" rel="L12614">there: gradually, as a tempter and an eavesdropper among the natives. He</li>
<li class="L12615" rel="L12615">knew that under the overthrown government he had been a spy upon Saint</li>
<li class="L12616" rel="L12616">Antoine and Defarge&#39;s wine-shop; had received from the watchful police</li>
<li class="L12617" rel="L12617">such heads of information concerning Doctor Manette&#39;s imprisonment,</li>
<li class="L12618" rel="L12618">release, and history, as should serve him for an introduction to</li>
<li class="L12619" rel="L12619">familiar conversation with the Defarges; and tried them on Madame</li>
<li class="L12620" rel="L12620">Defarge, and had broken down with them signally. He always remembered</li>
<li class="L12621" rel="L12621">with fear and trembling, that that terrible woman had knitted when he</li>
<li class="L12622" rel="L12622">talked with her, and had looked ominously at him as her fingers moved.</li>
<li class="L12623" rel="L12623">He had since seen her, in the Section of Saint Antoine, over and over</li>
<li class="L12624" rel="L12624">again produce her knitted registers, and denounce people whose lives the</li>
<li class="L12625" rel="L12625">guillotine then surely swallowed up. He knew, as every one employed as</li>
<li class="L12626" rel="L12626">he was did, that he was never safe; that flight was impossible; that</li>
<li class="L12627" rel="L12627">he was tied fast under the shadow of the axe; and that in spite of</li>
<li class="L12628" rel="L12628">his utmost tergiversation and treachery in furtherance of the reigning</li>
<li class="L12629" rel="L12629">terror, a word might bring it down upon him. Once denounced, and on such</li>
<li class="L12630" rel="L12630">grave grounds as had just now been suggested to his mind, he foresaw</li>
<li class="L12631" rel="L12631">that the dreadful woman of whose unrelenting character he had seen many</li>
<li class="L12632" rel="L12632">proofs, would produce against him that fatal register, and would quash</li>
<li class="L12633" rel="L12633">his last chance of life. Besides that all secret men are men soon</li>
<li class="L12634" rel="L12634">terrified, here were surely cards enough of one black suit, to justify</li>
<li class="L12635" rel="L12635">the holder in growing rather livid as he turned them over.</li>
<li class="L12636" rel="L12636"></li>
<li class="L12637" rel="L12637">“You scarcely seem to like your hand,” said Sydney, with the greatest</li>
<li class="L12638" rel="L12638">composure. “Do you play?”</li>
<li class="L12639" rel="L12639"></li>
<li class="L12640" rel="L12640">“I think, sir,” said the spy, in the meanest manner, as he turned to Mr.</li>
<li class="L12641" rel="L12641">Lorry, “I may appeal to a gentleman of your years and benevolence, to</li>
<li class="L12642" rel="L12642">put it to this other gentleman, so much your junior, whether he can</li>
<li class="L12643" rel="L12643">under any circumstances reconcile it to his station to play that Ace</li>
<li class="L12644" rel="L12644">of which he has spoken. I admit that _I_ am a spy, and that it is</li>
<li class="L12645" rel="L12645">considered a discreditable station--though it must be filled by</li>
<li class="L12646" rel="L12646">somebody; but this gentleman is no spy, and why should he so demean</li>
<li class="L12647" rel="L12647">himself as to make himself one?”</li>
<li class="L12648" rel="L12648"></li>
<li class="L12649" rel="L12649">“I play my Ace, Mr. Barsad,” said Carton, taking the answer on himself,</li>
<li class="L12650" rel="L12650">and looking at his watch, “without any scruple, in a very few minutes.”</li>
<li class="L12651" rel="L12651"></li>
<li class="L12652" rel="L12652">“I should have hoped, gentlemen both,” said the spy, always striving to</li>
<li class="L12653" rel="L12653">hook Mr. Lorry into the discussion, “that your respect for my sister--”</li>
<li class="L12654" rel="L12654"></li>
<li class="L12655" rel="L12655">“I could not better testify my respect for your sister than by finally</li>
<li class="L12656" rel="L12656">relieving her of her brother,” said Sydney Carton.</li>
<li class="L12657" rel="L12657"></li>
<li class="L12658" rel="L12658">“You think not, sir?”</li>
<li class="L12659" rel="L12659"></li>
<li class="L12660" rel="L12660">“I have thoroughly made up my mind about it.”</li>
<li class="L12661" rel="L12661"></li>
<li class="L12662" rel="L12662">The smooth manner of the spy, curiously in dissonance with his</li>
<li class="L12663" rel="L12663">ostentatiously rough dress, and probably with his usual demeanour,</li>
<li class="L12664" rel="L12664">received such a check from the inscrutability of Carton,--who was a</li>
<li class="L12665" rel="L12665">mystery to wiser and honester men than he,--that it faltered here and</li>
<li class="L12666" rel="L12666">failed him. While he was at a loss, Carton said, resuming his former air</li>
<li class="L12667" rel="L12667">of contemplating cards:</li>
<li class="L12668" rel="L12668"></li>
<li class="L12669" rel="L12669">“And indeed, now I think again, I have a strong impression that I</li>
<li class="L12670" rel="L12670">have another good card here, not yet enumerated. That friend and</li>
<li class="L12671" rel="L12671">fellow-Sheep, who spoke of himself as pasturing in the country prisons;</li>
<li class="L12672" rel="L12672">who was he?”</li>
<li class="L12673" rel="L12673"></li>
<li class="L12674" rel="L12674">“French. You don&#39;t know him,” said the spy, quickly.</li>
<li class="L12675" rel="L12675"></li>
<li class="L12676" rel="L12676">“French, eh?” repeated Carton, musing, and not appearing to notice him</li>
<li class="L12677" rel="L12677">at all, though he echoed his word. “Well; he may be.”</li>
<li class="L12678" rel="L12678"></li>
<li class="L12679" rel="L12679">“Is, I assure you,” said the spy; “though it&#39;s not important.”</li>
<li class="L12680" rel="L12680"></li>
<li class="L12681" rel="L12681">“Though it&#39;s not important,” repeated Carton, in the same mechanical</li>
<li class="L12682" rel="L12682">way--“though it&#39;s not important--No, it&#39;s not important. No. Yet I know</li>
<li class="L12683" rel="L12683">the face.”</li>
<li class="L12684" rel="L12684"></li>
<li class="L12685" rel="L12685">“I think not. I am sure not. It can&#39;t be,” said the spy.</li>
<li class="L12686" rel="L12686"></li>
<li class="L12687" rel="L12687">“It-can&#39;t-be,” muttered Sydney Carton, retrospectively, and idling his</li>
<li class="L12688" rel="L12688">glass (which fortunately was a small one) again. “Can&#39;t-be. Spoke good</li>
<li class="L12689" rel="L12689">French. Yet like a foreigner, I thought?”</li>
<li class="L12690" rel="L12690"></li>
<li class="L12691" rel="L12691">“Provincial,” said the spy.</li>
<li class="L12692" rel="L12692"></li>
<li class="L12693" rel="L12693">“No. Foreign!” cried Carton, striking his open hand on the table, as a</li>
<li class="L12694" rel="L12694">light broke clearly on his mind. “Cly! Disguised, but the same man. We</li>
<li class="L12695" rel="L12695">had that man before us at the Old Bailey.”</li>
<li class="L12696" rel="L12696"></li>
<li class="L12697" rel="L12697">“Now, there you are hasty, sir,” said Barsad, with a smile that gave his</li>
<li class="L12698" rel="L12698">aquiline nose an extra inclination to one side; “there you really give</li>
<li class="L12699" rel="L12699">me an advantage over you. Cly (who I will unreservedly admit, at this</li>
<li class="L12700" rel="L12700">distance of time, was a partner of mine) has been dead several years. I</li>
<li class="L12701" rel="L12701">attended him in his last illness. He was buried in London, at the church</li>
<li class="L12702" rel="L12702">of Saint Pancras-in-the-Fields. His unpopularity with the blackguard</li>
<li class="L12703" rel="L12703">multitude at the moment prevented my following his remains, but I helped</li>
<li class="L12704" rel="L12704">to lay him in his coffin.”</li>
<li class="L12705" rel="L12705"></li>
<li class="L12706" rel="L12706">Here, Mr. Lorry became aware, from where he sat, of a most remarkable</li>
<li class="L12707" rel="L12707">goblin shadow on the wall. Tracing it to its source, he discovered it</li>
<li class="L12708" rel="L12708">to be caused by a sudden extraordinary rising and stiffening of all the</li>
<li class="L12709" rel="L12709">risen and stiff hair on Mr. Cruncher&#39;s head.</li>
<li class="L12710" rel="L12710"></li>
<li class="L12711" rel="L12711">“Let us be reasonable,” said the spy, “and let us be fair. To show you</li>
<li class="L12712" rel="L12712">how mistaken you are, and what an unfounded assumption yours is, I will</li>
<li class="L12713" rel="L12713">lay before you a certificate of Cly&#39;s burial, which I happened to have</li>
<li class="L12714" rel="L12714">carried in my pocket-book,” with a hurried hand he produced and opened</li>
<li class="L12715" rel="L12715">it, “ever since. There it is. Oh, look at it, look at it! You may take</li>
<li class="L12716" rel="L12716">it in your hand; it&#39;s no forgery.”</li>
<li class="L12717" rel="L12717"></li>
<li class="L12718" rel="L12718">Here, Mr. Lorry perceived the reflection on the wall to elongate, and</li>
<li class="L12719" rel="L12719">Mr. Cruncher rose and stepped forward. His hair could not have been more</li>
<li class="L12720" rel="L12720">violently on end, if it had been that moment dressed by the Cow with the</li>
<li class="L12721" rel="L12721">crumpled horn in the house that Jack built.</li>
<li class="L12722" rel="L12722"></li>
<li class="L12723" rel="L12723">Unseen by the spy, Mr. Cruncher stood at his side, and touched him on</li>
<li class="L12724" rel="L12724">the shoulder like a ghostly bailiff.</li>
<li class="L12725" rel="L12725"></li>
<li class="L12726" rel="L12726">“That there Roger Cly, master,” said Mr. Cruncher, with a taciturn and</li>
<li class="L12727" rel="L12727">iron-bound visage. “So _you_ put him in his coffin?”</li>
<li class="L12728" rel="L12728"></li>
<li class="L12729" rel="L12729">“I did.”</li>
<li class="L12730" rel="L12730"></li>
<li class="L12731" rel="L12731">“Who took him out of it?”</li>
<li class="L12732" rel="L12732"></li>
<li class="L12733" rel="L12733">Barsad leaned back in his chair, and stammered, “What do you mean?”</li>
<li class="L12734" rel="L12734"></li>
<li class="L12735" rel="L12735">“I mean,” said Mr. Cruncher, “that he warn&#39;t never in it. No! Not he!</li>
<li class="L12736" rel="L12736">I&#39;ll have my head took off, if he was ever in it.”</li>
<li class="L12737" rel="L12737"></li>
<li class="L12738" rel="L12738">The spy looked round at the two gentlemen; they both looked in</li>
<li class="L12739" rel="L12739">unspeakable astonishment at Jerry.</li>
<li class="L12740" rel="L12740"></li>
<li class="L12741" rel="L12741">“I tell you,” said Jerry, “that you buried paving-stones and earth in</li>
<li class="L12742" rel="L12742">that there coffin. Don&#39;t go and tell me that you buried Cly. It was a</li>
<li class="L12743" rel="L12743">take in. Me and two more knows it.”</li>
<li class="L12744" rel="L12744"></li>
<li class="L12745" rel="L12745">“How do you know it?”</li>
<li class="L12746" rel="L12746"></li>
<li class="L12747" rel="L12747">“What&#39;s that to you? Ecod!” growled Mr. Cruncher, “it&#39;s you I have got a</li>
<li class="L12748" rel="L12748">old grudge again, is it, with your shameful impositions upon tradesmen!</li>
<li class="L12749" rel="L12749">I&#39;d catch hold of your throat and choke you for half a guinea.”</li>
<li class="L12750" rel="L12750"></li>
<li class="L12751" rel="L12751">Sydney Carton, who, with Mr. Lorry, had been lost in amazement at</li>
<li class="L12752" rel="L12752">this turn of the business, here requested Mr. Cruncher to moderate and</li>
<li class="L12753" rel="L12753">explain himself.</li>
<li class="L12754" rel="L12754"></li>
<li class="L12755" rel="L12755">“At another time, sir,” he returned, evasively, “the present time is</li>
<li class="L12756" rel="L12756">ill-conwenient for explainin&#39;. What I stand to, is, that he knows well</li>
<li class="L12757" rel="L12757">wot that there Cly was never in that there coffin. Let him say he was,</li>
<li class="L12758" rel="L12758">in so much as a word of one syllable, and I&#39;ll either catch hold of his</li>
<li class="L12759" rel="L12759">throat and choke him for half a guinea;” Mr. Cruncher dwelt upon this as</li>
<li class="L12760" rel="L12760">quite a liberal offer; “or I&#39;ll out and announce him.”</li>
<li class="L12761" rel="L12761"></li>
<li class="L12762" rel="L12762">“Humph! I see one thing,” said Carton. “I hold another card, Mr. Barsad.</li>
<li class="L12763" rel="L12763">Impossible, here in raging Paris, with Suspicion filling the air, for</li>
<li class="L12764" rel="L12764">you to outlive denunciation, when you are in communication with another</li>
<li class="L12765" rel="L12765">aristocratic spy of the same antecedents as yourself, who, moreover, has</li>
<li class="L12766" rel="L12766">the mystery about him of having feigned death and come to life again!</li>
<li class="L12767" rel="L12767">A plot in the prisons, of the foreigner against the Republic. A strong</li>
<li class="L12768" rel="L12768">card--a certain Guillotine card! Do you play?”</li>
<li class="L12769" rel="L12769"></li>
<li class="L12770" rel="L12770">“No!” returned the spy. “I throw up. I confess that we were so unpopular</li>
<li class="L12771" rel="L12771">with the outrageous mob, that I only got away from England at the risk</li>
<li class="L12772" rel="L12772">of being ducked to death, and that Cly was so ferreted up and down, that</li>
<li class="L12773" rel="L12773">he never would have got away at all but for that sham. Though how this</li>
<li class="L12774" rel="L12774">man knows it was a sham, is a wonder of wonders to me.”</li>
<li class="L12775" rel="L12775"></li>
<li class="L12776" rel="L12776">“Never you trouble your head about this man,” retorted the contentious</li>
<li class="L12777" rel="L12777">Mr. Cruncher; “you&#39;ll have trouble enough with giving your attention to</li>
<li class="L12778" rel="L12778">that gentleman. And look here! Once more!”--Mr. Cruncher could not</li>
<li class="L12779" rel="L12779">be restrained from making rather an ostentatious parade of his</li>
<li class="L12780" rel="L12780">liberality--“I&#39;d catch hold of your throat and choke you for half a</li>
<li class="L12781" rel="L12781">guinea.”</li>
<li class="L12782" rel="L12782"></li>
<li class="L12783" rel="L12783">The Sheep of the prisons turned from him to Sydney Carton, and said,</li>
<li class="L12784" rel="L12784">with more decision, “It has come to a point. I go on duty soon, and</li>
<li class="L12785" rel="L12785">can&#39;t overstay my time. You told me you had a proposal; what is it?</li>
<li class="L12786" rel="L12786">Now, it is of no use asking too much of me. Ask me to do anything in my</li>
<li class="L12787" rel="L12787">office, putting my head in great extra danger, and I had better trust my</li>
<li class="L12788" rel="L12788">life to the chances of a refusal than the chances of consent. In short,</li>
<li class="L12789" rel="L12789">I should make that choice. You talk of desperation. We are all desperate</li>
<li class="L12790" rel="L12790">here. Remember! I may denounce you if I think proper, and I can swear my</li>
<li class="L12791" rel="L12791">way through stone walls, and so can others. Now, what do you want with</li>
<li class="L12792" rel="L12792">me?”</li>
<li class="L12793" rel="L12793"></li>
<li class="L12794" rel="L12794">“Not very much. You are a turnkey at the Conciergerie?”</li>
<li class="L12795" rel="L12795"></li>
<li class="L12796" rel="L12796">“I tell you once for all, there is no such thing as an escape possible,”</li>
<li class="L12797" rel="L12797"> said the spy, firmly.</li>
<li class="L12798" rel="L12798"></li>
<li class="L12799" rel="L12799">“Why need you tell me what I have not asked? You are a turnkey at the</li>
<li class="L12800" rel="L12800">Conciergerie?”</li>
<li class="L12801" rel="L12801"></li>
<li class="L12802" rel="L12802">“I am sometimes.”</li>
<li class="L12803" rel="L12803"></li>
<li class="L12804" rel="L12804">“You can be when you choose?”</li>
<li class="L12805" rel="L12805"></li>
<li class="L12806" rel="L12806">“I can pass in and out when I choose.”</li>
<li class="L12807" rel="L12807"></li>
<li class="L12808" rel="L12808">Sydney Carton filled another glass with brandy, poured it slowly out</li>
<li class="L12809" rel="L12809">upon the hearth, and watched it as it dropped. It being all spent, he</li>
<li class="L12810" rel="L12810">said, rising:</li>
<li class="L12811" rel="L12811"></li>
<li class="L12812" rel="L12812">“So far, we have spoken before these two, because it was as well that</li>
<li class="L12813" rel="L12813">the merits of the cards should not rest solely between you and me. Come</li>
<li class="L12814" rel="L12814">into the dark room here, and let us have one final word alone.”</li>
<li class="L12815" rel="L12815"></li>
<li class="L12816" rel="L12816"></li>
<li class="L12817" rel="L12817"></li>
<li class="L12818" rel="L12818"></li>
<li class="L12819" rel="L12819">IX. The Game Made</li>
<li class="L12820" rel="L12820"></li>
<li class="L12821" rel="L12821"></li>
<li class="L12822" rel="L12822">While Sydney Carton and the Sheep of the prisons were in the adjoining</li>
<li class="L12823" rel="L12823">dark room, speaking so low that not a sound was heard, Mr. Lorry looked</li>
<li class="L12824" rel="L12824">at Jerry in considerable doubt and mistrust. That honest tradesman&#39;s</li>
<li class="L12825" rel="L12825">manner of receiving the look, did not inspire confidence; he changed the</li>
<li class="L12826" rel="L12826">leg on which he rested, as often as if he had fifty of those limbs,</li>
<li class="L12827" rel="L12827">and were trying them all; he examined his finger-nails with a very</li>
<li class="L12828" rel="L12828">questionable closeness of attention; and whenever Mr. Lorry&#39;s eye caught</li>
<li class="L12829" rel="L12829">his, he was taken with that peculiar kind of short cough requiring the</li>
<li class="L12830" rel="L12830">hollow of a hand before it, which is seldom, if ever, known to be an</li>
<li class="L12831" rel="L12831">infirmity attendant on perfect openness of character.</li>
<li class="L12832" rel="L12832"></li>
<li class="L12833" rel="L12833">“Jerry,” said Mr. Lorry. “Come here.”</li>
<li class="L12834" rel="L12834"></li>
<li class="L12835" rel="L12835">Mr. Cruncher came forward sideways, with one of his shoulders in advance</li>
<li class="L12836" rel="L12836">of him.</li>
<li class="L12837" rel="L12837"></li>
<li class="L12838" rel="L12838">“What have you been, besides a messenger?”</li>
<li class="L12839" rel="L12839"></li>
<li class="L12840" rel="L12840">After some cogitation, accompanied with an intent look at his patron,</li>
<li class="L12841" rel="L12841">Mr. Cruncher conceived the luminous idea of replying, “Agicultooral</li>
<li class="L12842" rel="L12842">character.”</li>
<li class="L12843" rel="L12843"></li>
<li class="L12844" rel="L12844">“My mind misgives me much,” said Mr. Lorry, angrily shaking a forefinger</li>
<li class="L12845" rel="L12845">at him, “that you have used the respectable and great house of Tellson&#39;s</li>
<li class="L12846" rel="L12846">as a blind, and that you have had an unlawful occupation of an infamous</li>
<li class="L12847" rel="L12847">description. If you have, don&#39;t expect me to befriend you when you</li>
<li class="L12848" rel="L12848">get back to England. If you have, don&#39;t expect me to keep your secret.</li>
<li class="L12849" rel="L12849">Tellson&#39;s shall not be imposed upon.”</li>
<li class="L12850" rel="L12850"></li>
<li class="L12851" rel="L12851">“I hope, sir,” pleaded the abashed Mr. Cruncher, “that a gentleman like</li>
<li class="L12852" rel="L12852">yourself wot I&#39;ve had the honour of odd jobbing till I&#39;m grey at it,</li>
<li class="L12853" rel="L12853">would think twice about harming of me, even if it wos so--I don&#39;t say it</li>
<li class="L12854" rel="L12854">is, but even if it wos. And which it is to be took into account that if</li>
<li class="L12855" rel="L12855">it wos, it wouldn&#39;t, even then, be all o&#39; one side. There&#39;d be two sides</li>
<li class="L12856" rel="L12856">to it. There might be medical doctors at the present hour, a picking</li>
<li class="L12857" rel="L12857">up their guineas where a honest tradesman don&#39;t pick up his</li>
<li class="L12858" rel="L12858">fardens--fardens! no, nor yet his half fardens--half fardens! no, nor</li>
<li class="L12859" rel="L12859">yet his quarter--a banking away like smoke at Tellson&#39;s, and a cocking</li>
<li class="L12860" rel="L12860">their medical eyes at that tradesman on the sly, a going in and going</li>
<li class="L12861" rel="L12861">out to their own carriages--ah! equally like smoke, if not more so.</li>
<li class="L12862" rel="L12862">Well, that &#39;ud be imposing, too, on Tellson&#39;s. For you cannot sarse the</li>
<li class="L12863" rel="L12863">goose and not the gander. And here&#39;s Mrs. Cruncher, or leastways wos</li>
<li class="L12864" rel="L12864">in the Old England times, and would be to-morrow, if cause given,</li>
<li class="L12865" rel="L12865">a floppin&#39; again the business to that degree as is ruinating--stark</li>
<li class="L12866" rel="L12866">ruinating! Whereas them medical doctors&#39; wives don&#39;t flop--catch &#39;em at</li>
<li class="L12867" rel="L12867">it! Or, if they flop, their floppings goes in favour of more patients,</li>
<li class="L12868" rel="L12868">and how can you rightly have one without t&#39;other? Then, wot with</li>
<li class="L12869" rel="L12869">undertakers, and wot with parish clerks, and wot with sextons, and wot</li>
<li class="L12870" rel="L12870">with private watchmen (all awaricious and all in it), a man wouldn&#39;t get</li>
<li class="L12871" rel="L12871">much by it, even if it wos so. And wot little a man did get, would never</li>
<li class="L12872" rel="L12872">prosper with him, Mr. Lorry. He&#39;d never have no good of it; he&#39;d want</li>
<li class="L12873" rel="L12873">all along to be out of the line, if he, could see his way out, being</li>
<li class="L12874" rel="L12874">once in--even if it wos so.”</li>
<li class="L12875" rel="L12875"></li>
<li class="L12876" rel="L12876">“Ugh!” cried Mr. Lorry, rather relenting, nevertheless, “I am shocked at</li>
<li class="L12877" rel="L12877">the sight of you.”</li>
<li class="L12878" rel="L12878"></li>
<li class="L12879" rel="L12879">“Now, what I would humbly offer to you, sir,” pursued Mr. Cruncher,</li>
<li class="L12880" rel="L12880">“even if it wos so, which I don&#39;t say it is--”</li>
<li class="L12881" rel="L12881"></li>
<li class="L12882" rel="L12882">“Don&#39;t prevaricate,” said Mr. Lorry.</li>
<li class="L12883" rel="L12883"></li>
<li class="L12884" rel="L12884">“No, I will _not_, sir,” returned Mr. Crunches as if nothing were</li>
<li class="L12885" rel="L12885">further from his thoughts or practice--“which I don&#39;t say it is--wot I</li>
<li class="L12886" rel="L12886">would humbly offer to you, sir, would be this. Upon that there stool, at</li>
<li class="L12887" rel="L12887">that there Bar, sets that there boy of mine, brought up and growed up to</li>
<li class="L12888" rel="L12888">be a man, wot will errand you, message you, general-light-job you, till</li>
<li class="L12889" rel="L12889">your heels is where your head is, if such should be your wishes. If it</li>
<li class="L12890" rel="L12890">wos so, which I still don&#39;t say it is (for I will not prewaricate to</li>
<li class="L12891" rel="L12891">you, sir), let that there boy keep his father&#39;s place, and take care of</li>
<li class="L12892" rel="L12892">his mother; don&#39;t blow upon that boy&#39;s father--do not do it, sir--and</li>
<li class="L12893" rel="L12893">let that father go into the line of the reg&#39;lar diggin&#39;, and make amends</li>
<li class="L12894" rel="L12894">for what he would have undug--if it wos so--by diggin&#39; of &#39;em in with</li>
<li class="L12895" rel="L12895">a will, and with conwictions respectin&#39; the futur&#39; keepin&#39; of &#39;em safe.</li>
<li class="L12896" rel="L12896">That, Mr. Lorry,” said Mr. Cruncher, wiping his forehead with his</li>
<li class="L12897" rel="L12897">arm, as an announcement that he had arrived at the peroration of his</li>
<li class="L12898" rel="L12898">discourse, “is wot I would respectfully offer to you, sir. A man don&#39;t</li>
<li class="L12899" rel="L12899">see all this here a goin&#39; on dreadful round him, in the way of Subjects</li>
<li class="L12900" rel="L12900">without heads, dear me, plentiful enough fur to bring the price down</li>
<li class="L12901" rel="L12901">to porterage and hardly that, without havin&#39; his serious thoughts of</li>
<li class="L12902" rel="L12902">things. And these here would be mine, if it wos so, entreatin&#39; of you</li>
<li class="L12903" rel="L12903">fur to bear in mind that wot I said just now, I up and said in the good</li>
<li class="L12904" rel="L12904">cause when I might have kep&#39; it back.”</li>
<li class="L12905" rel="L12905"></li>
<li class="L12906" rel="L12906">“That at least is true,” said Mr. Lorry. “Say no more now. It may be</li>
<li class="L12907" rel="L12907">that I shall yet stand your friend, if you deserve it, and repent in</li>
<li class="L12908" rel="L12908">action--not in words. I want no more words.”</li>
<li class="L12909" rel="L12909"></li>
<li class="L12910" rel="L12910">Mr. Cruncher knuckled his forehead, as Sydney Carton and the spy</li>
<li class="L12911" rel="L12911">returned from the dark room. “Adieu, Mr. Barsad,” said the former; “our</li>
<li class="L12912" rel="L12912">arrangement thus made, you have nothing to fear from me.”</li>
<li class="L12913" rel="L12913"></li>
<li class="L12914" rel="L12914">He sat down in a chair on the hearth, over against Mr. Lorry. When they</li>
<li class="L12915" rel="L12915">were alone, Mr. Lorry asked him what he had done?</li>
<li class="L12916" rel="L12916"></li>
<li class="L12917" rel="L12917">“Not much. If it should go ill with the prisoner, I have ensured access</li>
<li class="L12918" rel="L12918">to him, once.”</li>
<li class="L12919" rel="L12919"></li>
<li class="L12920" rel="L12920">Mr. Lorry&#39;s countenance fell.</li>
<li class="L12921" rel="L12921"></li>
<li class="L12922" rel="L12922">“It is all I could do,” said Carton. “To propose too much, would be</li>
<li class="L12923" rel="L12923">to put this man&#39;s head under the axe, and, as he himself said, nothing</li>
<li class="L12924" rel="L12924">worse could happen to him if he were denounced. It was obviously the</li>
<li class="L12925" rel="L12925">weakness of the position. There is no help for it.”</li>
<li class="L12926" rel="L12926"></li>
<li class="L12927" rel="L12927">“But access to him,” said Mr. Lorry, “if it should go ill before the</li>
<li class="L12928" rel="L12928">Tribunal, will not save him.”</li>
<li class="L12929" rel="L12929"></li>
<li class="L12930" rel="L12930">“I never said it would.”</li>
<li class="L12931" rel="L12931"></li>
<li class="L12932" rel="L12932">Mr. Lorry&#39;s eyes gradually sought the fire; his sympathy with his</li>
<li class="L12933" rel="L12933">darling, and the heavy disappointment of his second arrest, gradually</li>
<li class="L12934" rel="L12934">weakened them; he was an old man now, overborne with anxiety of late,</li>
<li class="L12935" rel="L12935">and his tears fell.</li>
<li class="L12936" rel="L12936"></li>
<li class="L12937" rel="L12937">“You are a good man and a true friend,” said Carton, in an altered</li>
<li class="L12938" rel="L12938">voice. “Forgive me if I notice that you are affected. I could not see my</li>
<li class="L12939" rel="L12939">father weep, and sit by, careless. And I could not respect your</li>
<li class="L12940" rel="L12940">sorrow more, if you were my father. You are free from that misfortune,</li>
<li class="L12941" rel="L12941">however.”</li>
<li class="L12942" rel="L12942"></li>
<li class="L12943" rel="L12943">Though he said the last words, with a slip into his usual manner, there</li>
<li class="L12944" rel="L12944">was a true feeling and respect both in his tone and in his touch,</li>
<li class="L12945" rel="L12945">that Mr. Lorry, who had never seen the better side of him, was wholly</li>
<li class="L12946" rel="L12946">unprepared for. He gave him his hand, and Carton gently pressed it.</li>
<li class="L12947" rel="L12947"></li>
<li class="L12948" rel="L12948">“To return to poor Darnay,” said Carton. “Don&#39;t tell Her of this</li>
<li class="L12949" rel="L12949">interview, or this arrangement. It would not enable Her to go to see</li>
<li class="L12950" rel="L12950">him. She might think it was contrived, in case of the worse, to convey</li>
<li class="L12951" rel="L12951">to him the means of anticipating the sentence.”</li>
<li class="L12952" rel="L12952"></li>
<li class="L12953" rel="L12953">Mr. Lorry had not thought of that, and he looked quickly at Carton to</li>
<li class="L12954" rel="L12954">see if it were in his mind. It seemed to be; he returned the look, and</li>
<li class="L12955" rel="L12955">evidently understood it.</li>
<li class="L12956" rel="L12956"></li>
<li class="L12957" rel="L12957">“She might think a thousand things,” Carton said, “and any of them would</li>
<li class="L12958" rel="L12958">only add to her trouble. Don&#39;t speak of me to her. As I said to you when</li>
<li class="L12959" rel="L12959">I first came, I had better not see her. I can put my hand out, to do any</li>
<li class="L12960" rel="L12960">little helpful work for her that my hand can find to do, without that.</li>
<li class="L12961" rel="L12961">You are going to her, I hope? She must be very desolate to-night.”</li>
<li class="L12962" rel="L12962"></li>
<li class="L12963" rel="L12963">“I am going now, directly.”</li>
<li class="L12964" rel="L12964"></li>
<li class="L12965" rel="L12965">“I am glad of that. She has such a strong attachment to you and reliance</li>
<li class="L12966" rel="L12966">on you. How does she look?”</li>
<li class="L12967" rel="L12967"></li>
<li class="L12968" rel="L12968">“Anxious and unhappy, but very beautiful.”</li>
<li class="L12969" rel="L12969"></li>
<li class="L12970" rel="L12970">“Ah!”</li>
<li class="L12971" rel="L12971"></li>
<li class="L12972" rel="L12972">It was a long, grieving sound, like a sigh--almost like a sob. It</li>
<li class="L12973" rel="L12973">attracted Mr. Lorry&#39;s eyes to Carton&#39;s face, which was turned to the</li>
<li class="L12974" rel="L12974">fire. A light, or a shade (the old gentleman could not have said which),</li>
<li class="L12975" rel="L12975">passed from it as swiftly as a change will sweep over a hill-side on a</li>
<li class="L12976" rel="L12976">wild bright day, and he lifted his foot to put back one of the little</li>
<li class="L12977" rel="L12977">flaming logs, which was tumbling forward. He wore the white riding-coat</li>
<li class="L12978" rel="L12978">and top-boots, then in vogue, and the light of the fire touching their</li>
<li class="L12979" rel="L12979">light surfaces made him look very pale, with his long brown hair,</li>
<li class="L12980" rel="L12980">all untrimmed, hanging loose about him. His indifference to fire was</li>
<li class="L12981" rel="L12981">sufficiently remarkable to elicit a word of remonstrance from Mr. Lorry;</li>
<li class="L12982" rel="L12982">his boot was still upon the hot embers of the flaming log, when it had</li>
<li class="L12983" rel="L12983">broken under the weight of his foot.</li>
<li class="L12984" rel="L12984"></li>
<li class="L12985" rel="L12985">“I forgot it,” he said.</li>
<li class="L12986" rel="L12986"></li>
<li class="L12987" rel="L12987">Mr. Lorry&#39;s eyes were again attracted to his face. Taking note of the</li>
<li class="L12988" rel="L12988">wasted air which clouded the naturally handsome features, and having</li>
<li class="L12989" rel="L12989">the expression of prisoners&#39; faces fresh in his mind, he was strongly</li>
<li class="L12990" rel="L12990">reminded of that expression.</li>
<li class="L12991" rel="L12991"></li>
<li class="L12992" rel="L12992">“And your duties here have drawn to an end, sir?” said Carton, turning</li>
<li class="L12993" rel="L12993">to him.</li>
<li class="L12994" rel="L12994"></li>
<li class="L12995" rel="L12995">“Yes. As I was telling you last night when Lucie came in so</li>
<li class="L12996" rel="L12996">unexpectedly, I have at length done all that I can do here. I hoped to</li>
<li class="L12997" rel="L12997">have left them in perfect safety, and then to have quitted Paris. I have</li>
<li class="L12998" rel="L12998">my Leave to Pass. I was ready to go.”</li>
<li class="L12999" rel="L12999"></li>
<li class="L13000" rel="L13000">They were both silent.</li>
<li class="L13001" rel="L13001"></li>
<li class="L13002" rel="L13002">“Yours is a long life to look back upon, sir?” said Carton, wistfully.</li>
<li class="L13003" rel="L13003"></li>
<li class="L13004" rel="L13004">“I am in my seventy-eighth year.”</li>
<li class="L13005" rel="L13005"></li>
<li class="L13006" rel="L13006">“You have been useful all your life; steadily and constantly occupied;</li>
<li class="L13007" rel="L13007">trusted, respected, and looked up to?”</li>
<li class="L13008" rel="L13008"></li>
<li class="L13009" rel="L13009">“I have been a man of business, ever since I have been a man. Indeed, I</li>
<li class="L13010" rel="L13010">may say that I was a man of business when a boy.”</li>
<li class="L13011" rel="L13011"></li>
<li class="L13012" rel="L13012">“See what a place you fill at seventy-eight. How many people will miss</li>
<li class="L13013" rel="L13013">you when you leave it empty!”</li>
<li class="L13014" rel="L13014"></li>
<li class="L13015" rel="L13015">“A solitary old bachelor,” answered Mr. Lorry, shaking his head. “There</li>
<li class="L13016" rel="L13016">is nobody to weep for me.”</li>
<li class="L13017" rel="L13017"></li>
<li class="L13018" rel="L13018">“How can you say that? Wouldn&#39;t She weep for you? Wouldn&#39;t her child?”</li>
<li class="L13019" rel="L13019"></li>
<li class="L13020" rel="L13020">“Yes, yes, thank God. I didn&#39;t quite mean what I said.”</li>
<li class="L13021" rel="L13021"></li>
<li class="L13022" rel="L13022">“It _is_ a thing to thank God for; is it not?”</li>
<li class="L13023" rel="L13023"></li>
<li class="L13024" rel="L13024">“Surely, surely.”</li>
<li class="L13025" rel="L13025"></li>
<li class="L13026" rel="L13026">“If you could say, with truth, to your own solitary heart, to-night,</li>
<li class="L13027" rel="L13027">&#39;I have secured to myself the love and attachment, the gratitude or</li>
<li class="L13028" rel="L13028">respect, of no human creature; I have won myself a tender place in no</li>
<li class="L13029" rel="L13029">regard; I have done nothing good or serviceable to be remembered by!&#39;</li>
<li class="L13030" rel="L13030">your seventy-eight years would be seventy-eight heavy curses; would they</li>
<li class="L13031" rel="L13031">not?”</li>
<li class="L13032" rel="L13032"></li>
<li class="L13033" rel="L13033">“You say truly, Mr. Carton; I think they would be.”</li>
<li class="L13034" rel="L13034"></li>
<li class="L13035" rel="L13035">Sydney turned his eyes again upon the fire, and, after a silence of a</li>
<li class="L13036" rel="L13036">few moments, said:</li>
<li class="L13037" rel="L13037"></li>
<li class="L13038" rel="L13038">“I should like to ask you:--Does your childhood seem far off? Do the</li>
<li class="L13039" rel="L13039">days when you sat at your mother&#39;s knee, seem days of very long ago?”</li>
<li class="L13040" rel="L13040"></li>
<li class="L13041" rel="L13041">Responding to his softened manner, Mr. Lorry answered:</li>
<li class="L13042" rel="L13042"></li>
<li class="L13043" rel="L13043">“Twenty years back, yes; at this time of my life, no. For, as I draw</li>
<li class="L13044" rel="L13044">closer and closer to the end, I travel in the circle, nearer and</li>
<li class="L13045" rel="L13045">nearer to the beginning. It seems to be one of the kind smoothings and</li>
<li class="L13046" rel="L13046">preparings of the way. My heart is touched now, by many remembrances</li>
<li class="L13047" rel="L13047">that had long fallen asleep, of my pretty young mother (and I so old!),</li>
<li class="L13048" rel="L13048">and by many associations of the days when what we call the World was not</li>
<li class="L13049" rel="L13049">so real with me, and my faults were not confirmed in me.”</li>
<li class="L13050" rel="L13050"></li>
<li class="L13051" rel="L13051">“I understand the feeling!” exclaimed Carton, with a bright flush. “And</li>
<li class="L13052" rel="L13052">you are the better for it?”</li>
<li class="L13053" rel="L13053"></li>
<li class="L13054" rel="L13054">“I hope so.”</li>
<li class="L13055" rel="L13055"></li>
<li class="L13056" rel="L13056">Carton terminated the conversation here, by rising to help him on with</li>
<li class="L13057" rel="L13057">his outer coat; “But you,” said Mr. Lorry, reverting to the theme, “you</li>
<li class="L13058" rel="L13058">are young.”</li>
<li class="L13059" rel="L13059"></li>
<li class="L13060" rel="L13060">“Yes,” said Carton. “I am not old, but my young way was never the way to</li>
<li class="L13061" rel="L13061">age. Enough of me.”</li>
<li class="L13062" rel="L13062"></li>
<li class="L13063" rel="L13063">“And of me, I am sure,” said Mr. Lorry. “Are you going out?”</li>
<li class="L13064" rel="L13064"></li>
<li class="L13065" rel="L13065">“I&#39;ll walk with you to her gate. You know my vagabond and restless</li>
<li class="L13066" rel="L13066">habits. If I should prowl about the streets a long time, don&#39;t be</li>
<li class="L13067" rel="L13067">uneasy; I shall reappear in the morning. You go to the Court to-morrow?”</li>
<li class="L13068" rel="L13068"></li>
<li class="L13069" rel="L13069">“Yes, unhappily.”</li>
<li class="L13070" rel="L13070"></li>
<li class="L13071" rel="L13071">“I shall be there, but only as one of the crowd. My Spy will find a</li>
<li class="L13072" rel="L13072">place for me. Take my arm, sir.”</li>
<li class="L13073" rel="L13073"></li>
<li class="L13074" rel="L13074">Mr. Lorry did so, and they went down-stairs and out in the streets. A</li>
<li class="L13075" rel="L13075">few minutes brought them to Mr. Lorry&#39;s destination. Carton left him</li>
<li class="L13076" rel="L13076">there; but lingered at a little distance, and turned back to the gate</li>
<li class="L13077" rel="L13077">again when it was shut, and touched it. He had heard of her going to</li>
<li class="L13078" rel="L13078">the prison every day. “She came out here,” he said, looking about him,</li>
<li class="L13079" rel="L13079">“turned this way, must have trod on these stones often. Let me follow in</li>
<li class="L13080" rel="L13080">her steps.”</li>
<li class="L13081" rel="L13081"></li>
<li class="L13082" rel="L13082">It was ten o&#39;clock at night when he stood before the prison of La Force,</li>
<li class="L13083" rel="L13083">where she had stood hundreds of times. A little wood-sawyer, having</li>
<li class="L13084" rel="L13084">closed his shop, was smoking his pipe at his shop-door.</li>
<li class="L13085" rel="L13085"></li>
<li class="L13086" rel="L13086">“Good night, citizen,” said Sydney Carton, pausing in going by; for, the</li>
<li class="L13087" rel="L13087">man eyed him inquisitively.</li>
<li class="L13088" rel="L13088"></li>
<li class="L13089" rel="L13089">“Good night, citizen.”</li>
<li class="L13090" rel="L13090"></li>
<li class="L13091" rel="L13091">“How goes the Republic?”</li>
<li class="L13092" rel="L13092"></li>
<li class="L13093" rel="L13093">“You mean the Guillotine. Not ill. Sixty-three to-day. We shall mount</li>
<li class="L13094" rel="L13094">to a hundred soon. Samson and his men complain sometimes, of being</li>
<li class="L13095" rel="L13095">exhausted. Ha, ha, ha! He is so droll, that Samson. Such a Barber!”</li>
<li class="L13096" rel="L13096"></li>
<li class="L13097" rel="L13097">“Do you often go to see him--”</li>
<li class="L13098" rel="L13098"></li>
<li class="L13099" rel="L13099">“Shave? Always. Every day. What a barber! You have seen him at work?”</li>
<li class="L13100" rel="L13100"></li>
<li class="L13101" rel="L13101">“Never.”</li>
<li class="L13102" rel="L13102"></li>
<li class="L13103" rel="L13103">“Go and see him when he has a good batch. Figure this to yourself,</li>
<li class="L13104" rel="L13104">citizen; he shaved the sixty-three to-day, in less than two pipes! Less</li>
<li class="L13105" rel="L13105">than two pipes. Word of honour!”</li>
<li class="L13106" rel="L13106"></li>
<li class="L13107" rel="L13107">As the grinning little man held out the pipe he was smoking, to explain</li>
<li class="L13108" rel="L13108">how he timed the executioner, Carton was so sensible of a rising desire</li>
<li class="L13109" rel="L13109">to strike the life out of him, that he turned away.</li>
<li class="L13110" rel="L13110"></li>
<li class="L13111" rel="L13111">“But you are not English,” said the wood-sawyer, “though you wear</li>
<li class="L13112" rel="L13112">English dress?”</li>
<li class="L13113" rel="L13113"></li>
<li class="L13114" rel="L13114">“Yes,” said Carton, pausing again, and answering over his shoulder.</li>
<li class="L13115" rel="L13115"></li>
<li class="L13116" rel="L13116">“You speak like a Frenchman.”</li>
<li class="L13117" rel="L13117"></li>
<li class="L13118" rel="L13118">“I am an old student here.”</li>
<li class="L13119" rel="L13119"></li>
<li class="L13120" rel="L13120">“Aha, a perfect Frenchman! Good night, Englishman.”</li>
<li class="L13121" rel="L13121"></li>
<li class="L13122" rel="L13122">“Good night, citizen.”</li>
<li class="L13123" rel="L13123"></li>
<li class="L13124" rel="L13124">“But go and see that droll dog,” the little man persisted, calling after</li>
<li class="L13125" rel="L13125">him. “And take a pipe with you!”</li>
<li class="L13126" rel="L13126"></li>
<li class="L13127" rel="L13127">Sydney had not gone far out of sight, when he stopped in the middle of</li>
<li class="L13128" rel="L13128">the street under a glimmering lamp, and wrote with his pencil on a scrap</li>
<li class="L13129" rel="L13129">of paper. Then, traversing with the decided step of one who remembered</li>
<li class="L13130" rel="L13130">the way well, several dark and dirty streets--much dirtier than usual,</li>
<li class="L13131" rel="L13131">for the best public thoroughfares remained uncleansed in those times of</li>
<li class="L13132" rel="L13132">terror--he stopped at a chemist&#39;s shop, which the owner was closing with</li>
<li class="L13133" rel="L13133">his own hands. A small, dim, crooked shop, kept in a tortuous, up-hill</li>
<li class="L13134" rel="L13134">thoroughfare, by a small, dim, crooked man.</li>
<li class="L13135" rel="L13135"></li>
<li class="L13136" rel="L13136">Giving this citizen, too, good night, as he confronted him at his</li>
<li class="L13137" rel="L13137">counter, he laid the scrap of paper before him. “Whew!” the chemist</li>
<li class="L13138" rel="L13138">whistled softly, as he read it. “Hi! hi! hi!”</li>
<li class="L13139" rel="L13139"></li>
<li class="L13140" rel="L13140">Sydney Carton took no heed, and the chemist said:</li>
<li class="L13141" rel="L13141"></li>
<li class="L13142" rel="L13142">“For you, citizen?”</li>
<li class="L13143" rel="L13143"></li>
<li class="L13144" rel="L13144">“For me.”</li>
<li class="L13145" rel="L13145"></li>
<li class="L13146" rel="L13146">“You will be careful to keep them separate, citizen? You know the</li>
<li class="L13147" rel="L13147">consequences of mixing them?”</li>
<li class="L13148" rel="L13148"></li>
<li class="L13149" rel="L13149">“Perfectly.”</li>
<li class="L13150" rel="L13150"></li>
<li class="L13151" rel="L13151">Certain small packets were made and given to him. He put them, one by</li>
<li class="L13152" rel="L13152">one, in the breast of his inner coat, counted out the money for them,</li>
<li class="L13153" rel="L13153">and deliberately left the shop. “There is nothing more to do,” said he,</li>
<li class="L13154" rel="L13154">glancing upward at the moon, “until to-morrow. I can&#39;t sleep.”</li>
<li class="L13155" rel="L13155"></li>
<li class="L13156" rel="L13156">It was not a reckless manner, the manner in which he said these words</li>
<li class="L13157" rel="L13157">aloud under the fast-sailing clouds, nor was it more expressive of</li>
<li class="L13158" rel="L13158">negligence than defiance. It was the settled manner of a tired man, who</li>
<li class="L13159" rel="L13159">had wandered and struggled and got lost, but who at length struck into</li>
<li class="L13160" rel="L13160">his road and saw its end.</li>
<li class="L13161" rel="L13161"></li>
<li class="L13162" rel="L13162">Long ago, when he had been famous among his earliest competitors as a</li>
<li class="L13163" rel="L13163">youth of great promise, he had followed his father to the grave. His</li>
<li class="L13164" rel="L13164">mother had died, years before. These solemn words, which had been</li>
<li class="L13165" rel="L13165">read at his father&#39;s grave, arose in his mind as he went down the dark</li>
<li class="L13166" rel="L13166">streets, among the heavy shadows, with the moon and the clouds sailing</li>
<li class="L13167" rel="L13167">on high above him. “I am the resurrection and the life, saith the Lord:</li>
<li class="L13168" rel="L13168">he that believeth in me, though he were dead, yet shall he live: and</li>
<li class="L13169" rel="L13169">whosoever liveth and believeth in me, shall never die.”</li>
<li class="L13170" rel="L13170"></li>
<li class="L13171" rel="L13171">In a city dominated by the axe, alone at night, with natural sorrow</li>
<li class="L13172" rel="L13172">rising in him for the sixty-three who had been that day put to death,</li>
<li class="L13173" rel="L13173">and for to-morrow&#39;s victims then awaiting their doom in the prisons,</li>
<li class="L13174" rel="L13174">and still of to-morrow&#39;s and to-morrow&#39;s, the chain of association that</li>
<li class="L13175" rel="L13175">brought the words home, like a rusty old ship&#39;s anchor from the deep,</li>
<li class="L13176" rel="L13176">might have been easily found. He did not seek it, but repeated them and</li>
<li class="L13177" rel="L13177">went on.</li>
<li class="L13178" rel="L13178"></li>
<li class="L13179" rel="L13179">With a solemn interest in the lighted windows where the people were</li>
<li class="L13180" rel="L13180">going to rest, forgetful through a few calm hours of the horrors</li>
<li class="L13181" rel="L13181">surrounding them; in the towers of the churches, where no prayers</li>
<li class="L13182" rel="L13182">were said, for the popular revulsion had even travelled that length</li>
<li class="L13183" rel="L13183">of self-destruction from years of priestly impostors, plunderers, and</li>
<li class="L13184" rel="L13184">profligates; in the distant burial-places, reserved, as they wrote upon</li>
<li class="L13185" rel="L13185">the gates, for Eternal Sleep; in the abounding gaols; and in the streets</li>
<li class="L13186" rel="L13186">along which the sixties rolled to a death which had become so common and</li>
<li class="L13187" rel="L13187">material, that no sorrowful story of a haunting Spirit ever arose among</li>
<li class="L13188" rel="L13188">the people out of all the working of the Guillotine; with a solemn</li>
<li class="L13189" rel="L13189">interest in the whole life and death of the city settling down to its</li>
<li class="L13190" rel="L13190">short nightly pause in fury; Sydney Carton crossed the Seine again for</li>
<li class="L13191" rel="L13191">the lighter streets.</li>
<li class="L13192" rel="L13192"></li>
<li class="L13193" rel="L13193">Few coaches were abroad, for riders in coaches were liable to be</li>
<li class="L13194" rel="L13194">suspected, and gentility hid its head in red nightcaps, and put on heavy</li>
<li class="L13195" rel="L13195">shoes, and trudged. But, the theatres were all well filled, and the</li>
<li class="L13196" rel="L13196">people poured cheerfully out as he passed, and went chatting home. At</li>
<li class="L13197" rel="L13197">one of the theatre doors, there was a little girl with a mother, looking</li>
<li class="L13198" rel="L13198">for a way across the street through the mud. He carried the child over,</li>
<li class="L13199" rel="L13199">and before the timid arm was loosed from his neck asked her for a kiss.</li>
<li class="L13200" rel="L13200"></li>
<li class="L13201" rel="L13201">“I am the resurrection and the life, saith the Lord: he that believeth</li>
<li class="L13202" rel="L13202">in me, though he were dead, yet shall he live: and whosoever liveth and</li>
<li class="L13203" rel="L13203">believeth in me, shall never die.”</li>
<li class="L13204" rel="L13204"></li>
<li class="L13205" rel="L13205">Now, that the streets were quiet, and the night wore on, the words</li>
<li class="L13206" rel="L13206">were in the echoes of his feet, and were in the air. Perfectly calm</li>
<li class="L13207" rel="L13207">and steady, he sometimes repeated them to himself as he walked; but, he</li>
<li class="L13208" rel="L13208">heard them always.</li>
<li class="L13209" rel="L13209"></li>
<li class="L13210" rel="L13210">The night wore out, and, as he stood upon the bridge listening to the</li>
<li class="L13211" rel="L13211">water as it splashed the river-walls of the Island of Paris, where the</li>
<li class="L13212" rel="L13212">picturesque confusion of houses and cathedral shone bright in the light</li>
<li class="L13213" rel="L13213">of the moon, the day came coldly, looking like a dead face out of the</li>
<li class="L13214" rel="L13214">sky. Then, the night, with the moon and the stars, turned pale and died,</li>
<li class="L13215" rel="L13215">and for a little while it seemed as if Creation were delivered over to</li>
<li class="L13216" rel="L13216">Death&#39;s dominion.</li>
<li class="L13217" rel="L13217"></li>
<li class="L13218" rel="L13218">But, the glorious sun, rising, seemed to strike those words, that burden</li>
<li class="L13219" rel="L13219">of the night, straight and warm to his heart in its long bright rays.</li>
<li class="L13220" rel="L13220">And looking along them, with reverently shaded eyes, a bridge of light</li>
<li class="L13221" rel="L13221">appeared to span the air between him and the sun, while the river</li>
<li class="L13222" rel="L13222">sparkled under it.</li>
<li class="L13223" rel="L13223"></li>
<li class="L13224" rel="L13224">The strong tide, so swift, so deep, and certain, was like a congenial</li>
<li class="L13225" rel="L13225">friend, in the morning stillness. He walked by the stream, far from the</li>
<li class="L13226" rel="L13226">houses, and in the light and warmth of the sun fell asleep on the</li>
<li class="L13227" rel="L13227">bank. When he awoke and was afoot again, he lingered there yet a little</li>
<li class="L13228" rel="L13228">longer, watching an eddy that turned and turned purposeless, until the</li>
<li class="L13229" rel="L13229">stream absorbed it, and carried it on to the sea.--“Like me.”</li>
<li class="L13230" rel="L13230"></li>
<li class="L13231" rel="L13231">A trading-boat, with a sail of the softened colour of a dead leaf, then</li>
<li class="L13232" rel="L13232">glided into his view, floated by him, and died away. As its silent track</li>
<li class="L13233" rel="L13233">in the water disappeared, the prayer that had broken up out of his heart</li>
<li class="L13234" rel="L13234">for a merciful consideration of all his poor blindnesses and errors,</li>
<li class="L13235" rel="L13235">ended in the words, “I am the resurrection and the life.”</li>
<li class="L13236" rel="L13236"></li>
<li class="L13237" rel="L13237">Mr. Lorry was already out when he got back, and it was easy to surmise</li>
<li class="L13238" rel="L13238">where the good old man was gone. Sydney Carton drank nothing but a</li>
<li class="L13239" rel="L13239">little coffee, ate some bread, and, having washed and changed to refresh</li>
<li class="L13240" rel="L13240">himself, went out to the place of trial.</li>
<li class="L13241" rel="L13241"></li>
<li class="L13242" rel="L13242">The court was all astir and a-buzz, when the black sheep--whom many fell</li>
<li class="L13243" rel="L13243">away from in dread--pressed him into an obscure corner among the crowd.</li>
<li class="L13244" rel="L13244">Mr. Lorry was there, and Doctor Manette was there. She was there,</li>
<li class="L13245" rel="L13245">sitting beside her father.</li>
<li class="L13246" rel="L13246"></li>
<li class="L13247" rel="L13247">When her husband was brought in, she turned a look upon him, so</li>
<li class="L13248" rel="L13248">sustaining, so encouraging, so full of admiring love and pitying</li>
<li class="L13249" rel="L13249">tenderness, yet so courageous for his sake, that it called the healthy</li>
<li class="L13250" rel="L13250">blood into his face, brightened his glance, and animated his heart. If</li>
<li class="L13251" rel="L13251">there had been any eyes to notice the influence of her look, on Sydney</li>
<li class="L13252" rel="L13252">Carton, it would have been seen to be the same influence exactly.</li>
<li class="L13253" rel="L13253"></li>
<li class="L13254" rel="L13254">Before that unjust Tribunal, there was little or no order of procedure,</li>
<li class="L13255" rel="L13255">ensuring to any accused person any reasonable hearing. There could have</li>
<li class="L13256" rel="L13256">been no such Revolution, if all laws, forms, and ceremonies, had not</li>
<li class="L13257" rel="L13257">first been so monstrously abused, that the suicidal vengeance of the</li>
<li class="L13258" rel="L13258">Revolution was to scatter them all to the winds.</li>
<li class="L13259" rel="L13259"></li>
<li class="L13260" rel="L13260">Every eye was turned to the jury. The same determined patriots and good</li>
<li class="L13261" rel="L13261">republicans as yesterday and the day before, and to-morrow and the day</li>
<li class="L13262" rel="L13262">after. Eager and prominent among them, one man with a craving face, and</li>
<li class="L13263" rel="L13263">his fingers perpetually hovering about his lips, whose appearance</li>
<li class="L13264" rel="L13264">gave great satisfaction to the spectators. A life-thirsting,</li>
<li class="L13265" rel="L13265">cannibal-looking, bloody-minded juryman, the Jacques Three of St.</li>
<li class="L13266" rel="L13266">Antoine. The whole jury, as a jury of dogs empannelled to try the deer.</li>
<li class="L13267" rel="L13267"></li>
<li class="L13268" rel="L13268">Every eye then turned to the five judges and the public prosecutor.</li>
<li class="L13269" rel="L13269">No favourable leaning in that quarter to-day. A fell, uncompromising,</li>
<li class="L13270" rel="L13270">murderous business-meaning there. Every eye then sought some other eye</li>
<li class="L13271" rel="L13271">in the crowd, and gleamed at it approvingly; and heads nodded at one</li>
<li class="L13272" rel="L13272">another, before bending forward with a strained attention.</li>
<li class="L13273" rel="L13273"></li>
<li class="L13274" rel="L13274">Charles Evremonde, called Darnay. Released yesterday. Reaccused and</li>
<li class="L13275" rel="L13275">retaken yesterday. Indictment delivered to him last night. Suspected and</li>
<li class="L13276" rel="L13276">Denounced enemy of the Republic, Aristocrat, one of a family of tyrants,</li>
<li class="L13277" rel="L13277">one of a race proscribed, for that they had used their abolished</li>
<li class="L13278" rel="L13278">privileges to the infamous oppression of the people. Charles Evremonde,</li>
<li class="L13279" rel="L13279">called Darnay, in right of such proscription, absolutely Dead in Law.</li>
<li class="L13280" rel="L13280"></li>
<li class="L13281" rel="L13281">To this effect, in as few or fewer words, the Public Prosecutor.</li>
<li class="L13282" rel="L13282"></li>
<li class="L13283" rel="L13283">The President asked, was the Accused openly denounced or secretly?</li>
<li class="L13284" rel="L13284"></li>
<li class="L13285" rel="L13285">“Openly, President.”</li>
<li class="L13286" rel="L13286"></li>
<li class="L13287" rel="L13287">“By whom?”</li>
<li class="L13288" rel="L13288"></li>
<li class="L13289" rel="L13289">“Three voices. Ernest Defarge, wine-vendor of St. Antoine.”</li>
<li class="L13290" rel="L13290"></li>
<li class="L13291" rel="L13291">“Good.”</li>
<li class="L13292" rel="L13292"></li>
<li class="L13293" rel="L13293">“Therese Defarge, his wife.”</li>
<li class="L13294" rel="L13294"></li>
<li class="L13295" rel="L13295">“Good.”</li>
<li class="L13296" rel="L13296"></li>
<li class="L13297" rel="L13297">“Alexandre Manette, physician.”</li>
<li class="L13298" rel="L13298"></li>
<li class="L13299" rel="L13299">A great uproar took place in the court, and in the midst of it, Doctor</li>
<li class="L13300" rel="L13300">Manette was seen, pale and trembling, standing where he had been seated.</li>
<li class="L13301" rel="L13301"></li>
<li class="L13302" rel="L13302">“President, I indignantly protest to you that this is a forgery and</li>
<li class="L13303" rel="L13303">a fraud. You know the accused to be the husband of my daughter. My</li>
<li class="L13304" rel="L13304">daughter, and those dear to her, are far dearer to me than my life. Who</li>
<li class="L13305" rel="L13305">and where is the false conspirator who says that I denounce the husband</li>
<li class="L13306" rel="L13306">of my child!”</li>
<li class="L13307" rel="L13307"></li>
<li class="L13308" rel="L13308">“Citizen Manette, be tranquil. To fail in submission to the authority of</li>
<li class="L13309" rel="L13309">the Tribunal would be to put yourself out of Law. As to what is dearer</li>
<li class="L13310" rel="L13310">to you than life, nothing can be so dear to a good citizen as the</li>
<li class="L13311" rel="L13311">Republic.”</li>
<li class="L13312" rel="L13312"></li>
<li class="L13313" rel="L13313">Loud acclamations hailed this rebuke. The President rang his bell, and</li>
<li class="L13314" rel="L13314">with warmth resumed.</li>
<li class="L13315" rel="L13315"></li>
<li class="L13316" rel="L13316">“If the Republic should demand of you the sacrifice of your child</li>
<li class="L13317" rel="L13317">herself, you would have no duty but to sacrifice her. Listen to what is</li>
<li class="L13318" rel="L13318">to follow. In the meanwhile, be silent!”</li>
<li class="L13319" rel="L13319"></li>
<li class="L13320" rel="L13320">Frantic acclamations were again raised. Doctor Manette sat down, with</li>
<li class="L13321" rel="L13321">his eyes looking around, and his lips trembling; his daughter drew</li>
<li class="L13322" rel="L13322">closer to him. The craving man on the jury rubbed his hands together,</li>
<li class="L13323" rel="L13323">and restored the usual hand to his mouth.</li>
<li class="L13324" rel="L13324"></li>
<li class="L13325" rel="L13325">Defarge was produced, when the court was quiet enough to admit of his</li>
<li class="L13326" rel="L13326">being heard, and rapidly expounded the story of the imprisonment, and of</li>
<li class="L13327" rel="L13327">his having been a mere boy in the Doctor&#39;s service, and of the release,</li>
<li class="L13328" rel="L13328">and of the state of the prisoner when released and delivered to him.</li>
<li class="L13329" rel="L13329">This short examination followed, for the court was quick with its work.</li>
<li class="L13330" rel="L13330"></li>
<li class="L13331" rel="L13331">“You did good service at the taking of the Bastille, citizen?”</li>
<li class="L13332" rel="L13332"></li>
<li class="L13333" rel="L13333">“I believe so.”</li>
<li class="L13334" rel="L13334"></li>
<li class="L13335" rel="L13335">Here, an excited woman screeched from the crowd: “You were one of the</li>
<li class="L13336" rel="L13336">best patriots there. Why not say so? You were a cannonier that day</li>
<li class="L13337" rel="L13337">there, and you were among the first to enter the accursed fortress when</li>
<li class="L13338" rel="L13338">it fell. Patriots, I speak the truth!”</li>
<li class="L13339" rel="L13339"></li>
<li class="L13340" rel="L13340">It was The Vengeance who, amidst the warm commendations of the audience,</li>
<li class="L13341" rel="L13341">thus assisted the proceedings. The President rang his bell; but, The</li>
<li class="L13342" rel="L13342">Vengeance, warming with encouragement, shrieked, “I defy that bell!”</li>
<li class="L13343" rel="L13343"> wherein she was likewise much commended.</li>
<li class="L13344" rel="L13344"></li>
<li class="L13345" rel="L13345">“Inform the Tribunal of what you did that day within the Bastille,</li>
<li class="L13346" rel="L13346">citizen.”</li>
<li class="L13347" rel="L13347"></li>
<li class="L13348" rel="L13348">“I knew,” said Defarge, looking down at his wife, who stood at the</li>
<li class="L13349" rel="L13349">bottom of the steps on which he was raised, looking steadily up at him;</li>
<li class="L13350" rel="L13350">“I knew that this prisoner, of whom I speak, had been confined in a cell</li>
<li class="L13351" rel="L13351">known as One Hundred and Five, North Tower. I knew it from himself. He</li>
<li class="L13352" rel="L13352">knew himself by no other name than One Hundred and Five, North Tower,</li>
<li class="L13353" rel="L13353">when he made shoes under my care. As I serve my gun that day, I resolve,</li>
<li class="L13354" rel="L13354">when the place shall fall, to examine that cell. It falls. I mount to</li>
<li class="L13355" rel="L13355">the cell, with a fellow-citizen who is one of the Jury, directed by a</li>
<li class="L13356" rel="L13356">gaoler. I examine it, very closely. In a hole in the chimney, where a</li>
<li class="L13357" rel="L13357">stone has been worked out and replaced, I find a written paper. This is</li>
<li class="L13358" rel="L13358">that written paper. I have made it my business to examine some specimens</li>
<li class="L13359" rel="L13359">of the writing of Doctor Manette. This is the writing of Doctor Manette.</li>
<li class="L13360" rel="L13360">I confide this paper, in the writing of Doctor Manette, to the hands of</li>
<li class="L13361" rel="L13361">the President.”</li>
<li class="L13362" rel="L13362"></li>
<li class="L13363" rel="L13363">“Let it be read.”</li>
<li class="L13364" rel="L13364"></li>
<li class="L13365" rel="L13365">In a dead silence and stillness--the prisoner under trial looking</li>
<li class="L13366" rel="L13366">lovingly at his wife, his wife only looking from him to look with</li>
<li class="L13367" rel="L13367">solicitude at her father, Doctor Manette keeping his eyes fixed on the</li>
<li class="L13368" rel="L13368">reader, Madame Defarge never taking hers from the prisoner, Defarge</li>
<li class="L13369" rel="L13369">never taking his from his feasting wife, and all the other eyes there</li>
<li class="L13370" rel="L13370">intent upon the Doctor, who saw none of them--the paper was read, as</li>
<li class="L13371" rel="L13371">follows.</li>
<li class="L13372" rel="L13372"></li>
<li class="L13373" rel="L13373"></li>
<li class="L13374" rel="L13374"></li>
<li class="L13375" rel="L13375"></li>
<li class="L13376" rel="L13376">X. The Substance of the Shadow</li>
<li class="L13377" rel="L13377"></li>
<li class="L13378" rel="L13378"></li>
<li class="L13379" rel="L13379">“I, Alexandre Manette, unfortunate physician, native of Beauvais, and</li>
<li class="L13380" rel="L13380">afterwards resident in Paris, write this melancholy paper in my doleful</li>
<li class="L13381" rel="L13381">cell in the Bastille, during the last month of the year, 1767. I write</li>
<li class="L13382" rel="L13382">it at stolen intervals, under every difficulty. I design to secrete it</li>
<li class="L13383" rel="L13383">in the wall of the chimney, where I have slowly and laboriously made a</li>
<li class="L13384" rel="L13384">place of concealment for it. Some pitying hand may find it there, when I</li>
<li class="L13385" rel="L13385">and my sorrows are dust.</li>
<li class="L13386" rel="L13386"></li>
<li class="L13387" rel="L13387">“These words are formed by the rusty iron point with which I write with</li>
<li class="L13388" rel="L13388">difficulty in scrapings of soot and charcoal from the chimney, mixed</li>
<li class="L13389" rel="L13389">with blood, in the last month of the tenth year of my captivity. Hope</li>
<li class="L13390" rel="L13390">has quite departed from my breast. I know from terrible warnings I have</li>
<li class="L13391" rel="L13391">noted in myself that my reason will not long remain unimpaired, but I</li>
<li class="L13392" rel="L13392">solemnly declare that I am at this time in the possession of my right</li>
<li class="L13393" rel="L13393">mind--that my memory is exact and circumstantial--and that I write the</li>
<li class="L13394" rel="L13394">truth as I shall answer for these my last recorded words, whether they</li>
<li class="L13395" rel="L13395">be ever read by men or not, at the Eternal Judgment-seat.</li>
<li class="L13396" rel="L13396"></li>
<li class="L13397" rel="L13397">“One cloudy moonlight night, in the third week of December (I think the</li>
<li class="L13398" rel="L13398">twenty-second of the month) in the year 1757, I was walking on a retired</li>
<li class="L13399" rel="L13399">part of the quay by the Seine for the refreshment of the frosty air,</li>
<li class="L13400" rel="L13400">at an hour&#39;s distance from my place of residence in the Street of the</li>
<li class="L13401" rel="L13401">School of Medicine, when a carriage came along behind me, driven very</li>
<li class="L13402" rel="L13402">fast. As I stood aside to let that carriage pass, apprehensive that it</li>
<li class="L13403" rel="L13403">might otherwise run me down, a head was put out at the window, and a</li>
<li class="L13404" rel="L13404">voice called to the driver to stop.</li>
<li class="L13405" rel="L13405"></li>
<li class="L13406" rel="L13406">“The carriage stopped as soon as the driver could rein in his horses,</li>
<li class="L13407" rel="L13407">and the same voice called to me by my name. I answered. The carriage</li>
<li class="L13408" rel="L13408">was then so far in advance of me that two gentlemen had time to open the</li>
<li class="L13409" rel="L13409">door and alight before I came up with it.</li>
<li class="L13410" rel="L13410"></li>
<li class="L13411" rel="L13411">“I observed that they were both wrapped in cloaks, and appeared to</li>
<li class="L13412" rel="L13412">conceal themselves. As they stood side by side near the carriage door,</li>
