<li class="L13413" rel="L13413">I also observed that they both looked of about my own age, or rather</li>
<li class="L13414" rel="L13414">younger, and that they were greatly alike, in stature, manner, voice,</li>
<li class="L13415" rel="L13415">and (as far as I could see) face too.</li>
<li class="L13416" rel="L13416"></li>
<li class="L13417" rel="L13417">“&#39;You are Doctor Manette?&#39; said one.</li>
<li class="L13418" rel="L13418"></li>
<li class="L13419" rel="L13419">“I am.”</li>
<li class="L13420" rel="L13420"></li>
<li class="L13421" rel="L13421">“&#39;Doctor Manette, formerly of Beauvais,&#39; said the other; &#39;the young</li>
<li class="L13422" rel="L13422">physician, originally an expert surgeon, who within the last year or two</li>
<li class="L13423" rel="L13423">has made a rising reputation in Paris?&#39;</li>
<li class="L13424" rel="L13424"></li>
<li class="L13425" rel="L13425">“&#39;Gentlemen,&#39; I returned, &#39;I am that Doctor Manette of whom you speak so</li>
<li class="L13426" rel="L13426">graciously.&#39;</li>
<li class="L13427" rel="L13427"></li>
<li class="L13428" rel="L13428">“&#39;We have been to your residence,&#39; said the first, &#39;and not being</li>
<li class="L13429" rel="L13429">so fortunate as to find you there, and being informed that you were</li>
<li class="L13430" rel="L13430">probably walking in this direction, we followed, in the hope of</li>
<li class="L13431" rel="L13431">overtaking you. Will you please to enter the carriage?&#39;</li>
<li class="L13432" rel="L13432"></li>
<li class="L13433" rel="L13433">“The manner of both was imperious, and they both moved, as these words</li>
<li class="L13434" rel="L13434">were spoken, so as to place me between themselves and the carriage door.</li>
<li class="L13435" rel="L13435">They were armed. I was not.</li>
<li class="L13436" rel="L13436"></li>
<li class="L13437" rel="L13437">“&#39;Gentlemen,&#39; said I, &#39;pardon me; but I usually inquire who does me</li>
<li class="L13438" rel="L13438">the honour to seek my assistance, and what is the nature of the case to</li>
<li class="L13439" rel="L13439">which I am summoned.&#39;</li>
<li class="L13440" rel="L13440"></li>
<li class="L13441" rel="L13441">“The reply to this was made by him who had spoken second. &#39;Doctor,</li>
<li class="L13442" rel="L13442">your clients are people of condition. As to the nature of the case,</li>
<li class="L13443" rel="L13443">our confidence in your skill assures us that you will ascertain it for</li>
<li class="L13444" rel="L13444">yourself better than we can describe it. Enough. Will you please to</li>
<li class="L13445" rel="L13445">enter the carriage?&#39;</li>
<li class="L13446" rel="L13446"></li>
<li class="L13447" rel="L13447">“I could do nothing but comply, and I entered it in silence. They both</li>
<li class="L13448" rel="L13448">entered after me--the last springing in, after putting up the steps. The</li>
<li class="L13449" rel="L13449">carriage turned about, and drove on at its former speed.</li>
<li class="L13450" rel="L13450"></li>
<li class="L13451" rel="L13451">“I repeat this conversation exactly as it occurred. I have no doubt that</li>
<li class="L13452" rel="L13452">it is, word for word, the same. I describe everything exactly as it took</li>
<li class="L13453" rel="L13453">place, constraining my mind not to wander from the task. Where I make</li>
<li class="L13454" rel="L13454">the broken marks that follow here, I leave off for the time, and put my</li>
<li class="L13455" rel="L13455">paper in its hiding-place.</li>
<li class="L13456" rel="L13456"></li>
<li class="L13457" rel="L13457">        *****</li>
<li class="L13458" rel="L13458"></li>
<li class="L13459" rel="L13459">“The carriage left the streets behind, passed the North Barrier, and</li>
<li class="L13460" rel="L13460">emerged upon the country road. At two-thirds of a league from the</li>
<li class="L13461" rel="L13461">Barrier--I did not estimate the distance at that time, but afterwards</li>
<li class="L13462" rel="L13462">when I traversed it--it struck out of the main avenue, and presently</li>
<li class="L13463" rel="L13463">stopped at a solitary house, We all three alighted, and walked, by</li>
<li class="L13464" rel="L13464">a damp soft footpath in a garden where a neglected fountain had</li>
<li class="L13465" rel="L13465">overflowed, to the door of the house. It was not opened immediately, in</li>
<li class="L13466" rel="L13466">answer to the ringing of the bell, and one of my two conductors struck</li>
<li class="L13467" rel="L13467">the man who opened it, with his heavy riding glove, across the face.</li>
<li class="L13468" rel="L13468"></li>
<li class="L13469" rel="L13469">“There was nothing in this action to attract my particular attention,</li>
<li class="L13470" rel="L13470">for I had seen common people struck more commonly than dogs. But, the</li>
<li class="L13471" rel="L13471">other of the two, being angry likewise, struck the man in like manner</li>
<li class="L13472" rel="L13472">with his arm; the look and bearing of the brothers were then so exactly</li>
<li class="L13473" rel="L13473">alike, that I then first perceived them to be twin brothers.</li>
<li class="L13474" rel="L13474"></li>
<li class="L13475" rel="L13475">“From the time of our alighting at the outer gate (which we found</li>
<li class="L13476" rel="L13476">locked, and which one of the brothers had opened to admit us, and had</li>
<li class="L13477" rel="L13477">relocked), I had heard cries proceeding from an upper chamber. I was</li>
<li class="L13478" rel="L13478">conducted to this chamber straight, the cries growing louder as we</li>
<li class="L13479" rel="L13479">ascended the stairs, and I found a patient in a high fever of the brain,</li>
<li class="L13480" rel="L13480">lying on a bed.</li>
<li class="L13481" rel="L13481"></li>
<li class="L13482" rel="L13482">“The patient was a woman of great beauty, and young; assuredly not much</li>
<li class="L13483" rel="L13483">past twenty. Her hair was torn and ragged, and her arms were bound to</li>
<li class="L13484" rel="L13484">her sides with sashes and handkerchiefs. I noticed that these bonds were</li>
<li class="L13485" rel="L13485">all portions of a gentleman&#39;s dress. On one of them, which was a fringed</li>
<li class="L13486" rel="L13486">scarf for a dress of ceremony, I saw the armorial bearings of a Noble,</li>
<li class="L13487" rel="L13487">and the letter E.</li>
<li class="L13488" rel="L13488"></li>
<li class="L13489" rel="L13489">“I saw this, within the first minute of my contemplation of the patient;</li>
<li class="L13490" rel="L13490">for, in her restless strivings she had turned over on her face on the</li>
<li class="L13491" rel="L13491">edge of the bed, had drawn the end of the scarf into her mouth, and was</li>
<li class="L13492" rel="L13492">in danger of suffocation. My first act was to put out my hand to relieve</li>
<li class="L13493" rel="L13493">her breathing; and in moving the scarf aside, the embroidery in the</li>
<li class="L13494" rel="L13494">corner caught my sight.</li>
<li class="L13495" rel="L13495"></li>
<li class="L13496" rel="L13496">“I turned her gently over, placed my hands upon her breast to calm her</li>
<li class="L13497" rel="L13497">and keep her down, and looked into her face. Her eyes were dilated and</li>
<li class="L13498" rel="L13498">wild, and she constantly uttered piercing shrieks, and repeated the</li>
<li class="L13499" rel="L13499">words, &#39;My husband, my father, and my brother!&#39; and then counted up to</li>
<li class="L13500" rel="L13500">twelve, and said, &#39;Hush!&#39; For an instant, and no more, she would pause</li>
<li class="L13501" rel="L13501">to listen, and then the piercing shrieks would begin again, and she</li>
<li class="L13502" rel="L13502">would repeat the cry, &#39;My husband, my father, and my brother!&#39; and</li>
<li class="L13503" rel="L13503">would count up to twelve, and say, &#39;Hush!&#39; There was no variation in the</li>
<li class="L13504" rel="L13504">order, or the manner. There was no cessation, but the regular moment&#39;s</li>
<li class="L13505" rel="L13505">pause, in the utterance of these sounds.</li>
<li class="L13506" rel="L13506"></li>
<li class="L13507" rel="L13507">“&#39;How long,&#39; I asked, &#39;has this lasted?&#39;</li>
<li class="L13508" rel="L13508"></li>
<li class="L13509" rel="L13509">“To distinguish the brothers, I will call them the elder and the</li>
<li class="L13510" rel="L13510">younger; by the elder, I mean him who exercised the most authority. It</li>
<li class="L13511" rel="L13511">was the elder who replied, &#39;Since about this hour last night.&#39;</li>
<li class="L13512" rel="L13512"></li>
<li class="L13513" rel="L13513">“&#39;She has a husband, a father, and a brother?&#39;</li>
<li class="L13514" rel="L13514"></li>
<li class="L13515" rel="L13515">“&#39;A brother.&#39;</li>
<li class="L13516" rel="L13516"></li>
<li class="L13517" rel="L13517">“&#39;I do not address her brother?&#39;</li>
<li class="L13518" rel="L13518"></li>
<li class="L13519" rel="L13519">“He answered with great contempt, &#39;No.&#39;</li>
<li class="L13520" rel="L13520"></li>
<li class="L13521" rel="L13521">“&#39;She has some recent association with the number twelve?&#39;</li>
<li class="L13522" rel="L13522"></li>
<li class="L13523" rel="L13523">“The younger brother impatiently rejoined, &#39;With twelve o&#39;clock?&#39;</li>
<li class="L13524" rel="L13524"></li>
<li class="L13525" rel="L13525">“&#39;See, gentlemen,&#39; said I, still keeping my hands upon her breast, &#39;how</li>
<li class="L13526" rel="L13526">useless I am, as you have brought me! If I had known what I was coming</li>
<li class="L13527" rel="L13527">to see, I could have come provided. As it is, time must be lost. There</li>
<li class="L13528" rel="L13528">are no medicines to be obtained in this lonely place.&#39;</li>
<li class="L13529" rel="L13529"></li>
<li class="L13530" rel="L13530">“The elder brother looked to the younger, who said haughtily, &#39;There is</li>
<li class="L13531" rel="L13531">a case of medicines here;&#39; and brought it from a closet, and put it on</li>
<li class="L13532" rel="L13532">the table.</li>
<li class="L13533" rel="L13533"></li>
<li class="L13534" rel="L13534">        *****</li>
<li class="L13535" rel="L13535"></li>
<li class="L13536" rel="L13536">“I opened some of the bottles, smelt them, and put the stoppers to my</li>
<li class="L13537" rel="L13537">lips. If I had wanted to use anything save narcotic medicines that were</li>
<li class="L13538" rel="L13538">poisons in themselves, I would not have administered any of those.</li>
<li class="L13539" rel="L13539"></li>
<li class="L13540" rel="L13540">“&#39;Do you doubt them?&#39; asked the younger brother.</li>
<li class="L13541" rel="L13541"></li>
<li class="L13542" rel="L13542">“&#39;You see, monsieur, I am going to use them,&#39; I replied, and said no</li>
<li class="L13543" rel="L13543">more.</li>
<li class="L13544" rel="L13544"></li>
<li class="L13545" rel="L13545">“I made the patient swallow, with great difficulty, and after many</li>
<li class="L13546" rel="L13546">efforts, the dose that I desired to give. As I intended to repeat it</li>
<li class="L13547" rel="L13547">after a while, and as it was necessary to watch its influence, I then</li>
<li class="L13548" rel="L13548">sat down by the side of the bed. There was a timid and suppressed woman</li>
<li class="L13549" rel="L13549">in attendance (wife of the man down-stairs), who had retreated into</li>
<li class="L13550" rel="L13550">a corner. The house was damp and decayed, indifferently</li>
<li class="L13551" rel="L13551">furnished--evidently, recently occupied and temporarily used. Some thick</li>
<li class="L13552" rel="L13552">old hangings had been nailed up before the windows, to deaden the</li>
<li class="L13553" rel="L13553">sound of the shrieks. They continued to be uttered in their regular</li>
<li class="L13554" rel="L13554">succession, with the cry, &#39;My husband, my father, and my brother!&#39; the</li>
<li class="L13555" rel="L13555">counting up to twelve, and &#39;Hush!&#39; The frenzy was so violent, that I had</li>
<li class="L13556" rel="L13556">not unfastened the bandages restraining the arms; but, I had looked to</li>
<li class="L13557" rel="L13557">them, to see that they were not painful. The only spark of encouragement</li>
<li class="L13558" rel="L13558">in the case, was, that my hand upon the sufferer&#39;s breast had this much</li>
<li class="L13559" rel="L13559">soothing influence, that for minutes at a time it tranquillised the</li>
<li class="L13560" rel="L13560">figure. It had no effect upon the cries; no pendulum could be more</li>
<li class="L13561" rel="L13561">regular.</li>
<li class="L13562" rel="L13562"></li>
<li class="L13563" rel="L13563">“For the reason that my hand had this effect (I assume), I had sat by</li>
<li class="L13564" rel="L13564">the side of the bed for half an hour, with the two brothers looking on,</li>
<li class="L13565" rel="L13565">before the elder said:</li>
<li class="L13566" rel="L13566"></li>
<li class="L13567" rel="L13567">“&#39;There is another patient.&#39;</li>
<li class="L13568" rel="L13568"></li>
<li class="L13569" rel="L13569">“I was startled, and asked, &#39;Is it a pressing case?&#39;</li>
<li class="L13570" rel="L13570"></li>
<li class="L13571" rel="L13571">“&#39;You had better see,&#39; he carelessly answered; and took up a light.</li>
<li class="L13572" rel="L13572"></li>
<li class="L13573" rel="L13573">        *****</li>
<li class="L13574" rel="L13574"></li>
<li class="L13575" rel="L13575">“The other patient lay in a back room across a second staircase, which</li>
<li class="L13576" rel="L13576">was a species of loft over a stable. There was a low plastered ceiling</li>
<li class="L13577" rel="L13577">to a part of it; the rest was open, to the ridge of the tiled roof, and</li>
<li class="L13578" rel="L13578">there were beams across. Hay and straw were stored in that portion of</li>
<li class="L13579" rel="L13579">the place, fagots for firing, and a heap of apples in sand. I had to</li>
<li class="L13580" rel="L13580">pass through that part, to get at the other. My memory is circumstantial</li>
<li class="L13581" rel="L13581">and unshaken. I try it with these details, and I see them all, in</li>
<li class="L13582" rel="L13582">this my cell in the Bastille, near the close of the tenth year of my</li>
<li class="L13583" rel="L13583">captivity, as I saw them all that night.</li>
<li class="L13584" rel="L13584"></li>
<li class="L13585" rel="L13585">“On some hay on the ground, with a cushion thrown under his head, lay a</li>
<li class="L13586" rel="L13586">handsome peasant boy--a boy of not more than seventeen at the most.</li>
<li class="L13587" rel="L13587">He lay on his back, with his teeth set, his right hand clenched on his</li>
<li class="L13588" rel="L13588">breast, and his glaring eyes looking straight upward. I could not see</li>
<li class="L13589" rel="L13589">where his wound was, as I kneeled on one knee over him; but, I could see</li>
<li class="L13590" rel="L13590">that he was dying of a wound from a sharp point.</li>
<li class="L13591" rel="L13591"></li>
<li class="L13592" rel="L13592">“&#39;I am a doctor, my poor fellow,&#39; said I. &#39;Let me examine it.&#39;</li>
<li class="L13593" rel="L13593"></li>
<li class="L13594" rel="L13594">“&#39;I do not want it examined,&#39; he answered; &#39;let it be.&#39;</li>
<li class="L13595" rel="L13595"></li>
<li class="L13596" rel="L13596">“It was under his hand, and I soothed him to let me move his hand away.</li>
<li class="L13597" rel="L13597">The wound was a sword-thrust, received from twenty to twenty-four hours</li>
<li class="L13598" rel="L13598">before, but no skill could have saved him if it had been looked to</li>
<li class="L13599" rel="L13599">without delay. He was then dying fast. As I turned my eyes to the elder</li>
<li class="L13600" rel="L13600">brother, I saw him looking down at this handsome boy whose life was</li>
<li class="L13601" rel="L13601">ebbing out, as if he were a wounded bird, or hare, or rabbit; not at all</li>
<li class="L13602" rel="L13602">as if he were a fellow-creature.</li>
<li class="L13603" rel="L13603"></li>
<li class="L13604" rel="L13604">“&#39;How has this been done, monsieur?&#39; said I.</li>
<li class="L13605" rel="L13605"></li>
<li class="L13606" rel="L13606">“&#39;A crazed young common dog! A serf! Forced my brother to draw upon him,</li>
<li class="L13607" rel="L13607">and has fallen by my brother&#39;s sword--like a gentleman.&#39;</li>
<li class="L13608" rel="L13608"></li>
<li class="L13609" rel="L13609">“There was no touch of pity, sorrow, or kindred humanity, in this</li>
<li class="L13610" rel="L13610">answer. The speaker seemed to acknowledge that it was inconvenient to</li>
<li class="L13611" rel="L13611">have that different order of creature dying there, and that it would</li>
<li class="L13612" rel="L13612">have been better if he had died in the usual obscure routine of his</li>
<li class="L13613" rel="L13613">vermin kind. He was quite incapable of any compassionate feeling about</li>
<li class="L13614" rel="L13614">the boy, or about his fate.</li>
<li class="L13615" rel="L13615"></li>
<li class="L13616" rel="L13616">“The boy&#39;s eyes had slowly moved to him as he had spoken, and they now</li>
<li class="L13617" rel="L13617">slowly moved to me.</li>
<li class="L13618" rel="L13618"></li>
<li class="L13619" rel="L13619">“&#39;Doctor, they are very proud, these Nobles; but we common dogs are</li>
<li class="L13620" rel="L13620">proud too, sometimes. They plunder us, outrage us, beat us, kill us; but</li>
<li class="L13621" rel="L13621">we have a little pride left, sometimes. She--have you seen her, Doctor?&#39;</li>
<li class="L13622" rel="L13622"></li>
<li class="L13623" rel="L13623">“The shrieks and the cries were audible there, though subdued by the</li>
<li class="L13624" rel="L13624">distance. He referred to them, as if she were lying in our presence.</li>
<li class="L13625" rel="L13625"></li>
<li class="L13626" rel="L13626">“I said, &#39;I have seen her.&#39;</li>
<li class="L13627" rel="L13627"></li>
<li class="L13628" rel="L13628">“&#39;She is my sister, Doctor. They have had their shameful rights, these</li>
<li class="L13629" rel="L13629">Nobles, in the modesty and virtue of our sisters, many years, but we</li>
<li class="L13630" rel="L13630">have had good girls among us. I know it, and have heard my father say</li>
<li class="L13631" rel="L13631">so. She was a good girl. She was betrothed to a good young man, too: a</li>
<li class="L13632" rel="L13632">tenant of his. We were all tenants of his--that man&#39;s who stands there.</li>
<li class="L13633" rel="L13633">The other is his brother, the worst of a bad race.&#39;</li>
<li class="L13634" rel="L13634"></li>
<li class="L13635" rel="L13635">“It was with the greatest difficulty that the boy gathered bodily force</li>
<li class="L13636" rel="L13636">to speak; but, his spirit spoke with a dreadful emphasis.</li>
<li class="L13637" rel="L13637"></li>
<li class="L13638" rel="L13638">“&#39;We were so robbed by that man who stands there, as all we common dogs</li>
<li class="L13639" rel="L13639">are by those superior Beings--taxed by him without mercy, obliged to</li>
<li class="L13640" rel="L13640">work for him without pay, obliged to grind our corn at his mill, obliged</li>
<li class="L13641" rel="L13641">to feed scores of his tame birds on our wretched crops, and forbidden</li>
<li class="L13642" rel="L13642">for our lives to keep a single tame bird of our own, pillaged and</li>
<li class="L13643" rel="L13643">plundered to that degree that when we chanced to have a bit of meat, we</li>
<li class="L13644" rel="L13644">ate it in fear, with the door barred and the shutters closed, that his</li>
<li class="L13645" rel="L13645">people should not see it and take it from us--I say, we were so robbed,</li>
<li class="L13646" rel="L13646">and hunted, and were made so poor, that our father told us it was a</li>
<li class="L13647" rel="L13647">dreadful thing to bring a child into the world, and that what we should</li>
<li class="L13648" rel="L13648">most pray for, was, that our women might be barren and our miserable</li>
<li class="L13649" rel="L13649">race die out!&#39;</li>
<li class="L13650" rel="L13650"></li>
<li class="L13651" rel="L13651">“I had never before seen the sense of being oppressed, bursting forth</li>
<li class="L13652" rel="L13652">like a fire. I had supposed that it must be latent in the people</li>
<li class="L13653" rel="L13653">somewhere; but, I had never seen it break out, until I saw it in the</li>
<li class="L13654" rel="L13654">dying boy.</li>
<li class="L13655" rel="L13655"></li>
<li class="L13656" rel="L13656">“&#39;Nevertheless, Doctor, my sister married. He was ailing at that time,</li>
<li class="L13657" rel="L13657">poor fellow, and she married her lover, that she might tend and comfort</li>
<li class="L13658" rel="L13658">him in our cottage--our dog-hut, as that man would call it. She had not</li>
<li class="L13659" rel="L13659">been married many weeks, when that man&#39;s brother saw her and admired</li>
<li class="L13660" rel="L13660">her, and asked that man to lend her to him--for what are husbands among</li>
<li class="L13661" rel="L13661">us! He was willing enough, but my sister was good and virtuous, and</li>
<li class="L13662" rel="L13662">hated his brother with a hatred as strong as mine. What did the two</li>
<li class="L13663" rel="L13663">then, to persuade her husband to use his influence with her, to make her</li>
<li class="L13664" rel="L13664">willing?&#39;</li>
<li class="L13665" rel="L13665"></li>
<li class="L13666" rel="L13666">“The boy&#39;s eyes, which had been fixed on mine, slowly turned to the</li>
<li class="L13667" rel="L13667">looker-on, and I saw in the two faces that all he said was true. The two</li>
<li class="L13668" rel="L13668">opposing kinds of pride confronting one another, I can see, even in this</li>
<li class="L13669" rel="L13669">Bastille; the gentleman&#39;s, all negligent indifference; the peasant&#39;s, all</li>
<li class="L13670" rel="L13670">trodden-down sentiment, and passionate revenge.</li>
<li class="L13671" rel="L13671"></li>
<li class="L13672" rel="L13672">“&#39;You know, Doctor, that it is among the Rights of these Nobles to</li>
<li class="L13673" rel="L13673">harness us common dogs to carts, and drive us. They so harnessed him and</li>
<li class="L13674" rel="L13674">drove him. You know that it is among their Rights to keep us in their</li>
<li class="L13675" rel="L13675">grounds all night, quieting the frogs, in order that their noble sleep</li>
<li class="L13676" rel="L13676">may not be disturbed. They kept him out in the unwholesome mists at</li>
<li class="L13677" rel="L13677">night, and ordered him back into his harness in the day. But he was</li>
<li class="L13678" rel="L13678">not persuaded. No! Taken out of harness one day at noon, to feed--if he</li>
<li class="L13679" rel="L13679">could find food--he sobbed twelve times, once for every stroke of the</li>
<li class="L13680" rel="L13680">bell, and died on her bosom.&#39;</li>
<li class="L13681" rel="L13681"></li>
<li class="L13682" rel="L13682">“Nothing human could have held life in the boy but his determination to</li>
<li class="L13683" rel="L13683">tell all his wrong. He forced back the gathering shadows of death, as</li>
<li class="L13684" rel="L13684">he forced his clenched right hand to remain clenched, and to cover his</li>
<li class="L13685" rel="L13685">wound.</li>
<li class="L13686" rel="L13686"></li>
<li class="L13687" rel="L13687">“&#39;Then, with that man&#39;s permission and even with his aid, his</li>
<li class="L13688" rel="L13688">brother took her away; in spite of what I know she must have told his</li>
<li class="L13689" rel="L13689">brother--and what that is, will not be long unknown to you, Doctor, if</li>
<li class="L13690" rel="L13690">it is now--his brother took her away--for his pleasure and diversion,</li>
<li class="L13691" rel="L13691">for a little while. I saw her pass me on the road. When I took the</li>
<li class="L13692" rel="L13692">tidings home, our father&#39;s heart burst; he never spoke one of the words</li>
<li class="L13693" rel="L13693">that filled it. I took my young sister (for I have another) to a place</li>
<li class="L13694" rel="L13694">beyond the reach of this man, and where, at least, she will never be</li>
<li class="L13695" rel="L13695">_his_ vassal. Then, I tracked the brother here, and last night climbed</li>
<li class="L13696" rel="L13696">in--a common dog, but sword in hand.--Where is the loft window? It was</li>
<li class="L13697" rel="L13697">somewhere here?&#39;</li>
<li class="L13698" rel="L13698"></li>
<li class="L13699" rel="L13699">“The room was darkening to his sight; the world was narrowing around</li>
<li class="L13700" rel="L13700">him. I glanced about me, and saw that the hay and straw were trampled</li>
<li class="L13701" rel="L13701">over the floor, as if there had been a struggle.</li>
<li class="L13702" rel="L13702"></li>
<li class="L13703" rel="L13703">“&#39;She heard me, and ran in. I told her not to come near us till he was</li>
<li class="L13704" rel="L13704">dead. He came in and first tossed me some pieces of money; then struck</li>
<li class="L13705" rel="L13705">at me with a whip. But I, though a common dog, so struck at him as to</li>
<li class="L13706" rel="L13706">make him draw. Let him break into as many pieces as he will, the sword</li>
<li class="L13707" rel="L13707">that he stained with my common blood; he drew to defend himself--thrust</li>
<li class="L13708" rel="L13708">at me with all his skill for his life.&#39;</li>
<li class="L13709" rel="L13709"></li>
<li class="L13710" rel="L13710">“My glance had fallen, but a few moments before, on the fragments of</li>
<li class="L13711" rel="L13711">a broken sword, lying among the hay. That weapon was a gentleman&#39;s. In</li>
<li class="L13712" rel="L13712">another place, lay an old sword that seemed to have been a soldier&#39;s.</li>
<li class="L13713" rel="L13713"></li>
<li class="L13714" rel="L13714">“&#39;Now, lift me up, Doctor; lift me up. Where is he?&#39;</li>
<li class="L13715" rel="L13715"></li>
<li class="L13716" rel="L13716">“&#39;He is not here,&#39; I said, supporting the boy, and thinking that he</li>
<li class="L13717" rel="L13717">referred to the brother.</li>
<li class="L13718" rel="L13718"></li>
<li class="L13719" rel="L13719">“&#39;He! Proud as these nobles are, he is afraid to see me. Where is the</li>
<li class="L13720" rel="L13720">man who was here? Turn my face to him.&#39;</li>
<li class="L13721" rel="L13721"></li>
<li class="L13722" rel="L13722">“I did so, raising the boy&#39;s head against my knee. But, invested for the</li>
<li class="L13723" rel="L13723">moment with extraordinary power, he raised himself completely: obliging</li>
<li class="L13724" rel="L13724">me to rise too, or I could not have still supported him.</li>
<li class="L13725" rel="L13725"></li>
<li class="L13726" rel="L13726">“&#39;Marquis,&#39; said the boy, turned to him with his eyes opened wide, and</li>
<li class="L13727" rel="L13727">his right hand raised, &#39;in the days when all these things are to be</li>
<li class="L13728" rel="L13728">answered for, I summon you and yours, to the last of your bad race, to</li>
<li class="L13729" rel="L13729">answer for them. I mark this cross of blood upon you, as a sign that</li>
<li class="L13730" rel="L13730">I do it. In the days when all these things are to be answered for,</li>
<li class="L13731" rel="L13731">I summon your brother, the worst of the bad race, to answer for them</li>
<li class="L13732" rel="L13732">separately. I mark this cross of blood upon him, as a sign that I do</li>
<li class="L13733" rel="L13733">it.&#39;</li>
<li class="L13734" rel="L13734"></li>
<li class="L13735" rel="L13735">“Twice, he put his hand to the wound in his breast, and with his</li>
<li class="L13736" rel="L13736">forefinger drew a cross in the air. He stood for an instant with the</li>
<li class="L13737" rel="L13737">finger yet raised, and as it dropped, he dropped with it, and I laid him</li>
<li class="L13738" rel="L13738">down dead.</li>
<li class="L13739" rel="L13739"></li>
<li class="L13740" rel="L13740">        *****</li>
<li class="L13741" rel="L13741"></li>
<li class="L13742" rel="L13742">“When I returned to the bedside of the young woman, I found her raving</li>
<li class="L13743" rel="L13743">in precisely the same order of continuity. I knew that this might last</li>
<li class="L13744" rel="L13744">for many hours, and that it would probably end in the silence of the</li>
<li class="L13745" rel="L13745">grave.</li>
<li class="L13746" rel="L13746"></li>
<li class="L13747" rel="L13747">“I repeated the medicines I had given her, and I sat at the side of</li>
<li class="L13748" rel="L13748">the bed until the night was far advanced. She never abated the piercing</li>
<li class="L13749" rel="L13749">quality of her shrieks, never stumbled in the distinctness or the order</li>
<li class="L13750" rel="L13750">of her words. They were always &#39;My husband, my father, and my brother!</li>
<li class="L13751" rel="L13751">One, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, ten, eleven,</li>
<li class="L13752" rel="L13752">twelve. Hush!&#39;</li>
<li class="L13753" rel="L13753"></li>
<li class="L13754" rel="L13754">“This lasted twenty-six hours from the time when I first saw her. I had</li>
<li class="L13755" rel="L13755">come and gone twice, and was again sitting by her, when she began to</li>
<li class="L13756" rel="L13756">falter. I did what little could be done to assist that opportunity, and</li>
<li class="L13757" rel="L13757">by-and-bye she sank into a lethargy, and lay like the dead.</li>
<li class="L13758" rel="L13758"></li>
<li class="L13759" rel="L13759">“It was as if the wind and rain had lulled at last, after a long and</li>
<li class="L13760" rel="L13760">fearful storm. I released her arms, and called the woman to assist me to</li>
<li class="L13761" rel="L13761">compose her figure and the dress she had torn. It was then that I knew</li>
<li class="L13762" rel="L13762">her condition to be that of one in whom the first expectations of being</li>
<li class="L13763" rel="L13763">a mother have arisen; and it was then that I lost the little hope I had</li>
<li class="L13764" rel="L13764">had of her.</li>
<li class="L13765" rel="L13765"></li>
<li class="L13766" rel="L13766">“&#39;Is she dead?&#39; asked the Marquis, whom I will still describe as the</li>
<li class="L13767" rel="L13767">elder brother, coming booted into the room from his horse.</li>
<li class="L13768" rel="L13768"></li>
<li class="L13769" rel="L13769">“&#39;Not dead,&#39; said I; &#39;but like to die.&#39;</li>
<li class="L13770" rel="L13770"></li>
<li class="L13771" rel="L13771">“&#39;What strength there is in these common bodies!&#39; he said, looking down</li>
<li class="L13772" rel="L13772">at her with some curiosity.</li>
<li class="L13773" rel="L13773"></li>
<li class="L13774" rel="L13774">“&#39;There is prodigious strength,&#39; I answered him, &#39;in sorrow and</li>
<li class="L13775" rel="L13775">despair.&#39;</li>
<li class="L13776" rel="L13776"></li>
<li class="L13777" rel="L13777">“He first laughed at my words, and then frowned at them. He moved a</li>
<li class="L13778" rel="L13778">chair with his foot near to mine, ordered the woman away, and said in a</li>
<li class="L13779" rel="L13779">subdued voice,</li>
<li class="L13780" rel="L13780"></li>
<li class="L13781" rel="L13781">“&#39;Doctor, finding my brother in this difficulty with these hinds, I</li>
<li class="L13782" rel="L13782">recommended that your aid should be invited. Your reputation is high,</li>
<li class="L13783" rel="L13783">and, as a young man with your fortune to make, you are probably mindful</li>
<li class="L13784" rel="L13784">of your interest. The things that you see here, are things to be seen,</li>
<li class="L13785" rel="L13785">and not spoken of.&#39;</li>
<li class="L13786" rel="L13786"></li>
<li class="L13787" rel="L13787">“I listened to the patient&#39;s breathing, and avoided answering.</li>
<li class="L13788" rel="L13788"></li>
<li class="L13789" rel="L13789">“&#39;Do you honour me with your attention, Doctor?&#39;</li>
<li class="L13790" rel="L13790"></li>
<li class="L13791" rel="L13791">“&#39;Monsieur,&#39; said I, &#39;in my profession, the communications of patients</li>
<li class="L13792" rel="L13792">are always received in confidence.&#39; I was guarded in my answer, for I</li>
<li class="L13793" rel="L13793">was troubled in my mind with what I had heard and seen.</li>
<li class="L13794" rel="L13794"></li>
<li class="L13795" rel="L13795">“Her breathing was so difficult to trace, that I carefully tried the</li>
<li class="L13796" rel="L13796">pulse and the heart. There was life, and no more. Looking round as I</li>
<li class="L13797" rel="L13797">resumed my seat, I found both the brothers intent upon me.</li>
<li class="L13798" rel="L13798"></li>
<li class="L13799" rel="L13799">        *****</li>
<li class="L13800" rel="L13800"></li>
<li class="L13801" rel="L13801">“I write with so much difficulty, the cold is so severe, I am so</li>
<li class="L13802" rel="L13802">fearful of being detected and consigned to an underground cell and total</li>
<li class="L13803" rel="L13803">darkness, that I must abridge this narrative. There is no confusion or</li>
<li class="L13804" rel="L13804">failure in my memory; it can recall, and could detail, every word that</li>
<li class="L13805" rel="L13805">was ever spoken between me and those brothers.</li>
<li class="L13806" rel="L13806"></li>
<li class="L13807" rel="L13807">“She lingered for a week. Towards the last, I could understand some few</li>
<li class="L13808" rel="L13808">syllables that she said to me, by placing my ear close to her lips. She</li>
<li class="L13809" rel="L13809">asked me where she was, and I told her; who I was, and I told her. It</li>
<li class="L13810" rel="L13810">was in vain that I asked her for her family name. She faintly shook her</li>
<li class="L13811" rel="L13811">head upon the pillow, and kept her secret, as the boy had done.</li>
<li class="L13812" rel="L13812"></li>
<li class="L13813" rel="L13813">“I had no opportunity of asking her any question, until I had told the</li>
<li class="L13814" rel="L13814">brothers she was sinking fast, and could not live another day. Until</li>
<li class="L13815" rel="L13815">then, though no one was ever presented to her consciousness save the</li>
<li class="L13816" rel="L13816">woman and myself, one or other of them had always jealously sat behind</li>
<li class="L13817" rel="L13817">the curtain at the head of the bed when I was there. But when it came to</li>
<li class="L13818" rel="L13818">that, they seemed careless what communication I might hold with her; as</li>
<li class="L13819" rel="L13819">if--the thought passed through my mind--I were dying too.</li>
<li class="L13820" rel="L13820"></li>
<li class="L13821" rel="L13821">“I always observed that their pride bitterly resented the younger</li>
<li class="L13822" rel="L13822">brother&#39;s (as I call him) having crossed swords with a peasant, and that</li>
<li class="L13823" rel="L13823">peasant a boy. The only consideration that appeared to affect the mind</li>
<li class="L13824" rel="L13824">of either of them was the consideration that this was highly degrading</li>
<li class="L13825" rel="L13825">to the family, and was ridiculous. As often as I caught the younger</li>
<li class="L13826" rel="L13826">brother&#39;s eyes, their expression reminded me that he disliked me deeply,</li>
<li class="L13827" rel="L13827">for knowing what I knew from the boy. He was smoother and more polite to</li>
<li class="L13828" rel="L13828">me than the elder; but I saw this. I also saw that I was an incumbrance</li>
<li class="L13829" rel="L13829">in the mind of the elder, too.</li>
<li class="L13830" rel="L13830"></li>
<li class="L13831" rel="L13831">“My patient died, two hours before midnight--at a time, by my watch,</li>
<li class="L13832" rel="L13832">answering almost to the minute when I had first seen her. I was alone</li>
<li class="L13833" rel="L13833">with her, when her forlorn young head drooped gently on one side, and</li>
<li class="L13834" rel="L13834">all her earthly wrongs and sorrows ended.</li>
<li class="L13835" rel="L13835"></li>
<li class="L13836" rel="L13836">“The brothers were waiting in a room down-stairs, impatient to ride</li>
<li class="L13837" rel="L13837">away. I had heard them, alone at the bedside, striking their boots with</li>
<li class="L13838" rel="L13838">their riding-whips, and loitering up and down.</li>
<li class="L13839" rel="L13839"></li>
<li class="L13840" rel="L13840">“&#39;At last she is dead?&#39; said the elder, when I went in.</li>
<li class="L13841" rel="L13841"></li>
<li class="L13842" rel="L13842">“&#39;She is dead,&#39; said I.</li>
<li class="L13843" rel="L13843"></li>
<li class="L13844" rel="L13844">“&#39;I congratulate you, my brother,&#39; were his words as he turned round.</li>
<li class="L13845" rel="L13845"></li>
<li class="L13846" rel="L13846">“He had before offered me money, which I had postponed taking. He now</li>
<li class="L13847" rel="L13847">gave me a rouleau of gold. I took it from his hand, but laid it on</li>
<li class="L13848" rel="L13848">the table. I had considered the question, and had resolved to accept</li>
<li class="L13849" rel="L13849">nothing.</li>
<li class="L13850" rel="L13850"></li>
<li class="L13851" rel="L13851">“&#39;Pray excuse me,&#39; said I. &#39;Under the circumstances, no.&#39;</li>
<li class="L13852" rel="L13852"></li>
<li class="L13853" rel="L13853">“They exchanged looks, but bent their heads to me as I bent mine to</li>
<li class="L13854" rel="L13854">them, and we parted without another word on either side.</li>
<li class="L13855" rel="L13855"></li>
<li class="L13856" rel="L13856">        *****</li>
<li class="L13857" rel="L13857"></li>
<li class="L13858" rel="L13858">“I am weary, weary, weary--worn down by misery. I cannot read what I</li>
<li class="L13859" rel="L13859">have written with this gaunt hand.</li>
<li class="L13860" rel="L13860"></li>
<li class="L13861" rel="L13861">“Early in the morning, the rouleau of gold was left at my door in a</li>
<li class="L13862" rel="L13862">little box, with my name on the outside. From the first, I had anxiously</li>
<li class="L13863" rel="L13863">considered what I ought to do. I decided, that day, to write privately</li>
<li class="L13864" rel="L13864">to the Minister, stating the nature of the two cases to which I had been</li>
<li class="L13865" rel="L13865">summoned, and the place to which I had gone: in effect, stating all the</li>
<li class="L13866" rel="L13866">circumstances. I knew what Court influence was, and what the immunities</li>
<li class="L13867" rel="L13867">of the Nobles were, and I expected that the matter would never be</li>
<li class="L13868" rel="L13868">heard of; but, I wished to relieve my own mind. I had kept the matter a</li>
<li class="L13869" rel="L13869">profound secret, even from my wife; and this, too, I resolved to state</li>
<li class="L13870" rel="L13870">in my letter. I had no apprehension whatever of my real danger; but</li>
<li class="L13871" rel="L13871">I was conscious that there might be danger for others, if others were</li>
<li class="L13872" rel="L13872">compromised by possessing the knowledge that I possessed.</li>
<li class="L13873" rel="L13873"></li>
<li class="L13874" rel="L13874">“I was much engaged that day, and could not complete my letter that</li>
<li class="L13875" rel="L13875">night. I rose long before my usual time next morning to finish it.</li>
<li class="L13876" rel="L13876">It was the last day of the year. The letter was lying before me just</li>
<li class="L13877" rel="L13877">completed, when I was told that a lady waited, who wished to see me.</li>
<li class="L13878" rel="L13878"></li>
<li class="L13879" rel="L13879">        *****</li>
<li class="L13880" rel="L13880"></li>
<li class="L13881" rel="L13881">“I am growing more and more unequal to the task I have set myself. It is</li>
<li class="L13882" rel="L13882">so cold, so dark, my senses are so benumbed, and the gloom upon me is so</li>
<li class="L13883" rel="L13883">dreadful.</li>
<li class="L13884" rel="L13884"></li>
<li class="L13885" rel="L13885">“The lady was young, engaging, and handsome, but not marked for long</li>
<li class="L13886" rel="L13886">life. She was in great agitation. She presented herself to me as the</li>
<li class="L13887" rel="L13887">wife of the Marquis St. Evremonde. I connected the title by which the</li>
<li class="L13888" rel="L13888">boy had addressed the elder brother, with the initial letter embroidered</li>
<li class="L13889" rel="L13889">on the scarf, and had no difficulty in arriving at the conclusion that I</li>
<li class="L13890" rel="L13890">had seen that nobleman very lately.</li>
<li class="L13891" rel="L13891"></li>
<li class="L13892" rel="L13892">“My memory is still accurate, but I cannot write the words of our</li>
<li class="L13893" rel="L13893">conversation. I suspect that I am watched more closely than I was, and I</li>
<li class="L13894" rel="L13894">know not at what times I may be watched. She had in part suspected, and</li>
<li class="L13895" rel="L13895">in part discovered, the main facts of the cruel story, of her husband&#39;s</li>
<li class="L13896" rel="L13896">share in it, and my being resorted to. She did not know that the girl</li>
<li class="L13897" rel="L13897">was dead. Her hope had been, she said in great distress, to show her,</li>
<li class="L13898" rel="L13898">in secret, a woman&#39;s sympathy. Her hope had been to avert the wrath of</li>
<li class="L13899" rel="L13899">Heaven from a House that had long been hateful to the suffering many.</li>
<li class="L13900" rel="L13900"></li>
<li class="L13901" rel="L13901">“She had reasons for believing that there was a young sister living, and</li>
<li class="L13902" rel="L13902">her greatest desire was, to help that sister. I could tell her nothing</li>
<li class="L13903" rel="L13903">but that there was such a sister; beyond that, I knew nothing. Her</li>
<li class="L13904" rel="L13904">inducement to come to me, relying on my confidence, had been the hope</li>
<li class="L13905" rel="L13905">that I could tell her the name and place of abode. Whereas, to this</li>
<li class="L13906" rel="L13906">wretched hour I am ignorant of both.</li>
<li class="L13907" rel="L13907"></li>
<li class="L13908" rel="L13908">        *****</li>
<li class="L13909" rel="L13909"></li>
<li class="L13910" rel="L13910">“These scraps of paper fail me. One was taken from me, with a warning,</li>
<li class="L13911" rel="L13911">yesterday. I must finish my record to-day.</li>
<li class="L13912" rel="L13912"></li>
<li class="L13913" rel="L13913">“She was a good, compassionate lady, and not happy in her marriage. How</li>
<li class="L13914" rel="L13914">could she be! The brother distrusted and disliked her, and his influence</li>
<li class="L13915" rel="L13915">was all opposed to her; she stood in dread of him, and in dread of her</li>
<li class="L13916" rel="L13916">husband too. When I handed her down to the door, there was a child, a</li>
<li class="L13917" rel="L13917">pretty boy from two to three years old, in her carriage.</li>
<li class="L13918" rel="L13918"></li>
<li class="L13919" rel="L13919">“&#39;For his sake, Doctor,&#39; she said, pointing to him in tears, &#39;I would do</li>
<li class="L13920" rel="L13920">all I can to make what poor amends I can. He will never prosper in his</li>
<li class="L13921" rel="L13921">inheritance otherwise. I have a presentiment that if no other innocent</li>
<li class="L13922" rel="L13922">atonement is made for this, it will one day be required of him. What</li>
<li class="L13923" rel="L13923">I have left to call my own--it is little beyond the worth of a few</li>
<li class="L13924" rel="L13924">jewels--I will make it the first charge of his life to bestow, with the</li>
<li class="L13925" rel="L13925">compassion and lamenting of his dead mother, on this injured family, if</li>
<li class="L13926" rel="L13926">the sister can be discovered.&#39;</li>
<li class="L13927" rel="L13927"></li>
<li class="L13928" rel="L13928">“She kissed the boy, and said, caressing him, &#39;It is for thine own dear</li>
<li class="L13929" rel="L13929">sake. Thou wilt be faithful, little Charles?&#39; The child answered her</li>
<li class="L13930" rel="L13930">bravely, &#39;Yes!&#39; I kissed her hand, and she took him in her arms, and</li>
<li class="L13931" rel="L13931">went away caressing him. I never saw her more.</li>
<li class="L13932" rel="L13932"></li>
<li class="L13933" rel="L13933">“As she had mentioned her husband&#39;s name in the faith that I knew it,</li>
<li class="L13934" rel="L13934">I added no mention of it to my letter. I sealed my letter, and, not</li>
<li class="L13935" rel="L13935">trusting it out of my own hands, delivered it myself that day.</li>
<li class="L13936" rel="L13936"></li>
<li class="L13937" rel="L13937">“That night, the last night of the year, towards nine o&#39;clock, a man in</li>
<li class="L13938" rel="L13938">a black dress rang at my gate, demanded to see me, and softly followed</li>
<li class="L13939" rel="L13939">my servant, Ernest Defarge, a youth, up-stairs. When my servant came</li>
<li class="L13940" rel="L13940">into the room where I sat with my wife--O my wife, beloved of my heart!</li>
<li class="L13941" rel="L13941">My fair young English wife!--we saw the man, who was supposed to be at</li>
<li class="L13942" rel="L13942">the gate, standing silent behind him.</li>
<li class="L13943" rel="L13943"></li>
<li class="L13944" rel="L13944">“An urgent case in the Rue St. Honore, he said. It would not detain me,</li>
<li class="L13945" rel="L13945">he had a coach in waiting.</li>
<li class="L13946" rel="L13946"></li>
<li class="L13947" rel="L13947">“It brought me here, it brought me to my grave. When I was clear of the</li>
<li class="L13948" rel="L13948">house, a black muffler was drawn tightly over my mouth from behind, and</li>
<li class="L13949" rel="L13949">my arms were pinioned. The two brothers crossed the road from a dark</li>
<li class="L13950" rel="L13950">corner, and identified me with a single gesture. The Marquis took from</li>
<li class="L13951" rel="L13951">his pocket the letter I had written, showed it me, burnt it in the light</li>
<li class="L13952" rel="L13952">of a lantern that was held, and extinguished the ashes with his foot.</li>
<li class="L13953" rel="L13953">Not a word was spoken. I was brought here, I was brought to my living</li>
<li class="L13954" rel="L13954">grave.</li>
<li class="L13955" rel="L13955"></li>
<li class="L13956" rel="L13956">“If it had pleased _God_ to put it in the hard heart of either of the</li>
<li class="L13957" rel="L13957">brothers, in all these frightful years, to grant me any tidings of</li>
<li class="L13958" rel="L13958">my dearest wife--so much as to let me know by a word whether alive or</li>
<li class="L13959" rel="L13959">dead--I might have thought that He had not quite abandoned them. But,</li>
<li class="L13960" rel="L13960">now I believe that the mark of the red cross is fatal to them, and that</li>
<li class="L13961" rel="L13961">they have no part in His mercies. And them and their descendants, to the</li>
<li class="L13962" rel="L13962">last of their race, I, Alexandre Manette, unhappy prisoner, do this last</li>
<li class="L13963" rel="L13963">night of the year 1767, in my unbearable agony, denounce to the times</li>
<li class="L13964" rel="L13964">when all these things shall be answered for. I denounce them to Heaven</li>
<li class="L13965" rel="L13965">and to earth.”</li>
<li class="L13966" rel="L13966"></li>
<li class="L13967" rel="L13967">A terrible sound arose when the reading of this document was done. A</li>
<li class="L13968" rel="L13968">sound of craving and eagerness that had nothing articulate in it but</li>
<li class="L13969" rel="L13969">blood. The narrative called up the most revengeful passions of the time,</li>
<li class="L13970" rel="L13970">and there was not a head in the nation but must have dropped before it.</li>
<li class="L13971" rel="L13971"></li>
<li class="L13972" rel="L13972">Little need, in presence of that tribunal and that auditory, to show</li>
<li class="L13973" rel="L13973">how the Defarges had not made the paper public, with the other captured</li>
<li class="L13974" rel="L13974">Bastille memorials borne in procession, and had kept it, biding their</li>
<li class="L13975" rel="L13975">time. Little need to show that this detested family name had long been</li>
<li class="L13976" rel="L13976">anathematised by Saint Antoine, and was wrought into the fatal register.</li>
<li class="L13977" rel="L13977">The man never trod ground whose virtues and services would have</li>
<li class="L13978" rel="L13978">sustained him in that place that day, against such denunciation.</li>
<li class="L13979" rel="L13979"></li>
<li class="L13980" rel="L13980">And all the worse for the doomed man, that the denouncer was a</li>
<li class="L13981" rel="L13981">well-known citizen, his own attached friend, the father of his wife. One</li>
<li class="L13982" rel="L13982">of the frenzied aspirations of the populace was, for imitations of</li>
<li class="L13983" rel="L13983">the questionable public virtues of antiquity, and for sacrifices and</li>
<li class="L13984" rel="L13984">self-immolations on the people&#39;s altar. Therefore when the President</li>
<li class="L13985" rel="L13985">said (else had his own head quivered on his shoulders), that the good</li>
<li class="L13986" rel="L13986">physician of the Republic would deserve better still of the Republic by</li>
<li class="L13987" rel="L13987">rooting out an obnoxious family of Aristocrats, and would doubtless feel</li>
<li class="L13988" rel="L13988">a sacred glow and joy in making his daughter a widow and her child an</li>
<li class="L13989" rel="L13989">orphan, there was wild excitement, patriotic fervour, not a touch of</li>
<li class="L13990" rel="L13990">human sympathy.</li>
<li class="L13991" rel="L13991"></li>
<li class="L13992" rel="L13992">“Much influence around him, has that Doctor?” murmured Madame Defarge,</li>
<li class="L13993" rel="L13993">smiling to The Vengeance. “Save him now, my Doctor, save him!”</li>
<li class="L13994" rel="L13994"></li>
<li class="L13995" rel="L13995">At every juryman&#39;s vote, there was a roar. Another and another. Roar and</li>
<li class="L13996" rel="L13996">roar.</li>
<li class="L13997" rel="L13997"></li>
<li class="L13998" rel="L13998">Unanimously voted. At heart and by descent an Aristocrat, an enemy</li>
<li class="L13999" rel="L13999">of the Republic, a notorious oppressor of the People. Back to the</li>
<li class="L14000" rel="L14000">Conciergerie, and Death within four-and-twenty hours!</li>
<li class="L14001" rel="L14001"></li>
<li class="L14002" rel="L14002"></li>
<li class="L14003" rel="L14003"></li>
<li class="L14004" rel="L14004"></li>
<li class="L14005" rel="L14005">XI. Dusk</li>
<li class="L14006" rel="L14006"></li>
<li class="L14007" rel="L14007"></li>
<li class="L14008" rel="L14008">The wretched wife of the innocent man thus doomed to die, fell under</li>
<li class="L14009" rel="L14009">the sentence, as if she had been mortally stricken. But, she uttered no</li>
<li class="L14010" rel="L14010">sound; and so strong was the voice within her, representing that it was</li>
<li class="L14011" rel="L14011">she of all the world who must uphold him in his misery and not augment</li>
<li class="L14012" rel="L14012">it, that it quickly raised her, even from that shock.</li>
<li class="L14013" rel="L14013"></li>
<li class="L14014" rel="L14014">The Judges having to take part in a public demonstration out of doors,</li>
<li class="L14015" rel="L14015">the Tribunal adjourned. The quick noise and movement of the court&#39;s</li>
<li class="L14016" rel="L14016">emptying itself by many passages had not ceased, when Lucie stood</li>
<li class="L14017" rel="L14017">stretching out her arms towards her husband, with nothing in her face</li>
<li class="L14018" rel="L14018">but love and consolation.</li>
<li class="L14019" rel="L14019"></li>
<li class="L14020" rel="L14020">“If I might touch him! If I might embrace him once! O, good citizens, if</li>
<li class="L14021" rel="L14021">you would have so much compassion for us!”</li>
<li class="L14022" rel="L14022"></li>
<li class="L14023" rel="L14023">There was but a gaoler left, along with two of the four men who had</li>
<li class="L14024" rel="L14024">taken him last night, and Barsad. The people had all poured out to the</li>
<li class="L14025" rel="L14025">show in the streets. Barsad proposed to the rest, “Let her embrace</li>
<li class="L14026" rel="L14026">him then; it is but a moment.” It was silently acquiesced in, and they</li>
<li class="L14027" rel="L14027">passed her over the seats in the hall to a raised place, where he, by</li>
<li class="L14028" rel="L14028">leaning over the dock, could fold her in his arms.</li>
<li class="L14029" rel="L14029"></li>
<li class="L14030" rel="L14030">“Farewell, dear darling of my soul. My parting blessing on my love. We</li>
<li class="L14031" rel="L14031">shall meet again, where the weary are at rest!”</li>
<li class="L14032" rel="L14032"></li>
<li class="L14033" rel="L14033">They were her husband&#39;s words, as he held her to his bosom.</li>
<li class="L14034" rel="L14034"></li>
<li class="L14035" rel="L14035">“I can bear it, dear Charles. I am supported from above: don&#39;t suffer</li>
<li class="L14036" rel="L14036">for me. A parting blessing for our child.”</li>
<li class="L14037" rel="L14037"></li>
<li class="L14038" rel="L14038">“I send it to her by you. I kiss her by you. I say farewell to her by</li>
<li class="L14039" rel="L14039">you.”</li>
<li class="L14040" rel="L14040"></li>
<li class="L14041" rel="L14041">“My husband. No! A moment!” He was tearing himself apart from her.</li>
<li class="L14042" rel="L14042">“We shall not be separated long. I feel that this will break my heart</li>
<li class="L14043" rel="L14043">by-and-bye; but I will do my duty while I can, and when I leave her, God</li>
<li class="L14044" rel="L14044">will raise up friends for her, as He did for me.”</li>
<li class="L14045" rel="L14045"></li>
<li class="L14046" rel="L14046">Her father had followed her, and would have fallen on his knees to both</li>
<li class="L14047" rel="L14047">of them, but that Darnay put out a hand and seized him, crying:</li>
<li class="L14048" rel="L14048"></li>
<li class="L14049" rel="L14049">“No, no! What have you done, what have you done, that you should kneel</li>
<li class="L14050" rel="L14050">to us! We know now, what a struggle you made of old. We know, now what</li>
<li class="L14051" rel="L14051">you underwent when you suspected my descent, and when you knew it. We</li>
<li class="L14052" rel="L14052">know now, the natural antipathy you strove against, and conquered, for</li>
<li class="L14053" rel="L14053">her dear sake. We thank you with all our hearts, and all our love and</li>
<li class="L14054" rel="L14054">duty. Heaven be with you!”</li>
<li class="L14055" rel="L14055"></li>
<li class="L14056" rel="L14056">Her father&#39;s only answer was to draw his hands through his white hair,</li>
<li class="L14057" rel="L14057">and wring them with a shriek of anguish.</li>
<li class="L14058" rel="L14058"></li>
<li class="L14059" rel="L14059">“It could not be otherwise,” said the prisoner. “All things have worked</li>
<li class="L14060" rel="L14060">together as they have fallen out. It was the always-vain endeavour to</li>
<li class="L14061" rel="L14061">discharge my poor mother&#39;s trust that first brought my fatal presence</li>
<li class="L14062" rel="L14062">near you. Good could never come of such evil, a happier end was not in</li>
<li class="L14063" rel="L14063">nature to so unhappy a beginning. Be comforted, and forgive me. Heaven</li>
<li class="L14064" rel="L14064">bless you!”</li>
<li class="L14065" rel="L14065"></li>
<li class="L14066" rel="L14066">As he was drawn away, his wife released him, and stood looking after him</li>
<li class="L14067" rel="L14067">with her hands touching one another in the attitude of prayer, and</li>
<li class="L14068" rel="L14068">with a radiant look upon her face, in which there was even a comforting</li>
<li class="L14069" rel="L14069">smile. As he went out at the prisoners&#39; door, she turned, laid her head</li>
<li class="L14070" rel="L14070">lovingly on her father&#39;s breast, tried to speak to him, and fell at his</li>
<li class="L14071" rel="L14071">feet.</li>
<li class="L14072" rel="L14072"></li>
<li class="L14073" rel="L14073">Then, issuing from the obscure corner from which he had never moved,</li>
<li class="L14074" rel="L14074">Sydney Carton came and took her up. Only her father and Mr. Lorry were</li>
<li class="L14075" rel="L14075">with her. His arm trembled as it raised her, and supported her head.</li>
<li class="L14076" rel="L14076">Yet, there was an air about him that was not all of pity--that had a</li>
<li class="L14077" rel="L14077">flush of pride in it.</li>
<li class="L14078" rel="L14078"></li>
<li class="L14079" rel="L14079">“Shall I take her to a coach? I shall never feel her weight.”</li>
<li class="L14080" rel="L14080"></li>
<li class="L14081" rel="L14081">He carried her lightly to the door, and laid her tenderly down in a</li>
<li class="L14082" rel="L14082">coach. Her father and their old friend got into it, and he took his seat</li>
<li class="L14083" rel="L14083">beside the driver.</li>
<li class="L14084" rel="L14084"></li>
<li class="L14085" rel="L14085">When they arrived at the gateway where he had paused in the dark not</li>
<li class="L14086" rel="L14086">many hours before, to picture to himself on which of the rough stones of</li>
<li class="L14087" rel="L14087">the street her feet had trodden, he lifted her again, and carried her up</li>
<li class="L14088" rel="L14088">the staircase to their rooms. There, he laid her down on a couch, where</li>
<li class="L14089" rel="L14089">her child and Miss Pross wept over her.</li>
<li class="L14090" rel="L14090"></li>
<li class="L14091" rel="L14091">“Don&#39;t recall her to herself,” he said, softly, to the latter, “she is</li>
<li class="L14092" rel="L14092">better so. Don&#39;t revive her to consciousness, while she only faints.”</li>
<li class="L14093" rel="L14093"></li>
<li class="L14094" rel="L14094">“Oh, Carton, Carton, dear Carton!” cried little Lucie, springing up and</li>
<li class="L14095" rel="L14095">throwing her arms passionately round him, in a burst of grief. “Now that</li>
<li class="L14096" rel="L14096">you have come, I think you will do something to help mamma, something to</li>
<li class="L14097" rel="L14097">save papa! O, look at her, dear Carton! Can you, of all the people who</li>
<li class="L14098" rel="L14098">love her, bear to see her so?”</li>
<li class="L14099" rel="L14099"></li>
<li class="L14100" rel="L14100">He bent over the child, and laid her blooming cheek against his face. He</li>
<li class="L14101" rel="L14101">put her gently from him, and looked at her unconscious mother.</li>
<li class="L14102" rel="L14102"></li>
<li class="L14103" rel="L14103">“Before I go,” he said, and paused--“I may kiss her?”</li>
<li class="L14104" rel="L14104"></li>
<li class="L14105" rel="L14105">It was remembered afterwards that when he bent down and touched her face</li>
<li class="L14106" rel="L14106">with his lips, he murmured some words. The child, who was nearest to</li>
<li class="L14107" rel="L14107">him, told them afterwards, and told her grandchildren when she was a</li>
<li class="L14108" rel="L14108">handsome old lady, that she heard him say, “A life you love.”</li>
<li class="L14109" rel="L14109"></li>
<li class="L14110" rel="L14110">When he had gone out into the next room, he turned suddenly on Mr. Lorry</li>
<li class="L14111" rel="L14111">and her father, who were following, and said to the latter:</li>
<li class="L14112" rel="L14112"></li>
<li class="L14113" rel="L14113">“You had great influence but yesterday, Doctor Manette; let it at least</li>
<li class="L14114" rel="L14114">be tried. These judges, and all the men in power, are very friendly to</li>
<li class="L14115" rel="L14115">you, and very recognisant of your services; are they not?”</li>
<li class="L14116" rel="L14116"></li>
<li class="L14117" rel="L14117">“Nothing connected with Charles was concealed from me. I had the</li>
<li class="L14118" rel="L14118">strongest assurances that I should save him; and I did.” He returned the</li>
<li class="L14119" rel="L14119">answer in great trouble, and very slowly.</li>
<li class="L14120" rel="L14120"></li>
<li class="L14121" rel="L14121">“Try them again. The hours between this and to-morrow afternoon are few</li>
<li class="L14122" rel="L14122">and short, but try.”</li>
<li class="L14123" rel="L14123"></li>
<li class="L14124" rel="L14124">“I intend to try. I will not rest a moment.”</li>
<li class="L14125" rel="L14125"></li>
<li class="L14126" rel="L14126">“That&#39;s well. I have known such energy as yours do great things before</li>
<li class="L14127" rel="L14127">now--though never,” he added, with a smile and a sigh together, “such</li>
<li class="L14128" rel="L14128">great things as this. But try! Of little worth as life is when we misuse</li>
<li class="L14129" rel="L14129">it, it is worth that effort. It would cost nothing to lay down if it</li>
<li class="L14130" rel="L14130">were not.”</li>
<li class="L14131" rel="L14131"></li>
<li class="L14132" rel="L14132">“I will go,” said Doctor Manette, “to the Prosecutor and the President</li>
<li class="L14133" rel="L14133">straight, and I will go to others whom it is better not to name. I will</li>
<li class="L14134" rel="L14134">write too, and--But stay! There is a Celebration in the streets, and no</li>
<li class="L14135" rel="L14135">one will be accessible until dark.”</li>
<li class="L14136" rel="L14136"></li>
<li class="L14137" rel="L14137">“That&#39;s true. Well! It is a forlorn hope at the best, and not much the</li>
<li class="L14138" rel="L14138">forlorner for being delayed till dark. I should like to know how you</li>
<li class="L14139" rel="L14139">speed; though, mind! I expect nothing! When are you likely to have seen</li>
<li class="L14140" rel="L14140">these dread powers, Doctor Manette?”</li>
<li class="L14141" rel="L14141"></li>
<li class="L14142" rel="L14142">“Immediately after dark, I should hope. Within an hour or two from</li>
<li class="L14143" rel="L14143">this.”</li>
<li class="L14144" rel="L14144"></li>
<li class="L14145" rel="L14145">“It will be dark soon after four. Let us stretch the hour or two. If I</li>
<li class="L14146" rel="L14146">go to Mr. Lorry&#39;s at nine, shall I hear what you have done, either from</li>
<li class="L14147" rel="L14147">our friend or from yourself?”</li>
<li class="L14148" rel="L14148"></li>
<li class="L14149" rel="L14149">“Yes.”</li>
<li class="L14150" rel="L14150"></li>
<li class="L14151" rel="L14151">“May you prosper!”</li>
<li class="L14152" rel="L14152"></li>
<li class="L14153" rel="L14153">Mr. Lorry followed Sydney to the outer door, and, touching him on the</li>
<li class="L14154" rel="L14154">shoulder as he was going away, caused him to turn.</li>
<li class="L14155" rel="L14155"></li>
<li class="L14156" rel="L14156">“I have no hope,” said Mr. Lorry, in a low and sorrowful whisper.</li>
<li class="L14157" rel="L14157"></li>
<li class="L14158" rel="L14158">“Nor have I.”</li>
<li class="L14159" rel="L14159"></li>
<li class="L14160" rel="L14160">“If any one of these men, or all of these men, were disposed to spare</li>
<li class="L14161" rel="L14161">him--which is a large supposition; for what is his life, or any man&#39;s</li>
<li class="L14162" rel="L14162">to them!--I doubt if they durst spare him after the demonstration in the</li>
<li class="L14163" rel="L14163">court.”</li>
<li class="L14164" rel="L14164"></li>
<li class="L14165" rel="L14165">“And so do I. I heard the fall of the axe in that sound.”</li>
<li class="L14166" rel="L14166"></li>
<li class="L14167" rel="L14167">Mr. Lorry leaned his arm upon the door-post, and bowed his face upon it.</li>
<li class="L14168" rel="L14168"></li>
<li class="L14169" rel="L14169">“Don&#39;t despond,” said Carton, very gently; “don&#39;t grieve. I encouraged</li>
<li class="L14170" rel="L14170">Doctor Manette in this idea, because I felt that it might one day be</li>
<li class="L14171" rel="L14171">consolatory to her. Otherwise, she might think &#39;his life was wantonly</li>
<li class="L14172" rel="L14172">thrown away or wasted,&#39; and that might trouble her.”</li>
<li class="L14173" rel="L14173"></li>
<li class="L14174" rel="L14174">“Yes, yes, yes,” returned Mr. Lorry, drying his eyes, “you are right.</li>
<li class="L14175" rel="L14175">But he will perish; there is no real hope.”</li>
<li class="L14176" rel="L14176"></li>
<li class="L14177" rel="L14177">“Yes. He will perish: there is no real hope,” echoed Carton.</li>
<li class="L14178" rel="L14178"></li>
<li class="L14179" rel="L14179">And walked with a settled step, down-stairs.</li>
<li class="L14180" rel="L14180"></li>
<li class="L14181" rel="L14181"></li>
<li class="L14182" rel="L14182"></li>
<li class="L14183" rel="L14183"></li>
<li class="L14184" rel="L14184">XII. Darkness</li>
<li class="L14185" rel="L14185"></li>
<li class="L14186" rel="L14186"></li>
<li class="L14187" rel="L14187">Sydney Carton paused in the street, not quite decided where to go. “At</li>
<li class="L14188" rel="L14188">Tellson&#39;s banking-house at nine,” he said, with a musing face. “Shall I</li>
<li class="L14189" rel="L14189">do well, in the mean time, to show myself? I think so. It is best that</li>
<li class="L14190" rel="L14190">these people should know there is such a man as I here; it is a sound</li>
<li class="L14191" rel="L14191">precaution, and may be a necessary preparation. But care, care, care!</li>
<li class="L14192" rel="L14192">Let me think it out!”</li>
<li class="L14193" rel="L14193"></li>
<li class="L14194" rel="L14194">Checking his steps which had begun to tend towards an object, he took a</li>
<li class="L14195" rel="L14195">turn or two in the already darkening street, and traced the thought</li>
<li class="L14196" rel="L14196">in his mind to its possible consequences. His first impression was</li>
<li class="L14197" rel="L14197">confirmed. “It is best,” he said, finally resolved, “that these people</li>
<li class="L14198" rel="L14198">should know there is such a man as I here.” And he turned his face</li>
<li class="L14199" rel="L14199">towards Saint Antoine.</li>
<li class="L14200" rel="L14200"></li>
<li class="L14201" rel="L14201">Defarge had described himself, that day, as the keeper of a wine-shop in</li>
<li class="L14202" rel="L14202">the Saint Antoine suburb. It was not difficult for one who knew the city</li>
<li class="L14203" rel="L14203">well, to find his house without asking any question. Having ascertained</li>
<li class="L14204" rel="L14204">its situation, Carton came out of those closer streets again, and dined</li>
<li class="L14205" rel="L14205">at a place of refreshment and fell sound asleep after dinner. For the</li>
<li class="L14206" rel="L14206">first time in many years, he had no strong drink. Since last night he</li>
<li class="L14207" rel="L14207">had taken nothing but a little light thin wine, and last night he had</li>
<li class="L14208" rel="L14208">dropped the brandy slowly down on Mr. Lorry&#39;s hearth like a man who had</li>
<li class="L14209" rel="L14209">done with it.</li>
<li class="L14210" rel="L14210"></li>
<li class="L14211" rel="L14211">It was as late as seven o&#39;clock when he awoke refreshed, and went out</li>
<li class="L14212" rel="L14212">into the streets again. As he passed along towards Saint Antoine, he</li>
<li class="L14213" rel="L14213">stopped at a shop-window where there was a mirror, and slightly altered</li>
<li class="L14214" rel="L14214">the disordered arrangement of his loose cravat, and his coat-collar, and</li>
<li class="L14215" rel="L14215">his wild hair. This done, he went on direct to Defarge&#39;s, and went in.</li>
<li class="L14216" rel="L14216"></li>
<li class="L14217" rel="L14217">There happened to be no customer in the shop but Jacques Three, of the</li>
<li class="L14218" rel="L14218">restless fingers and the croaking voice. This man, whom he had seen upon</li>
<li class="L14219" rel="L14219">the Jury, stood drinking at the little counter, in conversation with the</li>
<li class="L14220" rel="L14220">Defarges, man and wife. The Vengeance assisted in the conversation, like</li>
<li class="L14221" rel="L14221">a regular member of the establishment.</li>
<li class="L14222" rel="L14222"></li>
<li class="L14223" rel="L14223">As Carton walked in, took his seat and asked (in very indifferent</li>
<li class="L14224" rel="L14224">French) for a small measure of wine, Madame Defarge cast a careless</li>
<li class="L14225" rel="L14225">glance at him, and then a keener, and then a keener, and then advanced</li>
<li class="L14226" rel="L14226">to him herself, and asked him what it was he had ordered.</li>
<li class="L14227" rel="L14227"></li>
<li class="L14228" rel="L14228">He repeated what he had already said.</li>
<li class="L14229" rel="L14229"></li>
<li class="L14230" rel="L14230">“English?” asked Madame Defarge, inquisitively raising her dark</li>
<li class="L14231" rel="L14231">eyebrows.</li>
<li class="L14232" rel="L14232"></li>
<li class="L14233" rel="L14233">After looking at her, as if the sound of even a single French word were</li>
<li class="L14234" rel="L14234">slow to express itself to him, he answered, in his former strong foreign</li>
<li class="L14235" rel="L14235">accent. “Yes, madame, yes. I am English!”</li>
<li class="L14236" rel="L14236"></li>
<li class="L14237" rel="L14237">Madame Defarge returned to her counter to get the wine, and, as he</li>
<li class="L14238" rel="L14238">took up a Jacobin journal and feigned to pore over it puzzling out its</li>
<li class="L14239" rel="L14239">meaning, he heard her say, “I swear to you, like Evremonde!”</li>
<li class="L14240" rel="L14240"></li>
<li class="L14241" rel="L14241">Defarge brought him the wine, and gave him Good Evening.</li>
<li class="L14242" rel="L14242"></li>
<li class="L14243" rel="L14243">“How?”</li>
<li class="L14244" rel="L14244"></li>
<li class="L14245" rel="L14245">“Good evening.”</li>
<li class="L14246" rel="L14246"></li>
<li class="L14247" rel="L14247">“Oh! Good evening, citizen,” filling his glass. “Ah! and good wine. I</li>
<li class="L14248" rel="L14248">drink to the Republic.”</li>
<li class="L14249" rel="L14249"></li>
<li class="L14250" rel="L14250">Defarge went back to the counter, and said, “Certainly, a little like.”</li>
<li class="L14251" rel="L14251"> Madame sternly retorted, “I tell you a good deal like.” Jacques Three</li>
<li class="L14252" rel="L14252">pacifically remarked, “He is so much in your mind, see you, madame.”</li>
<li class="L14253" rel="L14253"> The amiable Vengeance added, with a laugh, “Yes, my faith! And you</li>
<li class="L14254" rel="L14254">are looking forward with so much pleasure to seeing him once more</li>
<li class="L14255" rel="L14255">to-morrow!”</li>
<li class="L14256" rel="L14256"></li>
<li class="L14257" rel="L14257">Carton followed the lines and words of his paper, with a slow</li>
<li class="L14258" rel="L14258">forefinger, and with a studious and absorbed face. They were all leaning</li>
<li class="L14259" rel="L14259">their arms on the counter close together, speaking low. After a silence</li>
<li class="L14260" rel="L14260">of a few moments, during which they all looked towards him without</li>
<li class="L14261" rel="L14261">disturbing his outward attention from the Jacobin editor, they resumed</li>
<li class="L14262" rel="L14262">their conversation.</li>
<li class="L14263" rel="L14263"></li>
<li class="L14264" rel="L14264">“It is true what madame says,” observed Jacques Three. “Why stop? There</li>
<li class="L14265" rel="L14265">is great force in that. Why stop?”</li>
<li class="L14266" rel="L14266"></li>
<li class="L14267" rel="L14267">“Well, well,” reasoned Defarge, “but one must stop somewhere. After all,</li>
<li class="L14268" rel="L14268">the question is still where?”</li>
<li class="L14269" rel="L14269"></li>
<li class="L14270" rel="L14270">“At extermination,” said madame.</li>
<li class="L14271" rel="L14271"></li>
<li class="L14272" rel="L14272">“Magnificent!” croaked Jacques Three. The Vengeance, also, highly</li>
<li class="L14273" rel="L14273">approved.</li>
<li class="L14274" rel="L14274"></li>
<li class="L14275" rel="L14275">“Extermination is good doctrine, my wife,” said Defarge, rather</li>
<li class="L14276" rel="L14276">troubled; “in general, I say nothing against it. But this Doctor has</li>
<li class="L14277" rel="L14277">suffered much; you have seen him to-day; you have observed his face when</li>
<li class="L14278" rel="L14278">the paper was read.”</li>
<li class="L14279" rel="L14279"></li>
<li class="L14280" rel="L14280">“I have observed his face!” repeated madame, contemptuously and angrily.</li>
<li class="L14281" rel="L14281">“Yes. I have observed his face. I have observed his face to be not the</li>
<li class="L14282" rel="L14282">face of a true friend of the Republic. Let him take care of his face!”</li>
<li class="L14283" rel="L14283"></li>
<li class="L14284" rel="L14284">“And you have observed, my wife,” said Defarge, in a deprecatory manner,</li>
<li class="L14285" rel="L14285">“the anguish of his daughter, which must be a dreadful anguish to him!”</li>
<li class="L14286" rel="L14286"></li>
<li class="L14287" rel="L14287">“I have observed his daughter,” repeated madame; “yes, I have observed</li>
<li class="L14288" rel="L14288">his daughter, more times than one. I have observed her to-day, and I</li>
<li class="L14289" rel="L14289">have observed her other days. I have observed her in the court, and</li>
<li class="L14290" rel="L14290">I have observed her in the street by the prison. Let me but lift my</li>
<li class="L14291" rel="L14291">finger--!” She seemed to raise it (the listener&#39;s eyes were always on</li>
<li class="L14292" rel="L14292">his paper), and to let it fall with a rattle on the ledge before her, as</li>
<li class="L14293" rel="L14293">if the axe had dropped.</li>
<li class="L14294" rel="L14294"></li>
<li class="L14295" rel="L14295">“The citizeness is superb!” croaked the Juryman.</li>
<li class="L14296" rel="L14296"></li>
<li class="L14297" rel="L14297">“She is an Angel!” said The Vengeance, and embraced her.</li>
<li class="L14298" rel="L14298"></li>
<li class="L14299" rel="L14299">“As to thee,” pursued madame, implacably, addressing her husband, “if it</li>
<li class="L14300" rel="L14300">depended on thee--which, happily, it does not--thou wouldst rescue this</li>
<li class="L14301" rel="L14301">man even now.”</li>
<li class="L14302" rel="L14302"></li>
<li class="L14303" rel="L14303">“No!” protested Defarge. “Not if to lift this glass would do it! But I</li>
<li class="L14304" rel="L14304">would leave the matter there. I say, stop there.”</li>
<li class="L14305" rel="L14305"></li>
<li class="L14306" rel="L14306">“See you then, Jacques,” said Madame Defarge, wrathfully; “and see you,</li>
<li class="L14307" rel="L14307">too, my little Vengeance; see you both! Listen! For other crimes as</li>
<li class="L14308" rel="L14308">tyrants and oppressors, I have this race a long time on my register,</li>
<li class="L14309" rel="L14309">doomed to destruction and extermination. Ask my husband, is that so.”</li>
<li class="L14310" rel="L14310"></li>
<li class="L14311" rel="L14311">“It is so,” assented Defarge, without being asked.</li>
<li class="L14312" rel="L14312"></li>
<li class="L14313" rel="L14313">“In the beginning of the great days, when the Bastille falls, he finds</li>
<li class="L14314" rel="L14314">this paper of to-day, and he brings it home, and in the middle of the</li>
<li class="L14315" rel="L14315">night when this place is clear and shut, we read it, here on this spot,</li>
<li class="L14316" rel="L14316">by the light of this lamp. Ask him, is that so.”</li>
<li class="L14317" rel="L14317"></li>
<li class="L14318" rel="L14318">“It is so,” assented Defarge.</li>
<li class="L14319" rel="L14319"></li>
<li class="L14320" rel="L14320">“That night, I tell him, when the paper is read through, and the lamp is</li>
<li class="L14321" rel="L14321">burnt out, and the day is gleaming in above those shutters and between</li>
<li class="L14322" rel="L14322">those iron bars, that I have now a secret to communicate. Ask him, is</li>
<li class="L14323" rel="L14323">that so.”</li>
<li class="L14324" rel="L14324"></li>
<li class="L14325" rel="L14325">“It is so,” assented Defarge again.</li>
<li class="L14326" rel="L14326"></li>
<li class="L14327" rel="L14327">“I communicate to him that secret. I smite this bosom with these two</li>
<li class="L14328" rel="L14328">hands as I smite it now, and I tell him, &#39;Defarge, I was brought up</li>
<li class="L14329" rel="L14329">among the fishermen of the sea-shore, and that peasant family so injured</li>
<li class="L14330" rel="L14330">by the two Evremonde brothers, as that Bastille paper describes, is my</li>
<li class="L14331" rel="L14331">family. Defarge, that sister of the mortally wounded boy upon the ground</li>
<li class="L14332" rel="L14332">was my sister, that husband was my sister&#39;s husband, that unborn child</li>
<li class="L14333" rel="L14333">was their child, that brother was my brother, that father was my father,</li>
<li class="L14334" rel="L14334">those dead are my dead, and that summons to answer for those things</li>
<li class="L14335" rel="L14335">descends to me!&#39; Ask him, is that so.”</li>
<li class="L14336" rel="L14336"></li>
<li class="L14337" rel="L14337">“It is so,” assented Defarge once more.</li>
<li class="L14338" rel="L14338"></li>
<li class="L14339" rel="L14339">“Then tell Wind and Fire where to stop,” returned madame; “but don&#39;t</li>
<li class="L14340" rel="L14340">tell me.”</li>
<li class="L14341" rel="L14341"></li>
<li class="L14342" rel="L14342">Both her hearers derived a horrible enjoyment from the deadly nature</li>
<li class="L14343" rel="L14343">of her wrath--the listener could feel how white she was, without seeing</li>
<li class="L14344" rel="L14344">her--and both highly commended it. Defarge, a weak minority, interposed</li>
<li class="L14345" rel="L14345">a few words for the memory of the compassionate wife of the Marquis; but</li>
<li class="L14346" rel="L14346">only elicited from his own wife a repetition of her last reply. “Tell</li>
<li class="L14347" rel="L14347">the Wind and the Fire where to stop; not me!”</li>
<li class="L14348" rel="L14348"></li>
<li class="L14349" rel="L14349">Customers entered, and the group was broken up. The English customer</li>
<li class="L14350" rel="L14350">paid for what he had had, perplexedly counted his change, and asked, as</li>
<li class="L14351" rel="L14351">a stranger, to be directed towards the National Palace. Madame Defarge</li>
