<li class="L14352" rel="L14352">took him to the door, and put her arm on his, in pointing out the road.</li>
<li class="L14353" rel="L14353">The English customer was not without his reflections then, that it might</li>
<li class="L14354" rel="L14354">be a good deed to seize that arm, lift it, and strike under it sharp and</li>
<li class="L14355" rel="L14355">deep.</li>
<li class="L14356" rel="L14356"></li>
<li class="L14357" rel="L14357">But, he went his way, and was soon swallowed up in the shadow of the</li>
<li class="L14358" rel="L14358">prison wall. At the appointed hour, he emerged from it to present</li>
<li class="L14359" rel="L14359">himself in Mr. Lorry&#39;s room again, where he found the old gentleman</li>
<li class="L14360" rel="L14360">walking to and fro in restless anxiety. He said he had been with Lucie</li>
<li class="L14361" rel="L14361">until just now, and had only left her for a few minutes, to come and</li>
<li class="L14362" rel="L14362">keep his appointment. Her father had not been seen, since he quitted the</li>
<li class="L14363" rel="L14363">banking-house towards four o&#39;clock. She had some faint hopes that his</li>
<li class="L14364" rel="L14364">mediation might save Charles, but they were very slight. He had been</li>
<li class="L14365" rel="L14365">more than five hours gone: where could he be?</li>
<li class="L14366" rel="L14366"></li>
<li class="L14367" rel="L14367">Mr. Lorry waited until ten; but, Doctor Manette not returning, and</li>
<li class="L14368" rel="L14368">he being unwilling to leave Lucie any longer, it was arranged that he</li>
<li class="L14369" rel="L14369">should go back to her, and come to the banking-house again at midnight.</li>
<li class="L14370" rel="L14370">In the meanwhile, Carton would wait alone by the fire for the Doctor.</li>
<li class="L14371" rel="L14371"></li>
<li class="L14372" rel="L14372">He waited and waited, and the clock struck twelve; but Doctor Manette</li>
<li class="L14373" rel="L14373">did not come back. Mr. Lorry returned, and found no tidings of him, and</li>
<li class="L14374" rel="L14374">brought none. Where could he be?</li>
<li class="L14375" rel="L14375"></li>
<li class="L14376" rel="L14376">They were discussing this question, and were almost building up some</li>
<li class="L14377" rel="L14377">weak structure of hope on his prolonged absence, when they heard him on</li>
<li class="L14378" rel="L14378">the stairs. The instant he entered the room, it was plain that all was</li>
<li class="L14379" rel="L14379">lost.</li>
<li class="L14380" rel="L14380"></li>
<li class="L14381" rel="L14381">Whether he had really been to any one, or whether he had been all that</li>
<li class="L14382" rel="L14382">time traversing the streets, was never known. As he stood staring at</li>
<li class="L14383" rel="L14383">them, they asked him no question, for his face told them everything.</li>
<li class="L14384" rel="L14384"></li>
<li class="L14385" rel="L14385">“I cannot find it,” said he, “and I must have it. Where is it?”</li>
<li class="L14386" rel="L14386"></li>
<li class="L14387" rel="L14387">His head and throat were bare, and, as he spoke with a helpless look</li>
<li class="L14388" rel="L14388">straying all around, he took his coat off, and let it drop on the floor.</li>
<li class="L14389" rel="L14389"></li>
<li class="L14390" rel="L14390">“Where is my bench? I have been looking everywhere for my bench, and I</li>
<li class="L14391" rel="L14391">can&#39;t find it. What have they done with my work? Time presses: I must</li>
<li class="L14392" rel="L14392">finish those shoes.”</li>
<li class="L14393" rel="L14393"></li>
<li class="L14394" rel="L14394">They looked at one another, and their hearts died within them.</li>
<li class="L14395" rel="L14395"></li>
<li class="L14396" rel="L14396">“Come, come!” said he, in a whimpering miserable way; “let me get to</li>
<li class="L14397" rel="L14397">work. Give me my work.”</li>
<li class="L14398" rel="L14398"></li>
<li class="L14399" rel="L14399">Receiving no answer, he tore his hair, and beat his feet upon the</li>
<li class="L14400" rel="L14400">ground, like a distracted child.</li>
<li class="L14401" rel="L14401"></li>
<li class="L14402" rel="L14402">“Don&#39;t torture a poor forlorn wretch,” he implored them, with a dreadful</li>
<li class="L14403" rel="L14403">cry; “but give me my work! What is to become of us, if those shoes are</li>
<li class="L14404" rel="L14404">not done to-night?”</li>
<li class="L14405" rel="L14405"></li>
<li class="L14406" rel="L14406">Lost, utterly lost!</li>
<li class="L14407" rel="L14407"></li>
<li class="L14408" rel="L14408">It was so clearly beyond hope to reason with him, or try to restore him,</li>
<li class="L14409" rel="L14409">that--as if by agreement--they each put a hand upon his shoulder, and</li>
<li class="L14410" rel="L14410">soothed him to sit down before the fire, with a promise that he should</li>
<li class="L14411" rel="L14411">have his work presently. He sank into the chair, and brooded over the</li>
<li class="L14412" rel="L14412">embers, and shed tears. As if all that had happened since the garret</li>
<li class="L14413" rel="L14413">time were a momentary fancy, or a dream, Mr. Lorry saw him shrink into</li>
<li class="L14414" rel="L14414">the exact figure that Defarge had had in keeping.</li>
<li class="L14415" rel="L14415"></li>
<li class="L14416" rel="L14416">Affected, and impressed with terror as they both were, by this spectacle</li>
<li class="L14417" rel="L14417">of ruin, it was not a time to yield to such emotions. His lonely</li>
<li class="L14418" rel="L14418">daughter, bereft of her final hope and reliance, appealed to them both</li>
<li class="L14419" rel="L14419">too strongly. Again, as if by agreement, they looked at one another with</li>
<li class="L14420" rel="L14420">one meaning in their faces. Carton was the first to speak:</li>
<li class="L14421" rel="L14421"></li>
<li class="L14422" rel="L14422">“The last chance is gone: it was not much. Yes; he had better be taken</li>
<li class="L14423" rel="L14423">to her. But, before you go, will you, for a moment, steadily attend to</li>
<li class="L14424" rel="L14424">me? Don&#39;t ask me why I make the stipulations I am going to make, and</li>
<li class="L14425" rel="L14425">exact the promise I am going to exact; I have a reason--a good one.”</li>
<li class="L14426" rel="L14426"></li>
<li class="L14427" rel="L14427">“I do not doubt it,” answered Mr. Lorry. “Say on.”</li>
<li class="L14428" rel="L14428"></li>
<li class="L14429" rel="L14429">The figure in the chair between them, was all the time monotonously</li>
<li class="L14430" rel="L14430">rocking itself to and fro, and moaning. They spoke in such a tone as</li>
<li class="L14431" rel="L14431">they would have used if they had been watching by a sick-bed in the</li>
<li class="L14432" rel="L14432">night.</li>
<li class="L14433" rel="L14433"></li>
<li class="L14434" rel="L14434">Carton stooped to pick up the coat, which lay almost entangling his</li>
<li class="L14435" rel="L14435">feet. As he did so, a small case in which the Doctor was accustomed to</li>
<li class="L14436" rel="L14436">carry the lists of his day&#39;s duties, fell lightly on the floor. Carton</li>
<li class="L14437" rel="L14437">took it up, and there was a folded paper in it. “We should look</li>
<li class="L14438" rel="L14438">at this!” he said. Mr. Lorry nodded his consent. He opened it, and</li>
<li class="L14439" rel="L14439">exclaimed, “Thank _God!_”</li>
<li class="L14440" rel="L14440"></li>
<li class="L14441" rel="L14441">“What is it?” asked Mr. Lorry, eagerly.</li>
<li class="L14442" rel="L14442"></li>
<li class="L14443" rel="L14443">“A moment! Let me speak of it in its place. First,” he put his hand in</li>
<li class="L14444" rel="L14444">his coat, and took another paper from it, “that is the certificate which</li>
<li class="L14445" rel="L14445">enables me to pass out of this city. Look at it. You see--Sydney Carton,</li>
<li class="L14446" rel="L14446">an Englishman?”</li>
<li class="L14447" rel="L14447"></li>
<li class="L14448" rel="L14448">Mr. Lorry held it open in his hand, gazing in his earnest face.</li>
<li class="L14449" rel="L14449"></li>
<li class="L14450" rel="L14450">“Keep it for me until to-morrow. I shall see him to-morrow, you</li>
<li class="L14451" rel="L14451">remember, and I had better not take it into the prison.”</li>
<li class="L14452" rel="L14452"></li>
<li class="L14453" rel="L14453">“Why not?”</li>
<li class="L14454" rel="L14454"></li>
<li class="L14455" rel="L14455">“I don&#39;t know; I prefer not to do so. Now, take this paper that Doctor</li>
<li class="L14456" rel="L14456">Manette has carried about him. It is a similar certificate, enabling him</li>
<li class="L14457" rel="L14457">and his daughter and her child, at any time, to pass the barrier and the</li>
<li class="L14458" rel="L14458">frontier! You see?”</li>
<li class="L14459" rel="L14459"></li>
<li class="L14460" rel="L14460">“Yes!”</li>
<li class="L14461" rel="L14461"></li>
<li class="L14462" rel="L14462">“Perhaps he obtained it as his last and utmost precaution against evil,</li>
<li class="L14463" rel="L14463">yesterday. When is it dated? But no matter; don&#39;t stay to look; put it</li>
<li class="L14464" rel="L14464">up carefully with mine and your own. Now, observe! I never doubted until</li>
<li class="L14465" rel="L14465">within this hour or two, that he had, or could have such a paper. It is</li>
<li class="L14466" rel="L14466">good, until recalled. But it may be soon recalled, and, I have reason to</li>
<li class="L14467" rel="L14467">think, will be.”</li>
<li class="L14468" rel="L14468"></li>
<li class="L14469" rel="L14469">“They are not in danger?”</li>
<li class="L14470" rel="L14470"></li>
<li class="L14471" rel="L14471">“They are in great danger. They are in danger of denunciation by Madame</li>
<li class="L14472" rel="L14472">Defarge. I know it from her own lips. I have overheard words of that</li>
<li class="L14473" rel="L14473">woman&#39;s, to-night, which have presented their danger to me in strong</li>
<li class="L14474" rel="L14474">colours. I have lost no time, and since then, I have seen the spy. He</li>
<li class="L14475" rel="L14475">confirms me. He knows that a wood-sawyer, living by the prison wall,</li>
<li class="L14476" rel="L14476">is under the control of the Defarges, and has been rehearsed by</li>
<li class="L14477" rel="L14477">Madame Defarge as to his having seen Her”--he never mentioned Lucie&#39;s</li>
<li class="L14478" rel="L14478">name--“making signs and signals to prisoners. It is easy to foresee that</li>
<li class="L14479" rel="L14479">the pretence will be the common one, a prison plot, and that it will</li>
<li class="L14480" rel="L14480">involve her life--and perhaps her child&#39;s--and perhaps her father&#39;s--for</li>
<li class="L14481" rel="L14481">both have been seen with her at that place. Don&#39;t look so horrified. You</li>
<li class="L14482" rel="L14482">will save them all.”</li>
<li class="L14483" rel="L14483"></li>
<li class="L14484" rel="L14484">“Heaven grant I may, Carton! But how?”</li>
<li class="L14485" rel="L14485"></li>
<li class="L14486" rel="L14486">“I am going to tell you how. It will depend on you, and it could depend</li>
<li class="L14487" rel="L14487">on no better man. This new denunciation will certainly not take place</li>
<li class="L14488" rel="L14488">until after to-morrow; probably not until two or three days afterwards;</li>
<li class="L14489" rel="L14489">more probably a week afterwards. You know it is a capital crime, to</li>
<li class="L14490" rel="L14490">mourn for, or sympathise with, a victim of the Guillotine. She and her</li>
<li class="L14491" rel="L14491">father would unquestionably be guilty of this crime, and this woman (the</li>
<li class="L14492" rel="L14492">inveteracy of whose pursuit cannot be described) would wait to add that</li>
<li class="L14493" rel="L14493">strength to her case, and make herself doubly sure. You follow me?”</li>
<li class="L14494" rel="L14494"></li>
<li class="L14495" rel="L14495">“So attentively, and with so much confidence in what you say, that for</li>
<li class="L14496" rel="L14496">the moment I lose sight,” touching the back of the Doctor&#39;s chair, “even</li>
<li class="L14497" rel="L14497">of this distress.”</li>
<li class="L14498" rel="L14498"></li>
<li class="L14499" rel="L14499">“You have money, and can buy the means of travelling to the seacoast</li>
<li class="L14500" rel="L14500">as quickly as the journey can be made. Your preparations have been</li>
<li class="L14501" rel="L14501">completed for some days, to return to England. Early to-morrow have your</li>
<li class="L14502" rel="L14502">horses ready, so that they may be in starting trim at two o&#39;clock in the</li>
<li class="L14503" rel="L14503">afternoon.”</li>
<li class="L14504" rel="L14504"></li>
<li class="L14505" rel="L14505">“It shall be done!”</li>
<li class="L14506" rel="L14506"></li>
<li class="L14507" rel="L14507">His manner was so fervent and inspiring, that Mr. Lorry caught the</li>
<li class="L14508" rel="L14508">flame, and was as quick as youth.</li>
<li class="L14509" rel="L14509"></li>
<li class="L14510" rel="L14510">“You are a noble heart. Did I say we could depend upon no better man?</li>
<li class="L14511" rel="L14511">Tell her, to-night, what you know of her danger as involving her child</li>
<li class="L14512" rel="L14512">and her father. Dwell upon that, for she would lay her own fair head</li>
<li class="L14513" rel="L14513">beside her husband&#39;s cheerfully.” He faltered for an instant; then went</li>
<li class="L14514" rel="L14514">on as before. “For the sake of her child and her father, press upon her</li>
<li class="L14515" rel="L14515">the necessity of leaving Paris, with them and you, at that hour. Tell</li>
<li class="L14516" rel="L14516">her that it was her husband&#39;s last arrangement. Tell her that more</li>
<li class="L14517" rel="L14517">depends upon it than she dare believe, or hope. You think that her</li>
<li class="L14518" rel="L14518">father, even in this sad state, will submit himself to her; do you not?”</li>
<li class="L14519" rel="L14519"></li>
<li class="L14520" rel="L14520">“I am sure of it.”</li>
<li class="L14521" rel="L14521"></li>
<li class="L14522" rel="L14522">“I thought so. Quietly and steadily have all these arrangements made in</li>
<li class="L14523" rel="L14523">the courtyard here, even to the taking of your own seat in the carriage.</li>
<li class="L14524" rel="L14524">The moment I come to you, take me in, and drive away.”</li>
<li class="L14525" rel="L14525"></li>
<li class="L14526" rel="L14526">“I understand that I wait for you under all circumstances?”</li>
<li class="L14527" rel="L14527"></li>
<li class="L14528" rel="L14528">“You have my certificate in your hand with the rest, you know, and will</li>
<li class="L14529" rel="L14529">reserve my place. Wait for nothing but to have my place occupied, and</li>
<li class="L14530" rel="L14530">then for England!”</li>
<li class="L14531" rel="L14531"></li>
<li class="L14532" rel="L14532">“Why, then,” said Mr. Lorry, grasping his eager but so firm and steady</li>
<li class="L14533" rel="L14533">hand, “it does not all depend on one old man, but I shall have a young</li>
<li class="L14534" rel="L14534">and ardent man at my side.”</li>
<li class="L14535" rel="L14535"></li>
<li class="L14536" rel="L14536">“By the help of Heaven you shall! Promise me solemnly that nothing will</li>
<li class="L14537" rel="L14537">influence you to alter the course on which we now stand pledged to one</li>
<li class="L14538" rel="L14538">another.”</li>
<li class="L14539" rel="L14539"></li>
<li class="L14540" rel="L14540">“Nothing, Carton.”</li>
<li class="L14541" rel="L14541"></li>
<li class="L14542" rel="L14542">“Remember these words to-morrow: change the course, or delay in it--for</li>
<li class="L14543" rel="L14543">any reason--and no life can possibly be saved, and many lives must</li>
<li class="L14544" rel="L14544">inevitably be sacrificed.”</li>
<li class="L14545" rel="L14545"></li>
<li class="L14546" rel="L14546">“I will remember them. I hope to do my part faithfully.”</li>
<li class="L14547" rel="L14547"></li>
<li class="L14548" rel="L14548">“And I hope to do mine. Now, good bye!”</li>
<li class="L14549" rel="L14549"></li>
<li class="L14550" rel="L14550">Though he said it with a grave smile of earnestness, and though he even</li>
<li class="L14551" rel="L14551">put the old man&#39;s hand to his lips, he did not part from him then. He</li>
<li class="L14552" rel="L14552">helped him so far to arouse the rocking figure before the dying embers,</li>
<li class="L14553" rel="L14553">as to get a cloak and hat put upon it, and to tempt it forth to find</li>
<li class="L14554" rel="L14554">where the bench and work were hidden that it still moaningly besought</li>
<li class="L14555" rel="L14555">to have. He walked on the other side of it and protected it to the</li>
<li class="L14556" rel="L14556">courtyard of the house where the afflicted heart--so happy in</li>
<li class="L14557" rel="L14557">the memorable time when he had revealed his own desolate heart to</li>
<li class="L14558" rel="L14558">it--outwatched the awful night. He entered the courtyard and remained</li>
<li class="L14559" rel="L14559">there for a few moments alone, looking up at the light in the window of</li>
<li class="L14560" rel="L14560">her room. Before he went away, he breathed a blessing towards it, and a</li>
<li class="L14561" rel="L14561">Farewell.</li>
<li class="L14562" rel="L14562"></li>
<li class="L14563" rel="L14563"></li>
<li class="L14564" rel="L14564"></li>
<li class="L14565" rel="L14565"></li>
<li class="L14566" rel="L14566">XIII. Fifty-two</li>
<li class="L14567" rel="L14567"></li>
<li class="L14568" rel="L14568"></li>
<li class="L14569" rel="L14569">In the black prison of the Conciergerie, the doomed of the day awaited</li>
<li class="L14570" rel="L14570">their fate. They were in number as the weeks of the year. Fifty-two were</li>
<li class="L14571" rel="L14571">to roll that afternoon on the life-tide of the city to the boundless</li>
<li class="L14572" rel="L14572">everlasting sea. Before their cells were quit of them, new occupants</li>
<li class="L14573" rel="L14573">were appointed; before their blood ran into the blood spilled yesterday,</li>
<li class="L14574" rel="L14574">the blood that was to mingle with theirs to-morrow was already set</li>
<li class="L14575" rel="L14575">apart.</li>
<li class="L14576" rel="L14576"></li>
<li class="L14577" rel="L14577">Two score and twelve were told off. From the farmer-general of seventy,</li>
<li class="L14578" rel="L14578">whose riches could not buy his life, to the seamstress of twenty, whose</li>
<li class="L14579" rel="L14579">poverty and obscurity could not save her. Physical diseases, engendered</li>
<li class="L14580" rel="L14580">in the vices and neglects of men, will seize on victims of all degrees;</li>
<li class="L14581" rel="L14581">and the frightful moral disorder, born of unspeakable suffering,</li>
<li class="L14582" rel="L14582">intolerable oppression, and heartless indifference, smote equally</li>
<li class="L14583" rel="L14583">without distinction.</li>
<li class="L14584" rel="L14584"></li>
<li class="L14585" rel="L14585">Charles Darnay, alone in a cell, had sustained himself with no</li>
<li class="L14586" rel="L14586">flattering delusion since he came to it from the Tribunal. In every line</li>
<li class="L14587" rel="L14587">of the narrative he had heard, he had heard his condemnation. He had</li>
<li class="L14588" rel="L14588">fully comprehended that no personal influence could possibly save him,</li>
<li class="L14589" rel="L14589">that he was virtually sentenced by the millions, and that units could</li>
<li class="L14590" rel="L14590">avail him nothing.</li>
<li class="L14591" rel="L14591"></li>
<li class="L14592" rel="L14592">Nevertheless, it was not easy, with the face of his beloved wife fresh</li>
<li class="L14593" rel="L14593">before him, to compose his mind to what it must bear. His hold on life</li>
<li class="L14594" rel="L14594">was strong, and it was very, very hard, to loosen; by gradual efforts</li>
<li class="L14595" rel="L14595">and degrees unclosed a little here, it clenched the tighter there; and</li>
<li class="L14596" rel="L14596">when he brought his strength to bear on that hand and it yielded,</li>
<li class="L14597" rel="L14597">this was closed again. There was a hurry, too, in all his thoughts,</li>
<li class="L14598" rel="L14598">a turbulent and heated working of his heart, that contended against</li>
<li class="L14599" rel="L14599">resignation. If, for a moment, he did feel resigned, then his wife and</li>
<li class="L14600" rel="L14600">child who had to live after him, seemed to protest and to make it a</li>
<li class="L14601" rel="L14601">selfish thing.</li>
<li class="L14602" rel="L14602"></li>
<li class="L14603" rel="L14603">But, all this was at first. Before long, the consideration that there</li>
<li class="L14604" rel="L14604">was no disgrace in the fate he must meet, and that numbers went the same</li>
<li class="L14605" rel="L14605">road wrongfully, and trod it firmly every day, sprang up to stimulate</li>
<li class="L14606" rel="L14606">him. Next followed the thought that much of the future peace of mind</li>
<li class="L14607" rel="L14607">enjoyable by the dear ones, depended on his quiet fortitude. So,</li>
<li class="L14608" rel="L14608">by degrees he calmed into the better state, when he could raise his</li>
<li class="L14609" rel="L14609">thoughts much higher, and draw comfort down.</li>
<li class="L14610" rel="L14610"></li>
<li class="L14611" rel="L14611">Before it had set in dark on the night of his condemnation, he had</li>
<li class="L14612" rel="L14612">travelled thus far on his last way. Being allowed to purchase the means</li>
<li class="L14613" rel="L14613">of writing, and a light, he sat down to write until such time as the</li>
<li class="L14614" rel="L14614">prison lamps should be extinguished.</li>
<li class="L14615" rel="L14615"></li>
<li class="L14616" rel="L14616">He wrote a long letter to Lucie, showing her that he had known nothing</li>
<li class="L14617" rel="L14617">of her father&#39;s imprisonment, until he had heard of it from herself,</li>
<li class="L14618" rel="L14618">and that he had been as ignorant as she of his father&#39;s and uncle&#39;s</li>
<li class="L14619" rel="L14619">responsibility for that misery, until the paper had been read. He had</li>
<li class="L14620" rel="L14620">already explained to her that his concealment from herself of the name</li>
<li class="L14621" rel="L14621">he had relinquished, was the one condition--fully intelligible now--that</li>
<li class="L14622" rel="L14622">her father had attached to their betrothal, and was the one promise he</li>
<li class="L14623" rel="L14623">had still exacted on the morning of their marriage. He entreated her,</li>
<li class="L14624" rel="L14624">for her father&#39;s sake, never to seek to know whether her father had</li>
<li class="L14625" rel="L14625">become oblivious of the existence of the paper, or had had it recalled</li>
<li class="L14626" rel="L14626">to him (for the moment, or for good), by the story of the Tower, on</li>
<li class="L14627" rel="L14627">that old Sunday under the dear old plane-tree in the garden. If he had</li>
<li class="L14628" rel="L14628">preserved any definite remembrance of it, there could be no doubt that</li>
<li class="L14629" rel="L14629">he had supposed it destroyed with the Bastille, when he had found no</li>
<li class="L14630" rel="L14630">mention of it among the relics of prisoners which the populace had</li>
<li class="L14631" rel="L14631">discovered there, and which had been described to all the world. He</li>
<li class="L14632" rel="L14632">besought her--though he added that he knew it was needless--to console</li>
<li class="L14633" rel="L14633">her father, by impressing him through every tender means she could think</li>
<li class="L14634" rel="L14634">of, with the truth that he had done nothing for which he could justly</li>
<li class="L14635" rel="L14635">reproach himself, but had uniformly forgotten himself for their joint</li>
<li class="L14636" rel="L14636">sakes. Next to her preservation of his own last grateful love and</li>
<li class="L14637" rel="L14637">blessing, and her overcoming of her sorrow, to devote herself to their</li>
<li class="L14638" rel="L14638">dear child, he adjured her, as they would meet in Heaven, to comfort her</li>
<li class="L14639" rel="L14639">father.</li>
<li class="L14640" rel="L14640"></li>
<li class="L14641" rel="L14641">To her father himself, he wrote in the same strain; but, he told her</li>
<li class="L14642" rel="L14642">father that he expressly confided his wife and child to his care. And</li>
<li class="L14643" rel="L14643">he told him this, very strongly, with the hope of rousing him from any</li>
<li class="L14644" rel="L14644">despondency or dangerous retrospect towards which he foresaw he might be</li>
<li class="L14645" rel="L14645">tending.</li>
<li class="L14646" rel="L14646"></li>
<li class="L14647" rel="L14647">To Mr. Lorry, he commended them all, and explained his worldly affairs.</li>
<li class="L14648" rel="L14648">That done, with many added sentences of grateful friendship and warm</li>
<li class="L14649" rel="L14649">attachment, all was done. He never thought of Carton. His mind was so</li>
<li class="L14650" rel="L14650">full of the others, that he never once thought of him.</li>
<li class="L14651" rel="L14651"></li>
<li class="L14652" rel="L14652">He had time to finish these letters before the lights were put out. When</li>
<li class="L14653" rel="L14653">he lay down on his straw bed, he thought he had done with this world.</li>
<li class="L14654" rel="L14654"></li>
<li class="L14655" rel="L14655">But, it beckoned him back in his sleep, and showed itself in shining</li>
<li class="L14656" rel="L14656">forms. Free and happy, back in the old house in Soho (though it had</li>
<li class="L14657" rel="L14657">nothing in it like the real house), unaccountably released and light of</li>
<li class="L14658" rel="L14658">heart, he was with Lucie again, and she told him it was all a dream, and</li>
<li class="L14659" rel="L14659">he had never gone away. A pause of forgetfulness, and then he had even</li>
<li class="L14660" rel="L14660">suffered, and had come back to her, dead and at peace, and yet there</li>
<li class="L14661" rel="L14661">was no difference in him. Another pause of oblivion, and he awoke in the</li>
<li class="L14662" rel="L14662">sombre morning, unconscious where he was or what had happened, until it</li>
<li class="L14663" rel="L14663">flashed upon his mind, “this is the day of my death!”</li>
<li class="L14664" rel="L14664"></li>
<li class="L14665" rel="L14665">Thus, had he come through the hours, to the day when the fifty-two heads</li>
<li class="L14666" rel="L14666">were to fall. And now, while he was composed, and hoped that he could</li>
<li class="L14667" rel="L14667">meet the end with quiet heroism, a new action began in his waking</li>
<li class="L14668" rel="L14668">thoughts, which was very difficult to master.</li>
<li class="L14669" rel="L14669"></li>
<li class="L14670" rel="L14670">He had never seen the instrument that was to terminate his life. How</li>
<li class="L14671" rel="L14671">high it was from the ground, how many steps it had, where he would be</li>
<li class="L14672" rel="L14672">stood, how he would be touched, whether the touching hands would be dyed</li>
<li class="L14673" rel="L14673">red, which way his face would be turned, whether he would be the first,</li>
<li class="L14674" rel="L14674">or might be the last: these and many similar questions, in nowise</li>
<li class="L14675" rel="L14675">directed by his will, obtruded themselves over and over again, countless</li>
<li class="L14676" rel="L14676">times. Neither were they connected with fear: he was conscious of no</li>
<li class="L14677" rel="L14677">fear. Rather, they originated in a strange besetting desire to know what</li>
<li class="L14678" rel="L14678">to do when the time came; a desire gigantically disproportionate to the</li>
<li class="L14679" rel="L14679">few swift moments to which it referred; a wondering that was more like</li>
<li class="L14680" rel="L14680">the wondering of some other spirit within his, than his own.</li>
<li class="L14681" rel="L14681"></li>
<li class="L14682" rel="L14682">The hours went on as he walked to and fro, and the clocks struck the</li>
<li class="L14683" rel="L14683">numbers he would never hear again. Nine gone for ever, ten gone for</li>
<li class="L14684" rel="L14684">ever, eleven gone for ever, twelve coming on to pass away. After a hard</li>
<li class="L14685" rel="L14685">contest with that eccentric action of thought which had last perplexed</li>
<li class="L14686" rel="L14686">him, he had got the better of it. He walked up and down, softly</li>
<li class="L14687" rel="L14687">repeating their names to himself. The worst of the strife was over.</li>
<li class="L14688" rel="L14688">He could walk up and down, free from distracting fancies, praying for</li>
<li class="L14689" rel="L14689">himself and for them.</li>
<li class="L14690" rel="L14690"></li>
<li class="L14691" rel="L14691">Twelve gone for ever.</li>
<li class="L14692" rel="L14692"></li>
<li class="L14693" rel="L14693">He had been apprised that the final hour was Three, and he knew he would</li>
<li class="L14694" rel="L14694">be summoned some time earlier, inasmuch as the tumbrils jolted heavily</li>
<li class="L14695" rel="L14695">and slowly through the streets. Therefore, he resolved to keep Two</li>
<li class="L14696" rel="L14696">before his mind, as the hour, and so to strengthen himself in the</li>
<li class="L14697" rel="L14697">interval that he might be able, after that time, to strengthen others.</li>
<li class="L14698" rel="L14698"></li>
<li class="L14699" rel="L14699">Walking regularly to and fro with his arms folded on his breast, a very</li>
<li class="L14700" rel="L14700">different man from the prisoner, who had walked to and fro at La Force,</li>
<li class="L14701" rel="L14701">he heard One struck away from him, without surprise. The hour had</li>
<li class="L14702" rel="L14702">measured like most other hours. Devoutly thankful to Heaven for his</li>
<li class="L14703" rel="L14703">recovered self-possession, he thought, “There is but another now,” and</li>
<li class="L14704" rel="L14704">turned to walk again.</li>
<li class="L14705" rel="L14705"></li>
<li class="L14706" rel="L14706">Footsteps in the stone passage outside the door. He stopped.</li>
<li class="L14707" rel="L14707"></li>
<li class="L14708" rel="L14708">The key was put in the lock, and turned. Before the door was opened, or</li>
<li class="L14709" rel="L14709">as it opened, a man said in a low voice, in English: “He has never seen</li>
<li class="L14710" rel="L14710">me here; I have kept out of his way. Go you in alone; I wait near. Lose</li>
<li class="L14711" rel="L14711">no time!”</li>
<li class="L14712" rel="L14712"></li>
<li class="L14713" rel="L14713">The door was quickly opened and closed, and there stood before him</li>
<li class="L14714" rel="L14714">face to face, quiet, intent upon him, with the light of a smile on his</li>
<li class="L14715" rel="L14715">features, and a cautionary finger on his lip, Sydney Carton.</li>
<li class="L14716" rel="L14716"></li>
<li class="L14717" rel="L14717">There was something so bright and remarkable in his look, that, for the</li>
<li class="L14718" rel="L14718">first moment, the prisoner misdoubted him to be an apparition of his own</li>
<li class="L14719" rel="L14719">imagining. But, he spoke, and it was his voice; he took the prisoner&#39;s</li>
<li class="L14720" rel="L14720">hand, and it was his real grasp.</li>
<li class="L14721" rel="L14721"></li>
<li class="L14722" rel="L14722">“Of all the people upon earth, you least expected to see me?” he said.</li>
<li class="L14723" rel="L14723"></li>
<li class="L14724" rel="L14724">“I could not believe it to be you. I can scarcely believe it now. You</li>
<li class="L14725" rel="L14725">are not”--the apprehension came suddenly into his mind--“a prisoner?”</li>
<li class="L14726" rel="L14726"></li>
<li class="L14727" rel="L14727">“No. I am accidentally possessed of a power over one of the keepers</li>
<li class="L14728" rel="L14728">here, and in virtue of it I stand before you. I come from her--your</li>
<li class="L14729" rel="L14729">wife, dear Darnay.”</li>
<li class="L14730" rel="L14730"></li>
<li class="L14731" rel="L14731">The prisoner wrung his hand.</li>
<li class="L14732" rel="L14732"></li>
<li class="L14733" rel="L14733">“I bring you a request from her.”</li>
<li class="L14734" rel="L14734"></li>
<li class="L14735" rel="L14735">“What is it?”</li>
<li class="L14736" rel="L14736"></li>
<li class="L14737" rel="L14737">“A most earnest, pressing, and emphatic entreaty, addressed to you</li>
<li class="L14738" rel="L14738">in the most pathetic tones of the voice so dear to you, that you well</li>
<li class="L14739" rel="L14739">remember.”</li>
<li class="L14740" rel="L14740"></li>
<li class="L14741" rel="L14741">The prisoner turned his face partly aside.</li>
<li class="L14742" rel="L14742"></li>
<li class="L14743" rel="L14743">“You have no time to ask me why I bring it, or what it means; I have</li>
<li class="L14744" rel="L14744">no time to tell you. You must comply with it--take off those boots you</li>
<li class="L14745" rel="L14745">wear, and draw on these of mine.”</li>
<li class="L14746" rel="L14746"></li>
<li class="L14747" rel="L14747">There was a chair against the wall of the cell, behind the prisoner.</li>
<li class="L14748" rel="L14748">Carton, pressing forward, had already, with the speed of lightning, got</li>
<li class="L14749" rel="L14749">him down into it, and stood over him, barefoot.</li>
<li class="L14750" rel="L14750"></li>
<li class="L14751" rel="L14751">“Draw on these boots of mine. Put your hands to them; put your will to</li>
<li class="L14752" rel="L14752">them. Quick!”</li>
<li class="L14753" rel="L14753"></li>
<li class="L14754" rel="L14754">“Carton, there is no escaping from this place; it never can be done. You</li>
<li class="L14755" rel="L14755">will only die with me. It is madness.”</li>
<li class="L14756" rel="L14756"></li>
<li class="L14757" rel="L14757">“It would be madness if I asked you to escape; but do I? When I ask you</li>
<li class="L14758" rel="L14758">to pass out at that door, tell me it is madness and remain here. Change</li>
<li class="L14759" rel="L14759">that cravat for this of mine, that coat for this of mine. While you do</li>
<li class="L14760" rel="L14760">it, let me take this ribbon from your hair, and shake out your hair like</li>
<li class="L14761" rel="L14761">this of mine!”</li>
<li class="L14762" rel="L14762"></li>
<li class="L14763" rel="L14763">With wonderful quickness, and with a strength both of will and action,</li>
<li class="L14764" rel="L14764">that appeared quite supernatural, he forced all these changes upon him.</li>
<li class="L14765" rel="L14765">The prisoner was like a young child in his hands.</li>
<li class="L14766" rel="L14766"></li>
<li class="L14767" rel="L14767">“Carton! Dear Carton! It is madness. It cannot be accomplished, it never</li>
<li class="L14768" rel="L14768">can be done, it has been attempted, and has always failed. I implore you</li>
<li class="L14769" rel="L14769">not to add your death to the bitterness of mine.”</li>
<li class="L14770" rel="L14770"></li>
<li class="L14771" rel="L14771">“Do I ask you, my dear Darnay, to pass the door? When I ask that,</li>
<li class="L14772" rel="L14772">refuse. There are pen and ink and paper on this table. Is your hand</li>
<li class="L14773" rel="L14773">steady enough to write?”</li>
<li class="L14774" rel="L14774"></li>
<li class="L14775" rel="L14775">“It was when you came in.”</li>
<li class="L14776" rel="L14776"></li>
<li class="L14777" rel="L14777">“Steady it again, and write what I shall dictate. Quick, friend, quick!”</li>
<li class="L14778" rel="L14778"></li>
<li class="L14779" rel="L14779">Pressing his hand to his bewildered head, Darnay sat down at the table.</li>
<li class="L14780" rel="L14780">Carton, with his right hand in his breast, stood close beside him.</li>
<li class="L14781" rel="L14781"></li>
<li class="L14782" rel="L14782">“Write exactly as I speak.”</li>
<li class="L14783" rel="L14783"></li>
<li class="L14784" rel="L14784">“To whom do I address it?”</li>
<li class="L14785" rel="L14785"></li>
<li class="L14786" rel="L14786">“To no one.” Carton still had his hand in his breast.</li>
<li class="L14787" rel="L14787"></li>
<li class="L14788" rel="L14788">“Do I date it?”</li>
<li class="L14789" rel="L14789"></li>
<li class="L14790" rel="L14790">“No.”</li>
<li class="L14791" rel="L14791"></li>
<li class="L14792" rel="L14792">The prisoner looked up, at each question. Carton, standing over him with</li>
<li class="L14793" rel="L14793">his hand in his breast, looked down.</li>
<li class="L14794" rel="L14794"></li>
<li class="L14795" rel="L14795">“&#39;If you remember,&#39;” said Carton, dictating, “&#39;the words that passed</li>
<li class="L14796" rel="L14796">between us, long ago, you will readily comprehend this when you see it.</li>
<li class="L14797" rel="L14797">You do remember them, I know. It is not in your nature to forget them.&#39;”</li>
<li class="L14798" rel="L14798"></li>
<li class="L14799" rel="L14799">He was drawing his hand from his breast; the prisoner chancing to look</li>
<li class="L14800" rel="L14800">up in his hurried wonder as he wrote, the hand stopped, closing upon</li>
<li class="L14801" rel="L14801">something.</li>
<li class="L14802" rel="L14802"></li>
<li class="L14803" rel="L14803">“Have you written &#39;forget them&#39;?” Carton asked.</li>
<li class="L14804" rel="L14804"></li>
<li class="L14805" rel="L14805">“I have. Is that a weapon in your hand?”</li>
<li class="L14806" rel="L14806"></li>
<li class="L14807" rel="L14807">“No; I am not armed.”</li>
<li class="L14808" rel="L14808"></li>
<li class="L14809" rel="L14809">“What is it in your hand?”</li>
<li class="L14810" rel="L14810"></li>
<li class="L14811" rel="L14811">“You shall know directly. Write on; there are but a few words more.” He</li>
<li class="L14812" rel="L14812">dictated again. “&#39;I am thankful that the time has come, when I can prove</li>
<li class="L14813" rel="L14813">them. That I do so is no subject for regret or grief.&#39;” As he said these</li>
<li class="L14814" rel="L14814">words with his eyes fixed on the writer, his hand slowly and softly</li>
<li class="L14815" rel="L14815">moved down close to the writer&#39;s face.</li>
<li class="L14816" rel="L14816"></li>
<li class="L14817" rel="L14817">The pen dropped from Darnay&#39;s fingers on the table, and he looked about</li>
<li class="L14818" rel="L14818">him vacantly.</li>
<li class="L14819" rel="L14819"></li>
<li class="L14820" rel="L14820">“What vapour is that?” he asked.</li>
<li class="L14821" rel="L14821"></li>
<li class="L14822" rel="L14822">“Vapour?”</li>
<li class="L14823" rel="L14823"></li>
<li class="L14824" rel="L14824">“Something that crossed me?”</li>
<li class="L14825" rel="L14825"></li>
<li class="L14826" rel="L14826">“I am conscious of nothing; there can be nothing here. Take up the pen</li>
<li class="L14827" rel="L14827">and finish. Hurry, hurry!”</li>
<li class="L14828" rel="L14828"></li>
<li class="L14829" rel="L14829">As if his memory were impaired, or his faculties disordered, the</li>
<li class="L14830" rel="L14830">prisoner made an effort to rally his attention. As he looked at Carton</li>
<li class="L14831" rel="L14831">with clouded eyes and with an altered manner of breathing, Carton--his</li>
<li class="L14832" rel="L14832">hand again in his breast--looked steadily at him.</li>
<li class="L14833" rel="L14833"></li>
<li class="L14834" rel="L14834">“Hurry, hurry!”</li>
<li class="L14835" rel="L14835"></li>
<li class="L14836" rel="L14836">The prisoner bent over the paper, once more.</li>
<li class="L14837" rel="L14837"></li>
<li class="L14838" rel="L14838">“&#39;If it had been otherwise;&#39;” Carton&#39;s hand was again watchfully and</li>
<li class="L14839" rel="L14839">softly stealing down; “&#39;I never should have used the longer opportunity.</li>
<li class="L14840" rel="L14840">If it had been otherwise;&#39;” the hand was at the prisoner&#39;s face; “&#39;I</li>
<li class="L14841" rel="L14841">should but have had so much the more to answer for. If it had been</li>
<li class="L14842" rel="L14842">otherwise--&#39;” Carton looked at the pen and saw it was trailing off into</li>
<li class="L14843" rel="L14843">unintelligible signs.</li>
<li class="L14844" rel="L14844"></li>
<li class="L14845" rel="L14845">Carton&#39;s hand moved back to his breast no more. The prisoner sprang up</li>
<li class="L14846" rel="L14846">with a reproachful look, but Carton&#39;s hand was close and firm at his</li>
<li class="L14847" rel="L14847">nostrils, and Carton&#39;s left arm caught him round the waist. For a few</li>
<li class="L14848" rel="L14848">seconds he faintly struggled with the man who had come to lay down his</li>
<li class="L14849" rel="L14849">life for him; but, within a minute or so, he was stretched insensible on</li>
<li class="L14850" rel="L14850">the ground.</li>
<li class="L14851" rel="L14851"></li>
<li class="L14852" rel="L14852">Quickly, but with hands as true to the purpose as his heart was, Carton</li>
<li class="L14853" rel="L14853">dressed himself in the clothes the prisoner had laid aside, combed back</li>
<li class="L14854" rel="L14854">his hair, and tied it with the ribbon the prisoner had worn. Then, he</li>
<li class="L14855" rel="L14855">softly called, “Enter there! Come in!” and the Spy presented himself.</li>
<li class="L14856" rel="L14856"></li>
<li class="L14857" rel="L14857">“You see?” said Carton, looking up, as he kneeled on one knee beside the</li>
<li class="L14858" rel="L14858">insensible figure, putting the paper in the breast: “is your hazard very</li>
<li class="L14859" rel="L14859">great?”</li>
<li class="L14860" rel="L14860"></li>
<li class="L14861" rel="L14861">“Mr. Carton,” the Spy answered, with a timid snap of his fingers, “my</li>
<li class="L14862" rel="L14862">hazard is not _that_, in the thick of business here, if you are true to</li>
<li class="L14863" rel="L14863">the whole of your bargain.”</li>
<li class="L14864" rel="L14864"></li>
<li class="L14865" rel="L14865">“Don&#39;t fear me. I will be true to the death.”</li>
<li class="L14866" rel="L14866"></li>
<li class="L14867" rel="L14867">“You must be, Mr. Carton, if the tale of fifty-two is to be right. Being</li>
<li class="L14868" rel="L14868">made right by you in that dress, I shall have no fear.”</li>
<li class="L14869" rel="L14869"></li>
<li class="L14870" rel="L14870">“Have no fear! I shall soon be out of the way of harming you, and the</li>
<li class="L14871" rel="L14871">rest will soon be far from here, please God! Now, get assistance and</li>
<li class="L14872" rel="L14872">take me to the coach.”</li>
<li class="L14873" rel="L14873"></li>
<li class="L14874" rel="L14874">“You?” said the Spy nervously.</li>
<li class="L14875" rel="L14875"></li>
<li class="L14876" rel="L14876">“Him, man, with whom I have exchanged. You go out at the gate by which</li>
<li class="L14877" rel="L14877">you brought me in?”</li>
<li class="L14878" rel="L14878"></li>
<li class="L14879" rel="L14879">“Of course.”</li>
<li class="L14880" rel="L14880"></li>
<li class="L14881" rel="L14881">“I was weak and faint when you brought me in, and I am fainter now you</li>
<li class="L14882" rel="L14882">take me out. The parting interview has overpowered me. Such a thing has</li>
<li class="L14883" rel="L14883">happened here, often, and too often. Your life is in your own hands.</li>
<li class="L14884" rel="L14884">Quick! Call assistance!”</li>
<li class="L14885" rel="L14885"></li>
<li class="L14886" rel="L14886">“You swear not to betray me?” said the trembling Spy, as he paused for a</li>
<li class="L14887" rel="L14887">last moment.</li>
<li class="L14888" rel="L14888"></li>
<li class="L14889" rel="L14889">“Man, man!” returned Carton, stamping his foot; “have I sworn by no</li>
<li class="L14890" rel="L14890">solemn vow already, to go through with this, that you waste the precious</li>
<li class="L14891" rel="L14891">moments now? Take him yourself to the courtyard you know of, place</li>
<li class="L14892" rel="L14892">him yourself in the carriage, show him yourself to Mr. Lorry, tell him</li>
<li class="L14893" rel="L14893">yourself to give him no restorative but air, and to remember my words of</li>
<li class="L14894" rel="L14894">last night, and his promise of last night, and drive away!”</li>
<li class="L14895" rel="L14895"></li>
<li class="L14896" rel="L14896">The Spy withdrew, and Carton seated himself at the table, resting his</li>
<li class="L14897" rel="L14897">forehead on his hands. The Spy returned immediately, with two men.</li>
<li class="L14898" rel="L14898"></li>
<li class="L14899" rel="L14899">“How, then?” said one of them, contemplating the fallen figure. “So</li>
<li class="L14900" rel="L14900">afflicted to find that his friend has drawn a prize in the lottery of</li>
<li class="L14901" rel="L14901">Sainte Guillotine?”</li>
<li class="L14902" rel="L14902"></li>
<li class="L14903" rel="L14903">“A good patriot,” said the other, “could hardly have been more afflicted</li>
<li class="L14904" rel="L14904">if the Aristocrat had drawn a blank.”</li>
<li class="L14905" rel="L14905"></li>
<li class="L14906" rel="L14906">They raised the unconscious figure, placed it on a litter they had</li>
<li class="L14907" rel="L14907">brought to the door, and bent to carry it away.</li>
<li class="L14908" rel="L14908"></li>
<li class="L14909" rel="L14909">“The time is short, Evremonde,” said the Spy, in a warning voice.</li>
<li class="L14910" rel="L14910"></li>
<li class="L14911" rel="L14911">“I know it well,” answered Carton. “Be careful of my friend, I entreat</li>
<li class="L14912" rel="L14912">you, and leave me.”</li>
<li class="L14913" rel="L14913"></li>
<li class="L14914" rel="L14914">“Come, then, my children,” said Barsad. “Lift him, and come away!”</li>
<li class="L14915" rel="L14915"></li>
<li class="L14916" rel="L14916">The door closed, and Carton was left alone. Straining his powers of</li>
<li class="L14917" rel="L14917">listening to the utmost, he listened for any sound that might denote</li>
<li class="L14918" rel="L14918">suspicion or alarm. There was none. Keys turned, doors clashed,</li>
<li class="L14919" rel="L14919">footsteps passed along distant passages: no cry was raised, or hurry</li>
<li class="L14920" rel="L14920">made, that seemed unusual. Breathing more freely in a little while, he</li>
<li class="L14921" rel="L14921">sat down at the table, and listened again until the clock struck Two.</li>
<li class="L14922" rel="L14922"></li>
<li class="L14923" rel="L14923">Sounds that he was not afraid of, for he divined their meaning, then</li>
<li class="L14924" rel="L14924">began to be audible. Several doors were opened in succession, and</li>
<li class="L14925" rel="L14925">finally his own. A gaoler, with a list in his hand, looked in, merely</li>
<li class="L14926" rel="L14926">saying, “Follow me, Evremonde!” and he followed into a large dark room,</li>
<li class="L14927" rel="L14927">at a distance. It was a dark winter day, and what with the shadows</li>
<li class="L14928" rel="L14928">within, and what with the shadows without, he could but dimly discern</li>
<li class="L14929" rel="L14929">the others who were brought there to have their arms bound. Some were</li>
<li class="L14930" rel="L14930">standing; some seated. Some were lamenting, and in restless motion;</li>
<li class="L14931" rel="L14931">but, these were few. The great majority were silent and still, looking</li>
<li class="L14932" rel="L14932">fixedly at the ground.</li>
<li class="L14933" rel="L14933"></li>
<li class="L14934" rel="L14934">As he stood by the wall in a dim corner, while some of the fifty-two</li>
<li class="L14935" rel="L14935">were brought in after him, one man stopped in passing, to embrace him,</li>
<li class="L14936" rel="L14936">as having a knowledge of him. It thrilled him with a great dread of</li>
<li class="L14937" rel="L14937">discovery; but the man went on. A very few moments after that, a young</li>
<li class="L14938" rel="L14938">woman, with a slight girlish form, a sweet spare face in which there was</li>
<li class="L14939" rel="L14939">no vestige of colour, and large widely opened patient eyes, rose from</li>
<li class="L14940" rel="L14940">the seat where he had observed her sitting, and came to speak to him.</li>
<li class="L14941" rel="L14941"></li>
<li class="L14942" rel="L14942">“Citizen Evremonde,” she said, touching him with her cold hand. “I am a</li>
<li class="L14943" rel="L14943">poor little seamstress, who was with you in La Force.”</li>
<li class="L14944" rel="L14944"></li>
<li class="L14945" rel="L14945">He murmured for answer: “True. I forget what you were accused of?”</li>
<li class="L14946" rel="L14946"></li>
<li class="L14947" rel="L14947">“Plots. Though the just Heaven knows that I am innocent of any. Is it</li>
<li class="L14948" rel="L14948">likely? Who would think of plotting with a poor little weak creature</li>
<li class="L14949" rel="L14949">like me?”</li>
<li class="L14950" rel="L14950"></li>
<li class="L14951" rel="L14951">The forlorn smile with which she said it, so touched him, that tears</li>
<li class="L14952" rel="L14952">started from his eyes.</li>
<li class="L14953" rel="L14953"></li>
<li class="L14954" rel="L14954">“I am not afraid to die, Citizen Evremonde, but I have done nothing. I</li>
<li class="L14955" rel="L14955">am not unwilling to die, if the Republic which is to do so much good</li>
<li class="L14956" rel="L14956">to us poor, will profit by my death; but I do not know how that can be,</li>
<li class="L14957" rel="L14957">Citizen Evremonde. Such a poor weak little creature!”</li>
<li class="L14958" rel="L14958"></li>
<li class="L14959" rel="L14959">As the last thing on earth that his heart was to warm and soften to, it</li>
<li class="L14960" rel="L14960">warmed and softened to this pitiable girl.</li>
<li class="L14961" rel="L14961"></li>
<li class="L14962" rel="L14962">“I heard you were released, Citizen Evremonde. I hoped it was true?”</li>
<li class="L14963" rel="L14963"></li>
<li class="L14964" rel="L14964">“It was. But, I was again taken and condemned.”</li>
<li class="L14965" rel="L14965"></li>
<li class="L14966" rel="L14966">“If I may ride with you, Citizen Evremonde, will you let me hold your</li>
<li class="L14967" rel="L14967">hand? I am not afraid, but I am little and weak, and it will give me</li>
<li class="L14968" rel="L14968">more courage.”</li>
<li class="L14969" rel="L14969"></li>
<li class="L14970" rel="L14970">As the patient eyes were lifted to his face, he saw a sudden doubt in</li>
<li class="L14971" rel="L14971">them, and then astonishment. He pressed the work-worn, hunger-worn young</li>
<li class="L14972" rel="L14972">fingers, and touched his lips.</li>
<li class="L14973" rel="L14973"></li>
<li class="L14974" rel="L14974">“Are you dying for him?” she whispered.</li>
<li class="L14975" rel="L14975"></li>
<li class="L14976" rel="L14976">“And his wife and child. Hush! Yes.”</li>
<li class="L14977" rel="L14977"></li>
<li class="L14978" rel="L14978">“O you will let me hold your brave hand, stranger?”</li>
<li class="L14979" rel="L14979"></li>
<li class="L14980" rel="L14980">“Hush! Yes, my poor sister; to the last.”</li>
<li class="L14981" rel="L14981"></li>
<li class="L14982" rel="L14982">        *****</li>
<li class="L14983" rel="L14983"></li>
<li class="L14984" rel="L14984">The same shadows that are falling on the prison, are falling, in that</li>
<li class="L14985" rel="L14985">same hour of the early afternoon, on the Barrier with the crowd about</li>
<li class="L14986" rel="L14986">it, when a coach going out of Paris drives up to be examined.</li>
<li class="L14987" rel="L14987"></li>
<li class="L14988" rel="L14988">“Who goes here? Whom have we within? Papers!”</li>
<li class="L14989" rel="L14989"></li>
<li class="L14990" rel="L14990">The papers are handed out, and read.</li>
<li class="L14991" rel="L14991"></li>
<li class="L14992" rel="L14992">“Alexandre Manette. Physician. French. Which is he?”</li>
<li class="L14993" rel="L14993"></li>
<li class="L14994" rel="L14994">This is he; this helpless, inarticulately murmuring, wandering old man</li>
<li class="L14995" rel="L14995">pointed out.</li>
<li class="L14996" rel="L14996"></li>
<li class="L14997" rel="L14997">“Apparently the Citizen-Doctor is not in his right mind? The</li>
<li class="L14998" rel="L14998">Revolution-fever will have been too much for him?”</li>
<li class="L14999" rel="L14999"></li>
<li class="L15000" rel="L15000">Greatly too much for him.</li>
<li class="L15001" rel="L15001"></li>
<li class="L15002" rel="L15002">“Hah! Many suffer with it. Lucie. His daughter. French. Which is she?”</li>
<li class="L15003" rel="L15003"></li>
<li class="L15004" rel="L15004">This is she.</li>
<li class="L15005" rel="L15005"></li>
<li class="L15006" rel="L15006">“Apparently it must be. Lucie, the wife of Evremonde; is it not?”</li>
<li class="L15007" rel="L15007"></li>
<li class="L15008" rel="L15008">It is.</li>
<li class="L15009" rel="L15009"></li>
<li class="L15010" rel="L15010">“Hah! Evremonde has an assignation elsewhere. Lucie, her child. English.</li>
<li class="L15011" rel="L15011">This is she?”</li>
<li class="L15012" rel="L15012"></li>
<li class="L15013" rel="L15013">She and no other.</li>
<li class="L15014" rel="L15014"></li>
<li class="L15015" rel="L15015">“Kiss me, child of Evremonde. Now, thou hast kissed a good Republican;</li>
<li class="L15016" rel="L15016">something new in thy family; remember it! Sydney Carton. Advocate.</li>
<li class="L15017" rel="L15017">English. Which is he?”</li>
<li class="L15018" rel="L15018"></li>
<li class="L15019" rel="L15019">He lies here, in this corner of the carriage. He, too, is pointed out.</li>
<li class="L15020" rel="L15020"></li>
<li class="L15021" rel="L15021">“Apparently the English advocate is in a swoon?”</li>
<li class="L15022" rel="L15022"></li>
<li class="L15023" rel="L15023">It is hoped he will recover in the fresher air. It is represented that</li>
<li class="L15024" rel="L15024">he is not in strong health, and has separated sadly from a friend who is</li>
<li class="L15025" rel="L15025">under the displeasure of the Republic.</li>
<li class="L15026" rel="L15026"></li>
<li class="L15027" rel="L15027">“Is that all? It is not a great deal, that! Many are under the</li>
<li class="L15028" rel="L15028">displeasure of the Republic, and must look out at the little window.</li>
<li class="L15029" rel="L15029">Jarvis Lorry. Banker. English. Which is he?”</li>
<li class="L15030" rel="L15030"></li>
<li class="L15031" rel="L15031">“I am he. Necessarily, being the last.”</li>
<li class="L15032" rel="L15032"></li>
<li class="L15033" rel="L15033">It is Jarvis Lorry who has replied to all the previous questions. It</li>
<li class="L15034" rel="L15034">is Jarvis Lorry who has alighted and stands with his hand on the coach</li>
<li class="L15035" rel="L15035">door, replying to a group of officials. They leisurely walk round the</li>
<li class="L15036" rel="L15036">carriage and leisurely mount the box, to look at what little luggage it</li>
<li class="L15037" rel="L15037">carries on the roof; the country-people hanging about, press nearer to</li>
<li class="L15038" rel="L15038">the coach doors and greedily stare in; a little child, carried by its</li>
<li class="L15039" rel="L15039">mother, has its short arm held out for it, that it may touch the wife of</li>
<li class="L15040" rel="L15040">an aristocrat who has gone to the Guillotine.</li>
<li class="L15041" rel="L15041"></li>
<li class="L15042" rel="L15042">“Behold your papers, Jarvis Lorry, countersigned.”</li>
<li class="L15043" rel="L15043"></li>
<li class="L15044" rel="L15044">“One can depart, citizen?”</li>
<li class="L15045" rel="L15045"></li>
<li class="L15046" rel="L15046">“One can depart. Forward, my postilions! A good journey!”</li>
<li class="L15047" rel="L15047"></li>
<li class="L15048" rel="L15048">“I salute you, citizens.--And the first danger passed!”</li>
<li class="L15049" rel="L15049"></li>
<li class="L15050" rel="L15050">These are again the words of Jarvis Lorry, as he clasps his hands, and</li>
<li class="L15051" rel="L15051">looks upward. There is terror in the carriage, there is weeping, there</li>
<li class="L15052" rel="L15052">is the heavy breathing of the insensible traveller.</li>
<li class="L15053" rel="L15053"></li>
<li class="L15054" rel="L15054">“Are we not going too slowly? Can they not be induced to go faster?”</li>
<li class="L15055" rel="L15055"> asks Lucie, clinging to the old man.</li>
<li class="L15056" rel="L15056"></li>
<li class="L15057" rel="L15057">“It would seem like flight, my darling. I must not urge them too much;</li>
<li class="L15058" rel="L15058">it would rouse suspicion.”</li>
<li class="L15059" rel="L15059"></li>
<li class="L15060" rel="L15060">“Look back, look back, and see if we are pursued!”</li>
<li class="L15061" rel="L15061"></li>
<li class="L15062" rel="L15062">“The road is clear, my dearest. So far, we are not pursued.”</li>
<li class="L15063" rel="L15063"></li>
<li class="L15064" rel="L15064">Houses in twos and threes pass by us, solitary farms, ruinous buildings,</li>
<li class="L15065" rel="L15065">dye-works, tanneries, and the like, open country, avenues of leafless</li>
<li class="L15066" rel="L15066">trees. The hard uneven pavement is under us, the soft deep mud is on</li>
<li class="L15067" rel="L15067">either side. Sometimes, we strike into the skirting mud, to avoid the</li>
<li class="L15068" rel="L15068">stones that clatter us and shake us; sometimes, we stick in ruts and</li>
<li class="L15069" rel="L15069">sloughs there. The agony of our impatience is then so great, that in our</li>
<li class="L15070" rel="L15070">wild alarm and hurry we are for getting out and running--hiding--doing</li>
<li class="L15071" rel="L15071">anything but stopping.</li>
<li class="L15072" rel="L15072"></li>
<li class="L15073" rel="L15073">Out of the open country, in again among ruinous buildings, solitary</li>
<li class="L15074" rel="L15074">farms, dye-works, tanneries, and the like, cottages in twos and threes,</li>
<li class="L15075" rel="L15075">avenues of leafless trees. Have these men deceived us, and taken us back</li>
<li class="L15076" rel="L15076">by another road? Is not this the same place twice over? Thank Heaven,</li>
<li class="L15077" rel="L15077">no. A village. Look back, look back, and see if we are pursued! Hush!</li>
<li class="L15078" rel="L15078">the posting-house.</li>
<li class="L15079" rel="L15079"></li>
<li class="L15080" rel="L15080">Leisurely, our four horses are taken out; leisurely, the coach stands in</li>
<li class="L15081" rel="L15081">the little street, bereft of horses, and with no likelihood upon it</li>
<li class="L15082" rel="L15082">of ever moving again; leisurely, the new horses come into visible</li>
<li class="L15083" rel="L15083">existence, one by one; leisurely, the new postilions follow, sucking and</li>
<li class="L15084" rel="L15084">plaiting the lashes of their whips; leisurely, the old postilions count</li>
<li class="L15085" rel="L15085">their money, make wrong additions, and arrive at dissatisfied results.</li>
<li class="L15086" rel="L15086">All the time, our overfraught hearts are beating at a rate that would</li>
<li class="L15087" rel="L15087">far outstrip the fastest gallop of the fastest horses ever foaled.</li>
<li class="L15088" rel="L15088"></li>
<li class="L15089" rel="L15089">At length the new postilions are in their saddles, and the old are left</li>
<li class="L15090" rel="L15090">behind. We are through the village, up the hill, and down the hill, and</li>
<li class="L15091" rel="L15091">on the low watery grounds. Suddenly, the postilions exchange speech with</li>
<li class="L15092" rel="L15092">animated gesticulation, and the horses are pulled up, almost on their</li>
<li class="L15093" rel="L15093">haunches. We are pursued?</li>
<li class="L15094" rel="L15094"></li>
<li class="L15095" rel="L15095">“Ho! Within the carriage there. Speak then!”</li>
<li class="L15096" rel="L15096"></li>
<li class="L15097" rel="L15097">“What is it?” asks Mr. Lorry, looking out at window.</li>
<li class="L15098" rel="L15098"></li>
<li class="L15099" rel="L15099">“How many did they say?”</li>
<li class="L15100" rel="L15100"></li>
<li class="L15101" rel="L15101">“I do not understand you.”</li>
<li class="L15102" rel="L15102"></li>
<li class="L15103" rel="L15103">“--At the last post. How many to the Guillotine to-day?”</li>
<li class="L15104" rel="L15104"></li>
<li class="L15105" rel="L15105">“Fifty-two.”</li>
<li class="L15106" rel="L15106"></li>
<li class="L15107" rel="L15107">“I said so! A brave number! My fellow-citizen here would have it</li>
<li class="L15108" rel="L15108">forty-two; ten more heads are worth having. The Guillotine goes</li>
<li class="L15109" rel="L15109">handsomely. I love it. Hi forward. Whoop!”</li>
<li class="L15110" rel="L15110"></li>
<li class="L15111" rel="L15111">The night comes on dark. He moves more; he is beginning to revive, and</li>
<li class="L15112" rel="L15112">to speak intelligibly; he thinks they are still together; he asks him,</li>
<li class="L15113" rel="L15113">by his name, what he has in his hand. O pity us, kind Heaven, and help</li>
<li class="L15114" rel="L15114">us! Look out, look out, and see if we are pursued.</li>
<li class="L15115" rel="L15115"></li>
<li class="L15116" rel="L15116">The wind is rushing after us, and the clouds are flying after us, and</li>
<li class="L15117" rel="L15117">the moon is plunging after us, and the whole wild night is in pursuit of</li>
<li class="L15118" rel="L15118">us; but, so far, we are pursued by nothing else.</li>
<li class="L15119" rel="L15119"></li>
<li class="L15120" rel="L15120"></li>
<li class="L15121" rel="L15121"></li>
<li class="L15122" rel="L15122"></li>
<li class="L15123" rel="L15123">XIV. The Knitting Done</li>
<li class="L15124" rel="L15124"></li>
<li class="L15125" rel="L15125"></li>
<li class="L15126" rel="L15126">In that same juncture of time when the Fifty-Two awaited their fate</li>
<li class="L15127" rel="L15127">Madame Defarge held darkly ominous council with The Vengeance and</li>
<li class="L15128" rel="L15128">Jacques Three of the Revolutionary Jury. Not in the wine-shop did Madame</li>
<li class="L15129" rel="L15129">Defarge confer with these ministers, but in the shed of the wood-sawyer,</li>
<li class="L15130" rel="L15130">erst a mender of roads. The sawyer himself did not participate in the</li>
<li class="L15131" rel="L15131">conference, but abided at a little distance, like an outer satellite who</li>
<li class="L15132" rel="L15132">was not to speak until required, or to offer an opinion until invited.</li>
<li class="L15133" rel="L15133"></li>
<li class="L15134" rel="L15134">“But our Defarge,” said Jacques Three, “is undoubtedly a good</li>
<li class="L15135" rel="L15135">Republican? Eh?”</li>
<li class="L15136" rel="L15136"></li>
<li class="L15137" rel="L15137">“There is no better,” the voluble Vengeance protested in her shrill</li>
<li class="L15138" rel="L15138">notes, “in France.”</li>
<li class="L15139" rel="L15139"></li>
<li class="L15140" rel="L15140">“Peace, little Vengeance,” said Madame Defarge, laying her hand with</li>
<li class="L15141" rel="L15141">a slight frown on her lieutenant&#39;s lips, “hear me speak. My husband,</li>
<li class="L15142" rel="L15142">fellow-citizen, is a good Republican and a bold man; he has deserved</li>
<li class="L15143" rel="L15143">well of the Republic, and possesses its confidence. But my husband has</li>
<li class="L15144" rel="L15144">his weaknesses, and he is so weak as to relent towards this Doctor.”</li>
<li class="L15145" rel="L15145"></li>
<li class="L15146" rel="L15146">“It is a great pity,” croaked Jacques Three, dubiously shaking his head,</li>
<li class="L15147" rel="L15147">with his cruel fingers at his hungry mouth; “it is not quite like a good</li>
<li class="L15148" rel="L15148">citizen; it is a thing to regret.”</li>
<li class="L15149" rel="L15149"></li>
<li class="L15150" rel="L15150">“See you,” said madame, “I care nothing for this Doctor, I. He may wear</li>
<li class="L15151" rel="L15151">his head or lose it, for any interest I have in him; it is all one to</li>
<li class="L15152" rel="L15152">me. But, the Evremonde people are to be exterminated, and the wife and</li>
<li class="L15153" rel="L15153">child must follow the husband and father.”</li>
<li class="L15154" rel="L15154"></li>
<li class="L15155" rel="L15155">“She has a fine head for it,” croaked Jacques Three. “I have seen blue</li>
<li class="L15156" rel="L15156">eyes and golden hair there, and they looked charming when Samson held</li>
<li class="L15157" rel="L15157">them up.” Ogre that he was, he spoke like an epicure.</li>
<li class="L15158" rel="L15158"></li>
<li class="L15159" rel="L15159">Madame Defarge cast down her eyes, and reflected a little.</li>
<li class="L15160" rel="L15160"></li>
<li class="L15161" rel="L15161">“The child also,” observed Jacques Three, with a meditative enjoyment</li>
<li class="L15162" rel="L15162">of his words, “has golden hair and blue eyes. And we seldom have a child</li>
<li class="L15163" rel="L15163">there. It is a pretty sight!”</li>
<li class="L15164" rel="L15164"></li>
<li class="L15165" rel="L15165">“In a word,” said Madame Defarge, coming out of her short abstraction,</li>
<li class="L15166" rel="L15166">“I cannot trust my husband in this matter. Not only do I feel, since</li>
<li class="L15167" rel="L15167">last night, that I dare not confide to him the details of my projects;</li>
<li class="L15168" rel="L15168">but also I feel that if I delay, there is danger of his giving warning,</li>
<li class="L15169" rel="L15169">and then they might escape.”</li>
<li class="L15170" rel="L15170"></li>
<li class="L15171" rel="L15171">“That must never be,” croaked Jacques Three; “no one must escape. We</li>
<li class="L15172" rel="L15172">have not half enough as it is. We ought to have six score a day.”</li>
<li class="L15173" rel="L15173"></li>
<li class="L15174" rel="L15174">“In a word,” Madame Defarge went on, “my husband has not my reason for</li>
<li class="L15175" rel="L15175">pursuing this family to annihilation, and I have not his reason for</li>
<li class="L15176" rel="L15176">regarding this Doctor with any sensibility. I must act for myself,</li>
<li class="L15177" rel="L15177">therefore. Come hither, little citizen.”</li>
<li class="L15178" rel="L15178"></li>
<li class="L15179" rel="L15179">The wood-sawyer, who held her in the respect, and himself in the</li>
<li class="L15180" rel="L15180">submission, of mortal fear, advanced with his hand to his red cap.</li>
<li class="L15181" rel="L15181"></li>
<li class="L15182" rel="L15182">“Touching those signals, little citizen,” said Madame Defarge, sternly,</li>
<li class="L15183" rel="L15183">“that she made to the prisoners; you are ready to bear witness to them</li>
<li class="L15184" rel="L15184">this very day?”</li>
<li class="L15185" rel="L15185"></li>
<li class="L15186" rel="L15186">“Ay, ay, why not!” cried the sawyer. “Every day, in all weathers, from</li>
<li class="L15187" rel="L15187">two to four, always signalling, sometimes with the little one, sometimes</li>
<li class="L15188" rel="L15188">without. I know what I know. I have seen with my eyes.”</li>
<li class="L15189" rel="L15189"></li>
<li class="L15190" rel="L15190">He made all manner of gestures while he spoke, as if in incidental</li>
<li class="L15191" rel="L15191">imitation of some few of the great diversity of signals that he had</li>
<li class="L15192" rel="L15192">never seen.</li>
<li class="L15193" rel="L15193"></li>
<li class="L15194" rel="L15194">“Clearly plots,” said Jacques Three. “Transparently!”</li>
<li class="L15195" rel="L15195"></li>
<li class="L15196" rel="L15196">“There is no doubt of the Jury?” inquired Madame Defarge, letting her</li>
<li class="L15197" rel="L15197">eyes turn to him with a gloomy smile.</li>
<li class="L15198" rel="L15198"></li>
<li class="L15199" rel="L15199">“Rely upon the patriotic Jury, dear citizeness. I answer for my</li>
<li class="L15200" rel="L15200">fellow-Jurymen.”</li>
<li class="L15201" rel="L15201"></li>
<li class="L15202" rel="L15202">“Now, let me see,” said Madame Defarge, pondering again. “Yet once more!</li>
<li class="L15203" rel="L15203">Can I spare this Doctor to my husband? I have no feeling either way. Can</li>
<li class="L15204" rel="L15204">I spare him?”</li>
<li class="L15205" rel="L15205"></li>
<li class="L15206" rel="L15206">“He would count as one head,” observed Jacques Three, in a low voice.</li>
<li class="L15207" rel="L15207">“We really have not heads enough; it would be a pity, I think.”</li>
<li class="L15208" rel="L15208"></li>
<li class="L15209" rel="L15209">“He was signalling with her when I saw her,” argued Madame Defarge; “I</li>
<li class="L15210" rel="L15210">cannot speak of one without the other; and I must not be silent, and</li>
<li class="L15211" rel="L15211">trust the case wholly to him, this little citizen here. For, I am not a</li>
<li class="L15212" rel="L15212">bad witness.”</li>
<li class="L15213" rel="L15213"></li>
<li class="L15214" rel="L15214">The Vengeance and Jacques Three vied with each other in their fervent</li>
<li class="L15215" rel="L15215">protestations that she was the most admirable and marvellous of</li>
<li class="L15216" rel="L15216">witnesses. The little citizen, not to be outdone, declared her to be a</li>
<li class="L15217" rel="L15217">celestial witness.</li>
<li class="L15218" rel="L15218"></li>
<li class="L15219" rel="L15219">“He must take his chance,” said Madame Defarge. “No, I cannot spare</li>
<li class="L15220" rel="L15220">him! You are engaged at three o&#39;clock; you are going to see the batch of</li>
<li class="L15221" rel="L15221">to-day executed.--You?”</li>
<li class="L15222" rel="L15222"></li>
<li class="L15223" rel="L15223">The question was addressed to the wood-sawyer, who hurriedly replied in</li>
<li class="L15224" rel="L15224">the affirmative: seizing the occasion to add that he was the most ardent</li>
<li class="L15225" rel="L15225">of Republicans, and that he would be in effect the most desolate of</li>
<li class="L15226" rel="L15226">Republicans, if anything prevented him from enjoying the pleasure of</li>
<li class="L15227" rel="L15227">smoking his afternoon pipe in the contemplation of the droll national</li>
<li class="L15228" rel="L15228">barber. He was so very demonstrative herein, that he might have been</li>
<li class="L15229" rel="L15229">suspected (perhaps was, by the dark eyes that looked contemptuously at</li>
<li class="L15230" rel="L15230">him out of Madame Defarge&#39;s head) of having his small individual fears</li>
<li class="L15231" rel="L15231">for his own personal safety, every hour in the day.</li>
<li class="L15232" rel="L15232"></li>
<li class="L15233" rel="L15233">“I,” said madame, “am equally engaged at the same place. After it is</li>
<li class="L15234" rel="L15234">over--say at eight to-night--come you to me, in Saint Antoine, and we</li>
<li class="L15235" rel="L15235">will give information against these people at my Section.”</li>
<li class="L15236" rel="L15236"></li>
<li class="L15237" rel="L15237">The wood-sawyer said he would be proud and flattered to attend the</li>
<li class="L15238" rel="L15238">citizeness. The citizeness looking at him, he became embarrassed, evaded</li>
<li class="L15239" rel="L15239">her glance as a small dog would have done, retreated among his wood, and</li>
<li class="L15240" rel="L15240">hid his confusion over the handle of his saw.</li>
<li class="L15241" rel="L15241"></li>
<li class="L15242" rel="L15242">Madame Defarge beckoned the Juryman and The Vengeance a little nearer to</li>
<li class="L15243" rel="L15243">the door, and there expounded her further views to them thus:</li>
<li class="L15244" rel="L15244"></li>
<li class="L15245" rel="L15245">“She will now be at home, awaiting the moment of his death. She will</li>
<li class="L15246" rel="L15246">be mourning and grieving. She will be in a state of mind to impeach the</li>
<li class="L15247" rel="L15247">justice of the Republic. She will be full of sympathy with its enemies.</li>
<li class="L15248" rel="L15248">I will go to her.”</li>
<li class="L15249" rel="L15249"></li>
<li class="L15250" rel="L15250">“What an admirable woman; what an adorable woman!” exclaimed Jacques</li>
<li class="L15251" rel="L15251">Three, rapturously. “Ah, my cherished!” cried The Vengeance; and</li>
<li class="L15252" rel="L15252">embraced her.</li>
<li class="L15253" rel="L15253"></li>
<li class="L15254" rel="L15254">“Take you my knitting,” said Madame Defarge, placing it in her</li>
<li class="L15255" rel="L15255">lieutenant&#39;s hands, “and have it ready for me in my usual seat. Keep</li>
<li class="L15256" rel="L15256">me my usual chair. Go you there, straight, for there will probably be a</li>
<li class="L15257" rel="L15257">greater concourse than usual, to-day.”</li>
<li class="L15258" rel="L15258"></li>
<li class="L15259" rel="L15259">“I willingly obey the orders of my Chief,” said The Vengeance with</li>
<li class="L15260" rel="L15260">alacrity, and kissing her cheek. “You will not be late?”</li>
<li class="L15261" rel="L15261"></li>
<li class="L15262" rel="L15262">“I shall be there before the commencement.”</li>
<li class="L15263" rel="L15263"></li>
<li class="L15264" rel="L15264">“And before the tumbrils arrive. Be sure you are there, my soul,” said</li>
<li class="L15265" rel="L15265">The Vengeance, calling after her, for she had already turned into the</li>
<li class="L15266" rel="L15266">street, “before the tumbrils arrive!”</li>
<li class="L15267" rel="L15267"></li>
<li class="L15268" rel="L15268">Madame Defarge slightly waved her hand, to imply that she heard, and</li>
<li class="L15269" rel="L15269">might be relied upon to arrive in good time, and so went through the</li>
<li class="L15270" rel="L15270">mud, and round the corner of the prison wall. The Vengeance and the</li>
<li class="L15271" rel="L15271">Juryman, looking after her as she walked away, were highly appreciative</li>
<li class="L15272" rel="L15272">of her fine figure, and her superb moral endowments.</li>
<li class="L15273" rel="L15273"></li>
<li class="L15274" rel="L15274">There were many women at that time, upon whom the time laid a dreadfully</li>
<li class="L15275" rel="L15275">disfiguring hand; but, there was not one among them more to be dreaded</li>
<li class="L15276" rel="L15276">than this ruthless woman, now taking her way along the streets. Of a</li>
<li class="L15277" rel="L15277">strong and fearless character, of shrewd sense and readiness, of great</li>
<li class="L15278" rel="L15278">determination, of that kind of beauty which not only seems to impart</li>
<li class="L15279" rel="L15279">to its possessor firmness and animosity, but to strike into others an</li>
<li class="L15280" rel="L15280">instinctive recognition of those qualities; the troubled time would have</li>
<li class="L15281" rel="L15281">heaved her up, under any circumstances. But, imbued from her childhood</li>
<li class="L15282" rel="L15282">with a brooding sense of wrong, and an inveterate hatred of a class,</li>
<li class="L15283" rel="L15283">opportunity had developed her into a tigress. She was absolutely without</li>
<li class="L15284" rel="L15284">pity. If she had ever had the virtue in her, it had quite gone out of</li>
<li class="L15285" rel="L15285">her.</li>
<li class="L15286" rel="L15286"></li>
<li class="L15287" rel="L15287">It was nothing to her, that an innocent man was to die for the sins of</li>
<li class="L15288" rel="L15288">his forefathers; she saw, not him, but them. It was nothing to her, that</li>
<li class="L15289" rel="L15289">his wife was to be made a widow and his daughter an orphan; that was</li>
<li class="L15290" rel="L15290">insufficient punishment, because they were her natural enemies and</li>
<li class="L15291" rel="L15291">her prey, and as such had no right to live. To appeal to her, was made</li>
<li class="L15292" rel="L15292">hopeless by her having no sense of pity, even for herself. If she had</li>
<li class="L15293" rel="L15293">been laid low in the streets, in any of the many encounters in which</li>
<li class="L15294" rel="L15294">she had been engaged, she would not have pitied herself; nor, if she had</li>
<li class="L15295" rel="L15295">been ordered to the axe to-morrow, would she have gone to it with any</li>
<li class="L15296" rel="L15296">softer feeling than a fierce desire to change places with the man who</li>
<li class="L15297" rel="L15297">sent her there.</li>
<li class="L15298" rel="L15298"></li>
<li class="L15299" rel="L15299">Such a heart Madame Defarge carried under her rough robe. Carelessly</li>
<li class="L15300" rel="L15300">worn, it was a becoming robe enough, in a certain weird way, and her</li>
<li class="L15301" rel="L15301">dark hair looked rich under her coarse red cap. Lying hidden in her</li>
<li class="L15302" rel="L15302">bosom, was a loaded pistol. Lying hidden at her waist, was a sharpened</li>
<li class="L15303" rel="L15303">dagger. Thus accoutred, and walking with the confident tread of such</li>
<li class="L15304" rel="L15304">a character, and with the supple freedom of a woman who had habitually</li>
<li class="L15305" rel="L15305">walked in her girlhood, bare-foot and bare-legged, on the brown</li>
<li class="L15306" rel="L15306">sea-sand, Madame Defarge took her way along the streets.</li>
<li class="L15307" rel="L15307"></li>
<li class="L15308" rel="L15308">Now, when the journey of the travelling coach, at that very moment</li>
<li class="L15309" rel="L15309">waiting for the completion of its load, had been planned out last night,</li>
<li class="L15310" rel="L15310">the difficulty of taking Miss Pross in it had much engaged Mr. Lorry&#39;s</li>
<li class="L15311" rel="L15311">attention. It was not merely desirable to avoid overloading the coach,</li>
<li class="L15312" rel="L15312">but it was of the highest importance that the time occupied in examining</li>
<li class="L15313" rel="L15313">it and its passengers, should be reduced to the utmost; since their</li>
<li class="L15314" rel="L15314">escape might depend on the saving of only a few seconds here and there.</li>
<li class="L15315" rel="L15315">Finally, he had proposed, after anxious consideration, that Miss Pross</li>
<li class="L15316" rel="L15316">and Jerry, who were at liberty to leave the city, should leave it at</li>
<li class="L15317" rel="L15317">three o&#39;clock in the lightest-wheeled conveyance known to that period.</li>
<li class="L15318" rel="L15318">Unencumbered with luggage, they would soon overtake the coach, and,</li>
<li class="L15319" rel="L15319">passing it and preceding it on the road, would order its horses in</li>
