<li class="L15320" rel="L15320">advance, and greatly facilitate its progress during the precious hours</li>
<li class="L15321" rel="L15321">of the night, when delay was the most to be dreaded.</li>
<li class="L15322" rel="L15322"></li>
<li class="L15323" rel="L15323">Seeing in this arrangement the hope of rendering real service in that</li>
<li class="L15324" rel="L15324">pressing emergency, Miss Pross hailed it with joy. She and Jerry had</li>
<li class="L15325" rel="L15325">beheld the coach start, had known who it was that Solomon brought, had</li>
<li class="L15326" rel="L15326">passed some ten minutes in tortures of suspense, and were now concluding</li>
<li class="L15327" rel="L15327">their arrangements to follow the coach, even as Madame Defarge,</li>
<li class="L15328" rel="L15328">taking her way through the streets, now drew nearer and nearer to the</li>
<li class="L15329" rel="L15329">else-deserted lodging in which they held their consultation.</li>
<li class="L15330" rel="L15330"></li>
<li class="L15331" rel="L15331">“Now what do you think, Mr. Cruncher,” said Miss Pross, whose agitation</li>
<li class="L15332" rel="L15332">was so great that she could hardly speak, or stand, or move, or live:</li>
<li class="L15333" rel="L15333">“what do you think of our not starting from this courtyard? Another</li>
<li class="L15334" rel="L15334">carriage having already gone from here to-day, it might awaken</li>
<li class="L15335" rel="L15335">suspicion.”</li>
<li class="L15336" rel="L15336"></li>
<li class="L15337" rel="L15337">“My opinion, miss,” returned Mr. Cruncher, “is as you&#39;re right. Likewise</li>
<li class="L15338" rel="L15338">wot I&#39;ll stand by you, right or wrong.”</li>
<li class="L15339" rel="L15339"></li>
<li class="L15340" rel="L15340">“I am so distracted with fear and hope for our precious creatures,” said</li>
<li class="L15341" rel="L15341">Miss Pross, wildly crying, “that I am incapable of forming any plan. Are</li>
<li class="L15342" rel="L15342">_you_ capable of forming any plan, my dear good Mr. Cruncher?”</li>
<li class="L15343" rel="L15343"></li>
<li class="L15344" rel="L15344">“Respectin&#39; a future spear o&#39; life, miss,” returned Mr. Cruncher, “I</li>
<li class="L15345" rel="L15345">hope so. Respectin&#39; any present use o&#39; this here blessed old head o&#39;</li>
<li class="L15346" rel="L15346">mine, I think not. Would you do me the favour, miss, to take notice o&#39;</li>
<li class="L15347" rel="L15347">two promises and wows wot it is my wishes fur to record in this here</li>
<li class="L15348" rel="L15348">crisis?”</li>
<li class="L15349" rel="L15349"></li>
<li class="L15350" rel="L15350">“Oh, for gracious sake!” cried Miss Pross, still wildly crying, “record</li>
<li class="L15351" rel="L15351">them at once, and get them out of the way, like an excellent man.”</li>
<li class="L15352" rel="L15352"></li>
<li class="L15353" rel="L15353">“First,” said Mr. Cruncher, who was all in a tremble, and who spoke with</li>
<li class="L15354" rel="L15354">an ashy and solemn visage, “them poor things well out o&#39; this, never no</li>
<li class="L15355" rel="L15355">more will I do it, never no more!”</li>
<li class="L15356" rel="L15356"></li>
<li class="L15357" rel="L15357">“I am quite sure, Mr. Cruncher,” returned Miss Pross, “that you</li>
<li class="L15358" rel="L15358">never will do it again, whatever it is, and I beg you not to think it</li>
<li class="L15359" rel="L15359">necessary to mention more particularly what it is.”</li>
<li class="L15360" rel="L15360"></li>
<li class="L15361" rel="L15361">“No, miss,” returned Jerry, “it shall not be named to you. Second: them</li>
<li class="L15362" rel="L15362">poor things well out o&#39; this, and never no more will I interfere with</li>
<li class="L15363" rel="L15363">Mrs. Cruncher&#39;s flopping, never no more!”</li>
<li class="L15364" rel="L15364"></li>
<li class="L15365" rel="L15365">“Whatever housekeeping arrangement that may be,” said Miss Pross,</li>
<li class="L15366" rel="L15366">striving to dry her eyes and compose herself, “I have no doubt it</li>
<li class="L15367" rel="L15367">is best that Mrs. Cruncher should have it entirely under her own</li>
<li class="L15368" rel="L15368">superintendence.--O my poor darlings!”</li>
<li class="L15369" rel="L15369"></li>
<li class="L15370" rel="L15370">“I go so far as to say, miss, moreover,” proceeded Mr. Cruncher, with a</li>
<li class="L15371" rel="L15371">most alarming tendency to hold forth as from a pulpit--“and let my words</li>
<li class="L15372" rel="L15372">be took down and took to Mrs. Cruncher through yourself--that wot my</li>
<li class="L15373" rel="L15373">opinions respectin&#39; flopping has undergone a change, and that wot I only</li>
<li class="L15374" rel="L15374">hope with all my heart as Mrs. Cruncher may be a flopping at the present</li>
<li class="L15375" rel="L15375">time.”</li>
<li class="L15376" rel="L15376"></li>
<li class="L15377" rel="L15377">“There, there, there! I hope she is, my dear man,” cried the distracted</li>
<li class="L15378" rel="L15378">Miss Pross, “and I hope she finds it answering her expectations.”</li>
<li class="L15379" rel="L15379"></li>
<li class="L15380" rel="L15380">“Forbid it,” proceeded Mr. Cruncher, with additional solemnity,</li>
<li class="L15381" rel="L15381">additional slowness, and additional tendency to hold forth and hold</li>
<li class="L15382" rel="L15382">out, “as anything wot I have ever said or done should be wisited on my</li>
<li class="L15383" rel="L15383">earnest wishes for them poor creeturs now! Forbid it as we shouldn&#39;t all</li>
<li class="L15384" rel="L15384">flop (if it was anyways conwenient) to get &#39;em out o&#39; this here dismal</li>
<li class="L15385" rel="L15385">risk! Forbid it, miss! Wot I say, for-_bid_ it!” This was Mr. Cruncher&#39;s</li>
<li class="L15386" rel="L15386">conclusion after a protracted but vain endeavour to find a better one.</li>
<li class="L15387" rel="L15387"></li>
<li class="L15388" rel="L15388">And still Madame Defarge, pursuing her way along the streets, came</li>
<li class="L15389" rel="L15389">nearer and nearer.</li>
<li class="L15390" rel="L15390"></li>
<li class="L15391" rel="L15391">“If we ever get back to our native land,” said Miss Pross, “you may rely</li>
<li class="L15392" rel="L15392">upon my telling Mrs. Cruncher as much as I may be able to remember and</li>
<li class="L15393" rel="L15393">understand of what you have so impressively said; and at all events</li>
<li class="L15394" rel="L15394">you may be sure that I shall bear witness to your being thoroughly in</li>
<li class="L15395" rel="L15395">earnest at this dreadful time. Now, pray let us think! My esteemed Mr.</li>
<li class="L15396" rel="L15396">Cruncher, let us think!”</li>
<li class="L15397" rel="L15397"></li>
<li class="L15398" rel="L15398">Still, Madame Defarge, pursuing her way along the streets, came nearer</li>
<li class="L15399" rel="L15399">and nearer.</li>
<li class="L15400" rel="L15400"></li>
<li class="L15401" rel="L15401">“If you were to go before,” said Miss Pross, “and stop the vehicle and</li>
<li class="L15402" rel="L15402">horses from coming here, and were to wait somewhere for me; wouldn&#39;t</li>
<li class="L15403" rel="L15403">that be best?”</li>
<li class="L15404" rel="L15404"></li>
<li class="L15405" rel="L15405">Mr. Cruncher thought it might be best.</li>
<li class="L15406" rel="L15406"></li>
<li class="L15407" rel="L15407">“Where could you wait for me?” asked Miss Pross.</li>
<li class="L15408" rel="L15408"></li>
<li class="L15409" rel="L15409">Mr. Cruncher was so bewildered that he could think of no locality but</li>
<li class="L15410" rel="L15410">Temple Bar. Alas! Temple Bar was hundreds of miles away, and Madame</li>
<li class="L15411" rel="L15411">Defarge was drawing very near indeed.</li>
<li class="L15412" rel="L15412"></li>
<li class="L15413" rel="L15413">“By the cathedral door,” said Miss Pross. “Would it be much out of</li>
<li class="L15414" rel="L15414">the way, to take me in, near the great cathedral door between the two</li>
<li class="L15415" rel="L15415">towers?”</li>
<li class="L15416" rel="L15416"></li>
<li class="L15417" rel="L15417">“No, miss,” answered Mr. Cruncher.</li>
<li class="L15418" rel="L15418"></li>
<li class="L15419" rel="L15419">“Then, like the best of men,” said Miss Pross, “go to the posting-house</li>
<li class="L15420" rel="L15420">straight, and make that change.”</li>
<li class="L15421" rel="L15421"></li>
<li class="L15422" rel="L15422">“I am doubtful,” said Mr. Cruncher, hesitating and shaking his head,</li>
<li class="L15423" rel="L15423">“about leaving of you, you see. We don&#39;t know what may happen.”</li>
<li class="L15424" rel="L15424"></li>
<li class="L15425" rel="L15425">“Heaven knows we don&#39;t,” returned Miss Pross, “but have no fear for me.</li>
<li class="L15426" rel="L15426">Take me in at the cathedral, at Three o&#39;Clock, or as near it as you can,</li>
<li class="L15427" rel="L15427">and I am sure it will be better than our going from here. I feel certain</li>
<li class="L15428" rel="L15428">of it. There! Bless you, Mr. Cruncher! Think-not of me, but of the lives</li>
<li class="L15429" rel="L15429">that may depend on both of us!”</li>
<li class="L15430" rel="L15430"></li>
<li class="L15431" rel="L15431">This exordium, and Miss Pross&#39;s two hands in quite agonised entreaty</li>
<li class="L15432" rel="L15432">clasping his, decided Mr. Cruncher. With an encouraging nod or two, he</li>
<li class="L15433" rel="L15433">immediately went out to alter the arrangements, and left her by herself</li>
<li class="L15434" rel="L15434">to follow as she had proposed.</li>
<li class="L15435" rel="L15435"></li>
<li class="L15436" rel="L15436">The having originated a precaution which was already in course of</li>
<li class="L15437" rel="L15437">execution, was a great relief to Miss Pross. The necessity of composing</li>
<li class="L15438" rel="L15438">her appearance so that it should attract no special notice in the</li>
<li class="L15439" rel="L15439">streets, was another relief. She looked at her watch, and it was twenty</li>
<li class="L15440" rel="L15440">minutes past two. She had no time to lose, but must get ready at once.</li>
<li class="L15441" rel="L15441"></li>
<li class="L15442" rel="L15442">Afraid, in her extreme perturbation, of the loneliness of the deserted</li>
<li class="L15443" rel="L15443">rooms, and of half-imagined faces peeping from behind every open door</li>
<li class="L15444" rel="L15444">in them, Miss Pross got a basin of cold water and began laving her eyes,</li>
<li class="L15445" rel="L15445">which were swollen and red. Haunted by her feverish apprehensions, she</li>
<li class="L15446" rel="L15446">could not bear to have her sight obscured for a minute at a time by the</li>
<li class="L15447" rel="L15447">dripping water, but constantly paused and looked round to see that there</li>
<li class="L15448" rel="L15448">was no one watching her. In one of those pauses she recoiled and cried</li>
<li class="L15449" rel="L15449">out, for she saw a figure standing in the room.</li>
<li class="L15450" rel="L15450"></li>
<li class="L15451" rel="L15451">The basin fell to the ground broken, and the water flowed to the feet of</li>
<li class="L15452" rel="L15452">Madame Defarge. By strange stern ways, and through much staining blood,</li>
<li class="L15453" rel="L15453">those feet had come to meet that water.</li>
<li class="L15454" rel="L15454"></li>
<li class="L15455" rel="L15455">Madame Defarge looked coldly at her, and said, “The wife of Evremonde;</li>
<li class="L15456" rel="L15456">where is she?”</li>
<li class="L15457" rel="L15457"></li>
<li class="L15458" rel="L15458">It flashed upon Miss Pross&#39;s mind that the doors were all standing open,</li>
<li class="L15459" rel="L15459">and would suggest the flight. Her first act was to shut them. There were</li>
<li class="L15460" rel="L15460">four in the room, and she shut them all. She then placed herself before</li>
<li class="L15461" rel="L15461">the door of the chamber which Lucie had occupied.</li>
<li class="L15462" rel="L15462"></li>
<li class="L15463" rel="L15463">Madame Defarge&#39;s dark eyes followed her through this rapid movement,</li>
<li class="L15464" rel="L15464">and rested on her when it was finished. Miss Pross had nothing beautiful</li>
<li class="L15465" rel="L15465">about her; years had not tamed the wildness, or softened the grimness,</li>
<li class="L15466" rel="L15466">of her appearance; but, she too was a determined woman in her different</li>
<li class="L15467" rel="L15467">way, and she measured Madame Defarge with her eyes, every inch.</li>
<li class="L15468" rel="L15468"></li>
<li class="L15469" rel="L15469">“You might, from your appearance, be the wife of Lucifer,” said Miss</li>
<li class="L15470" rel="L15470">Pross, in her breathing. “Nevertheless, you shall not get the better of</li>
<li class="L15471" rel="L15471">me. I am an Englishwoman.”</li>
<li class="L15472" rel="L15472"></li>
<li class="L15473" rel="L15473">Madame Defarge looked at her scornfully, but still with something of</li>
<li class="L15474" rel="L15474">Miss Pross&#39;s own perception that they two were at bay. She saw a tight,</li>
<li class="L15475" rel="L15475">hard, wiry woman before her, as Mr. Lorry had seen in the same figure a</li>
<li class="L15476" rel="L15476">woman with a strong hand, in the years gone by. She knew full well that</li>
<li class="L15477" rel="L15477">Miss Pross was the family&#39;s devoted friend; Miss Pross knew full well</li>
<li class="L15478" rel="L15478">that Madame Defarge was the family&#39;s malevolent enemy.</li>
<li class="L15479" rel="L15479"></li>
<li class="L15480" rel="L15480">“On my way yonder,” said Madame Defarge, with a slight movement of</li>
<li class="L15481" rel="L15481">her hand towards the fatal spot, “where they reserve my chair and my</li>
<li class="L15482" rel="L15482">knitting for me, I am come to make my compliments to her in passing. I</li>
<li class="L15483" rel="L15483">wish to see her.”</li>
<li class="L15484" rel="L15484"></li>
<li class="L15485" rel="L15485">“I know that your intentions are evil,” said Miss Pross, “and you may</li>
<li class="L15486" rel="L15486">depend upon it, I&#39;ll hold my own against them.”</li>
<li class="L15487" rel="L15487"></li>
<li class="L15488" rel="L15488">Each spoke in her own language; neither understood the other&#39;s words;</li>
<li class="L15489" rel="L15489">both were very watchful, and intent to deduce from look and manner, what</li>
<li class="L15490" rel="L15490">the unintelligible words meant.</li>
<li class="L15491" rel="L15491"></li>
<li class="L15492" rel="L15492">“It will do her no good to keep herself concealed from me at this</li>
<li class="L15493" rel="L15493">moment,” said Madame Defarge. “Good patriots will know what that means.</li>
<li class="L15494" rel="L15494">Let me see her. Go tell her that I wish to see her. Do you hear?”</li>
<li class="L15495" rel="L15495"></li>
<li class="L15496" rel="L15496">“If those eyes of yours were bed-winches,” returned Miss Pross, “and I</li>
<li class="L15497" rel="L15497">was an English four-poster, they shouldn&#39;t loose a splinter of me. No,</li>
<li class="L15498" rel="L15498">you wicked foreign woman; I am your match.”</li>
<li class="L15499" rel="L15499"></li>
<li class="L15500" rel="L15500">Madame Defarge was not likely to follow these idiomatic remarks in</li>
<li class="L15501" rel="L15501">detail; but, she so far understood them as to perceive that she was set</li>
<li class="L15502" rel="L15502">at naught.</li>
<li class="L15503" rel="L15503"></li>
<li class="L15504" rel="L15504">“Woman imbecile and pig-like!” said Madame Defarge, frowning. “I take no</li>
<li class="L15505" rel="L15505">answer from you. I demand to see her. Either tell her that I demand</li>
<li class="L15506" rel="L15506">to see her, or stand out of the way of the door and let me go to her!”</li>
<li class="L15507" rel="L15507"> This, with an angry explanatory wave of her right arm.</li>
<li class="L15508" rel="L15508"></li>
<li class="L15509" rel="L15509">“I little thought,” said Miss Pross, “that I should ever want to</li>
<li class="L15510" rel="L15510">understand your nonsensical language; but I would give all I have,</li>
<li class="L15511" rel="L15511">except the clothes I wear, to know whether you suspect the truth, or any</li>
<li class="L15512" rel="L15512">part of it.”</li>
<li class="L15513" rel="L15513"></li>
<li class="L15514" rel="L15514">Neither of them for a single moment released the other&#39;s eyes. Madame</li>
<li class="L15515" rel="L15515">Defarge had not moved from the spot where she stood when Miss Pross</li>
<li class="L15516" rel="L15516">first became aware of her; but, she now advanced one step.</li>
<li class="L15517" rel="L15517"></li>
<li class="L15518" rel="L15518">“I am a Briton,” said Miss Pross, “I am desperate. I don&#39;t care an</li>
<li class="L15519" rel="L15519">English Twopence for myself. I know that the longer I keep you here, the</li>
<li class="L15520" rel="L15520">greater hope there is for my Ladybird. I&#39;ll not leave a handful of that</li>
<li class="L15521" rel="L15521">dark hair upon your head, if you lay a finger on me!”</li>
<li class="L15522" rel="L15522"></li>
<li class="L15523" rel="L15523">Thus Miss Pross, with a shake of her head and a flash of her eyes</li>
<li class="L15524" rel="L15524">between every rapid sentence, and every rapid sentence a whole breath.</li>
<li class="L15525" rel="L15525">Thus Miss Pross, who had never struck a blow in her life.</li>
<li class="L15526" rel="L15526"></li>
<li class="L15527" rel="L15527">But, her courage was of that emotional nature that it brought the</li>
<li class="L15528" rel="L15528">irrepressible tears into her eyes. This was a courage that Madame</li>
<li class="L15529" rel="L15529">Defarge so little comprehended as to mistake for weakness. “Ha, ha!” she</li>
<li class="L15530" rel="L15530">laughed, “you poor wretch! What are you worth! I address myself to that</li>
<li class="L15531" rel="L15531">Doctor.” Then she raised her voice and called out, “Citizen Doctor! Wife</li>
<li class="L15532" rel="L15532">of Evremonde! Child of Evremonde! Any person but this miserable fool,</li>
<li class="L15533" rel="L15533">answer the Citizeness Defarge!”</li>
<li class="L15534" rel="L15534"></li>
<li class="L15535" rel="L15535">Perhaps the following silence, perhaps some latent disclosure in the</li>
<li class="L15536" rel="L15536">expression of Miss Pross&#39;s face, perhaps a sudden misgiving apart from</li>
<li class="L15537" rel="L15537">either suggestion, whispered to Madame Defarge that they were gone.</li>
<li class="L15538" rel="L15538">Three of the doors she opened swiftly, and looked in.</li>
<li class="L15539" rel="L15539"></li>
<li class="L15540" rel="L15540">“Those rooms are all in disorder, there has been hurried packing, there</li>
<li class="L15541" rel="L15541">are odds and ends upon the ground. There is no one in that room behind</li>
<li class="L15542" rel="L15542">you! Let me look.”</li>
<li class="L15543" rel="L15543"></li>
<li class="L15544" rel="L15544">“Never!” said Miss Pross, who understood the request as perfectly as</li>
<li class="L15545" rel="L15545">Madame Defarge understood the answer.</li>
<li class="L15546" rel="L15546"></li>
<li class="L15547" rel="L15547">“If they are not in that room, they are gone, and can be pursued and</li>
<li class="L15548" rel="L15548">brought back,” said Madame Defarge to herself.</li>
<li class="L15549" rel="L15549"></li>
<li class="L15550" rel="L15550">“As long as you don&#39;t know whether they are in that room or not, you are</li>
<li class="L15551" rel="L15551">uncertain what to do,” said Miss Pross to herself; “and you shall not</li>
<li class="L15552" rel="L15552">know that, if I can prevent your knowing it; and know that, or not know</li>
<li class="L15553" rel="L15553">that, you shall not leave here while I can hold you.”</li>
<li class="L15554" rel="L15554"></li>
<li class="L15555" rel="L15555">“I have been in the streets from the first, nothing has stopped me,</li>
<li class="L15556" rel="L15556">I will tear you to pieces, but I will have you from that door,” said</li>
<li class="L15557" rel="L15557">Madame Defarge.</li>
<li class="L15558" rel="L15558"></li>
<li class="L15559" rel="L15559">“We are alone at the top of a high house in a solitary courtyard, we are</li>
<li class="L15560" rel="L15560">not likely to be heard, and I pray for bodily strength to keep you here,</li>
<li class="L15561" rel="L15561">while every minute you are here is worth a hundred thousand guineas to</li>
<li class="L15562" rel="L15562">my darling,” said Miss Pross.</li>
<li class="L15563" rel="L15563"></li>
<li class="L15564" rel="L15564">Madame Defarge made at the door. Miss Pross, on the instinct of the</li>
<li class="L15565" rel="L15565">moment, seized her round the waist in both her arms, and held her tight.</li>
<li class="L15566" rel="L15566">It was in vain for Madame Defarge to struggle and to strike; Miss Pross,</li>
<li class="L15567" rel="L15567">with the vigorous tenacity of love, always so much stronger than hate,</li>
<li class="L15568" rel="L15568">clasped her tight, and even lifted her from the floor in the struggle</li>
<li class="L15569" rel="L15569">that they had. The two hands of Madame Defarge buffeted and tore her</li>
<li class="L15570" rel="L15570">face; but, Miss Pross, with her head down, held her round the waist, and</li>
<li class="L15571" rel="L15571">clung to her with more than the hold of a drowning woman.</li>
<li class="L15572" rel="L15572"></li>
<li class="L15573" rel="L15573">Soon, Madame Defarge&#39;s hands ceased to strike, and felt at her encircled</li>
<li class="L15574" rel="L15574">waist. “It is under my arm,” said Miss Pross, in smothered tones, “you</li>
<li class="L15575" rel="L15575">shall not draw it. I am stronger than you, I bless Heaven for it. I hold</li>
<li class="L15576" rel="L15576">you till one or other of us faints or dies!”</li>
<li class="L15577" rel="L15577"></li>
<li class="L15578" rel="L15578">Madame Defarge&#39;s hands were at her bosom. Miss Pross looked up, saw</li>
<li class="L15579" rel="L15579">what it was, struck at it, struck out a flash and a crash, and stood</li>
<li class="L15580" rel="L15580">alone--blinded with smoke.</li>
<li class="L15581" rel="L15581"></li>
<li class="L15582" rel="L15582">All this was in a second. As the smoke cleared, leaving an awful</li>
<li class="L15583" rel="L15583">stillness, it passed out on the air, like the soul of the furious woman</li>
<li class="L15584" rel="L15584">whose body lay lifeless on the ground.</li>
<li class="L15585" rel="L15585"></li>
<li class="L15586" rel="L15586">In the first fright and horror of her situation, Miss Pross passed the</li>
<li class="L15587" rel="L15587">body as far from it as she could, and ran down the stairs to call for</li>
<li class="L15588" rel="L15588">fruitless help. Happily, she bethought herself of the consequences of</li>
<li class="L15589" rel="L15589">what she did, in time to check herself and go back. It was dreadful to</li>
<li class="L15590" rel="L15590">go in at the door again; but, she did go in, and even went near it, to</li>
<li class="L15591" rel="L15591">get the bonnet and other things that she must wear. These she put on,</li>
<li class="L15592" rel="L15592">out on the staircase, first shutting and locking the door and taking</li>
<li class="L15593" rel="L15593">away the key. She then sat down on the stairs a few moments to breathe</li>
<li class="L15594" rel="L15594">and to cry, and then got up and hurried away.</li>
<li class="L15595" rel="L15595"></li>
<li class="L15596" rel="L15596">By good fortune she had a veil on her bonnet, or she could hardly have</li>
<li class="L15597" rel="L15597">gone along the streets without being stopped. By good fortune, too, she</li>
<li class="L15598" rel="L15598">was naturally so peculiar in appearance as not to show disfigurement</li>
<li class="L15599" rel="L15599">like any other woman. She needed both advantages, for the marks of</li>
<li class="L15600" rel="L15600">gripping fingers were deep in her face, and her hair was torn, and her</li>
<li class="L15601" rel="L15601">dress (hastily composed with unsteady hands) was clutched and dragged a</li>
<li class="L15602" rel="L15602">hundred ways.</li>
<li class="L15603" rel="L15603"></li>
<li class="L15604" rel="L15604">In crossing the bridge, she dropped the door key in the river. Arriving</li>
<li class="L15605" rel="L15605">at the cathedral some few minutes before her escort, and waiting there,</li>
<li class="L15606" rel="L15606">she thought, what if the key were already taken in a net, what if</li>
<li class="L15607" rel="L15607">it were identified, what if the door were opened and the remains</li>
<li class="L15608" rel="L15608">discovered, what if she were stopped at the gate, sent to prison, and</li>
<li class="L15609" rel="L15609">charged with murder! In the midst of these fluttering thoughts, the</li>
<li class="L15610" rel="L15610">escort appeared, took her in, and took her away.</li>
<li class="L15611" rel="L15611"></li>
<li class="L15612" rel="L15612">“Is there any noise in the streets?” she asked him.</li>
<li class="L15613" rel="L15613"></li>
<li class="L15614" rel="L15614">“The usual noises,” Mr. Cruncher replied; and looked surprised by the</li>
<li class="L15615" rel="L15615">question and by her aspect.</li>
<li class="L15616" rel="L15616"></li>
<li class="L15617" rel="L15617">“I don&#39;t hear you,” said Miss Pross. “What do you say?”</li>
<li class="L15618" rel="L15618"></li>
<li class="L15619" rel="L15619">It was in vain for Mr. Cruncher to repeat what he said; Miss Pross could</li>
<li class="L15620" rel="L15620">not hear him. “So I&#39;ll nod my head,” thought Mr. Cruncher, amazed, “at</li>
<li class="L15621" rel="L15621">all events she&#39;ll see that.” And she did.</li>
<li class="L15622" rel="L15622"></li>
<li class="L15623" rel="L15623">“Is there any noise in the streets now?” asked Miss Pross again,</li>
<li class="L15624" rel="L15624">presently.</li>
<li class="L15625" rel="L15625"></li>
<li class="L15626" rel="L15626">Again Mr. Cruncher nodded his head.</li>
<li class="L15627" rel="L15627"></li>
<li class="L15628" rel="L15628">“I don&#39;t hear it.”</li>
<li class="L15629" rel="L15629"></li>
<li class="L15630" rel="L15630">“Gone deaf in an hour?” said Mr. Cruncher, ruminating, with his mind</li>
<li class="L15631" rel="L15631">much disturbed; “wot&#39;s come to her?”</li>
<li class="L15632" rel="L15632"></li>
<li class="L15633" rel="L15633">“I feel,” said Miss Pross, “as if there had been a flash and a crash,</li>
<li class="L15634" rel="L15634">and that crash was the last thing I should ever hear in this life.”</li>
<li class="L15635" rel="L15635"></li>
<li class="L15636" rel="L15636">“Blest if she ain&#39;t in a queer condition!” said Mr. Cruncher, more and</li>
<li class="L15637" rel="L15637">more disturbed. “Wot can she have been a takin&#39;, to keep her courage up?</li>
<li class="L15638" rel="L15638">Hark! There&#39;s the roll of them dreadful carts! You can hear that, miss?”</li>
<li class="L15639" rel="L15639"></li>
<li class="L15640" rel="L15640">“I can hear,” said Miss Pross, seeing that he spoke to her, “nothing. O,</li>
<li class="L15641" rel="L15641">my good man, there was first a great crash, and then a great stillness,</li>
<li class="L15642" rel="L15642">and that stillness seems to be fixed and unchangeable, never to be</li>
<li class="L15643" rel="L15643">broken any more as long as my life lasts.”</li>
<li class="L15644" rel="L15644"></li>
<li class="L15645" rel="L15645">“If she don&#39;t hear the roll of those dreadful carts, now very nigh their</li>
<li class="L15646" rel="L15646">journey&#39;s end,” said Mr. Cruncher, glancing over his shoulder, “it&#39;s my</li>
<li class="L15647" rel="L15647">opinion that indeed she never will hear anything else in this world.”</li>
<li class="L15648" rel="L15648"></li>
<li class="L15649" rel="L15649">And indeed she never did.</li>
<li class="L15650" rel="L15650"></li>
<li class="L15651" rel="L15651"></li>
<li class="L15652" rel="L15652"></li>
<li class="L15653" rel="L15653"></li>
<li class="L15654" rel="L15654">XV. The Footsteps Die Out For Ever</li>
<li class="L15655" rel="L15655"></li>
<li class="L15656" rel="L15656"></li>
<li class="L15657" rel="L15657">Along the Paris streets, the death-carts rumble, hollow and harsh. Six</li>
<li class="L15658" rel="L15658">tumbrils carry the day&#39;s wine to La Guillotine. All the devouring and</li>
<li class="L15659" rel="L15659">insatiate Monsters imagined since imagination could record itself,</li>
<li class="L15660" rel="L15660">are fused in the one realisation, Guillotine. And yet there is not in</li>
<li class="L15661" rel="L15661">France, with its rich variety of soil and climate, a blade, a leaf,</li>
<li class="L15662" rel="L15662">a root, a sprig, a peppercorn, which will grow to maturity under</li>
<li class="L15663" rel="L15663">conditions more certain than those that have produced this horror. Crush</li>
<li class="L15664" rel="L15664">humanity out of shape once more, under similar hammers, and it will</li>
<li class="L15665" rel="L15665">twist itself into the same tortured forms. Sow the same seed of</li>
<li class="L15666" rel="L15666">rapacious license and oppression over again, and it will surely yield</li>
<li class="L15667" rel="L15667">the same fruit according to its kind.</li>
<li class="L15668" rel="L15668"></li>
<li class="L15669" rel="L15669">Six tumbrils roll along the streets. Change these back again to what</li>
<li class="L15670" rel="L15670">they were, thou powerful enchanter, Time, and they shall be seen to be</li>
<li class="L15671" rel="L15671">the carriages of absolute monarchs, the equipages of feudal nobles, the</li>
<li class="L15672" rel="L15672">toilettes of flaring Jezebels, the churches that are not my father&#39;s</li>
<li class="L15673" rel="L15673">house but dens of thieves, the huts of millions of starving peasants!</li>
<li class="L15674" rel="L15674">No; the great magician who majestically works out the appointed order</li>
<li class="L15675" rel="L15675">of the Creator, never reverses his transformations. “If thou be changed</li>
<li class="L15676" rel="L15676">into this shape by the will of God,” say the seers to the enchanted, in</li>
<li class="L15677" rel="L15677">the wise Arabian stories, “then remain so! But, if thou wear this</li>
<li class="L15678" rel="L15678">form through mere passing conjuration, then resume thy former aspect!”</li>
<li class="L15679" rel="L15679"> Changeless and hopeless, the tumbrils roll along.</li>
<li class="L15680" rel="L15680"></li>
<li class="L15681" rel="L15681">As the sombre wheels of the six carts go round, they seem to plough up</li>
<li class="L15682" rel="L15682">a long crooked furrow among the populace in the streets. Ridges of faces</li>
<li class="L15683" rel="L15683">are thrown to this side and to that, and the ploughs go steadily onward.</li>
<li class="L15684" rel="L15684">So used are the regular inhabitants of the houses to the spectacle, that</li>
<li class="L15685" rel="L15685">in many windows there are no people, and in some the occupation of the</li>
<li class="L15686" rel="L15686">hands is not so much as suspended, while the eyes survey the faces in</li>
<li class="L15687" rel="L15687">the tumbrils. Here and there, the inmate has visitors to see the sight;</li>
<li class="L15688" rel="L15688">then he points his finger, with something of the complacency of a</li>
<li class="L15689" rel="L15689">curator or authorised exponent, to this cart and to this, and seems to</li>
<li class="L15690" rel="L15690">tell who sat here yesterday, and who there the day before.</li>
<li class="L15691" rel="L15691"></li>
<li class="L15692" rel="L15692">Of the riders in the tumbrils, some observe these things, and all</li>
<li class="L15693" rel="L15693">things on their last roadside, with an impassive stare; others, with</li>
<li class="L15694" rel="L15694">a lingering interest in the ways of life and men. Some, seated with</li>
<li class="L15695" rel="L15695">drooping heads, are sunk in silent despair; again, there are some so</li>
<li class="L15696" rel="L15696">heedful of their looks that they cast upon the multitude such glances as</li>
<li class="L15697" rel="L15697">they have seen in theatres, and in pictures. Several close their eyes,</li>
<li class="L15698" rel="L15698">and think, or try to get their straying thoughts together. Only one, and</li>
<li class="L15699" rel="L15699">he a miserable creature, of a crazed aspect, is so shattered and made</li>
<li class="L15700" rel="L15700">drunk by horror, that he sings, and tries to dance. Not one of the whole</li>
<li class="L15701" rel="L15701">number appeals by look or gesture, to the pity of the people.</li>
<li class="L15702" rel="L15702"></li>
<li class="L15703" rel="L15703">There is a guard of sundry horsemen riding abreast of the tumbrils,</li>
<li class="L15704" rel="L15704">and faces are often turned up to some of them, and they are asked some</li>
<li class="L15705" rel="L15705">question. It would seem to be always the same question, for, it is</li>
<li class="L15706" rel="L15706">always followed by a press of people towards the third cart. The</li>
<li class="L15707" rel="L15707">horsemen abreast of that cart, frequently point out one man in it with</li>
<li class="L15708" rel="L15708">their swords. The leading curiosity is, to know which is he; he stands</li>
<li class="L15709" rel="L15709">at the back of the tumbril with his head bent down, to converse with a</li>
<li class="L15710" rel="L15710">mere girl who sits on the side of the cart, and holds his hand. He has</li>
<li class="L15711" rel="L15711">no curiosity or care for the scene about him, and always speaks to the</li>
<li class="L15712" rel="L15712">girl. Here and there in the long street of St. Honore, cries are raised</li>
<li class="L15713" rel="L15713">against him. If they move him at all, it is only to a quiet smile, as he</li>
<li class="L15714" rel="L15714">shakes his hair a little more loosely about his face. He cannot easily</li>
<li class="L15715" rel="L15715">touch his face, his arms being bound.</li>
<li class="L15716" rel="L15716"></li>
<li class="L15717" rel="L15717">On the steps of a church, awaiting the coming-up of the tumbrils, stands</li>
<li class="L15718" rel="L15718">the Spy and prison-sheep. He looks into the first of them: not there.</li>
<li class="L15719" rel="L15719">He looks into the second: not there. He already asks himself, “Has he</li>
<li class="L15720" rel="L15720">sacrificed me?” when his face clears, as he looks into the third.</li>
<li class="L15721" rel="L15721"></li>
<li class="L15722" rel="L15722">“Which is Evremonde?” says a man behind him.</li>
<li class="L15723" rel="L15723"></li>
<li class="L15724" rel="L15724">“That. At the back there.”</li>
<li class="L15725" rel="L15725"></li>
<li class="L15726" rel="L15726">“With his hand in the girl&#39;s?”</li>
<li class="L15727" rel="L15727"></li>
<li class="L15728" rel="L15728">“Yes.”</li>
<li class="L15729" rel="L15729"></li>
<li class="L15730" rel="L15730">The man cries, “Down, Evremonde! To the Guillotine all aristocrats!</li>
<li class="L15731" rel="L15731">Down, Evremonde!”</li>
<li class="L15732" rel="L15732"></li>
<li class="L15733" rel="L15733">“Hush, hush!” the Spy entreats him, timidly.</li>
<li class="L15734" rel="L15734"></li>
<li class="L15735" rel="L15735">“And why not, citizen?”</li>
<li class="L15736" rel="L15736"></li>
<li class="L15737" rel="L15737">“He is going to pay the forfeit: it will be paid in five minutes more.</li>
<li class="L15738" rel="L15738">Let him be at peace.”</li>
<li class="L15739" rel="L15739"></li>
<li class="L15740" rel="L15740">But the man continuing to exclaim, “Down, Evremonde!” the face of</li>
<li class="L15741" rel="L15741">Evremonde is for a moment turned towards him. Evremonde then sees the</li>
<li class="L15742" rel="L15742">Spy, and looks attentively at him, and goes his way.</li>
<li class="L15743" rel="L15743"></li>
<li class="L15744" rel="L15744">The clocks are on the stroke of three, and the furrow ploughed among the</li>
<li class="L15745" rel="L15745">populace is turning round, to come on into the place of execution, and</li>
<li class="L15746" rel="L15746">end. The ridges thrown to this side and to that, now crumble in and</li>
<li class="L15747" rel="L15747">close behind the last plough as it passes on, for all are following</li>
<li class="L15748" rel="L15748">to the Guillotine. In front of it, seated in chairs, as in a garden of</li>
<li class="L15749" rel="L15749">public diversion, are a number of women, busily knitting. On one of the</li>
<li class="L15750" rel="L15750">fore-most chairs, stands The Vengeance, looking about for her friend.</li>
<li class="L15751" rel="L15751"></li>
<li class="L15752" rel="L15752">“Therese!” she cries, in her shrill tones. “Who has seen her? Therese</li>
<li class="L15753" rel="L15753">Defarge!”</li>
<li class="L15754" rel="L15754"></li>
<li class="L15755" rel="L15755">“She never missed before,” says a knitting-woman of the sisterhood.</li>
<li class="L15756" rel="L15756"></li>
<li class="L15757" rel="L15757">“No; nor will she miss now,” cries The Vengeance, petulantly. “Therese.”</li>
<li class="L15758" rel="L15758"></li>
<li class="L15759" rel="L15759">“Louder,” the woman recommends.</li>
<li class="L15760" rel="L15760"></li>
<li class="L15761" rel="L15761">Ay! Louder, Vengeance, much louder, and still she will scarcely hear</li>
<li class="L15762" rel="L15762">thee. Louder yet, Vengeance, with a little oath or so added, and yet</li>
<li class="L15763" rel="L15763">it will hardly bring her. Send other women up and down to seek her,</li>
<li class="L15764" rel="L15764">lingering somewhere; and yet, although the messengers have done dread</li>
<li class="L15765" rel="L15765">deeds, it is questionable whether of their own wills they will go far</li>
<li class="L15766" rel="L15766">enough to find her!</li>
<li class="L15767" rel="L15767"></li>
<li class="L15768" rel="L15768">“Bad Fortune!” cries The Vengeance, stamping her foot in the chair, “and</li>
<li class="L15769" rel="L15769">here are the tumbrils! And Evremonde will be despatched in a wink, and</li>
<li class="L15770" rel="L15770">she not here! See her knitting in my hand, and her empty chair ready for</li>
<li class="L15771" rel="L15771">her. I cry with vexation and disappointment!”</li>
<li class="L15772" rel="L15772"></li>
<li class="L15773" rel="L15773">As The Vengeance descends from her elevation to do it, the tumbrils</li>
<li class="L15774" rel="L15774">begin to discharge their loads. The ministers of Sainte Guillotine are</li>
<li class="L15775" rel="L15775">robed and ready. Crash!--A head is held up, and the knitting-women who</li>
<li class="L15776" rel="L15776">scarcely lifted their eyes to look at it a moment ago when it could</li>
<li class="L15777" rel="L15777">think and speak, count One.</li>
<li class="L15778" rel="L15778"></li>
<li class="L15779" rel="L15779">The second tumbril empties and moves on; the third comes up. Crash!--And</li>
<li class="L15780" rel="L15780">the knitting-women, never faltering or pausing in their Work, count Two.</li>
<li class="L15781" rel="L15781"></li>
<li class="L15782" rel="L15782">The supposed Evremonde descends, and the seamstress is lifted out next</li>
<li class="L15783" rel="L15783">after him. He has not relinquished her patient hand in getting out, but</li>
<li class="L15784" rel="L15784">still holds it as he promised. He gently places her with her back to the</li>
<li class="L15785" rel="L15785">crashing engine that constantly whirrs up and falls, and she looks into</li>
<li class="L15786" rel="L15786">his face and thanks him.</li>
<li class="L15787" rel="L15787"></li>
<li class="L15788" rel="L15788">“But for you, dear stranger, I should not be so composed, for I am</li>
<li class="L15789" rel="L15789">naturally a poor little thing, faint of heart; nor should I have been</li>
<li class="L15790" rel="L15790">able to raise my thoughts to Him who was put to death, that we might</li>
<li class="L15791" rel="L15791">have hope and comfort here to-day. I think you were sent to me by</li>
<li class="L15792" rel="L15792">Heaven.”</li>
<li class="L15793" rel="L15793"></li>
<li class="L15794" rel="L15794">“Or you to me,” says Sydney Carton. “Keep your eyes upon me, dear child,</li>
<li class="L15795" rel="L15795">and mind no other object.”</li>
<li class="L15796" rel="L15796"></li>
<li class="L15797" rel="L15797">“I mind nothing while I hold your hand. I shall mind nothing when I let</li>
<li class="L15798" rel="L15798">it go, if they are rapid.”</li>
<li class="L15799" rel="L15799"></li>
<li class="L15800" rel="L15800">“They will be rapid. Fear not!”</li>
<li class="L15801" rel="L15801"></li>
<li class="L15802" rel="L15802">The two stand in the fast-thinning throng of victims, but they speak as</li>
<li class="L15803" rel="L15803">if they were alone. Eye to eye, voice to voice, hand to hand, heart to</li>
<li class="L15804" rel="L15804">heart, these two children of the Universal Mother, else so wide apart</li>
<li class="L15805" rel="L15805">and differing, have come together on the dark highway, to repair home</li>
<li class="L15806" rel="L15806">together, and to rest in her bosom.</li>
<li class="L15807" rel="L15807"></li>
<li class="L15808" rel="L15808">“Brave and generous friend, will you let me ask you one last question? I</li>
<li class="L15809" rel="L15809">am very ignorant, and it troubles me--just a little.”</li>
<li class="L15810" rel="L15810"></li>
<li class="L15811" rel="L15811">“Tell me what it is.”</li>
<li class="L15812" rel="L15812"></li>
<li class="L15813" rel="L15813">“I have a cousin, an only relative and an orphan, like myself, whom I</li>
<li class="L15814" rel="L15814">love very dearly. She is five years younger than I, and she lives in a</li>
<li class="L15815" rel="L15815">farmer&#39;s house in the south country. Poverty parted us, and she knows</li>
<li class="L15816" rel="L15816">nothing of my fate--for I cannot write--and if I could, how should I</li>
<li class="L15817" rel="L15817">tell her! It is better as it is.”</li>
<li class="L15818" rel="L15818"></li>
<li class="L15819" rel="L15819">“Yes, yes: better as it is.”</li>
<li class="L15820" rel="L15820"></li>
<li class="L15821" rel="L15821">“What I have been thinking as we came along, and what I am still</li>
<li class="L15822" rel="L15822">thinking now, as I look into your kind strong face which gives me so</li>
<li class="L15823" rel="L15823">much support, is this:--If the Republic really does good to the poor,</li>
<li class="L15824" rel="L15824">and they come to be less hungry, and in all ways to suffer less, she may</li>
<li class="L15825" rel="L15825">live a long time: she may even live to be old.”</li>
<li class="L15826" rel="L15826"></li>
<li class="L15827" rel="L15827">“What then, my gentle sister?”</li>
<li class="L15828" rel="L15828"></li>
<li class="L15829" rel="L15829">“Do you think:” the uncomplaining eyes in which there is so much</li>
<li class="L15830" rel="L15830">endurance, fill with tears, and the lips part a little more and tremble:</li>
<li class="L15831" rel="L15831">“that it will seem long to me, while I wait for her in the better land</li>
<li class="L15832" rel="L15832">where I trust both you and I will be mercifully sheltered?”</li>
<li class="L15833" rel="L15833"></li>
<li class="L15834" rel="L15834">“It cannot be, my child; there is no Time there, and no trouble there.”</li>
<li class="L15835" rel="L15835"></li>
<li class="L15836" rel="L15836">“You comfort me so much! I am so ignorant. Am I to kiss you now? Is the</li>
<li class="L15837" rel="L15837">moment come?”</li>
<li class="L15838" rel="L15838"></li>
<li class="L15839" rel="L15839">“Yes.”</li>
<li class="L15840" rel="L15840"></li>
<li class="L15841" rel="L15841">She kisses his lips; he kisses hers; they solemnly bless each other.</li>
<li class="L15842" rel="L15842">The spare hand does not tremble as he releases it; nothing worse than</li>
<li class="L15843" rel="L15843">a sweet, bright constancy is in the patient face. She goes next before</li>
<li class="L15844" rel="L15844">him--is gone; the knitting-women count Twenty-Two.</li>
<li class="L15845" rel="L15845"></li>
<li class="L15846" rel="L15846">“I am the Resurrection and the Life, saith the Lord: he that believeth</li>
<li class="L15847" rel="L15847">in me, though he were dead, yet shall he live: and whosoever liveth and</li>
<li class="L15848" rel="L15848">believeth in me shall never die.”</li>
<li class="L15849" rel="L15849"></li>
<li class="L15850" rel="L15850">The murmuring of many voices, the upturning of many faces, the pressing</li>
<li class="L15851" rel="L15851">on of many footsteps in the outskirts of the crowd, so that it swells</li>
<li class="L15852" rel="L15852">forward in a mass, like one great heave of water, all flashes away.</li>
<li class="L15853" rel="L15853">Twenty-Three.</li>
<li class="L15854" rel="L15854"></li>
<li class="L15855" rel="L15855">        *****</li>
<li class="L15856" rel="L15856"></li>
<li class="L15857" rel="L15857">They said of him, about the city that night, that it was the</li>
<li class="L15858" rel="L15858">peacefullest man&#39;s face ever beheld there. Many added that he looked</li>
<li class="L15859" rel="L15859">sublime and prophetic.</li>
<li class="L15860" rel="L15860"></li>
<li class="L15861" rel="L15861">One of the most remarkable sufferers by the same axe--a woman--had asked</li>
<li class="L15862" rel="L15862">at the foot of the same scaffold, not long before, to be allowed to</li>
<li class="L15863" rel="L15863">write down the thoughts that were inspiring her. If he had given any</li>
<li class="L15864" rel="L15864">utterance to his, and they were prophetic, they would have been these:</li>
<li class="L15865" rel="L15865"></li>
<li class="L15866" rel="L15866">“I see Barsad, and Cly, Defarge, The Vengeance, the Juryman, the Judge,</li>
<li class="L15867" rel="L15867">long ranks of the new oppressors who have risen on the destruction of</li>
<li class="L15868" rel="L15868">the old, perishing by this retributive instrument, before it shall cease</li>
<li class="L15869" rel="L15869">out of its present use. I see a beautiful city and a brilliant people</li>
<li class="L15870" rel="L15870">rising from this abyss, and, in their struggles to be truly free, in</li>
<li class="L15871" rel="L15871">their triumphs and defeats, through long years to come, I see the evil</li>
<li class="L15872" rel="L15872">of this time and of the previous time of which this is the natural</li>
<li class="L15873" rel="L15873">birth, gradually making expiation for itself and wearing out.</li>
<li class="L15874" rel="L15874"></li>
<li class="L15875" rel="L15875">“I see the lives for which I lay down my life, peaceful, useful,</li>
<li class="L15876" rel="L15876">prosperous and happy, in that England which I shall see no more. I see</li>
<li class="L15877" rel="L15877">Her with a child upon her bosom, who bears my name. I see her father,</li>
<li class="L15878" rel="L15878">aged and bent, but otherwise restored, and faithful to all men in his</li>
<li class="L15879" rel="L15879">healing office, and at peace. I see the good old man, so long their</li>
<li class="L15880" rel="L15880">friend, in ten years&#39; time enriching them with all he has, and passing</li>
<li class="L15881" rel="L15881">tranquilly to his reward.</li>
<li class="L15882" rel="L15882"></li>
<li class="L15883" rel="L15883">“I see that I hold a sanctuary in their hearts, and in the hearts of</li>
<li class="L15884" rel="L15884">their descendants, generations hence. I see her, an old woman, weeping</li>
<li class="L15885" rel="L15885">for me on the anniversary of this day. I see her and her husband, their</li>
<li class="L15886" rel="L15886">course done, lying side by side in their last earthly bed, and I know</li>
<li class="L15887" rel="L15887">that each was not more honoured and held sacred in the other&#39;s soul,</li>
<li class="L15888" rel="L15888">than I was in the souls of both.</li>
<li class="L15889" rel="L15889"></li>
<li class="L15890" rel="L15890">“I see that child who lay upon her bosom and who bore my name, a man</li>
<li class="L15891" rel="L15891">winning his way up in that path of life which once was mine. I see him</li>
<li class="L15892" rel="L15892">winning it so well, that my name is made illustrious there by the</li>
<li class="L15893" rel="L15893">light of his. I see the blots I threw upon it, faded away. I see him,</li>
<li class="L15894" rel="L15894">fore-most of just judges and honoured men, bringing a boy of my name,</li>
<li class="L15895" rel="L15895">with a forehead that I know and golden hair, to this place--then fair to</li>
<li class="L15896" rel="L15896">look upon, with not a trace of this day&#39;s disfigurement--and I hear him</li>
<li class="L15897" rel="L15897">tell the child my story, with a tender and a faltering voice.</li>
<li class="L15898" rel="L15898"></li>
<li class="L15899" rel="L15899">“It is a far, far better thing that I do, than I have ever done; it is a</li>
<li class="L15900" rel="L15900">far, far better rest that I go to than I have ever known.”</li>
<li class="L15901" rel="L15901"></li>
<li class="L15902" rel="L15902"></li>
<li class="L15903" rel="L15903"></li>
<li class="L15904" rel="L15904"></li>
<li class="L15905" rel="L15905"></li>
<li class="L15906" rel="L15906"></li>
<li class="L15907" rel="L15907"></li>
<li class="L15908" rel="L15908"></li>
<li class="L15909" rel="L15909"></li>
<li class="L15910" rel="L15910"></li>
<li class="L15911" rel="L15911"></li>
<li class="L15912" rel="L15912">End of the Project Gutenberg EBook of A Tale of Two Cities, by Charles Dickens</li>

<li class="L16054" rel="L16054">posted on the official Project Gutenberg-tm web site (www.gutenberg.org),</li>
<li class="L16055" rel="L16055">you must, at no additional cost, fee or expense to the user, provide a</li>
<li class="L16056" rel="L16056">copy, a means of exporting a copy, or a means of obtaining a copy upon</li>
<li class="L16057" rel="L16057">request, of the work in its original “Plain Vanilla ASCII” or other</li>
<li class="L16058" rel="L16058">form.  Any alternate format must include the full Project Gutenberg-tm</li>
<li class="L16059" rel="L16059">License as specified in paragraph 1.E.1.</li>
<li class="L16060" rel="L16060"></li>
<li class="L16061" rel="L16061">1.E.7.  Do not charge a fee for access to, viewing, displaying,</li>
<li class="L16062" rel="L16062">performing, copying or distributing any Project Gutenberg-tm works</li>
<li class="L16063" rel="L16063">unless you comply with paragraph 1.E.8 or 1.E.9.</li>
<li class="L16064" rel="L16064"></li>
<li class="L16065" rel="L16065">1.E.8.  You may charge a reasonable fee for copies of or providing</li>
<li class="L16066" rel="L16066">access to or distributing Project Gutenberg-tm electronic works provided</li>

<li class="L16073" rel="L16073">     has agreed to donate royalties under this paragraph to the</li>

<li class="L16075" rel="L16075">     must be paid within 60 days following each date on which you</li>

<li class="L16077" rel="L16077">     returns.  Royalty payments should be clearly marked as such and</li>

<li class="L16182" rel="L16182">Gutenberg Literary Archive Foundation was created to provide a secure</li>

function submitDeleteForm() {
    var message = prompt("delete_confirm_message\n\ndelete_commit_summary", "Delete ''");
    if (message != null) {
        $("#delete-message").val(message);
        $("#delete-file-form").submit()
    }
}
</script>
